name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission in preparation for the European Council (18-19 February 2016) (2015/3022 (RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am glad to address you today on the forthcoming meeting of the European Council. After the proposal made by President Tusk yesterday, the European Council will discuss and agree a set of arrangements to address the concerns of the United Kingdom as set out by Prime Minister Cameron. However, given the urgency of the refugee crisis, EU leaders will also assess progress in implementation of earlier decisions and address any immediate issues ahead. The meeting will also take a new step forward in the European Semester 2016 with the examination of the recommendation for the euro area, so a recommendation for the euro area as a whole. First, the United Kingdom. I think we all agree that the upcoming EU referendum in the United Kingdom is a political event of the first order for both United Kingdom citizens and the rest of Europe. It will be up to the British people to make their choice. In this light, the current negotiations mark an important step in securing the UK’s long-term relationship with the European Union, and although there may be difficult issues at the table it is of paramount importance that we continue our constructive dialogue to make the European Union work better for both the United Kingdom and all other Member States. Building on the fruitful discussion held at the December 2015 meeting, EU leaders will explore solutions to address the concerns raised by the UK Prime Minister in November. All involved have shown a readiness to work hard towards a mutually-satisfactory solution. I believe it is in our common interest to adequately respond to the United Kingdom’s concerns in a way that benefits all of the EU Member States and institutions, and of course with full respect for the European Union’s fundamental principles. As you know, yesterday the President of the European Council put forward a proposal for a new settlement of the United Kingdom within the European Union. It covers all four areas of economic governance, competitiveness, sovereignty, and social benefits and free movement. This proposal will be discussed later this week and next week by EU ‘sherpas’ and permanent representatives. Your Parliament will be represented at these meetings. Obviously it is first and foremost for the heads of state of the European Council to decide on the President’s proposal. Therefore, I cannot comment on this in detail today. All governments will now study the proposals; yet I do believe that it paves the way, this discussion, for an agreement in the European Council. Further discussions are of course needed and some of the issues are particularly complex, but I am sure a solution can be found if there is ample political will. The Council looks forward to working with Parliament as a partner in the follow-up of what we hope will be a good outcome of the discussions at the European Council for the European Union as a whole. Ultimately though, the final decision will not be in our hands. It will be for the British people to decide whether the United Kingdom should remain in the Union. You had a long and comprehensive debate on migration yesterday. I think it was a good debate. It is indeed essential to make progress on this key issue which is mobilising all our institutions. The Presidency, the Commission and the EEAS will report on progress before the European Council meeting. You showed the urgency of this matter yesterday. You took a number of important decisions last year. Implementation of these decisions is now our priority and many of you have repeatedly made that point as well and again yesterday. Further developing a policy to secure the borders is of crucial importance. We should also make full use of the tools at our disposal to ensure humanitarian assistance where needed. The Presidency is fully committed to ensuring that we improve on the results achieved so far. The central issues remain well-functioning hotspots which are crucial in our efforts to address the migration flows; progress in relocation and resettlement; coordinated efforts between institutions and Member States – this is crucial, in particular to engage with key countries of origin and transit on all aspects of migration, including return and readmissions. We are engaged with Turkey to implement on both sides joint action plan commitments. Agreement should now be carried out fast. As President Tusk and Prime Minister Rutte stated at the last plenary, it is also crucial that we get Europe’s borders under control. Work in the Council has therefore started rapidly on the Commission border package proposals presented in December. The Presidency is committed to ensuring the best and closest possible cooperation with Parliament on these proposals. We are convinced that they must lead to tangible results as soon as possible. The February European Council will be an opportunity to take stock of the situation in all areas and to address immediate issues ahead of the upcoming European Councils. Finally, the February European Council will examine the recommendation on the economic policy of the euro area as part of the European Semester 2016. You have discussed the matter several times, notably last December in the presence of Eurogroup President Dijsselbloem. As you know, for the first time, this examination will take place in February rather than in June. We welcome this innovation proposed by the Commission as part of efforts to improve and streamline the European Semester. The new timing means the discussions on individual Member States will be informed by challenges common to the euro area. The European Council in March will, as usual, discuss priorities for the 2016 exercise and provide guidance to Member States. I thank you very much for your attention and look forward to our debate.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the next European Council will be devoted to two questions which crystallize many concerns about the future of Europe: the question of refugees and that of the United Kingdom. Our conclusions will be scrutinized closely, while many observers abound every day in comments which are sub-categorized, roughly speaking, between those who claim that, from psychodrama to psychodrama, Europe is gradually falling apart and those who expect from European leaders a burst of energy, foresight and long-term vision. It will be up to us to prove the former wrong and give hope to the latter, starting with our management of the refugee crisis, about which everything has already been said, but where much remains to be done. For that, we have to pull ourselves together, because, for the moment, we have nothing to be proud of our collective performance. The refugee crisis is turning more and more every day into a crisis of European solidarity where there is a need for more coordination, cooperation and union. If I decided last year to bring together around the same table the leaders of the countries affected by the migratory flows on the Western Balkans route, it was so that they finally talk to each other, that they understand. better than the problems of some are also the problems of others. Since then, a process of virtuous cooperation and regular exchanges has taken place. Blaming each other for not doing enough or doing it badly gets nowhere and gets nowhere. We have a joint responsibility in the face of these challenges and it is this shared responsibility that must be put into action by all. Everyone must respect the common rules, in particular the rules concerning Schengen. There is only one way to save Schengen: we must apply all these rules. We will save Schengen by applying Schengen. (Laughter from the British EFDD members) I am happy to contribute to your good humor. This is why the proper functioning of the Schengen evaluation mechanism is a priority for the Commission: not to punish where deficiencies are observed, but to quickly define corrective measures. This is what is happening with Greece, where visits made last November to the sea and land borders between Greece and Turkey revealed serious shortcomings, which Greece must absolutely remedy. It is not a question of isolating Greece - as some say -. That does not make sense. If I have never considered a Eurozone Grexit, it is not to consider a Schengen Grexit. Neither is it a question of stigmatizing the Greeks, who are subject to very strong migratory pressure and whose numerous gestures of individual solidarity with regard to refugees we too quickly forget, as well as the lives that have been saved from the drowning, again in recent days, thanks to Greek rescuers. It is not a question of isolating or stigmatizing the Greeks but of helping Greece to respect its obligations by helping it to correct the failings which may exist. This is what the Commission has already done, in particular through significant financial assistance and logistical support on the spot. Since last December and in response to Greece's request, Frontex has deployed a rapid response team to the external border of the Aegean Islands. Frontex is also helping Greece identify and register migrants at the border with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. While further efforts on the part of Greece are clearly essential, their scope will remain limited until the other Member States apply the decisions that have already been taken, in particular as regards the reinforcement of staff for the proper functioning of the centers reception and registration and acceleration of relocation. The scope of these efforts will remain limited until we create a European corps of border and coast guards. It is the responsibility of all of us to help protect our common external borders in a more optimal way if we want to avoid seeing internal borders reintroduced on a lasting basis in Europe. It is obvious that the control of refugee flows and the future of the Schengen area are not only played out in Europe, between Europeans, but also beyond our common borders with our partners in third countries. On the issue of readmissions, it must be clear to everyone that we are going to step up our efforts to ensure that all those who do not qualify for international protection are returned promptly. As regards, in particular, the return of irregular migrants from Greece to Turkey, until the readmission agreement between the European Union and Turkey enters into force, the Commission stands ready to work closely with the Greek and Turkish authorities, in order to speed up these returns within the framework of the bilateral agreement existing between these two countries. It is essential to strengthen our return policy across Europe: it is an essential element in restoring the confidence of our citizens in our management of refugee flows and in devoting our energy and resources to those who have right to international protection. Herr President, es kommt selbstverständlich in erheblichem Maße darauf an, dass wir den Aktionsplan mit der Türkei mit Leben erfüllen. Die türkischen Behörden haben jüngst der Kommission versichert, dass sie alles tun werden, um die eingegangenen Verpflichtungen einzuhalten und gegen Schlepperbanden zu kämpfen und um die illegale Einwanderung zu kontrollieren. Aber auch wir müssen unsere Verpflichtungen, die wir gegenüber der Türkei eingegangen sind, erfüllen. Die Türkei beherbergt auf ihrem Staatsgebiet nahezu drei Millionen Flüchtlinge, und es ist deshalb eine ausgemachte Sache, dass die drei Milliarden Hilfe für die syrischen Flüchtlinge in der Türkei von der Europäischen Union undes ist deshalb eine ausgemachte Sache, dass die drei Milliarden Hilfe für die syrischen Flüchtlinge in der Türkei von der Europäischen Union undentüdenat den Mitiedung. Ich begrüße es ausdrücklich, dass die Italienische Regierung sich inzwischen auch zu dieser notwendigen Solidarleistung bekannt hat. Es ist ein wichtiges Anliegen der Europäischen Kommission, alles zu tun, damit die Flüchtlinge möglichst nahe an ihren Herkunftsländern leben können. Deshalb müssen wir die Länder, die den Flüchtlingen zur Seite stehen, nicht nur unter die Arme greifen, Sondern ihnen tätige Solidarität zuteil werden lassen. Dies gilt nicht nur für die Türkei, dies gilt auch für Jordanien und für den Libanon, die sich in einem sehr erheblichen Maße und viel stärker als wir mit den Folgen der syrischen Kriegsauseinandersetzungen auseinandersetzen müssen. Diese Länder, Jordanien und Libanon, haben die höchste Flüchtlingsdichte, die es zurzeit weltweit zu beobachten gibt. Und es ist so, dass sich diese Länder gefährlich dem Sättigungsgrad nähern; das dürfen wir nicht aus den Augen verlieren. Das gesamte Problem - Flüchtlinge hier und dort, auch Flüchtlinge in Griechenland - hat natürlich mit den kriegerischen Auseinandersetzungen in Syrien zu tun. Solange es uns und der internationalen Völkergemeinschaft nicht gelingt, den Krieg in Syrien zu beenden, solange werden wir mit den Folgen dieses Krieges leben müssen. Deshalb hat die Kommission auch ab Januar die humanitären Konvois nach Madaja kofinanziert. Aber es gibt viele Madajas und es gibt hunderte Orte in Syrien, in denen Menschen sterben, weil Hilfe sie nicht erreicht. Dies können wir so nicht hinnehmen. Wir haben einen Treuhandfonds für Syrien aufgelegt. Die Kommission hat 500 Millionen Euro Finanzmittel zur Verfügung gestellt, und die Mitgliedstaaten sollten das Gleiche tun, haben es aber bis jetzt nicht getan. Es fehlen auf der Seite der Mitgliedstaaten immer noch 448 von 500 Millionen Euro. Dies kann so nicht bleiben. Ähnliches gilt für den Dringlichkeitsfonds, den wir für Afrika aufgelegt haben. Die Kommission hat hier geliefert, in gemeinsamer Anstrengung mit dem Europäischen Parlament. Die Mitgliedstaaten haben das bislang nicht getan. Dies muss schnellstens nachgeholt werden. Symptombekämpfung ist wichtig, weil es um die Erleichterung für das Leben der betroffenen Menschen geht. Aber Ursachenbekämpfung ist wichtiger. Wir müssen beides tun: Hilfe vor Ort aber auch Ursachenbekämpfung. Yesterday, President Tusk presented his proposed new settlement for the United Kingdom in the European Union. Let me be clear from the start: the European Commission has been fully associated with the work on this settlement. The Commission’s best experts have worked over many months to find creative solutions. I have worked closely with President Tusk and Prime Minister Cameron to shape the proposal presented yesterday. Therefore, the Commission supports this text. I have always said that I want the UK to remain a member of the European Union on the basis of a fair deal. The settlement that has been proposed is fair for the UK and fair for the other 27 Member States. It is also fair for the European Parliament. The European Parliament has a key say in the process and a crucial role to play. Many of your Members have been involved already. I salute the contributions of President Schulz, Manfred Weber, Gianni Pittella, Syed Kamall and Guy Verhofstadt, amongst others. As of Friday, your ‘sherpas’ will take part in discussions leading to the decisive European Council of 18 February. President Schulz will be sitting at the table in the European Council. All understand that the European Parliament must be fully signed up to the new settlement. If the citizens of the UK deliver a positive verdict, you will be called upon to deliver crucial legislative elements on the settlement. I will not take you through the main elements of the settlement. That is, by the way, a duty for the President of the European Council and not so much for the President of the European Commission. However, like Prime Minister Cameron, we all want the European Union to become more competitive and to create more jobs. We must not stifle innovation and competitiveness with regulations that are too prescriptive and too detailed, notably when it comes to small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why the Commission has shortened and streamlined its Annual Work Programs, withdrawing a greater number of legislative acts than it proposes. That is why it is so important, as the Commission and the Dutch Presidency are saying, to complete the single market, to build our Energy Union, to complete the Digital Single Market and to establish a Capital Markets Union. This is the program of the European Commission, and I appreciate the support of the United Kingdom in this respect. The settlement proposed by President Tusk recognizes that not all Member States participate in all areas of EU policy. The UK benefits from more protocols and opt-outs than any other Member State. This is why, as a matter of law and as a matter of fact, the concept of ever closer union has already assumed a different meaning in its case. The settlement recognizes that if the United Kingdom considered that it is now at the limits of its level of integration, then that is fine. At the same time, it makes clear that other Member States can move towards a deeper degree of integration as they see fit. In this way, we have addressed the prime ministers concerned while respecting the Treaties. I advocated, from the start of my election campaign, that national parliaments should play a greater role in our democratic system. I included this pledge in the political guidelines, on the basis of which you elected this Commission. The settlement presented yesterday provides for this. Monsieur the President, I wish to preserve the integrity of the internal market while deepening our Economic and Monetary Union. The agreement proposed by President Tusk respects these two imperatives. President Tusk's proposals aim to protect the legitimate interests of Member States participating in the internal market without being members of the euro area. It is legitimate to give these Member States the opportunity to refer the matter to the European Council if they consider that the principle of non-discrimination could be violated. It is legitimate to remove these Member States from financial responsibility linked to measures taken to ensure the stability of the euro area. At the same time, the red line - the possibility of having more Europe within the euro zone, in order to strengthen the single currency - has been respected. The euro remains the single currency of the Union and the European Parliament remains the Parliament of the euro area and of the Union as a whole. As you know, the most difficult discussions we had with our British colleagues related to free movement. The settlement addresses situations in which large-scale movements of EU nationals are related not to the attractiveness of labor markets but to the structure and the generosity of social security systems. We propose to create a safeguard mechanism, tailor-made to the concerns of the United Kingdom, that would allow it to restrict the access of EU workers newly entering its labor market to in-work benefits in a graduated manner for a period of up to four years. The duration of the mechanism will be limited in time. That is a crucial characteristic of a safeguard mechanism, necessary in order to make it compatible with the Treaties. It will apply in exceptional cases, as all derogations from the Four Freedoms should. In 2004, the UK did not use the transitional periods that would have allowed it to phase in the right to free movement of the citizens of eight new Member States. As a result, over the past decade the UK has attracted a record number of mobile EU citizens. In effect, we will enable the United Kingdom to use the safeguard mechanism to address the consequences of that decision. In einem Wort wie in tausend: Die Tagesordnung des Europäischen Rates für die übernächste Woche ist dicht gefüllt. Ich weiß, dass ich wie immer auf die tatkräftige Unterstützung das Europäischen Parlaments zählen kann, wenn es darum geht, als Kommission, aber nicht nur als Kommission, europäische Interessen vorrangig zu behandeln. (Beifall)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Gentlemen Presidents, dear colleagues! The goal is clear, also for my group, the European People's Party: we want the UK to stay on board, we want to convince the people of Great Britain that it is better to stand together as a family. Therefore I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker, Donald Tusk and also David Cameron for the efforts of the last weekend. Respect to David Cameron! He fought hard for British interests. As the EPP Group, we do not want a British Europe; we want a proposal that will make Europe better for everyone. That must be the focus of the deliberations that will be held over the next few weeks. Our group fully supports the issues of better regulation, less bureaucracy, more competitiveness, including the euro. Thank you for making it clear that the euro is the currency of Europe, but that we are improving the coexistence of currencies and that Great Britain is also prepared to support the deepening of monetary union, even if it does not concern itself or itself Put away. These are positive aspects. In all honesty, there is one point that the President of the Commission pointed out and that we knew would be the most difficult, and that is the issue of free movement, the fight against abuse of welfare systems. The balance is difficult. It is difficult to explain why citizens who work in Great Britain, EU citizens who work there, who pay taxes there, who contribute to insurance there, like every British person who works there, should be denied access to certain welfare systems. On the other hand, we understand that there are also elements of abuse that we find and have in all countries of the European Union. Finding this balance is one of the most difficult subject areas. I can promise the EPP Group that we will support the next talks constructively and that we want a solution in the end. We want a result in these negotiations. But that is admittedly the most difficult area. Cameron fought hard now. But I believe that leadership is now also required to go one step further. What is the British question actually about? Is it really about child benefit, is it really about the issues of the working time directive, bureaucracy issues? For the British, I think it is about something completely different, namely whether in times of globalization it is better to stand alone or to stand together in the European family. When we see Putin imperialism - is it better for Britain to stand alone or be part of the family? When we see the TTIP negotiations with America - is it better to negotiate alone or to negotiate Europe as a large economic area? When we see the questions of the City of London, access to euro laws - is it better to be out of Europe or better to be in and have a say? Those are the questions that citizens have to answer. And I believe that people can be convinced: If you are a good patriot, if you love your country, then in a globalized world it is better to be a patriot in Europe. The second big issue is the general mood in the European Council. Today I would like to make a general shout, because perhaps the European Council should introduce a new item on the agenda, namely "The future of the European Council", as one sees the institution in the first place. It has become a meeting of the fearful, it has become a meeting of the despondent, it has become a meeting of politicians who unfortunately get stuck in the small, in national egoism, on the question of "Will I be re-elected or not?" secret mood, that you might even be happy when another head of government sometimes has problems and maybe fails at home. That is the mood we have there. That is why the council should look at itself and what its job actually is. If you see previous generations of politicians in the European Council, then they had the courage to take decisions on the internal market - overcoming a lot of obstacles, but creating millions of jobs - they had the courage to create the Schengen area - many, many worries and Overcoming resistance and creating a future for Europe - they had the courage to get the euro off the ground - a historic decision with the question that we have one of the world's leading currencies on this continent - and they had the courage to To overcome the division of this continent, to manage the reunification of Europe in the last decades. It all took courage. That meant that you sometimes stand up against populists and show leadership. That is why this generation of politicians, who will meet again in Brussels in two weeks' time, really has the question of whether they can build on these historic decisions of the European Council. I see more of a historical failure in many areas that we unfortunately have to attest to God. And so my plea, my great plea to the Council, is to take the lead and move forward in our times of responsibility today. Dear Colleagues! Finally, I would like to address one point that moves us internally, namely the question of the reform course in economic policy. One thing I am concerned about is that we are getting more and more governments at the national level who are doing common cause with extreme forces, that it is not democrats who work together, but extremists. In Portugal we have seen that unfortunately God's parties, which completely reject NATO and the EU, are now responsible. In Spain there are unfortunately God's tendencies that separatists, national separatists who want the division of Spain, can take responsibility. That is why I appeal to everyone: We must take responsibility at all levels - in Europe and at national level. Democrats have to stick together so that Europe has a bright future! (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question asked under the 'blue card' procedure."This is the first time, Mr. Weber, that I congratulate you on your speech."I hope to congratulate you on the answer you give me to the question I ask.Specifically: you lead a very large group in Parliament.Do you agree with what Mr Juncker is proposing, with a mechanism for the United Kingdom, especially for the United Kingdom, to restrict the freedom of movement of workers?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!I've done that, I'm not sure whether it came across properly in the translation.The EPP Group wants an agreement.We want Britain to choose Europe.This requires concessions, we know that - a deal is made in which both sides take a step towards each other.The foundation that Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker and David Cameron have given us is a solid foundation.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to reiterate our strong concerns today as well. Unfortunately, today in Europe the wind is not good. The neo-Nazi raids in Sweden and Germany in recent days, the shameful calls from political leaders to shoot refugees, even children: all this tells us that a virus has infected Europe, the virus of fear. Jean-Claude Juncker spoke of psychodrama. No country, no political party is immune to this virus. Too many taboos have been broken in recent months: Schengen, the duty of humanitarian assistance, respect for human life. And so today this House no longer has only the duty to discuss technical solutions to respond to the migrant crisis. There are solutions, the European Commission has put them correctly on the table. We already have measures to strengthen external border controls, identification with hotspots, redistribution in all European countries. But this system does not work and does not work because it is blocked by selfishness, by fears, by electoral calculations. So the problem is political and cultural. Selfishness, fear and nationalistic calculations would never have led to the construction of the European Union. So, if we want to give effective answers, we have to change the direction of the wind and start from the values. It is the blackmail of the populists that prevents too many governments from assuming their responsibilities. Instead of talking about issues that frankly have little to do with this debate - the reference to Spain and Portugal frankly seems to me a pretext given that in Spain and Portugal the political leadership always march in the direction of strengthening European integration, on this there are no doubts - let's focus instead on the real dangers, we do not mislead, we do not miss the goal, otherwise we divide ourselves and play the game of others. We have a duty to clearly tell our citizens that it is a moral duty to welcome those who flee the barbarism of ISIS and that we will do everything to ensure that those who arrive here can integrate, speak our language and find a job, because this is the only answer. that works. And we must clearly say that Schengen is the solution to this crisis and not the problem. So let the European Commission go ahead on the immigration package and also on the Dublin review. As for the UK, Tusk's letter can provide useful clarifications on the UK's role in the Union. During the negotiation we may ask for some further clarifications especially on the issue of workers' rights, on which our concern is great, but it must be clear that our commitment as socialists and democrats of the European Parliament is for the United Kingdom to remain in the Union. European. It is essential for the European Union and, as Jean-Claude Juncker said, it is essential for the United Kingdom. The UK outside the European Union is weaker. It is in the interest of British citizens, especially weaker citizens of the UK, to remain in the European Union. We will have to be able to speak the language of clarity with regard to the advantages and benefits that British citizens have from their stay in the European Union. Only if we rediscover our values, the values ​​that brought us here as representatives of the largest democratic forum in the European Union, will we be able to resolve our crisis. Here this is my appeal. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pittella, you mentioned earlier that the Portuguese and Spanish Governments were working towards European values, and yet youth unemployment there is closing up on 50%. Is it not true that the EU policy of supporting bankers, rather than the ordinary working people and the youth of these countries, is the problem and not the solution?

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- Each of us is very good at making generalizations, indifferent accusations and indifferent reflections.Talking about unemployment and youth unemployment deserves and demands a lot of seriousness.Certainly there are some things to correct in European economic policy: less austerity and less rigorism and more support for recovery, employment and job creation are needed.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, when I first became an MEP in 2005, it was around the time that the French and Dutch had voted ‘No’ in their referenda on the European Constitution. As we stood here in this Parliament and considered the implications of those ‘No’ votes, I was shocked by the number of MEPs who simply wanted to ignore the results and push on with further European integration. But perhaps the most shocking moment for me was when the then leader of the PPE Group stood up and said: ‘nothing must be allowed to get in the way of the European project. Nothing must be allowed to get in the way of European political integration. Nothing must be allowed to get in the way of European economic integration.’ As a British MEP, the belief in the European project, where the eventual goal was to build a United States of Europe or a Federal Republic of Europe, was news to me. There and then, I realised that there was a massive gap in the perception between many in EU institutions who believe in this European project, and the people of Britain, many of whom tell me that they believe that they voted to stay in a common market. Reading more about the history of the EU, I realised that the political dimension of the EU has been played down by politicians of all parties in the UK for the last 40 years. It is still being played down. In my first few weeks here in Parliament I was approached by a British MEP who asked me to join a cross-party group – a cross-party federal group – to support the European project. When I asked him: have you told your voters this? I found out he was saying one thing here and a different thing in his constituency. So unless this gap in perceptions is resolved, the UK will continue to have an ambiguous relationship with the EU. This is why David Cameron was absolutely right to call this referendum to give the British people a say, because we should never be afraid to ask the people what they want and then to stick by the outcome. A large number of voters I speak to say that they do not yet know how to vote and that they will wait to see the details of the deal. Rather like going to a shop and someone promising you a great deal in a couple of weeks and asking you to commit now: they want to read the small print. Donald Tusk’s letter to the European Council and his draft proposals are a good place to start on the four areas set out by the British Prime Minister: mutual respect between euro area and non-euro area countries; the EU becoming more competitive by opening the single market, cutting red tape and increasing global trade; ever closer union not applying to all countries, with national parliaments playing a larger role; and freedom of movement to work, and not to claim, and those people who move should only get something out of the system once they have put something in. It is hard to see how these are just British questions. These are matters that should benefit all European Union countries. For the next few weeks we will see a lot of travel, a lot of papers being read, a lot of persuading being done. And as the Council seeks a final deal, and once a deal is done, the real debate begins. Because for this referendum to be meaningful, it needs a full, frank and honest debate, with both sides being clear what remaining in the EU means and what leaving the EU could mean for Britain and for the EU. Those of you who want to build your project of a United States of Europe, come to Britain and tell the British people if that is what you believe. Do not hide your views until after the referendum. Mr Verhofstadt is an example, as you say. But at the end of the day it does not matter what we say, it does not matter what Donald Tusk or David Cameron says, it does not matter what politicians on both sides of this debate may say, it does not matter what we say in the European Parliament or what they say in the Westminster Parliament. At the end of the day, it is the British people who will have their say. It is time for the British people to have their say for the first time in 40 years. Please, on all sides of this House, respect that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Kamall, I have a question for you: colleague Coburn held up his blue card before you started speaking.I now ask myself: How can you put an intervening question about a speech that has not yet been given?We will definitely hear that now.Here you go!

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kamall, thank you for taking my question. You are always a good sport. Mr Kamall, if you want a fair British immigration policy, can you have that within the EU?

name: Syed Kamall (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, Mr Coburn, thank you very much. I must say I admire your abilities to predict my speech. In future I might actually ask you to write some of the speech. Or when I am struggling for words I can ring you up and say: what do you think will be in my speech tomorrow? But in this case, you asked a very fair question, and it is something that has to be put to the British people. If you want immigration policy – what you call a fair immigration policy – whereby everyone outside the UK is treated equally, whether they are from Austria or Australia, Croatia or the Caribbean, Italy or India, you cannot achieve that by remaining in the EU. You have to be honest, but you have to make that clear to the British people. What I do not like, when your party talks about immigration, is trying to imitate the BNP and be anti-immigration.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will start today where I ended yesterday, because we had a whole debate yesterday with Mr Koenders about the refugee crisis. Mr Koenders, I am pleased that now – at the request of the Commission – the refugee crisis will be the main topic on the agenda of the summit on 18 and 19 February 2016 because, despite the importance of the British issue, let us be honest, the refugee crisis we are facing is far more important. We have to show our citizens that we are capable of solving this. Mr Koenders and Mr Juncker, my request to you is to put two proposals on the table on 18 February. First of all, regarding the rapid response force: why not, using Article 78(3) of the Treaty, advance the European Border and Coastguard? We can do that without a change of legislation. We can also immediately start to send the 2 000 civil servants from the national border agencies. Mr Juncker, the Commission’s latest report said that there was a disaster on the border between Greece and Turkey. Four of the five hotspots are not there. There is no fingerprinting control and there is no appropriate registration. Those are not my findings but the findings of the Commission. So my proposal is to do that, to propose Article 78 as the basis to launch this rapid response force immediately. Secondly, let us also consider the idea that the EUR 3 billion will now be directed as financial assistance to the people in the refugee camps instead of giving it to the Turkish Government. I completely agree with Mr Weber when he says that if the Council is not capable now of taking such decisions in such a situation, then we have to ask ourselves: why have we created the European Council? In the Treaty, it says that all strategic options are a competence of the European Council. You are not capable of taking strategic options. You demonstrate and illustrate that every time. I hope I am wrong; I hope that Mr Weber is wrong and that the European Council will surprise us this time by taking decisions that really make a difference. That brings me to the official topic of the summit: the request of the United Kingdom to renegotiate its position. Let me be very clear: it would be a huge mistake for Britain to leave the European Union. Not so much economically, Mr Kamall, but most of all geopolitically. I think Britain without Europe will be a dwarf. Let us be honest, we Belgians know that we are dwarves, but maybe they will know it too. On the other hand, Europe without Great Britain does not count and is not a counterweight against China, against Russia and against the United States. In fact, Mr Kamall, it is Putin who will win in this game in the end, because Putin likes a divided Europe. Mr Farage and Mr Putin: they are the ones who want a divided Europe. I am very sympathetic to David Cameron’s request with the aim of reforming Europe. The question is only whether the paper we received yesterday from Mr Tusk is really what we need.  In any case, I do not have so much of a problem with the four points, but only with one of the four points. That is the point, Mr Koenders, that, in my opinion, you have to completely rewrite – in the days to come in the ‘sherpa’ meetings, and in the European Council – the part where Mr Tusk says that an ever closer union is not an ever closer union. That is in the text. It has nothing to do with sharing values; it has nothing to do with more political integration. I think I should tell you that Magritte and surrealism were not only part of Belgian culture, but I can now see that it is also a part of Polish culture and of Mr Tusk’s culture. You know that painting of Magritte’s where we show a pipe and then we put in French ‘Ceci n’est pas une pipe’? It is little like that in this proposal of Mr Tusk’s. An ever closer union is not an ever closer union. In one page, he explained what the difference is. I have to tell you that, not only is it in contradiction with Article 352 of the Treaty, but I think that it is perhaps better to have another option. Instead of really destroying our project of political integration in one page, why is it not better to give a new opt-out to Britain? They have an opt-out on Schengen; they have an opt-out on the euro; they have opt-out on police coordination. They have an opt-out on at least seven different elements today. Well, create another opt-out. The reality is that we have a two-tier Europe today. Okay, if they want another opt-out, I think that is better than to do the opposite and to destroy the idea of an ever-closer union, because Britain has to stay. No, I think it is better to be honest with the people and to create an additional opt-out. Finally, on the emergency brake: this will be discussed in the normal legislative procedure. However, let us be honest, Mr Juncker, I hope that this is the last time. We got an emergency brake from Mr Sarkozy on Schengen. Maybe tomorrow, Mr Renzi will ask for one for the Stability Pact, and maybe the day after tomorrow Mr François Hollande will ask for one for the internal market. I think that is enough. Okay, give Mr Cameron his emergency brake, but then stop destroying the Union with emergency brakes in all directions. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!Mr Verhofstadt, you said that Greece is not properly guarding its borders.The Commission has also noticed that there are major shortcomings.Why don't you want to exclude Greece from the Schengen area?It happens again that one's own rules are not followed.Europe only has the biggest problems because it does not obey its own rules.With the euro zone, with Schengen, with Dublin - Europe is violating its own rules everywhere!Isn't it time, and that is my question, to finally muster up the courage to follow your own rules?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I see, Mr Sulík, why we are not in the same group; I am a positive person and you are a negative one. Instead of pushing Greece out immediately, I think: let us take all responsibility with the European Union. We have a common border, the common border of Schengen; let us protect it and manage it together with a European border and coastguard. That seems to me to be a better, a positive European result than to exclude members of the Union. That is the difference between you and us.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! The upcoming summit has the two tasks that have already been mentioned today, namely to talk about the overall position of the Member States on the negotiating package that was drawn up with a view to the referendum in Great Britain and, secondly, the refugee issue. And I think in both the central point is actually the question of the future of the European Union. How do we imagine this? And how do we answer them? Will the decisions that have been taken there be practically unilateral preliminary decisions that will shape the future path of the European Union? Namely the question of the extent to which the citizens of the European Union can continue to identify with this project. And then I would like to begin with the proposal that was put on the table and reached us yesterday. I think a basic criticism must be: if we want more democracy in the European Union, then it cannot be that essential decisions are made practically outside of the formal framework that the European Union offers. You said earlier, Mr Juncker, and also the representative of the Dutch Presidency: the European Parliament is involved. I think that's great! I just don't find a single word about the European Parliament in the documents submitted by Mr Tusk - not a word! The European Parliament does not matter! And it was said earlier that the European Parliament will be included in the follow-up process - great! When the decisions have been made, then we can participate and, Mr Juncker, the European Parliament is not just made up of individual gentlemen, whom you mentioned earlier, and a few political groups. The European Parliament and the Parliament's position-building emerge from a joint discussion, and there is a lack of that. But if that is to open the door to how decisions will be made about the Union in the future, then we will continue to lose credibility. That has nothing to do with the fact that citizens have the feeling that we are asked here and that we have to represent the interests of the European Union here. And the second point I have to make: the idea of ​​social union is being buried. This is clear to me after what I've read here. This is not a compromise that has been offered, it is the kneeling before the City of London that we are getting here. And I don't know whether everyone is really aware of what it means if I only turn one of the four fundamental freedoms into half. If I make it clear in principle: Dear people, especially when it comes to the question of mobility, the demand “equal pay for the same work in the same place”, we will make a difference in the future - what does that mean for future social development, for employment protection Great Britain, but also in the other Member States? We are making an opt-out on a path where everyone can choose what they want in the future. And we are already stipulating that these changes - and also very democratically - will be included in the next treaty change. And when the point is that we want to exert an influence and want to make it clear that there is added value, also for the citizens of Great Britain, to remain in the European Union, then it is a terrible mistake if we are precisely concerned with the social question start big dismantling. Because some will look at it. Don't just look at those representing the City of London! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You referred to bending the knee to the City of London when it comes to concessions to the UK negotiations. Would you, in your opinion, rather see the EU and the UK go separate ways than for the EU to acknowledge the concerns of the UK in any way? The UK, by the way, is not just the City of London; it is the whole country, as shown by the fact that UKIP won the European elections.

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- If you tell me now that UKIP represents the entire population of Great Britain, then you have a peculiar understanding of law and democracy.Let me be very clear: there are very different views in Great Britain too.And not only the interests of the financial markets, not only the interests of the big banks, should play a role in the future of the European Union, but also the representatives of the citizens - those who are employed and those who are not.we should keep an eye on.And I think there are certainly different views in your country.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I say to the dear citizens of the United Kingdom, I do not know how often in recent years we have discussed this vote, which will probably soon take place, and which nobody doubts is the vote of the citizens of the United Kingdom. But since it is about the European Union it matters for all of us, and I sometimes do not know whether everybody in the United Kingdom is aware of the fact that the result of the vote will matter for millions of citizens across the European Union. So you decide in the United Kingdom, but it is very important that you know that the majority of citizens across the European Union – not only the Germans – want the UK to stay in the European Union. So how can we have an honest exchange on this issue between the citizens in the UK and in the European Union? We recently held discussions on Poland, before that we discussed Hungary, and before that we had years of discussions on the values of the European Union in the context of Greece and the euro crisis. For me it is again one of those moments where we have really to talk about Europe: where we came from, for example. And the answer is very simple: we really came from war, and we achieved peace. And so looking to the east, looking to the south, looking to our neighbourhoods, do not forget what we achieved, where we are. So looking to the Minsk Agreement, looking to the Iran deal and looking to the climate deal achieved in Paris recently, European strength is visible again and again. And let us look to challenges still ahead: Syria, growing terrorism, soon probably hundreds of millions of refugees globally. So what are you really saying in the UK? Do you think you will deal with all those challenges better outside of the European Union? Some Members shout but, I am sorry, shouting is not at all about arguments. Yesterday my colleague, Mr Smith, from the UK, from Scotland, said let us look at the wood and not only the trees. So let us become serious about what keeps us together. I have an idea; I do not know whether it is too small an idea – it is maybe not convincing. When I go home to my region – and I cannot go often – I sit together with my neighbours, I have a cup of tea and we talk about our gardens and about Europe. So let us be honest: there must be more exchange between the citizens of the UK and us. So invite us for this famous cup of tea. Let us create possibilities before the vote to talk about lilies and about roses. I like to do it as a gardener, and I really appreciate the British as a nation of gardeners. Let us create situations to talk about us, about the British and about Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for taking the question. What Donald Tusk, the President of the Council, has described as the UK’s emergency brake on benefits requires a majority in the European Parliament.  Will you and your Group be voting for the emergency brake on benefits?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – You can be sure that my colleague Jean Lambert especially will, as she always does, try to achieve at its best social responsibility at the European level. The idea of social Europe has its cradle in my Group, and you can trust Jean Lambert – well known also in the UK context – to take care of all the social issues.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Ms. Harms.(Heckling) Calm down!Now comes Mr. Farage, you have to get in shape.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, thank you. They are slightly over enthusiastic. It was not supposed to be like this, was it? Mr Cameron’s renegotiation began with really big intentions: Treaty change – blue cards going up already, this is going to be fun!  – he was going to control the free movement of people, he was going to achieve a fundamental change, not just in Britain’s relationship with the European Union, but he was going to reform the EU itself. What we got was a letter from Mr Tusk in which there is no Treaty change, no powers returned to the United Kingdom and no control over our borders at all. In fact, it was hardly worth the wait. It is really rather pathetic. But there is one more chance for the Prime Minister, because he goes to the European summit in a couple of weeks’ time. Like Oliver Twist, he will parade in front of the other leaders and say, ‘please can we have some more concessions?’ I find it rather humiliating that a British prime minister has to do this, but I am certain of one thing: he will not get another thing. Just look at the substance of this: we have an emergency brake on migrant benefits. Wow! It was supposed to be a total ban on migrant benefits for up to four years, so it is hardly an emergency brake. It is more of a handbrake turn. Also, the Prime Minister is saying we have got a red card. Isn’t that wonderful! Well, what that means is that a majority of parliaments in the European Union can say to Mr Juncker that they do not want one of his directives. Is that a cause for celebration? If 15 parliaments could not stop a piece of law, we would be living in a communist dictatorship. What I have gone through here are the good bits, but the most bizarre thing is that Mr Cameron said that with this deal, he would now vote for Britain to join the European Union. So let us have a little think about that. If the question in June is: ‘should we join the European Union?’ we would have to tell the British people: ‘you must surrender the control and sovereignty of your parliament and have 75% of your laws made somewhere else. Your Supreme Court will not be supreme. You will be overruled by a Court in Luxembourg made up of people who are not even judges. You will have to give up your fishing grounds, including in some places 200 miles of the North Sea, and you must cut your links with the Commonwealth and the wider world because you are no longer fit to negotiate your own global trade deals. Oh, and by the way, for all of this you will be paying GBP 55 million a day as a membership fee.’ Would the British people vote for that? Not a snowball’s chance in Hades. All we have to do is recognise that, whilst the politicians and the big banks and the big businesses will in this referendum defend their own vested self-interests, it is people power that will win this referendum. After we have won this referendum, I hope that it will win in many other countries in Europe too. (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I wanted to have the opportunity to say that as a British Member here I am embarrassed and ashamed by the rude and disrespectful behaviour by the UKIP Members here. I would like to ask Mr Farage if, during the forthcoming campaign, he will do anything to control the behaviour of his Members. (The President interrupted the speaker) I hope I can have a few more seconds. I want to say that I am embarrassed and ashamed by the behaviour of UKIP Members here today and their disrespect for other Members, which ironically I find to be extremely un-British. I would like to ask Mr Farage whether he is going to attempt to control his Members and prevent them from this sort of intimidation both inside the Chamber and, more widely, on social media during this campaign. (Applause)

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not know if you have a television in your house or not, but if you do, you might have watched Prime Minister’s questions and you might have seen that actually in elected assemblies all over the world there is vigorous, lively debate, or sometimes even humour too. How about that? The most vociferous Members I have known in this Parliament since I have been here are our President, when he led the Socialist Group for many years, and indeed Mr Verhofstadt, who leads the Liberal Group. They have very often shouted or mocked things that I have said. Frankly, as an elected representative, I am big enough and ugly enough to take it, and so should you be. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the English have had enough of the European Union and most, it seems, want to get out of this straitjacket. They long for their sovereignty, that is to say, their ability to deal with the problems, problems that arise in a national framework, with their particular objectives, their own thoughts and their culture, whether it be for immigration, economy or any other matter. Mr Verhofstadt, whose departure has not been noted - I see that when I leave the hemicycle, that makes a statement, but this does not seem to be the case for Mr Verhofstadt -, - said that Britain, if it came out, would be a geopolitical dwarf. He must stop looking at himself in a distorting mirror, because it is the European Union, which is a geopolitical dwarf, which has no say and which is not respected in any of the major problems of this world, no great balance and no great conflict. She played absolutely no role, to the point that we are also regularly humiliated by Mr. Obama, who calls on Mr. Cameron to order him to remain in the European Union or who speaks after the attacks. November before the President of the French Republic to impose on the European Union the obligation to maintain the crazy policy of welcoming migrants. We can understand the desire of the English to move towards the exit door, since repeated crises more and more serious shake the European Union: the crisis of the single currency created by the European elites, the euro which has mutated into general economic and social crisis throughout the European Union, the immigration crisis, with millions of people marching to join a European Union without borders, open to all winds and dislocated. The European Union is collapsing under the weight of its own contradictions. The pseudo-negotiation that has started is a play and I don't think anyone is fooled. Notwithstanding this masquerade aimed at making the British believe that an improvement in the European Union could be achieved and thus keep them in the structure, you have to admit that for years you have been in a corner of the ring. That's the reality, you are forced to patch up day after day a drifting liner that is taking water on all sides. You are on the defensive, your actions are based on lies, pressure, blackmail, threats, violation of the will of the people expressed by referendum. It is glaring proof of your weakness. Today, you are taking a first step backwards and just that, we can still rejoice. You will not be able to save time indefinitely. A near day will come when this big worm-eaten liner will sink and finally the lifeboats that are the nations will be able to bring the peoples back to safe harbor. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs. Le Pen!I do not know why Mr Verhofstadt left the room shortly before your speech.I don't know if there are any reasons.But I will tell him that you were sad that he left.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Le Pen, do you think that the people sitting in Calais trying to get to Great Britain are speaking with their feet about what they think of the European economy and that if they want a brighter future – and I do not blame them – they want to get to Britain, where the future is brighter, against the European Union, which is falling to bits?

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: response "blue card".- Mr President, I am sadly afraid, Sir, that a number of migrants are piling up in Calais precisely because Great Britain has a border and we do not.If we each had our internal borders, if we weren't in this madness that is Schengen, the people who crowd in the slums around our cities or around the departure points to reach Great Britain would very likely betoday at home.This means that each country must regain its borders and that Great Britain must not abandon hers;this is, in my opinion, a false good idea.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, after the flurry of activity yesterday over the Prime Minister’s deal, many in my constituency are asking: what was it all about? Having read the draft agreement, we see that the renegotiation of our relationship with the EU amounts to little more than a choreographed talks process, a faux battle, a smoke-and-mirrors charade that has resulted in little more than the status quo: I am saddened to say, a failure of our Prime Minister to stand up for our United Kingdom. Treaty change and retaking control over our laws has disappeared, and a promise to return control over our borders has been watered down to a benefit curb that has to be agreed by Brussels. The ever-present issue of the cost of membership has not even been addressed – a cost estimated by the Office for Budget Responsibility to rise by a further EUR 3 billion in 2020. I am delighted that the democratic process will now take control. I look forward to a frank and honest debate over our relationship with the European Union. (Applause)

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! If you talk to ordinary citizens these days, you can feel that they are very worried and uneasy about whether everything will go well with their future. But if you talk to them a little longer, everyone confirms that it is right and necessary in this increasingly global world that we can only solve big questions together, solve them on a European basis. Everyone says that! The only problem is that confidence fades because no action follows, because no action is taken, because no action is taken. And the inability to act at European level has a name - Manfred Weber has described it correctly: The name is Council, European Council. It is a disaster that we are unable to take any action in these troubled times because there are only egoists on the Council, because the Member States only agree on this, or mostly agree that they only have their own interests in mind. Lack of solidarity - gossiping every day about the need to show solidarity and then, when it comes down to it, not be ready to show it. Everyone is only interested in their own advantage, their own benefit. It can't work that way! If it is true that we can no longer solve the great challenges in economic policy, in the fight against terrorism, in the refugee question alone, but only together, damn it, there must be a few political leaders in Europe who will say now : We pull ourselves together and we tie the knot, we sometimes put back a little. Not everyone can assert their fat head on their own, that's perfectly clear! There is only one answer to the question of stability policy, to the question of refugee policy, to the question of combating terrorism, and that is common ground. And the Council ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Weber, first of all, a message: being able to worry about the Hungarian Government, which is shaming its political group, you have worried about the Spanish Socialist Party, which has been commissioned to form a Government. I want to remind you that it was under the presidency of a socialist government that Spain entered the European Union; a Government led by Felipe González, one of those leaders that you yourself, this morning, have claimed as necessary for the European Union to take on its near future with ambition. Now I want to point out that an important topic of this meeting, of course, is the subject of immigration. A fortnight ago, both the Council and the Commission pointed out that we only had two months to solve this problem. Two weeks have passed, a quarter of the time of the countdown we have to face. Have there been changes? Has there been progress? Have the measures previously adopted been applied? The answer is no. Yesterday we had Commissioner Avramopoulos here, who told us that in the month of January there have been more admissions, there have been more deaths. And a new hotspot has been launched - with it there are four, of the total of thirty that we have to launch. I therefore believe that, as some other speakers have pointed out, it is good news that the Commission has lobbied for a relevant issue for this Council to be the issue of immigration. I hope that the next time we meet we will not have to face this topic again as if it were Ravel's Bolero: the same tune, but with an increasingly higher tone.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: -  Mister President! President Schulz said yesterday: No extra sausages for Great Britain! Ladies and gentlemen, let's not kid ourselves! If Great Britain leaves the European Union, the European Union will slowly but surely be at an end. Other countries would follow suit. And by the way, Mr Reul and Mr Weber, I can also tell you clearly: Guess who will then be allowed to pay the second largest net contribution that will then be lost! Finally, the last country with common sense would leave this Parliament. So: Prime Minister Cameron's proposals are not only good for Great Britain, they are also good for Europe, because subsidiarity is always better than centralism, and personal responsibility is always better than everyone's responsibility for everyone's national and bank debt. Of course, competition is also better than harmonization. Ladies and gentlemen! The currency must correspond to the economic and cultural conditions. We must stop subordinating these conditions to the needs of a single currency. Too much Europe has brought Britain into this situation, not too little. Unfortunately, Mr. Verhofstadt is not there, who in his unique modesty has presented himself as a positive person and denigrated one of my colleagues as a negative person. I can only say one thing to him: we also need an opt-out from people and politicians and policies like Mr Verhofstadt's. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, Mr Henkel, you mentioned the prospect of Britain leaving, which would mean, in your opinion, the end of the European Union, and you championed subsidiarity.Don't you think that a subsidiary Europe is impossible as long as we keep the Brussels Commission?Are you in favor of a Europe of nations or not?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- The best the European Union has offered us so far is the internal market.And we have to maintain that - regardless of whether the UK pulls out or not.Indeed, I am not for the United States of Europe, but for a Europe of sovereign states.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, so the proposals for British changes are on the table. The negotiations can start and in the UK the referendum campaign begins in earnest. The anti-Europeans and nationalists in Britain depict the UK as isolated in Europe, constantly bossed around by Brussels. They say Britain is too small to take a leading role in the EU and that we are constantly pushed around, and then they claim that outside the EU we would be a world leader, taking on the rest of the world. This is a complete contradiction. We know that Britain can only play a bigger role in the world by playing a bigger role in the EU. Britain has always been an influential member of the European Union. In the 1980s the UK led the creation of the single market, which has increased competitiveness across the EU and increased British-EU trade by 55%. Only in the EU can we get the best deal for British consumers, driving down prices and allowing British businesses to grow and prosper with our neighbours. Being part of the EU is better for Britain under all circumstances: better for our prosperity, our security and our environment. But the renegotiation should not be only about getting a better deal for the UK but for all the countries in the EU. Together we will all be stronger, creating opportunity, peace and prosperity for the future generations of this great continent. The people I meet up and down my country want to know that the future for their children and grandchildren will be bright, prosperous and stable. They want Europe to be the engine of science and technology and innovation, driving the world to a cleaner and more sustainable future. Only together with the EU can we secure this future. The best deal for the British public is a strong Britain in a strong European Union. As the most internationalist and outward-facing party, the Lib Dems are committed to keeping Britain a full member of the EU because we are focused on the bigger issues at stake: the reason why Britain and Europe are stronger, safer and more prosperous together.

name: President. –
text: Your intervention has yielded five demands for blue cards. I am going to admit one and that is from Bill Etheridge. Are you prepared to answer it?

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – No, I think we have had enough blue cards already today.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Sinn Féin wants to see the creation of a social Europe, a Europe with democracy at its core and a Europe that is closer to citizens. It is clear that the right-wing agenda of these institutions, and of several EU leaders, is being put before the needs of citizens. The failed policies of deregulation, austerity, discrimination and scapegoating are at the heart of the EU reform agenda heading into February’s Council. Mr Cameron and Mr Tusk’s vision for Europe is that of a race to the bottom and of disregard for the concept of human rights and equality. Along with the attacks on workers’ rights and migrant rights contained in these proposals, the agenda of the British Government is to undermine human rights, as evident in its proposed repeal of the Human Rights Act which gives effect to the European Convention of Human Rights. Brexit and the repeal of the Human Rights Act have implications for Ireland and for the Good Friday Agreement, and there is no mention of that. So whilst the EU is in need of radical reform, it is clear that these proposals are pushing the EU reform in the wrong direction. In most international agreements, disputes or otherwise, it is ‘all about the economy, stupid’. In the case of Brexit, it is ‘all about human rights, stupid’. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful to my Irish colleague for giving way. Coming from Scotland, the diversity of the United Kingdom is of course very important, and we have very different domestic politics. We have elections in the North of Ireland, Scotland and Wales in May. Would you agree with me that it is a democratic outrage for the vote to be held in June? That would be disrespectful to Northern Irish, Scottish and Welsh democracy. Further, given that we have different attitudes to the European Union within Scotland, the North of Ireland and Wales, would you agree with me that it would be a democratic outrage for those countries to be taken out of the EU against our democratic will?

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for that question. I think I would absolutely concur with what you are saying with regard to Ireland’s place being in Europe, just as you are saying that Scotland’s place is in Europe. We hope that an English vote on this does not result in the North of Ireland being taken out of the EU. Therefore we would argue that for the North of Ireland – and perhaps you are saying the same for Scotland – there should be a separate referendum. It should be calculated and counted separately and that should be respected.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I represent Wales, and EU membership has brought positive economic, social and cultural benefits. I also believe that the EU has benefited from having Wales as a member. There is a great deal about the EU that I would like to change, but we can only do that by working with our European partners to improve policy and make the EU more effective. We are far better off working for change within than shouting from the sidelines. The UK Government wants more subsidiarity; well, so do I. And that is why the proposed changes to be discussed in Council must be fully considered too in terms of their impact on the devolved governments of the UK. There must be a proper debate involving those governments, and I regret that the UK Government has not done that to date. It is a matter of democracy and fairness. My party, Plaid Cymru, is committed to remaining in the EU, and I believe that the majority of the people of Wales want that too. And if Wales votes to remain in, we should not be dragged out against our democratic will. That is why we have called for a mandate to leave only if the four constituent parts of the UK agree to leave. I want to engage people in an open, honest, fact-based and mature debate about this, because it is a decision that will affect many generations to come. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Mr President, I also wanted an intervention on the procedure.I also have a question.Let us know if we pick up the card when our colleague didn't even start talking or after.I disciplinedly waited for our colleague to finish and picked up the card.That's a problem.My question to the colleague who spoke now is this: plead for a European Union.And I want a European Union and I want us not to have a British exit from the European Union.But what do you think about what the Commission and the Council are telling us?We have two Europeans: Schengen states, non-Schengen states, a mechanism for restricting free movement.However, do you think we have a united Europe or not?

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. I believe in making a much more democratic Europe. That is why I think that there are other regional and national levels of government and small nations that are currently excluded from the decision—making process, and if we had a stronger voice for that level of government it would encourage more democratic participation and build a much better and stronger Europe for the future.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - Apparently today we will talk again about how critical the situation is, how difficult it is in the European Union, and tomorrow the Mediterranean will bring a new batch of European aliens. I remember many previous meetings where we talked similarly about how to strengthen the Union's external borders, catch and prosecute smugglers. Dear ones, why did it all end up in languages ​​only? Why, even today, months and months after the problem began, the Union's southern external borders remain more perforated than scarred. Where are those smugglers caught and convicted with the utmost severity, where are the ships they confiscated in a European port? The Schengen clause and the temporary reintroduction of border controls will not solve the problem today. If the Union's external border controls had been properly carried out, no one would have had to fence or take any other measures. Let us show the unity of the states of the European Union precisely by protecting its external borders. All with the help of one or more. And that would be a good step towards a Europe of nations and states, and let us not be afraid of it. Let us also not be afraid of Britain's proposals to strengthen states, not federal Europe. These are probably the only two chances for the European Union to survive, and there will be no forgiveness for European politicians if we fail to seize them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- The question actually goes on to list what you have done about the problems, especially in the Mediterranean.We recently read a data from a German child rescue service that last year alone 60,000 unaccompanied minors crossed German borders.For example, how do you see this?What do you explain?

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- There are apparently many versions to explain this fact and I think one of the versions - it could be an approach to the future of Europe and the creation of a federal globalist Europe on the grounds that twenty-eight states and national parliaments - is a complex system and cannot guarantee effective governance..I don’t think the truth is.I believe that every country must be equal and we have joined the Union of European States.And I think we should live in such a union.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: -  Mister President! I don't understand the excitement that is here. We are debating no more and no less than whether a country - one in twenty-eight - would like to go through a democratic referendum to remain within this European Union or to leave this Union. One has to say that the European Union is not something God-given, the European Union is not a sacred commandment and it is certainly not a law of nature. The European Union is an association. You can leave any club as normal, and any club can also change the rules that hold that club together. Against this background I understand very well that wishes come from Great Britain - wishes to protect one's own labor market in a time of record unemployment, when one's own labor market cannot be open to a whole Europe with all its problems. I understand the British when they say that they want to stabilize their own social system because it is not possible as a country here to be able to solve all the social problems of a community. I understand the British when they say they want security in their own country, they want control of their borders back and know whether people with a terrorist or jihadist background are coming into the country. We shall see how this decision turns out. I can only wish the British all the best for this process and hope that there will be pressure to reform the European Union. I would like to tell you one thing: in a democracy someone is always right. It is not you, it is not the Commission, it is not us. That's the population. Please respect that!

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). - Mr President, on the refugee issue, which was central to the European Council at yesterday's debate, the Union's position on the repression of refugees was reaffirmed. Let the people worry. What do those who have equipped the Islamic State say, sowing wars with millions of victims and appeals, to control the oil regions? Closing borders with more dead, lost refugee children, reinforcing trafficking circuits. They open them only for cheap refugee workers, squeezing wages for profit, drowning and imprisoning the rest. That turn Greece into a refugee concentration camp, fueling the propaganda of miserable racists and Nazis. Separating refugee families, stealing their belongings at the border. They want to control, bargain or change countries' borders with the European Border Guard for business interests. You call them all the European Union, bourgeois governments. The Communist Party of Greece calls them capitalists, cold-blooded exploiters, murderers of refugees and peoples. Getting rid of them means getting rid of unemployment, poverty, wars and refugee drama.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
