text: - Mr Chairman! In the case of such difficult matters as those envisaged on the agenda of the nearest Council, trust is the most needed. We have a problem with this, because how can emigration issues be solved, how can we solve the issues of sealing borders, if we do not trust each other as member states. And yet border management, solving this problem is a necessary condition to maintain the free movement of people, the free movement of goods, but also the entire market. It is also a condition for the functioning of Schengen. Here, it was once said on the basis of calculations that one hour of parking for a truck with goods at the border would cost EUR 55 - this is what President Juncker probably said. Secondly, the free movement of people and goods is also related to the summit's second theme. It is a question of Britain, its possible exit. All solutions - or, in fact, most of them - that will be adopted on this issue will apply to the entire EU, not just Great Britain. I would like to emphasize that the proposal presented by the Council maintains the pillars of the Union: freedom of movement and non-discrimination. I believe that there is no place for discrimination against its citizens, no matter what country they are in, and that should be upheld. Of course, where these rights are abused, there is a need to act. And thirdly, the declaration on strengthening the principle of subsidiarity of national parliaments is also very important. The current mechanism requires improvement and we seem to agree with that.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the participation of the United Kingdom in the European Union is a strategic interest of British citizens and all European citizens and therefore it is good news that a draft agreement is on the table which, on the one hand, underlines the need for further integration to complete the Economic and Monetary Union and, on the other hand, recognizes the rights of those who have chosen not to adopt the euro. The European legal system allows not only different speeds, but also different levels of integration, and it is good that this is recognized in what appears to be a good agreement. Of course, the draft can be improved and made legally more solid and consistent with this system, first of all by clearly clarifying the difference between who has a temporary derogation and who has an opt-out towards the euro, and the European Parliament intends to contribute in constructive and responsible way to negotiate the next few days. The European Council is also called upon to adopt the recommendation on the euro area and it is good that this happens recognizing the importance of the rules of the Stability Pact including ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: - I want to affirm the Vienna Convention on the law of treaties.Poland is bound by it just like other Member States of the European Union.I respect the political will of the British, and at the same time say that the urgent decision of the Council and, consequently, changes to the treaties should be negotiated in accordance with the provisions of the Vienna Convention.

name: Sophia in ′t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, it is for the British people to decide whether this so-called deal is good enough for either an ‘in’ or an ‘out’ vote; but I personally think that there are actually much better reasons for the British to vote for ‘in’, because in these times of globalisation and the internet age, it would be better for Britain to be in the European Union for reasons of the economy and trade, but also security, police and justice cooperation, and the geopolitical position. I would like to say, in particular to all the self-proclaimed defenders of democracy on that side of the House – who have disappeared by now, incidentally – that this is not only for the British people. This affects all EU citizens and they, actually, do not have a say, and I do note that this deal contains a lot of, you know, red cards, emergency brakes, and I would say Europe has got plenty of paralysis. We do not need more paralysis; we do not need more breaks. We actually need a stronger ability to act and face all the big challenges, and I hope that we will have the British on board for that purpose.

name: President. –
text: There was a request for a blue card. Colleagues, I cannot admit any more blue cards though, because otherwise the debate will run way into the votes. I hope you are with me on this. The blue card, incidentally, came from Luke Flanagan, who now has the floor anyway for a minute and a half.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr Juncker, I would appreciate it if you would listen to my question. It is now generally accepted that when the euro was launched, it lacked even the most basic structures to deal with a crisis situation. Ireland was one that was hit with a crisis situation. On Monday, ECB President Mario Draghi was in this Chamber. I pointed out that the report of the banking inquiry in Ireland stated that over EUR 9 billion could have been saved but for the threats and bullying of his predecessor, Mr Trichet. The EUR 9 billion is gone, but there is an even greater injustice happening in Ireland just now. In 2009 and 2010, in the absence of any official structures to deal with troubled banks, the ECB, the Central Bank of Ireland and the then Irish Government colluded to create EUR 31 billion to bail out the failed creditors of two insolvent European banks. This was done not to save the banks – they were non-systemic – but to protect the euro itself – to protect the entire eurozone banking system. It worked, but now the ECB insists that the entire EUR 31 billion must be taken out of circulation by our Central Bank. Already we borrowed and destroyed EUR 6 billion; our Central Bank still holds EUR 25 billion awaiting the same fate. On Monday in this Chamber, I asked Mr Draghi if he would work with us, the Irish MEPs, to help end this obscenity. I got no reply, Mr Juncker. Today I ask you: will you work with us to help end this obscenity? You talk about what is important… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Mr Flanagan, you are overrunning your time and you are not speaking about the point on the agenda. I am sorry.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to start by talking a little about subsidiarity. We are going to hear a lot about that over the next few weeks in the UK, and of course it is about making decisions at the lowest appropriate level. That can be a parish, it can be global and it can be the European Union. In terms of the refugee situation, there we have a clear need for cooperation and coordination beyond an intergovernmental approach and for that cooperation to be based on a clear commitment to fundamental rights and international obligations. It is a duty of this Parliament to remind the Council of those values. That clear need for international cooperation on this and many other issues is one of the reasons why my party will support a ‘remain’ position in the referendum, despite the desire for change that we have about the European Union. I wanted to make that clear to the House.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, in recent months the Council has developed a strategy full of good intentions which, at first glance, really seem to be useful in containing the emergency of migratory flows in the enormous scale with which one presents today at our borders. However, from our point of view, the implementation of this strategy is still very far from a level that can be considered sufficient. It is not possible to try to implement an agreed resettlement program without real cooperation with African countries. But this is only possible if the European Union is capable of adopting a strategy to combat this emergency, which has now become chronic, freeing itself from the slavery of the interests of individual European states. Individual European states that are doing business with arms trafficking, individual European states that are doing business with the exploitation of resources and individual European states closing their national borders. What is happening with the management of migration flows in Europe is emblematic of the failure of this project of Europe itself. The countries of Northern Europe are dumping an international problem on the Mediterranean countries and are creating a security fort by suspending Schengen and thinking of an agreement that, as usual, will make them safe from the rest of the world, and then they don't care. if the problems are for the Mediterranean countries where landings take place! So don't tell us that we are the anti-Europeans and you are the Europeanists. The cause of the failure of this Europe is precisely in those countries that only look after their own national interests.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: - We are talking today about a possible Brexit, but of course it is really about the dismantling of the EU and that dismantling has started.I imagine that is very difficult for many of you to accept.You have believed in that for years, decades.That's why I'm helping you with a reality rehab.My tip is: stand in front of the mirror at home when it is quiet for a while and then slowly say to yourself: "Schengen is dead", slowly but clearly: "Schengen is dead".Do that ten times a day, that's my recipe.Then the brain gets used to the new reality because things have changed.Then the shock will not be as severe as Schengen will be abolished in a few weeks or months.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the referendum on the United Kingdom's membership of Europe should be an opportunity to say openly what the European project is, our European ideal. Regaining confidence in the capabilities of our continent is an opportunity to recall that there is only one Europe, with its history, its values, its requirements, its free movement, its single currency, its internal market and Schengen. Do we have to accept that a single country imposes its pace and demands on the rest of the continent? It is important, yes, that the United Kingdom remains in the European Union. In such an unstable world, division is weakening, and this is the goal pursued by those who want to unravel Europe. I remind you that every citizen who works, who pays his taxes, has the right to social protection, whatever his origin, because he contributes to the wealth of this country. Finally, it is not conceivable to weaken the role of the European Parliament, which certainly has nothing to be ashamed of in the face of national parliaments. The opposite would undoubtedly be more true. In a Europe traumatized by the events in Paris, Cologne and Calais, we must respond to the frustrations and fears of public opinion, to those who are tempted to see the fight against Europe and populism as a way out. to their misfortunes. The migration crisis is, in this respect, symptomatic of the situation that Europe is going through today. The European Commission and Parliament have reacted quickly, but Member States are dragging their feet to implement decisions taken several months ago to strengthen the external borders. We must act, act, that is the urgency!

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - I want the UK to stay in the Union, but I have to be critical. The President of the European Council, Mr Tusk, explicitly emphasizes that the proposals largely address British demands, but that they have not transgressed the principles on which the Union is founded. But in my understanding, this is exactly what is happening. By amending the legislation, which will allow the country to use braking mechanisms and prevent workers from other countries from accessing social transfers, it will legalize discrimination and give the green light for different concessions to different countries. Because if we do this in the case of Britain and foreign workers, tomorrow we will be forced to give a discount to, say, Bulgaria in enforcing environmental policy measures or Germany in food safety standards. What will be the limit in the case of the UK with an increased number of migrants? How quickly will the internal market be threatened and how quickly will fundamental human rights be violated? However, the Union operates on these principles. I sincerely want Britain to remain in the Union, but not to satisfy British selective appetites in any way. The UK already has quite a few exceptional rebates anyway - from Schengen to a budget rebate. Because of the latter alone, my country pays at least 30 million euros more into the budget each year, which it could spend, for example, on resolving the migrant crisis. What if we don't meet Cameron's wishes? How far are we willing to give in to whims, just to keep the country in the Union? Are we really willing to pay any price? We all know that marriage or family relationships can only be patched if they are based on a relationship of equality, not elimination. Indulgence for the sake of loving peace cannot have other consequences in the long run than the complete dissolution of the union.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is my view that the UK proposals, which we now have, form the basis of a good deal, and a deal which includes all four of my Prime Minister’s major issues of concern. We can confidently put that in due course to the British people. This is never going to please those who have always wanted to leave the EU regardless, nor will it be music to the ears of Euro-federalists. Some of the details still need to be worked out and there are still matters that require further discussion. But if we can finalise this work in the upcoming European Council, then we will have a deal that I would welcome. We must emphasise that any good deal must also just be the start of the wider long-term reforms for the whole continent. The reforms must not just be for the benefit of the UK but for the prosperity and the security of the whole EU, and indeed for future generations as well.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I made my points on migration yesterday so I have just one single sentence on this for the Minister. Minister, you referred to the fact that measures have to be taken as soon as possible, so just let me underline that it is possible: it is badly needed and needed now. I think that if we do not arrive at a conclusion at the European Council, we will fail. On the UK deal, I think that it is up to the British to assess whether it is sufficient. I must say that I very much welcome and appreciate the words of my colleague, Mr Kirkhope, because I think that he was the loudest and the clearest on the position. But I must say that I am not that happy with the deal. I think there is a certain consequence for the EU and there are consequences for our citizens and for us, but if this is the price to be paid for the UK to stay in the EU, I am ready to go along. I have two remarks. One is that I would have expected to have gone further on the reforms. Second, I greatly appreciate that we have achieved a deal on better regulation, something that I and a few other colleagues have worked very hard on in the past months or year and a half.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the European Commission is carrying out an unspeakable operation of pressure and blackmail that aims to condition the Portuguese state budget for 2016. With an arrogance of colonial character, they want to perpetuate the path that the Portuguese rejected in the last elections, the same path of impoverishment, exploitation, depletion. You know what, Mr. Juncker, the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic says that it is the exclusive responsibility of the Assembly of the Republic to organize, prepare and approve state budgets. So calm your bureaucrats there. What is at stake in this budget is to comply with commitments made to the Portuguese people, to return to the Portuguese a part of what was stolen from them in recent years, and to stop the national sinking path. When these objectives, which are fair, despite being modest and limited, contradict the rules and constraints of the European Union, it says a lot of what this has all become: a doomed and futile project that will not be missed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Ferreira.Again, I am not entirely clear why that was a speech on an item that looks different on the agenda.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, it is a time of crisis for our continent. Britain must be seen to be strongly committed to the European Union and working in partnership with our European neighbours to achieve the best for our continent as a whole, not seeking to negotiate a special deal based on self-interest. Yesterday we saw what the European Union is really about when Members of this Parliament voted overwhelmingly against fracking operations and to apply the precautionary principle to GMO approvals. We also voted to oppose any revision of the Nature Directives, which protect some of the UK’s best-loved sites and areas of natural beauty. The environment knows no borders and EU cooperation is essential to protecting our shared heritage. The European Union is a beacon to the rest of the world on standards of environmental protection, animal welfare and employment rights. These things are not red tape, challenging competitiveness, but symbols of living in a civilised society. This is what makes me proud to be a European, and this is what convinces me and my party that we will campaign wholeheartedly for the UK to remain a member of the European Union.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President!The problem with you in here, is that you no longer listen to the people.You have become like crocodiles: big jaws and no ears.Gianni Pittella says that a virus is spreading, and he is right about that. Most people here suffer from that virus, the virus is called arrogance.Arrogance against the concerns of the European people.Worries about what is happening in their countries, worries about their daughters who cannot walk safely on the streets, worries about the brutal violence that is only increasing, worries about terrorist threats, worries about their old age, worries about how they will cope, quite simply.But do you listen to their concerns?No!You shine in your arrogance and try to educate the people in what they should think or not.It is your opinion that applies and everything else is stamped with ugly epithets.You have lost the trust of the people because ofyour inability to listen to their concerns.I hope that Britain leaves the EU and that it will be the beginning of the end for this failure that the EU is.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, a point of order with regard to the conduct of the proceedings and the comment you made just after my speech.As you may know, one of the items on the European Council's agenda is precisely the recommendations for the euro area.In that sense, I believe that his intervention was extemporaneous, given that my intervention was perfectly included within that agenda I could not fail to make this repair.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, well it is ‘Camsham’, and Labour, along with the Greens and the remaining Lib Dems, will keep the white flag flying. The British public knows that this was a Chamberlain moment, and so do the British newspapers. Let me read to you what the British media are saying. The Sun: ‘Who do you think you are kidding, Mr. Cameron?’; the Daily Mail: ‘footling, pedantic and almost ineffective’; the Express: ‘a joke’; the Mirror: ‘sophistry and spin’. Voters are very well informed and they read newspapers; the media matters. There is nothing on agriculture, fishing, trade and environmental policies. Now it is very clear: there is no change, no treaty change and no repatriation of British sovereignty. Britain will keep paying the billions into the EU and, crucially, our borders remain open to migrants and terrorists. The truth is Cameron got pretty much what he asked for: absolutely nothing. It means nothing, and this is what the British people will do (tears up a piece of paper) and go for Brexit.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Many Thanks.I have to agree with Mr Ferreira: the item is actually on the agenda.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the next Council meeting will be one of the most important in recent years because of the refugee crisis, but also because of the possible departure from the United Kingdom. For us, the UK is a fundamental part of Europe. Without the UK, Europe is not complete. Yesterday, President Tusk gave us the offer with which we will go to negotiate those meetings that will take place now, and we will have to talk. We will have to talk a lot, because that's what Europe is all about. In speaking and doing it with the obligation to reach agreements, because our past forces us to ensure that the future is always peaceful, always agreed. There will be lines that cannot be exceeded, especially those that have to do with basic, foundational principles of the European Union, such as the free movement of people, the free movement of goods and the free movement of capital and, above all, the nondiscrimination. Because this European Union is founded on the fact that all Europeans are free and that all Europeans are equal. Nobody wants the exit of Great Britain. Britain's departure would harm everyone: it would harm Europe, it would harm England, it would harm Wales, it would harm Northern Ireland, it would harm Scotland. I ask what would happen if, in the referendum, England decided to leave the European Union, but Scotland did not. Or if Wales decided no. Or if Northern Ireland decided no. We are creating problems where we didn't have them. All the countries of the European Union have the right to hold a referendum, but as one Briton said, as Oscar Wilde said: "When the gods want to punish us, they grant us our wishes."

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Dear Colleagues! A few sentences on the subject of Brexit. I have read carefully what we were presented with and I am deeply concerned. The restriction of freedom of movement, the right not to have to take part in the deepening of the Union, more economic liberalism - that is what the friends of Mr Cameron call more competitiveness - and not having to participate in the euro, but to have a say, plus of all previous opt-out options - that's what I call Europe á la carte. I warn against the role model character. I really ask the Council to take their time to carefully discuss the details. Nobody has to put time pressure on us. We want to convince the British to stay in the EU, but to continue to water down the ideas and the possibilities of the EU and the EU until Mr Cameron finally finds us sexy - it doesn't work that way either. The result must also taste good to people in the twenty-seven Member States who are not allowed to vote on the result. Second: I am very grateful to Mr Juncker for what he said about the refugee crisis. He used the words "approaching saturation" in relation to Jordan and Lebanon. That's exactly the point: one to three in Lebanon and two million to 500 million on the richest continent we have on earth. Our problems are not the two million refugees, but the fact that the wealth of this rich continent is not distributed fairly on this continent and that problems arise from this. I would like, very specifically, that we do not repeatedly accuse Greece, but help them; however, they also need help. We need the action plan with Turkey as quickly as possible, we have to pick up speed here, and the Member States must finally pay in so that it is a meaningful basis at all and that we can move forward.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: -  Mister President!I originally wanted to say something about the British referendum.But since I can see that Mr Juncker is still in the room, which I really appreciate, I would like to say something directly to you about the euro.Mr. Juncker, in 1970 a Deutsche Mark cost 8 drachmas.30 years later, in 2000, a Deutsche Mark cost 170 drachmas.If the euro hadn't existed, a German mark would cost 250 drachmas today.But no, it was said that one German mark would cost 174 drachmas once and for all.This is a total disregard for reality.And the result is: The euro is far too cheap for Germany, which is why Germany is the artificial world export champion.The euro is far too expensive for Greece, which is why Greece even imports tomatoes.No matter what you do, you cannot fight the market!Thank you for your attention, Mr. Juncker!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Sulík!Something fell down here by a photographer, in the presidium area.That caused a shock.But we still listened, dear colleague Sulík.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to make two concrete proposals. The first concerns refugees. You announced several weeks ago that we were going to give money to Turkey - money which I believe we do not have. I ask you one thing: before paying any money, demand that Turkey put an end to the criminal trafficking, I mean criminal, which is in place to transport Syrian refugees to Europe, in particular to the islands. Greek. This is the first thing to do and, at the same time - and it will be our responsibility - let us increase our capacity to take into account asylum requests where the refugees are, that is to say in the camps. in Jordan, Lebanon or Turkey. This is my first proposal. My second proposal relates to Great Britain. I don't believe - but it's personal - in small arrangements between friends. I don’t think they’ll benefit David Cameron, but that’s another story. Rather than questioning the social rights of workers, not foreigners but European, who work in Great Britain, I ask you to review the issue of the posting of foreign workers. This would be beneficial for the entire European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, tackling the refugee crisis requires solidarity and a humanitarian approach. The strengthening of xenophobic, racist Europe as a deadly fortress with closed borders that sees appeals as a threat to its citizens cannot continue. Beyond the far-right parties, we have, unfortunately, recently seen xenophobic approaches by some Eastern European governments, racist voices from parties in the ECR Group, but also dangerous statements by party officials in the PPP Group and must be dealt with effectively. Unfortunately, the tolerance and failure of the European Council to manage refugees has led to an increase in xenophobia, racism and violence. The progressive and democratic forces must act decisively to stop crime now, so that the ideology of racism and fascism in Europe is not revived. And finally, instead of blackmailing and targeting Greece, the Greek people must be actively supported, who selflessly save .... (The President removes the floor from the rapporteur.)

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I should say in this debate that the European Union is not working as it should. Decisions are not being taken, although this is necessary and urgent. But the biggest problem is not in the European institutions but in the Member States and their governments. In country after country the discussion revolves around ‘me’ and ‘we’ against ‘them’, against the refugees and against the other countries. We are asking the wrong questions. In Sweden, in Great Britain and in Poland we should instead be asking ourselves what our own responsibilities are, what leadership we can take and how we can contribute to making our part of the world a little better. Great Britain is a good example. It has a proud, honourable people and it should not be the hit-and-run driver. It should be the leader in Europe and, instead, take that role for the future.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since Commissioner Juncker is here, I wanted to ask him an immediate question. Some time ago they said that oil at $ 130 a barrel was a disaster for the economy and the people lost a lot of money. Now oil is less than $ 30 a barrel and they say that the stock markets are collapsing, that it is a total disaster, that the price of oil is too low! Are you kidding us? What is this story that once it suits you the oil is too high and then it is too low and who pays is always the people? But is this a Europe of stoners? But what kind of country, of continent is it? But do we want to defend the people or not? Talk about Great Britain, fine. They choose whether to stay in Europe or not. What's the problem? Isn't it the peoples who have to decide? Then all the countries, even Italy, comes to her and tells her: we are leaving Europe. What do you do, do you come to give us a lot of money? Everyone would do that! But what kind of reasoning are they? Then comes Weber, the one who has in his head something that many boys like, comes and says: here there is only selfishness. But if it is Germany that will tell us in a while when we have to go to the toilet, when we have to go to make love, when we have to do everything! Wake up you are a zombie!

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must acknowledge, whether we like it or not, that the consensus of the European institutions has been declining somewhat lately and that, in some cases, unfortunately it has collapsed. I've seen polls that bring it below 30%. I am convinced that, more than the bureaucracy and the regulatory emergency you spoke of - and therefore the simplification that the Commission is implementing is welcome -, the political weakness of Europe certainly weighs on the disaffection of citizens today, which has also emerged in our debate today. For this, however, courage is needed, let me tell you. First of all, the courage to get out of pro-European rhetoric, on the one hand, and easy anti-Europeanism, on the other, of which we had a perfect example just now. We need to speak clearly, call things by their name. We can no longer afford to hide the different positions and divisions even within us, using linguistic tricks, and even less can we afford the acrobatics of those who, and there are many, say one thing in Brussels and then go home and say maybe the exact opposite. We are faced with gigantic challenges, it is useless to remember them. But do we really think that the solution is to go back to small countries? Do you want to tell me what are the tools and policies that individual states have to face and give concrete answers to these gigantic and epochal challenges? Instead, we must take the opportunity for the negotiations between the European Union and the United Kingdom to become a broader debate on the role of the European Union. Let us not miss this opportunity and then we will truly have a better Europe for everyone.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what is at stake at the next European Council is to say, once and for all, if European leaders can think and decide about the European Union as an entity in political, economic and geostrategic terms. Of course, the Brexit issue will be a big test, and we believe that the deal on the table is indeed a fair deal. But the refugee crisis is a much bigger challenge, and what is at stake is to build up a real European border – and a real European border is not a wall. It is an infrastructure that is able to provide the relevant services: first of all, managing refugee flows with European standards; secondly, to provide security for European citizens; and third, to protect the Schengen area as a big undertaking to foster the single market agenda. At the same time that we cope with these external challenges, we need to address the internal ones. That is why the discussion on the euro area recommendation is also so relevant: because we need to have a much better policy mix in the euro area to ensure recovery, which is still not there, and most of all to ensure upward economic and social convergence. We cannot have a situation where some members of the eurozone are pushed into recession again just to address major macro-imbalances and flaws in our monetary zone. Of course we need to see national efforts put into investment and reform, but these efforts need to be supported by banking union and fiscal capacity. Most of all, we cannot ask pro-European governments, such as the Portuguese and the upcoming Spanish one, to go down this negative road. They are pro-European governments.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: - Mr President, one of the topics on the Council's agenda is the setting of new rules for Britain.I believe that the debate on the new rules is not only important for Britain, but is crucial for the European Union as a whole, far from the threat of Britain's departure from the European Union.For me, the ongoing negotiations are mainly a topic of a new perspective on the functioning of the European Union.Indeed, it is high time to seriously consider how the Union should work.As the world changes dramatically, the Union must not insist on its administratively complex, often dysfunctional, model.The inability to act quickly in crisis situations such as Ukraine, or the current groping in a refugee crisis, only increases the need to change the internal rules of operation.For me, adopting new rules for Britain is a real chance for the necessary changes for the whole of Europe.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE).
text: – Mr President, whatever the nature of the final package, the strategy of the United Kingdom has turned out to be a high—risk one. The decision to call a referendum on UK membership of the European Union is primarily about the United Kingdom’s domestic politics satisfying the Eurosceptics. Let us hope that the package that emerges from the February summit will assuage the dissatisfaction of the Eurosceptics, though I rather doubt it frankly – their campaign will certainly continue. What hardly anybody seems to be saying, however, is that there is a two-way relationship between the United Kingdom and the rest of the European Union. The European Union, therefore, is a stakeholder – indeed, a major stakeholder – in the outcome of the referendum. Even if the vote is for staying, much will change. The relationship between the EU and the 27 and the United Kingdom will be conditioned by the sense that the European Union went up to the wire for the United Kingdom, so the United Kingdom had better be more constructive in future. If, of course, the eventual vote is for leaving, then years of upheaval will follow. For Central Europe, the key question is the free movement of labour: one of the Four Freedoms. Any derogation from this immediately raises the question of the free movement of the other three, the free movement of capital being a key issue for the United Kingdom. No-one wants to see these freedoms endangered.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President!Since the outbreak of the refugee crisis, we have seen Council summit inflation with no relevant results.Decisions are postponed, postponed and not pursued any further.The summits degenerate into a show stage for national egocentrics.The last summit was a disappointment.A coalition of the willing wanted a European solution.They did not get through - the result: a series of border closings that endanger the entire existence of Schengen.We finally need action, we need local help, we need functioning external borders, we finally need the promised hotspots, we need a fair distribution of refugees.The citizens of Europe at least expect that the decisions that we have taken over and over again will finally be implemented.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: - To be or not to be together, that is indeed the question, to continue together or not.This is the question that British voters will have to answer.Whether the referendum deal will suffice for them, you must ask them.They have to decide, they alone.But one thing is certain: Europe urgently needs these real reforms.What is on the table is also a strong step towards a European Union that is more competitive, more efficient and more supported.What strikes me is that some now take their dreams for reality.They dream of the British leaving the Union or of getting B status in the European margins, because then the rest of the European Union could fully integrate into that European superstate.I say very clearly: no, no, no.The core of Europe will always remain that unity and diversity.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr President, of a European Council, we are still waiting for it to take stock of the situation and give perspectives. On the issue of migration, I have two observations. We must first remedy the shortcomings observed in the operation of reception and registration centers: three are operational for the moment and the establishment of the other eight must be speeded up. Then, as regards the readmission agreements and their effective implementation, it is necessary to relaunch the negotiations where they have been blocked for years, to verify and sanction the implementation of the agreements where they exist. Regarding the discussions with the United Kingdom, I welcome the desire to move quickly to reach an agreement. This is important so as not to create more misunderstanding among some European citizens about this situation. In this regard, Mr. President, I would like to draw your attention to several issues. First, on the issue of strengthening the principle of subsidiarity, can we really go further by giving national parliaments blocking power without at the same time strengthening the role of the European Parliament? Second, in this process with the United Kingdom, we will officially allow a Member State to strip one of the fundamental freedoms of the European Union. How can we not thus open Pandora's box and encourage other Member States to question other of our founding principles in the years to come? My deep thought is that of not moving towards a dynamic completely opposite to that of the Treaty of Lisbon. I wish you the best of success in these talks and I hope that as a result of this agreement cohesion and consensus will be safeguarded in the Union.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: - Mister President!The Schengen area creates a borderless Europe and our external borders are common European borders.But as long as there is no pan-European willingness to accept refugees, states at the external borders will remain overwhelmed.Are we really talking about border control?We are discussing the fact that Turkey can take good care of three million refugees.Because we, a small continent with 500 million inhabitants, are overwhelmed with such numbers.A pathetic debate!Before we hand over responsibility to Erdoğan, we should first clarify our responsibilities.Otherwise we run the risk of Europe finally falling apart into national egoisms.I don't want to experience that.And one sentence about Brexit: constant extras for the UK are not helpful - in or out, the decision should now be finally made.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let me start on migration. For almost a year we have been testing solutions that do not work. By this I mean so-called national solutions. During that time things have just got worse. We have more debates; we have more blame and shaming; we have no improvement. So I clearly support what Mr Juncker has said. We have on the table a portfolio of solutions and measures – measures that are linked. We must deliver them. If we do so, we will gradually get the situation under control. So let me refer to what Manfred Weber said at the beginning: there is no excuse for the Council not to act, so I call on the Council to really act. We must finally do it, otherwise the cost will be huge. Let me say now three points on the Brexit. First, I appreciate the great effort of President Tusk, the Council and all the others involved in addressing the requests of Prime Minister Cameron. They have made a great effort. Similarly, I hope they were not only considering how to accommodate his request, but how to make sure that the functionality of the European Union – which is not great, as we know – will not be harmed after the deal is agreed. Let me also express one thing. As I said, there was great effort on the side of the Council and European politicians. We need no less effort from Mr Cameron himself. He should not hesitate to say to the British people how important it is for Britain to stay. I hope he knows it.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a theme that links the two points on the agenda of the next Council and it is once again the theme of immigration, both from the external point of view, this human tide of refugees, and from the internal profile, the British requests to reduce the number and the concessions and benefits to immigrants, including intra-European ones, given that even European citizens can take on the appearance of foreigners these days. All this is a sign of a closure, of Europe's powerlessness in the face of the new times, I would say of a loss, and if Europe loses itself, its values ​​and its vision, it is the beginning of a decline. . President Juncker, you said - listening to her is always useful because it touches the real problems and says things sincerely - that she does not want to be on the side of those who, day after day, are destroying Europe and making it retreat - because this is a destiny that we all know to be the end for everyone, not only for Europe, but for all the states that can prosper in Europe - but on the side of those who want farsightedness and hope. Here I tell you this: we, my group and my country are also on the side of those who want to have farsightedness and hope and act in this direction.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: - Mister President! President Juncker, ladies and gentlemen! I urge the Council to begin the next summit by reading out Robert Schuman's quote. The European Union does not come into being in one fell swoop. It is not a simple summary, but it will arise from events that create an act of solidarity. These acts of solidarity, this assumption of responsibility for the community - for all 508 million citizens - are currently being neglected. Where are the next steps towards integration towards a common foreign policy so that we can combat the causes of the refugee crisis? Where are the actions for a common security policy so that we get protection of the external border? Where is the common defense policy so that we can start the fight against ISIS together? And where are the efforts in asylum, migration and integration policy and in a common social policy that an internal market needs, a continent that is committed to the eco-social market economy? People keep asking: where is the EU? I ask: where are the Member States in the implementation of the seven proposals, decisions of the Commission and Parliament? Where is the Council in implementing the seven Commission proposals that have not yet been adopted? And where will the Council be when the Commission makes four new proposals in March? Get to work, do not endanger the Europe project!

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - This is a critical period for the European Union. Today’s challenges, the refugee crisis, Schengen, the economic crisis, the euro crisis, the British referendum, the pursuit of democracy and the fundamental values ​​of the EU in some Member States, are all issues that need to be addressed. For a common and European solution. Our responses to these challenges will determine the future of the Union, the fate of our children and grandchildren, decades in advance. I could also say we are at a crossroads. Either we will have the strength and the courage to find real, courageous, common and forward-looking solutions or we will collapse everything we have built so far. We cannot accept seeming solutions that are not in line with the EU's fundamental values, human rights, democracy and solidarity between Member States. Member State selfishness and nationalism do not advance us, but take us back in time. That is why cooperation within the European Union must be extended and deepened. We need a common Europe, a common European policy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, solidarity and responsibility are the two main words. I agree with my colleague, without that we cannot move forward. It would be a historic mistake if the European Union failed to manage this process, that is, to manage this crisis. So we must have solidarity, but above all responsibility. I agree with the question asked whether it would be better for us to live individually in our nation states or together in the European Union. We have opted for the European Union, we want to live in the Union and we have to solve problems together. Therein lies the key, together. We have passed the regulations, we have all the regulations, however, the regulations are unfortunately not applied. So we need to implement everything we have already brought, first of all I mean Greece here, we need to strengthen Greece, we need to strengthen the European Coast Guard that we talked about, we need to strengthen the Agency and that is the key to the problem. We need to agree on how to replenish the fund for Turkey. It’s something we’ve been talking about for months, but by no means to become effective. And therefore, I urge all of us to take care of that. We would not be talking about Brexit here at all today. Brexit would not have existed at all if migration had not happened, if what is in the world had not happened. So, English to be or not to be! I hope that we are getting closer to the answer to this question, after these negotiations between Mr Cameron, the Commission and the Council, and we expect the Council to take the lead and make a decision without remaining locked in their narrow national egoisms.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the proposed solution to the British question contains elements which are significant concessions by the other Member States, and also some that are symbolic or trivial. Labour would not have gone down the route chosen by Mr Cameron, but we recognise its significance. We also share the concerns that many colleagues have expressed about these significant concessions that have been given, especially perhaps those that affect the welfare rights of employed, tax-paying European citizens working in Britain. But we also note that Mr Cameron has not managed – or even, I think, attempted, perhaps thanks to our pressure – to weaken the social chapter of the Treaty that enshrines workplace rights. There are other things that he has not managed to do, and we are glad of that. But whatever one’s view of the package that is there, we have to bear in mind that there is a much bigger question at stake: the very membership of Britain in the European Union and the threat of the break—up of the European Union. That has to be our overriding consideration. Whether or not Mr Cameron’s package helps secure the result necessary in this referendum in all our interests: that has to be our overriding consideration. If the concessions help – and they will help – win that battle, then that is something we all have to take into account. It is of an overriding importance. There is far too much at stake for us to quibble or to try to oppose this package. Even if many colleagues are understandably not entirely happy with it, I would urge you nonetheless to accept it. (Applause)

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (
text: PPE). - Mr President, the complexity of the refugee issue is obvious and high on the European Council agenda. There are responsibilities at the international level. We are late. The refugee problem cannot be solved if the problem in Syria is not solved. And the problem in Syria cannot be solved unless ISIS is defeated on the ground. There are also responsibilities from the European Union: imperfect mechanisms for dealing with such a big problem. That is why we need more Europe and not less. Of course, to protect the borders of the European Union, which are the borders of Greece and Italy that are in the eye of the storm. Of course, to fulfill the commitments of the Member States and first of all Greece. But we also need solidarity for such a big problem. Responsibilities also exist in Turkey There is no fight against illegal migrant trafficking networks. There are no visas for countries like the Maghreb, and hundreds of thousands of refugees from North Africa and Arab countries are trying to cross the Aegean into the European Union illegally. Hot Spots are needed on the coasts of Asia Minor, with the identification of refugees on ships in both parts of the Aegean, and the repatriation of illegal immigrants. Refugees are a challenge we must tackle successfully. We trust the Commission and Mr Juncker and we believe that Europe will find a solution to this great problem.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the Tusk letter there are some useful things, some trivial things, and some things we do not particularly like. But the referendum is not a ‘yes’ or ‘no’ to Cameron’s deal, but the much bigger question of whether the UK should leave or remain in the EU. I believe, and my party believes, that remaining in the EU is in the best interest of Britain’s economy and security: it is good for jobs, workplace rights and the environment. We have to face our future challenges not through isolation but through cooperation. The alternative, which the Eurosceptics pedal, is for the UK to walk away, have no say but still have to pay. To the Scottish nationalists: this is not about when the referendum will be, but about the future of Scotland, being part of the EU through the UK, and the benefits we gain for jobs and working people in Scotland. I want the UK to remain part of the EU family for our long-term future as a country and our long-term prosperity as a nation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: - Mr President, before going to the subject that I consider to be the main one, which is precisely the question of the United Kingdom, I would like to say to Mrs Deputy Maria João Rodrigues that I do not know if the Portuguese Government is so European, because it depends the Communist Party, which here today made a totally anti-European declaration, and depends on the Left Bloc, which is also against a vision of the social market economy, and therefore its Europeanism is doubtful. In fact, when the Prime Minister's chief adviser yesterday compared the European Union to the Soviet Union, everything is said about this government's European convictions. It was Porfírio Silva, deputy of the PS, António Costa's main advisor, who compared the European Union to the Soviet Union. It is unfortunate that this is not taken into account. When it depends on the radical left, which is totally anti-European, it is evident that afterwards, the Government, even if it has good will, will not be able to fulfill the European commitments and, therefore, this is an evidence, and therefore "tells me who you are, I will tell you who you are ". This would undoubtedly be the answer I had to give you. That said, I would like to say that I am very satisfied with the proposal presented by President Tusk. I think it is essential that we keep the UK in Europe. The United Kingdom guarantees Europe's Atlantic balance. For countries like Portugal, like Ireland, like Holland, like Denmark, like Sweden, which are countries with a more maritime and not so continental vocation, the presence of the United Kingdom is essential for the European Union to be balanced between the center, east, north and south, and so I think we have taken a very big step with yesterday's statement by Council President Tusk.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ms. Rodrigues was approached personally.Therefore, not as a blue card, but under Article 164 you have the floor for one minute to reply.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Paulo Rangel, your claim regarding the Portuguese Government could not, of course, remain unanswered on my side.Everyone knows that this Portuguese Government is a Government that can be counted on for the great causes that are on the table, in terms of answering the British question, defending the Schengen area, responding to the refugee crisis.It is a government of the most solidly pro-European.Now, this Government cannot be counted on to apply in Portugal a recipe that takes the Portuguese back to a situation blocked from recession and without any hope.For that, this Government cannot be counted on.

name: President. –
text: No, Mr Rangel, I have just said that it is not a blue card. I am not admitting blue cards. This was an intervention under Article 164 of the Rules of Procedure answering a personal statement.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Some in this House would like to talk about more or less the EU, as if you could roll the EU out on a line and then go through it all with a ruler once a year to see if there was a little more or a little less EU . It's obviously something wet. That is why we must have no more or less EU, we must have a better EU, a more focused and efficient EU, an EU based on our citizens and the common problems. That is why I would like to commend Donald Tusk for his catalog of amendments, which was tabled yesterday. Letting national parliaments give a red card to EU proposals that go too far will strengthen the cooperation between this House and our national colleagues, and that is what is needed. It provides a clear and distinct division of labor, which will ensure that the EU truly grows big on big things and small on small things. There must also be right and fairness in access to social benefits and systems, and it must be a firm principle that the country in which you live / work and pay taxes is also the country that must take care of you, and therefore must ensuring, of course, equal treatment of EU citizens.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - The British Winston Churchill was among the first to highlight the vision of the United States of Europe. Otherwise, I have never doubted British common sense, so I know that the referendum decision will be reasonable and only theirs. It would be bad to force the British to make a decision or salt their brains. I believe that they will make their decision on the basis of comprehensive information and that they will see that the exit would be bad for them and for us. In this case, only a third party would benefit - those who do not wish well to either the European Union or the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, the Union must make its position clear. This was done by President Tusk yesterday. The deal must be fair. Not because of the EU structures as such, but because of the twenty-eight Member States. It seems wise to me that the EU is strong ... it is important that the EU is strong, immune to stress and even more flexible. The emergency brake instrument also goes in this direction if there is a threat of disintegration of a system, such as a social one. In short, the European Union needs innovative solutions to work better, even if it requires a change in the treaty. But the mega-agreement with the UK must remain one-off. It should not trigger a domino effect and possible further blackmail by Member States.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Mr President, there are crises that attack the heart of the European project: the euro, Brexit, the refugees. And we not only need a European Commission with the capacity to make proposals; also a Council that is at the height of the circumstances and that is capable of making dialogue and understanding a solution to all these problems. Because it is necessary that we do not put stones in the way towards the search for the solutions that today are fundamental in the project of the European Union. And I wanted to respond to Mr. Weber regarding his concerns regarding the future Government in Spain. Tell him, in the first place, not to advance events and, secondly, to have respect for democratic processes. Today, the Socialist Party is entrusted by the King to form a Government because the Popular Party has resigned, and has resigned because, after four years of absolute majority, they have been unable to have a capacity for dialogue with the rest of the political forces. I agree with what you say, Mr. Weber: the people do not want a government made up of radicals, but surely you agree with me that the people want a government that is clean and free from corruption.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). - Mr President, we are in Europe and we want a strong European Union. Imagine Europe without the European Union. It is easy to criticize the European Union and the work it does, especially the current European Commission, with all ease. We are wronging the current European Commission when we do not mention that it is the Commission that has had to deal with the most serious problems that the European Union has had since its inception. It had the Ukrainian, it had Greece, it had the refugee, it had terrorism and it also had the investment. We are constantly upgrading our criticism of the European Union and the European Commission and degrading our great successes. Yes, in this Commission, and we are happy that this Commission and its President are in charge in these difficult times of the European Union, otherwise the European Union could be disbanded. However, on this occasion I would like to make it clear to the European Commission for the European Council, half a minute, Mr President, and I conclude that .... (The President removed the floor from the speaker.)

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues here for their support for my country remaining in the EU. I hope an agreement is reached in February. Only through reaching that agreement can we finally get on to the referendum campaign and fight for Britain to remain in the EU. Citizens in the UK already benefit from our membership of the EU. They benefit from jobs, from rights in those jobs – like the right to paid holiday – from protection of our environment, tackling tax avoidance, dealing with climate change and protecting our security. Our future also lies in our membership of the EU: a future in innovation, in development and in research, and a future economy. So please get that agreement at the Council in February and let us take the campaign on to keep Britain at the heart of, and stronger in, the EU.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! In my country, it's Mardi Gras, it's just around the corner, but people don't feel like celebrating or laughing. People are worried, afraid and desperate because they cannot see how the European Union is going to deal with the refugee crisis. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, please take advantage of the summit and put pressure on those Member States who do not do their homework, those Member States who make commitments at Council summits and then fail to deliver, do not do what they have promised. If the Greek government does not secure the external border, it has to accept help. The hotspots must be set up so that registration is possible again when entering the Schengen area. We need to know in the European Union who is coming to us. And I would like to support my group chairman, Manfred Weber, who said that the Council should take a look at itself. The heads of state and government should show courage, take responsibility and hold together the European Union, which has brought us peace and freedom for 70 years.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we are currently witnessing party attacks in the context of our work as has rarely been seen in the history of this Parliament and it is very important, at this moment, and I appeal to Jean-Claude Juncker, here present, that the Commission European Union remains exempt and that it be like Caesar's wife, who does not just seem to be exempt, who is, and does not allow herself to be captured by the violent party agenda we are witnessing. As for Tusk's proposal, it is a good basis for work. It is absolutely essential that the United Kingdom remains in the European Union, but it is also important to ensure that the advances that need to be made at the moment in the framework of the single currency are possible to be achieved. That is why this clarification is welcome and our hope is that, analyzing the details of the proposal that is currently on the table, it will be possible for the United Kingdom to have a more stable relationship with the rest of the European Union, but also all the countries of the European Union have the conditions to succeed in making progress.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, three points. Firstly, the efficient protection of the EU external border is first of all dependent on the responsibility of the Member States coming forward with the financing they have committed themselves to. We also need to be prepared to defend our eastern border. Secondly, on the UK: Europe should concentrate on positive complementarity, trying to separate crucial issues from domestic policy debates. I fully agree with our British friends that the EU should become truly competitive to finally complete the single market and conduct radical deregulation. Thirdly, my special message to the Dutch Presidency is to see the data protection package as a matter of urgency and to decide about it by March, so that it can be adopted by Parliament in April. In fact, any delay means postponing the chances of developing the Single Digital Market as well as providing our citizens with reliable protection. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure, but as we have Council and Commission coming back in, we will have a shortened catch-the-eye, with two speakers only.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the forthcoming EU summit is very important for the future of the EU as a whole.The asylum crisis must be resolved.We need a common immigration policy.New decisions need to be made, but even more important is to implement the decisions that have already been taken.The establishment of order centers, external border controls, a more even distribution of migrants and asylum seekers throughout the EU have all been left halfway or even unimplemented.Now the Member States really need to take this seriously and implement the decisions that have already been taken.It is about the credibility of the EU as a whole.The second issue concerns Britain's EU membership.Barely the model presented yesterday provides an opportunity to reach an agreement.The EU needs Britain and Britain needs the EU.It must be remembered, however, that already today the United Kingdom has far more exceptions in its own terms than any other Member State.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Mr President, shame on Mr Weber and Mr Rangel for attacking the clearly pro-European Portuguese Government as extremist. Extremists are those who stick to stupid, self — defeating, anti-growth, anti-job-creation policies in Europe, fostering inequality, injustice and the distrust of the citizens in the EU. That said ... (the speaker continued in Portuguese) Mr President, we want the United Kingdom in the European Union, but we cannot continue to tolerate a boycott of the development of European capabilities within the framework of the common security and defense policy, bottom, weakening the European pillar of NATO, when pressing challenges and threats to our security and global security demand a European response and pooling and resource sharing between Member States. Mr Juncker said here that the refugee crisis will not end until the war in Syria is over. It is exactly the example where Europe failed, where Europe failed, as it did in Libya. Nobody spoke in Libya. Does the European Council not care about Libya? It is also exactly another case where Europe has failed and we have imminent dangers in which we need the Council to address itself.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Kommission. - Herr President! Ich gebe mir immer Mühe, treu und brav, der ganzen Debatte hier beizuwohnen. Das tun nicht alle Abgeordneten, aber ich gebe mir Mühe, dies zu tun. Mir fällt auf, dass jeder sich darüber beklagt, dass Europa immer nationaler wird, dass die Regierungen sich mit ihren eigenen Problemen beschäftigen statt mit den Problemen Europas. Es werden hier dauernd feierliche Appelle an die Adressen der Regierungen gerichtet, sich endlich wieder auf das Europäische zu besinnen. Alle die, die das sagen, haben Recht. Aber glaubwürdiger wäre es, wenn die Abgeordneten dies auch täten. Ich stelle fest, dass hier fast nur noch innenpolitische Debatten stattfinden. Diejenigen, die zu Hause die Opposition stellen, nutzen das Europäische Parlament, um ihrer Regierung am Zeug zu flicken, und diejenigen, die Regierungspartei in ihren Ländern sind und diese hier vertreten, beschäftigen sich mit den Vorschlenigen der National Oppstosition in. Dies ist nicht das Europäische Parlament, von dem ich mir gewünscht hätte, dass es seine Rolle in Europa spielen würde! Ich werde auch diese Fragen nicht mehr beantworten, denn das sind keine Fragen, die Sie an Rat oder Kommission richten, das sind Scharmützel zwischen Fraktionen, primitive Parteipolitik! Ich bin nicht der Meinung, dass man dies so weiterführen sollte, wie es inzwischen hier eingerissen ist. (Beifall) For the rest, and as I have to deal with the main principles only and not with each other's oratorical games, I will emphasize two or three elements. Some of our colleagues have argued that the Commission should not be concerned with national budgets. This is not true! There is a treaty, there is a growth and stability pact, there are country-by-country recommendations, there are debates within the Eurogroup and the Council, and the Commission must play its full role. . This is true for the budgets the Commission is examining and, in general, for all the budgets to be monitored. The Commission will play its role, without falling into a policy of strict and stupid austerity. It has also introduced some elements of flexibility in terms of the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact. These elements are more than enough to allow the various Member States, even those grappling with the worst difficulties, to come up with budgets which correspond to all the rules and all the requirements. I will not say anything more about Brexit, because everything has been said. I will allow myself to make just one remark: apart from the representatives of UKIP and other political parties - located rather at the extremes of this Assembly - all the deputies, all the parliamentary groups have constantly pleaded for the maintenance of the United Kingdom into the European Union. If we really want this maintenance, it should come as no surprise that President Tusk, the President of the Commission and a few others have negotiated with the British Prime Minister. The idea that it would suffice to say that the United Kingdom must remain a member of the European Union and at the same time refuse to engage in dialogue with representatives of the British government is an absurd idea. We will have to discuss and speak with the representatives of the United Kingdom if we want the latter to remain in the Union. For the rest, to make things clear, I would like to add that the fact that the United Kingdom will organize a referendum debate, which will be important and of size, should not lead us to cease all other activities of the European Union . During the Greek crisis, we were already very often invited not to do this or that, to abandon such and such an initiative, not to propose such another initiative. The UK will have a democratic debate - to which it is honored - but the Commission will continue its work, which is why, in the field of social policy, we will, over the coming weeks and months, develop a number of initiatives.We will come up with a mobility package, and don't tell us not to do it, because our British friends are discussing it among themselves.We are going to propose a base, a pillar of social rights, launch a wide consultation in March and we will propose amendments to be made to the directive on the posting of workers.It is an absolute necessity and we will do it.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for this debate and for the many questions that were raised. It is true that the next European Council will be crucial for very important aspects of the definition of our Union. It will deal with the two elements that determine our collective will to confront common challenges. One is obviously the debate on the United Kingdom, and I will come back to that in a second. It is true, as Mr Weber said, that it requires a certain amount of courage and leadership to deal with these two issues without any cost to discussing the many other challenges in the European Union. The position of the United Kingdom in the European Union, as well as the improved management of the refugee crisis – we talked about that for many hours yesterday – is obviously crucial for the decisions that we will have to make in February. First of all, I think it is important to say that I am encouraged by the level of support that I hear about the type of package that has been proposed by President Tusk. Of course, the devil is in the detail and everything has to be weighed up, but nevertheless I feel a large majority of Parliament here feels that it is in our interest to keep the United Kingdom in the European Union – not at the highest price. But in a reasonable constructive debate, these are important views. You are partners in this; you will be consulted; you have your ‘sherpas’, and you will be part of the Council meetings. Of course, it might involve changes to secondary legislation. Therefore, your role is also essential and your concerns need to be addressed. This package has to be fair not only to the United Kingdom, but also to all citizens in Europe. It is vitally important to underline that in all aspects, including the most complex part, which deals with social benefits. We have to talk about a deeper and a fairer internal market and we will have to see what the conclusions are in the Council discussions in February. Many elements in the package benefit us all – such as more competitiveness and a deeper internal market – but, as I said, fairness is also an important point in this. I would also like to say that it gratifies me to hear Mr Kamall speak. He qualifies this package as at least being a good starting point, and that gives me hope that the negotiations will be constructive. On the issue of ever-closer union, which was mentioned by Mr Verhofstadt, it would not be a good idea for there to be an opt-out for the United Kingdom. I would like to remind you that, in Article 1 of the Treaty, it states very clearly ‘an ever closer union between the peoples of the European Union’. That is what is written in the Treaty. For some it might mean a federal Europe and for others there might be another connotation, but what we do in the draft European Council decision is to clarify that, in itself, it does not offer a legal basis to transfer competences to the European Union. That is a statement of fact, nothing more and nothing less. At the same time, the draft European Council decision states that the Treaties allow for a deeper degree of integration. I think that is your point. So the Treaties do not represent an obstacle to your vision of Europe, but neither do they oblige us to transfer competences. Therefore I do not think that it would be wise to look at an opt—out. On the refugee crisis, I will not take up your time. We discussed it at length yesterday. Regarding Article 78(3), I would say that this is a possibility, but do not forget that at the moment we have a borders package which is being discussed every month in detail to make sure that we come to the quickest agreement on this. The EU Interior Ministers discussed these issues at their informal gathering held in Amsterdam on 25—26 January 2016, and this will continue to be done consecutively. So we do not need the Article to do it more quickly. What you need is the reality on the ground so that we have the right people from the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Frontex in the hotspots. In conclusion, let me stress the importance of Schengen. The continuing flow of migrants over the past months has seen several countries temporarily re-impose border controls. I would like to say here that the Presidency is committed to securing the preservation of Schengen – a system which is at the heart of the European project and one of the greatest achievements of European integration. We will do all we can to find a solution to the current problems on the basis of the expected Commission proposal and in cooperation with the Commission, Parliament and the Member States concerned.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Minister.The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The letter from the President of the European Council to the Heads of State and Government of the Union on the British question raises many questions. There is talk of a legally binding decision of the European Council to meet the demands of the British government, without specifying what will happen if the referendum that follows is in favor of Brexit. There is also talk of "enhancing competitiveness", which is supposed to be achieved by simplifying legislation and reducing the burden on business. I am afraid that these can translate in practice into further deregulation of the labor market and worse degradation of labor and other social rights. In fact, Mr Cameron's "concerns" may in fact be merely a pretext for making it easier for the dominant political forces in the Union to advance the implementation of similar plans of their own. The European Union can only meet the enormous challenges it faces with more solidarity, both between its Member States and within each of them, by redistributing from the rich to the poor. Satisfying the demands of the British Prime Minister, however, leads in the opposite direction, without even ensuring that the United Kingdom remains in the Union.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Council of 18 and 19 February will have to address the delicate issue of the proposed agreement between the European Union and the British government, in preparation for the referendum to be held next June. In this moment of crisis in the Union, in which national interests seem to prevail over the desire to find common and cohesive solutions, the European institutions must do everything possible to prevent the possibility of the United Kingdom leaving, a hypothesis that would undermine foundations of the Union itself. At the same time, the European Union will not be able to accept tout court the four conditions required by the Cameron government. In fact, while I believe it is necessary to address the discussion of the reform of the European institutions, as proposed by the British government, I am also convinced that this will have to take place in a shared and coordinated way at the European level, and not on the basis of the request of a single Member State, to how "special" it is. For this reason, the proposed agreement presented by Tusk today risks leading us in a dangerous direction for the future of European integration. The first response to the British government imagines a minimalist Europe, blocked by vetoes and orphaned by the federalist perspective, the exact opposite of that strong and ambitious Europe that we need today.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. - It took the threat of the United Kingdom's exit from the Union to finally make concrete proposals on a new way of understanding the place of the Member States in the European institutional architecture. But as we know, nothing has yet been decided and the course promises to be complex and uncertain, whether it is the endorsement of the 27 partners or the result of the referendum. It is obvious that the Union without our British friends would be unbalanced and deprived of part of its identity. It would be an indelible stain inflicted on its credibility and on the future of the European project. I am satisfied that compromise proposals have been put on the table and spark a debate on ideas for a more political Union, more respectful of the interests of its members and better suited to the challenges of our time. It is a first step towards the modernization of the European edifice, but it is also an awareness of the need to make the Union more efficient, more flexible and resolutely focused on the solutions to be provided to the problems which worry our fellow citizens. I hope that our British friends will renew their attachment to a reformed, responsible and operational European Union. Thank you.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - There are crises that attack the heart of the European project: the euro, Brexit, refugees. In response to these challenges, we need not only a European Commission with the capacity to make proposals, but also a Council that is up to the task and that is capable of finding a way out through dialogue and understanding. The future meeting of the European Council does not only address the issue of the referendum in the UK; he also wants to tackle the fundamental issue of migration. A fortnight ago, both the Council and the Commission pointed out that we only had two months to solve this problem. Two weeks have passed, a quarter of the time of the countdown we have to face. Have there been changes? Has there been progress? Have the measures previously adopted been applied? The answer is no. I hope that the next time we meet we will not have to face this topic again as if it were Ravel's Bolero: the same tune, but with an increasingly higher tone.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- The migrant crisis and Brexit will be discussed at a recent session.It is clear that both of these issues in many ways call into question the future of the European Union.While, on the one hand, the democratic decision is in the hands of the citizens of the United Kingdom, the migrant crisis must be urgently resolved by the Member States together with the European Commission.I want to believe that the majority of the citizens of the United Kingdom will decide to stay in the European Union, for which yesterday's proposal by the President of the Council of Turkey is a good basis for compromise.The European Union needs the United Kingdom and vice versa.In today's intertwined world of various relations, the unity of countries on the European continent is really the only real answer.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: written. - There are crises that attack the heart of the European project: the euro, Brexit, refugees.
