In response to these challenges, we need not only a European Commission with the capacity to make proposals, but also a Council that is up to the task and that is capable of finding a way out through dialogue and understanding. The future meeting of the European Council does not only address the issue of the referendum in the UK; he also wants to tackle the fundamental issue of migration. A fortnight ago, both the Council and the Commission pointed out that we only had two months to solve this problem. Two weeks have passed, a quarter of the time of the countdown we have to face. Have there been changes? Has there been progress? Have the measures previously adopted been applied? The answer is no. I hope that the next time we meet we will not have to face this topic again as if it were Ravel's Bolero: the same tune, but with an increasingly higher tone.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - We have already seen an example in the history of the European Union that some Member States wanted to slow down or even reverse political integration. The Luxembourg compromise of the 1960s, the reintroduction of the Member States' veto, then delayed the development of the Union for two decades. Half a century later, we cannot allow this to happen again. The President of the European Council recently unveiled a proposal to meet British reform demands. Among other things, the Council proposal would allow Britain to restrict the rights of EU citizens working on its territory and turn the European Community back on the bumpy path of nation-state existence. No one is claiming that the European Union is perfect or infallible. However, free employment and equality regardless of nationality are fundamental values ​​of the European Union, which cannot be the subject of political bargaining. The answer to the challenges facing the Union, the Greek crisis, the refugee crisis, the Russian aggression cannot be 'we will solve it alone'. We should finally forget the ideal of national sovereignty, which was very fashionable in the 19th century but is now obsolete. In the most difficult moments, the United States chose closer cooperation, a federation, and now the strongest state in the world. Why do some Member State leaders think that if we do the opposite, it is in Europe's interest?

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: written. - The President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, made a proposal this week to meet Britain's demands for special treatment. The EU cannot move forward in decision-making unless it finds unanimous solutions. According to this principle, there is no automatic mechanism that would pull Britain deeper into European integration. However, that does not mean that Britain could use its veto if the eurozone wants to move forward. The European Union has always progressed through different strokes, so that cooperation - including EMU - remains open to all. This must continue to be the basic idea of ​​integration. The more cumbersome proposal concerns, in principle, social benefits and the right of Member States to withhold the interests of workers from other EU countries. The development of social Europe has lagged behind the economy and the internal market, and it is therefore unfortunate that the content of its sector is being the first to be compromised. It would be unfortunate - above all for Britain itself, but also for the EU as a whole - if negotiations on a separation began.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. - The upcoming European summit will deal with two of the most pressing issues in the EU at the moment, ie negotiations with the United Kingdom and the migration crisis. How and whether we deal with these challenges will be critical to the future of the European project. Earlier this week, President Tusk presented his proposal for changes to change Great Britain's attitude towards the EU. This is certainly a good basis for a compromise, but much will depend on whether we can avoid a situation in which over-privileging Great Britain results in an avalanche of claims from other Member States. In such a situation, at best, integration may be leveled down to the "menu" level, and at worst, it may fall apart. The position of the so-called new member states that have serious reservations about the limitations of social benefits for immigrants proposed by London. An even greater threat to the Community is certainly the migration crisis, which has faded somewhat due to the winter, but will certainly come back with greater force in the spring. Recently, a new approach to refugees can be noticed among Western European countries, eg Sweden has started sending people who do not meet the asylum conditions. If this process is intensified, and maybe also combined with some form of financial support for the returned refugees, it can be assumed that it will weaken the wave of the influx of more.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. - None of the European Union institutions should have accepted David Cameron's blackmail. Because whatever the outcome of the referendum, its objective is to destroy our community destiny. And if a British exit would have serious consequences for the Union, it would have just as much for the United Kingdom. Pointing a pistol at the Council's temple, David Cameron got a deal. Besides the fact that it does not guarantee the maintenance of the United Kingdom in the Union since the Prime Minister has authorized his government to campaign for the "out", it seeks to smash the community building. On the one hand, the British government has obtained assurances that the market will prevail over Europeans. On the other hand, with the "red card" mechanism, Cameron is telling us that he wants to end European integration. In addition, Europeans may be stripped of their social rights. Finally, "last but not least", all of this should be part of the treaties. I will oppose it. We must trace a real path: that of federalism against inter-governmentalism, that of social rights against the market and, above all, that of solidarity in the face of national egoisms.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - One of the main items on the agenda of the next EiT is the draft compromise agreement between the EU and the British government. In addition to the issues criticized by the Cameron government (economic governance, competitiveness, sovereignty), the possible restriction of the free movement of labor and the possible restriction of social benefits for hundreds of thousands of Hungarian workers are among the most important demands. In connection with the latter, certain points of the document - such as the withdrawal of job search support - are completely untenable from the Hungarian point of view. The system of benefits for European workers can be partially revised and adjusted, but its fundamentals and achievements cannot be changed in any way. Cameron’s conservative, right-wing government has “overtaken the bike” in the populist race and is now serving the anti-EU electoral masses ramped up against external and internal migration to try to show and deliver on its election promises. The Community of the European Union must strive for compromises and agreement; however, he cannot allow populist blackmail to gain meaningful space at any time and set an example for others. It is feared that other European countries may join the queue, which will also have a negative impact on the lives of Hungarians living there. At the next meeting of the European Council, Viktor Orbán also has a duty to protect the rights and common sense interests of European workers, including the hundreds of thousands of Hungarians working in Great Britain, by all possible means.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: written.- There are crises that attack the heart of the European project: the euro, Brexit, refugees.In response to these challenges, we need not only a European Commission with the capacity to make proposals, but also a Council that is up to the task and that is capable of finding a way out through dialogue and understanding.The future meeting of the European Council does not only address the issue of the referendum in the UK;he also wants to tackle the fundamental issue of migration.A fortnight ago, both the Council and the Commission pointed out that we only had two months to solve this problem.Two weeks have passed, a quarter of the time of the countdown we have to face, and unfortunately we still do not see the progress and changes necessary to face this crisis effectively and with dignity.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the context of the upcoming European Council summit devoted to a large part of migration, I would like to pay particular attention to the use of satellite Earth observation systems developed in the EU in the field of internal security of the Member States. In order to deal effectively with the problem of millions of asylum seekers in Europe, it is essential to have reliable information on, for example, the number of people moving within the EU's external borders. The system that can provide this information is already owned by the EU. It's the Earth Observation Satellite System - Copernicus. One of the five priority actions for Copernicus is border surveillance, border traffic, maritime traffic and support for the EU's external action. Satellites collect radar and optical data for both sea and land situations. They include national borders, coasts, and transport routes essential for security. In this way, the Copernicus system is able to provide complete information on migratory movements. The key is the appropriate use of the information received, coordination of activities, and thus - more effective cooperation between Member States, as well as support for the further development of the program, which in the future will allow us to react faster to potential crises.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Dear President Buhari, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I warmly welcome the President of Nigeria to the European Parliament! Mr. Buhari was elected to his post as President almost a year ago, in March 2015. After a peaceful and democratic transfer of power, he proposed a very extensive reform agenda. In his government statement, he committed himself to fighting corruption in his country and investing in the economy. But above all, he is determined to fight terrorism. In Nigeria, we all know that we are all aware of the cruel deeds of Boko Haram. In view of the unimaginably cruel attack this weekend, in which, according to the current state of knowledge, 85 people lost their lives, I extend our deepest condolences to you, Mr President, and also our solidarity. I have also assured President Buhari that we as the European Union, and particularly as the European Parliament, will support him in his fight against terror. At the same time, of course, we want to support the reforms in the country. And we are ready, especially here in the European Parliament, Mr President, to help ensure that investment is made in the Nigerian economy and that we can expand our common trade. Once again, on behalf of the Members of the European Parliament, I warmly welcome you, Mr President, and I now ask you to speak to us. (Applause)

name: Muhammadu Buhari
text: President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. – Mr President, I wish to express my utmost appreciation to the President of the European Parliament, Mr Martin Schulz, for inviting me to address the plenary session of this legislative arm of the European Union. I am honoured and humbled at having been selected to make an address on this occasion. Let me also bring to the European leaders, parliamentarians and the good people of Europe, a goodwill message from my fellow countrymen and women. The Nigerian people acknowledge with deep appreciation the material and financial sacrifices the European Union, and individual friendly European nations, made towards the conduct of elections and institutionalisation of democratic norms in Nigeria. As it had done before, the European Union has supported the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) in the smooth conduct of the last general elections in Nigeria, the outcome of which received worldwide acclamation. Nigerians noted the huge contributions that Europe has made towards the realisation of acceptable, free and fair elections in our country. Today I will tell this august gathering that European investments are beginning to bear fruit. I am one of the returns on the European investments in the democratisation of Nigeria. Indeed, the present regime is the product of a democratic choice consciously made by the people of Nigeria through the ballot box. Democracy has come to Nigeria to stay – sooner than many of us would have imagined. Nigeria will be counted among the most stable, strongest and most virile democracies in Africa. There may be strife and stresses, but these can be contained by the safety mechanisms of an electoral democracy. The events leading to the general elections in Nigeria in the early part of the year 2015 gave strong indications that the country was in trouble. Seeming anger, expressions of vituperation and open animosity, as well as threats and violence unleashed against the electorate, aimed at forcing them to vote for the status quo, were unpalatable developments that brought the stability of Nigeria into question. The drama that took place at the National Collation Centre was a momentarily frightening situation, unleashed by desperate agents of the status quo with the purpose of maintaining their grip on the national resources for their selfish interests. The maturity and patience with which the officials of the Independent National Electoral Commission under Professor Attahiru Jega handled the matter saved the struggle for democracy and the huge European contributions. We must thank God that Nigeria survived this drama. As I have stated in other fora, the actions of Nigeria’s former President, Goodluck Ebele Jonathan, are commendable. For the first time in the history of Nigeria, a presidential candidate and sitting President conceded electoral defeat in defiance of calls by strong forces, including agents and benefactors of the regime, not to do so. I do appreciate the special relationship that exists between Nigeria and the European Union. The European Union is Nigeria’s main development partner and the pillar of support for the consolidation of democracy and the economic development of our country. We in Africa appreciate that your problems are mainly managing prosperity and competition. However, our problems are poverty, disease and technological backwardness. It is not too difficult to appreciate the kind of challenges these problems pose: internal strife, refugees, boat people, drug and human trafficking, etc. Chaos is not a neighbour anybody would wish to have. It is therefore in our collective interest to cooperate and tackle these serious problems in Africa. I am pleased that we already have the Nigeria-European Union Annual Political Dialogue, which has continued to strengthen our cooperation based on shared values and interests, especially in the areas of peace, security, democracy and good governance. Through this forum we have been able to continue, on a regular basis, to share perspectives on important regional, continental and global issues, with a view to forging common positions. We are committed to intensifying political dialogue and cooperation in the context of the Nigeria-European Union Joint Way Forward. Both of us believe in peace and security, respect for human rights, democracy and good governance, equality and tolerance, as ways of developing prosperous and strong societies. Furthermore, in the context of these European Union-Nigeria relations, I wish to acknowledge that the European Union had, severally, condemned the activities of extremist groups, including Boko Haram in Nigeria and in the entire Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS). The European Union had noted and commended Nigeria’s development of a National Counter-Terrorism Strategy and the amendment of the country’s Counter—Terrorism Act in demonstration of the Government’s commitment to finding a lasting solution to the threats posed by Boko Haram terror elements. Nigeria appreciates the EU’s collaboration, especially in the area of technical support, capacity-building for security services and provision of development assistance. For our part, we have updated our rules of engagement in fighting terrorism, and we pay very close attention during operations to the treatment of captured terrorists, to civilians caught up in the conflict and, in general, to safeguarding property. Our aim is to use the minimum force necessary in our fight against terrorists. In light of this, I wish to seize this opportunity to thank individual European Member States for their assistance towards the success of the Nigerian military onslaught against the Boko Haram terror elements. Many European Union Member States have pledged to support our efforts in the rescue of the kidnapped Chibok schoolgirls. It may interest you to know that in a recent meeting I had with the parents of the Chibok girls, I assured them that the Government would not rest until all the girls are rescued alive and reunited with their families. I remain fully committed to this pledge. (Applause) Since my assumption of office in May last year, we have reorganised the Nigerian Armed Forces and repositioned them to deal decisively with the Boko Haram terrorists. Indeed, all the Local Government Areas that were hitherto under the control of the Boko Haram terrorists in Adamawa, Borno and Yobe States in the north-eastern flank of Nigeria, have been recaptured. Internally displaced persons (IDPs) are gradually returning to their communities. The Federal Government is committed to rebuilding schools, hospitals and other vital infrastructure destroyed by the fleeing terrorists. Currently, the activities of Boko Haram have been reduced to the Sambisa Forest, and their capacity to launch major offensives has been degraded. Boko Haram has now resorted to attacking soft targets, such as markets, mosques and churches, using innocent, under-age, hapless children to detonate locally-made improvised explosive devices (IEDs). I must express our serious concerns about the alarming situation in southern Libya, which is becoming a strategic time bomb for Africa and indeed Europe. The ungoverned swathe of land of southern Libya has become a thriving arms bazaar which threatens the security of the Sahel region, as well as the West Africa region and beyond. We must therefore intensify our efforts to find a lasting solution to the Libyan crisis. Nigeria is a peace-loving nation and has played a critical role in conflict management and resolution within and outside Africa. Peace-keeping and peace-building have been part of Nigeria’s foreign policy since independence. Nigerian troops have participated in almost all United Nations sub-regional and regional peace-keeping and peace-building operations. In spite of our current security challenges, Nigeria is among the 10 top troop-contributing countries to the United Nations peacekeeping operations around the world, with huge financial and human commitment. Nigeria’s first outing on peacekeeping operations was to the Congo, as part of the 20 000—strong United Nations Operations in the Congo (ONUC) in July 1960, of which I was privileged to be a member of the contingent in 1963 – barely three months before Nigeria’s independence. Nigeria participated in United Nations operations in the Congo for only three-and-a-half years. It contributed the third largest national force in the Congo, after India and Ethiopia. Since then, Nigeria has maintained a presence in global peacekeeping efforts. Nigeria has indeed participated in the maintenance of law and order following a mutiny in Tanganyika in 1964. In 1979 and 1982, soldiers of Nigeria’s 21st Infantry Battalion and the 202 Reconnaissance Regiment were deployed to Chad as a peacekeeping force to monitor a ceasefire and inspire confidence in the ongoing peace process. In addition, it contributed to the largest contingent when the Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group (ECOMOG) was moved to Sierra Leone on a peacekeeping—cum—peace-enforcement mission. The Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group recovered most parts of the country from the rebels and returned the ousted President, Tejan Kabbah, to office on 10 March 1998. Under the mandate of the African Union, Nigeria embarked on a peacekeeping mission in São Tomé and Príncipe, where it succeeded in persuading dissident soldiers to subject themselves to constitutional authorities. Besides this, Nigeria has also deployed its personnel in Rwanda and in the Darfur Region of Sudan in order to maintain the peace in these two countries. Nigeria has additionally deployed its contingent to the following African countries: Angola (United Nations Angola Verification Mission); Namibia (United Nations Transition Assistance Group); Mozambique (United Nations Operations in Mozambique); Western Sahara (United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara); Somalia (United Nations Operation in Somalia); and the Auozou Strip (United Nations Aouzou Strip Observer Group). On migration from Africa to Europe: Nigeria wishes to acknowledge and share the concerns expressed by the European Union with respect to the influx of migrants from Africa through the Mediterranean Sea, with its attendant loss of lives. In this regard, Nigeria will collaborate with the European Union to address illegal immigration to Europe. The Federal Government of Nigeria is making concerted efforts to address the push factors that propel migration, especially from Nigeria, as both a destination and a transit country. In this year’s budget, the Government has provided for over 500 000 graduate employment positions in the teaching profession alone. We are also collaborating with the states and local governments to strengthen Skills Acquisition Centres, in order to train the teeming youth in various vocational skills so that they can be self-employed and eventually become employers of labour. We are also making efforts to diversify the economy, giving impetus to agriculture and solid minerals exploitation, to create wealth and employment. Nigeria welcomes the outcome of the Valletta EU-Africa Summit on Migration, including the launching of the EUR 1.8 billion Emergency Fund to address the root causes of migration from Africa to Europe. Nigeria will work with the countries of the Sahel and Central Africa to submit to the Board of the Emergency Trust Fund the projects that we have identified for funding in due course. The Common Agenda on Migration and Mobility (CAMM), which Nigeria signed on 12 March 2015 and was indeed the first country to sign from sub-Saharan Africa, is a demonstration of the positive spirit of our cooperation with the European Union in the field of migration and development. It is in the light of this understanding that I wish to propose the reciprocal visa waiver for holders of Nigerian diplomatic and official passports attending official meetings and conferences in Europe. Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs): the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, collectively endorsed by the Economic Community of West African States, is yet to be signed by Nigeria and a few others. During Economic Partnership Agreement negotiations, Nigeria raised some pertinent technical issues that are yet to be addressed. Giving due consideration to the mismatch of the two regions, Europe and ECOWAS, in terms of technology and manufacturing experience, the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria (MAN) and Associated Trade Unions raised concerns over the negative impact of EPAs on Nigeria’s industrialisation programme. Nigeria is working towards addressing its own side of the issues. I am therefore urging our European Union partners to also address our own concerns to allow for Economic Partnership Agreements that are mutually beneficial and contribute to the prosperity of our people, in the context of our shared values and interests in promoting cordial bilateral trade relations. On oil theft and illegal bunkering: Nigeria is facing the challenges of oil theft and illegal bunkering in the Niger Delta, as well as the recovery of illicit funds. It is therefore expedient to raise these issues with you, distinguished parliamentarians. In this regard, Nigeria solicits the cooperation of the European Parliament to support the efforts aimed at stemming these vices. Our attempts to restore security, curb corruption and fight crime will result not only in improving social stability in Nigeria but will re-open the doors for full economic relations with Europe and the outside world. Those who wish to invest in our country have vast opportunities, and we intend to guarantee the security of people and investments brought to Nigeria. The whole world recently converged in Paris, France, for the Climate Change Conference (COP21). A positive approach to the issue resulted in mutually-acceptable decisions. The world leaders have forged a common platform in addressing the devastating effects of climate change, particularly in the underprivileged countries across the entire length and breadth of the globe. During this all-important global event, I declared my country’s position on climate change. I reiterate here that it portends serious threats to Nigeria’s security and development. Nigeria is watching helplessly as Lake Chad dries up. This has monumental consequences for the people living in the Lake Chad basin, whose livelihood has, for generations, been dependent on the resources of the lake. These resources are fast dissipating, throwing communities out of jobs. It is pertinent to mention that all the states contiguous to Lake Chad are facing the effects of climate change. Collectively, we are under an obligation to face these common challenges. Our collective efforts may not be enough, as we are constrained by the dearth of funds, technology and manpower to initiate the right solutions. We are therefore calling for quick global action to address the issues. Indeed, these will serve in part as panaceas to the issues facing the countries sharing Lake Chad’s resources. In an effort to find a lasting solution to this problem, Nigeria has contributed the sum of USD 5 million, which has already been used in the conduct of a holistic study on the inter-basin water transfer from the Congo basin to Lake Chad. The study has revealed that the project will require the sum of USD 15 billion to reach completion. I wish to state that this study has indicated that the proposed Lake Chad project would be able to pay back this huge investment if it is private-sector driven. Against this background, let me invite Parliament to use its good offices by lending its support to the realisation of this laudable project. I wish once again to express, with all sense of humility, my profound appreciation to the President of the European Parliament, Members of the European Parliament, European leaders and the people of this continent for the honour personally extended to me, and by and large the people of Nigeria, to address the plenary session of one of the largest groups of democracies in the world. I thank you all for this rare honour. Thank you very much. (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, President Buhari, for your speech!Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your applause, which also supports the strenuous work that President Buhari has to do in his country.I would like to thank you once again, Mr President, certainly also on behalf of your colleagues, for your country's great commitment to the international obligations of the United Nations.Thank you for your visit!(Applause)

name: La Présidente. –
text: The order of the day calls Voting Time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see minutes)

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Georgia is probably the most advanced in implementing reforms related to the Association Agreement and visa liberalisation. The Georgian population remains strongly supportive of the European course, with 68% willing to join the EU and support the democratic development of the country. The deep and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA) is already bringing positive effects to Georgia and, with continuous reforms and standardisation, its exports to the EU will grow. But due to asymmetry in trade, the effects on the EU market will remain minimal. Georgia will gain in terms of job creation, encouraging growth and investment and creating a predictable and liberal business environment. Such a mechanism has never been used so far, but it provides a safety net – if needed – for EU producers of sensitive agricultural products and for Georgian producers against the fraudulent circumvention of origin requirements by third parties not covered by this Association Agreement. I thank the shadow-rapporteurs, all the interlocutors and advisers for their work and constructive approach, and I ask your support for this report.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I will read the official statement of the Commission, but firstly let me underline that the Commission and Parliament have a very common interest. We were able, during the last week, to present a very robust and stronger type of approval system in Europe. The Commission will get supervisory powers, and we will make sure that Member States enforce the rules. So there will be no new Volkswagen cases in the future. Now let me go onto the official Commission statement. COMMISSION STATEMENT The Commission is fully committed to putting very robust emission-testing procedures in place, as of September 2017, to measure real driving emissions (RDE). The Commission counts on the European Parliament’s support in this respect. On 28 October 2015, the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles (TCMV) voted on a draft Commission Regulation introducing RDE limits for light duty vehicles. The Commission is aware that the final result of the vote at the TCMV raised criticism from the European Parliament as to the level of conformity factors. The Commission considers the review mechanism of the draft regulations to be a very appropriate tool to address this criticism. The annual review of the second conformity factor is explicitly included in the enacting terms of the draft Commission regulation. The objectives of this revision clause are to bring the conformity factor to 1, as soon as possible and at the latest by 2023. The Commission is committed to making use of this revision clause to reduce the second conformity factor by 2017 already, and on an annual basis. Due to this revision clause and the technical improvements which can be expected, manufacturers will, as of today, have to design vehicles that will comply with a conformity factor of 1. The Commission welcomes the report on the reduction of pollutant emissions from road vehicles (DESS report) and agrees with the European Parliament on the need to ensure that the Commission is empowered to adopt measures and requirements on RDE test procedures, including conformity factors, through delegated acts following the revision of the Euro 5/6 legislation. The Commission is committed to working closely with the European Parliament and with the Council to reach a compromise to this end without delay. The Commission will, in any case, ensure that the European Parliament is duly and closely involved in the setting-out of the RDE conformity factors. The Commission believes that the joint work by both co-legislators will allow the establishment of a new, efficient and reliable approval framework for motor vehicle products.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: chair of the ENVI committee. – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Bieńkowska for her presence today in the Plenary, and also Vice-President Šefčovič, for their important work. This statement is proof of positive interinstitutional cooperation and represents a clear commitment for the future. I would like to invite all Members of the European Parliament to take this commitment into account during the vote – important for our European citizens.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This closes the Voting Hour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova, to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament.  Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- On 13 November 2014, Parliament approved an EU-Moldova Association Agreement establishing a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area.However, the agreement contains a bilateral safeguard clause by virtue of which the established trade preferences are temporarily suspended, should the import regime of the products from the associated country damage the European market.The safeguard clause is then accompanied by the anti-circumvention mechanism, which makes it possible to restore the original rate of customs duties if the imported products exceed a certain threshold.I voted in favor of the proposal to implement these clauses as I consider protecting the European market and its balance as a priority.

name: Tim Aker and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements.  The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament.  Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report because the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism in this type of trade agreement is a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU, where appropriate. This report deals with the application of the safeguard and anti-circumvention clauses included in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova, as well as the obligation of the European Commission to report. The Commission must present a report to the European Parliament in the event that it tries to activate the necessary mechanisms to protect the European industry and consumers from bad commercial practices that could harm their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement in order to be able to reinstate customs with the aim of protecting the European economy. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of the safeguard and anti-circumvention clause for agricultural products of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.Indeed, these clauses apply when the European branch is affected and not the national branches of the Member States which are not protected.In addition, the changes made through this text are minor;this amendment would bring no added value.Finally, the planned adjustment of customs duties to address the problem of large imports is too small to be effective.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. This was a technical file that amends a Commission proposal to harmonise the wording of a regulation with the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The EU-Moldova Association Agreement includes an anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the Parliament and Council is necessary to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as it applies the necessary safeguard clauses and anti-circumvention mechanism that may need to be activated in the event that a product originating in Moldova is imported in such large quantities into Europe that they create production problems.of the Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- The EU-Moldova Association Agreement has an "anti-circumvention mechanism" and a "safeguard clause".Also, if there is an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious prejudice to the European industry, the clause allows to activate a suspension of any further reduction in the tariffs of the product concerned or their replacement by the duty.most favored nation customs.We can only rejoice at such a reservation with regard to free trade.Unfortunately, the “most-favored-nation” clause is still far from sufficient.In addition, it is clear that this provision, more cosmetic than practical, is never used.To vote in favor of this text would therefore accredit an excessively minimalist protection policy.That is why, with my colleagues from the National Front, I chose to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ If the situation were the UK signing or updating such an Agreement with Moldova to bring British trade into line with World Trade Organisation rules, then I would vote in favour. However, I do not believe that the European Union should be the place for such matters to be decided as a consequence of my view that the United Kingdom should not be a part of it. Consequently, I felt that it was appropriate to abstain on this vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this agreement because it will facilitate monitoring of the implementation of a common commercial policy between the Union and Moldova for the sake of transparency and the objective of reducing corruption.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.It provides for a bilateral safeguard clause which would allow the preferences to be suspended in the event of a sudden increase in imports which would lead to an unexpected increase in imports which would cause economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing country.The agreement also provides for a so-called anti-circumvention regime, which provides for the possibility of re-establishing the most-favored-nation duty rate in the event of imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceeding a certain threshold and without due justification for their exact origin.The purpose of the proposed regulation is to ensure that Moldova's obligations under the agreement are met in order to protect EU producers where necessary.I support the proposal's reporting obligation for the Commission to submit an annual report to the legislator on the application and implementation of the regulation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. - Agricultural products imported from Moldova are mainly oilseeds, fresh nuts, apple juice, wines and cereals. The Association Agreement with Moldova contains a safeguard clause: if there is an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious prejudice to the "European" industry, the clause allows to activate a suspension of any further lower tariffs for the product concerned or their replacement by most-favored-nation tariffs. There is also an anti-circumvention clause: when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products exceeds a ceiling with a doubt about their origins, the clause allows the preferential tariff to be replaced by the tariff of the most favored nation (MFN ). These clauses are comparable to those already put in place in many free trade agreements. However, these clauses can only be applied when the "European branch" is affected as a whole: the branches of production in each state are therefore not protected. That's why I abstained.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing.- The European Union is Moldova's main trading partner, with an amount of trade equal to 46.4% of the country's total.My vote in favor of the Scholz report is based on the conviction that the Association Agreement between the EU and Moldova represents an important step forward in relations with this country, a step which must however take due account of the risks for European producers and consumers.For this reason, I believe that the implementation, within Community legislation, of the safeguard clauses aimed at protecting the continent's industry and production, which are threatened by the danger of excessive imports, is very positive.The arrival of non-Moldovan products on the European market, through a first passage in the country, can represent a problem whose resolution can be effectively identified in the introduction of the anti-circumvention mechanisms already provided for in the agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - We have voted in favor. It is a procedure that allows closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an internal EU Regulation, applicable to the Association Agreement between the EU and Moldova, which is the necessary instrument to be able to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that its application causes an unexpected and significant increase in imports, causing economic damage to the national industry. - The anti-circumvention mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favored-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without due justification.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I want to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report, which I have supported.The safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement are important.Through this instrument, preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application may cause a significant or unexpected increase in imports that causes economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing Party, that is, it is possible to suspend further tariff liberalization or restore the rate of duty.most-favored-nation customs.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report concerns the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism for the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.The clauses of this agreement apply when it comes to the European branch and not a national branch, which means the non-protection of the productions of each state.The goals of flattening tariffs over the MFN rate is clearly too low for any real resolution on imports.In reality, this agreement is only intended to facilitate adjustment, not to prevent it.Basically, the amended text in no way enriches the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.In light of their reaction, the terms of this agreement have no ambition to protect.The changes are very minimal and do not improve the text in any way, so I will abstain on this vote.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- Although it is not problematic, I have expressed my opinion on this provision with an abstention, since, although it does not generate a real risk for the Italian agricultural production system, I do not agree with the assumptions of this agreement.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I have given my support to this legislative resolution of the Parliament that makes it possible to put into practice the corresponding provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to which the European Parliament gave its approval on 13 November 2014. The Regulation needs to be approved proposed to enable compliance with Moldova's obligations under the Agreement with a view to protecting EU producers, where appropriate. The Agreement includes a bilateral safeguard clause whereby preferences can be temporarily suspended if their application may cause a significant and unexpected increase in imports that causes economic damage to the EU. In addition, it also includes an anti-circumvention mechanism, which offers the possibility of re-introducing customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it adopted Parliament's position on the regulation implementing the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention regime providing for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences provided for in the Association Agreement for Moldova. The Association Agreement with Moldova, like most of our trade agreements, contains a bilateral safeguard clause. This measure allows for the suspension of preferences in the event that their continued imposition would lead to an unexpected increase in imports which would cause economic injury to the domestic industry of the importing country. In addition, the agreement also provides for a so-called anti-circumvention regime, which provides for the possibility of re-establishing the most-favored-nation duty rate in the event of imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceeding a certain threshold and without due justification for their exact origin. A Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed in order to enshrine in EU internal law a measure that will allow for the application of the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention regime. The proposed regulation is necessary to ensure the fulfillment of Moldova's obligations under the agreement in order to protect EU producers where necessary.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing.- The proposed rules allow for the temporary suspension of the preferences provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova would jeopardize and harm the EU's internal market.The adoption of the current regulation is necessary in order to properly integrate it into EU internal law and thus make the anti-circumvention procedure applicable.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- In the Republic of Moldova, too, MEPs, with the support of the regulation, enabled the European Parliament to introduce the instrument needed to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism and to transpose it into EU internal law.With a few corrections, the European Parliament wants to harmonize the text of the regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.Prior to any possible interventions, an active consultation with the Moldovan authorities is planned.Given that these are more technical and explanatory changes, my support was not in question.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this report on safeguard measures that seek to protect EU Member States in the event of a product being imported from Moldova, in a way that could harm EU industry (eg reducing or eliminating tariffs leading to imports of large quantities of products).).So far, there has been no safeguard under the EU's free trade agreement, and I believe that Member States must protect themselves in such circumstances.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- The vote concerns a text amended by the European Parliament on the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism intended for agricultural products of the EU-Moldova association agreement, a text which brings almost nothing to the substance.These clauses are hardly protective as they are formulated.The changes made are very minor and do not improve the text.I therefore abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the EU-Republic of Moldova Association Agreement represents an opportunity for both contracting parties from both an economic and a geopolitical point of view.I also believe that it is important that this agreement contains adequate safeguard clauses and anti-circumvention mechanisms and that they are applied effectively.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The safeguard clauses contained in the anti-circumvention mechanism of the trade association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova should not be understood as an anachronistic protectionist measure that does not belong to the political will of either the Commission or Parliament, but rather a form of protection of producers and consumers through the possibility of reintroducing the MFN customs duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova (listed in Annex XV-C) exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their origin exact. The anti-circumvention clauses are important to avoid the importation of non-Moldovan products into the Union via Moldova, using the benefits of the agreement to circumvent the "rules of origin" requirements. Chapter II of the proposal (Article 13) establishes the procedures for the application of this mechanism, which is without prejudice to the application of the measures defined in Chapter I (safeguard measures). It is important to promote trade association agreements and free international trade, but this must take place on a basis of transparency and mutual respect for the rules.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report aims to provide details and modifications to the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the suspension of the tariff preferences granted to Moldova. These various clauses provide, in fact, that in the event of exceeding a certain volume of imports, in particular of agricultural products, which would threaten or cause serious damage to a European industry, the Union may suspend any further reduction. tariffs and replace preferential tariffs with most-favored-nation tariffs. Although they start from a good intention, these clauses remain ineffective insofar as the national branches of production remain vulnerable as long as there is no major danger for the European branch. In addition, the measures cited above are undoubtedly derisory. Finally, the changes made to the text are absolutely negligible. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Union law requires the existence of temporary protection instruments in the event of an increase in imports. Especially when this growth would cause economic damage to the European market and when there is a need to protect its producers, the Union must make use of regional surveillance measures and safeguard measures in the agreements. This is the case in the development of the preferential trade regime with the Republic of Moldova, which is, since November 2014, in the deep and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA). The EU is Moldova's largest trading partner, with 46.4% of trade, and trade with Moldova accounts for 0.1% of the Union's total trade. I also appreciate that the anti-circumvention mechanism to be applied provides for the possibility of reintroducing the customs duty applicable to the most-favored-nation, given that imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova have exceeded a certain threshold, without justification as to their exact origin. I voted in favor of this report, welcoming and supporting the Commission's proposal to protect the Union market and its producers by temporarily suspending the tariff preferences in the EAEC-Moldova Association Agreement.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained. The EU-Moldova Association Agreement was signed in June 2014 and entered into provisional application in September of the same year. This regulation is nothing more than an ancillary measure which provides for the possibility of suspending the preferential duties granted to Moldova for a maximum period of six months in the event of excessive entry of products into the EU. The measure, in itself, is absolutely not problematic. Indeed, they are, in practice, safeguard clauses to protect our production system. My abstention vote, however, is justified for several reasons: our delegation does not share and opposes the association agreement with a country, Moldova, of traditional Russian influence; this undue interference in a geopolitical area not very similar to us is, moreover, devoid of commercial interest for our companies; there is no concrete risk for the Italian and Po Valley production and agricultural system given by Moldova; if the problem does exist, our delegation does not believe in the functioning of safeguard procedures which, when the facts prove, are almost always slow and not very functional to their intended purposes.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation implementing the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences contained in the association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova. The bilateral safeguard clause makes it possible to temporarily suspend the preferences granted to the Republic of Moldova in the event of an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing significant economic damage to the domestic industry of the European Union. This is done only under the obligation on the part of the Union to hold consultations with the Moldovan authorities before the imposition of a definitive safeguard measure. In line with the report, I believe that the Commission's proposal is to be welcomed, as it is necessary to integrate in Union law the necessary instruments for the application of temporary safeguard measures in the event of an increase in imports which economic damage to the Union market and its producers.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements.  The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Association Agreement, like most agreements, includes a bilateral safeguard clause, which triggers the suspension of the Agreement in the case of an unexpected and significant increase of imports and causing damage to the EU domestic industry. I voted in favour of this report as it provides reasonable amendments to the Commission proposal, namely the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism so that they can be easily implemented should such a need arise. The two mechanisms themselves are a good way of protecting the interests of our domestic industry.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement with Moldova, like most EU trade agreements, contains a bilateral safeguard clause.That is, through this instrument, preferences can be temporarily suspended in the event that their application would lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party.I voted in favor of the report also in the light of some positive elements contained in the text, such as the obligation for the Commission to present an annual report on the application, implementation and compliance with the regulation and the obligation of the Union to keepconsultations with the Moldovan authorities prior to the imposition of a definitive safeguard measure.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the Association Agreement with Moldova, which includes a bilateral safeguard clause. Thus, the preferences can be temporarily suspended in case their application may lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing financial loss to the import industry of the importing party (ie it is possible to either suspend further customs clearance or reintroduce tariff rate of the most favored state - MFN). In addition, the agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of re-establishing the "most-favored-nation" tariff rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without proper justification of their exact origin .

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We have discussed today the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part. I believe that the moves to strengthen the existing rules, aimed at ensuring both sides are positive and have a similar impact on the citizens of the EU, but also of Moldova, especially in the economic field. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences contained in the association agreement between the European Union and the European Community atomic energy and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other. These commercial protection instruments are indispensable to prevent infringements of the agreement. Specifically, through the bilateral safeguard clause, tariff preferences can be temporarily suspended in the event that their application would lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports, causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. In addition, the agreement also includes an "anti-circumvention" mechanism, which allows for the reintroduction of the customs duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of a valid justification as to their exact origin.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- A shrewd neighborhood policy is one that promotes the growth of neighboring countries without damaging their own development potential.The safeguard clauses to which this report refers are exactly that: a correct valve to avoid imbalances.It is from this point of view that I have evaluated this proposal and therefore voted in favor.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement introduces a preferential trade regime – the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA). The European Union is Moldova’s largest trading partner, while imports from Moldova increased by 20% following the entry into force of the DCFTA. The agreement includes a bilateral safeguard clause in Articles 165 to 169. This clause protects the Union’s industry against an excess of imported goods which could cause ‘serious injury’ to industry. This may result in the suspension of a further reduction in the rate of customs duty on the concerned product. Article 148 of the agreement allows for an ‘anti-circumvention mechanism’. This enables the reintroduction of the ‘most-favoured-nation’ customs duty rate when imports from Moldova are in excess of a certain threshold without justification of their origin. This clause is crucial to avoid the Union importing non-Moldovan products via Moldova. Safeguard measures and anti-circumvention mechanism cannot be applied in unison to the same product.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova introduces a regime of trade preferences, the Comprehensive and Deepened Free Trade Area.The Agreement includes the so-called "anti-circumvention mechanism", which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the Most Favored Nation customs duty rate whenever imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain limit without due justification for their origin.exact.The establishment of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is indispensable in order to establish, in EU internal legislation, the necessary instrument to be able to apply this bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism.I support the Scholz Report, which is precisely implementing the provisions of the Association Agreement between the EU and Moldova, protecting EU producers if necessary.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements.  The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I have decided to vote in favor of the proposed regulation because the latter is able to provide the necessary tools to intervene to protect European producers when attempts to circumvent occur and will also allow the bilateral safeguard clause to be applied.These elements are necessary because, when creating in-depth free trade areas as in the case in question between the EU and Moldova, it is necessary to take into consideration possible problems that could emerge to the detriment of European producers, which can be answered with the guarantee of use.established commercial instruments such as the aforementioned safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In November 2013 Parliament voted in favour of an EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The current report seeks the suspension of a previously-contracted agreement with Moldova so as to align both agreements. It is important that the EU’s relationship with Moldova is founded on clear rules and structures. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Like most of our trade agreements, the association agreement with Moldova contains a bilateral safeguard clause. Through this instrument, preferences can be temporarily suspended in the event that their application should lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. In addition, the agreement also includes an "anti-circumvention" mechanism, which allows for the reintroduction of the MFN customs duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin. . The proposal applies the provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement which Parliament approved on 13 November 2014. Among the positive elements: the obligation for the Commission to submit an annual report on the application, implementation and compliance of the Regulation and the obligation of the Union to hold consultations with the Moldovan authorities before the imposition of a definitive safeguard measure. This aspect was the subject of negotiation and agreement between the EU and Moldova and is reflected in Article 160 of the Association Agreement. My vote is in favor.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report because the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism in this type of trade agreement is a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU, where appropriate. This report deals with the application of the safeguard and anti-circumvention clauses included in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova, as well as the obligation of the European Commission to report. The Commission must present a report to the European Parliament in the event that it tries to activate the necessary mechanisms to protect the European industry and consumers from bad commercial practices that could harm their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement in order to be able to reinstate customs with the aim of protecting the European economy. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - A Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to introduce into EU internal legislation the necessary instrument for the application of the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism. The Association Agreement with Moldova contains a bilateral safeguard clause. This instrument may temporarily suspend trade preferences in case their application would lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports, which would cause material economic injury to the domestic industry of the importing Party. Furthermore, this agreement is called It also contains an anti-circumvention mechanism which provides for the possibility of restoring the most-favored-nation duty if imports of certain agricultural products originating in Moldova exceed a certain threshold and do not provide adequate justification for their exact origin. In other words, the proposed regulation is necessary in order to protect EU producers where appropriate. I therefore voted in favor of the Commission's proposal.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement with Moldova of June 2014 includes a bilateral safeguard clause.The layout includes, among othersthe so-calledan anti-circumvention mechanism that allows the reintroduction of the most-favored-nation duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products, vegetables and drinks from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without duly substantiating their exact origin.A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to bring the necessary instrument into the EU internal legal order for the application of this bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism.Bearing in mind the value of EU relations with Moldova, I voted in favor of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that establishes safeguard measures for European trade with the Republic of Moldova.  Specifically, this report spells out safeguard measures in the case that a product originating in the Republic of Moldova is, as a result of the reduction or the elimination of the customs duties on that product, imported into the Union in such increased quantities that it could threaten to cause serious harm to the Union’s industry. Furthermore, anti-circumvention clauses are important to avoid imports into the Union of non-Moldovan products via Moldova using the advantages of the Agreement to circumvent ‘rules of origin’ requirements.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this temporary suspension of tariff preferences under the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. It is important that tariff preferences under an association agreement only benefit the country with which the EU signed the deal. The Association Agreement with Moldova signed in June 2014 includes an anti-circumvention mechanism designed to be used when necessary, and I welcome its implementation in this case to ensure Moldovan farmers continue to benefit from the free trade agreement signed with the EU.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - Since September 2014, after the conclusion of the Association Agreement, the European Union has become the largest trading partner of the Republic of Moldova: the significant intensification of trade has seen exports to the Union double or even triple for some products European. I am convinced that trade must continue to be an effective tool for supporting the profound process of structural reforms in Moldova, increasingly favoring the stabilization of the country, especially in the light of recent political developments. The proposal in question is largely based on regulations already adopted for free trade agreements with South Korea, Central America and Colombia / Peru and creates a valid safety net for the European industry and producers, protecting them in case they arise. particularly critical conditions for the European market. Furthermore, it has the merit of introducing the obligation for the Commission to submit an annual report to Parliament and the Council, guaranteeing adequate democratic control over the application of this regulation. That is why I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation implementing the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism which provides for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences contained in the association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This legislative report aims to implement the safeguard clause in the framework of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, allowing the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences granted to Moldova.This instrument, provided for in the Union's association agreements with third countries, aims to guarantee the interests of European companies when the preferences granted to third countries lead to a significant and unexpected increase in imports, to the detriment of European production.The suspension is scheduled for a maximum period of six months.Considering that the development aid policy for third countries of the European Union must not be carried out to the detriment of the interests of our economy, especially agriculture, I am in favor of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the integration into European Union law of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism provided for in the association agreement between the European Union and Moldova.It is indeed important to be able to temporarily suspend the application of preferences in the event that these would cause serious economic damage to European producers.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. - The association agreement with Moldova contains a bilateral safeguard clause. Through this instrument, trade preferences can be temporarily suspended in the event that their application would lead to an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. The agreement also includes an "anti-circumvention" mechanism, which allows the "Most Favored Nation" (MFN) customs duty rate to be reintroduced if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification. about their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed in order to introduce the necessary instrument to make the application of the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism possible in internal EU legislation. For this reason, I voted in favor of this measure.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova is an important instrument for strengthening trade ties, promoting respect for human rights and good governance in Moldova.As such, it should be seen as an opportunity for Moldovans and Europeans.The trade component of this agreement must be beneficial for the economies of both parties but also include safety nets for products deemed to be sensitive.This is why the establishment of the "anti-circumvention" mechanism will make it possible to suspend as far as necessary the tariff preferences on certain agricultural products in the event of an unjustified increase in imports from Moldova.In particular, it makes it possible to avoid fraud on rules of origin such as the transit of products from neighboring countries through Moldova to benefit from European preferences.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a regulation on the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences provided for in the association agreement between the European Union and the European Community of atomic energy and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other hand. This proposal for a regulation aims to create the legal instrument allowing the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism provided for in the agreement already concluded with Moldova. As regards safeguard measures, these could only be adopted if the product in question is imported into the Union in such increased quantities and under conditions such as to cause or threaten to cause serious injury to producers in the EU. Union manufacturing similar or directly competitive products. For the anti-circumvention mechanism, the proposed regulation provides for the possibility of suspending preferential tariffs for a period of up to six months when imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products reach the annual import volumes defined in the agreement. Implementing powers are conferred on the Commission in order to be able to guarantee uniformity of the conditions for adopting safeguard measures.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- The amended text does not improve the functioning of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.These devices do not apply when a national branch is affected, but only to protect the European branch.Aligning tariffs with the most favored country will not solve the problem of excessive imports.Likewise, the customs duty provided for by the anti-circumvention clause is not a sufficient solution.This is why I abstained on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
