text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clause and the mechanism for preventing circumvention of measures providing for the suspension of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Community on nuclear energy and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part. The agreement introduces a preferential trade regime - a deep and comprehensive free trade area (FTA). In 2014, following the entry into force of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement, Union imports from Moldova increased by 20%, while imports of agricultural goods increased particularly significantly, rising by 30%. Agricultural products represent a significant share of the Union's total imports from Moldova. The Union's main exports to Moldova are spirits, food and cigarettes. The reason for supporting the proposal is that the safeguard measure is imposed when, as a result of the reduction or elimination of customs duties on a product originating in the Republic of Moldova, imports of this product into the Union take place in such increased quantities as absolute value or the Union industry that it is causing or threatening to cause "serious injury" to the Union industry.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- The proposal for a regulation concerns the implementation of the anti - circumvention mechanism which provides for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Moldova, of the other part.It is proposed to vote in favor of the proposal as the implementation of the above mechanism achieves the protection of the financial interests of agricultural producers in the Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing.- The proposed rules allow for the temporary suspension of the preferences provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova would jeopardize and harm the EU's internal market.The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to ensure the practical application of the so-called anti-circumvention procedure provided for in the Association Agreement.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Association Agreement with Moldova, like most of our trade agreements, includes a bilateral safeguard clause.In addition, this agreement includes the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the 'Most Favored Nation' customs duty rate whenever imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without due justification for their origin.exact.This Commission proposal is largely based on comparable implementing regulations, which have been discussed among and co-legislated by the co-legislators under several recent EU free trade agreements currently in force.The approval of the proposed regulation is necessary to make Moldova fulfill its obligations under the Agreement and, consequently, to protect EU producers, if necessary.I voted in favor.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this report because these circumvention measures have no real impact and are ineffective.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Association Agreement with Moldova includes a bilateral safeguard clause. Through this instrument, preferences can be temporarily suspended if their application results in an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic losses. In addition, this agreement also includes the so-called "anti-circumvention" mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the 'most favored nation' customs duty rate, whenever imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without due justification of its exact origin. The Agreement - which we condemn and against which we were - introduces a regime of trade preferences, the Comprehensive and Deepened Free Trade Area (ZCLAA). Moldova's main exports to the European Union are oilseeds, fresh and dried nuts, apple juice, wines and cereals. The EU's main exports to Moldova are spirits, food preparations, cigarettes, some fruit and vegetables, including citrus fruit, pork and animal feed. This clause and mechanism does not alter the nature of this agreement, which we reject. They can, in certain circumstances, only mitigate some of its most damaging consequences.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it would be good for citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing - This report concerns the incorporation of a safeguard and anti-circumvention clause, as provided for in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova.This means that no new fundamental conditions can be introduced during the legislative process, which was not approved during the negotiations on the Association Agreement with Moldova.A safeguard measure may be imposed where a product originating in Moldova is imported into the European Union in such increased quantities as to result in a reduction or elimination of customs duties that it could cause material injury to the industry.The association agreement also includes the so-calledan anti-circumvention clause providing for the possibility of imposing customs duties if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain authorized threshold, without proper justification for their exact origin.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstain because I consider it an agreement without any commercial interest for our companies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of this proposal as the implementation of the above mechanism achieves the protection of the financial interests of the agricultural producers of the Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file concerns the incorporation in EU law of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The legislation can lay down the rules to be followed during the procedure and how decisions under the mechanism are to be taken. A safeguard measure may be imposed where a product originating in Moldova is, as a result of the reduction or the elimination of customs duties, imported into the Union in such increased quantities as to cause harm to the Union industry. So far, no bilateral safeguard measure has been taken under the EU’s trade agreements. A safeguard measure may take the form of a suspension of a further reduction of the tariff rate, an increase in the rate of the customs duty (following the ‘lesser duty rule’). A safeguard measure must be limited for such a period of time as is necessary to prevent or remedy the serious injury to Union industry. The Association Agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to introduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed legislation allows the benefits provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be temporarily suspended in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova threatens to damage the EU internal market. The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to apply in practice the so-called anti-circumvention procedure laid down in the Association Agreement.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova, like most of our trade agreements, contains a bilateral safeguards guarantee. With this instrument, trade preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase in imports, thereby causing significant economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing Party (i.e. it is possible to either suspend further customs liberalisation or reinstate the most-reduced duty rate). Furthermore, this Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides that it is possible to reinstate the most-reduced duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products originating in Moldova exceed a certain limit and do not give adequate justification for their exact origin. I am convinced that a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is necessary in order to introduce into EU internal legislation the necessary instrument for the application of the bilateral safeguards and the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, which has the main objective of establishing safeguard measures and anti-avoidance mechanisms under the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, which has been provisionally implemented since 1 September 2014. Through this instrument, preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application can cause a significant and unexpected increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing Party. In addition, this Agreement also includes a mechanism called an anti-avoidance mechanism, which provides the possibility of reintroducing MFN customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position on a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova , on the other hand, because I believe that it is important to have measures in place that can safeguard the European economy in the event of extraordinary circumstances. Indeed, I agree with the need to have a safeguard clause allowing trade preferences to be suspended in the event of an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to European industry. I also think it would be appropriate to provide for an anti-circumvention mechanism that could be triggered in the event of imports beyond the threshold that is not validly justified, measures that have already been discussed in the trade agreement, which need to be simply transposed into the regulation. The provision of regular reports by the European Commission on the effects of this regulation, which allows Parliament to exercise the necessary democratic control on behalf of european citizens, is also a good thing. Finally, the substantial agreement with the Council will speed up the entry into force of the regulation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the EU-Republic of Moldova Association Agreement: safeguard clause and procedures to combat circumvention practices, as I consider a further rapprochement and intensive partnership with this EU neighbour to be geopolitically sensible and important.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Both sides will benefit from the development of economic and trade relations. This will incentivise companies to make further investments. Combating opaque circumvention practices is an important element in this.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which includes a bilateral safeguard clause to accompany the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) embedded in the Association Agreement with Moldova. Safeguard clauses are legal instruments to protect European industry by providing a mechanism to take action against a surge in imports which distort the EU market due to the reduction or elimination of tariffs under a preferential trade agreement.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Moldova Partnership Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry. - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal for the application of the safeguard clause and counter-circumvention mechanism vis-à-vis the Republic of Moldova plays a very important role in the Commission's trade policy. The Association Agreement with Moldova protects the European Union's industry without exposing it to economic losses. The Republic of Moldova, which is not a member of the European Union, should supply agricultural products, vegetables and beverages without exceeding certain thresholds, as well as duly justifying the exact origin of those products.  I fully support the above-mentioned proposal from the European Parliament and the Council, and I support the Commission's obligation to report on the application and implementation of the Regulation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Association Agreement with Moldova, like the majority of our trade agreements, includes a bilateral safeguard clause. By this instrument preferences can be temporarily suspended in case their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase of imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party (i.e. it is possible to either suspend the further tariff liberalization or reintroduce the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate). Furthermore, this agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed legislation allows the benefits provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be temporarily suspended in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova would jeopardise or damage the EU internal market. The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to make the so-called anti-circumvention procedure laid down in the Association Agreement applicable in practice.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report implements provisions adopted under the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. It essentially concerns safeguard clauses for the introduction of measures when the import of certain products reaches a level at which it is considered that producers in the EU may be affected or when there is no proper justification for their exact origin (circumvention mechanism). Despite our disagreement with the content of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement we voted in favour of the report since safeguard clauses and the circumvention mechanism are important tools.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. The Association Agreement concluded by the EU and the Republic of Moldova in November 2014 has increased tensions in the region. Russia has declared an import freeze on products from Moldova in response. By introducing autonomous trade preferences and the introduction of the safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism in the Association Agreement for the Republic of Moldova, Europe wants to limit the impact on the agricultural sector.  However, this is not a question of aid, but rather a retaliatory action against Russia. The intensification of trade relations with Moldova and thus the increase in European influence on the region has major geopolitical consequences. It will further increase tension between the European Union and Russia. International security, human rights and democracy are at all times more important than short-sighted trade policy. That is why, in November 2014, I voted against the Association Treaty, in December 2014 against the introduction of autonomous trade preferences and now against the safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism in the Association Agreement for the Republic of Moldova.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I support the rapporteur’s approach and the aim to reach a quick first-reading agreement with the Council.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures, which allows for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other (COM(2015)0154 - C8-0092/2015-2015/0079 (COD)) - in the ordinary legislative procedure, first reading. The Agreement includes a 'mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures' allowing the reintroduction of the duty rate, in cases where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from the Republic of Moldova exceed the established threshold without a valid justification or without a valid correct origin. The inclusion of the avoidance clause is important to prevent imports in the EU of non-dairy products through the Republic of Moldova, taking advantage of the provisions of the Agreement.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU-Moldova Association Agreement has an anti-circumvention mechanism and a safeguard clause. Thus, if there is an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious harm to the European industry, the clause allows for the suspension of any further reduction in tariffs on the product concerned or their replacement by the customs duties of the most favoured nation. It is quite positive that such a reserve exists in the area of free trade. However, the most favoured nation clause is not an important protection. Moreover, we find that this provision, more cosmetic than practical, is never used. To vote in favour of this text would be to accredit a protection policy that is too minimalist. So I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Helmut Scholz's report on the proposed regulation on the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The safeguard clause allows for the temporary suspension of trade preferences if a significant increase in imports causes damage to European industry. This text is necessary for the implementation of the clauses contained in the Union's Association Agreement with Moldova, which I supported. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which validates the proposal to create two protection mechanisms within the framework of the association agreement signed between the Union and Moldova. These mechanisms will stop preferential clauses signed with Moldova in cases where the importation of Moldovan products would endanger a European production chain.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The protection of Austrian agriculture is my top priority. At the same time, I see major problems with an agreement with Moldova in terms of food standards and farming methods. However, Moldova's low degree of industrialisation means that there are currently development opportunities primarily in agriculture. On the basis of these considerations, I am abstaining on this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report and the two amendments adopted in the INTA Committee, which aim to bring the wording of the Regulation into line with the wording of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. I believe that the adoption of the proposed regulation is necessary to enforce the obligations of Moldova stemming from the Agreement in order to protect EU producers. This instrument ensures that preferences can be temporarily suspended in a case where their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase of imports causing economic damage to EU domestic industry. I believe that this implementing regulation is required to put the necessary instrument in place in the EU’s internal legislation in order to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism present in the Moldova Association Agreement in order to ensure the protection of EU producers.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is simply incorporation in EU law of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguards and the anti-circumvention mechanism contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union, the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part. The proposed legislation allows the benefits provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be temporarily suspended in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova would jeopardise the EU internal market. The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to apply in practice the so-called anti-circumvention procedure laid down in the Association Agreement.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union is Moldova’s biggest trade partner. It is then essential, to have a European trade agreement with this country. I voted in favour of this resolution, in order to safeguard our mutual clauses and harmonise this process. For example, to consult the Moldovan authorities before each definitive imposition of the safeguard clause.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In addition to the association agreement with Georgia, we have today voted on the association agreement with Moldova. It contains both an anti-circumvention mechanism, as in the previous one, and a bilateral safeguard clause. In addition, the proposal provides for an obligation on the part of the Commission to publish an annual report on the application and compliance with the regulation, allowing parliamentary monitoring of the implementation of the common commercial policy by the Commission.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the safeguard clause and the anti-touring mechanism under the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The amended text brings almost nothing on the substance to the safeguard clause and the anti-touring mechanism of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. These clauses are very unprotective as they are written. These clauses apply when the European branch is affected and not any national branch. The changes made are very minor and do not improve the text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it does not bring anything interesting to the association agreement.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2014, the European Parliament supported the EU-Moldova Association Agreement establishing a wide-lying free trade area between the two territories. This agreement includes a bilateral safeguard clause, where means that preferences may be temporarily suspended in the event that their application results in a significant increase in imports and imports, in turn, cause economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. On the other hand, in the event that certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without their origin being duly justified, the anti-avoidance mechanism offers the possibility of reintroducing the rates of customs duties of MFN (most-favoured nation) so as not to result in abuse. I consider the adoption of this report relevant, as it is necessary to have a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council which serves as an internal EU legislative instrument in order to implement the safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The EU-Moldovan Association Agreement, as well as in most EU trade agreements, is also set out in a bilateral safeguard clause. A safeguard may be imposed if a product originating in the Republic of Moldova, due to the reduction or elimination of tariffs on that product, is imported into the Union in such increased quantities that it causes or could cause significant harm to the Union industry.  The Agreement also includes a so-called 'mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures', which allows for the reintroduction of the customs rate set out in the principle of the most advantaged nation. I supported MEP Helmut Scholz's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a safeguard clause and mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures allowing preferential customs treatment to be temporarily suspended.  Instruments necessary for the application of temporary safeguards should be included in the event of an increase in imports in order to prevent economic damage to the Union market and its producers.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This vote in no way relates to the temporary suspension of certain tariff preferences in respect of the Republic of Moldova, which is simply an addition of specificity within the framework of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, which has already become a standard addition to this type of documents. The Commission's proposal was accompanied, by the way, by the need to organise consultations with Moldovan representatives before any suspension, which should take place within 30 days. If no compromise is reached during this period, only then will the Commission be able to implement any temporary suspension of tariff preferences. Since this vote concerns perfectly logical specific amendments, rather than temporarily withdrawing Moldova's trade preferences, there was no reason to vote against.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I agree with the introduction of safeguards in a bilateral agreement with Moldova aimed at protecting the Union's agricultural market from excessive or illegal imports of agricultural products from Moldova. Measures in the form of a safeguard clause and an anti-circumvention mechanism should avoid harming the interests of the agricultural market in the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova , on the other hand, because it is not complete.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This safeguard clause and anti-touring mechanism are an integral part of the CURRENT EU-Moldova Association Agreement. This clause allows for a suspension of any further reductions in the tariffs of a product in the event of an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious harm to the European industry. As for the anti-competition mechanism, it allows, when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products exceeds a certain stage with doubts about their origins, to replace the preferential tariff with the tariff of the most favoured nation. This amended text brings absolutely nothing on the substance to this safeguard clause or to the anti-touring mechanism. This text therefore has no interest and that is why we prefer abstention.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Association Agreement with Moldova, like the majority of our trade agreements, includes a bilateral safeguard clause. By this instrument preferences can be temporarily suspended in case their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase of imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party (i.e. it is possible to either suspend the further tariff liberalization or reintroduce the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate). Furthermore, this agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the EU-Republic of Moldova Association Agreement on safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism. This Agreement includes a mechanism known as 'anti-circumvention', which allows the 'most-favoured nation' (MFN) customs duty rate to be reinstated if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that the EU tightens trade relations with its neighbours, but we cannot put our economy at risk. Liberalising tariffs, while maintaining bilateral safeguards, together with an anti-circumvention mechanism, is the safest way. I expressed my support for this agreement because I believe it can be a vehicle for development for both parties.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. On 27 June 2014, following a five-year negotiation process, the European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed an association agreement. The latter has been applied provisionally since then but remains incomplete on two essential points: the anti-tour mechanism and the safeguard clause. Anti-competition instruments allow for the temporary suspension of preferential duties for certain products under the agreement when maximum import volumes are reached. More protective, the safeguard clauses allow trade preferences to be suspended if it is imported into the EU in quantities so great that they cause or threaten to cause serious injury to EU producers producing similar products. It is to endorse the introduction of these two schemes that the European Parliament has been consulted. Without commenting on the political and strategic merits of an association agreement with Moldova, whose political landscape is torn apart, I supported the introduction of such instruments, already present in a number of agreements concluded by the Union, in order to preserve the balance of the European market. More broadly, however, I regret that the Commission only uses the safeguard measures in trade agreements in a very parsimonious way.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal is intended to protect the domestic economy, but such association agreements are critical, as there is often a fear of further centralisation to Brussels and the disempowerment of nation states. I therefore abstain from voting

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation providing for measures and conditions for the suspension of the preferential tariff in the context of the implementation of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The inclusion in EU law of the provisions on the suspension of preferential tariffs is important in order to protect the EU market and producers when imports so much increase that it becomes detrimental to the European economy. The conditions for combating circumvention are also important in order to prevent imports into EU countries of products originating in non-Moldova through Moldova from benefiting from the benefits of this Agreement in order to avoid the requirements of the rules of origin.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Union has had an association agreement with Moldova for almost two years. For what results? Economic destabilization of the country, particularly in its trade relations with Russia and its Customs Union, reinforced by neoliberal measures demanded by the Union and the IMF. On 21 January, the Moldovan population was demonstrating against the umpteenth pro-European government, an oligarchy that manages to mysteriously wipe out 15% of GDP without the Union, supposedly concerned about the fight against corruption, finding something to say. The regulation put to the vote is supposed to protect the EU industry (or Moldova) in the event of a large and unsured increase in imports causing "serious damage". A means of overcoming the free trade agreement which, in fact, can never be invoked, apart from its complexity, because both sides must agree to any reintroduction of tariffs. Neoliberal policies, the enlargement of the Union and the economic annexation of its neighbourhood, support for corrupt elites, escalation of tensions against Russia: all reasons to vote against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU-Moldova Association Agreement has an anti-tour mechanism and a safeguard clause. If there is an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious harm to the European industry, the clause thus allows for the suspension of any further reduction in tariffs on the product concerned or their replacement by the tariff of the most favoured nation. I think it is good that there is such a reservation about free trade. The most favoured nation clause is not, however, an important protection. Moreover, I note that this provision is ultimately never used. I would not like to endorse an overly minimalist protection policy by voting on this text. So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clause and the circumvention mechanism which provide for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other. The safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism are common in most trade agreements and the amendments to the Commission proposal are intended only to clarify the terms of the procedure, in particular as regards relations between the European institutions and national authorities.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which is important to protect the Union’s market and its producers. In case of an increase in imports, the amendments outline the instruments necessary to place temporary safeguards to protect the economy of the Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The introduction of safeguard measures is a mandatory step to protect our companies from possible abuses and to prevent any negative repercussions on the European market. The safeguard clause in this report allows for the temporary suspension of the application of tariff preferences in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement in the event that, following the removal of tariff barriers, certain products from Moldova are imported to the EU in excessive quantities, thereby causing economic harm to European producers. On the other hand, the anti-circumvention mechanism is important to prevent imports into the Union of non-Moldovan products via Moldova, thus taking advantage of the benefits derived from the agreement, from circumventing the obligations of rules of origin. This mechanism allows the reintroduction of the MFN rate when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified. This mechanism therefore leads to an obligation of transparency in terms of rules of origin when the volume of imports is high, thus protecting European companies from possible abuses.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Republic of Moldova and the European Union agreed during the joint negotiations on the safeguard measures referred to in Article 9 of the resolution, so it was a logical step to adopt their legislative text. The adoption of the amendments to the resolution in question is also important because they bring the regulation into line with the wording of the Association Agreement with Moldova. In addition, it also contributes to clarifying and unifying terminology, which in legal acts is an essential precondition for the possibility of complying with agreements in the way intended in advance. The anti-circumvention mechanism included in the agreement serves to protect the European economy. I consider all these measures to be logical and appropriate, which is why I support the draft legislative resolution.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement: temporary suspension of tariff preferences, as this report concerns the incorporation into EU law of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. This means that no fundamentally new conditions can be introduced during the legislative procedure which have not already been agreed during the negotiations on the Association Agreement with Moldova.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Moldova Association Agreement signed in June 2014 and provisionally applied as of September 2014 includes a Bilateral Safeguard Clause, as is the case for the majority of EU trade agreements. The clause allows both Parties (therefore also Moldova) to temporarily suspend preferences in case their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase of imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. The Agreement also foresees an Anti-Circumvention Mechanism which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. We voted today on the implementing regulation which simply incorporates the two mechanisms into EU law in order to make them applicable in the EU. Therefore the provisions related to the two instruments as agreed by the parties in the agreement have not been modified.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova contains a bilateral safeguards guarantee under which trade preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase in imports resulting in significant economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing Party. The agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, according to which it is possible to reintroduction of the most-reduced duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products originating in Moldova exceed a certain limit and do not provide adequate justification for their exact origin. However, in order to introduce into EU internal legislation the necessary instrument for the application of the bilateral safeguards and the anti-circumvention mechanism, a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed. This is what the Commission has proposed. In its report, the Committee on International Trade points out that the proposed Regulation will put into practice the provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to which the European Parliament agreed on 13 November 2014. Its adoption is necessary in order to enforce Moldova's obligations under the Agreement in order to protect Union producers where appropriate. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova includes a bilateral safeguard clause, according to which preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application results in an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic import ing industry, and the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which stems from the possibility of reintroducing the rate of the 'Most Favoured Nation' customs duty where imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain without the due justification of its exact origin. In order to be able to apply this bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism, it is necessary to establish in EUROPEAN Union legislation the establishment of a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council. I endorse the rapporteur's position that the adoption of the proposal for a regulation is necessary to make Moldova comply with the obligations under the Agreement and, consequently, to protect EU producers if necessary.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova on the other. This text contains a safeguard clause which allows for the suspension of any further reductions in tariffs on the product concerned or their replacement by the tariff of the most favoured nation if there is an unforeseen and significant increase in imports with serious harm to the European industry. However, these clauses, as drafted, are very unprotective and the amendments make little change the substance. So I decided to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova. The agreement provides for restrictive measures in the event of importation of products in quantities such as they cause or threaten to cause damage to EU producers producing similar or directly competing products. I have approved this text which aims to protect the European economy and jobs.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism in the framework of EU-Moldova cooperation are intended to protect European industry in the event of a massive increase in imports to Moldova. This measure, necessary to ensure the safety of European producers, had to be supported. So I voted in favour of the report.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU-Republic of Moldova Association Agreement. The regulation contains both an anti-circumvention mechanism and a bilateral safeguard clause. In addition, the proposal provides for an obligation on the part of the Commission to publish an annual report on the application and compliance with the regulation, allowing parliamentary monitoring of the implementation of the common commercial policy by the Commission.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement is largely based on comparable implementing regulations like EU/Korea, EU/Central America, EU/ Colombia and Peru. I have voted for this report that spells-out the obligation of the EU to consult with the Moldovan authorities before implementing such a definitive safeguard measure, and that will harmonise the terminology of the Commission proposal with the Association Agreement.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Statistics show that in 2014, following the entry into force of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement, imports into the Union from Moldova increased by 20%, while imports of agricultural goods increased significantly, with a 30% increase. Agricultural products represent a major share of the Union's total imports from Moldova.  The products of Moldovan agriculture, which is a traditional livelihood, are also in the regions of the republic, inhabited by ethnic Bulgarians and citizens with Bulgarian self-awareness, are known for their good quality.  For these reasons, I supported this proposal on the application of a safeguard clause within the framework of the Association Agreement between Moldova and the EU. I also believe that such mechanisms provide protection for both European producers in the event of abuse of the preferential regime and for local producers. By such a mechanism, they are also protected in the event of artificially created competition through regulated imports from third countries.  I support the policy of good trade relations between the European Union and its direct neighbours, but I also believe that this should be done without jeopardisation of the livelihoods of European farmers.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I vote to support the two proposed amendments to the Commission’s proposal of introducing a new regulation in the EU’s trade Agreement with the Republic of Moldova.  The European Parliament’s proposed amendments should ensure that the safeguard clause and an anti-circumvention mechanism proposed by the Commission are in line with the Association Agreement between the EU and Moldova signed on 24 June 2014. More precisely, this implies that prior to any introduction of the safeguard clause it is required of the EU to deliberate the matter with the appropriate Moldovan authorities.  Further, the amendments address the need for the Commission to draft the regulation in a language corresponding to the Association Agreement and to include, in the regulation, a paragraph explicitly concerning the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. Although the agreement would also protect domestic agriculture up to a certain point by reaching certain quantities of imports, I am generally opposed to such association agreements.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The adoption of the proposed Regulation is necessary in order to give effect to the obligations under the Moldova Agreement and, where appropriate, to protect European Union producers.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I consider trade agreements between the EU and third parties to be positive, I believe that the safeguard clause included in the agreement with Moldova, as is customary in trade agreements concluded by the EU, is necessary so that the preferences granted respectively do not alter the competition rules to the detriment of domestic industry. Similarly, I believe that the anti-circumvention mechanism aimed at preventing the import into the Union of non-Moldovan products through Moldova is fundamental. I therefore say that I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a safeguard clause and mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures, which allow for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other.  I believe that the European Union must take care of its own producers and their interests in the first and foremost. The implementation of the safeguard clause and the mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures will ensure the position of European and Croatian producers, in case Moldova starts unexpectedly delivering products in quantities higher than agreed. Special attention must be paid to farmers who are most at risk as far as products from Moldova are concerned. Indeed, agricultural exports account for a large part of Moldova's exports to the EU, which is why it is necessary to take appropriate measures so as not to flood the market with products of questionable quality.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I welcome and support the Commission's proposal, as union law requires the use of temporary safeguards in the event of an increase in imports that would cause economic damage to the Union market and its producers. A safeguard clause and mechanism should be incorporated into EU law to prevent the avoidance of measures provided for in the Moldovan Association Agreement. I agree that the safeguard must be limited in time for the period necessary to prevent significant damage to the Union industry. I hope it will have a positive impact on EU-Moldova trade, as the EU is Moldova's largest trading partner with which it generates 46.4% of its trade.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Association Agreement with Moldova includes a bilateral safeguard clause whereby preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application results in an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage. It also includes the so-called 'anti-circumvention' mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the 'most favoured nation' customs duty rate. The Agreement – which we condemn and against which we have been – introduces a regime of trade preferences, the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAD). This clause and this mechanism do not alter the nature of this agreement, which we reject and may only, in limited circumstances, mitigate some of its most harmful consequences.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support colleague Helmut Scholz's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a safeguard clause and mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures, which allow for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other. The agreement was signed on 24 June 2014 and provisionally applies from 1 September 2014.  The European Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of this Agreement on 13 November 2014. The agreement introduces a preferential trade regime - a detailed and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA). Trade with Moldova accounts for 0.1 % of total Union trade, and after the entry into force of the IDM in 2014, imports from Moldova to the Union increased by 20%, in particular imports of agricultural products (30%).  The existing instrument may temporarily suspend preferential customs treatment in the event that the use of such treatment would result in an unexpected and significant increase in imports, the resulting in damage to EU domestic industry. The adoption of the proposal is necessary so that Moldova's obligations stemming from the Agreement can be implemented to protect EU producers, if necessary.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of a bilateral safeguard clause to the Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova will allow both parties to temporarily suspend tariff preferences in the event of a significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic sector of the importing Party. This clause will, for example, help to protect the European market from a high increase in imports of certain agricultural products without a clear justification for its origin. The agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which is a guarantee for the protection of the EU market, but it is worth remembering that, in practice, the EU has never had to apply this type of clause before.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, following the entry into force of the Free Trade Agreement, Union imports from Moldova increased by 20%, while imports of agricultural products increased significantly, an increase of 30%. In view of the unjustified increase in imports from Moldova, which could cause economic damage to the EU market and its producers, I voted in favour of this report. The latter provides for the temporary suspension, for two years, of two more in exceptional cases, of the tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part. The Commission's proposal also provides for an anti-circumvention mechanism, which restores the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova , signed in June 2014, includes a bilateral safeguard clause. With this instrument, preferences may be temporarily suspended in the event that their application leads to an unexpected and significant increase in imports, causing economic losses for EU industry. Furthermore, this agreement also takes into account the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which allows the reintroducing of the rate of duty applicable to the most favoured country where imports of certain agricultural products, vegetables and beverages from Moldova exceed a certain threshold, without duly justifying their exact origin. In order to introduce the necessary instrument into the EU's internal legal order so that this bilateral safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism can be applied, a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed. In particular, the report stresses the Commission's obligation to report, according to which the Commission submits to the co-rapporteurs and then publishes an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation. Reporting is important for parliamentary scrutiny of the Commission's implementation of the common commercial policy and for increasing its transparency. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support moldova's EU Association Agreement because it is a clear signal that Moldova wants to go to Europe and the EU, on the contrary, is willing to help it on this path. The 20% increase in Moldovan exports to the Union and even 30% in agricultural products demonstrates that the EU-Moldova free trade area has been established and is meeting its objective. However, I support today's legislation because we need to prevent any excesses in EU law. This will only strengthen the entire association structure.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this European Parliament's legislative resolution of 3 February 2016 on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-contourance mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand , and the Republic of Moldova, on the other hand. This Regulation should provide for the possibility of suspending preferential duties for up to six months when imports of certain agricultural and processed agricultural products reach defined annual import volumes.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The Association Agreement between the EU and Moldova - signed on 24 June 2014 and subject to parliamentary approval on 13 November 2014 - includes, like most other trade agreements, a bilateral safeguard clause. Under this clause, preferences may be temporarily suspended where, as a result of the reduction or elimination of customs duties, imports of products originating in Moldova increase significantly in terms which cause or athreat to cause serious injury to the Union industry. The Agreement also includes the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, under which the rate of the Most Favoured Nation customs duty may be reintroduced where imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain limit, without due justification as to their exact origin. The commission's proposal for a Regulation at issue here is precisely intended to implement those provisions of the Association Agreement and to this extent appears necessary to ensure moldova's fulfilment of the obligations under the Agreement and the consequent protection of EU producers. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. The vote was for a technical matter confirming a power of the Commission under an agreement that has been approved by the European Parliament. Because the Commission’s power in that regard would reapply WTO rules, we voted to abstain.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union (EU) and the Republic of Moldova, signed on 24 June 2014, introduces a trade preference sregime - the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTA). The Regulation has recently been amended to extend the duty-free exemption for Moldovan wine and to grant duty-free tariff quotas for apples, plums and table grapes. These amendments aim to harmonise the content of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement and I have so i voted in favour. The EU is Moldova's main trading partner, accounting for 46.4% of its trade, followed by Russia (21.9 %) ukraine (11.8 %). Trade with Moldova accounts for 0.1 % of the Union's overall trade. Agricultural products account for a significant proportion of all Union imports from Moldova. Moldova's main exports to the Union are oilseeds, fresh and dried nuts, apple juice, wines and cereals. On the other hand, the European Union's main exports to Moldova are spirits, food preparations, cigarettes, some fruits and vegetables, including citrus, pigmeat and feed.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this Parliament's Legislative Resolution which makes it possible for the relevant provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be implemented to which the European Parliament gave its approval on 13 November 2014. The proposed Regulation needs to be adopted to enable compliance with Moldova's obligations under the Agreement with a view to protecting EU producers, where appropriate. The Agreement includes a bilateral safeguard clause where means that preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application can cause a significant and unexpected increase in imports causing economic damage to the EU. In addition, it also includes an anti-avoidance mechanism, which provides the possibility of reintroducing customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova was signed on 24 June 2014 and has been on an interim basis since 1 September 2014. It establishes a preferential regime for trade in goods, creating a deep free trade area. Regulation (EC) 55/2008 of the Council establishes autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova and will continue to apply in parallel until 31 December 2015. As a reminder, Moldova's largest trading partner is the Union, with which 46.4% of its trade takes place, followed by Russia (21.9%) Ukraine (11.8%). Trade with Moldova accounts for 0.1% of the EU's total trade. In 2014, EU imports from the country increased by 20%, with imports of agricultural products rising by a particularly significant 30%. The latter account for a significant share of the EU's total imports from Moldova. Moldova's main exports to the EU are oilseeds, nuts, apple juice and cereals, while the EU exports mainly spirits, certain fruits and vegetables, such as citrus fruits, as well as pork and animal feed.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it provides, like most EU trade agreements, a bilateral safeguard clause. This measure allows for the suspension of the preferences in the event that their continued application would lead to an unexpected increase in imports, causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing country. Despite the fact that this is more of a technical change and the EU is Moldova's largest trading partner, accounting for 46.4%. The use of the moldovan trade, the mutual safeguard clause, is rather problematic, as it is difficult to prove and apply both substantive and procedural requirements.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union (EU) and the Republic of Moldova was signed in June 2014 and started to apply (provisionally) from September 2014. As the EU is Moldova's main trading partner, accounting for around 46.4 % of its trade, the establishment of a sound and fair regulation for both co-signatories is essential for the development of good trade relations between the parties. However, in order to ensure a swift, fair and effective functioning and the correct dissemination of the mutual benefits inherent in this agreement, it is important to introduce a bilateral safeguard clause, which should be applied where such exchanges cause or threat to cause "serious injury" to the Union's domestic industry. Because I believe that this report includes necessary measures and safeguarding European commercial interests, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The Association Agreement with Moldova, signed on 24 June 2014, has been on an interim basis since 1 September 2014. In particular, the agreement contains a bilateral safeguard clause that allows for the temporary suspension of the application of preferences in the event that they result in an unforeseen and significant increase in imports causing economic harm to the importing party's domestic industry.  It also provides for an "anti-circumvention mechanism", which allows the reintroduction of the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation (NPF) when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified.  I supported this report, which deals with the Commission's proposal for a regulation to create the legal instrument for the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-touring mechanism in the agreement already concluded with Moldova. In particular, the report adds that it is the European Union's responsibility to hold consultations with the Moldovan authorities before the imposition of a final safeguard measure and also asks the Commission to provide information on the safeguard clause in its annual report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the various trade agreements that the European Union maintains with other countries, there is also the one with Moldova. Like most European agreements, this also contains a safeguard clause that serves to protect our producers. In fact, the adoption of the proposal for a regulation will implement Moldova's obligations under the agreement itself. That is why we have approved the Commission's text, which also includes the possibility for the European legislative body to take an active part in the decision on the progress of the agreements with the country in question, and thus to be able to express its opinion on the application or otherwise of the safeguard clause, and to call on the Union to request consultations with the Moldovan authorities before definitively applying the clause. It is an agreement that aims at transparency without neglecting European interests.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain because, over and above the substance of the matter, I have some doubts about the current EU policy underlying these types of agreements.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Moldova Partnership Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement.  - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I welcome and support the Commission's proposal, as it is necessary to incorporate into eu law the instruments necessary for the application of the temporary safeguard measures in the event of an increase in imports causing economic damage to the EU market and its producers.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of amending the clause on preferential access to the EU internal market in the Association Agreement with Moldova, because this is a concrete commitment to the Association Agreement, which we as a Parliament already approved in November 2014. Preferential access for poor neighbouring countries is important, but it must not be at the expense of our own producers in the EU. I think we have reached a good compromise that will allow us to restrict preferential market access again if imports from Moldova increase too much.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the implementation of the anti-avoidance mechanism in such trade agreements is a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU, where appropriate. This report concerns the application of the safeguard and anti-avoidance clauses contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova, as well as the obligation to report by the European Commission. The Commission shall submit a report to the European Parliament in the event that it is in the case of activating the necessary mechanisms to protect European industry and consumers from bad business practices which may damage their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement so that customs can be reinstated in order to protect the European economy. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed in 2014 introduced a preferential trade regime that guarantees mutual free market access. Following the entry into force of the agreement, EU imports from Moldova increased by 20%, while imports of agricultural products increased by as much as 30%. For this reason, the report voted on today calls for the implementation of the safeguard clauses and the anti-circumvention mechanism provided for in the agreement. These measures shall be imposed where a product originating in Moldova is imported from the Union in such increased quantities as to cause serious injury to the Union industry, and provide for the suspension or reinstatement of the customs duty on the product concerned. The anti-circumvention mechanism also avoids the import into the Union of non-Moldovan products through Moldova by using the benefits of the agreement to circumvent the requirements of origin. I voted in favour of this report because it makes it possible to protect European agricultural producers from excessive imports of Moldovan products.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Volumes of imported agricultural products from Moldova have increased significantly in the past several years. The Commission wants to impose the safeguard clause and anti-circumvention mechanism as part of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Moldova, to protect the market share of EU agricultural producers from Moldovan products. These measures would reapply the World Trade Organisation’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) tariffs on Moldovan products entering the EU that cause or threaten to cause ‘serious injury’ to EU industry, or that breach ‘rules of origin’ requirements. The proposal is in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Moldova to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file means that the safeguard clause, as well as the anti-circumvention mechanism which was foreseen in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, is incorporated into EU Law. It will mean that no fundamentally new conditions which were not already in the agreement can be introduced during the legislative procedure. Although I do not suspect that it would be very likely to be exploited, safeguards are always important and should be applied to all trade agreements in order to protect European industries. Hence I am glad to see that the association agreement also includes an anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported a mutual protection clause that can be applied within the limits of free trade with the Republic of Moldova. Already today, the EU is Moldova's largest trading partner, with agricultural products representing a significant proportion of total imports. In order to protect the Union's internal market, it is necessary to retain the possibility of restricting imports of a particular product if, as a result of the reduction or elimination of the duty, its imports could cause serious injury to production in EU countries. Such a measure could be used for two years. The clause to the Agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which makes it possible to reintroduce the duty rate should the volume of imports of certain products from Moldova exceed a specified threshold without justifying their exact origin. In this way, the Union wants to prevent non-Mercenant products from being imported from Moldova into the EU. For these reasons, I share the view that these provisional safeguard measures are necessary in order to prevent economic damage on the Union market in the event of increased imports.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Most trade agreements with the EU include a bilateral safeguard clause allowing the suspension of preferences in the event that their application would lead to an unexpected and substantial increase in imports which could cause economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing Party (op. Moldova).  Simplified this means that further tariff liberalisation or the reintroducmical rate of customs duty for most favoured countries can be suspended. That instrument also contains an agreement between the EU and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part.  Moreover, this agreement also contains a anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the reintroduction of the customs duty to the most favoured countries if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without adequate justification for their exact origin. In order to actually introduce these instruments, it is necessary to adopt an EP and Council regulation in eu internal law.  The Commission proposal currently under consideration allows the relevant provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement approved by the EP in November 2015 to be implemented in practice. I believe that the adoption of the proposed regulation is necessary in order to implement Moldova's obligations under the agreement and that, if necessary, EU producers should be adequately protected. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Agreement significantly deepened Moldova's political association with economic integration in the European Union, which I support. However, a clause is needed to protect EU producers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Agreement introduces a preferential trade regime – a detailed and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA). Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 55/2008 On the imposition of autonomous trade preferences for Moldova, it was recently amended to include Mouscarin wine and to approve duty-free quotas for apples, plums and table grapes.  As in most EU trade agreements, the Agreement includes a bilateral safeguard clause, set out in Articles 165 to 169. A safeguard may be imposed where a product originating in the Republic of Moldova, due to the reduction or elimination of tariffs on that product imported into the Union in such increased quantities, in absolute terms or in relation to Union production, that it causes or could cause harm to the Union industry.  I therefore support the Commission's proposal to place in EU law the instruments necessary for the application of temporary safeguards in the event of an increase in imports that would cause economic damage to the Union market and its producers.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. Safeguard clauses are standard mechanisms in FTAs. They are an essential means of protecting European industry by providing a mechanism to take action against a surge of imports which distort the EU market due to the reduction or elimination of tariffs under a preferential trade agreement.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The report, at the proposal of the INTA Committee, contains two minor technical amendments to the bilateral agreement between the European Union and Moldova. Moldova already has a preferential trade relationship agreement with the EU, to which the EU is the largest trading partner with which it accounts for 46.4% of its trade. The main products imported from Moldova into the Union are oilseeds, fresh and dried walnuts, apple juice, wine and cereals. The main products exported by the Union to Moldova are spirits, foodstuffs, cigarettes, certain types of fruits and vegetables, including citrus fruits, pork and feed.  The Union aspires to be a good partner, but also takes care of the interests of its own economy. I support the report because it requires only minor amendments intended to harmonise texts. Moldova has an open path towards reforming and moving closer to the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the suspension of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part. Like other trade agreements concluded by the EU, we need a bilateral safeguard clause in the Association Agreement with Moldova. This will reduce any economic damage to domestic industry in the event of an unexpected and substantial increase in imports. I also welcome that the report's proposal foresees that the EU must consult the Moldovan authorities before the safeguard measure is finally put in place.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
