text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's report approving the proposal for an EP and Council regulation de facto implementing those provisions already concluded last year by the Association Agreement with Moldova, which make it possible to temporarily suspend the tariff preferences introduced by the Association Agreement in the event that unexpected and excessive supplies of goods from Moldova threaten the interests of EU producers. The possibility of this 'rescue brake' is therefore already provided for in the Association Agreement and the current Regulation only allows this instrument to be used in the exceptional situations described. I also supported the report on a similar matter concerning Georgia.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed Regulation, which will help to ensure that products that enter the EU benefit only the country concerned by the relevant trade agreement.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We disagree with the content of the EU Association Agreement with Moldova because it fully serves the intended benefits of the EU's dominant circles. It creates relations of interdependence - economic as well as political - with partners and promotes extreme competition for the benefit of large capital and at the expense of the interests of society and peoples.  However, we voted in favour of this report as it specifically refers to the safeguard clause, which can be imposed when a product originating in Moldova is imported into the Union in such increased quantities as to cause economic damage to the EU domestic industry.  The report also refers to the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of restoring the ICN duty rate when imports of agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without due justification of their exact origin. Circumvention clauses are important in order to avoid imports of non-Moldovan products into the Union through Moldova benefiting from the Agreement and circumventing the requirements of rules of origin.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The implementation of this mechanism achieves the protection of the financial interests of agricultural producers in the Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed legislation allows the benefits provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be temporarily suspended in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova threatens to damage the EU internal market. The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to apply in practice the so-called anti-circumvention procedure laid down in the Association Agreement.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the decision, given that the additional provisions contained there there are essential for the implementation of the Association Agreement and are essentially identical to the defence mechanisms used in trade agreements with other EU partners. Trade policy safeguards and solutions to prevent them from being circumvented are also capable of preventing other third parties from aving the benefits granted to Moldova. At the same time, I have considered the fact that Moldova is a key trading advantage partner for the EU, but at the same time agricultural products account for a significant part of its exports, and it is therefore necessary to avoid any damage to the interests of EU producers as a result of the Association Agreement.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. A european Parliament and Council regulation is needed to integrate these instruments into EU legislation and allow the application of the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-touring mechanism. The association agreement with Moldova, like the majority of our trade agreements, contains a bilateral safeguard clause. This instrument allows for the temporary suspension of the application of preferences in the event that they result in an unforeseen and significant increase in imports and cause economic harm to the importing party's domestic industry (in other words, it makes it possible either to suspend further tariff liberalization or to reintroduce the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation). In addition, the agreement provides for an "anti-tour mechanism" which allows the reintroduction of the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which implements the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed legislation allows the benefits provided for in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement to be temporarily suspended in the event that a significant increase in imports from Moldova threatens to damage the EU internal market. The adoption of the proposal is necessary in order to apply in practice the so-called anti-circumvention procedure laid down in the Association Agreement.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported the report for several important reasons. Trade with the EU accounts for 46.4% of Moldova's trade volume, making the EU the country's largest trading partner. Like most of the Union's trade agreements, this agreement includes a reciprocal safeguard clause. A safeguard measure may be imposed if the product originating in the Republic of Moldova is transported, after a reduction or withdrawal of the duty, in quantities which would cause serious loss or risk to the Union industry. The treaty also has a rebound mechanism for circumvention, which allows the reintroducing rate of duty if the transport of certain agricultural products goes beyond the contractual threshold. The notification adopted contributes to the protection of Union producers, in particular farmers. Such records need to be supported.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I supported a proposal allowing for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Moldova, on the other. Given the need to include in Union law the instruments necessary for the application of safeguards in the event of an increase in imports that would cause economic damage to the European Union market and its producers, I support the inclusion of a bilateral safeguard clause in the agreement.  I also believe that clauses on the mechanism for preventing the avoidance of measures are important in order to prevent the import of non-Moldovan products through that Country by taking advantage of the Agreement for the Avoidance of Requirements relating to rules of origin. I also consider it extremely positive to reintroduce the duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products exceed the threshold set without a valid justification of their exact origin.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the suspension of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Moldova, of the other part, as I believe that these are necessary instruments to regulate possible surpluses of imports or exports which could have a negative impact on the economy of the Member State or countries doing business with it. The proposal, which is of a more technical nature, will thus allow Moldova to start enforcing the obligations arising from the protection agreement already adopted.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Moldova Partnership Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry. - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The amended text provides almost nothing substantive to the safeguard and anti-tour clause of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. These clauses are very unprotective and the changes made are very minor and do not improve the text. I choose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova, like most of our trade agreements, contains a bilateral safeguards guarantee. With this instrument, trade preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase in imports, thereby causing significant economic injury to the domestic industry of the importing Party. The adoption of the proposed Regulation is necessary in order to enforce Moldova's obligations under the Agreement in order to protect UNION producers where appropriate. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Moldova Partnership Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry. - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the obligation to report on the Commission's proposal, according to which the Commission must submit an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation to the co-legislators and make it public.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, which concerns the incorporation in the European Union law of the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. The Association Agreement with Moldova, like the majority of EU trade agreements with third countries, includes a bilateral safeguard clause. By this instrument preferences can be temporarily suspended in case their application would result in an unexpected and significant increase of imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party (i.e. it is possible to either suspend the further tariff liberalization or reintroduce the MFN customs duty rate). Furthermore, this agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Moldova exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. An implementing regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is in this case necessary, in order to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The bilateral safeguard clause of this Agreement provides that tariff preferences may be suspended if their application is an unexpected increase in imports causing economic damage to European industry. This Regulation should be adopted for the protection of European producers if necessary. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The adoption of the safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism is necessary within the framework of the Association Agreement with Moldova in order to enforce certain obligations and, if necessary, to protect European producers or directly competing companies from a sudden increase in imports of a particular product which could cause them serious harm.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova includes a bilateral safeguard clause. Through this instrument, preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application results in an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic import ing industry. In addition, this agreement also includes the so-called "anti-circumvention" mechanism which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the rate of 'most favoured nation' customs duty where imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold without the appropriate justification of their exact origin. It is a question of the European Commission's mechanisms for triggering these two clauses.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal is intended to protect the domestic economy, but such association agreements are critical, as there is often a fear of further centralisation to Brussels and the disempowerment of nation states. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the EU-Moldova Association Agreement: the safeguard clause and the circumvention prevention mechanism. By the bilateral safeguard clause, preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application would result in an unforeseen and significant increase in imports, causing economic damage to the national industry of the importing country. This agreement also includes a so-called circumvention prevention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the level of customs duties applicable to the most favoured nation when imports of certain agricultural products exceed a certain threshold. The EU-Moldova Association Agreement was signed on 24 June 2014 and the EP approved the conclusion of the agreement on 13 November 2014. The agreement introduces a preferential trade regime - the complex and comprehensive free trade area, introducing autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. The EU is Moldova's largest trading partner, with 46.4% of trade. In 2014, imports into the Union from Moldova increased by 20 % and imports of agricultural goods increased particularly, increasing by 30 %. However, duty-free export quotas were used to a modest extent by Moldovan producers.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote in favour, Mr Scholz's proposal, which was approved by a large majority of the members of the Committee on International Trade.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like most trade agreements, this association agreement with Moldova contains a bilateral safeguard clause. Through this instrument, preferences may be temporarily suspended if their application causes an unexpected and significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing party. In addition, the agreement also includes a mechanism known as 'anti-circumvention', which allows the MFN customs duty rate to be reinstated if imports of certain agricultural products from Moldova exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin. The proposal applies the provisions of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement which Parliament approved on 13 November 2014. The adoption of the proposal for a regulation is necessary in order to implement Moldova's obligations under the agreement, in order to protect, where appropriate, EU producers. The positive elements to be noted are the obligation for the Commission to submit an annual report on the application, implementation and compliance with the regulation and the Union's obligation to hold consultations with the Moldovan authorities prior to the imposition of a definitive safeguard measure.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Moldova contains, like most European Union trade agreements, a bilateral protection clause as well as a circumvention mechanism. I support this report because, in order to implement the measures contained in the agreement, it is necessary to introduce into the internal EU legal order the necessary instrument in the form of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council. It is necessary to protect EU producers where necessary, and it is therefore necessary to adopt a regulation. I agree with the proposal on the Commission's obligation to submit reports that will contribute to the parliamentary scrutiny of trade policy by the European Commission.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the report on the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Association Trade Agreement with Moldova, which includes a bilateral safeguard clause which may be introduced where a product originating in the Republic of Moldova is imported into the Union in such increased quantities as a result of the reduction or elimination of customs duties on that product, in absolute terms or in relation to Union production, that it causes serious injury or poses a risk of serious injury to the Union industry. I support this measure, as it is necessary to include instruments in Union legislation to protect the Union market and producers on the market, where appropriate.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU's Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014.  Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, UKIP abstained.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement, signed on 27 June 2014, provides for the removal of non-tariff barriers, regulatory alignment and binding rules on investment and services. As already provided for in other agreements concluded with the Eastern Partnership, the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area is accompanied by the establishment of a safeguard clause and an anti-circumvention mechanism. Both instruments are generally required when, by exceeding the threshold of imports granted, it is considered that the internal market may be damaged. I voted in favour because, although I believe it is important to proceed with the progressive economic integration of the associated states, the protection of the internal market and its consumers is a priority.

name: Tim Aker and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the implementation of the anti-avoidance mechanism in this type of trade agreement proposes a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU where appropriate. This report introduces an obligation to report on the application of the anti-avoidance clause for implementation in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The Commission shall submit a report containing information on the application of that clause in order to protect European industry and consumers from bad business practices which may damage their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement so that customs can be reinstated in order to protect the European economy. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this proposed regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the application of the anti-tourism clause for agricultural products in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. These clauses apply when the European branch is affected and not the national branches of the Member States, which are not protected. Moreover, the amendments made through this text are minor and do not protect European agriculture in the event of a problem with the agreement. Moreover, the planned adjustment of tariffs to address the problem of large imports of products with doubts about their origins is too small to be effective.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report. This was a technical file that amends a Commission proposal to harmonise the wording of a regulation with the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes an anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the Parliament and Council is necessary to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the anti-touring mechanism of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It stipulates that in the event of serious trade damage against the European Union, the European Union could suspend the free trade defined by the Association Agreement and return to the Most Favoured Nation (NPF) clause. But the amended text brings almost nothing on the substance to the clauses to protect European agriculture in the event of problems following the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. This clause is very unprotective as it is written. To vote in favour of this text would be to endorse a policy of protection that is far too minimalist in relation to what we are advocating. Hence my choice to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ If the situation were the UK signing or updating such an Agreement with Georgia to bring British trade into line with World Trade Organisation rules, then I would vote in favour. However, I do not believe that the European Union should be the place for such matters to be decided as a consequence of my view that the United Kingdom should not be a part of it. Consequently, I felt that it was appropriate to abstain on this vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement because it will help to improve parliamentary control over the implementation of the Common Trade Policy by the Commission and to improve its transparency.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It provides for the so-called anti-circumvention regime, which provides for the possibility of re-applying the most-favoured-nation rate of the duty on imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia beyond the threshold and without an adequate justification for their precise origin. The relevant provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement are in practice covered by the proposed Regulation. The proposed Regulation aims to ensure compliance with Georgia's obligations arising from the provisions of the Agreement on anti-circumvention procedures in order to protect EU producers where appropriate. I support the proposal to introduce a reporting obligation, according to which the Commission is to submit an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation to the co-legislators.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The products covered by the anti-tour clause are beef, pork and sheep, poultry meat, dairy products, eggs, mushrooms, cereals, sugar, corn, cigarettes. The association agreement with Georgia contains an anti-tour clause: when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products exceeds a ceiling with doubts about their origins, the clause allows the preferential tariff to be replaced by the most favoured nation's tariff (NPF). The anti-competition clause is applied after an investigation for a period of six months respectively on the products listed. However, apart from the fact that the European Commission is the only one that can decide whether or not to activate the safeguard clause, it is the "European branch" as a whole that is concerned and not a particular branch of a particular state. And the maximum alignment of tariffs with the MFN rate is clearly insufficient to address a problem of overspriced imports. That's why I abstained.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a total amount of €2.6 billion, the EU is Georgia's most important trading partner. Today, in my vote, I supported the Landsbergis report on the proposal for a regulation implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism within the EU-Georgia Trade Association Agreement. The purpose of the regulation is to restore customs duties in the event that imports of certain agricultural products exceed a certain threshold, in the absence of a valid justification as to their exact origin. Although the rate of agricultural products subject to the anti-circumvention mechanism was below 1% in 2015, the inclusion of the clause was necessary to prevent third countries from unduly taking advantage of the benefits offered by the agreement, while protecting Georgian products from abuse and unfair competition.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in this report, which I have supported. This agreement includes a mechanism, called the 'anti-avoidance mechanism', which offers the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, which calls for an anti-tour clause on trade between the EU and Georgia, provides for the possibility of reintroducing the tariff rate of the most favoured nation in cases where imports of certain agricultural products (beef, pork and sheep, cereals, sugar, etc.) from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without any justification for their origins. These clauses are comparable to those already implemented in many free trade agreements. It is regrettable that these clauses apply only when the European branch is affected and not in the case of a national branch.  The objectives of aligning tariffs as much as possible with the most favoured nation rate are clearly too low to address the problems of over-imports.  In this case, this amended text brings almost nothing substantively to the clauses to protect European agriculture in the event of problems following the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. In its current drafting, this clause is very unprotective. Finally, the changes made are very minor and do not improve the text.  I have therefore decided to abstain on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not agree with the EU-Georgia Association Agreement as I considered this measure to be europe's interference in the area of Russian influence, in addition to a country without commercial interests for our companies. It is precisely for these reasons that I have not now supported this text with my vote and abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this Parliament's Legislative Resolution which allows the respective provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement adopted by the European Parliament on 18 December 2014 to be implemented. The proposed Regulation needs to be adopted in order to comply with Georgia's obligations under the anti-circumvention provisions of the Agreement with a view to protecting EU producers, where appropriate. The anti-avoidance mechanism included in the agreement offers the possibility of reintroducing customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it adopted Parliament's position on a regulation implementing the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention regime providing for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences provided for in the Association Agreement for Georgia. The Association Agreement with Georgia, like most of our trade agreements, provides for a bilateral safeguard clause. This measure allows for the suspension of the preferences in the event that their continued application would lead to an unexpected increase in imports, causing economic damage to the domestic industry of the importing country. In addition, the agreement also provides for a so-called anti-circumvention regime which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation duty rate in the case of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia beyond the threshold and without an adequate justification of their precise origin. In order to introduce a measure in EU domestic legislation that will allow for the application of a bilateral safeguard clause and anti-circumvention procedures, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is necessary. The proposed Regulation must be adopted in order to ensure that georgia's obligations under the agreement are complied with in order to protect EU producers where necessary.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the threshold laid down in the Agreement without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 By supporting the proposed regulation, MEPs have made it possible to implement the relevant provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement adopted by the European Parliament last year, including in practice. The adoption of the proposed regulation is necessary in order to implement Georgia's obligations under the provisions of the agreement intended to prevent circumvention in order to protect EU producers where appropriate. The agreement allows the reintroduction of a customs rate for the most advantaged countries through the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without adequate justification of their exact origin.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report on safeguards aimed at protecting EU Member States in a situation where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain quota without a clearly defined origin of the product. In these cases, I support safeguards, such as the introduction of a customs rate, to protect EU member states.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The amended text provides almost nothing substantive to the clauses to protect European agriculture in the event of problems following the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. This clause is very unprotective as it is written. The changes made are very minor and do not improve the text. So I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the EU-Georgia Association Agreement represents an opportunity for both the economic and geopolitical contracting parties. I also believe that it is important for this agreement to contain an appropriate anti-circumvention mechanism and for it to be applied effectively.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement concluded with Georgia introduced an ambitious preferential trade regime between both parties known as the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA). It is important to promote trade association agreements and free international trade, but it must take place on a basis of transparency and mutual respect for the rules. That is why safeguard clauses have been included in the anti-circumvention mechanism of the trade association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Georgia. valid justification as to their exact origin. Anti-circumvention clauses are important to prevent non-Georgian products from being imported into the Eu ropean Union through Georgia by using the benefits of the agreement to circumvent the 'rules of origin' requirements.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to clarify and amend the application of the safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism allowing the suspension of tariff preferences granted to Georgia. These various clauses provide that if a certain volume of imports, particularly agricultural products, is exceeded, which would threaten or cause serious harm to a European industry, the Union may suspend any further reductions in tariffs and replace preferential tariffs with the tariffs of the most favoured nation. These clauses are also supposed to prevent the massive importation of products that are not of Georgian origin but which pass through this Caucasus country in order to benefit from these preferential tariffs. Although they are well-intentioned, these clauses remain ineffective as domestic industries remain vulnerable as long as there is no major danger to the European industry. Moreover, the measures mentioned above are unquestionably derisory. Finally, the changes to the text are absolutely negligible. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 An ambitious preferential trade regime, known as the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA), has been in place since September 2014, which has been negotiated following the same approach as in simultaneous negotiations with other countries in the region. The EU is currently Georgia's main trading partner. 27.2% of Georgia's trade takes place with the EU, with trade with Turkey and Azerbaijan in 2nd and 3rd places, respectively. On the other hand, trade with Georgia accounts for 0.1% of the EU's total trade, with a total value of EUR 2.6 billion in 2014. I note that the anti-elution mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the customs duty applicable to nCMF (i.e. applicable to the most favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a given threshold (annual average volume of imports) without adequate justification as to their exact origin, supporting such an approach. I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the procedures to ensure the effective application of the agreement so as to prevent a possible negative impact on the Union market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement was initialled in June 2014 and has been in provisional application since September 2014. This regulation is nothing more than an ancillary measure providing for the possibility of suspending the preferential duties granted to Georgia for a maximum period of six months in the event of excessive entry of products into the EU. The measure, in itself, is by no means problematic. On the contrary, these are, in concrete terms, safeguard clauses to protect our production system. Our abstention, however, is justified for several reasons: our delegation does not agree with and voted against the association agreement with a country, Georgia, which has traditionally been russian-influenced; this undue interference in an area of political influence close to us is, moreover, devoid of commercial interest to our companies; there is, in concrete terms, no risk to the Italian and Padano agricultural and production system given by Georgia; If the problem exists, our delegation does not believe in the operation of safeguard procedures which, on the evidence of the facts, are almost always slow and une functional to the aims they set themselves.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a regulation implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The anti-circumvention mechanism makes it possible to stop applying a customs duty more favourable to imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia in order to restore the original rate whenever a certain threshold is exceeded without any justification.  In addition, the draft resolution provides for the application of another circumvention clause, which makes it possible to prevent imports into the EU of non-Georgian products which, through Georgia, would be able to enter the European market thanks to the advantages provided for in the association agreement referred to above. In particular, the aim is to prevent other countries from circumventing the 'rules of origin' requirements, while still managing to get their goods into Europe. The proposed regulation applies the provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement to which Parliament gave its approval on 18 December 2014, and that is why I have decided to vote for its acceptance.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report so a regulation can be adopted, which will allow for an effective application of the anti-circumvention mechanism in the future in order to protect the EU producers if necessary.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not find any particular problems I voted in favour of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. In particular, this agreement provides for a mechanism known as 'anti-circumvention' which allows the 'most-favoured nation' (MFN) customs duty rate to be reinstated if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of restoring the tariff rate of the 'most favoured State' where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification of their exact origin. We therefore support the report and believe that it is necessary to issue a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council in order to incorporate into EU legislation the necessary means by which the anti-circumvention mechanism can be implemented.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We discussed today the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of the anti-circumvention mechanism which provides for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, on the other. The implementation of corresponding decisions aimed at strengthening regulations and cooperation between the EU and third States is a positive move that can ensure the smooth cooperation of citizens of both parties. I have therefore decided to support and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other, so that the necessary instrument to make it possible to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism is included in EU internal legislation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 International trade law attaches great importance to rules of origin, because too weak rules risk giving rise to out-of-the-way fraud to the detriment of consumers, while also damaging confidence in producers and exporters in an entire country. The anti-circumvention mechanism referred to in this proposal is, in my view, well calibrated to continue the happy trade cooperation with Georgia: clear pacts, long friendship!

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both parties, known as the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA). Currently the EU is Georgia’s main trading partner. Trade with Georgia amounts for 0.1% of the EU’s total trade. Article 27 of the agreement allows for an ‘anti-circumvention mechanism’. This enables the reintroduction of the ‘most-favoured-nation’ customs duty rate when imports from Georgia are in excess of a certain threshold without justification of their origin. This clause is crucial to avoid the Union importing non-Georgian products via Georgia. The measure must be used to stop countries with bilateral free-trade agreements with Georgia, like Turkey and EUROPMED countries using the Agreement to avoid ‘rules of origin’ requirement. This clause also works to protect Georgian producers from unprecedented competition from non-Georgian producers.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia introduces an ambitious regime of trade preferences between both parties, known as the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area. The Agreement includes, in Article 27a, the so-called 'anti-circumvention mechanism', which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the rate of the Most Favoured Nation customs duty where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain limit without the appropriate justification of their exact origin. I support Mr Lansbergis' report which includes an 'anti-circumvention clause' to prevent imports into the Union of non-Georgian products through Georgia, using the advantages of the provisions of the Agreement, preventing countries with bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia from using the agreement with the Union to circumvent the requirements of rules of origin.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism because it provides for the possibility of reintroducing the rate of customs duty when agricultural imports from Georgia exceed a threshold without justification. The proposal is part of the association agreement with that country, dated 18 December 2014, with the aim of preventing the possible emergence of situations of commercial disadvantage vis-à-vis European producers.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Like in the case of Moldova, I welcome the inclusion in the agreement of the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold. To this effect, a law needs to be put in place laying down the necessary instrument to be able to apply the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement provides for a mechanism called "anti-circumvention", which allows the "most-favoured nation" (MFN) customs duty rate to be re-established if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold in the absence of a valid justification as to their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to establish, in EU internal legislation, the instrument necessary for the application of this mechanism. For imports of the products listed in Annex II to C to the Agreement, subject to the anti-circumvention mechanism, if the threshold is exceeded, the Commission may decide to temporarily suspend the preferential duty applied to the products concerned for a maximum period of six months from the date of publication of the Decision. The proposal provides for an obligation on the Commission to submit to the co-legislators, and subsequently to make public, an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation. The European Parliament may invite the Commission to an ad hoc meeting of its committee responsible for presenting and explaining questions relating to the application of the Rules of Procedure. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the implementation of the anti-avoidance mechanism in this type of trade agreement proposes a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU where appropriate. This report introduces an obligation to report on the application of the anti-avoidance clause for implementation in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The Commission shall submit a report containing information on the application of that clause in order to protect European industry and consumers from bad business practices which may damage their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement so that customs can be reinstated in order to protect the European economy. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU is now Georgia's main trading partner, with 27.2% of its trade with the EU, while the European Union trades with Georgia at 0.1% in trade volume. The main agricultural products exported from Georgia to the EU are fresh and dried hazelnuts, mineral water and wine.  The regulation proposed by the European Commission put into practice the provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement approved by Parliament in December 2015. The adoption of the Regulation is necessary in order to enforce Georgia's obligations under the agreement's so-called anti-circumvention mechanism. The anti-circumvention mechanism allows for the reintroduction of the most-reduced duty rate if imports of agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a certain limit, without specifying their exact origin. The 'anti-circumvention clause' is necessary primarily to avoid the entry into the European Union of products not originating in Georgia through Georgia, benefiting from the agreed preferences. The clause also serves as a protection mechanism for Georgian producers against possible abuses. Annexes II to C to the Agreement were amended by Decision of the EEA Joint Committee No The average annual import volume for the products listed in Annex II to Regulation (EEC) No 2081/92 is set. The agreement introduces a preferential trading system. The Commission also sets out in the proposal a reporting obligation to submit an annual report to the co-legislators on the application and implementation of the Regulation. This increases parliamentary oversight and transparency over the common commercial policy. I supported the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Georgia of June 2014 contains a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism which allows the reintroducing of the rate of duty applicable to the most favoured country where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia , listed in Annex II-C to the Agreement, exceed a certain threshold, without due justification for their exact origin. The Commission may decide to temporarily suspend the preferential duties applicable to the products concerned or decide that such suspension is not appropriate. The provisional suspension of preferential duties shall apply for a maximum period of six months from the date of publication of the decision suspending the preferential duties. In order to introduce the necessary instrument into the EU's internal legal order so that this anti-circumvention mechanism can be applied, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed – I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that calls for an ‘anti-circumvention’ clause regarding trade between the European Union and Georgia.  This mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate in the event that imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. Ultimately such a safeguard measure would be dually beneficial: it would result in greater transparency and more security for domestic, European firms and it would serve as a mechanism to protect Georgian producers from this potential misuse and unprecedented competition from non-Georgian producers.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this temporary suspension of tariff preferences under the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It is important that tariff preferences under an association agreement only benefit the country with which the EU signed the deal. The Association Agreement with Georgia signed in June 2014 includes an anti-circumvention mechanism designed to be used when necessary, and I welcome its implementation in this case to ensure Georgian farmers continue to benefit from the free trade agreement signed with the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to implement the safeguard clause within the framework of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which allows for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences granted to Georgia. This instrument, provided for in each of the EU's association agreements with third countries, aims to guarantee the interests of European companies when preferences granted to third countries lead to a large and unexpected increase in imports, to the detriment of European production. The suspension is expected to last up to six months. Considering that the development aid policy of third countries of the European Union must not be at the expense of the interests of our economy, particularly agricultural, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This text aims to integrate into European law the anti-contouration mechanism provided for in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. I am in favour of the possibility of suspending preferential tariffs when the volume of imports of certain agricultural and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement provides for a mechanism known as 'anti-circumvention', which allows the "most-favoured nation" (MFN) customs duty rate to be re-established if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold in the absence of a valid justification as to their exact origin. I voted in favour of this measure because we need a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council in order to establish, in EU internal legislation, the instrument necessary for the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism with Giorgia.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia is an important instrument for strengthening trade ties, promoting respect for human rights and good governance in Georgia. As such, it should be seen as an opportunity for Georgians and Europeans. The trade component of this agreement must be beneficial to the economies of both parties but also include safety nets for products deemed sensitive. For this reason, the introduction of the "anti-touring" mechanism will allow tariff preferences on certain products such as meats, dairy products and cereals to be suspended as much as necessary in the event of an unjustified increase in imports from Georgia. In particular, it will prevent fraud having rules of origin, such as the transit of products from neighbouring countries by Georgia in order to benefit from European preferences.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. It is commendable to want to combat the use of Georgia's preferential tariffs by exporters of products outside Georgia. However, the amended text does not improve the measures to protect European agriculture. The anti-competition clause applies after six months of investigation, via the European Commission. Moreover, it aims to protect only the branch of the Union concerned and not the branch of one of the Member States. So I have decided to abstain on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the mechanism to prevent circumvention, which provides for the suspension of the application of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part. This is because the proposed Regulation put into practice the relevant provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, to which the European Parliament agreed on 18 December 2014.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a mechanism called the 'anti-circumvention mechanism' which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the 'most favoured nation' customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification for their exact origin. The proposed amendment to the Commission text aims to harmonise the wording of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It sets out the Commission's obligation to draw up a report in more detail in order to expressly mention the application of an anti-circumvention mechanism. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution because I consider these anti-tourism measures to be of no real scope and ineffectiveness.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a mechanism called the "anti-circumvention mechanism", which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the 'most favoured nation' customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification for their exact origin. The Agreement – which we condemn and against which we have been – introduces a regime of trade preferences between both parties, known as the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAA). Currently, the EU is Georgia's main trading partner, accounting for 27.2% of its trade. On the other hand, trade with Georgia accounts for 0.1% of the EU's overall trade, totaling €2.6 billion in 2014. In terms of agricultural products, the main EU imports from Georgia are fresh and dried hazelnuts, mineral water and wine. The EU's main exports to Georgia are processed agricultural products (such as spirits and food preparations) and dairy products. This mechanism does not alter the nature of this agreement, which we reject, which can only, in certain circumstances, mitigate some of its most harmful consequences.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to implement an 'anti-circumvention mechanism' between the European Union and Georgia. This mechanism provides the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty when imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due reason for their exact origin. The European Union is Georgia's main trading partner, and I therefore believe that an agreement that promotes transparency in trade is essential. I am convinced that this agreement brings mutual benefits, while improving the overall quality of trade.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this report is about incorporating an anti-circumvention clause as provided for in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The Association Agreement shall apply provisionally from 1 September 2015.To means that no new essential conditions can be imposed during the legislative process which was not approved during the negotiations on the Association Agreement with Georgia. The Association Agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention clause, which provides for the possibility of introducing tariffs if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain permitted threshold, without due justification for their exact origin.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain because I consider it an agreement without any commercial interest for our companies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this proposal because the implementation of this mechanism achieves the protection of the financial interests of agricultural producers in the Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative report concerns the incorporation in the EU law of the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The agreement has been provisionally applied since 1 September 2014. No fundamentally new conditions can be introduced during the legislative procedure which have not already been agreed during the negotiations with Georgia. However, the legislation can lay down the rules to be followed during the procedure and how decisions under the mechanism are to be taken. The anti-circumvention mechanism provides for the possibility to introduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. An implementing regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is necessary to put the instrument in place in the EU’s internal legislation to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism. In the report the Committee adopted one amendment relating to the reports which the Commission has to supply to Parliament and Council on the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism. Measures adopted under the anti-circumvention mechanism are limited to a maximum of six months.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I stress that the proposed regulation will put into practice the relevant provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement approved by the European Parliament on 18 December 2015. The adoption of the proposed Regulation is necessary in order to enforce Georgia's obligations under the provisions of the Agreement on the Anti-Circumvention Mechanism, thereby protecting European producers where necessary. I also welcome the Commission's obligation to report in the proposal, according to which the Commission will submit an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation to the co-legislators, which will then be made public. The European Parliament may invite the Commission to an ad hoc meeting of its competent committee to explain and explain any issues arising from the implementation of the Agreement. According to the rapporteur, this reporting increases parliamentary oversight and transparency over the Commission's implementation of the common commercial policy. In the light of the above considerations, I propose, in agreement with the rapporteur, that the European Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal without amendments.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report which includes an anti-avoidance mechanism offering the possibility of reintroducing most-favoured-nation customs duty (MFN) rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified. The Commission may decide either temporarily suspend the preferential duty applied to the product(s) concerned, or that the suspension is not appropriate. The temporary suspension of preferential duty shall apply for a maximum period of six months from the date on which the decision to suspend that right is published.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, on the other. From the outset, the Group of the Party of European Democrats has supported the rapporteur's approach, based on close coordination with the Council, which will enable agreement to be reached within a tight timeframe between the two co-legislators. For the Caucasus country, the EU is the main trading partner and the introduction of an anti-circumvention clause, in order to prevent non-Georgian products from reaching the European market, is therefore essential to protect not only Georgian producers from possible fraud but above all European citizens.  It is important that this proposal for a regulation, implemented on the basis of the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia, imposes an obligation on the Commission to submit an annual report on the application and implementation of this regulation so that the co-legislators can exercise the function of monitoring the implementation of European trade policy and in order to give a strong signal of transparency on the part of the institutions.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the EU-Georgia Association Agreement: Procedures to Combat Circumvention Practices, as I consider a further rapprochement and intensive partnership between the EU and Georgia to be geopolitically sensible and important.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Both sides will benefit from the development of economic and trade relations. This will incentivise companies to make further investments. Combating opaque circumvention practices is an important element in this.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which introduces an anti-circumvention mechanism to accompany the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) which is embedded in the Association Agreement with Georgia. This is for cases where the Union suspects imports (particularly agricultural imports) are being circumvented through Georgia to enter the EU market under the preferential agreement, but in fact originate in other countries.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As in the case of the Republic of Moldova, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council introducing a mechanism to prevent circumvention of customs duties against Georgia. It will make it possible to reintroduce customs duties in the event of a breach of certain thresholds by Georgia and a failure to duly justify the exact origin of agricultural products transported across the borders of the Member States of the European Union. The Commission's reporting on the application and implementation of the Regulation will also play a key role in increasing the transparency of the Commission's trade policy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is necessary to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the implementation of an anti-circumvention mechanism, because being able to temporarily suspend preferential tariffs as a result of excess imports will limit negative effects on the Union market, and will protect Georgian businesses from threat and competition by non-Georgian businesses.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report implements provisions adopted under the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It is essentially a question of introducing measures where there is no proper justification for their exact origin (circumvention mechanism). Despite our disagreement with the content of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, we voted in favour of the report because the circumvention mechanism is an important tool to prevent imports of non-Georgian products into the Union through the country.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this anti-circumvention mechanism between the EU and Georgia. This allows for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. The reason this mechanism is important as it will help to avoid imports into the Union of non-Georgian products via Georgia using the advantages of the Agreement provisions and in particular to avoid that countries with bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia, for example Turkey and EUROPMED countries, use the agreement with the Union to circumvent ‘rules of origin’ requirements. This will benefit European consumers while it will also serve as a mechanism to protect Georgian producers from this potential misuse and from unprecedented competition from non-Georgian producers.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the rapporteur's approach and the aim to reach a quick first-reading agreement with Council.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures, which allows for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other (COM(2015)0155 - C8-0091/2015-2015/0080 (COD)) - in the ordinary legislative procedure, first reading.  The Agreement includes a 'prevention of avoidance of measures' allowing the reintroduction of the duty rate, where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed the established threshold without a valid justification, i.e. without a valid correct origin. The inclusion of the avoidance clause is important to prevent imports in the EU of non-eu products via Georgia, taking advantage of the provisions of the Agreement.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the anti-touring mechanism of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It stipulates that in the event of serious trade damage against the European Union, the European Union could suspend the free trade defined by the Association Agreement and return to the Most Favoured Nation (NPF) clause. But the amended text brings almost nothing on the substance to the clauses to protect European agriculture in the event of problems following the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. This clause is very unprotective as it is written. The changes made are very minor and do not improve the text. To vote in favour of this text would be to accredit a protection policy that is too minimalist. So I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Gabrielius Landsbergis on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on the application of the anti-touring mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  The EU has the option of reintroducing tariffs when agricultural imports with Georgia's unclarified origins exceed a certain threshold. The aim is to be able to protect European producers. This text is necessary for the establishment of the Association Agreement with Georgia, which I approved with my fellow MEPs in 2014. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which validates the proposal to create two protection mechanisms within the framework of the association agreement signed between the Union and Georgia. These mechanisms will stop preferential clauses signed with Georgia in cases where the importation of Georgian agricultural products would endanger European production.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The protection of Austrian agriculture is my top priority. At the same time, I see major problems with an agreement with Georgia in terms of food standards and farming methods. However, Georgia's low degree of industrialisation means that there are currently development opportunities primarily in agriculture. On the basis of these considerations, I am abstaining on this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which concerns the incorporation into European Union law of the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. I agree with the rapporteur that the adoption of the proposed regulation is necessary to enforce the obligations of Georgia stemming from the anti-circumvention provisions of the Agreement in order to protect EU producers if necessary. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. Therefore, I believe a regulation is required to put in place the necessary instrument in the EU’s internal legislation to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism and ensure the protection of the EU’s producers.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is simply incorporation into EU law of the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union, the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part, The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure a possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification.
