The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement provides for the 'anti-circumvention' mechanism. In the light of this, I have decided to give a positive opinion because anti-circumvention allows the 'most-favoured nation' (MFN) customs duty rate to be reinstated if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold. This mechanism is also designed to prevent countries, through bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia, from using the agreement with the Eu ropean Union to circumvent the 'rules of origin' requirements.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the safeguard clause and the anti-touring mechanism under the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The amended text brings almost nothing on the substance to the safeguard and anti-tour clause of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. These clauses are very unprotective as they are written. These clauses apply when the European branch is affected and not any national branch. The changes made are very minor and do not improve the text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it does not bring anything interesting to the association agreement.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2014, the European Parliament approved the conclusion of an EU-Georgia Partnership Agreement in order to strengthen political and economic ties between the two sides. This report includes, as in the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, an anti-avoidance mechanism to prevent bad practices and protect EU producers where appropriate. In this context, the possibility of reintroducing most-favoured-nation customs duties (MFNs) is offered if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without their origin being duly justified. It is for the Commission to decide either temporarily suspend the preferential duty applied to the product or to consider that such a suspension is not appropriate. In my view, this report must be adopted as it will contribute to greater parliamentary scrtrolling of the Commission's implementation of the common commercial policy and greater transparency of it.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Back in 2014, Sweden Democrats opposed the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia due to concerns over Georgia’s future accession to the EU. When this Agreement was signed both parties (the EU and Georgia) agreed on a preferential trade regime.  However the Agreement contains a clause (Article 27) called the ‘anti-circumvention mechanism’ which establishes an average annual volume of imports from Georgia into the EU of certain agricultural products. When the volume of imports exceeds the annual volume Georgia must provide the EU with justification that Georgia has the capacity to produce the products concerned in excess, otherwise the EU may temporarily suspend preferential treatment for the products concerned for a period of six months.  The anti-circumvention mechanism would therefore limit the amount of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia to the EU and would also avoid imports of non-Georgian products via Georgia using the advantages of the Agreement’s provisions.  To prevent a possible negative impact on the Swedish market and more importantly to protect our Swedish farmers’ best interests, Sweden Democrats supports this proposal for a regulation providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MEP Gabrielius Landbergi's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of the mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures. This proposal allows for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand Georgia, on the other.  The Association Agreement between the European Union (EU) and Georgia has been provisionally applied since 1 September 2014. The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both sides, known as a detailed and comprehensive free trade area. The agreement also includes a so-called 'mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures', which allows for the reintroduction of the customs rate set out in the principle of the most advantageous nation, in cases where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed the threshold set without a valid justification of their exact origin.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement included from the outset a mechanism to prevent circumvention of the so-called 'anti-circumvention' of the rules, which provides for the possibility of reintrousing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate for Georgia if imports of certain agricultural goods from there without proper justification for their exact origin exceed a certain level of imports. Consequently, this Regulation does not in any way introduce any new principles that do not yet exist, but it does specify what has already been included in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement since December 2014. The Commission's proposal also provides that it will present an annual public annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation. One amendment was also voted on during the vote, namely that the Commission's report will also include information on the application of the anti-circumvention mechanism. In other words, the purpose of this vote was not to introduce any restrictions on TRADE between the EU and Georgia: only to specify the existing principles and rules, so that there was no reason to vote against this proposal and the inline amendment.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Georgia's trade with the EU accounts for 27.2% of its total trade, making the EU the largest trading partner for Georgia. The Association Agreement has been in force since 2014 and constitutes protection against illegal or excessive imports of agricultural products from Georgia, as well as protecting Georgian producers from possible abuse by other non-Georgian producers. I therefore support the introduction of an anti-circumvention mechanism as a control and sanction measure. It makes it possible to reintroduce the most-valued duty rate in the event that the volume of imports of certain products originating in Georgia exceeds that threshold without duly substantiated reasons for their true origin.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, on the other, because it is not complete.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. As with the previous text, on the agreement with Moldova, the anti-touring mechanism allows, when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products exceeds a certain stage with doubts about their origins, to replace the preferential tariff with the tariff of the most favoured nation. Again, this text does not bring anything on the substance to this mechanism. Faced with its futility, we prefer to abstain.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is necessary to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia introduces a preferential trade regime between both parties, known as the Global Free Trade Area. The agreement includes a so-called 'anti-circumvention mechanism', which provides the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without appropriate justification of their exact origin. The inclusion of this 'circumvention clause' is, however, necessary to prevent imports into the EU of non-Georgian products through Georgia and to prevent countries with bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As evidenced by the data, trade relations between the EU and Georgia have very important growth potential. It is also clear, however, that uncontrolled growth can be very dangerous. Having said that, I am satisfied with the protection clauses and anti-circumvention mechanisms provided for, and for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. After four years of negotiations, the European Union signed an association agreement with Georgia in June 2014, which has since been implemented on an interim basis. Still incomplete, this agreement grants a series of trade preferences to Georgia but did not include, until today, an anti-tour mechanism - an instrument that allows the temporary suspension of preferential duties for certain products under the agreement when maximum import volumes are reached. It is in this context that the European Parliament - without prejudging the political or strategic expediency of an association agreement with Georgia - has been forced to validate the inclusion of an anti-tour mechanism. I voted in favour of the introduction of such an instrument, which already exists in all the association agreements concluded by the European Union with the countries of its eastern or Mediterranean neighbourhood, because it is necessary to compensate for any potential imbalance in the European market, despite the small volumes in question.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal is intended to protect the domestic economy, but such association agreements are critical, as there is often a fear of further centralisation to Brussels and the disempowerment of nation states. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation implementing the anti-circumvention regime established by the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which provides for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences. The inclusion of an anti-circumvention clause in EU law was necessary in order to prevent imports into the EU of products originating in Non-Georgia through Georgia under the provisions of the Agreement. At the same time, the aim is for states that have signed bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia not to use this Agreement to avoid the requirements of the 'rules of origin'. This condition is also a measure designed to protect Georgian producers from such possible abuse and competition.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Eu-Georgia Association Agreement provides for the establishment of an "anti-tour mechanism" to suspend preferential tariffs granted to the country when import quotas for certain agricultural products defined in the agreement are exceeded. Above all, it aims to minimize the devastating effects of the free trade agreement by an anti-dumping measure that is very difficult to implement and, moreover, never invoked in agreements where it already exists. It is a bandage on a wooden leg, in the context of economic and political war against Russia and its Eurasian Union.  I am opposed to these free trade agreements, which are a real danger to our farmers, and will therefore not endorse this measure. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the anti-circumvention mechanism of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It provides that in the event of serious trade damage against the European Union, the European Union could suspend the free trade defined by the Association Agreement and return to the Most Favoured Nation (NPF) clause. In fact, the amended text provides almost nothing substantive to the clauses to protect European agriculture in the event of problems following the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The tone of this clause reveals its very unprotective nature. The changes made are very minor and do not make the text better. I would endorse a policy of protection that was too minimalist by being in favour of this text. So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council implementing the safeguard clause and the anti-circumvention mechanism which provide for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other. The safeguard clause and circumvention mechanism are common in most trade agreements and the amendments to the Commission proposal are intended only to clarify the terms of the procedure, in particular as regards relations between the European institutions and national authorities.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed regulation because it is essential to protect EU producers and economy. This amendment aims at clarifying the wording of the agreement and expanding upon the application of the anti-circumvention process.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I congratulate the adoption by the European Parliament of the report on the establishment of an anti-circumvention mechanism with regard to Georgia. As with Moldova, it is important to protect European companies from possible abuse of the benefits of tariff preferences granted under the Association Agreement with Georgia. Indeed, this mechanism, aimed at limiting the risks of tariff circumvention via transit through Georgia, sets thresholds beyond which tariff preferences under the agreement can be suspended. This is essential in order to preserve our businesses. The "anti-competition mechanism" for sensitive agricultural products thus allows the reintroduction of the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The draft legislative resolution contains a new provision introducing into the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism. This is the same mechanism that is also used, for example, in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Moldova. This instrument serves to protect the European economy, so I fully share its incorporation into the text and the entire text of the proposal. At the same time, the amendment fulfils its role of aligning the regulations with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which I also welcome as an appropriate and necessary step.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my approval to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement: temporary suspension of tariff preferences, which concerns the incorporation in the EU law of the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The Agreement has been provisionally applied since 1 September 2014. No fundamentally new conditions can be introduced during the legislative procedure which have not already been agreed during the negotiations with Georgia. However, the legislation can lay out the rules to be followed during the procedure and how decisions under the mechanism are to be taken.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia was signed in June 2014 and has been provisionally applied as of September 2014. The agreement includes an Anti-Circumvention Mechanism which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. This implementing regulation incorporates the mechanism into EU law in order to make it applicable in the EU if necessary. Being an implementing regulation, the provisions related to the mechanism as negotiated by the parties in the agreement have not been modified.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Georgia includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, under which it is possible to reinstate the most-reduced duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a certain limit and do not provide adequate justification for their exact origin. However, in order to introduce into EU internal legislation the means of applying the anti-circumvention mechanism, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed. The Commission has proposed to adopt this. In its report, the Committee on International Trade points out that the proposed Regulation put into practice the provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement which were approved by the European Parliament on 18 December 2015. The adoption of the proposed Regulation is necessary in order to enforce Georgia's obligations under the anti-circumvention mechanism provisions of the Agreement, thereby protecting European producers where necessary.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia includes a mechanism called the "anti-circumvention mechanism" whereby it is possible to reintroduce the "most favoured nation" customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification for their exact origin. In order to be able to implement this anti-circumvention mechanism, it is necessary to establish in EU legislation the establishment of a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council. I endorse the rapporteur's position that the adoption of the proposal for a regulation is necessary to make Georgia comply with the obligations under the Agreement and, consequently, to protect EU producers if necessary.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the application of the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia on the other. This text contains an anti-tour clause, which allows the preferential tariff to be replaced by the most favoured nation's tariff. In reality, this text brings nothing more than the existing law, which does not protect our farmers in the event of problems. So I decided to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the safeguard clause and the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The agreement provides for restrictive measures in the event of importation of products in quantities such as they cause or threaten to cause damage to EU producers producing similar or directly competing products. I have approved this text, which aims to protect the European economy and jobs.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In the framework of the EU-Euratom-Georgia Association Agreement, I voted in favour of the report on the anti-competition mechanism which allows the temporary suspension of tariff preferences, and emphasises the importance for the European Parliament of access to information.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement provides for the anti-circumvention mechanism to restore the "most-favoured nation" (MFN) customs duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold in the absence of valid justification as to their exact origin. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement is largely based on comparable implementing regulations like EU/Korea, EU/Central America, EU/ Colombia and Peru. I have voted for this report that will harmonise the terminology of the Commission proposal with the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union is Georgia's largest trading partner, with 27% of the Caucasus republic's trade with the EU. On the other hand, trade with Georgia accounts for 0.1% of EU trade.  The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia was signed in May 2014 and entered into force on 1 September of that year. It contains a clause providing for the suspension of the application of tariff preferences for Georgian imports into the European Union of goods listed in 'Annex II - C(e)' of the Agreement if imports of those goods and products reach excessive levels disproportionate to the current production capacity of Georgian agriculture. Given that, according to statistics, Georgian imports do not endanger European farmers and producers, including those from my country Bulgaria, even in these difficult times for a number of sectors, Today I gave my support to the Proposal of the European Commission.  With this step, Europe shows solidarity and supports the development of its neighbours and partners. This is a basis for stability and a model that must be applied to all neighbours, because stability in our neighbourhood is a prerequisite for the prosperity of all Europeans.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – An important element of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, the anti-circumvention mechanism, enables the possibility of reintroducing the ‘most favoured nation’ customs duty rate when imports of particular agricultural goods and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed an established threshold without the needed justification of their exact origin. In order to properly apply this anti-circumvention mechanism, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to put in place the required instrument in the EU’s internal legislation is essential.  The rapporteur highlights that the suggested regulation utilises the provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, to which the European Parliament gave its consent on 14 December 2014. Adopting the proposed legislation proves necessary to implement certain obligations of Georgia deriving from the anti-circumvention provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement to protect the EU producers if needed. In addition, the rapporteur embraces the reporting obligation of the Commission, under which the Commission shall submit an annual report on the application and implementation of the regulation to the co-legislators as well as making it accessible to the public. For the reasons stated above, I have voted in favour of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, too, I abstained from voting. This agreement, too, would protect domestic agriculture up to a certain point by reaching certain quantities of imports, but on the whole such association agreements must be rejected.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The adoption of the proposed Regulation is necessary in order to give effect to georgia's obligations under the provisions on the prevention of circumvention of anti-circumvention measures and to protect, where appropriate, the European Union producers.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ASSOCIATION AGREEMENT between the EU and Georgia contains a so-called 'anti-circumvention mechanism', which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty when imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without there being a satisfactory reason for their exact origin. As in the case of Moldova, I consider the introduction of this mechanism to be of fundamental importance. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of a mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures allowing for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other.  I believe that the European Union should stand firmly behind European producers and take care of their interests, in particular in the conclusion of trade agreements with non-EU countries. While the EU and Georgia are achieving a very successful trade, I believe that some measures should be taken, such as implementing a mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures, in order to further protect European producers from products imported from Georgia.  I believe that the existence of this mechanism will be particularly beneficial for European farmers who are particularly vulnerable to imports of cheaper agricultural products. In this way, the EU will be able to control much better the amount of products imported, balancing between the interests of its producers and our non-EU partners.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal regarding inclusion in Union legislation of the relevant parts of the agreed text of the Agreement and the procedures ensuring its effective application, in order to prevent possible negative impact on the market.  I also support the incorporation into EU law of the "mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures" provided for in the association agreement with Georgia. The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both sides that will represent a detailed and comprehensive free trade area as well as additional connectivity and support from the European Union to Georgia.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, the EU is Georgia's main trading partner. This Agreement – which we condemn and against which we have been – introduces a regime of trade preferences between both parties, known as the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTA). It includes the so-called "anti-circumvention mechanism", which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the 'most favoured nation' customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from that country exceed a certain threshold. This mechanism only allows, in certain circumstances, to mitigate some of its most harmful consequences, in no way altering the nature of this agreement, which we reject.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support my colleague Gabrielius Landbergi's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of the mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures, which allows for the temporary suspension of preferential customs treatment under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia, signed on 27 June 2014, was approved by the European Parliament on 18 December 2014 and provisionally applies from 1 September 2014.  The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both sides, known as a detailed and comprehensive free trade area. It was negotiated in the same way as at the same time as other countries in the region, such as the Republic of Moldova and Armenia (Armenia abandoned the signing of the agreement with the EU and signed a trade agreement with Russia instead). The EU is currently Georgia's main trading partner.  The agreement, namely Article 27, includes a so-called 'mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures', which allows for the reintroduction of the duty rate set out in the principle of the most advantageous nation where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed the threshold set (average annual volume of imports) without a valid justification of their exact origin.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of a bilateral safeguard clause to the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia will allow both parties to temporarily suspend tariff preferences in the event of a significant increase in imports causing economic damage to the importing Party's domestic sector. The agreement contains in Article 27 the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroduce a duty rate under the most favoured nation clause if imports of certain processed agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a certain threshold (average annual volume of imports) without proper justification for their exact origin. The inclusion of a circumvention clause is necessary to prevent imports of negro-eu products into the Union via Georgia benefiting from the provisions of the Agreement and, in particular, to prevent countries having a bilateral free trade agreement with Georgia, such as Turkey and europmed countries, from using the agreement with the Union in order to circumvent the 'rules of origin'. This provision also serves as a mechanism to protect Georgian producers against possible abuse and unprecedented competition from non-Georgian producers.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia, signed on 27 June 2014, introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both parties. This agreement provides, inter a way, for a mechanism called 'anti-circumvention', which allows the reinstating of the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate (MFN) if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold. The European Commission may decide to temporarily suspend the preferential duty applied to certain products or to decide that such suspension is not appropriate. I voted in favour of this mechanism to prevent imports into the EU of non-Georgian products through Georgia, using the benefits of the provisions of the agreement and, in particular, to prevent countries with bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia, such as Turkey, from using the agreement with the EU to circumvent the 'rules of origin' requirements.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement signed between the European Union and Georgia in June 2014 and given its consent by the European Parliament on 18 December of the same year is an important means for Georgian exporters to reach European markets and thus relieve the pressure of russia's neighbour. The Association Agreement, which, incidentally, has also been offered to both Armenia and Moldova, introduces an important preferential regime between the EU and Georgia and allows Georgian exporters access to the European single market with better conditions. It should be noted that for Georgia, the EU market is the most important export point. The amendment we are debating here is an important part of the signed agreement, namely Article 27, which contains the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism. I take a positive view on the included circumvention clause, which is intended to prevent non-compliance with the wording of the agreement and to prevent falsification of rules of origin. This provision is intended to protect both Georgian and European producers and to prevent the use of favourable rules and imports of negro products under that Agreement. It is our duty to comply with the signed agreements and to ensure that both interested parties comply with the rules of the game. At the same time, I would like to support the proposal for a reporting obligation set out in this proposal to the Commission, according to which the Commission submits an annual report to the co-legislators on the implementation of that Regulation, which it will subsequently publish.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Georgia, signed in June 2014, contains a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism which allows the reintroducing of the rate of duty applicable to the most favoured country where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia , listed in Annex II-C to the Agreement, exceed a certain threshold, without duly justifying their exact origin. The Commission may decide to temporarily suspend the preferential duties applicable to the products concerned or decide that such suspension is not appropriate. The provisional suspension of preferential duties shall apply for a maximum period of six months from the date of publication of the decision suspending the preferential duties. In order to introduce the necessary instrument into the EU's internal legal order so that this anti-circumvention mechanism can be applied, a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed. In particular, the report underlines the Commission's obligation to report on the application and implementation of the Regulation to the Co-Rapporteurs and subsequently publish an annual report on the application and implementation of the Regulation. Reporting is important for parliamentary scrutiny of the Commission's implementation of the common commercial policy and for increasing its transparency. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Georgian Association Agreement with the EU. This is, in my view, a clear signal that Georgia wants to go to Europe and the EU is willing to help it in real life on this path. The rise of Georgian exports to the Union demonstrates that the free trade area established between Georgia and the Union is indeed working and meeting its objective. Today's legislation has my support because we need to prevent any excesses in EU law. However, such an institute will only strengthen the entire association structure.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 3 February 2016 on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the application of the anti-tour mechanism allowing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States on the one hand and Georgia. In particular, we call for the possibility of suspending preferential duties for up to six months when imports of certain agricultural and processed agricultural products reach the defined annual import volumes.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia - signed on 27 June 2014 and subject to parliamentary approval on 18 December 2014 - includes the so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, under which the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate may be reintroduced where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain limit , without due justification as to its exact origin.  The aim is, in essence, to prevent countries with free trade agreements with Georgia, such as Turkey and europmed countries, from use of this Agreement to circumvent the requirements of "rules of origin".  The commission's proposal for a Regulation at issue here is precisely intended to define the procedures necessary to ensure the implementation of this mechanism, ensuring, on the one hand, Georgia's fulfilment of the obligations under the Agreement and, on the other hand, avoiding potential negative impacts on the EU market. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU's Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014.  Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union (EU) and Georgia, signed on 27 June 2014, guarantees an ambitious regime of trade preferences between both parties, known as the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTA). It was negotiated according to the same approach that was adopted in the negotiations held simultaneously with other countries in the region, such as Moldova and Armenia, the latter abandoning the idea of signing an agreement with the EU, preferring to sign a trade agreement with Russia.  Currently, the EU is Georgia's main trading partner, accounting for 27.2% of its trade. In terms of agricultural products, the main EU imports from Georgia are fresh and dried hazelnuts, mineral water and wine. The EU's main exports to Georgia are processed agricultural products (such as spirits and food preparations) and dairy products. The proposed amendment to the Commission text aims to harmonise the wording of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and sets out the Commission's obligation to draw up a report in more detail, in order to expressly mention the application of an anti-circumvention mechanism, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this Parliament's Legislative Resolution implementing the respective provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement adopted by the European Parliament on 18 December 2014. The proposed Regulation needs to be adopted in order to comply with Georgia's obligations under the anti-circumvention provisions of the Agreement with a view to protecting EU producers, where appropriate. The anti-avoidance mechanism included in the Agreement provides the possibility of reintroducing customs duty rates if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without their exact origin being duly justified.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia was signed on 27 June 2014. The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential regime for trade in goods between the two parties, establishing a comprehensive free trade area. The EU is now Georgia's largest trading partner, with 27.2% of trade with the EU (neighbouring Turkey and Azerbaijan occupy the second and third places respectively). At the same time, trade with Georgia accounts for 0.1% of the EU's total trade. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement referred to at noon provides for an "anti-touring mechanism" that allows the reintroduction of the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified. It is necessary that a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council create, within the framework of EU legislation, the instrument to apply the anti-touring mechanism.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because the EU is Georgia's main trading partner. 27.2% of its current trade is trade with the EU. In the meantime, this amendment concerns the inclusion of European Union law in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which ensures the effective application of this right, with a view to preventing the possible negative impact on the Union market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia was signed on 27 June 2014 and has been in force since 1 September. It is an Agreement establishing a comprehensive and in-depth Free Trade Area and introducing an ambitious regime of trade preferences between both sides.  The Agreement includes the anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the "most favoured nation" customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without justification for their exact origin. Because I believe that this is an instrument that will strengthen Georgia's obligations on the anti-circumvention provisions of the Agreement, with the aim of also providing a greater degree of protection to producers in the European Union, I have decided to support this report by voting in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The Association Agreement with Georgia, signed on 27 June 2014, has been on an interim basis since 1 September 2014. This agreement includes an "anti-tour mechanism" which allows the reintroduction of the tariff rate granted to the most favoured nation (NPF) when the volume of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceeds a specified ceiling without their exact origin being validly justified. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Commission's proposal for a regulation to create the legal instrument for the application of the anti-competition mechanism provided for in the agreement already concluded with Georgia. In addition, Parliament's text calls for the Commission's annual report to include, among other things, information on the application of the anti-touring mechanism.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because I am not convinced that the measure can bring concrete benefits for companies and, more generally, for the economies of European countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I support the Commission's proposal as it concerns the incorporation into EU law of the relevant parts of the negotiated text of the agreement and establishes procedures to ensure its effective application to prevent any negative impact on the EU market.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the implementation of the anti-avoidance mechanism in this type of trade agreement proposes a guarantee to ensure the protection of European industry against agricultural products imported into the EU where appropriate. This report introduces an obligation to report on the application of the anti-avoidance clause for implementation in the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The Commission shall submit a report containing information on the application of that clause in order to protect European industry and consumers from bad business practices which may damage their interests. This report seeks to adapt the Regulation to the new trade agreement so that customs can be reinstated in order to protect the European economy. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia signed in 2014 introduced a preferential trade regime that guarantees mutual free access to the market. In order to protect producers on both sides, the Agreement includes an anti-circumvention mechanism which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification of their exact origin. Furthermore, the 'circumvention clause' is necessary to prevent imports into the EU of non-Georgian products through Georgia by making use of the benefits of the agreement and to prevent countries with bilateral free trade agreements with Georgia, such as Turkey, from using the agreement with the EU to circumvent the requirements of origin. Thanks to the anti-circumvention mechanism, the tariff preferences contained in the agreement will therefore be temporarily suspended, to protect European producers and citizens. For this reason, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The anti-circumvention mechanism would reapply WTO rules to products exported from Georgia to the EU that are believed to violate ‘rules of origin’ requirements, in accordance with the EU’s Association Agreement with Georgia to which the European Parliament gave its consent in 2014. Using the same justification as for the Moldova vote, we abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Just as with the mechanism concerning anti-circumvention in the EU-Moldova Association agreement, this mechanism seeks to do a similar thing: to introduce MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain goods – primarily agricultural goods – from Georgia out-strip the threshold that is in place without due justification of their exact origin. While this file is relatively uncontroversial, I feel it is always important to protect EU industry through trade mechanisms such as these.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing a most-benefit tariff when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia cross a given border without duly substantiated reasons for their exact origin. It was necessary to introduce a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council into EU law as an essential tool enabling anti-circumvention mechanisms to be applied.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union and Georgia have reached an agreement on a free trade area that establishes an ambitious preferential trade regime. This agreement also includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which makes it possible to reintroduce a duty rate on certain agricultural products if their imports from Georgia into the EU exceed a specified threshold and their exact origin is not duly justified. The Agreement determines the average annual volume of imports of a specific list of products. Should this volume be exceeded by Georgia and could not justify this situation, the Commission may temporarily suspend the preferential duty applicable to the product concerned. This provisional measure could be applied for a maximum of six months. The proposed regulation will achieve enforcement of Georgia's obligations under the agreement, as well as the protection of EU producers where necessary. I also supported this proposal because it requires the Commission to report on the application and implementation of the agreement with Georgia, which will also contribute to greater transparency and parliamentary scrutiny of the EU's common commercial policy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ an integral part of the agreement is to effectively implement economic and institutional reforms and a commitment to shared values. The Agreement significantly deepened Georgia's political association with economic integration in the European Union, which resulted in the need to adopt a mechanism provide for the temporary suspension of the tariff preferences contained in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. The Association Agreement between the European Union (EU) and Georgia was signed on 27 June 2014 and provisionally applies from 1 September 2014. The agreement introduces an ambitious preferential trade regime between both sides, known as a detailed and comprehensive free trade area. The EU is currently Georgia's main trading partner.  27.2 % of Georgia's trade takes place with the EU . On the other hand, trade with Georgia amounts to 0.1% of total EU trade, with a total value of €2.6 billion in 2014. As regards agricultural products, the main products imported from Georgia in the EU are fresh or dried hazelnuts, mineral water and wine. The EU mainly exports processed agricultural products (such as spirit drinks and food products) and dairy products to Georgia.  The inclusion of an avoidance clause is necessary to prevent imports into the Union of non-eu products through Georgia using the advantages of the provisions of the Agreement and in particular to avoid that countries that have concluded bilateral trade agreements with Georgia, such as Turkey, or EUROPMED countries, use the Agreement with the Union to avoid the requirements of the "rules of origin". The clause is a protection mechanism for Georgian products against this potential abuse and competition of unprecedented non-corrosion products.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. Safeguard clauses are standard mechanisms in FTAs. They are an essential means of protecting European industry in cases where the Union suspects imports are being circumvented through Georgia to enter the EU market under the preferential agreement, but in fact originate in other countries.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Association Agreement contains several key points expected to be fulfilled by Georgia. Trade liberalization is one of them. The European Union is currently Georgia's main trading partner and in Article 27. The agreement with Georgia includes a so-called 'mechanism to prevent avoidance of measures' allowing the reintroduction of the duty rate, set out in cases where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products from Georgia exceed the threshold set, without a valid justification of their exact origin.  The inclusion of an avoidance clause is necessary to prevent imports into the Union of non-eu products via Georgia in order to avoid countries that have concluded bilateral trade agreements with Georgia avoiding the requirements of 'rules of origin'. Therefore, I support this Commission proposal to include in Union legislation the relevant parts of the agreed text of the Agreement, in order to prevent a possible negative impact on the market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing a anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the suspension of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part. I welcome the amendment which harmonises the text of the regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. It requires the Commission to explicitly indicate in its reporting the application of a anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the reintroduction of a customs rate for the most favoured countries where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without adequate justification for their exact origin.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed Regulation, which will help to ensure that products that enter the EU benefit only the country concerned by the relevant trade agreement.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We disagree with the content of the EU Association Agreement with Georgia because it fully serves the intended benefits of the EU's dominant circles. It creates relations of interdependence - economic as well as political - with partners and promotes extreme competition for the benefit of large capital and at the expense of the interests of society and peoples.  However, we voted in favour of this report as it refers to the anti-circumvention mechanism which provides for the possibility of restoring the ICN tariff rate when imports of agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification of their exact origin. Circumvention clauses are important in order to avoid imports of non-Georgian products into the Union through Georgia benefiting from the Agreement and circumventing the requirements of rules of origin.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The implementation of this mechanism achieves the protection of the financial interests of agricultural producers in the Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) if imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the decision, given that the additional provisions contained there there are essential for the implementation of the Association Agreement and are essentially identical to the defence mechanisms used in trade agreements with other EU partners. Trade policy safeguards and solutions to prevent them from being circumvented are also capable of preventing other third parties from arreating the benefits granted to Georgia. At the same time, I have considered the fact that Georgia is a high trade advantage partner for the EU, but agricultural products account for a significant part of its exports and it is therefore necessary to avoid any damage to the interests of EU producers as a result of the Association Agreement.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Association Agreement between the Union and Georgia contains a counter-circumvention mechanism which allows the reintroducing of the duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products exceed a certain threshold, without duly justifying their exact origin. However, in order for this instrument to be implemented, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council of the EU is needed. The temporary suspension of preferential duties by the Union is necessary for legal reasons, but should be maintained as soon as possible so that Georgia, one of the poorest countries in Europe, can once again make full use of the opportunities offered by the Association Agreement with the Union. Parliament's report also appropriately emphasises the need for the European Commission to report more in detail on the application of this mechanism. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the EP document.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has developed a strong and consistent relationship with the Georgian state over the past decade. This contributed both to the Tbilisi government's interest in having a predictable and influential global strategic partner and to the Union's interest in stability in the South Caucasus area. The signing of the Association Agreement between the two parties in 2014 has helped to strengthen good relations and deepen cooperation in all areas of common interest. However, European legislation sets for a number of limits in relation to the countries with which the EU has signed association agreements, which concern imports of agricultural products which do not have a justification for their exact origin. This is the circumvention prevention mechanism, which allows the temporary suspension of certain imports of products (mainly agricultural, in the case of Georgia). In order to avoid unwanted problems on the European market, it is necessary to adopt this mechanism, which allows for a flexible approach, if necessary. Its application is rather a matter of exceptional conditions and does not harm the long-term European ambitions of the Georgian State. Rather, it is about protecting the economies of the two parties until they are compatible for greater integration.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. This report will help to improve parliamentary oversight and transparency of the Commission's implementation of the Common Trade Policy. The proposed regulation requires the Commission to submit an annual report on the implementation and implementation of the regulation to the co-legislators before making it public. The European Parliament may invite the Commission to attend an ad hoc meeting of its relevant committee to set out or clarify any points related to the implementation of the regulation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which implements the anti-circumvention mechanism providing for the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called anti-circumvention procedure, which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the duties applicable to the 'most favoured nation' (now favoured nation) where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the agreed threshold without giving due justification. The current regulation is necessary in order to properly incorporate it into EU internal legislation so that the anti-circumvention procedure can be applied.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The association agreement with Georgia, signed in 2014, includes a so-called mechanism aimed at preventing avoidance of measures, which allows for the reintroduction of the tariff rate set out in the principle of the most advantageous nation in cases where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed the established threshold without a valid justification of their exact origin.  By temporarily suspending preferential customs treatment, EU internal legislation will provide for an instrument that will allow the implementation of the mechanism to prevent the avoidance of measures under the agreement, the conclusion of which Georgia has committed to comply with all rules.  It aims to create precisely a transparent business and investment environment and appropriate regulatory reform, and the rules must be the same for all. That is why this report is extremely important because of the more effective oversight of the implementation of the common trade policy and for greater transparency of the agreement itself, so I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing a anti-circumvention mechanism allowing the suspension of tariff preferences under the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part, as I believe that this is an instrument that can regulate and protect Member States , which cooperate with it in the field of import of agricultural products.  The proposal, which is of a more technical nature, will thus allow Georgia to start enforcing the obligations arising from the protection agreement already adopted. At the same time, I support the proposal as it will contribute to greater transparency and parliamentary scrutiny of the implementation of the common commercial policy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The amended text brings almost nothing on the substance to the safeguard and anti-tour clause of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  These clauses are very unprotective and the changes made are very minor and do not improve the text.  I choose the ABSTENTION.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a so-called 'anti-circumvention' mechanism, which provides that it is possible to reintroduction of the most-reduced duty rate if imports of certain agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a certain limit and do not provide adequate justification for their exact origin. A regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is needed to introduce into EU internal legislation the means of applying the anti-circumvention mechanism. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. This is a procedure for closing the procedure and approving the Regulation with the inclusion of the two amendments of the European Parliament. In this case, it is an EU Rules of Procedure, applicable to the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is the necessary instrument to be able to implement the bilateral safeguard clause and the anti-avoidance mechanism. These amendments are intended to harmonize the text of the Regulation with that of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.  - The safeguard clause allows the parties to temporarily suspend preferences in the event that their application causes imports to increase unexpectedly and significantly, causing economic damage to domestic industry.  - The anti-avoidance mechanism provides for the possibility of reintroducing the most-favoured-nation customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without proper justification.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The proposed Regulation needs to be adopted in order to ensure the fulfilment of Georgia's obligations arising from the Provisions of the Agreement on Anti-Circumvention Procedures in order to protect EU producers where necessary.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, which concerns the incorporation in the European Union law of the anti-circumvention mechanism foreseen in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The Association Agreement with Georgia includes a so-called anti-circumvention mechanism, which provides for the possibility to reintroduce the MFN customs duty rate when imports of certain agricultural goods from Georgia exceed a given threshold without due justification of their exact origin. An implementing regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council is in this case necessary, in order to put in place in the EU’s internal legislation the necessary instrument to be able to apply the anti-circumvention mechanism. It is also worthwhile to note that this proposal for an implementing Regulation is directly derived from the text of the agreement negotiated with Georgia, which means that neither a separate consultation with interested parties nor any impact assessment are necessary.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes an anti-avoidance mechanism in the event that imports of some Georgian agricultural goods exceed a certain threshold without proper justification for their exact origin. The adoption of this mechanism is a necessary requirement to protect European producers if necessary. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this anti-avoidance mechanism because it provides for the possible reintroduction of customs duties when imports of agricultural products from Georgia exceed certain thresholds without adequately clarifying the exact origin of these products.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement includes a mechanism called the "anti-circumvention mechanism", which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the 'most favoured nation' customs duty rate where imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia exceed a certain threshold without due justification for their exact origin. It is a question of the European Commission's mechanisms for triggering these two clauses. The Agreement introduces a regime of trade preferences between both parties, known as the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAA). It was negotiated according to the same approach that was adopted in the negotiations held simultaneously with other countries in the region, such as Moldova and Armenia (the latter abandoned the idea of signing such an agreement with the EU, preferring to sign a trade agreement with Russia). Currently, the EU is Georgia's main trading partner, accounting for 27.2% of its trade (with neighbours Turkey and Azerbaijan in 2nd and 3rd place respectively). On the other hand, trade with Georgia accounts for 0.1% of the EU's overall trade, totaling €2.6 billion in 2014.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal is intended to protect the domestic economy, but such association agreements are critical, as there is often a fear of further centralisation to Brussels and the disempowerment of nation states. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the EU-Georgia Association Agreement: the circumvention prevention mechanism. This agreement includes a so-called 'anti-circumvention mechanism', which provides for the possibility of reintroducing the customs duty applicable to the most favoured nation where imports of certain agricultural products and processed agricultural products originating in Georgia exceed a given threshold, without adequate justification as to their exact origin. The inclusion of the 'circumvention clause' is necessary to avoid importing non-Georgia products into the EU using the advantages of the provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. The Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia was signed on 27 June 2014 and approved by the European Parliament on 18 December 2014. The EU is currently Georgia's main trading partner, with 27.2% of the country's trade taking place with the EU, with trade with neighbours Turkey and Azerbaijan in 2nd and 3rd places respectively.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Back in 2014, the Sweden Democrats opposed the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia due to concerns of Georgia’s future accession to the EU. When this Agreement was signed both parties (the EU and Georgia) agreed on preferential trade regime.  However the agreement contains a clause (article 27) that is called an ‘anti-circumvention mechanism’ which establishes an average annual volume of imports from Georgia into the EU of certain agricultural products. When the volume of imports exceeds the annual volume, Georgia shall provide the EU with a justification that Georgia has the capacity to produce the products concerned in excess. By an absence of a duly justification the EU may temporarily suspend the preferential treatment for the products concerned for a period of 6 months. The anti-circumvention mechanism would therefore limit the amount of imports of certain agricultural products from Georgia to the EU and would also avoid imports of non-Georgian products via Georgia using the advantages of the Agreement’s provisions.  In order to prevent a possible negative impact on the Swedish market and more importantly to protect our Swedish farmers’ best interests the Sweden Democrats are supporting this proposal for regulation providing the temporary suspension of tariff preferences of the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because the adoption of the proposed regulation is necessary to strengthen Georgia's obligations under the provisions of the Anti-Circumvention Mechanism Agreement. This mechanism is intended to protect Union producers where necessary. As in the case of a similar report on the Association Agreement with Moldova, I welcome the proposal on the European Commission's obligation to submit reports, according to which the Commission will subsequently submit an annual report on the implementation of that Regulation to the co-legislators.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a regulation implementing the anti-circumvention mechanism, as it is necessary for the implementation of the relevant provisions of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and the mechanism will protect EU producers if necessary.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the consideration of the call for the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to be unlocked for Member States to implement a number of measures aimed at facilitating access to printed works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or other impaired to access printed texts. Although the EU and Member States signed the Treaty in April 2014, a minority of seven Member States (including the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy) are blocking their entry into force at the European Council.  I believe that this Resolution is positive as yet another pressure mechanism to unlock final ratification and implement these measures as soon as possible , including the adoption of exceptions to state copyright laws aimed at facilitating the distribution and reproduction of Braille works — which would positively affect almost twenty-five million European citizens.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to facilitate the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty.  Indeed, this text aims to put in place exceptions to copyright in order to facilitate access to the works of blind or visually impaired people. If this treaty reveals the Union's failure to protect people with disabilities, it is necessary to support its implementation.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of ratifying the Marrakes Treaty, because the Committee on Petitions is making use of Article 216(2), according to which it is in a position to table a short motion for a resolution. There will be a simple vote, without amendments or debate. The short resolution calls on the Council to speed up the process of ratification of the Marrakes Treaty signed by the EU in June 2014. The Treaty focuses on exceptions to the right to allow greater distribution of books, in forms accessible to the visually impaired, thus preventing discrimination, since all citizens should have access to the same books. All but seven Member States have ratified the Treaty and this short resolution hopes to put pressure on the other countries to disengage. There are more than 26 million visually impaired people across Europe and only 5% of all published books are accessible (less than 1% in developing countries).

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to facilitate the ratification of this treaty, I voted in favour of this resolution. I agree with its content in favour of persons with disabilities, which will allow exceptions to copyrights for these persons, which would facilitate the provision of works published in formats that are appropriate for them. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is not on my voting list as being a roll-call vote. I wish to clarify for the record that I abstained, for similar reasons to the previous vote, because although I do not believe that such matters should be dealt with at EU level, I would support the accession of the UK to this Treaty if it were in the British Parliament.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation estimates in 2010 that there are 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 visually impaired people in Europe, bringing the total to 26 350 000 visually impaired people. Only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are available to persons with form disorders. The Marrakesh Treaty concerns the faucular access to published works for blind people, visually impaired or other persons with print disabilities. Seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that hinders the ratification process of the Treaty. I support calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process. It is necessary to ensure the right of persons with disabilities to education, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while at the same time ensuring that legislation on the protection of intellectual property rights does not become an unjustified or discriminatory barrier to the use of cultural material by persons with disabilities.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to create copyright exceptions to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind and visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book. Adopted on 27 June 2013, it is one of the international copyright treaties administered by WIPO (World Intellectual Property Organization). The European Union and member states signed the treaty in April 2014. However, this treaty will not enter into force until 20 ratifications have been carried out and it seems that seven Member States of the Union refuse to do so.  In the meantime, I have supported this report, which I think is fair.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential that all the Member States of the European Union ratify the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible. Only 5% of the literature published in Europe is done taking into account the accessibility of the format for the blind, visually weak or deaf. We need to ensure access to hearing books, braille books and applications that move towards true equal opportunities. Due to the blockade of some Member States, this Treaty has not entered into force in the EU, which we strongly condemn in the Resolution, while urging the Commission and the Member States to take all appropriate measures to ensure equal access to all people.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The WHO estimated in 2010 about 2.5 million blind people and almost 24 million visually impaired people in Europe. The EU's signing of the Marrakesh Treaty, aimed at facilitating access to published texts for people with vision or other difficulties, was an important moment in the process of strengthening the european institutions' commitment to defending the right to education of people with disabilities.  The exception to copyright in the Treaty is of fundamental importance since it introduces the possibility of cross-border exchanges of books, favouring the dissemination and sharing of texts. Ratification of the Treaty must therefore be a priority, and that is why I voted in favour of the report proposed by the Committee on Petitions. Seven Member States have not yet ratified, and the EU must therefore make efforts to make culture truly accessible to all citizens.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, since the Treaty has already been signed by EU Member States, to facilitate access to published works for blind or visually impaired persons, and we welcome the EU's ratification of the Treaty. We believe that all Member States should respect the rights of access to culture of all people on an equal footing and facilitate access to it for those with disabilities, in this visual case, and that intellectual property rights cannot be a barrier to discriminating against this group. Therefore, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the signing of this Marrakesh Treaty, we support the ratification of this Treaty by the EU.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing.
