I have supported this Resolution on the Marrakesh Treaty, which recalls that Articles 24 and 30 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities emphasize the right of persons with disabilities to access education without discrimination, in accordance with the principle of equal opportunities, while ensuring that laws protecting intellectual property rights do not constitute an excessive barrier or discrimination to access for people with disabilities to cultural materials. In addition, there are seven EU Member States that form a blocking minority that is preventing the process of ratification of the Treaty, which gives me deep outrage.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This treaty envisages interesting avenues to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind and visually impaired people. Such a treaty can only be welcomed.  However, this treaty wanted by the citizens of the European Union illustrates Europe's clear failure to defend people with disabilities. The willingness of seven EU Member States to block the ratification of the Treaty is regrettable.  The idea of promoting the reproduction of works accessible to people with disabilities is commendable.  So I decided to vote for this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to world health organisation estimates, 285 million people worldwide are affected by visual disabilities and of these 39 million are blind and 246 million are visually impaired. In Europe, however, only 5% of published books are available in accessible formats for people with visual disabilities. Considering this to be unacceptable, I strongly call on the EU to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution by which Parliament urges the Council and the Member States to speed up the process of ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, since the EU and the Member States signed the Treaty in 2014, but that seven Member States have not yet ratified it, which keeps its entry into force blocked. As it has done on previous occasions, Parliament calls for rapid ratification of the Treaty, in order to facilitate greater distribution and easier access to books in formats accessible to the blind or visually impaired, more than 26 million in the European Union, which are limited to their right of access to culture since only 5% of books published in developed countries are presented in formats accessible to them.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it expresses outrage at the member states' avoidance of ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, which commits to making published works easier for persons with visual impairment or other printed text problems, taking into account petitions submitted by citizens. The World Health Organisation estimated in 2010 that there are 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 visually impaired people in Europe, bringing the total to 26 350 000 visually impaired people. However, only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are available in form. In April 2014, the EU and the Member States adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. signed the Marrakesh Treaty and thus made a political commitment to ratify it. Parliament has therefore emphasised with deep indignation that seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that hinders the ratification process of the Treaty. Parliament called on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process so that ratification does not become dependent on the revision of EU legislation or the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process.  Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues).  However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. There are around 26 million blind and visually impaired people in Europe who are in many ways unable to live a normal life. Normal in this sense, as everyone else knows, who we do not face such problems. The Marrakesh Treaty, signed by EU Member States in 2014, represents one of the important steps towards increasing the accessibility of book works to the blind and visually impaired. Unfortunately, there are too many countries that have not yet ratified the Treaty, which is why it cannot enter into force. This means, however, that the blind and the visually impaired continue to be violated by the rights that we take for granted. One of the fundamentals is the right to education. The fact that only 5% of printed books are available in forms understandable to the blind and visually impaired must be a reminder that we are putting more pressure on the Member States that have not yet ratified this Treaty. For all the above reasons, I also supported the proposed resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal calling on the Council to speed up the process of ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. The contract focuses on exceptions to copyright protection to allow for greater distribution of books in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens. There are more than 26 million visually impaired people in Europe, and only 5% of published books are accessible in these formats!

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The treaty facilitates the reproduction, distribution, and provision of works published in formats accessible to people who are blind or visually impaired or disabled to the point of not being able to handle a book. This treaty signed by all Member States is slow to be ratified in some of them, probably as a result of the intervention of publishing-related lobbies, and thus coming into force.  I am in favour of this resolution to ratify this treaty. So I voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I firmly believe that it is the duty of the Union and the Member States to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible in order to put an end to the terrible discrimination against blind or visually impaired citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the WHO (World Health Organization) there are 26,350,000 people living in Europe with visual disabilities (of whom 2,550,000 are blind and 23,800,000 visually impaired). Despite this considerable figure, only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are available in accessible formats. The European Union and its Member States are parties to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and, in April 2014, signed the Marrakesh Treaty, which affirms the principle that copyright finds an important derogation from the need to allow the blind or visually impaired access to knowledge on an equal footing. : Books for the visually impaired and the blind can be exchanged transnationally between organization and organization. The European Union and its Member States have a political and moral duty to ratify and implement in practice the Treaty they have signed, so as to put an end to the unjust discrimination against citizens with visual disabilities and to facilitate access to knowledge and studies in a position of fairness between people.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to facilitate the reproduction and distribution of works published in formats suitable for the blind or disabled, including the creation of copyright exceptions. In June 2013, it was adopted and is now part of the International Copyright Treaties of the World Intellectual Property Organization. However, even if the Treaty was signed by the European Union and its Member States in April 2014, it will only come into force when the Union has 20 ratifications. To date, seven Member States do not seem to want to ratify this treaty. That is why the Council wants to include the provisions of this treaty in a new copyright directive.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to facilitate the ratification of the Treaty of Marrakech, although it illustrates the failure of the European Union in the defence of the disabled.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union respects the right of persons with disabilities to education and, in this respect, must also ensure that laws protecting intellectual property rights do not constitute an unreasonable or discriminatory barrier to access of persons with disabilities to cultural materials.  Knowing that the World Health Organisation estimated in 2010 that a total of 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 persons with partial views are registered in Europe, I believe that the Union must be concerned about the rights of all its citizens, including those persons. Or this means considering including Petition No. 924/2011, addressed by Dan Pescod, a British national, on behalf of the European Union of the Blind (EBU)/Royal National Institute for the Blind (NIB), on blind access to books and other printed products and to ensure equal opportunities. In conclusion, I believe that the European institutions and the Member States must speed up the ratification process, without making ratification conditional on the revision of the EU legal framework or the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union; for this very reason, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Following the notification by certain petitions, the resolution calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the process of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, without making this ratification conditional on a revision of the Legal Framework of the European Union. The Italian Blind Union underlines the importance of the Marrakesh Agreement aimed at facilitating access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access for visually impaired people and people with difficulties reading printed texts to published works has been signed by the European Union and its Member States. This treaty will make access to books more egalitarian and will be a first step in the fight against book shortages. The implementation of the treaty will be made possible within the Union in the next revision of EU copyright legislation. I voted in favour of this resolution, which echoes a petition on the same subject. The resolution calls for ratification of the treaty by all Member States.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution, tabled pursuant to Rule 216(2) of the Rules of Procedure, on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, on the basis of petitions received, in particular Petition 924/2011.  It is estimated that more than twenty-six million people with visual disabilities live in Europe, but only a small percentage of books are published in formats accessible to them. In this way, the right of visually impaired people to education is being thoverted. I believe that access to cultural materials should be guaranteed to all, removing any possible unreasonable or discriminatory barriers. In April 2014, the European Union and its Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty, which calls on the undersigned countries to do everything possible to facilitate the reading of printed texts for people who are blind or have severe visual disabilities. The motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the Member States of the Union to speed up the process of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, which is why I have chosen to vote for its acceptance.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as I believe that the Marrakesh Treaty should be ratified by all Member States as soon as possible to ease the access to suitable versions of books, among others, for those who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print disabled. At the moment, production of such versions of published works is restricted due to domestic copyright laws.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has 2,550,000 blind people and 23,800,000 visually impaired people (2010 WHO data). The Marrakesh Treaty aims to facilitate access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts. Seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that prevents the process of ratifying the Treaty from the EU. Mrs Wikström's report therefore calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process, without making this ratification conditional on a revision of the EU legal framework or on the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union. I could not do otherwise than vote in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the ratification of the Treaty and call on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that facilitating access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts is essential to guarantee the right of blind people to education, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities. In 2010, the World Health Organisation estimated that more than 26 million people with visual disabilities live in Europe, and only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are available in accessible formats. I hope that the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty will be the first step towards decisively addressing this issue.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my experience as a politician I deal with a lot of people and I deal with many issues, and so I am lucky enough to always be able to learn something. A great lesson that I often find myself repeating along my way is that "disability" is a term that evokes a world and therefore cannot be generalized to infer anything on those who suffer from it. In fact, there are so many problems under the name of 'disability' that the world of disabled people is extremely heterogeneous. In Asti there is a hotel where only disabled children work and I can assure you that it is an example of efficiency. I can therefore testify that there is no good reason to prevent disabled people from having access to education and to so many other services that are usually taken for granted for the so-called 'skilled'. I voted with great disdain in favour of this resolution, in the hope that this message will reach those responsible loud and clear.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Numerous petitions from EU citizens with print disabilities have been received, calling for blind people to have access to books and other print products. The World Health Organisation estimates that in 2010 there were a total of 26 350 000 European citizens suffering from visual impairments. In contrast only 5% of all books published in developed countries and fewer than 1% of those in developing countries are made in accessible formats. Both the EU and its Member States are parties to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The UN CRPD Committee encourages the European Union to ratify and implement the Marrakesh Treaty without delay. Article 24 and 30 of the UN CRPD recall the rights of persons with disabilities to education on the basis of equal opportunity. Despite seven EU Member States attempting to impede the process of ratification the Council and the Member States should ratify the treaty as soon as possible. Ratification should be possible without the revision of the EU legal framework of a decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is proud to promote the openness of institutions and the approximation of citizens to European decision-making centres. Following a petition submitted by the European Association of the Blind, Parliament decided to rule on the Marrakesh Treaty aimed at facilitating access to published works by blind, visually impaired or other difficulties in reading printed material. This Parliament is also proud to defend the fundamental rights of all people throughout the continent. And in this case too, i could not let go of the attempt by seven Member States to block the ratification of this treaty, signed by the Union and its individual Members. Access to education and the principle of equality are inalienable values of the European Union. It is therefore not acceptable that, despite the political commitment made through the signing of the treaty, its entry into force is now blocked and the fundamental rights of millions of people are now being respected. It is not acceptable that in the so-called "developed world", only 5% of published books are accessible to the blind and visually impaired.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the motion tabled by the Committee on Petitions because speeding up the procedure for ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty would bring great benefits to people with visual impairments, which in Europe exceed 26 million, considering in this number both those suffering from blindness and those who have only partial visual perception.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Only 5 per cent of all published books in the developed countries and less than 1 per cent in the developing countries are ever produced in accessible formats. This shows how developments in technologies have not been incorporated in making culture more accessible to persons with disabilities. Today different technologies make it possible for persons with disabilities to have greater and more effective access to cultural goods and services such as books. Member States have been somewhat hesitant to ratify this treaty to the detriment of persons with disability and of the cultural sector itself. The motion for resolution calls on the Commission to facilitate the process of ratification of the Treaty by the EU. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the consideration of the call for the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to be unlocked for Member States to implement a number of measures aimed at facilitating access to printed works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or other impaired to access printed text. Although the EU and Member States signed the Treaty in April 2014, a minority of seven Member States (including the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy) are blocking their entry into force at the European Council.  I believe that this Resolution is positive as yet another pressure mechanism to unlock final ratification and implement these measures as soon as possible , including the adoption of exceptions to state copyright laws aimed at facilitating the distribution and reproduction of Braille works — which would positively affect almost twenty-five million European citizens.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Committee on Petitions has recently been contacted by a number of petitions from citizens who are representatives of organisations of the blind and partially sighted and persons with other disabilities, asking Parliament to facilitate the ratification of the Marrakech Treaty. Ratification of the Treaty would facilitate access to printed works by the EU citizens concerned. On the basis of these petitions, a motion for a resolution for the plenum was drafted in the commission. The motion for a resolution expresses its untenation that some EU Member States are slowing down the process of ratification within the Council. I believe that ratification should be supported as soon as possible, but that the necessary eu legal guarantees should not be ignored. I hope that the current situation will be resolved as soon as possible so that the blind and partially sighted can assert their rights, all in a cross-border context, including national minorities.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 According to the WHO, there are 314 million blind and visually impaired people in the world today. Polish Association of the Blind brings together about 60,000 people. At the same time, it is estimated that there are 300,000 people who cannot read black print in Poland. Peti's resolution calls for faster ratification of the Treaty, without having to wait for a ruling by the Court of Justice of the EU, given the importance of the Treaty on blind and visually impaired persons and persons with print disabilities, and the fact that waiting for a ruling by the Court of Justice would significantly delay ratification. I fully support the resolution tabled – I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that calls on the Council to accelerate the ratification process of the Marrakech Treaty. Essentially the Treaty concentrates on copyright exceptions to allow for greater distributions of books in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens in an effort to prevent discrimination of visually impaired and print disabled persons. They should have access to the same books as other persons. This short resolution hopes to put pressure on the remaining seven Members which as yet have not ratified the Treaty. This is important because there are over 26 million visually impaired individuals across Europe with only 5% of all published books produced in accessible formats.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased we brought forward this motion for a resolution in Parliament; the delay in ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty has gone on too long. In the UK we have consistently supported the ratification of the Marrakech Treaty as a vital enabler of access to works by visually impaired persons and persons with print disabilities. The sooner we can ratify this Treaty across the EU the better.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, MEPs in the European Parliament, reacting to a number of petitions, strongly criticise the seven Member States of the European Union who have formed a blocking minority in the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty. This treaty aims to facilitate access for the blind, visually impaired and other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works. The European Parliament is calling on the Council and member states to speed up the ratification process. Considering that it is necessary to increase the accessibility of cultural products to people with disabilities, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament calls on the Council and Member States to speed up the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty aimed at facilitating access for the blind, the visually impaired and those with other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works. It is necessary to promote the rights of people with disabilities, as well as their access to cultural property without discrimination.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Making published works accessible to all blind or visually impaired people is an act of civilization. If the civilization of a society is also recognized by the accessibility of places, the accessibility of books for 26,350,000 people with visual disabilities is a fact of no secondary importance: in fact, only 5% of books are available in accessible formats. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process.  Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues).  However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty of 27 June 2013 allows exceptions to copyrights to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of accessible works for visually impaired or physically disabled people. Its implementation requires twenty ratifications, but seven EU states seem to oppose it. In order to move forward on this issue, the Council of the European Union would like to take up the provisions of the Treaty in the new Copyright Directive, rather than wait for the treaty to be ratified. Although the redesign of the directive may also take time, I have supported this text which is in the right direction, that of action towards the most fragile among us.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I join the many complaints lodged with the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions condemning the fact that the Council and the European Parliament have not yet been able to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access to published works for blind people, visually impaired or with other disabilities preventing the reading of printed material.  Seven European Union countries have not yet ratified the treaty. I take every opportunity to emphasise this fact, justifying the need to swiftly ratify this treaty for the good of all European citizens. Access to published material is important for blind people and is part of their rights in our society. That is why I have supported this resolution and I believe that swift action is needed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The right of disabled people to benefit from measures to ensure their autonomy, social and professional integration and participation in social life is undeniable.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. As Vice-President of the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament, I have been one of the drivers in my political group of this Resolution. The Marrakesh Treaty requires all signatory parties to introduce exceptions to copyright law to meet the needs of visually impaired persons by creating special national authorities responsible for providing accessible content in collaboration with NGOs. Ratification will facilitate access for visually descient or non-printed persons to copyrighted works.  The European Parliament has contributed greatly to the development and success of this Treaty, which, based on international copyright conventions, has also been designed to respect copyright after ratification and entry into force, visually impaired persons will be able to access the same books that the general public can read. Millions of blind people will enjoy access to copyrighted works in the future, which in turn will promote and expand their educational and training options and thus allow them to qualify for better job opportunities in the labour market.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to facilitate access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts. I voted in favour of this resolution, which stems from petitions received from the Committee on Petitions, calling on the seven Member States that have not yet ratified the Treaty, including Italy, to proceed without further delay and to listen to the requests of the many European citizens who have visual difficulties.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The World Health Organisation estimated that in 2010 there were 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 people in Europe, out of a total of 26,350,000 people with visual impairments. However, only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are produced in accessible formats. There are seven EU Member States that have formed a blocking minority preventing the process of ratifying the Treaty, which is regrettable. Member States should speed up this process without making ratification dependent on the revision of the EU legal framework or the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, because the Marrakesh Treaty creates exceptions to copyright for blind people.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are published in accessible formats. The purpose of the Marrakesh Treaty is to facilitate, through copyright exceptions, the development of versions accessible to people with visual difficulties of books originally protected by intellectual property (copyright) laws.  The EU and most of its Member States have signed the Marrakesh Treaty and have made a political commitment to ratify it. The resolution is outraged that 7 Member States form a blocking minority which prevents ratification of the Treaty. It recalls Articles 24 and 30 of the UN CRPD: the right to education of persons with disabilities, without discrimination and on an equal opportunity basis and access to cultural goods. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it benefits people with disabilities.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing \ u2012 In this particular case, the Committee on Petitions uses its right to table a short motion for a resolution calling on the Council to speed up the ratification process of the Marrakesh Agreement, adopted in June 2014 and focusing on exceptions to copyright, to ensure and enable the distribution of books in larger volumes, in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens, thereby avoiding discrimination against the visually impaired and persons with disabilities. , as they should have access to the same books as other citizens. It remains for the Treaty to be ratified by 7 Member States, and this resolution will put pressure on the states concerned, as there are more than 26 million visually impaired citizens living in Europe and only 5% of all books are published in accessible formats.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The right of disabled people to benefit from measures to ensure their autonomy, social and professional integration and participation in social life is undeniable, which is why I am voting in favour of the ratification of the Marrakes Treaty, on the basis of the petitions received, in particular Reference 924/2011.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Here the Petitions Committee is making use of Rule 216, para 2 which enables it to submit a short motion for a resolution. There will be a simple vote, without amendments or debate. The short resolution is calling on the Council to accelerate the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty. Signed by the EU in June 2014, the treaty focuses on copyright exceptions to allow greater distribution of books, in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens, thereby preventing discrimination of visually impaired and print disabled persons, who should have access to the same books as other persons. All except seven Member States have ratified the treaty and this short resolution hopes to put pressure on these remaining countries to unblock. There are more than 26 million visually impaired individuals across Europe with only 5% of all published books ever produced in accessible formats (less than 1% in developing countries).

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Articles 24 and 30 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities emphasise the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while ensuring that laws protecting intellectual property rights do not constitute an unjustified or discriminatory barrier to access to cultural products for persons with disabilities. I find it deeply outrageous that seven EU Member States have formed a minority group, which is hampering the process of ratifying the Treaty. It calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process and not to tie it to a review of the EU legal framework or to a decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, bearing in mind that the World Health Organization estimates that in 2010 2,550,000 blind people and 23,800,000 people with partial vision lived in Europe, representing a total of 26,350,000 visually impaired people. Only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are presented in accessible formats, so we must work to make books and culture more accessible in general to this important group, even more so considering that the EU and Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 and , therefore, they have made a political commitment to ratify it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I have long supported the campaign for the marrakesh Treaty to enter into force as soon as possible, which finally recognises the right of the blind to wider access to culture. The Committee on Petitions does a good job in continuing to keep a close eye on this campaign. The European Parliament is at international level the institution that has spent the most on the defence of this right. The Council continues to hold thousands and thousands of citizens hostage to archaic rules and discriminate against a fundamental right, that of knowledge and culture. I therefore also appeal to the Council to reach an agreement to unblock the resistance that still exist, and I call on the European Commission to play a more active role in this respect.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the European Parliament resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on the basis of petitions received, in particular Petition 924/2011, because I believe it is essential that the Council speed up and rapidly approve the Marrakesh Treaty aimed at facilitating access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts. Indeed, I consider the regrettable delay in the approval of the Treaty by six Member States, which are actuallying the achievement of a sacrosanct right of the approximately 2 550 000 blind European citizens and the 23 800 000 visually impaired citizens: 26 million citizens who demand respect for their right to read, access to culture and information and accessible formats. National copyright laws cannot and must not be a brake on copyright, and I firmly believe that citizens with visibility problems are entitled to the same texts and readings as other citizens. I therefore call on the Member States to do more to quickly approve the Treaty and to develop a market for accessible texts that exceeds the current very low 5%.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Marrakesh Treaty was adopted on 28 June 2013 at the Diplomatic Conference of the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO). Its aim was to establish an international standard for the use by blind and visually impaired persons of works intended for printing and protected by law. There are 2 550 000 blind people in Europe and 23 800 000 visually impaired people, more than 26 million citizens interested in these changes. Despite this, EU Member States are dragging themselves in on the ratification of the Treaty, and at Council level seven countries are making the process even more difficult. In many countries, including Poland, there is a law providing for easier access to blind and visually impaired work (in adapted formats), but it currently covers only 5% of publications in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries.  The EU and its Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 and thus committed themselves to ratifying it. Furthermore, Article 24 and 30 of the UN Convention highlight the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while ensuring that copyright legislation does not constitute an unjustified barrier to access to cultural material. Today's vote is a call on the European Parliament to ratify the Treaty without delay by all the Member States of the European Union and to swiftly enter into force its provisions.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which aims to have the Marrakesh Treaty ratified as soon as possible. This treaty creates exceptions to copyright to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works for blind and visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book. It seems that some Member States of the Union have obstructed the ratification of the Treaty. The resolution calls on the Council and Member States to speed up the ratification process, without subjecting it to the revision of the EU's legal framework or to the decision of the European Court of Justice.  In any event, the non-ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty illustrates Europe's failure to defend the disabled. If this text is not yet ratified, it is probably because it limits (somewhat) copyright. It therefore goes against important interests: those of authors, publishers, translators...

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, since the Treaty has already been signed by EU Member States, to facilitate access to published works for blind or visually impaired persons, and we welcome the EU's ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. We believe that all Member States should respect the rights of access to culture of all people on an equal footing and facilitate access to it for those with disabilities, in this visual case, and that intellectual property rights cannot be a barrier to discriminating against this group.  Therefore, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the signing of this Marrakesh Treaty, we support the ratification of this Treaty by the EU.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I warmly welcome the ratification of the Treaty of Marrakesh. The World Health Organisation estimated in 2010 that across Europe there are 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 partially sighted people, giving a total of 26 350 000 visually impaired individuals, yet only 5% of all published books in the developed countries and less than 1% in the developing countries are ever produced in accessible formats.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. While WHO estimates that more than 314 million people are blind and visually impaired worldwide, 90% of them in developing countries, and less than 5% of the one million books released worldwide each year are published in formats accessible to the visually impaired, urgent action is needed! Together with my fellow Members, however, we must note with bitterness that this is not the direction in which the European Union is currently heading. Seven Member States of the European Union (Germany, Cyprus, Hungary, Italy, Poland, the United Kingdom and Slovenia) have formed a blocking minority that obstructs the ratification process of the 2013 Marrakesh Treaty, which aims to facilitate access to cultural heritage for blind and visually impaired people. However, by signing the Treaty of Marrakech, the Union and the Member States have made a political commitment to ratify the Treaty. The lack of real will of Member States to reach a constructive agreement is a flagrant violation of the right to information that is easily accessible, which is enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the resolution to call on the Council and Member States to accelerate ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, because there are over 26 million visually impaired individuals who are being negatively affected and deprived of the opportunity to learn from published books and cultural materials, mainly due to a lack of commitment and communication from EU governments, specifically seven Member States. This is slowing the process of ratifying a bill that has already been signed, and should be quickly dealt with thanks to a quick ratification.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Despite the fact that the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competences and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission pledged to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle disputes, which is of guarantee for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We supported the European Parliament resolution on the ratification of the Marrakes Treaty, on the basis of the petitions submitted, and in particular Reference No 1. 924/2011 on the ground that it establishes the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and equality, while at the same time ensuring that the provisions on the protection of intellectual property rights do not create barriers to access to cultural goods for persons with disabilities. It also condemns the fact that seven EU Member States have not yet ratified the Treaty.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the petitions received from EU citizens on behalf of people with disabilities and given the fact that the EU and its Member States are parties to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the rights of persons with disabilities should be emphasised, especially in relation to the right to education, to be free from discrimination , and their rights to intellectual property. The Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled should be ratified by all Member States of the EU. The ratification process for the Marrakesh Treaty should be accelerated and should be done without revision of EU law or the decision of the CJEU. It is past time to find a political solution for those who are blind or visually impaired. Like the rest of us they have the right to accessible literature.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's decision to make the Marrakech Treaty a european union law, on the basis of a proposal from the Committee on Petitions, urges the Member States that constitute a minority blocking the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Despite the fact that the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly because of the dispute between the European Commission and the Council. However, the decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency. On 14 July 2015, the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Visually impaired and print disabled persons should have access to the same books as other persons. This resolution is calling on the Council to accelerate the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty, which focuses on copyright exceptions in order to allow greater distribution of books, in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, based on petitions received, in particular Petition No 1000/2013. 924/2011, as I fully support efforts and measures targeting the blind and visually impaired, of which there are over 26 350 000 in Europe.  The Marrakesh Treaty also represents a political message by which the European Union fully advocates for the rights of persons with disabilities, i.e. to apply equal opportunities rights, non-discriminatory education, and access to cultural materials. Therefore, I support this motion for a resolution in its entirety.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to facilitate the ratification of this treaty, I voted in favour of this resolution. I agree with its content in favour of people with disabilities. It would allow copyright exceptions for these individuals, which would facilitate the provision of works published in formats that are appropriate to them. As a result I vote for.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the ratification of the Treaty of Marrakech, based on petitions received by the European Parliament. The Marrakesh Treaty, of which the European Union is a signatory, aims to facilitate access to works published for the blind and visually impaired. I fully support the ratification of this treaty since today less than 10% of the world's works are made available in accessible forms for the visually impaired. The ratification of this treaty by the Member States will make up for this shortfall and will be effective once the revision of the European copyright framework is carried out, as the European Commission plans to do in 2016. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Agreement. In principle, there is nothing to prevent the ratification of this agreement.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There are more than 26 million visually impaired individuals across Europe with only 5% of all published books ever produced in accessible formats. Therefore, I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls on Member States to accelerate the ratification process of the Marrakech Treaty to allow greater distribution of books in formats accessible to visually impaired citizens. All except seven Member States have ratified the Treaty and this resolution hopes to put pressure on these remaining countries to unblock.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Articles 24 and 30 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities underline the right of persons with disabilities to education. Petitions from European citizens concerning difficulties in accessing printed texts show that the EU has not paid due attention to this issue. It is imperative to ensure access to published works for blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution and I stress the importance of the citizens' demands, in this case through the instrument of the petition, a tangible sign of democracy and participation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. It aims to create exceptions to copyright to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind or visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book. The European Union and member states signed the treaty in April 2014, but the treaty will not enter into force until 20 ratifications have been completed. It would appear that seven EU Member States have obstructed the ratification of the Treaty. For the time being, the Council of the European Union would like to include the provisions of the Treaty in the new Copyright Directive, rather than ratifying the Treaty. But the revision of this directive could take time...

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to encourage ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty.  This is an interesting treaty because it aims to create exceptions to copyright to facilitate the reproduction of works in formats accessible to blind and visually impaired people.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament is an institution that is at the service of citizens and this motion for a resolution is a clear example of this, as it is born due to the large number of petitions filed by European citizens who have difficulty accessing printed texts and books due to a visual impairment. According to World Health Organization data, an estimated 2,550,000 people and 23,800,000 people with partial vision, or 26,350,000 visually impaired persons, will be estimated to be in 2010. Today, however, only 5% of books published in developed countries have formats accessible to all audiences. The main purpose of the Marrakesh Treaty is to end the limited supply of books faced by people who are blind or visually impaired. Intellectual property should not be a barrier to access to cultural materials that discriminates against persons with disabilities. In my view, the adoption of this proposal is necessary to ensure the principle of equal opportunities contained in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on facilitating access to published works for blind, visually impaired and other print-reading impaired persons. The entry into force of this Treaty represents an opportunity for 30 million Europeans to have easier access to publications available in a format adapted for the visually impaired, thereby increasing their participation in education, cultural, social life and, in general, improving their quality of life.  In accordance m.in article 14 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union: 'Everyone has the right to education and access to vocational and continuing education'. It should therefore be our task to take urgent action so that persons with disabilities can fully exercise their rights in this regard. I would like to stress that this is about the fundamental rights of these people, not some additional powers. Given that only a small percentage of books worldwide are adapted to the needs of people with disabilities, it is essential to facilitate access to and enlargement of the current collections. The Marrakesh Treaty gives us this opportunity, which is why I strongly call once again for it to be ratified and entered into force as soon as possible.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support that blind people have easy access to literature and that an extensive interpretation of copyright does not prevent the dissemination of literature. However, given that many Member States have a different view of copyright protection and do not want to ratify the Treaty, the EU cannot impose this treaty on states against their will. I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty allows the blind and visually impaired and other people with reading difficulties to fully exercise their right to freedom of expression. It is important to facilitate access to published works to the blind, visually impaired and to persons who for some other reason cannot use the standard press. I supported the proposal for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, as people with disabilities should be given the right to education without discrimination. It is necessary to ensure that laws protecting intellectual property copyright do not constitute an obstacle to people with disabilities in their access to cultural and other printed materials.  Devastating is the fact that less than 5% of published books in the world are available in alternative formats for the blind, visually impaired and disabled in general, and this situation must change urgently.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities recognises the right to education (Art. 24) and the right to participate in cultural life (Art. 30), without discrimination and in equal opportunities. At the same time, only 5% of all published books in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are in accessible reading formats, with over 26 million visually impaired people in Europe alone. On 27 June 2013, the Marrakesh Treaty laying down an international legal framework ensuring the application of restrictions or exceptions to copyright for the benefit of the blind was signed. Its signing has raised doubts that the problem of the blind is being used to completely weaken copyright protections, which has negatively affected the ratification process.  My Colleagues in the European Parliament have adopted a resolution on ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible. There are seven EU Member States that form a blocking minority and hinder the ratification process. I join the European Parliament's call for laws protecting intellectual property rights not to serve as an unjustified barrier to visually impaired people's access to cultural material.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Marrakesh Agreement, signed on June 28, 2013, is the Marrakesh Agreement, which facilitates access to printed works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or print-insuance for other reasons. The idea was to make it easier for copyright holders to be granted permission to print texts in specialised formats that could also be read by visually impaired and print disabled persons. In the case of the EU in particular, the problem is that, while the EU and its Member States signed the Treaty in April 2014, there are still seven countries that actually block full ratification of the Treaty. Currently, only 5% of all published books in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are accessible to people with visual impairments. In Europe, there were 2.55 million blinds and 23.8 million visually impaired people in Europe in 2010 – a total of 26.35 million. In other words, the fact that we are still not fully ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty and not going to implement its principles intensively is simply disgusting and completely unlogious, given the existing long-term efforts of the EU and their Member States to maximise the rights of all their citizens.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Marrakesh Treaty of 2013 obliges the parties to introduce in their legal systems an arrangement allowing the cross-border dissemination of available printed, literary works of art in formats (braille, éclarg, enlarged font) available to authorised persons. These are people who have reading problems, blind, low vision and people with reading disabilities. Ratification of the Treaty will contribute to facilitating and improving the lives of these people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakes Treaty, on the basis of the petitions submitted, and in particular Reference 924/2011, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this ratification. The Marrakesh Treaty allows for the creation of copyright exceptions to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in a format designed to be accessible to blind or visually impaired people, and to people whose physical disabilities prevent them from holding or manipulating a book.  In any case, this treaty can only enter into force once it has been ratified by 20 Member States, but at the moment seven Member States seem to be blocking ratification.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I warmly welcome the ratification of the Treaty of Marrakesh. The World Health Organization estimated in 2010 that across Europe there are 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 partially sighted people, giving a total of 26 350 000 visually impaired individuals yet only 5% of all published books in the developed countries and less than 1% in the developing countries are ever produced in accessible formats.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased that Parliament is finally working on the Marrakesh Treaty, which gives basic accessibility to millions of people with visual disabilities in the EU. We must do everything in our power to make the world accessible to all those with visual disabilities. This is a decisive step in this direction, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty is intended to ensure that intellectual property rights do not constitute disproportionate or discriminatory obstacles to access to cultural goods by persons with disabilities. It also calls for the ratification process to be speeded up in this respect. I therefore agree with this request.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I am voting for this resolution, which calls on the Council to ratify as soon as possible the Marrakesh Treaty aimed at facilitating access to printed texts for the blind and visually impaired. Only 5% of all published books exist in Braille. Associations have been campaigning for several years now to put an end to this "famine of books" which introduces a profound inequality from school.  But the real point of this story is that seven Member States, including Germany, are holding back and prefer to wait for the revision of the Copyright Directive. As a result, the European machine is stalling because the Commission would have to ratify this treaty on behalf of all the Member States. It is a fine example of what I denounce. France must disobey and ratify this treaty for its people without delay.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to facilitate the ratification of this treaty, I voted in favour of this resolution. I agree with its content in favour of people with disabilities. It would allow copyright exceptions for these individuals, which would facilitate the provision of works published in formats that are appropriate to them. As a result, I vote for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on the basis of the petitions received, in particular petition No 924/2011. Blind or visually impaired persons must have access to published works and other printed products. It is regrettable that only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of those published in developing countries are produced in accessible formats. The EU and the Member States are part of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. For this reason, the EU should ratify and implement the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because people with disabilities should have access to equal access to education and opportunity and I will continue to work to this end.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union and member states signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 and have made a political commitment to ratify it. This treaty aims to facilitate access for the blind, visually impaired and other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works. The World Health Organization estimated in 2010 that there were 2,550,000 blind people and 23,800,000 visually impaired people across Europe. In addition, only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are produced in accessible formats. The European Union should therefore be encouraged to take all appropriate measures to ratify and implement this treaty as soon as possible and also to ask the Council and Member States to speed up the ratification process. I support this project because it is important that the right of people with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities is respected.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – People with visual impairments overcome a number of obstacles that make their lives difficult. This is also difficult in accessing published works, the availability of which is taken for granted by healthy people. While there is legislation in most countries that allows access to works in the corresponding formats, the problem lies in making works available from abroad. The Marrakesh Treaty is of great benefit to all people with visual or other disabilities, which prevents them from accessing information, because it is she who solves the release of the international movement of works and also allows access to foreign literature. I find the unnecessary delays in ratifying the Treaty explicitly cruel to anyone who needs this help. I therefore support the motion for a resolution tabled in an effort to make life easier for millions of people.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Worldwide 285 million people are visually impaired and yet only 5% of published books in Europe are available in an accessible format for them. The Marrakesh Treaty will help improve access to books, education and cultural content in formats such as Braille, large print, e-books and audio books with special navigation tools. This will create equal opportunities for millions of visually impaired people around the world. It will improve their lives by helping them become independent and self-reliant through education and empowerment. The Marrakesh Treaty is the instrument visually impaired people have been waiting for to facilitate delivery of accessible format books that people with disabilities need for education, employment and full social inclusion. Therefore, I voted in favour of Parliament’s resolution calling for widespread ratification and implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty which will have a huge impact and improve the lives of people with print disabilities.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. The Marrakesh Treaty on facilitating access to published works for the blind, visually impaired and unable to use printed text was adopted on 27 June 2013. The Treaty was signed by the EU and its Member States in April 2014 and thus a political commitment to its ratification. However, seven EU Member States have formed a minority group which is hampering the process of ratifying the Treaty, despite world health organisation estimates in 2010 that there are around 26 350 000 visually impaired people in Europe on whose behalf a number of petitions for access to books and other printed products have been submitted. The report of the Committee on Petitions recommends that the European Parliament express its deep indignation in this resolution and call on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process, not to tie it to a review of the EU legal framework or to a decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union. I supported the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union and member states signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 to create copyright exceptions to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind and visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book.  For the time being, the Council of the European Union would like to include the provisions of the Treaty in the new Copyright Directive, rather than ratifying the Treaty. But the revision of this directive could take time. The Marrakesh Treaty illustrates Europe's failure to defend the disabled. It is not yet ratified, probably because it limits copyright. It therefore runs counter to important interests: those of authors, publishers, translators.  It is therefore proposed to vote in favour of ratification.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Articles 24 and 30 of the Un Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities highlight the right of persons with disabilities to education, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while ensuring that legislation protecting intellectual property rights does not constitute an excessive or discriminatory obstacle to access by persons with disabilities to cultural materials. According to estimates by the World Health Organisation, 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 people were blinded in Europe in 2010 and 23 800 000 people were blinded and 23,800 000 people were visually impaired. And only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are produced in accessible formats. The EU and the Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 and therefore made a political commitment to ratify it; however, there is a blocking force of seven Member States which impedes the ratification process. I believe that the Council and the Member States should speed up the ratification process with a view to further integration and enable all citizens to be treated equally.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote aims to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty adopted in 2013. The latter introduces copyright exceptions to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind and visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book. I have decided to vote for this text, which slightly limits the excessive expansion of copyright.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Council and Member States to speed up the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty aimed at facilitating access for the blind, visually impaired and other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works. The aim is to allow cross-border exchange, within the Union and between the EU and third countries, of books in Braille or large print, digital or digital books with special navigation tools, produced under copyright exceptions. The European Union signed the treaty in 2014, which must be signed and ratified by each member country to be implemented. The current French government is conditioning this ratification on the amendment of the 2001 European Directive on the Disability Exception and thus blocking this process, which I deplore. The World Health Organization estimated in 2010 that there were more than 26 million blind and visually impaired people across Europe. However, only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are produced in formats accessible to people with this type of disability.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the petition for ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, which goes in the direction of greater protection of the right to read for disabled citizens.  The copyright exception made by the Treaty is of paramount importance, allowing for greater dissemination of books in formats accessible to the visually impaired and to people who cannot read on paper. It is important to point out that the Treaty also introduces the possibility of exchanges of books at transnational level, in order to promote the dissemination and sharing of books, which contribute to the enrichment of the cultural heritage of people with visual disabilities. The ratification of this Treaty is significant because it is the right response to the too small number of books published in a version accessible to the blind and visually impaired. Fortunately, this Treaty has already been ratified by a number of Member States, although delays persist in some key States, which we are calling on today to work to speed up the ratification procedures. The European Union wants to be at the forefront, especially in the area of the protection of rights, and the Marrakesh Treaty goes in this direction.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, calling on the Council and Member States to speed up the process to ensure respect for the right of people with disabilities to access education and culture, as well as the protection of intellectual property rights.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion because the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty is intended to safeguard intellectual property rights. It also aims to ensure access to cultural goods for people with disabilities. Overall, it calls for the ratification process to be speeded up in this respect.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Marrakesh Treaty concerns the simplification of access to published works for people with visual impairments and the disabled who prevent the reading of printed works. It is regrettable that seven Member States of the European Union have so far not ratified the Treaty. Given the fact that only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are produced in a format suitable for visually impaired people, it is important that these Member States, as soon as possible, ratify the Marrakesh Treaty so that it can enter into force.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that since 2011 the EU has been bound by the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and that at present blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts do not yet have full access to books and printed material, I therefore consider ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, as supplemented by petitions, to be inevitable. My vote can therefore only be positive.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the resolution to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty in the light of the petitions received, in particular petition No 924/2011, because I want an EG equal opportunities for the blind and visually impaired. The Convention represents a step forward in increasing equality between the blind and the visually impaired and aims to raise the percentage of adjusted books issued above 5%.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ People with disabilities strive for full civic status, active participation in society, equalisation of opportunities and independent living aimed at improving its quality. This implies inclusion in all segments of life and society. I consider the right to education free of discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities for all blind and visually impaired people to be one of the basic rights that must be enabled, not only for the benefit of the blind and visually impaired, but of the entire community.  I believe that every state must take all possible measures to provide an adequate educational program, which would be accompanied by also adequate educational materials, all persons who want to work on their education, especially people with disabilities. Ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty would achieve certain conditions that would help overcome the problems that blind and visually impaired people encounter on a daily basis, and the denial of printed materials in the language of the blind would have extremely detrimental consequences for the entire community.
