Therefore, I fully support the resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty and call on the EU Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the treaty and unblock the ratification process.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In 2010, the World Health Organisation estimated that there were 2 550,000 blind people and 23 800,000 visually impaired people in Europe, making a total of 26 350,000 blind and visually impaired people,. At the same time, only 5% of books are produced in developed countries in the available form and as much as less than 1% in developing countries. I therefore agree with the fact that the process of ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, signed by the EU in June 2014, must be accelerated.  I point out with dissatisfaction that seven EU Member States form a blocked minority that prevents the treaty ratification process. The blind, visually impaired and persons who for some other reason cannot use the press must have equal access to books and printed material in order to participate fully and effectively in society. The Marrakesh Treaty is a human rights issue, I hope to ratify soon for the sake of fair protection of these rights.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Marrakesh Treaty is to facilitate, through copyright exceptions, the development of accessible versions for people with visual difficulties of books originally protected by intellectual property laws (copyright), in a context in which only a small fraction of books are published in response to that need.  The EU and most of its Member States have signed the Marrakesh Treaty and have made a political commitment to ratify it. The resolution expresses outrage that 7 Member States form a blocking minority which prevents the ratification of the Treaty and recalls Articles 24 and 30 of the UN CRPD: the right to education of persons with disabilities, without discrimination and on an equal opportunity basis and access to cultural goods.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010, the World Health Organization estimated that 2,550,000 blind people and 23,800,000 visually impaired people live in Europe, for a total of 26,350,000 people with visual disabilities. Only 5% of all books published in developed countries, and less than 1% of books published in developing countries, are available in accessible formats for people with visual disabilities. I support this motion for a resolution in order to speed up the process of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access to the reading of printed texts of blind people.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At its meeting of 17 September 2015, PETI heard petition 924/2011 by Dan Pescod (United Kingdom) on behalf of the European Blind Union (EBU) and the Royal National Institute of the Blind (RNIB) on access to books and other printed material. In view of the numerous petitions on this subject, PETI members expressed their concern at the council's failure by the Council of the European Union to approve the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on facilitating access to published printed works for blind and visually impaired persons and persons with print disabilities (Marrakesh Treaty). Although many EU Member States have already implemented this Treaty, seven of them have still not done so. The resolution calls for faster ratification of the Treaty, without having to wait for a ruling by the Court of Justice of the EU, given the importance of the Treaty on blind and visually impaired persons and persons with print disabilities, and the fact that waiting for a ruling by the Court of Justice would significantly delay ratification. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the request to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty. To date, 79 countries have signed the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access for the blind, visually impaired and other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works, but it must be ratified for its provisions to enter into force. European citizens were right to call on us, through a petition to the European Parliament, to ask for an acceleration of the process. We have therefore been responsible for pushing for ratification to accelerate. This shows the effectiveness and relay role that the petition gives to European citizens.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The World Health Organisation estimated that in 2010 there were more than two and a half million blind people and about 23 million people with visual impairments in Europe – representing a total of 26 million and 350,000 visually impaired people. In addition, only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of those published in developing countries are produced in formats accessible to those same people. This report, which I have approved favourably, strengthens and highlights the right to education of persons with disabilities, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while ensuring that legislation protecting intellectual property rights does not represent an excessive or discriminatory obstacle to access by persons with disabilities to cultural materials. Furthermore, the report notes with deep indignation that seven EU Member States have formed a blocking minority that impedes the process of ratifying the Treaty; calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process without making ratification dependent on the revision of the EU legal framework or the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution by which Parliament urges the Council and the Member States to speed up the process of ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, since the EU and the Member States signed the Treaty in 2014, but that seven Member States have not yet ratified it, which keeps its entry into force blocked. As it has done on previous occasions, Parliament calls for rapid ratification of the Treaty, in order to facilitate greater distribution and easier access to books in formats accessible to the blind or visually impaired, more than 26 million in the European Union, which are limited to their right of access to culture since only 5% of books published in developed countries are presented in formats accessible to them.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to facilitate access to books and other printed books and other printed works for people who are blind or visually defiant. In Europe, there are more than 26,350,000 visually impaired or blind citizens. However, only 5% of all books published in the Member States (and... less than 1% in developing countries) are produced in accessible formats. The text I voted on deplores the fact that seven Member States of the Union have formed a blocking minority to obstruct the ratification process of the Treaty and calls on the Council to speed up this ratification.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it points out that the EU and the Member States adopted in April 2014 a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. signed the Marrakesh Treaty and thus made a political commitment to ratify it. However, seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that hinders the ratification process of the Treaty. This resolution calls for a solution and ratification of the Treaty at last.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported this motion for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, taking into account petitions received by European citizens, in particular those with inability to read. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to facilitate access to works published with those with visual impairments and which are estimated to be more than 26 000 000 in Europe. Currently, only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% of those published in developing countries are produced in accessible formats, so in the name of equality, non-discrimination and the right to education, we cannot accept the delay in ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, which the EU and the Member States have already signed in April 2014 , nor make it dependent on the revision of the EU legal framework. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access for the blind, the visually impaired and those with other difficulties in reading printed texts to published works.  The treaty currently has 79 signatories and the European Union signed the text on 30 April 2014. Nevertheless, each Member State must now also ratify the treaty and the process is long.  While only 1% to 7% of works published worldwide are made available in accessible formats, it is urgent that all parties ratify this treaty as soon as possible in order to ensure indiscriminate access to cultural products.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, since the Treaty has already been signed by EU Member States, to facilitate access to published works for blind or visually impaired persons, and we welcome the EU's ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. We believe that all Member States should respect the rights of access to culture of all people on an equal footing and facilitate access to it for those with disabilities, in this visual case, and that intellectual property rights cannot be a barrier to discriminating against this group. Therefore, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the signing of this Marrakesh Treaty, we support the ratification of this Treaty by the EU.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I support this resolution because it is important to protect disabled people in the EU.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Only 5% of all books are published today in formats available to people with visual impairments, and in many countries they are even less widespread. For people with visual impairments, this is a fundamental obstacle in terms of accessibility to education and full participation in society. I therefore supported the European Parliament's call for EU Member States, including the Czech Republic, to ratify the Treaty as a lasting result.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the consideration of the call for the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to be unlocked for Member States to implement a number of measures aimed at facilitating access to printed works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or other impaired to access printed text. Although the EU and Member States signed the Treaty in April 2014, a minority of seven Member States (including the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy) are blocking their entry into force at the European Council.  I believe that this Resolution is positive as yet another pressure mechanism to unlock final ratification and implement these measures as soon as possible , including the adoption of exceptions to state copyright laws aimed at facilitating the distribution and reproduction of Braille works — which would positively affect almost twenty-five million European citizens.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Petitions Committee has tabled this short motion for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. In particular, it calls for the Council to accelerate the ratification process, as it was signed two and a half years ago, and I want to put pressure on the Member States who have not yet ratified the Treaty, hence I voted in favour of this short motion for a resolution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Marrakesh Treaty is a treaty to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. In my opinion all people, disabled or not, have the same rights to access published works. However, we have to wait for the decision of the court to see where the competences are. Therefore I abstained.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the World Health Organisation estimates that we have around 2.5 million blind people and almost 24 million low vision in Europe. In addition, we have only 5% of books in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries made in available formats for the visually impaired. As EU Member States are parties to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and since the Marrakesh Treaty was signed by the Member States as early as April 2014, I agree with the call for individual countries to ratify the Treaty as soon as possible. The Marrakesh Treaty was created as an initiative to ensure non-discriminatory access to education for persons with disabilities. It aims to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise affected by a reading disorder. We therefore call on the Member States not to block the ratification of this Treaty, but, on the contrary, to speed up this process without making it subject to the revision of the EU legal framework and to delay it unnecessarily. Everyone has the right to education and access to cultural goods, regardless of their health restrictions.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Marrakesh Treaty is the first international agreement in the field of intellectual property rights which takes priority over the public interest rather than the interests of rights holders. After all, any commercial advantage must not prevent the blind and partially sighted and those with other reading difficulties from having free access to books accessible to them and from sharing them internationally. Currently, only 5% of books published in developed countries are available in accessible formats, while there are more than 26 million blind and partially sighted people in Europe alone. Ensuring effective equal opportunities cannot be done through sound statements, but through such concrete actions, and the attitude of some Member States to this issue is therefore appalling.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. According to 2010 World Health Organisation estimates, there are 2,550,000 blind and visually impaired people in Europe, which represents a total of 26,350,000 blind and visually impaired EU citizens. Despite such a large number, only 5% of all published books are available to the blind and visually impaired in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries.  The EU and its Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014, making a political commitment to ratify it. The motion for a resolution expresses deep outrage that seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that makes it impossible to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty. It therefore calls on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process without requesting a preliminary review of the EU legal framework or a decision of the Court of Justice of the EU. I believe that the motion for a resolution under consideration is an important reminder that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to which the EU and the Member States are parties, provides for the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities.  However, the Convention also ensures that laws on the protection of intellectual property do not unreasonably or discriminatoryly impede access to cultural material by persons with disabilities. I agree that the Member States must ratify the Marrakesh Treaty as soon as possible, which is why I voted in plenary.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In 2010, the World Health Organisation estimated that there were 2 550,000 blind people and 23 800,000 visually impaired people in Europe, making a total of 26 350,000 blind and visually impaired people. In developed countries, only 5% of books are produced in the available form and as many as less than 1% of books are produced in developing countries.  The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCPRD) highlights the rights of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, while ensuring that laws protecting intellectual property rights do not constitute an unreasonable or discriminatory barrier for people with disabilities when accessing cultural materials, and therefore supported the resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Marrakesh Treaty provides for facilitating access to books and other traditionally printed materials for visually impaired and blind people. Less than 5% of all materials in the world are available for this many and vulnerable group, while the situation in underdeveloped and developing countries is far worse than the global average.  The agreement is based on author's exceptions to facilitate the creation of available and accessible versions of books and other author's works. The international community has made great efforts to reach this agreement, and certain member states in the Council are stalling ratification. The treaty complies with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and needs to show more political will to apply it. I support the ratification of the Marrakesh treaty because equality of chance is something we must strive for, and by delaying the ratification of this treaty, the EU, as a veteran of human rights, is stalling on the application of it.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty on the basis of petitions received, in particular petition 924/2011. More than two years after the signing of the Marrakesh Treaty, some Member States have not yet ratified it. I believe that the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty, which brings facilitate access to literary works for people with reading difficulties, must be accelerated. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities also provides for the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities. Because, according to the data, only 5% of all published books are available in accessible forms in developed countries and only 1% in developing countries. In Slovenia, for example, the proportion of printed books that are accessible to the blind and visually impaired is only one to two percent, which is a very worrying figure.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The right of disabled people to benefit from measures to ensure their autonomy, social and professional integration and participation in social life is undeniable.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a multidimensional political project that places particular emphasis on ensuring equal rights among its citizens. A clearly disadvantaged category in our societies is one that includes blind, partially impaired or reading difficulties. Currently, according to World Health Organisation estimates, there are a total of 2,550,000 blind people and 23 800 000 people with partial views in Europe. At the same time, however, only 5% of all books published in developed countries are currently accessible to visually impaired people (Braille alphabet).  Petitions by EU citizens, and in particular Petition No. 924/2011, addressed on behalf of the European Union of the Blind, highlight the problems that exist in this area. The Marrakesh Treaty, signed in April 2014, including by the EU and the Member States, aims to facilitate access to published works by all visually impaired people. The implementation of the provisions of this Treaty within the Union cannot be done if the document is not ratified by all EU Member States. In these circumstances, it is necessary to coordinate the efforts of all European decision-makers to support the elimination of this obvious discrimination of visually impaired people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which, on the one hand, recalls that Articles 24 and 30 of the UN Convention underline the right of persons with disabilities to education, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, and the need to ensure that laws protecting intellectual property rights do not constitute an unreasonable or discriminatory barrier to access to cultural products for persons with disabilities , and, on the other hand, notes with deep indignation that seven Member States of the European Union have formed a minority bloc that is obstructing the ratification process of the Treaty. We call on the Council and the Member States to speed up the ratification process, without subjecting ratification to the revision of the EU's legal framework or to the decision of the European Court of Justice.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution urging EU Member States to accelerate the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. Indeed, only five per cent of the literature published in Europe is published in accessible formats, adapted for blind and visually impaired persons, such as Braille, large print and audio books. The Marrakech Treaty adopted in summer 2013 allows for literature adapted for visually impaired persons to be freely used across borders without having to take copyright rules or other trade restrictions into consideration. However, ratification of the Treaty is still blocked by a minority of EU Member States and, therefore, the agreement has not yet entered into force in the EU.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council and the Member States must speed up the process of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty in order to guarantee the right to education for persons with disabilities, without discrimination, while also ensuring that intellectual property laws do not constitute an unreasonable or discriminatory barrier to access to cultural materials by blind people with visual disabilities or other difficulties in reading printed texts. This is a necessary step to ensure that millions of people who are both the and the visually impaired throughout the world have access to education, culture and leisure.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities, as proposed by the PETI Committee (Petition 924/2011), urges the Member States that are blocking the minority in the European Council not to further impede the ratification process. Although the Treaty was adopted in June 2013, it has still not been ratified by the European Union, mainly due to disputes between the European Commission and the Council (e.g. competence and certain enforcement-procedural issues). However, the draft decision is outdated because of the formal information provided by the Luxembourg Presidency, since on 14 July 2015 the European Commission appealed to the Court of Justice of the EU to provide guidance on the scope and nature of the Treaty. On the other hand, in October 2015, the European Commission promised to come up with a concrete legislative proposal to settle the disputes, which is of guarantee importance for the future proper implementation of the Convention. From this moment on, we are facing a legal issue, not a political one, which is also a condition for ratification. Against this all, I have now abstained in the vote, continuing to support swift, effective ratification, guaranteeing clear implementation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. Two years after the signing, the Marrakesh Treaty has not yet been ratified. Despite the support of the European Parliament, the Commission and the vast majority of member states, several major EU Member States oppose ratification and block the Council's compromise. This delay in ratification means that today 250 million blind and visually impaired people, as well as other people who are unable to use standard printing, are still unable to have as much access to books, information and published papers as other people have. This undermines almost every right guaranteed by the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, from education, information to political participation.  Access to culture and information is a fundamental human right, and the Marrakesh Treaty is the first stage in exercising these rights. However, without ratification everything remains only on words. The delay was caused by a lack of political will, not a legal obstacle. It is time for the EU to bridge the gap between words and deeds and fulfil its obligations to people with disabilities.  The European Union and all Member States should set an example for their nationals on how to integrate people with disabilities into society and facilitate their everyday life, not complicate it further. Therefore, I fully support the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty and urge all institutions to do so as soon as possible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 216(2) of the Rules of Procedure on ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on the basis of petitions received, in particular, I supported petition 924/2011, as I believe that, in a time of high technological progress, people with disabilities such as visual impairment and blindness (of which, according to the World Health Organisation, there are around 26 350 000 in Europe) should be given the same access to education as others.  The fact that only 5% of all published books are available in accessible formats in developed countries today, and even fewer in underdeveloped countries, is truly worrying. That is why I support the call for seven Member States to speed up the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty, which they are delaying.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, since the Treaty has already been signed by EU Member States, to facilitate access to published works for blind or visually impaired persons, and we welcome the EU's ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. We believe that all Member States should respect the rights of access to culture of all people on an equal footing and facilitate access to it for those with disabilities, in this visual case, and that intellectual property rights cannot be a barrier to discriminating against this group. Therefore, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the signing of this Marrakesh Treaty, we support the ratification of this Treaty by the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to create copyright exceptions to facilitate the reproduction, distribution and provision of works published in formats designed to be accessible to blind and visually impaired people. This also applies to people whose physical disability prevents them from holding or handling a book. The treaty will not enter into force until 20 ratifications have been completed. It would appear that seven EU Member States have obstructed the ratification of the Treaty. The Marrakesh Treaty illustrates Europe's failure to defend the disabled. It is not yet ratified, probably because it limits copyright. The resolution proposed for vote is intended to facilitate ratification of the treaty. I'm voting for.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The World Health Organisation estimates in 2010 that there are 2 550 000 blind people and 23 800 000 visually impaired people in Europe, which represents a total of 26 350 000 visually impaired people. The so-called Marrakesh Treaty, signed by the EU and the Member States in April 2014, is about facilitating access to published works for people who are blind, visually impaired and unable to use printed text. A commitment has been made to ratify this. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying the Marrakesh Treaty, since the Treaty has already been signed by EU Member States, to facilitate access to published works for blind or visually impaired persons, and we welcome the EU's ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. We believe that all Member States should respect the rights of access to culture of all people on an equal footing and facilitate access to it for those with disabilities, in this visual case, and that intellectual property rights cannot be a barrier to discriminating against this group.  Therefore, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and the signing of this Marrakesh Treaty, we support the ratification of this Treaty by the EU.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution urging EU Member States to accelerate the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. The Marrakech Treaty adopted in summer 2013 allows for literature adapted for visually impaired persons to be freely used across borders without having to take copyright rules or other trade restrictions into consideration. The problem is that ratification of the Treaty is still blocked by a minority of EU Member States and, therefore, the agreement has not yet entered into force in the EU. The lack of commitment by EU governments to reach an agreement on the Treaty is a clear violation of the right to easily accessible information, which is an important part of the UN Convention on Rights for Persons with Disabilities. I believe that after four years it is time to find a political solution in support of blind and visually impaired persons’ right to accessible literature.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this act, Parliament intends to confirm its willingness to make progress in the process of ratification by both the Council and the Member States of a Treaty whose main objective is nothing more than to facilitate reading to blind people around the world. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of this ratification.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This resolution calls on the Council to urgently speed up the ratification process of the Marrakesh Convention as it was signed two and a half years ago. At the same time, we are also calling on the Member States, which have not yet ratified the Treaty, to do so urgently. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. According to 2010 WHO data, it is estimated that in Europe there are 2 550 000 people blind and 23 800 000 partially blind, totalling 26 350 000 people. On the other hand, only 5% of books published in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries are published in accessible formats. The EU and the Member States signed the Marrakesh Treaty in April 2014 and made a political commitment to ratify it. It is regrettable that seven Member States form a blocking minority which prevents the ratification of the Treaty. The Marrakesh Treaty has been considered a milestone of positive paradigm shift both with regard to the international regulation of the copyright and intellectual property rights system and with regard to concern for accessibility and the rights of persons with disabilities.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty is intended to ensure that intellectual property rights do not constitute disproportionate or discriminatory obstacles to access to cultural goods by persons with disabilities. It also calls for the ratification process to be speeded up in this respect. I therefore agree with this request.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, which provides for the right of blind and visually impaired persons to education, without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities. With this resolution, the European Parliament notes with deep indignation that seven EU Member States have formed a minority bloc that hinders the ratification process of this treaty.  According to the WHO, in 2010 there were a total of 2 550 000 blind and 23 800 000 persons with partial vision in Europe, a total of 26 350 000 visually impaired persons. Only 5% of all books published in developed countries and less than 1% of books published in developing countries are produced at any given time in formats accessible to the blind or visually impaired.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. – Our primary concern is the smooth living of our fellow citizens, especially those who need us most. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution of the Committee on Petitions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Participation in cultural life remains one of the key elements of community life. The Treaty of the World Intellectual Property Organisation on facilitating access to published printed works for the blind and visually impaired and persons with print disabilities puts the right to participate in cultural life and the rights of users as such at the heart of its interest and is to establish an international standard for the use by persons with visual impairments of works published in print and protected by copyright law. According to the WHO, there are 285 million people with visual impairments worldwide today. Despite the law in many countries providing for easier access to blind and visually impaired works, no more than 5% of printed publications in the world are available in formats that enable them to become familiar with the content. The need for the Marrakesh Treaty thus appears to be pressing.  The ratification procedure for the Treaty is necessary at both European Union and signatory level and will require the introduction or adaptation of a number of provisions. However, it should also be stressed that the need to ensure satisfactory, fuller access to printed material for persons with visual impairments should go hand in hand with protecting publishers' interests in the production and distribution of printed work formats.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on the basis of the petitions received. I think that, in view of the lengthy process of ratifying this agreement, as well as the fact that the PETI Committee has received a number of petitions on this matter, it is appropriate that we adopt an opinion in the plenary of the European Parliament on this issue. The Marrakesh Treaty deals with blind people's access to books and other printed documents, and extending the ratification process is certainly not in the interests of respect for their rights. In this matter, the Council and the Member States should take measures to unblock the ratification of the Treaty, as well as encourage Member States that have not yet ratified the Marrakesh Treaty to do so as soon as possible.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament resolution on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty on facilitated access to published works for the blind, visually impaired persons and persons with other reading disabilities. The EU and its Member States are also signatories to the UN CRPD, which obliges them, inter alia, to provide the right of persons with disabilities to education without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunities, and that laws on the protection of intellectual property will not unreasonably or discriminatoryly impede access to cultural material by persons with disabilities. Only 5% of all published books are available to the blind and visually impaired in developed countries and less than 1% in developing countries. It is therefore necessary to take all appropriate measures as soon as possible to ratify and implement the Marrakesh Treaty.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106: authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Food safety must be a priority for the European Union. The placing on the European market of food and feed based on or containing genetically modified soya is a very sensitive subject that affects the lives of millions of citizens on a daily basis. I voted in favour of the objection procedure for the placing on the market of these products because Bayer's application for authorisation risks endangering the health of European citizens.

name: Tim Aker and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Bayer CropScience AG to the competent authority in Belgium. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and isoxaflutol. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans.  Indeed, I am deeply opposed to the introduction of new GMOs on the market. In addition, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment which highlights, among other things, relevant observations from Member States in this direction. Although I regret that this text has only symbolic significance because it is not binding on the Commission, I support this objection.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this objection resolution. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 the Commission has made authorisation decisions on new GMOs without the support of the Member State committees.  This situation was intended to be an exception in the legislation, which has unfortunately become the norm. Commission President Juncker has failed to fulfil the promise he made as a candidate for the Presidency of the Commission to fix this democratic deficit in decision-making for GMOs in the European Union. The Commission is therefore authorising the placing on the market of products with a system which it itself has recognised is flawed. It is essential that the Commission now comes up with a real proposal on GMOs to correct this democratic deficit.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of objecting in accordance with Article 106, which refers to genetically modified food and feed and asks the Commission to come up with a new one. In the meantime, any new provision on GM food/feed should therefore be adopted in accordance with the current legal framework, which the Commission recognises is not working satisfactorily. Approved soybeans are resistant to certain herbicides, so its cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment or even to human health.  In accordance with Article 11 of Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003, the Member States shall, in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 11 In the case of implementing acts, the European Parliament may, at any time, designate to the European Commission a draft implementing act which goes beyond its implementing powers. The Commission should then review the draft implementing act, taking into account the position expressed, and may maintain, amend or withdraw it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament rejects a Commission decision to allow glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans across the EU. In view of the fact that the plant protection product glyphosate in particular has been classified by the World Health Organisation as potentially carcinogenic, and that I generally reject GMO foods because of the unknown long-term consequences, I fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests and, in the short term, those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary to ask that authorisations be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Therefore, I very logically voted in favour of the objection to the introduction of genetically modified FG72 soybeans.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106; I am concerned by the increasing usage of delegated acts and am therefore minded to support any objections as a matter of course. In this instance, I note specifically that the World Health Organization has described these specific varieties as being potentially carcinogenic to humans.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. With regard to my general position on GMOs, I am against the precautionary principle that prevents research in Europe. Moreover, I am surprised at the hypocrisy of banning the marketing of these products, which Europe then allows itself to import. Nevertheless, I voted against the introduction of this pesticide-resistant variety, as it is considered by many research centres, including Lyon, to be a variety that could be dangerous.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal requesting the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision concerning the authorisation of genetically modified soybean FG72. The draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with EU law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation No 1829/2003 and Regulation No 396/2005, which aims to establish a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Bayer CropScience and Monsanto. All three are tolerant to glyphosate, with another characteristic for Monsanto's two GMOs: different fatty acid composition for GMO MON 87705 × MON 89788 and dicamba tolerance (a pesticide) for GMO MON 87708 × MON 89788. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven). As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, the assessment provided by EFSA remains manifestly unsatisfactory.  Alas, the objections to the acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission and the amendments that my group has tabled - to make the objections binding and to remind us that the Commission is not even waiting for the end of the objection procedures to publish the GMO authorisations - have unfortunately been rejected.  Their rejection, recorded by roll call vote, thus shows the hypocrisy of elected officials who are in fact against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs. However, GMO authorizations should be able to be issued by delegated deed and not by deed of execution.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The introduction of herbicide-resistant genetically modified organisms can pose a serious threat to the health of European citizens and the environment. I have today voted in favour of objections to the authorisation of three types of GENETICALLY MODIFIED soya, including FG72, because I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. With regard to soya FG72, in particular, concern concerns the presence of 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins which give tolerance to herbicides based on glyphosate and isoxaflutol. In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a who's specialised body, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Given the potential danger to health, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs and feed from GMOs as soon as possible, in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to explain that I voted against my group's line in this report on the objection raised on the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72. The Basque Country is a GMO-free region and, as I did in 2015, I voted in favour of the ENVI Commission's motion for a resolution which considers that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not consistent with EU law as it is incompatible with the purpose of several Regulations. I therefore support the request for withdrawal of the draft Implementing Decision.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's objection to the Commission's address to a marketing authorization for products relating to genetically modified FG72 soybeans.  Indeed, despite repeated warnings from Member States and the concern of consumer protection associations, the European Food Safety Authority - which bears its name badly - is insisting on marketing this modified soybean, for the benefit and sole interest of Monsanto. Note that this genetically modified FG72 soybean is of course tolerant to glyphosate, a total herbicide that Monsanto markets under the "Roundup" brand, which remains the most widely used herbicide in the world and which, according to recent studies, would have tumor and toxic effects.  Once again, the Commission shows its willingness to submit to the major industrial groups, to the detriment of European economic interests but also of food safety and health in Europe.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified soya FG72.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Bayer CropScience AG to introduce the FG72 GM soybean variety in Belgium. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it criticised, did not approve the Commission's implementing decision and requested the submission of a new draft decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybeans. In 2011, Bayer CropScience AG submitted to the competent authority of Belgium an application for placing on the market of foods, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from FG72 soybean. The request refers to genetically modified soy synthesized protein, which makes soy resistant to glufosinate herbicides and isoxapafufloil herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (specialised World Health Organisation Cancer Agency) classified glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I have supported the proposed objection to the authorisation of the MST-FGØ72-2 GM soy bee, as I am very reluctant to grow GMos as long as there is the lowest risk to human health. I myself am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, and we must also respect the majority will of European citizens who are against the use of GMOs in Europe. I am aware that soybees are one of the raw materials that we produce the least in Europe. Almost all of this is imported from third countries, where they produce mostly GMO soy bees. However, perhaps Europe could become more interesting by producing soy without GMOs, thus increasing its own production of this culture and reducing its dependence on external markets. In addition, we would also take into account the wishes and expectations of our citizens.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with our priorities for the protection of health and food safety, I agree with the commission's proposal voted on today. I would also like to reiterate the need for the Commission to draw up a new proposal for GMOs in food and feed, which will take a deeper look at their environmental and human health impact.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO food authorisation system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  For five years, Member States could not agree on the granting or refusal of an FG72 soybean licence. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The three GMOs of soybeans proposed by the Commission to allow the importation have properties that serve only the interests of Monsanto and possibly industrial producers. I consider that, once again, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment of the risks involved and that the objections proposed by the ENVI Committee are well founded. For all these reasons, I voted FOR these objections.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision on genetically modified soya FG72 does not comply with EU law as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consists, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, in providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. I therefore believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to allow the marketing of three new types of genetically modified soybeans from the US company Monsanto. It is in this context that this objection is intended to signal Parliament's opposition to the marketing of these three genetically modified organisms (GMOs), which are tolerant to glyphosate. One of them also has a tolerance to the pesticide dicamba.  While this objection will not force the Commission to abandon the commercialisation of these GMOs, we consider it essential to support it in order to show Parliament's disapproval of the Commission and EFSA, whose assessments are unsatisfactory and do not take into account the comments of the Member States' authorities.  That is why I voted for this objection.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The health of its citizens and the protection of the environment have always been important objectives for the European Union. In order to guarantee them, more attention is needed to foods that end up being produced, marketed and consumed within its borders. At the production stage, the risks to be monitored are related to genetically modified organisms. Of these, genetically modified soybeans MST-FGØ72-2 contain a protein that confers tolerance to glyphosate herbicides, or this substance is classified as likely carcinogenic to humans. However, no study confirms this, with no scientific arguments linking glyphosate to the occurrence of cancer. I support a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environmental and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, and I believe that this can be achieved while ensuring the efficient functioning of the internal market. I voted against the objection to the draft commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or manufactured from genetically modified soybeans FG72 (MST-FGØø72-2).

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Since the adoption of Directive (EU) 2015/412, which allows Member States to ban the cultivation of authorised GMOs internally, the Commission, although permanently deadlocked in the competent committee due to cross-vetoes, has been unblocking all pending GMO authorisation procedures. That is why the ENVI Committee is systematically proposing objections to any new authorised GMOs. Unfortunately, in these cases Parliament's objections are not binding on the Commission, since they are implementing acts.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection concerning the authorisation of genetically modified soya FG72.  In June 2011, Bayer CropScience AG submitted an application to the competent authority of Belgium for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified soya. This type of soya expresses a protein that gives tolerance to herbicides based on glyphosate, a substance that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified as probably carcinogenic to humans. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not therefore appear to be in accordance with EU law, as it does not guarantee a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, nor the effective functioning of the internal market.  Consequently, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection to this draft implementing decision by asking the Commission, as indicated in the motion for a resolution, to present a new legislative proposal that takes account of the frequently expressed national concerns about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment and the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution for the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision as amongst other matters it does not aim to sufficiently protect human health. Genetically modified foods still raise concerns and it is questionable whether they are safe for human consumption.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution opposes the Commission's proposal to authorise the placing on the market of food and feed containing glyphosate-resistant transgenic soya. This opposition is mainly based on the fact that transgenic soya resistant to the action of glyphosate has recently been classified as probably carcinogenic. In view of the serious risks that may arise from the use of this product, I voted in favour of the resolution opposing the Commission's initiative.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the proposal, taking into account the concerns often expressed at national level concerning issues related to the safety of genetically modified organisms for health or the environment.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the objections raised to the authorisation of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans. As is easily understood, this issue concerns the entire population of Europe, as it directly affects the public health sector and any approval must be given after thorough discussion and research in order to ensure the health of citizens.  In fact, the decisions we will take are of particular importance, as the genetically modified food sector can potentially cause major turbulence in Europe's economy as well. In this light, I believe that the objections raised are correct and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with EU law as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulations (EC) No. Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consist of providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was not easy to decide what to vote on this objection, because there is always the dilemma between science and belief, modernity and tradition, experimentation and tranquility. In this particular case, I voted in favour of the objection, so that the authorisation should not be granted, because I have serious doubts about the way in which this product enters the food chain and I would like to have had time to inform myself better, which is not allowed by the timing of the procedures for approving the Delegated Acts of the European Commission.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this objection as individual GMOs and the GMO combinations in question have been authorised by the Commission and deemed safe for human consumption by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA). This objection is an attempt to change the system of authorisation by those who are opposed to GM. Member States can decide whether to cultivate GM crops or not. There is no commercial cultivation of GMO products in Ireland, nor is there any expected in the short to mid-term given the lack of relevant GMO products on the market.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution seeks to place on the market products containing genetically modified soybean. The production of goods containing genetically modified ingredients is not limited to consumption or use in one State as this facilitates the development of GMO trade across borders. This will make it impossible for those Member States who ban the sales and use of genetically modified products to effectively take such health—related decisions.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution aims to block the Commission's proposal to place on the market feed and food derived from, consisting of or obtained from FG72 soya. On 24 June 2011, Bayer CropScience AG submitted an application for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or obtained from glyphosate-resistant soya FG72. The Commission's proposal to grant authorisation was discussed in the Standing Committee in 2015, but neither a majority for nor against was obtained. Since the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the WHO's specialised institute, has classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic, I am voting in favour of the resolution and am therefore opposed to the placing on the market of soya FG72.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Bayer CropScience AG to the competent authority in Belgium. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and isoxaflutol. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Last October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on genetically modified food and feed, and asked the Commission to come up with a new proposal. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework, which the Commission acknowledges is not working well. The soybeans in these three authorisation processes in question are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. I voted in favour of the objection, because I believe that the Commission should review the draft implementing act, taking account of the position expressed.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the objection resolution to the authorisation of soybean FG72. I believe that it is absolutely vital for public confidence that in Europe we have a GM regulation system that is underpinned by science. This means that products passing a robust, independent safety assessment should have fair market access. The European Food safety agency has declared this GM trait safe for food and feed use, and we should respect that decision made by experts, otherwise we risk undermining not only our own credibility but also the principle of science-based decision-making.  The use of GM material in animal feed is significant across the EU, and our livestock sector is heavily dependent on imported GM feed materials, so it is important that EU GM authorisations proceed as rapidly as possible to keep pace with authorisations in other parts of the world and avoid significant disruption in the international trade of agricultural commodities, which could have a negative impact on food prices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This proposal for objection by a member of the Socialists and Democrats group concerns the Commission's draft decision in favour of authorising GMO FG72 soybeans tolerating glyphosate in food and animal products. The rapporteur argues that glyphosate is a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). However, this justification is questionable. On the one hand, the European Commission's draft decision follows the positive opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Its conclusions are based on a large number of studies, including those of the IARC, and scientific data as explained by the authors in an exchange of views with MEPs last December. On the other hand, the Commission has respected its mandate as part of its enforcement power, which stems from European legislation, approved by the European Parliament. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the many precautionary measures voted by the European legislator in this area. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I believe in science-based policy; to this extent I believe that it is the task of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to decide whether a genetically modified organism is safe and fit for consumption. The EFSA advice should be the basis for the final decision. Since the EFSA advice was positive, I voted against this objection.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of three genetically modified soybeans tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to isoxaflutole and herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. The risk assessment carried out has a number of shortcomings, including: • in field trials, the control of FG72 soybeans was not an isogenic line, but a selected uncontected conventional line;  • when examining the internal components, phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, FG72 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. In 2015, the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'This resolution not only opposes the authorisation of a specific GMO on the EU market, but also advocates a de facto moratorium on GMOs pending a new approval procedure and a referral to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.000. The N-VA did not support the objection.  The approval procedure for GMOs is strict. The EFSA risk assessment plays a crucial role in this. The N-VA strongly believes in science-based and evidence-based policies. Adopting the text before us would undermine EFSA's credibility.  Moreover, the European Commission has not exceeded its mandate in this executive action: if the Member States do not achieve a qualified majority, the European Commission is authorised to approve GMOs on the basis of a positive opinion from EFSA. With regard to glyphosate, it is noted that there is no scientific consensus. I recognise the concerns about glyphosate and call for the discussion on this controversial substance to be further and further deseeded.  It remains important to distinguish between GMO technology and application. It is also clear that the (possible) use of GMOs should always be part of an agricultural policy that integrates the protection of public health, the environment and biodiversity, with an integrated pest control system (integrated pest management) essential for the sustainable use of pesticides and non-chemical alternatives.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the objection of the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) against three European Commission decisions authorising the marketing of animal feed containing GM soybeans produced by Monsanto and Bayer. These three genetically modified soybeans have the distinction of developing a tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides, including Monsanto's Roundup, a substance classified as probably carcinogenic by the World Health Organization. I believe that the three authorisation decisions are not compatible with the European Union's objectives on human and animal health, as defined in legislation. That is why I welcome today's vote and the clear majority that has emerged to veto the European Parliament's marketing of genetically modified soy products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto, tolerant to glyphosate. GMO B has a different composition in fatty acid and GMO C is a tolerance to the pesticide "dicamba". To the extent that these properties are intended only to serve Monsanto's interests, and EFSA has not taken into account the relevant views of the States, I have naturally voted in favour of these objections. Finally, our three amendments were aimed at ensuring that authorisations take the form of delegated acts, in order to ensure democratic control over the marketing of GMOs.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I and the party I represent – THE MRRO, we are against any genetically modified food and feed. In a draft decision, the Commission shall announce the authorisation of the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2). GMOs are not a solution for what we eat or what we feed the animals we consume, and that is why I oppose it always and everywhere.  For me, citizens' health is more important than trade and competitiveness. Recently (in October 2015), I rejected the EC's proposal that each country be able to decide for itself whether to authorise or ban GMOs. To some extent, the proposal was very attractive, but virtually unworkable, because of the EU single market.  I have always been a supporter of the overall ban on GMOs across the European market so that our citizens know that their rulers put their health first and I think this is the only policy we can have on this issue. In the present case, I voted in favour of the objection leading to a ban on the placing on the market of GMO soybeans.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of products from genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to isoxaflutole and herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. The risk assessment carried out has a number of shortcomings, including: • in field trials, the control of FG72 soybeans was not an isogenic line, but a selected uncontected conventional line.  • when examining the internal components, phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, FG72 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. In 2015, the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The process of authoring GMOs in Europe is not democratic. In this case, as in all previous clearance cases, the Commission acted unilaterally despite the fact that the proposal had not been adopted by the technical reference committee. I therefore supported the objection to the authorisation of GM FG72 soya, not least because of the scientific doubts that GMOs entail. In fact, the soybeans in question express the 2mEPSPS protein that gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides and the HPPD W336 protein that gives tolerance to herbicides based on isoxaflutol. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised body of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I am opposed to the introduction of GMOs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the FG72 was submitted by Bayer to the competent authority in Belgium on 24/6/2011. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee of 18/11/2015 having been assessed with "no opinion", as has been the case since this procedure was agreed. This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation of a decision, on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised, nor to renew the old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection as I feel the technology is being used to help multinationals dominate the food market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion objecting to any new authorised GMOs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as it proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of products from genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on genetically modified (GM) food and feed and asked the Commission to come up with a new one. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework which the Commission acknowledges is not working in a satisfactory way.
