The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to isoxaflutole and herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. The risk assessment carried out has a number of shortcomings, including: • in field trials, the control of FG72 soybeans was not an isogenic line, but a selected uncontected conventional line.  • when examining the internal components, phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, FG72 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. In 2015, the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of the draft Commission Implementing Decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybab under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council, that the Commission implementing decision does not comply with EU law as it is incompatible with the objectives of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. On the basis of the above, I call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection by considering that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision lays the ground for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumers' interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed , while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I strongly supported the proposal to reject the adoption of the delegated act on the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soya relating to the three patents presented today. In particular, I agree with what was said in the text on the principle of caution on GMOs, as we MEPs voted on a few weeks ago when we examined the proposal to amend the 2003 regulation on GMOs.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified soya FG72, because I believe that the European Commission must present a new comprehensive proposal on GMOs and feed originating from GMOs and carefully assess their environmental and health impact. I think, in fact, that the European Parliament clearly expressed its opposition to the Commission's proposal on GMOs in the vote last October. Indeed, many doubts and questions remain, not even in relation to the established practice of adopting delegated acts on GMOs in the absence of a technical opinion from the Scientific Committee representing the Member States. The introduction of pesticide-resistant GMOs, such as genetically modified soya FG72, poses environmental and health problems, leading to an increase in the use of pesticides. I believe that these concerns must be addressed by EFSA and the Commission with appropriate impact assessments and, above all, require comprehensive, clear legislation that takes due account of the concerns of our citizens. Pending this legislation, therefore, I believe it is necessary to reject the implementing decision proposed by the Commission.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the objection under Article 106: Authorisation of genetically modified fg72 soya beans. The Family Party of Germany is opposed to the use of genetically modified seeds in agriculture.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding GMOs, I support the existing, science-based decision-making process, judged independently by the European Food Safety Authority. The Commission needs to make a proposal which includes a greater assessment of the environmental impact of GMOs.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow the importation of three new GMO soybeans, all tolerant to glyphosate. One of them is a soy from Bayer Cropscience. I supported this objection in committee and in plenary, not least because glyphosate weedkillers are carcinogenic according to the World Health Organization. It should also be stressed that EFSA's assessment is unsatisfactory and does not take into account the observations of the relevant agencies of the Member States.  Nevertheless, the European Commission can ignore these objections, as GMO authorisations are its sole authority. It demonstrated this last December by authorising a new GMO maize, the NK603xT25, despite opposition from the European Parliament. That is why it is necessary that these authorisations are now under the democratic control of Parliament, which I have proposed by way of amendments to amend the GMO authorisation regulation and replace enforcement acts with delegated acts. Indeed, the objections voted by Parliament can put a real veto on the Commission's decisions.  But when it comes to asking for real democratic measures, especially when it comes to GMOs, this Parliament is decidedly absent subscribers.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament should be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this objection because I do not believe the Commission should authorise the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM soybeans in food and feed.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Commission’s proposal on authorisation of genetically modified soybean FG72 as well as placing products that consist of or were produced from genetically modified soya. The main reasoning behind this comes from the possible threat of cancer for humans because of the chemical composition of genetically modified soya.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to herbicides active in isoxaflutole and glyphosate. There are a number of shortcomings in the risk assessment carried out.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. The herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO in 2015. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, A GM products should not be authorised in the European Union which have not been thoroughly examined from a health and environmental safety point of view. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore did not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, and I supported the objection.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given our opposition to GMOs, we supported the three objections in this area. In October last year, the Commission's proposal on GMOs was rejected by the EP. Through these objections we want to put pressure on the Commission to make a proposal that respects the right of Member States not to allow the movement of GMOs on their territory.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to isoxaflutole and herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. The risk assessment carried out has a number of shortcomings, including: • in field trials, the control of FG72 soybeans was not an isogenic line, but a selected uncontected conventional line;  • when examining the internal components, phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, FG72 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. In 2015, the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The environmental impacts of GMOs must be assessed through a new proposal from the Commission for GMO food and fodder.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. My vote clearly goes against the objection of approving three varieties of gene soya on the grounds that not all chances of progress can be built up by rejections. Basically, a new technology must always be accompanied by a risk assessment. What makes me think, however, is that the opponents of genetic engineering themselves reject free-range experiments for a scientifically based risk assessment. For this reason alone, I consider some of the reasons for rejection to be ideologically advanced. Of course, I believe that the protection of citizens' health is a top priority. My decision is also scientifically supported, even if even the Food Safety Authority (EFSA) voted in favour of the approval of the three soybean varieties, as it did last November.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing the genetically modified FG72 strain (MST-FGO72-2), consisting of or manufactured under Regulation (EC) No 1000/2013. 1829/2003 Of Parliament and the Council, as this requires the Commission to withdraw its draft decision.  The genetically modified strain in question contains certain substances that are very likely carcinogenic to humans. In this context, the proposed national prohibition on the sale and use of the same would be unenforceable, even though the cultivation takes place exclusively on the territory of one Member State, as trade in products takes place beyond national borders.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary to ask that authorisations be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Of course, I voted in favour of the objection to the introduction of genetically modified FG72 soybeans.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the report of my colleagues Bart Staes, Sirpa Pietik-inen, Guillaume Balas, Lynn Boylan and Eleonora Evi on the objection in accordance with Article 106 concerning the authorisation to market products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans. Indeed, some political groups led by the Greens accuse the Commission of failing to comply with the authorisation procedure for genetically modified organisms. However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a study that concluded that this product is safe for humans, animals and the environment. Above all, the authorisation to market is currently the responsibility of the Member States. This resolution was adopted, which I regret.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though as this vote is an objection to an implementing act, and this objection might be more of a political move made by different groups in the chamber, EH Bildu has maintained a coherent position on matters related to GMOs and always votes against those, or, as in cases such as last December with maize NK603*T25, vote in favour of objections to allowing the authorisation of GMOs. The genetically modified MST-FGØ72-2 soybean, as described in the application for authorisation, expresses the 2mEPSPS protein which confers tolerance to glyphosate herbicides and HPPD W336 protein which confers tolerance to isoxaflutole herbicides; whereas the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised cancer agency of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. Therefore, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this objection, and will keep voting in the same way to any future objection concerning authorisation of GMOs, as we would like to put pressure to the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal that is more satisfactory than the one rejected by Parliament last October.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This objection has been lodged by some political groups who believe that the European Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of genetically modified FG72 soybeans.  However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a comprehensive and proper study to authorise this soy. Moreover, if the authorisation to grow GMOs is granted at European level, it is the States that retain control over the marketing authorisation. I therefore voted against this objection, which was purely declaratory, unfounded and has no legal effect.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 We voted today on motions for resolutions in which the European Parliament opposes the European Commission's implementing decisions allowing products containing genetically modified soybean varieties to be placed on the market. As we know, the basic component of feed is protein, mainly that contained in soy bean shot. However, despite the increasing production of soybean in the European Union, we are not able to cover the need for high-protein feed components necessary for livestock production. That is why the EU imports huge quantities of soybean (14 million tonnes in 2015-2016) as the second importer in the world. Almost all imported soybean is genetically modified soybean, nearly 30% cheaper than unmodified soybean. The conclusion is therefore extremely simple: if we prevent the import of cheaper soybean without being able to produce large enough quantities to cover its own demand, the European Union will be forced to import much more expensive soy or increase imports of meat that has, after all, been produced using genetically modified soybean. The European economy will suffer severe losses, farmers will lose revenue and consumers will, in the end, still consume products containing genetically modified organisms. I therefore do not support the opposition of parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that Europe should use the latest science to develop its agriculture and compete internationally, while ensuring food security for its citizens.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution on the problem of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The Rejection of GMOs throughout Austria must be accepted by the Commission. This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to withdraw immediately the implementing decision approving the genetically modified maize variety NK603xT25. Instead, a new legislative proposal is to be presented, which responds to the concerns of the countless Member States, which are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported resolutions B8-0135/2016 and B8-0134/2016, I supported and also voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution calling for the withdrawal of the Commission Implementing Decision permitting the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified soybean FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2). The European Commission must come up with a better proposal on authorisation procedures. The current proposal does not address the often expressed concerns about the potential health and environmental risks of GMOs. The consequences that products containing GMOs can have on humans and the environment are not yet sufficiently identified and there is too much uncertainty for genetically modified products.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection in order to express my opposition to authorisation of these varieties of GM soybean.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FG72 genetically modified soy produces 2mEPSPS and HPPD W336 proteins, making it resistant to isoxaflutole and herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. The risk assessment carried out has a number of shortcomings, including: • in field trials, the control of FG72 soybeans was not an isogenic line, but a selected uncontected conventional line;  • when examining the internal components, phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, FG72 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  During its cultivation, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. In 2015, the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Motion for a Resolution deals with the draft Commission decision that authorises the placement on the market of products containing or produced from genetically modified FG72 soybean. According to the International Agency for Research on Cancer, soybean contains a protein that confers tolerance to glyphosate, which is probably carcinogenic to humans. Given that fact, this Motion underlines the non-conformity of this draft decision with the general European principles for ensuring a high level of protection of human and animal health, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and calls on the Commission to withdraw it. This is the reason why I voted in favour.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against a resolution opposing the possibility of trading in products containing modified FG72 soybean, as the content of this resolution is a threat to the interests of Polish farmers. Genetically modified soybean is a rich source of protein and an essential component of feed used in poultry farming. Poland, as the largest poultry producer in the region, has the chance to maintain its position only if the competitive conditions of producers are maintained. The GMO Scientific Panel of the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) has published three scientific opinions on the safety assessment of m.in. genetically modified soya FG72 and SOYA MON 87705 × MON 89788, which confirmed the safety of both grains for health and the environment compared to their unmodified counterparts. However, modified soybean is cheaper, thus its availability affects the competitiveness of agricultural production.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against this objection. Genetically modified soybeans MST-FGØ72-2express the 2mEPSPS protein that gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. In this regard, I have a duty to specify that, on 12 November 2015, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) updated the toxicological profile of glyphosate. The joint review team has come to the conclusion that glyphosate is unlikely to be genotoxic (i.e. dna damage). Finally, I would like to point out that EFSA has established an acute reference dose (DAR) for glyphosate of 0.5 mg per kg of body weight. This is significant as this is the first time such an exposure threshold has been applied to a substance.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission asked us to allow the importation of three glyphosate-resistant transgenic soybeans. Glyphosate is a herbicide recognized as a carcinogen by the World Health Organization. Despite these recommendations, the European Health Authority (EFSA), whose relationship with the GMO industries has too often been demonstrated, continues to regard it as non-harmful. So I voted against those authorizations. They are dangerous, do not respect the precautionary principle and undermine the European position against GMOs to promote trade at the expense of our health. EFSA's positions in favour of GMOs are becoming increasingly problematic. EFSA must take into account the concerns of citizens and, above all, thoroughly review its assessment procedures, which are playing into the hands of the big multinational seed companies.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the section 106 objection to the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans. The Commission proposes to allow genetically modified FG72 soybeans. This GMO is tolerant to glyphosate, which is probably carcinogenic to humans. As with previous GMO authorisation cases, EFSA (Europesan Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including ignoring relevant observations from Member States. Unfortunately, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. This is the purpose of the amendment of the ENL Group, which draws attention to this fact and calls for the authorisations to be issued in the form of delegated acts.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The impact of GM foods on human health is questionable. I therefore support the consumer having information on whether the product is natural or genetically modified. I support the idea that it should be up to individual Member States whether or not to authorise the import of GM products. I am not joining the appeal to ban the import of these foodstuffs across the EU across the eu. I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Bayer CropScience AG sought approval in June 2011 to market food, food and feed ingredients containing FG72 strain. The FG72 strain contains a protein that also has glyphosate in it. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, an agency of the World Health Organization specializing in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances that are probably carcinogenic to man.  Parliament found in October 2015 that although cultivation takes place on the territory of one Member State, the Commission's prohibition on use and sale is unenforceable because it would require the reintroduction of border controls on imports. The Commission is being asked to withdraw its draft decision and to present a new legislative proposal on the amendment, taking into account national issues that do not relate only to problems related to the safety of GMOs for health and the environment.  I did not support the proposal for an objection in accordance with Article 106, because I think it is important to ensure the protection of the health of all EU and Croatian citizens.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This complaint concerns the Commission's wish to authorise the placing on the market of the genetically modified soybean MST-FGØ72-2 produced by Bayer CropScience AG in foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs. One of the reasons why the European Parliament voted against was that these beans are synthesized by the protein 2mEPSPS, which confers resistance to glyphosate herbicides, while on 20 March 2015 the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a suspected carcinogen in humans. In view of the above, and in view of the fact that the Commission's proposal is not in line with Union law, such as Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the amendments of which, on a proposal from the Commission, the European Parliament refused to approve in October 2015, it was also not possible to vote in favour of the Commission proposal this time, so I voted in favour of the EP's rejection decision.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in 2015, the World Health Organization's Specialized Agency for Research on Cancer included genetically modified FG72 soybean among the substances likely to have a cancer-forming effect on humans. The Belgian company has requested approval to place this soybean and its products on the market. I support the proposal for the Commission to withdraw its proposal for an implementing decision authorising the placing and use of this product on the market unconditionally. National bans on the placing on the market of such products are ineffective and uncontrollable in times of free trade, so such a decision must be taken at EU level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution based on objections pursuance to Article 106 on the draft Commission implementing decision approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybeans FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this objection. The European Commission is proposing to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto. These three GMOs, which include FG72, have the characteristic of being tolerant to glyphosate, a property that serves only the interests of Monsanto and industrial producers. In addition, EFSA (the European Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including excluding relevant observations from Member States.  We therefore support this objection.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this objection because I do not believe the Commission should authorise the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM soybeans in food and feed.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the motion for a resolution tabled pursuant to Rule 106: authorisation of genetically modified soya. In addressing such an issue, it is clear that, in addition to compliance with EU law, the primary need is to guarantee high levels of protection of life and human health, also taking into account the welfare and health of animals, and to take due account of the interests of consumers.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission's decision authorising imports into EU countries of three types of genetically modified soybean FG72. The EC's authorisations for the marketing of food and feed containing The FG72 of Genetically Modified Beans by Monsanto Europe S.A. do not comply with the principles laid down in EU legislation to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests. SoybeanS FG72 are genetically modified to become resistant to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer by the World Health Organisation as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans. On the basis of the scientific conclusions on the negative effects of GMOs and taking into account the negative human opinion on GMO products, the European Commission must review the authorisation procedure and present a new proposal allowing decisions on GMOs to be taken by the Member States themselves. Until a new regime is agreed, the Commission should not issue new authorisations, and I will never accept attempts to do so.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution opposes the Commission's enforcement decision authorizing the marketing of products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans (MST-FG-72-2). Indeed, this GMO soybean, as described in the application, expresses the protein 2mEPSPS, which confers tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate. However, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), the World Health Organization's specialized agency for cancer research, classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the exploitation of Europe by foreign interests. The properties of this GMO soybean serve only Monsanto's interests and, in the short term, those of industrial producers. These GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, although its assessment of GMOs has been widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of identifying elected representatives who are against the "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  I of course voted in favour of the objection to the introduction of FG72 soybeans.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted negatively on the marketing authorisation of products containing, consisting of, or produced from, fg72 genetically modified soya (MST-FGØ72-2) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The motion for a resolution is to ask the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision by presenting a new proposal which may reflect all the concerns expressed in various Community regulations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. When the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) published its full study at the end of July 2015, the European Commission asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to take it into account as part of its assessment of glyphosate renewal at European level. A Belgian toxicology expert collaborated on EFSA's analysis of the study. The company finally published its opinion on glyphosate on November 12, 2015 and concluded that glyphosate is unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard to humans. EFSA was based on the report of the rapporteur Member State, Germany, but also on the relevant studies published over the past ten years and with the cooperation of representatives of the Member States' risk assessment bodies. This conclusion, while contradicting the IARC's opinion, confirms the conclusions of the majority of international toxicology bodies.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Members of the European Parliament, who are also members of the ENVI Committee and of which I am one, have previously expressed serious concerns about the impact that the Commission's proposal has on the functioning of the internal market in food and feed. I am of the opinion that the Commission's proposal has a negative impact on imports of products, which may adversely affect the Economy of the European Union. In practice, the proposal would inevitably have to lead to the resumption of border controls, which is impossible in view of the European Customs Union. Member States often express their comments in this area, but they do not sufficiently deal with the Commission's proposal in question. I consider it essential for the Commission to make proposals that take account of Union law while taking into account the requirements of the Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected the authorisation of genetically modified soybean FG72. The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bayer CropScience submitted to the competent authority of Belgium an application, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, to place on the market foodstuffs, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of, or produced from FG72 soya. This genetically modified soya MST-FGØ72-2, as described in the application, expresses the GAT protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide glyphosate, which, according to the classification of the International Cancer Research Centre, is probably carcinogenic to humans. I believe that the European Union must ensure the protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests, especially with regard to genetically modified food and feed. I hope that the Commission will present a new proposal for a legislative amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and to take into account the concerns of the World Health Organisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. These votes are intended to signal the European Parliament's opposition to the introduction of three new GMOs by way of importation. This is the GMO FG72. Indeed, the Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto that serve only the interests of this multinational company. As usual, EFSA has provided incomplete explanations that do not take into account the relevant comments of the Member States. It is therefore the whole process of granting authorisations that is at issue, since a study to question EFSA's action will be produced with a view to rejecting the budgetary discharge of this uneasy agency. However, these objections from Parliament are likely to remain a dead letter as they are not binding. That is why the ENF group has tabled three amendments calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts rather than in the form of enforcement acts.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection by the Socialists, the Greens, the far left and supported by the extreme right, concerning genetically modified FG72 soybeans. These groups based their objection on the fact that the European Commission exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of products containing this genetically modified soybean variety, consisting of or manufactured from this genetically modified soybean. Unfortunately, this objection was adopted, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity, and while the Commission complied, before issuing its proposal for authorisation, with the procedure in place for GMOs, based in particular on an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority on the safety of the plant on human and animal health, as well as on the environment. This proposal was forwarded to the Council, which did not reject it.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans, which were wrongly charged with a so-called non-compliance with the Commission's powers. The authorisation to market these products was carried out within the scope of the Commission's powers. Moreover, the objection does not have to be to me, as the Member States themselves determine whether or not the authorisation is applied. I therefore voted against a baseless symbolic objection to support the work of the European Commission.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Motion for a Resolution with regard to the authorisation of placing on the market products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified soybean FG72. The report states that the implementing decision is not consistent with Parliament’s and the Council’s Regulation on ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring effective operation of the internal market.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution of the Committee on Environment and Society Health to withdraw the draft Implementing Decision of the European Commission on the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from MST-FGØ72-2 soybeans.  According to scientific information, this type of soybean helps to express the protein 2mEPSPS, which gives resistance to the herbicide glyphosate, and the protein HPPD W336, which gives resistance to isoxaflutol-based herbicides. The International Agency for Research on Cancer classifies glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans. I believe that even that alone is a sufficient argument to reject such a proposal.  In addition to the scientific justification, much of the public opinion is increasingly strongly opposed to the use of GMOs techniques and technologies. On the eve of the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, this became clear enough.  I think it is socially irresponsible in the name of public health to allow such a culture within the EU or any Member State.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the European Union must have one point of view on the problems faced by all its countries. There are values to which we all tend, as peoples, and I am referring here to the need to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environmental and consumer interests, when we consider genetically modified food and feed. It is an area where I believe that we must not venture without having concrete data on the long-term implications. Thus, the call on the European Commission to withdraw its draft decision entitles the use of the genetically modified soybean plant to be used is, in my opinion, a beneficial one for the future of the EU.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against proposals to object to the authorisation of GM soybeans. All three species whose authorisation is in question are characterised by resistance to herbicides and are therefore well placed to grow them effectively. Applications have also been scientificly assessed at european level (GMO panel of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA)) and at national level, and these assessments have been in their favour. I therefore consider the vote to be a position motivated by political and not factual and technical reasons.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision and instead present a new legislative proposal, including the concerns of Member States that specifically oppose genetically modified organisms. Consequently, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support it because it is not necessary to decide on the placing on the market of each GMO product separately. A holistic approach is needed and the entire legal regulation of GMO products should be reviewed.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – It is essential that a high level of protection of people's lives and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests is ensured throughout the EU. It is therefore necessary to prevent the application of attenuating conditions and exemptions for the adoption of favourable decisions on GMOs. With a single EU market, the conditions of competition must be the same for producers, taking into account not only economic but also social and ecological principles. Genetically modified soybeans may not be allowed to be placed on the market. First of all, there is too little information and reliable scientific evidence to suggest that GMOs and food produced from them are completely harmless to the surrounding environment or to us. Moreover, it is not clear what consequences GMOs will have in the near future, and all the more so we cannot predict what future we are building for our offspring. In this context, I support the proposal calling on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2), I consider the choice to be appropriate to the regulatory provisions of the European Union. Therefore, I cannot support the objection and vote against it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission, authorised to import and use three types of SOy bee for food purposes, does not provide sufficient protection for the health of European citizens, who are overwhelmingly opposed to GMO, and I therefore supported the objection to the enforcement of the permit. The FG72-type GS is immune to the herbicide glifozate used in cultivation and is most likely carcinogenic to animals and also to humans, according to a specialised WHO agency.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing the genetically modified FG72 strain (MST-FGØ72-2), consisting or manufactured. In the genetically modified strain MST-FGØ72-2, and as described in the application, the protein 2mEPSPS is expressed, which causes tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate.  The International Agency for Research on Cancer, a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, placed glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be carcinogenic to humans on March 20, 2015, and on September 4, 2015, the California Office of Environmental Hazard Assessment for Health (OEHHA) also issued a notice of intent to add glyphosate to the list of chemicals of that federal state known to cause cancer. I consider the use of potentially carcinogenic substances in the environment to be a risk that is not justified.  Similarly, I consider that by rejecting the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013, 1829/2003 a situation arisen in which, until the adoption of the new proposal, the right of Member States to independently decide on the use of GMO food and feed on their territory and to monitor their decisions effectively is not guaranteed. In view of the above, I supported this objection.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Since the genetically modified strain of MST-FGØ72-2 expressed protein 2mEPS, which causes tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate, and the HPPD W336 protein, which causes tolerance to herbicides containing isoxaflutol, and that the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a World Health Organisation agency specialising in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be carcinogenic to humans, I consider that the Draft Commission's implementing decision does not comply with Union legislation , which entails ensuring a basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to GM food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.  There are several laws regulating GMO in Croatia, these new laws which are in some respects more restrictive than EU law. In countries where this type of legislation is in force, public debate and public consensus are more necessary for the authorization of the mentioned species, which was not there, which is why I agree with the proposed objection.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the FG72 was submitted by Bayer to the competent authority in Belgium on 24/6/2011. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee on 18/11/2015 and was assessed with "no opinion", as has happened since this procedure was agreed. This resolution opposes the adoption of the draft implementation of a decision on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised or renewed old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection because I have doubts about the use of genetically modified foods, and this also applies to FG72 soybeans. I am also aware of some of the advantages of GMOs, but personally some possible negatives prevail with me.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I objected to this objection because the arguments developed by the European left, which is largely at the origin of it, are false. The Commission has in no way exceeded these powers to authorise the marketing of these products. I would remind you that this is just an authorization. Effective marketing still depends on the states, and therefore on governments.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the assumption that the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from, genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) appears to be in line with EU law, in particular, in addition to the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed, I voted against this resolution which, pursuant to Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure, asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of ‘Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties.’ Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans to be imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with UNION law, as it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and the Council. In this way, and taking into account the need to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market, I support the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybeanFG72 (MST-FGØ72-2), in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the Commission should be asked to submit a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon this afternoon, mePs in the European Parliament have said no to the authorisation to market three types of GMO soybeans. The first objection concerns genetically modified soybean fG72 adopted by 427 votes in and 237 against. It was unilaterally authorised by the Commission on 18 November 2015. It is true that the marketing request for food ingredients and feed containing FG72 soybeans was made in June 2011 by Bayer CropScience to the Belgian authorities and that this file could not remain forever blocked.  But if the European Parliament has opposed the Commission, it is less to relay the rejection of a majority of European citizens towards GMOs than to underline the specific characteristics of FG72 soybeans, which are tolerant to herbicides containing glyphosate. However, this active substance, which is commercially found in roundup weedkiller for example, was classified as a "probable carcinogen" for humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization. This is a sufficient reason, coupled with a mistrust of the Commission, which uses and abuses this procedure for authorising GMOs for importation without any democratic legitimacy.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Commission doesn't care about the world. It has been condemned by the European Court of Justice for failing to define criteria for endocrine disruptors and would like to accept three glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans. This active substance found in Monsanto's herbicide RoundUp is itself an endocrine disruptor that has harmful effects, particularly on human reproductive functions. In addition, two of these soybeans are marketed by Monsanto, which would definitely win on all fronts. We were not elected to serve the interests of this delinquent multinational.  As long as the European legislation governing the authorisation of GMOs remains so lax and the Commission is outlawed, we will reject GMOs as a whole, especially when they are tolerant to chemicals poorly regulated by European law. We have already taken this position to the European Parliament in October 2015.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the same way as the objection to genetically modified maize passed last December, I supported the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified FG72 soybeans.  Rejecting the new GMO marketing authorisations is a way for our Parliament to send a clear message to the European Commission to review the current GMO authorisation process. This process is neither satisfactory nor democratic, as each authorisation decision has been adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of the Member States and by ignoring the opinion of Parliament. I would also like to point out that public opinion remains negative about GMOs, that the risk assessment is considered insufficient and the absence of a 90-day toxicity study.  Finally, I think the precautionary principle here is justified given the tolerance of the soybean in question to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance being evaluated that could be harmful to health.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Bayer CropScience AG to introduce the FG72 GM soybean variety in Belgium. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At noon, I voted for the European Commission not to allow the use of three genetically modified soybeans that tolerate glyphosate in food and animal products. Glyphosate has been classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO) since 20 March 2015. These three genetically modified soybeans that have already been authorised by the EU executive in food and animal products are FG72, MON 87708 x MON 89788 and MON 87705 x MON 89788. In today's vote, of course, I supported each of the three objections that call for their rejection.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I do not understand why the European Commission does not want to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed. The EC approved soya, which is "enriched" with not one, and two new proteins, one determines the resistance of soya to glufosanate and the other to another herbicide isoxoflutol. Glufosinate was added to the list of the 22 most dangerous chemicals as early as 2009 and the European Parliament had already voted not to extend these substances when it expired. I hope that the EC will hear Parliament's position and will not allow this soybea to enter the EU.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This objection concerns the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soya. Since this type of soybean is resistant to glyphosate (herbicide), it is natural that the products that contain it have traces of it. On 11/11 last, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) concluded that glyphosate is unlikely to be genotoxic (i.e. harmful to DNA) or pose a carcinogenic threat to humans – with just one vote against. However, there is a divergent opinion on the possible carcinogenic hazard/effect of glyphosate by the International Cancer Research Centre (WHO Agency) which has classified it as likely to be carcinogenic to humans (20/03/2015).  It should also be noted that this is an implementing act – the competence of which belongs to the European Commission. To that extent, both arguments were being comweighed, the fact that new legislation on GMOs is being prepared and the fact that the Ppe group did not object to the delegated act, on the basis of the opinion of the EFSA, I decided to abstain.  It also seems clear to me that EFSA and WHO should immediately initiate contacts to harmonise their position on this matter.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 There are still a lot of uncharted risks associated with genetically modified foods. It is not just a question of how these products affect human health, but how they affect the environment as a whole. It is worth remembering that GM varieties are a new thing. Long-term research data are not available. We simply do not know how exposure will affect people or nature over the decades. When deciding on access to the market for new GM products, we should therefore be very careful. Lack of information and irreversibility of decisions taken are major risk factors. It is essential that all solutions are made safety first. For these reasons, I decided to vote in favour of development proposals and, at the same time, of traditional and safe food production.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to protect the health of citizens, I felt it appropriate to support the objection to the authorisation of this type of genetically modified soya.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament should be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 The draft implementing Decision of the Commission is not in line with EU law as it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2003 on the common organisation of the market in beef and veal [1]. It is therefore necessary to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the efficient functioning of the internal market.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. "I voted against the objection to approving the genetically modified soybean, mainly because we have to trust science, i.e. if the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) considers, after evaluation, that a crop is safe, this is what we should start from and nothing else. With a growing population and increased climate threats, modern plant breeding is needed in Europe. This includes modern techniques for breeding arable crops and other plants that can feed the world's population and can contribute to a better climate.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Bayer CropScience AG to the competent authority in Belgium. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and isoxaflutol. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection, because I believe - like my other Socialist colleagues in the chamber today - that the Commission needs to come forward with a new proposal for Genetically Modified Organisms used in food and feed, one which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of the GMOs. Fully informed and scientifically guided decision making process with regards to GMOs that responds to public expectations is required and that is what my Labour colleagues and I are supporting today.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ by resolution of the European Parliament, we asked the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which takes into account the frequently expressed comments made by Member States, which do not only concern safety issues of GMOs for health or the environment. Genetically modified soybean FG72 expressed a protein allowing tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides and HPPD protein W336 allowing tolerance to isoxaflutol herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer — the World Health Organisation's specialised agency for cancer research — included glyphosate among substances with a likely cancer-forming effect on humans.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of GM crops is very technical and therefore, in my opinion, it should be primarily up to biology and genetics experts to assess whether a given GM food is dangerous or not. In these three cases voted on today by the European Parliament – namely mon 87708, 89788, 87705, 89788 and FG72 – we have the conclusions of the European Food Safety Authority, and in the Czech Republic the scientific committee on GM food and feed examined these crops. Neither of these professional institutions sees any health risks in them. Although I believe that restraint and caution are needed in the introduction of GM foods on the market, as the field of genetics is still evolving, albeit very quickly, I also believe that European legislation is sufficiently prudent in this respect and that the standards for placing GM foods on European markets are sufficiently strict. If the European Food Safety Authority has recognised, in accordance with the legislative procedure on the basis of research, that the crops in question are not defective, I see no reason to withdraw the Commission's draft implementing decisions.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today against the European Commission's proposals to authorise three new types of herbicide-resistant genetically modified soya in food and feed. Any authorisation of these types of soya would encourage the use of herbicides which could cause cancer and other serious consequences for human health, such as glyphosate. This substance in particular is in fact classified as "probably carcinogenic" by the World Health Organization (WHO) in an evaluation issued in 2015. With this vote, we are also calling on the Commission to propose a new, clearer and more coherent system of authorisation for genetically modified food and feed, to protect human health but also the environment.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \ u2012 Taking into account the protection of human life, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed, such a legislative proposal should be addressed and decided separately by each country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion to object to the Commission’s authorising decisions in order to express opposition to authorisation of these particular varieties of GM soybean and to call on the Commission to live up to its obligation to update the Annexes to Directive 2001/18/EC by 3 April 2017 as regards the environmental risk assessment of GMOs, in line with Parliament’s vote of 13 January 2015. With this decision I, along with other Labour MEPs, voted for a fully informed and scientifically guided decision-making process with regards to GMOs that responds to public expectations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ On 24 June 2011 Bayer CropScience AG submitted an application to the competent institutions in Belgium, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17. Regulations of the Commission and Parliament No 2013/2013 1829/2003, for placing on the market food consisting of or producing soy FG72. I don't support this objection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soy bee FG72. I do not agree with the motion in the resolution that the Commission should withdraw the implementing decision because it is incompatible with EU law. Certainly, whether the decision is in line with Eu law cannot be established in the resolution, as we have no basis for it. Research in the field of GMOs has been enormous in the past and the results of many have been very different, which casts doubt on the correctness of the research.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report to veto the approval of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans, since for us the aim remains to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and the interests of consumers. At the same time, we have taken into account the conclusions of the World Health Organisation's Cancer Research Agency, which state that the three species of genetically modified soybeans possess various types of herbicides which have been identified as potentially carcinogenic to humans. In addition, we oppose the EU's practice of deciding and imposing the placing and use of genetically modified products on Member States' markets, as under no circumstances should the sovereignty of states be sacrificed on the altar of profit and competition to decide on key issues such as the health and well-being of their citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of products from genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified FG72 soybeans.  On 24 June 2011, Bayer CropScience submitted a marketing application to the competent authority of Belgium. These soybeans express the 2mEPSPS protein, which provides resistance to glyphosate-containing herbicides, as well as the HPPD W336 protein, which provides resistance to herbicides active in isoxaflutol. The WHO's International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance "likely to be carcinogenic to humans" in 2015. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission without the opinions of the Committees of the Member States and, in the case of GM food and feed, it has become common for the dossier to be returned to the Commission for final approval. I agree that, even if production is necessarily carried out on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders, which means that the national 'sales and use' ban proposed by the Commission could not be enforced in the single internal market. I therefore supported the withdrawal of the implementing regulation and for the Commission to present a new legislative proposal, taking into account the frequently voiced concerns expressed by Member States, which are not only related to the risks posed by GMOs to health or the environment.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have contributed with my yes to the adoption of this resolution. I am against GMOs and I am – if possible – even more opposed to GMOs which, like soya FG72, express resistance to herbicides: in this case the infamous glyphosate and isoxaflutol, whose safety data sheet says: 'Highly toxic to aquatic organisms'.  Of course, if a crop is not affected by the use of isoxaflutol, there will be a tendency to use more of it. Rain transfers herbicides to waterways – the very environment in which herbicide is highly toxic – and to water aquifers. According to the twelfth national report on pesticides and water prepared by Ispra (Higher Institute for Protection and Research under the Ministry of the Environment), there is everything in Italian waters, starting with herbicides: up to 60 different substances in the same sample. The substances of this cocktail can produce an additive effect or, worse, a synergistic effect. In any case, damage greater than the mere sum of the factors that make it up. The 'no' to herbicide-resistant GMOs is a duty not only for the environment, but also for the health of people living in the areas from which soya imported into the EU originates.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Advances in agricultural sciences in recent decades have enabled contemporary societies to identify solutions to combat pests and diseases of various plants, which affect their yield in the production of the necessary food. At the same time, experiments on certain plants have led to the emergence of genetically modified varieties more resistant to pests, but also to certain herbicides.  The use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) has sparked much controversy at European level, with alleged effects on the human body being targeted. In order not to take hasty decisions until further scientific studies have been carried out in this field, the European Commission has avoided taking a cutting position, leaving it to the Member States to take measures deemed necessary. With regard to genetically modified soybean crops (FG72, MON 87708 × MON 89788, MON 87705 × MON 89788), herbicide resistance may be harmful to the environment or consumer health. For this reason, the European Parliament has raised this objection, which is justified and which is, in fact, a request for a more in-depth assessment of the effects of GMOs, in order to avoid any risks to the European environment and consumers.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. No, no The Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law.  Our goal is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests. The European consumer must not be the guinea pig of multinationals!!!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Contrary to the result of the final vote, I opposed the objection to authorise the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean FG72. The application to put the soybean concerned on the market was fully compliant with EU legislation; the technical decision to authorise it or not is then left to the Commission, which assesses the application based on scientific evidence. The Commission agreed to validate the placing on the market and I see no reason for denying the scientific assessment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: the authorisation of genetically modified FG72 soy bee, as I believe that our priority in the field of genetically modified food and feed is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection and the environment.  Given that this substance is classified as a carcinogen for humans, it is important to highlight this in order to protect the interests of consumers, the people of the Union and to strengthen their trust.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament should be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposed to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. Two of them have another characteristic: different fatty acid composition for GMO B and tolerance to dicamba (a pesticide) for GMO C. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven). As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including ignoring relevant observations from Member States. Moreover, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. So I vote for the objection, even symbolic.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Bayer CropScience AG has submitted an application to the competent authority of Belgium for the placing on the market of foods, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from FG72 soybeans. As described in the application, the genetically modified MST-FGØ72-2 soybean expresses the 2mEPSPS protein, which provides resistance to glyphosate-containing herbicides, as well as the HPPD W336 protein, which provides resistance to weed killers active in isoxaflutol. The referring authority invites the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the matter. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position on this issue.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans FG72 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament should be able to participate in the legislation.  In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have always advocated that Latvia and the European Union as a whole be free from genetically modified organisms (GMOs). We must not allow the health of our citizens to be put at risk in the interests of any economic interest.  It is regrettable that this is another time when the European Commission, contrary to the member states' position, wants to give the green light to the placing on the market of new GMO products, in the exercise of its powers under its own legislation. GMO soya beans are resistant to glyphosate, which has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer as a possible carcinogen for humans.  This time, the EC not only failed to take into account national concerns about the harmfulness of GMOs, but also ignored the world health organisation agency's research into glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance.  In the light of the studies carried out by the World Health Organisation Agency on glyphosate and the negative attitude of the Latvian public towards GMOs, I voted against the placing on the market of these three GMO soybeans.  Furthermore, I believe that the existing legislative procedure should be changed in order to give both the European Parliament and the states greater decision-making rights when authorising new GMOs for the placing on the market, thereby ensuring more effective democratic control and respect for the public interest.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection concerning the genetically modified soybean FG72 because I believe that the Commission should not authorise the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM soybeans in food and feed, specifically for two reasons: the first reason is that glyphosate, a herbicide, was classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization’s cancer agency. The second reason is that currently, GMOs are being authorised in the EU without the support of Member States: in fact, every GM authorisation decision has so far been taken by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of Member States.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted against the objection to accepting the genetically modified soybean. We must rely on science and our European Food Safety Authority. They believe that this crop is safe. With a growing population and increasing threats to the climate, we need modern plant breeding in Europe.
