These modern techniques for growing agricultural crops and other plants, among other things, can contribute to a better food for the world's population and a better climate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation decision on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well. It calls for no new varieties of GMOs to be authorised, nor have the old authorisations been renewed until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. Whereas all these soy products confer increased tolerance to different types of herbicides (especially glyphosate), which has been classified as probably carcinogenic to humans by IARC, on 15 March 2015, this draft Implementing Decision is not compatible with the objectives of Regulation (EC) 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed, as well as Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in human and animal feed.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I support the European Parliament resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or derived from genetically modified soya beans of the FG72 variety (MST-FG-72-2), in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to present a new legislative proposal that takes better account of national interests and concerns. That is my goal. I am opposed to the blanket admissibility of genetically modified organisms and I am in favour of greater consideration for national concerns at EU level, preferably through more subsidiarity.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this objection by giving my vote in favour. This initiative enhances food and feed safety for the benefit of producers and citizens, but also supports the proper functioning of the internal market within the Union.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution strongly calling on the European Commission not to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified soya FG72 (MST-FGØ72-2) designed by Monsanto to tolerate spraying of glyphosate. Once again, the large biotech multinationals have tried to bring GMO products back to 500 million European citizens.  Glyphosate-resistant soya and glyphosate are yet another commercial package designed by Monsanto, a multinational company that, in order to increase its profits, is ready to pass over people's health without any scruples, as the Argentina case shows. Glyphosate, the most widely used herbicant in the world, has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and the World Health Organization (WHO) as "probably carcinogenic" to humans and we in the 5 Star Movement have always been fighting for a ban in Europe. We do not therefore intend to allow in any way the cultivation on European territory of organisms specially modified to tolerate this pesticide. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have fought to make Europe a GMO-free territory, and with this vote I reiterate a dry no to the entry of gm products into European territory.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soy bee FG72. I agree that we must ensure high levels of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed. However, the fact is that not every genetically modified organism is harmful and therefore decisions on the possible authorisation to place products containing genetically modified enzymes on the market should be taken on the basis of independent and credible research on potential negative effects.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 5 Star Movement has always protected the interests of citizens, both in Italy and in Europe, and is fighting against the placing on the market of food and feed containing genetically modified soya. Monsanto's application for authorisation requires unanimous consent from the scientific community, and this consensus is lacking to date. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the objection procedure.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and dicamba. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection by the European Parliament on the marketing of products containing genetically modified GMO soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788. Indeed, I am deeply opposed to the introduction of new GMOs on the market. In addition, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment which highlights, among other things, relevant observations from Member States in this direction. Although I regret that this text has only symbolic significance, because being not binding on the Commission, I support this objection.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this objection resolution. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 the Commission has made authorisation decisions on new GMOs without the support of the Member State committees.  This situation was intended to be an exception in the legislation which has unfortunately become the norm. Commission President Juncker has failed to fulfil the promise he made as a candidate for the Presidency of the Commission to fix this democratic deficit in decision-making for GMOs in the European Union. The Commission is therefore authorising the placing on the market of products with a system which it itself has recognised is flawed. It is essential that the Commission now comes up with a real proposal on GMOs to correct this democratic deficit.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 In this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament wishes to raise its objections in accordance with Article 106 on the authorisation of the placing on the market of genetically modified soya MON87708 × MON89788. In October Parliament rejected the Commission's new proposal on genetically modified food and feed and asked it to come back with a new proposal.  In the meantime, therefore, new genetically modified foods and feedingstuffs should not be authorised to be placed on the market under the existing legal framework. This type of soya, the disposal of which has been approved, is resistant to certain herbicides and therefore its cultivation may encourage a freer use of herbicides, which may have harmful effects on human health.  For all the above reasons I voted in favour of objecting as we believe that the Commission should present a new proposal on genetically modified food and feed, which will more accurately assess the environmental impact of GMOs.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament rejects a Commission decision to allow glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans across the EU. In view of the fact that the plant protection product glyphosate in particular has been classified by the World Health Organisation as potentially carcinogenic, and that I generally reject GMO foods because of the unknown long-term consequences, I fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary to ask that authorisations be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Therefore, I logically voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106; I am concerned by the increasing usage of delegated acts and am therefore minded to support any objections as a matter of course. In this instance, I note specifically that the World Health Organization has described these specific varieties as being potentially carcinogenic to humans.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. With regard to my general position on GMOs, I am against the precautionary principle that prevents research in Europe. Moreover, I am surprised at the hypocrisy of banning the marketing of these products, which Europe then allows itself to import.  Nevertheless, I voted against the introduction of this pesticide-resistant variety, as it is considered by many research centres, including Lyon, to be a variety that could be dangerous.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal requesting the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision concerning the marketing authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788. The draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with EU law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation No 1829/2003 and Regulation No 396/2005, which aims to establish a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Bayer CropScience and Monsanto. All three are tolerant to glyphosate, with another characteristic for Monsanto's two GMOs: different fatty acid composition for GMO MON 87705 × MON 89788 and dicamba tolerance (a pesticide) for GMO MON 87708 × MON 89788. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven). As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, the assessment provided by EFSA remains manifestly unsatisfactory.  Alas, the objections to the acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission, and the amendments that my group has tabled - to make the objections binding and to remind us that the Commission is not even waiting for the end of the objection procedures to publish the GMO authorisations - have unfortunately been rejected.  Their rejection, recorded by RCV, thus shows the hypocrisy of elected officials who are in fact against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs. However, GMO authorizations should be able to be issued by delegated deed and not by deed of execution.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The introduction of herbicide-resistant genetically modified organisms can pose a serious threat to the health of European citizens and the environment. I have today voted in favour of objections to the authorisation of three types of genetically modified soya, including MON 87708 x MON 89788, because I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. With regard to soya MON 87708 x MON 89788, in particular, the concern concerns the presence of DMO proteins which give tolerance to dicamba-based herbicides and the EPSPS protein which gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a who's specialised body, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Given the potential danger to health, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs and feed from GMOs as soon as possible, in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GENETICally modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the acts implemented, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on food and food GMOs was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament who understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to explain that I voted against my group's line in this report on the objection raised on the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87708 x MON 89788. The Basque Country is a GMO-free region and, as I did in 2015, I voted in favour of the ENVI Commission's motion for a resolution which considers that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not consistent with EU law as it is incompatible with the purpose of several Regulations. I therefore support the request for withdrawal of the draft Implementing Decision.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wished to support Parliament's objection to a marketing authorization for products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788. In addition to my principled opposition to GMOs, which are potentially dangerous to health and threatening to the ecosystem, I would like to point out that, in this case, EFSA has once again shown dogmatism by issuing a more than wobbly assessment and ignoring the relevant observations of Member States on the subject. Apparently, the health and food security of the citizens of the EU Member States weighs little in the balance in the face of the interests of American industrialists, especially Monsanto, which is not afraid to market this soy with a different composition in fatty acid. A new wake-up call that suggests the worst in the event that the TTIP agreement comes into force, leaving European citizens at the mercy of the hybrid of multinationals.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified soya MON 87708 × MON 89788.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Monsanto to introduce the variety of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 into the Netherlands. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it criticised, did not approve the Commission's implementing decision and requested the submission of a new draft decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybeans. In 2012, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing soya consisting of them. Genetically modified soybeans contain a protein that gives resistance to dicamb herbicides and glyphosate herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a specialised Cancer Agency of the World Health Organisation, classified glyphosate as a probably carcinogenic substance in humans.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. As with the previous point, I also supported this objection, which concerns the rejection of the European Commission's decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing GMS. That objection concerns the genetically modified soy bean MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1 submitted by Monsanto Europe for approval for placing on the market. As I am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMO, I believe that the placing on the market of such products must be extremely conservative, as we do not yet know at the moment all the consequences for human health that may result from the consumption of products produced from GMOs. We must also take into account the will of people, who mostly do not want to grow GMOs in Europe. Since the EU imports the vast majority of soy bee containing GMO, it would be more appropriate to target the production of soy bee without GMO.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO food authorisation system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  For five years, Member States could not agree on granting or refusing a mon 87708xMON 89788 soybean licence. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The 3 GMOs of soybeans proposed by the Commission to authorize the importation have properties that serve only the interests of Monsanto and possibly industrial producers. I consider that once again EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment of the risks involved and that the objections proposed by the ENVI Committee are well founded. For all these reasons, I voted for these objections.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision on genetically modified soya MON 87708 x MON 89788 does not comply with EU law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consists, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, in providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. I therefore believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to allow the marketing of three new types of genetically modified soybeans from the US company Monsanto. It is in this context that this objection is intended to signal Parliament's opposition to the marketing of these three genetically modified organisms (GMOs), which are tolerant to glyphosate. One of them also has a tolerance to the pesticide dicamba.  While this objection will not force the Commission to abandon the commercialisation of these GMOs, we consider it essential to vote on it to show Parliament's disapproval of the Commission and EFSA, whose assessments are unsatisfactory and do not take into account the comments of the Member States' authorities.  That is why I voted for this objection.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The environment and food safety must be the limit framework for the development of the internal market, without which any economic progress would in fact mean an attack on the health of all consumers, consumers who are protected by the European Treaties. Either this protection must become an effective one and we cannot speak of effectiveness when we want to approve products with potential carcinogenic risk.  On the other hand, the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or manufactured from MON 87708 soybeans × MON 89788 should not be rejected, since there are no concrete scientific studies confirming the danger of this substance to consumers. In this context, I have spoken out against the objection raised under Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure: the authorisation for genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 x MON 89788.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Since the adoption of Directive (EU) 2015/412, which allows Member States to ban the cultivation of authorised GMOs internally, the Commission, although permanently deadlocked in the competent committee due to cross-vetoes, has been unblocking all pending GMO authorisation procedures. That is why the ENVI Committee is systematically proposing objections to any new authorised GMOs. Unfortunately, in these cases Parliament's objections are not binding on the Commission, since they are implementing acts.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection concerning the authorisation of genetically modified soya MON 87705 x MON 89788.  In August 2011, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified soya. This type of soya expresses a protein that gives tolerance to herbicides based on glyphosate, a substance that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified as probably carcinogenic to humans. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not therefore appear to be in accordance with EU law, not guaranteeing a high level of protection of human and animal life and health, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, nor the effective functioning of the internal market.  Consequently, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection to this draft implementing decision by asking the Commission, as indicated in the motion for a resolution, to present a new legislative proposal that takes account of the frequently expressed national concerns about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment and the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because the genetically modified MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1 soybean through various chemical processes was qualified by the World Health Organization as probably carcinogenic. This means that we cannot take the risk of authorising such a product in times when we are already exposed to many carcinogens over which we have no influence.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution opposing the Commission's initiative to authorise the placing on the market of food and feed based on transgenic soya resistant to glyphosate and Dicamba. Although transgenic soya feed may be an interesting solution for farmers, as the transgenic event makes them resistant to different herbicides, they are nevertheless substances that have been classified as probably carcinogenic and therefore highly harmful to both animals and humans.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the motion for a resolution and stress that our aim is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified foods and genetically modified feedingstuffs, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the objections raised to the authorisation of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans. As is easily understood, this issue concerns the entire population of Europe, as it directly affects the public health sector and any approval must be given after thorough discussion and research in order to ensure the health of citizens. In fact, the decisions we will take are of particular importance, as the genetically modified food sector can potentially cause major turbulence in Europe's economy as well. In this light, I believe that the objections raised are correct and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with EU law, it is not compatible with the objective of Regulations (EC) Nos 1829/2003 and 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consist of providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite my usual openness to news, in this case I preferred to vote in favour of the objection (and therefore against the authorization) of this product because I believe that in the food field you have to go with your feet of lead and make a thousand additional checks, which I am not sure happened for this product.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this objection as individual GMOs and the GMO combinations in question have been authorised by the Commission and deemed safe for human consumption by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA). This objection is an attempt to change the system of authorisation by those who are opposed to GM. Member States can decide whether to cultivate GM crops or not. There is no commercial cultivation of GMO products in Ireland, nor is there any expected in the short to mid-term given the lack of relevant GMO products on the market.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution seeks to place on the market products containing genetically modified soybean. The production of goods containing genetically modified ingredients is not limited to consumption or use in one State as this facilitates the development of GMO trade across borders. This will make it impossible for those Member States who ban the sales and use of genetically modified products to effectively take such health—related decisions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and dicamba. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Last October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on genetically modified food and feed and asked the Commission to come up with a new proposal. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework, which the Commission acknowledges is not working well. The soybeans in these three authorisation processes in question are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. I voted in favour of the objection, because I believe that the Commission should review the draft implementing act, taking account of the position expressed.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the objection resolution to the authorisation of soybean MON 87708 x MON 89788. I believe that it is absolutely vital for public confidence that in Europe we have a GM regulation system that is underpinned by science. This means that products passing a robust, independent safety assessment should have fair market access. The European Food safety agency has declared this GM trait safe for food and feed use, and we should respect that decision made by experts, otherwise we risk undermining not only our own credibility but also the principle of science-based decision-making.  The use of GM material in animal feed is significant across the EU, and our livestock sector is heavily dependent on imported GM feed materials, so it is important that EU GM authorisations proceed as rapidly as possible to keep pace with authorisations in other parts of the world and avoid significant disruption in the international trade of agricultural commodities, which could have a negative impact on food prices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This proposal to object from a member of the Socialists and Democrats group concerns the European Commission's draft decision in favour of authorising GMO soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 tolerant of glyphosate in food and animal products. The rapporteur argues that glyphosate is a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). However, this justification is questionable. On the one hand, the European Commission's draft decision follows the positive opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Its conclusions are based on a large number of studies, including those of the IARC, and scientific data as explained by the authors in an exchange of views with MEPs last December. On the other hand, the European Commission has respected its mandate as part of its enforcement power, which stems from European legislation, approved by the European Parliament. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the many precautionary measures voted by the European legislator in this area. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I believe in science-based policy; to this extent I believe that it is the task of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to decide whether a genetically modified organism is safe and fit for consumption. The EFSA advice should be the basis for the final decision. Since the EFSA advice was positive, I voted against this objection.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Currently, Genetically Modified Organizations (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of three genetically modified soybeans tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MONO 87708 (dicamba produces monooxygenase protein) and MON 89788 (CP4 EPSPS protein) single modified soy lines have been combined to create the double modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 GM soy. In this way, soy has become resistant to herbicides with the active substances dicamba and glyphosate. During its cultivation, increased use of herbicides dicamba and glyphosate may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. Their high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  There are a number of deficiencies in the risk assessment carried out, including: • no 90-day rat feeding study has been carried out with the product; • no repeated dose studies have been performed with the CP4 EPSPS protein. The amount of formaldehyde produced by GM soy is not solely a consequence of a natural process, since the neutralization of the active substance dicamba also takes place with the formation of formaldehyde. This substance is considered human carcinogenic. New research suggests that formaldehyde in herbicide-totering GM crops may be acumulated due to a disturbance in the metabolism of detoxification enzymes. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Environment Committee's objection to three European Commission decisions authorising the marketing of animal feed containing GM soybeans produced by Monsanto and Bayer. These three GMO soybeans have the distinction of developing a tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides, including Monsanto's Roundup, a substance classified as probably carcinogenic by the World Health Organization. I believe that the three authorisation decisions are not compatible with the European Union's objectives on human and animal health, as defined in legislation. That is why I welcome today's vote and the clear majority that has emerged to veto the European Parliament's marketing of GMO soybean products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto, tolerant to glyphosate. GMO B has a different composition in fatty acid and GMO C is a tolerance to the pesticide "dicamba". To the extent that these properties are intended only to serve Monsanto's interests, and EFSA has not taken into account the relevant views of the States, I have naturally voted in favour of these objections.  Finally, our three amendments were aimed at ensuring that the authorisations took place in the form of delegated acts, in order to ensure democratic control over the marketing of GMOs.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I and the party I represent – THE MRRO, we are against any genetically modified food and feed. In a draft decision, the Commission announced the authorisation of the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1). GMOs are not a solution for what we eat or what we feed the animals we consume, and that is why I oppose it always and everywhere.  For me, citizens' health is more important than trade and competitiveness. Recently (in October 2015), I rejected the EC's proposal that each country be able to decide for itself whether to authorise or ban GMOs. To some extent, the proposal was very attractive, but in practice not applicable because of the EU single market.  I have always been a supporter of the overall ban on GMOs across the European market so that our citizens know that their rulers put their health first and I think this is the only policy we can have on this issue. In the present case, I voted in favour of the objection leading to a ban on the placing on the market of GMO soybeans.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of products from genetically modified soybeans of the MON 87708 × MON 89788 series (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, health and animal welfare and the environment.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MONO 87708 (dicamba produces monooxygenase protein) and MON 89788 (CP4 EPSPS protein) single modified soy lines have been combined to create the double modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 GM soy. In this way, soy has become resistant to herbicides with the active substances dicamba and glyphosate. During its cultivation, increased use of herbicides dicamba and glyphosate may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. Their high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  There are a number of deficiencies in the risk assessment carried out, including: • no 90-day rat feeding study has been carried out with the product; • no repeated dose studies have been performed with the CP4 EPSPS protein. The amount of formaldehyde produced by GM soy is not solely a consequence of a natural process, since the neutralization of the active substance dicamba also takes place with the formation of formaldehyde. This substance is considered human carcinogenic. New research suggests that formaldehyde in herbicide-totering GM crops may be acumulated due to a disturbance in the metabolism of detoxification enzymes. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The process of authoring GMOs in Europe is not democratic. In this case, as in all previous clearance cases, the Commission acted unilaterally, despite the fact that the proposal had not been adopted by the technical reference committee. I therefore supported the objection to the authorisation of GM MON 87708 x MON 89788 soya, not least because of the scientific doubts that GMOs entail. In fact, the soybean in question expresses DMO proteins that give tolerance to dicamba-based herbicides and the EPSPS protein that gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised body of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I am opposed to the introduction of GMOs on the market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the MON87708xMON89788 was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands on 23/3/2012. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee of 18/11/2015 having been assessed with "no opinion", as has been the case since this procedure was agreed. This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation of a decision, on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised, nor to renew the old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection as I feel the technology is being used to help multinationals dominate the food market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the resolution objecting to any new authorised GMOs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as it proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified soya products of the MON 87708 × MON 89788 series (MON -877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health , as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on GM food and feed and asked the Commission to come up with a new one. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework which the Commission acknowledges is not working in a satisfactory way. The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MONO 87708 (dicamba produces monooxygenase protein) and MON 89788 (CP4 EPSPS protein) single modified soy lines have been combined to create the double modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 GM soy. name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The genetically modified soybeans described in the application express the dicamba monooxygenase proteins, which provide tolerance to dicamba-containing herbicides and a type of protein that provides tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. As the International Agency for Research on Cancer , the WHO's specialised agency for cancer diseases, has been working on the 2015 european commission's report on cancer, it is not the first time that the commission has been involved in the fight against cancer. On 20 March 2003, it classified glyphosate as a substance likely to be carcinogenic to humans, so I consider it appropriate to call on the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, taking into account the frequently voiced concerns expressed by Member States that are not only related to the risks posed by GMOs to health or the environment.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection on the ground that the Commission Implementation Decision guarantees a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I strongly supported the proposal to reject the adoption of the delegated act on the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soya. In particular, I agree with what was said in the text on the principle of caution on GMOs, as we MEPs voted on a few weeks ago when we examined the proposal to amend the 2003 regulation on GMOs.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, I believe that the European Commission × should present × a new comprehensive proposal on GMOs and carefully assess their environmental and health impact. I think, in fact, that the European Parliament clearly expressed its opposition to the Commission's proposal on GMOs in the vote last October, calling for adequate guarantees and a new legislative proposal. Many doubts and questions remain, given the established practice of taking decisions on GMOs without a technical opinion from the Standing Committee of the Member States. The introduction of genetically modified soya MON 87708 × MON 89788, with a high content of oleic acid and low in linoleic acid and containing glyphosate-resistant proteins, poses environmental and health problems, leading to an increase in the use of these pesticides. I believe that these concerns need to be adequately addressed by EFSA and the European Commission through impact assessments and require comprehensive, clear legislation that takes due account of the concerns of our citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the objection under Article 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soya beans of the MON 87708 × MON 89788. The Family Party of Germany is opposed to the use of genetically modified seeds in agriculture.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding GMOs, I support the existing, science-based decision-making process, judged independently by the European Food Safety Authority. The Commission needs to make a proposal which includes a greater assessment of the environmental impact of GMOs.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow the importation of three new GMO soybeans, all tolerant to glyphosate. One of them is a soybean from Monsanto. I supported this objection in committee and in plenary, not least because glyphosate weedkillers are carcinogenic, according to the World Health Organization. It should also be stressed that EFSA's assessment is unsatisfactory and does not take into account the observations of the relevant agencies of the Member States.  Nevertheless, the European Commission can ignore these objections, as GMO authorisations are its sole authority. It demonstrated this last December by authorising a new GMO maize, the NK603xT25, despite opposition from the European Parliament. That is why it is necessary that these authorisations are now under the democratic control of Parliament, which I have proposed by way of amendments to amend the GMO authorisation regulation and replace enforcement acts with delegated acts. Indeed, the objections voted by Parliament can put a real veto on the Commission's decisions.  But when it comes to asking for real democratic measures, especially when it comes to GMOs, this Parliament is decidedly absent subscribers.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation.  In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on food and food GMOs was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament who understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this objection based on the fact that the herbicide glyphosate, which the three GM soybeans tolerate (along with other herbicides in the case of FG72 and MON 87708 x MON 89788), was classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization’s cancer agency.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Commission’s proposal on the authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788 due to the same reasoning as for soybean FG72.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)

Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore did not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, and I supported the objection.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given our opposition to GMOs, we supported the three objections in this area. In October last year, the Commission's proposal on GMOs was rejected by the EP. Through these objections we want to put pressure on the Commission to make a proposal that respects the right of Member States not to allow the movement of GMOs on their territory.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MONO 87708 (dicamba produces monooxygenase protein) and MON 89788 (CP4 EPSPS protein) single modified soy lines have been combined to create the double modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 GM soy. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The environmental impacts of GMOs must be rigorously assessed through a new proposal from the Commission for GMO food and fodder.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I vote for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing the GM MON 87708 x MON 89788 (MON-87708-9 x MON-89788-1), consist of or manufactured under Regulation (EC) No 11000/2013. 1829/2003 Of Parliament and the Council on the fact that the interpretation of glyphosate contained in the soy in question by the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the World Health Organisation is such that that substance is likely to be carcinogenic to man.  Moreover, despite the fact that farming takes place exclusively on the territory of one Member State, trade in products takes place beyond national borders and therefore the proposed national prohibition on sales and use would be unenforceable. Accordingly, I voted FOR this proposal asking the Commission to withdraw its draft decision.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate.  EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Of course, I voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the report of my colleagues Bart Staes, Sirpa Pietik-inen, Guillaume Balas, Lynn Boylan and Eleonora Evi on the objection in accordance with Article 106 concerning the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.  Indeed, some political groups led by the Greens accuse the Commission of failing to comply with the authorisation procedure for genetically modified organisms. However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a study that concluded that this product is safe for humans, animals and the environment. Above all, the authorisation to market is currently the responsibility of the Member States. This resolution was adopted, which I regret.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though as this vote is an objection to an implementing act, and this objection might be more of a political move made by different groups in the chamber, EH Bildu has maintained a coherent position on matters related to GMOs and always vote against those, or, as in cases such as last December with maize NK603*T25, vote in favour of objections to allowing the authorisation of GMOs. The genetically modified MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1 soybean, as described in the application, expresses the DMO proteins which confer tolerance to dicamba-based herbicides and the CP4 EPSPS protein which confers tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides; whereas the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised cancer agency of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. Therefore, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this objection, and will keep voting in the same way to any future objection concerning authorisation of GMOs, as we would like to put pressure on the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal that is more satisfactory than the one rejected by Parliament last October.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This objection was brought by a number of political groups on the basis that the European Commission exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.  However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a comprehensive and proper study to authorise this soy. Moreover, if the authorisation to grow GMOs is granted at European level, it is the States that retain control over the marketing authorisation. I therefore voted against this objection, which was merely declaratory, without foundation and without any legal effect.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution on the problem of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The Rejection of GMOs throughout Austria must be accepted by the Commission. This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to withdraw immediately the implementing decision approving the genetically modified maize variety NK603xT25. Instead, a new legislative proposal is to be presented, which responds to the concerns of the countless Member States, which are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported resolutions B8-0133/2016 and B8-0135/2016, I supported and voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution, calling for the withdrawal of the Commission Implementing Decision permitting the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1). The European Commission must come up with a better proposal on authorisation procedures. The current proposal does not address the often expressed concerns about the potential health and environmental risks of GMOs. The consequences that products containing GMOs can have on humans and the environment are not yet sufficiently identified and there is too much uncertainty for genetically modified products.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection in order to express my opposition to authorisation of these varieties of GM soybean.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MONO 87708 (dicamba produces monooxygenase protein) and MON 89788 (CP4 EPSPS protein) single modified soy lines have been combined to create the double modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 GM soy. This substance is considered human carcinogenic. New research suggests that formaldehyde in herbicide-totering GM crops may be acumulated due to a disturbance in the metabolism of detoxification enzymes. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution opposing the possibility of trading products containing modified soya MON 87708 x MON 89788, as it is in the interest of Polish farmers to preserve the possibility of purchasing soybean feed components. Only about 10% of the feed used is more expensive organic feed. A ban on the purchase of cheaper feed and its components produced using genetic engineering would primarily affect Polish poultry producers and negatively affect poultry exports, in which Poland is a leader.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against this objection. Genetically modified soybeans MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1 expresses the EPSPS protein that gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. With regard to the latter, in-depth studies have been carried out on its effects on humans and animals. These studies were carried out by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which concluded that neither epidemiological data (i.e. in humans) nor the results of animal studies showed causal links between exposure to glyphosate and the onset of cancer in humans. This is the result of a detailed study carried out by EFSA scientists and representatives of risk assessment bodies from EU Member States.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission asked us to allow the importation of three glyphosate-resistant transgenic soybeans. Glyphosate is a herbicide recognized as a carcinogen by the World Health Organization. Despite these recommendations, the European Health Authority EFSA, whose relationship with the GMO industries has too often been demonstrated, continues to regard it as non-harmful. So I vote against these authorizations. They are dangerous, do not respect the precautionary principle and undermine the European position against GMOs to promote trade at the expense of our health. EFSA's positions in favour of GMOs are becoming increasingly problematic. EFSA must take into account the concerns of citizens and, above all, thoroughly review its assessment procedures, which are playing into the hands of the big multinational seed companies.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the section 106 objection to the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788. The Commission proposes to allow genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788. This GMO is tolerant to glyphosate, which is probably carcinogenic to humans. As with previous GMO authorisation cases, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, notably ignoring relevant observations from Member States.  Unfortunately, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. This is the purpose of the amendment of the ENL Group, which points to this fact and calls for the authorisations to be issued in the form of delegated acts.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The impact of GM foods on human health is questionable. I therefore support the consumer having information on whether the product is natural or genetically modified. I support the idea that it should be up to individual Member States whether or not to authorise the import of GM products. I am not joining the appeal to ban the import of these foodstuffs across the EU across the eu. I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Monsanto Europe S.A. in March 2012 applied to the competent authority in the Netherlands for authorisation to market food, food and feed ingredients containing MON 87708 × MON 89788. The MON 87708 × MON 89788 contains a protein that also has glyphosate in it. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, an agency of the World Health Organization specializing in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances that are probably carcinogenic to man.  Parliament found in October 2015 that although cultivation takes place on the territory of one Member State, the Commission's prohibition on use and sale is unenforceable because it would require the reintroduction of border controls on imports. The Commission is being asked to withdraw its draft decision and to present a new legislative proposal on the amendment, taking into account national issues that do not relate only to problems related to the safety of GMOs for health and the environment.  I did not support the objection under Article 106, as I think it is essential to ensure that the health of all EU citizens is protected.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As with the previous vote on the placing on the market of genetically modified soybean MST-FGØ72-2, this applies to genetically modified soybean MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1 developed by Monsanto Europe S.A. They produce the protein CP4 EPSPS, which confers resistance to glyphosate herbicides. As mentioned earlier, on 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a human potentially carcinogenic substance. The standard procedure, in line with EU legal practice, provides for close commission cooperation with national services in the case of the placing on the market of new genetically modified products, which has not been done regularly or at all for quite a long time. As a result, the Commission often does not take into account the concerns existing in the Union regarding the placing on the market of genetically modified products. As the Commission's proposal again does not comply with Union law, a decision was taken to reject it, which I support, so that i voted in favour of the EP's rejection decision.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: In march 2015, since the World Health Organisation's specialised agency for research on cancer included genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788 among the substances likely to have a cancer-forming effect on humans, I support the proposal to withdraw the Commission Implementing Decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from that genetically modified soybean.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution based on objections pursuance to Article 106 on the draft Commission implementing decision approving the placing on the market of products containing them, consist of or are produced from genetically modified soybeans of the MON 87708 × MON 89788 series (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 87788-1). This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this objection. As with the previous one, the European Commission is proposing to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto, including MON 87708 x MON 89788 which, like the previous one, is tolerant to glyphosate, and is in addition to a different composition of fatty acid, two properties that serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial producers. In addition, EFSA (the European Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including excluding relevant observations from Member States.  We therefore support this objection.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this objection based on the fact that the herbicide glyphosate, which the three GM soybeans tolerate (along with other herbicides in the case of FG72 and MON 87708 x MON 89788) was classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization’s cancer agency.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not support the objection under Article 106: authorisation of genetically modified soya. By stressing the importance of protecting human health, the importance of consumer health and the high level of control needed to protect health from products potentially harmful to the body and health, one understands the reason for the position expressed by the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution seeks that the commission's draft implementing decision on food and feed consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize should be reformulated and improved, as the manner in which it has been presented does not ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests. GMOs and, in particular, these products have great intolerance to various types of herbicides, such as glyphosate, which has been considered to be probably carcinogenic to humans by the International Cancer Research Centre, the WHO's specialized agency for this disease.   Health and food and environmental safety cannot be left aside in matters of this matter. I voted for it.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission decision authorising imports into EU countries of three types of genetically modified soybeans 87708 × MON 89788. The EC's marketing authorisations for food and feed containing Monsanto Europe S.A. genetically modified beans 87708 × MON 89788 do not comply with the principles laid down in EU legislation to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal health, the environment and consumer interests. Soybeans 87708 × MON 89788 are genetically modified to become resistant to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer by the World Health Organisation as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans. On the basis of the scientific conclusions on the negative effects of GMOs and taking into account the negative human opinion on GMO products, the European Commission must review the authorisation procedure and present a new proposal allowing decisions on GMOs to be taken by the Member States themselves. Until a new regime is agreed, the Commission should not issue new authorisations, and I will never accept attempts to do so.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution opposes the Commission's enforcement decision authorizing the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.  This genetically modified soybean expresses DMO proteins, which confer resistance to dicamba-containing herbicides and the CP4 EPSPS protein, which confers tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides.  However, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, WHO's specialized agency for cancer research, classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the exploitation of Europe by foreign interests. The properties of this GMO soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial producers. These GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, although its assessment of GMOs has been widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of identifying elected representatives who are against the "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs. Of course, I voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of MON 87708 × MON 89788 soybeans.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of marketing authorisation for products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize MON 87708 x MON 89788 (MON-88Ø17-9 x MON-ØØ81Ø-1) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The motion for a resolution is to ask the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision by presenting a new proposal which may reflect all the concerns expressed in various Community Regulations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and EU Member States have finalised the re-evaluation of glyphosate, a chemical widely used in pesticides, based on a study carried out by EFSA as part of the legal process for renewing the authorisation of glyphosate in the EU.  It concludes that it is unlikely that the substance is genotoxic (i.e., it damages DNA) or that it poses a carcinogenic threat to humans. Experts have not proposed that glyphosate be categorized as a carcinogen in EU regulations on the classification, labelling and packaging of chemicals. In particular, all experts in the Member States, with one exception, agreed that neither epidemiological data (human-related) nor evidence from animal studies have shown causality between glyphosate exposure and the development of cancer in humans.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the European Parliament rejected the Commission's proposal allowing a national ban on the sale and use of GMOs, as it indirectly leads to the closure of borders between the Member States of the European Union. Such a proposal is contrary to Union law because it does not respect the principle of the protection of human health while ensuring the functioning of the internal market. I reiterate my call on the Commission to make proposals in accordance with Union law, also taking into account the requirements of the Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected the authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788. The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed lays down the procedure for authorising the placing on the market of such products. Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands on 23 March 2012 for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87708 × MON 89788. The Commission has adopted a draft Commission implementing decision on authorisation under that Regulation.  In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety referred to Parliament's decision to × NK603 and T25 maize recommends that Parliament express its opinion on the fundamentally harmful effects of GMOs on human health on 16 December 2015 on a Commission implementing decision (EU) 2015/2279 authorising the placing on the market of products consisting of or produced from it. I am convinced that it is not for politics, but for science, to decide how GMO foods affect human health, so I abstained from voting for this decision.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands a request, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, to place on the market foodstuffs, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of, or produced from, MON 87708 × MON 89788. This genetically modified soy mon-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1, as described in the application, it expresses the DMO protein, which confers tolerance to dicamba-based herbicides, cry1ac protein, which confers resistance to lepidopteran pests, and cp4 protein EPSPS, which confers tolerance on herbicides containing glyphosate which, according to the International Cancer Research Centre classification, is probably carcinogenic to humans. I believe that the European Union must ensure the protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests, especially with regard to genetically modified food and feed. I hope that the Commission will present a new proposal for a legislative amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and to take into account the concerns of the World Health Organisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. These votes are intended to signal the European Parliament's opposition to the introduction of three new GMOs by way of importation. These are GMOs MON 87708 and MON89788. Indeed, the Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto that serve only the interests of this multinational company. As usual, EFSA has provided incomplete explanations that do not take into account the relevant comments of the Member States. It is therefore the whole process of granting authorisations that is at issue, since a study to question EFSA's action will be produced with a view to rejecting the budgetary discharge of this uneasy agency. However, these objections from Parliament are likely to remain a dead letter as they are not binding. That is why the ENF group has tabled 3 amendments calling for authorisations to now be in the form of delegated acts and no longer under acts of execution.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection filed by the Socialists, the Greens, the far left and supported by the extreme right, concerning genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 x MON 89788. These groups based their objection on the fact that the European Commission exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of products containing this genetically modified soybean variety, consisting of or manufactured from this genetically modified soybean. Unfortunately, this objection was adopted, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity, and while the Commission complied, before issuing its proposal for authorisation, with the procedure in place for GMOs, based in particular on an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority on the safety of the plant on human and animal health, as well as on the environment. This proposal was forwarded to the Council, which did not reject it.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788, which was charged with a so-called non-compliance with the Commission's powers. The authorisation to market these products was carried out within the scope of the Commission's powers. Moreover, the objection does not have to be to me, as the Member States themselves determine whether or not the authorisation is applied.  I therefore voted against a baseless symbolic objection to support the work of the European Commission.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution with regard to the authorisation of placing on the market products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified soybean MON 87708 x MON 89788. The report states that the implementing decision is not consistent with Parliament’s and the Council’s Regulation on ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring effective operation of the internal market.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution of the Committee on Environment and Society Health to withdraw the draft implementing decision of the European Commission on the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1.  According to scientific information, this type of soybean helps to express the proteins DMO, which give resistance to dikamba-based herbicides, and the protein CP4 EPSPS, which gives resistance to glyphosate-based herbicides. The International Agency for Research on Cancer classifies glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans. I believe that even that alone is a sufficient argument to reject such a proposal.  In addition to the scientific justification, much of the public opinion is increasingly strongly opposed to the use of GMOs techniques and technologies. On the eve of the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, this became clear enough.  I think it is socially irresponsible in the name of public health to allow such a culture within the EU or any Member State.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision and instead present a new legislative proposal, including the concerns of Member States that specifically oppose genetically modified organisms. Consequently, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support it because it is not necessary to decide on the placing on the market of each GMO product separately. A holistic approach is needed and the entire legal regulation of GMO products should be reviewed.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
