text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission, authorised to import and use three types of SOy bee for food purposes, does not provide sufficient protection for the health of European citizens, who are overwhelmingly opposed to GMO, and I therefore supported the objection to the enforcement of the permit. Gm soy type MON 87708 × MON 89788 is immune to the herbicide glifozate used in cultivation and is most likely carcinogenic to animals and also to humans, according to the who specialised agency.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing or manufactured by the GM strain MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1. In the genetically modified soybean MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1, as described in the application, it is also expressed with others and the CP4 EPSPS protein that causes tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides.  The International Agency for Research on Cancer, a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, placed glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be carcinogenic to humans on March 20, 2015, and on September 4, 2015, the California Office of Environmental Hazard Assessment for Health (OEHHA) also issued a notice of intent to add glyphosate to the list of chemicals of that federal state known to cause cancer. I consider the use of a potentially carcinogenic substance in the environment to be a risk that is not justified.  Similarly, I consider that by rejecting the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013, 1829/2003 a situation arisen in which, until the adoption of the new proposal, the right of Member States to independently decide on the use of GMO food and feed on their territory and the possibility to effectively monitor their decisions are not guaranteed. In view of the above, I supported this objection.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 In genetically modified soybean MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1, DMO proteins are expressed, causing tolerance to herbicides based on the active substance dikamba, and protein CP4 EPSPS, which causes tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer has included glyphosate in the category of substances that are likely carcinogenic to humans.  On this basis, I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision to authorising the marketing of products containing the GM strain MON 87708 × MON 89788 does not comply with Union legislation, as it is incompatible with the objectives and principles that entail ensuring a basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to GENETICally modified food and feed , while ensuring the efficient functioning of the internal market.  The Commission's approval is based solely on an assessment of the GMO's health and environmental risks, and excludes the socio-economic impact of GMO and the consequences of pollution arising from GMO, which I consider insufficiently comprehensive and therefore I agree with the proposal for an objection.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the MON87708xMON89788 was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands on 23.3.2012. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee of 18/11/2015 having been assessed with "no opinion", as has been the case since this procedure was agreed. This resolution opposes the adoption of the draft implementation of a decision on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised or renewed old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I also supported this objection to the Commission's decision because I still have doubts about the use of genetically modified foods, including in the case of MON87708xMON89788 soybeans. Of course, I am also aware of some of the advantages of using GMOs, but personally some possible negatives prevail with me, and that determines my position on this matter.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I objected to this objection because the arguments developed by the European left, which is largely at the origin of it, are false. The Commission has in no way exceeded its powers to allow these products to be put on the market. I would remind you that this is just an authorization. Effective marketing still depends on the states, and therefore on governments.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the assumption that the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing or produced from genetically modified soya MON 87708 x MON 89788 (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1) appears to be in line with EU law, in particular, in addition to the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed, I voted against this resolution which, pursuant to Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure, asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of ‘Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties.’ Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans to be imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with EU law, since it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission's draft implementing decision approves the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87708 soya × MON 89788, which expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein, which shows tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate. Consequently, on the basis that glisophate has been considered by the International Cancer Research Centre – the WHO's specialised agency in this disease – as probably carcinogenic to humans, I support the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and should therefore submit a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The political signal sent this afternoon by MEPs is clear. In approving the objection to the marketing authorization of genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 x MON 89788, by 433 votes in and 234 against, they expressed their displeasure at what is rightly called a strong passage by the European Commission on this issue. How else can we describe the decision taken unilaterally on 18 November 2015 in the absence of the support of a qualified majority of Member States and now without the approval of the Parliament representing European citizens! Certainly, in the absence of a veto right, the objection voted by 433 MEPs from all political groups has no effect on the Commission's discretionary right to allow genetically modified maize, cotton, rapeseed or sugar beet on a case-by-case basis. But this political pressure is not in vain. It shows that the European Parliament is more than ever waiting for a change in the procedure for authorising GMOs, as President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker pledged 18 months ago. And that there is still a joker in the game of MEPs: to operate Article 225 of the Treaty which gives it a right of legislative initiative.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Commission doesn't care about the world. It has been condemned by the European Court of Justice for failing to define criteria for endocrine disruptors and would like to accept three glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans. This active substance found in Monsanto's herbicide RoundUp is itself an endocrine disruptor that has harmful effects, particularly on human reproductive functions. In addition, two of these soybeans are marketed by Monsanto, which would definitely win on all fronts. We were not elected to serve the interests of this delinquent multinational.  As long as the European legislation governing the authorisation of GMOs remains so lax and the Commission is outlawed, we will reject GMOs as a whole, all the more so when they are tolerant to chemicals poorly regulated by European law. We have already taken this position to the European Parliament in October 2015.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the same way as the objection to genetically modified maize passed last December, I supported the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788.  Rejecting the new GMO marketing authorisations is a way for our Parliament to send a clear message to the European Commission to review the current GMO authorisation process. This process is neither satisfactory nor democratic, as each authorisation decision has been adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of the Member States and by ignoring the opinion of Parliament. I would also like to point out that public opinion remains negative about GMOs, that the risk assessment is considered insufficient and that there are no toxicity studies over 90 days.  Finally, I think the precautionary principle here is justified given the tolerance of the soybean in question to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance being evaluated that could be harmful to health.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Monsanto to introduce the variety of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 into the Netherlands. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At noon, I voted for the European Commission not to allow the use of three genetically modified soybeans that tolerate glyphosate in food and animal products. Glyphosate has been classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO) since 20 March 2015. These three genetically modified soybeans that have already been authorised by the EU executive in food and animal products are FG72, MON 87708 x MON 89788 and MON 87705 x MON 89788. In today's vote, of course, I supported each of the three objections that call for their rejection.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the new gmo approval. The soya is designed to be resistant to glyphosate. The World Health Organization's International Cancer Institute recently announced that glyphosate, which gm soybeans accumulate on average 10 mg/kg, is the most likely to be a human carcinogen. I do not understand why the EC refuses to hear these arguments, so I welcome the fact that the majority in the EP has decided to remind the Commission that it must take care of citizens' health.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following an application submitted in 2012 by Monsanto Europe S.A. to place foodstuffs on the market, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from a variety of genetically modified soya, it has been found that it contains glyphosate, so that, and for the same reasons added for the declaration of vote to report B8-0133/2016 on an objection to an equivalent delegated act, I decided to abstain.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to protect the health of citizens, here too, I felt it appropriate to support the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified soya.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on food and food GMOs was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament who understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I would ask the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and taking into account the frequently expressed national concerns, which do not relate solely to issues relating to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. "I voted against the objection to approving the genetically modified soya bean, above all because we have to rely on science, i.e. if the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) considers that a crop is safe after evaluation, this is what we should start from and nothing else. With a growing population and increased climate threats, modern plant breeding is needed in Europe. This includes modern techniques for breeding arable crops and other plants that can feed the world's population and can contribute to a better climate.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of herbicide-tolerant transgenic soybean based on glyphosate and dicamba. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection, because I believe – like my other Socialist colleagues in the chamber today – that the Commission needs to come forward with a new proposal for genetically modified organisms used in food and feed, one which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of the GMOs. Fully-informed and scientifically-guided decision-making process with regards to GMOs that responds to public expectations is required, and that is what my Labour colleagues and I are supporting today.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans because, although the cultivation of GMOs is necessarily taking place on the territory of a Member State, trade in them is of a cross-border nature, which means that a national ban on sale and use, as proposed by the Commission, could not be enforced without the reintroduction of border controls on imported goods. For this reason, we have called on the Commission, by resolution, to present, on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a new legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1289/2003, which takes into account the frequently expressed comments made by Member States, which do not only concern issues of safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 I support the principle of subsidiarity, so that it is the responsibility of each Member State to decide on this subject.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion to object to the Commission’s authorising decisions in order to express opposition to authorisation of these particular varieties of GM soybean and to call on the Commission to live up to its obligation to update the Annexes to Directive 2001/18/EC by 3 April 2017 as regards the environmental risk assessment of GMOs, in line with Parliament’s vote of 13 January 2015. With this decision I, along with other Labour MEPs, voted for a fully informed and scientifically guided decision-making process with regards to GMOs that responds to public expectations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ on 23 March 2012, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application to the competent institutions in the Netherlands, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17. Regulations of the Commission and Parliament No 2013/2013 1829/2003, for placing on the market food consisting of or produced of soybean MON 87708 x MON 89788. I don't support this objection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soy × MON 89788. I cannot support the proposal that the Commission should withdraw the implementing decision. The non-opinion of the Standing Committee on this Decision cannot be an argument for the withdrawal of the Commission's implementing decision. I also believe that, in the area of GMOs, we need a debate based on scientific data and evidence, only then will we show credibility in the argument.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report to veto the approval of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans, since for us the aim remains to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and the interests of consumers.  At the same time, we have taken into account the conclusions of the World Health Organisation's Cancer Research Agency, which state that the three species of genetically modified soybeans possess various types of herbicides which have been identified as potentially carcinogenic to humans. In addition, we oppose the EU's practice of deciding and enforcing the placing and use of genetically modified products on Member States' markets, as under no circumstances should the sovereignty of states be sacrificed on the altar of profit and competition to decide on key issues such as the health and well-being of their citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The placing on the market of genetically modified soya products is not in conformity with Union law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified MON 87708 x MON 89788 soyba. On 23 March 2012, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted a marketing application to the competent authority of the Netherlands. The genetically modified soybeans in question express the dicamba monooxygenase proteins, which provide tolerance to diamba-containing herbicides, and the CP 4 EPSPS protein, which provides tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. The WHO's International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance "likely to be carcinogenic to humans" in 2015. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission without the opinions of the Committees of the Member States and, in the case of GM food and feed, it has become common practice to return the dossier to the Commission for final approval. I agree that, even if production necessarily occurs on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders. Thus, the national 'sales and use' ban proposed by the Commission could not be enforced in the single internal market. I supported the withdrawal of the regulation and for the Commission to present a new legislative proposal based on a high level of protection of human and animal health, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have contributed my yes to the adoption of this resolution. Mon 87708 soybeans × MON 89788 is tolerant of the infamous glyphosate and dicamba. Of course, those who grow it will tend to use more of the two substances, in the certainty that the harvest will not suffer. I am strongly opposed to GMOs and even more opposed, if possible, to those who express resistance to herbicides. The German professional study ForCare, which deals with toxicology, published a report last November in which it points out that EFSA, assessing the safety of soya MON 87708 × MON 89788, did not take into account the combined effects of residues of these two herbicides contained in soya itself. Moreover, there is no scientific literature on this subject, but one consideration seems reasonable: glyphosate and dicamba residues, combined together, can produce an additive effect or, even worse, a synergistic effect. Animals fed on this soya and citizens who feed on products obtained from these animals shall be exposed to the additive and/or synergistic effect. We must not venture into territories that science has not yet been able to explore. The precautionary principle must apply to GMO soya resistant to two herbicides.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. No, no The Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law.  Our goal is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests. The European consumer must not be the guinea pig of multinationals!!!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Contrary to the result of the final vote, I opposed the objection to authorise the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788. The application to put the soybean concerned on the market was fully compliant with EU legislation; the technical decision to authorise it or not is then left to the Commission, which assesses the application based on scientific evidence. The Commission agreed to validate the placing on the market and I see no reason for denying the scientific assessment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: approval of genetically modified soy bee MON 87708 × MON 89788, as I believe that our priority in the field of genetically modified food and feed is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection and the environment.  Given that this substance is classified as a carcinogen for humans, it is important that we be particularly careful here to highlight this in order to protect the interests of consumers, the people of the Union and to strengthen their confidence.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on food and food GMOs was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament who understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposed to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. Two of them have another characteristic: different fatty acid composition for GMO B and tolerance to dicamba (a pesticide) for GMO C. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven).  As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including ignoring relevant observations from Member States. Moreover, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. So I vote for the objection, even symbolic.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. has submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87708 × MON 89788. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position on this issue.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87708 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure responds more to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on food and food GMOs was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament who understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Владимир Уручев (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 At today's vote, I supported the objection to the authorisation of imports of three types of genetically modified soybean for use as food and feed. These types of soybeans are engineered for resistance when spraying with herbicide glyphosate and combinations with other herbicides. On the other hand, in 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (a specialist WHO agency) already classified glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans. The European Food Safety Agency has not carried out the necessary assessment of the risk of this herbicide and the effects of combining it with other herbicides.  With the final vote against the admission of these three GMOs, albeit by a small majority, for the third time in a row, the EP has shown consistent disagreement with the procedures for authorising GMOs in the EU. Despite the fact that the objections adopted are not binding on the Commission, the EP's consistently expressed position requires a rethink of the pan-European system for approving GMOs and until this happens, new authorisations for GMOs should not be available. I therefore call for a revision of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 to allow GMO authorisations to be adopted by means of delegated acts rather than implementing acts, thereby allowing Parliament to exercise more effective democratic control.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I do not support it because: unpredictable health risks, possible emergence of new allergens or toxic substances in foodstuffs. Potential environmental threats: genetic contamination, uncontrolled spread of genes in the environment. Danger to biodiversity. Development of resistant forms of pests and weeds.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have always advocated that Latvia and the European Union as a whole be free from genetically modified organisms (GMOs). We must not allow the health of our citizens to be put at risk in the interests of any economic interest.  It is regrettable that this is another time when the European Commission, contrary to the member states' position, wants to give the green light to the placing on the market of new GMO products, in the exercise of its powers under its own legislation. GMO soya beans are resistant to glyphosate, which has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer as a possible carcinogen for humans.  This time, the EC not only failed to take into account national concerns about the harmfulness of GMOs, but also ignored the world health organisation agency's research into glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance.  In the light of the studies carried out by the World Health Organisation Agency on glyphosate and the negative attitude of the Latvian public towards GMOs, I voted against the placing on the market of these three GMO soybeans.  Furthermore, I believe that the existing legislative procedure should be changed in order to give both the European Parliament and the states greater decision-making rights when authorising new GMOs for the placing on the market, thereby ensuring more effective democratic control and respect for the public interest.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection concerning the genetically modified soybean MON 87708 x MON 89788 because I believe that the Commission should not authorise the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM soybeans in food and feed, specifically for two reasons: the first reason is that glyphosate, a herbicide, was classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization’s cancer agency. The second reason is that currently GMOs are being authorised in the EU without the support of Member States: in fact, every GM authorisation decision has so far been taken by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of Member States.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted against the objection to accepting the genetically modified soybean. We must rely on science and our European Food Safety Authority. They believe that this crop is safe. With a growing population and increasing threats to the climate, we need modern plant breeding in Europe. These modern techniques for growing agricultural crops and other plants, among other things, can contribute to a better food for the world's population and a better climate.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Following the Commission's authorisation to import three GMOs, FG 72, MON 87708 and MON 87705, for human food purposes, the European Parliament has used, on the proposals of my GUE/NGL policy group and the Greens, its right to oppose these authorisations. By giving the go-ahead for these authorisations, the Commission has once again ignored the European Parliament's position on GMOs. It has always authorised applications filed following the positive opinions of the European Food Safety Authority. Such decisions are contrary to the rejection of the proposal for a legislative revision made in April 2015 allowing national bans by the European Parliament in October 2014, as the European Parliament considered that such a relaxation did not respond to the need to protect European citizens from the environmental and health risks of GMOs. I voted to reject these authorizations. The European Parliament is sending a new political signal for the Commission to review EU GMO legislation and to hear the voices of European citizens who are overwhelmingly opposed to GMOs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation decision on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well. It requests that no new range of GMOs be authorised, nor have the old authorisations renewed, until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. Whereas all these soy products confer increased tolerance to different types of herbicides (especially glyphosate, which was classified as likely to be carcinogenic to humans by the IARC on 15 March 2015), this draft implementing decision is not compatible with the objectives of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in human and animal feed.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. I opposed the Commission's proposal to authorise two new GMOs. No GMOs will have to be authorised until democratic control over authorisations is adequately strengthened, so that the positions of citizens and Member States are taken into account. In this respect, Parliament has already asked the Commission to present a new legislative proposal. In addition, the import of these specific GMOs could expose consumers and animals to negative effects of the herbicides with which they were treated. We cannot allow any herbicide-tolerant GMOs to be authorised until its effects are absolutely clear.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products, the genetically modified soya beans of the variety MON 87708 × MON 89788 (MON-877-8-9 × MON-89788-1) contain, consist of or are derived from, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to present a new legislative proposal that takes better account of national interests and concerns. That is my goal. I am opposed to the blanket admissibility of genetically modified organisms and I am in favour of greater consideration for national concerns at EU level, preferably through more subsidiarity.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr La Via's proposal on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection. The resolution lays down the conditions for strengthening food safety, protecting the environment and the consumer public.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported all three objections concerning GM soybeans. In them, we called on the Commission to withdraw its proposal for an implementing regulation authorising the placing on the market of GM soybeans and to submit a proposal for a new one that takes into account the possible cancer-forming effects of substances contained in so-called soybeans. My opinion on GMOs has been unchanged for a long time. I believe that health protection is the most important value on this issue, which we must not underestimate under any circumstances, and since GMOs and their effects on human health are not sufficiently examined and evaluated in the long term, we should be extremely careful on this issue.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Parliament's resolution calls on the European Commission not to place on the market food and feed containing transgenic soya MON 87708 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1) resistant not only to glyphosate but also to another herbicide, Dicamba.  Transgenic soybeans have the characteristic of designed in the laboratory to resist the action of glyphosate, a pesticide that was recently classified by IARC, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in Lyon, as "probably carcinogenic" to humans. In particular, this genetically modified soybean is also resistant to Dicamba, an organic chlorine-based compound highly persistent in the environment once used and which has a higher toxicity than glyphosate itself. Further genetic modification was necessary, since weeds were beginning to develop glyphosate resistance. I have always fought to ensure that genetically modified food and feed do not enter European territory, and I repeat once again by voting in favour of this report, which was promoted together with my colleagues in the 5 Star Movement. I believe in a GMO-free Europe that protects people's health and not the interests of biotech multinationals.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted × against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing × on the market of products containing, consisting of or consisting of or produced from MON-87708-1 genetically modified soybee, mon 87708 and MON 89788 .1. We must certainly ensure high levels of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed. However, there is no consistent evidence in scientific studies of the potential toxicity and allergenicity of genetically modified enzymes.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objection is based on the characteristic of transgenic soya to resist the action of glyphosate recently classified by the IARC in Lyon as a probable carcinogen for humans, despite a diatribe between researchers at the WHO institute and EFSA.  In the interests of the health of European citizens, I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of the resolution opposing the Commission's proposal for an implementing decision (EU) on the placing on the market of food and feed based on or containing glyphosate-resistant transgenic soya.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of transgenic soybean with a reduced expression of two enzymes, resulting in a profile rich in oleic acid and poor in linoleic acid and is tolerant to glyphosate-based herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection by the European Parliament on the marketing of products containing genetically modified GMO soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788. Indeed, I am deeply opposed to the introduction of new GMOs on the market. In addition, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment which highlights, among other things, relevant observations from Member States in this direction. Although I regret that this text has only symbolic significance, because being not binding on the Commission, I support this objection.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this objection resolution. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 the Commission has made authorisation decisions on new GMOs without the support of the Member State committees.  This situation was intended to be an exception in the legislation which has unfortunately become the norm. Commission President Juncker has failed to fulfil the promise he made as a candidate for the Presidency of the Commission to fix this democratic deficit in decision-making for GMOs in the European Union. The Commission is therefore authorising the placing on the market of products with a system which it itself has recognised is flawed. It is essential that the Commission now comes up with a real proposal on GMOs to correct this democratic deficit.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 In this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament wishes to raise its objections in accordance with Article 106 on the authorisation of the placing on the market of genetically modified soya MON87705 × MON89788.  In October Parliament rejected the Commission's new proposal on genetically modified food and feed and asked it to come back with a new proposal. In the meantime, new genetically modified foods and feedingstuffs should not be authorised to be placed on the market under the existing legal framework. The specific type of soybeans whose disposal has been approved is resistant to certain herbicides and therefore its cultivation may encourage a freer use of herbicides, which may have harmful effects on human health.  For all the above reasons I voted in favour of objecting as we believe that the Commission should present a new proposal on genetically modified food and feed, which will more accurately assess the environmental impact of GMOs.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament rejects a Commission decision to allow glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans across the EU. In view of the fact that the plant protection product glyphosate in particular has been classified by the World Health Organisation as potentially carcinogenic, and that I generally reject GMO foods because of the unknown long-term consequences, I fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate.  EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Therefore, I logically voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106; I am concerned by the increasing usage of delegated acts and am therefore minded to support any objections as a matter of course. In this instance, I note specifically that the World Health Organization has described these specific varieties as being potentially carcinogenic to humans.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. With regard to my general position on GMOs, I am against the precautionary principle that prevents research in Europe. Moreover, I am surprised at the hypocrisy of banning the marketing of these products, which Europe then allows itself to import.  Nevertheless, I voted against the introduction of this pesticide-resistant variety, as it is considered by many research centres, including lyon, to be a variety that could be dangerous.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal requesting the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision concerning the marketing authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788. The draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with EU law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation No 1829/2003 and Regulation No 396/2005, which aims to establish a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Bayer CropScience and Monsanto. All three are tolerant to glyphosate, with another characteristic for Monsanto's two GMOs: different fatty acid composition for GMO MON 87705 × MON 89788 and dicamba tolerance (a pesticide) for GMO MON 87708 × MON 89788. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven). As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, the assessment provided by EFSA remains manifestly unsatisfactory.  Alas, the objections to the acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission, and the amendments that my group has tabled - to make the objections binding and to remind us that the Commission is not even waiting for the end of the objection procedures to publish the GMO authorisations - have unfortunately been rejected.  Their rejection, recorded by RCV, thus shows the hypocrisy of elected officials who are in fact against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs. However, GMO authorizations should be able to be issued by delegated deed and not by deed of execution.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The introduction of herbicide-resistant genetically modified organisms can pose a serious threat to the health of European citizens and the environment.  I have today voted in favour of objections to the authorisation of three types of genetically modified soya, including MON 87705 x MON 89788, because I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs.  With regard to soya MON 87705 x MON 89788, in particular, concern concerns the presence of the CP4 EPSPS protein which gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. In March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a who's specialised body, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Given the potential danger to health, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs and feed from GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GENETICally modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the acts implemented, this measure is more responsive to an act of a purely political nature and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to explain that I voted against my group's line in this report on the objection raised on the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87705 x MON 89788. The Basque Country is a GMO-free region and, as I did in 2015, I voted in favour of the ENVI Commission's motion for a resolution which considers that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not consistent with EU law as it is incompatible with the purpose of several Regulations. I therefore support the request for withdrawal of the draft Implementing Decision.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's objection to the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788. Its approval by EFSA demonstrates the phasing out of the precautionary principle in food safety and the Commission's submission to pressure from major industrial groups such as Monsanto. This genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788 has a tolerance to dicamba, a pesticide known to be teratogenic and more widely toxic to men, especially pregnant women. Such endangering consumers, despite the reservations expressed by Member States, is an irresponsibility on the part of EFSA.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified soya MON MON 87705 × MON 89788.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Monsanto to introduce the variety of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 897888 into the Netherlands. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it criticised, did not approve the Commission's implementing decision and requested the submission of a new draft decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soybeans. In 2011, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application for placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed containing soya consisting of them. Genetically modified soybeans produce less fatty acid desaturase and palmitoyl acyl acid carrier tioesterase enzymes, resulting in more oleic acid and less linoleic acid, as well as a protein that makes soy resistant to glyphosate herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a specialised Cancer Agency of the World Health Organisation, classified glyphosate as a probably carcinogenic substance in humans.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported this objection for the same reasons as the previous two. I myself am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for such a soy behable to get through the process as sensitive as the registration of GMOs. Blaming institutions and putting responsibilities on top is also counterproductive. We are at a sensitive moment when institutions should have greater respect among themselves, and above all we must respect the will of the people who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO food authorisation system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  For five years, Member States could not agree on granting or refusing a MON 87705xMON 89788 soybean licence. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The 3 GMOs of soybeans proposed by the Commission to authorize the importation have properties that serve only the interests of Monsanto and possibly industrial producers. I consider that once again EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment of the risks involved and that the objections proposed by the ENVI Committee are well founded. For all these reasons, I voted FOR these objections.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision on genetically modified soya MON 87705 x MON 89788 does not comply with EU law as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consists, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, in providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. I therefore believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to allow the marketing of three new types of genetically modified soybeans from the US company Monsanto. It is in this context that this objection is intended to signal Parliament's opposition to the marketing of these three genetically modified organisms (GMOs), which are tolerant to glyphosate. One of them also has a tolerance to the pesticide dicamba.  While this objection will not force the Commission to abandon the commercialisation of these GMOs, we consider it essential to vote on it to show Parliament's disapproval of the Commission and EFSA, whose assessments are unsatisfactory and do not take into account the comments of the Member States' authorities.  That is why I voted for this objection.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this century, the development of agriculture is occurring on a microcellular level, and the risks to be supervised by the Union, as a guarantor of the food safety of its citizens, as well as the protection of the environment, hover around the safety of genetically modified organisms. Furthermore, we recall that inadequate nutrition is by far the leading cause of disease and mortality worldwide - more important than tobacco, alcohol and lack of physical activity together. It becomes clear that guaranteeing the union and global security of food is not only an important objective assumed by the Union, but also a situation that requires attention from the stakeholders. However, given that there are no scientific studies confirming the negative effects that certain substances have on those who consume them, I believe that we should not have a radical position in withdrawing them from the market. In view of the need for concrete evidence, I voted against the resolution on the objection raised under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: the authorisation for genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 x MON 89788.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Since the adoption of Directive (EU) 2015/412, which allows Member States to ban the cultivation of authorised GMOs internally, the Commission, although permanently deadlocked in the competent committee due to cross-vetoes, has been unblocking all pending GMO authorisation procedures. That is why the ENVI Committee is systematically proposing objections to any new authorised GMOs. Unfortunately, in these cases Parliament's objections are not binding on the Commission, since they are implementing acts.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection concerning the authorisation of genetically modified soya MON 87705 x MON 89788.  In August 2011, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified soya. This type of soya expresses a protein that gives tolerance to herbicides based on glyphosate, a substance that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified as probably carcinogenic to humans. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not therefore appear to be in accordance with EU law, not guaranteeing a high level of protection of human and animal life and health, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, nor the effective functioning of the internal market.  Consequently, I have decided to vote in favour of the objection to this draft implementing decision by asking the Commission, as indicated in the motion for a resolution, to present a new legislative proposal that takes account of the frequently expressed national concerns about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment and the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because authorisation of this specific genetically modified soybean would be against the interests of consumers. Studies of genetically modified foods have shown that they bring no benefits to human health, but on the other hand may have negative consequences.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution opposes the placing on the market of food and feed based on hybrid transgenic soya resistant to glyphosate and with an increased content of oleic acoro.  I have decided to support this resolution and to vote in favour of it. These products are classified as potentially carcinogenic and therefore put the health of citizens at risk.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the motion for a resolution and stress that our aim is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified foods and genetically modified feedingstuffs, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the objections raised to the authorisation of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans. As is easily understood, this issue concerns the entire population of Europe, as it directly affects the public health sector and any approval must be given after thorough discussion and research in order to ensure the health of citizens. In fact, the decisions we will take are of particular importance, as the genetically modified food sector can potentially cause major turbulence in Europe's economy as well. In this light, I believe that the objections raised are correct and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with EU law as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulations (EC) No. Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which consists of providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Coming from an agricultural land, I am well aware that the role of technology allows to avoid physical fatigue but is not usually a substitute for those procedures tested over the millennia and refined by practice, and that give us those agro-food excellences of which our Italy is very rich. That is why, with great perplexity, I voted against the authorisation of this product (thus voting in favour of the objection).

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this objection as individual GMOs and the GMO combinations in question have been authorised by the Commission and deemed safe for human consumption by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA). This objection is an attempt to change the system of authorisation by those who are opposed to GM. Member States can decide whether to cultivate GM crops or not. There is no commercial cultivation of GMO products in Ireland, nor is there any expected in the short to mid-term given the lack of relevant GMO products on the market.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution seeks to place on the market products containing genetically modified soybean. The production of goods containing genetically modified ingredients is not limited to consumption or use in one State as this facilitates the development of GMO trade across borders. This will make it impossible for those Member States who ban the sales and use of genetically modified products to effectively take such health—related decisions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of transgenic soybean with a reduced expression of two enzymes, resulting in a profile rich in oleic acid and poor in linoleic acid and is tolerant to glyphosate-based herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Last October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on genetically modified food and feed and asked the Commission to come up with a new proposal. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework, which the Commission acknowledges is not working well. The soybeans in these three authorisation processes in question are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. I voted in favour of the objection, because I believe that the Commission should review the draft implementing act, taking account of the position expressed.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the objection resolution to the authorisation of soybean MON 87705 x MON 89788. I believe that it is absolutely vital for public confidence that in Europe we have a GM regulation system that is underpinned by science. This means that products passing a robust, independent safety assessment should have fair market access. The European Food safety agency has declared this GM trait safe for food and feed use, and we should respect that decision made by experts, otherwise we risk undermining not only our own credibility but also the principle of science-based decision-making.  The use of GM material in animal feed is significant across the EU, and our livestock sector is heavily dependent on imported GM feed materials, so it is important that EU GM authorisations proceed as rapidly as possible to keep pace with authorisations in other parts of the world and avoid significant disruption in the international trade of agricultural commodities, which could have a negative impact on food prices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This proposal to object from a member of the Socialists and Democrats group concerns the European Commission's draft decision in favour of authorising GMO soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 tolerant of glyphosate in food and animal products. The rapporteur argues that glyphosate is a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). However, this justification is questionable. On the one hand, the European Commission's draft decision follows the positive opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Its conclusions are based on a large number of studies, including those of the IARC, and scientific data as explained by the authors in an exchange of views with MEPs last December. On the other hand, the European Commission has respected its mandate as part of its enforcement power, which stems from European legislation, approved by the European Parliament. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the many precautionary measures voted by the European legislator in this area. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I believe in science-based policy; to this extent I believe that it is the task of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to decide whether a genetically modified organism is safe and fit for consumption. The EFSA advice should be the basis for the final decision. Since the EFSA advice was positive, I voted against this objection.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Currently, Genetically Modified Organizations (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of three genetically modified soybeans tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MON 87705 and MON 89788 have been combined with single-amendment soy lines to create the genetically modified soy mon 87705 x MON 89788 with double modification. Thus, soy has become resistant to herbicides with the active substance glyphosate and has a different fatty acid profile. Although the abovementioned active substance is not considered to have an outlier toxicity, there are a number of scientific literature data on its negative effects on human and animal health.  A number of deficiencies were identified in the risk assessment carried out, including: • when examining the internal components (excluding the altered fatty acid profile), phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, MON 87705 x MON 89788 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  • Instead of in vivo feeding tests, only in vitro indigestion tests have been carried out, which is not always suitable for the feeding experiment. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Environment Committee's objection to three European Commission decisions authorising the marketing of animal feed containing GM soybeans produced by Monsanto and Bayer. These three GMO soybeans have the distinction of developing a tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides, including Monsanto's Roundup, a substance classified as probably carcinogenic by the World Health Organization. I believe that the three authorisation decisions are not compatible with the European Union's objectives on human and animal health, as defined in legislation. That is why I welcome today's vote and the clear majority that has emerged to veto the European Parliament's marketing of GMO soybean products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto, tolerant to glyphosate. GMO B has a different composition in fatty acid and GMO C is a tolerance to the pesticide "dicamba". To the extent that these properties are intended only to serve Monsanto's interests, and EFSA has not taken into account the relevant views of the States, I have naturally voted in favour of these objections. Finally, our three amendments were aimed at ensuring that the authorisations took place in the form of delegated acts, in order to ensure democratic control over the marketing of GMOs.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I and the party I represent – THE MRRO, we are against any genetically modified food and feed. In a draft decision, the Commission announced the authorisation of the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1). GMOs are not a solution for what we eat or what we feed the animals we consume, and that is why I oppose it always and everywhere.  For me, citizens' health is more important than trade and competitiveness. Recently (in October 2015), I rejected the EC's proposal that each country be able to decide for itself whether to authorise or ban GMOs. To some extent, the proposal was very attractive, but in practice not applicable because of the EU single market.  I have always been a supporter of the overall ban on GMOs across the European market so that our citizens know that their rulers put their health first and I think this is the only policy we can have on this issue. In the present case, I voted in favour of the objection leading to a ban on the placing on the market of GMO soybeans.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified soya products of the MON 87705 × MON 89788 series (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1) which is not in accordance with Union law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MON 87705 and MON 89788 have been combined with single-amendment soy lines to create the genetically modified soy mon 87705 x MON 89788 with double modification. Thus, soy has become resistant to herbicides with the active substance glyphosate and has a different fatty acid profile. Although the abovementioned active substance is not considered to have an outlier toxicity, there are a number of scientific literature data on its negative effects on human and animal health. A number of deficiencies were identified in the risk assessment carried out, including: • when examining the internal components (excluding the altered fatty acid profile), phenotypic and agronomic characteristics, MON 87705 x MON 89788 genetically modified soy was significantly different from control. However, EFSA considered none of the significant differences to be such as to require further studies, which it considered to be biologically irrelevant differences.  • Instead of in vivo feeding tests, only in vitro indigestion tests have been carried out, which is not always suitable for the feeding experiment. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The process of authoring GMOs in Europe is not democratic.  In this case, as in all previous clearance cases, the Commission acted unilaterally despite the fact that the proposal had not been adopted by the technical reference committee. I therefore supported the objection to the authorisation of GM MON 87705 x MON 89788 soya, not least because of the scientific doubts that GMOs entail. In fact, the soybean in question expresses the enzymes FAD2 (fatty acid Δ12-desaturase) and FATB (palmitoil ACP theoesterase), which results in a profile high in oleic acid and low in linoleic acid, and expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein that gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised body of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application to place on the market food, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87705 × MON 89788, which contains glycophafate, considered by the International Cancer Research Centre to be probably carcinogenic to humans.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I am opposed to the introduction of GMOs on the market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the MON87705xMON89788 was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands on 11/08/2011. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee of 18/11/2015 having been assessed with "no opinion", as has been the case since this procedure was agreed. This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation of a decision, on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised, nor to renew the old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection as I feel the technology is being used to help multinationals dominate the food market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the resolution objecting to any new authorised GMOs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as it proposes that the Commission withdraw the draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified soya products of the MON 87705 × MON 89788 series (MON -877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1) which is not in accordance with EU law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health , as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In October Parliament rejected the new Commission proposal on GM food and feed and asked the Commission to come up with a new one. In the meantime, no new GM food/feed should therefore be authorised under the current legal framework which the Commission acknowledges is not working in a satisfactory way. The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.
