In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The genetically modified soybeans described in the application express the dicamba monooxygenase proteins, which provide tolerance to dicamba-containing herbicides and a type of protein that provides tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. As the International Agency for Research on Cancer , the WHO's specialised agency for cancer diseases, has been working on the 2015 european commission's report on cancer, it is not the first time that the commission has been involved in the fight against cancer. On 20 March 2003, it classified glyphosate as a substance likely to be carcinogenic to humans, so I consider it appropriate to call on the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, taking into account the frequently voiced concerns expressed by Member States that are not only related to the risks posed by GMOs to health or the environment.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection on the ground that the Commission Implementation Decision guarantees a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, I believe that the European Commission × should present × a new comprehensive proposal on GMOs and carefully assess their environmental and health impact. Indeed, I think that the European Parliament has clearly expressed, in the vote last October, its opposition to the Commission's proposal on GMOs, calling for adequate guarantees and a new legislative proposal: there are still many doubts and questions, given the established practice of taking decisions on GMOs without a technical opinion from the Standing Committee of the Member States. The introduction of genetically modified soya MON 87708 × MON 89788, with a high content of oleic acid and low in linoleic acid and containing glyphosate-resistant proteins, poses environmental and health problems, leading to an increase in the use of these pesticides. I believe that these concerns need to be adequately addressed by EFSA and the European Commission through impact assessments and require comprehensive, clear legislation that takes due account of the concerns of our citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the objection under Article 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soya beans of the MON 87708 × MON 89788. The Family Party of Germany is opposed to the use of genetically modified seeds in agriculture.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding GMOs, I support the existing, science-based decision-making process, judged independently by the European Food Safety Authority. The Commission needs to make a proposal which includes a greater assessment of the environmental impact of GMOs.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wants to allow the importation of three new GMO soybeans, all tolerant to glyphosate. One of them is a soybean from the American company Monsanto. I supported this objection in committee and in plenary, not least because glyphosate weedkillers are carcinogenic, according to the World Health Organization. It should also be stressed that EFSA's assessment is unsatisfactory and does not take into account the observations of the relevant agencies of the Member States.  Nevertheless, the European Commission can ignore these objections, as GMO authorisations are its sole authority. It demonstrated this last December by authorising a new GMO maize, the NK603xT25, despite opposition from the European Parliament. That is why it is necessary that these authorisations are now under the democratic control of Parliament, which I have proposed by way of amendments to amend the GMO authorisation regulation and replace enforcement acts with delegated acts. Indeed, the objections voted by Parliament can put a real veto on the Commission's decisions.  But when it comes to asking for real democratic measures, especially when it comes to GMOs, this Parliament is decidedly absent subscribers.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure is more responsive to a purely political act and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal noting that GMOs are being authorised in the EU without the support of Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Commission’s proposal on the authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788 due to the same reasoning as for soybean FG72.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MON 87705 and MON 89788 have been combined with single-amendment soy lines to create the genetically modified soy mon 87705 x MON 89788 with double modification. Thus, soy has become resistant to herbicides with the active substance glyphosate and has a different fatty acid profile. Although the abovementioned active substance is not considered to have an outlier toxicity, there are a number of scientific literature data on its negative effects on human and animal health.  There are a number of shortcomings in the risk assessment carried out. In my view, a GM product which has not been thoroughly examined from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore did not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. Given our opposition to GMOs, we supported the three objections in this area. In October last year, the Commission's proposal on GMOs was rejected by the EP. Through these objections we want to put pressure on the Commission to make a proposal that respects the right of Member States not to allow the movement of GMOs on their territory.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MON 87705 and MON 89788 have been combined with single-amendment soy lines to create the genetically modified soy mon 87705 x MON 89788 with double modification. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The environmental impacts of GMOs must be rigorously assessed through a new proposal from the Commission for GMO food and fodder.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I vote for a motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing the GENETICALLY modified mon 87705 x MON 89788 strain (MON-87705-6 x MON-89788-1), consist of or manufactured under Regulation (EC) No 1. 1829/2003 Of Parliament and the Council, as this requires the Commission to withdraw its draft decision.  The genetically modified strain in question contains certain substances which, following research by the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the World Health Organization, are very likely carcinogenic to humans. Notwithstanding that farming takes place exclusively on the territory of one Member State, trade in products takes place beyond national borders and therefore the proposed national prohibition on sale and use would be unenforceable.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Monsanto's soybean cultivation is the colonization of Europe by foreign interests: the properties of this soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial farmers. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, while its assessment of GMOs is widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of flushing out elected representatives who are against "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs.  Of course, I voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the report of my colleagues Bart Staes, Sirpa Pietik-inen, Guillaume Balas, Lynn Boylan and Eleonora Evi on the objection in accordance with Article 106 concerning the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788. Indeed, some political groups led by the Greens accuse the Commission of failing to comply with the authorisation procedure for genetically modified organisms. However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a study that concluded that this product is safe for humans, animals and the environment. Above all, the authorisation to market is currently the responsibility of the Member States. This resolution was adopted, which I regret.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though as this vote is an objection to an implementing act, and this objection might be more of a political move made by different groups in the chamber, EH Bildu has maintained a coherent position on matters related to GMOs and always vote against those, or, in cases such as last December with maize NK603*T25, vote in favour of objections to allowing the authorisation of GMOs. The genetically modified MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1 soybean, as described in the application, has a reduced expression of fatty acid Δ12-desaturase (FAD2) and palmitoyl acyl carrier protein thioesterase (FATB) enzymes, which results in increased oleic acid and reduced linoleic acid profile and expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein which confers tolerance to glyphosate herbicides; whereas the International Agency for Research on Cancer – the specialised cancer agency of the World Health Organisation – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. Therefore, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this objection, and will keep voting in the same way to any future objection concerning authorisation of GMOs, as we would like to put pressure to the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal that is more satisfactory than the one rejected by Parliament last October.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This objection has been lodged by a number of political groups who believe that the European Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788.  However, the European Food Safety Authority has conducted a comprehensive and proper study to authorise this soy. Moreover, if the authorisation to grow GMOs is granted at European level, it is the States that retain control over the marketing authorisation. I therefore voted against this objection, which was merely declaratory, without foundation and without any legal effect.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution on the problem of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The Rejection of GMOs throughout Austria must be accepted by the Commission. This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to withdraw immediately the implementing decision approving the genetically modified maize variety NK603xT25. Instead, a new legislative proposal is to be presented, which responds to the concerns of the countless Member States, which are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported resolutions B8-0133/2016 and B8-0134/2016, I supported and voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution, calling for the withdrawal of, or produced from, the Commission Implementing Decision permitting the placing on the market of products containing, genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1). The European Commission should come up with a better proposal on authorisation procedures. The current proposal does not address the often expressed concerns about the potential health and environmental risks of GMOs. The consequences that products containing GMOs can have on humans and the environment are not yet sufficiently identified and there is too much uncertainty for genetically modified products.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection in order to express my opposition to authorisation of these varieties of GM soybean.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 MON 87705 and MON 89788 have been combined with single-amendment soy lines to create the genetically modified soy mon 87705 x MON 89788 with double modification. name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution opposing the possibility of trading products containing modified soya MON 87708 x MON 89788, as it is in the interest of Polish farmers to retain the possibility of purchasing soybean feed components. Only about 10% of the feed used is more expensive organic feed. A ban on the purchase of cheaper feed and its components produced using genetic engineering would primarily affect Polish poultry producers and negatively affect poultry exports, in which Poland is a leader.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against this objection. Genetically modified soybeans MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1 expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein, and therefore gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. The latter has been studied by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). On 12 November 2015, it published its conclusions, which were reached through detailed studies by a group of experts responsible for the joint review. The Latter concluded that glyphosate does not pose a threat to humans. In addition to introducing an acute reference dose (DAR), the disamine proposed additional toxicological safety thresholds as a guide for risk assessors: the permissible level of operator exposure (LAEO) was set at 0.1 mg/kg body weight per day and the acceptable daily intake (ADI) for consumers was set at 0.5 mg/kg body weight, in line with the acute reference dose.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission asked us to allow the importation of three glyphosate-resistant transgenic soybeans. Glyphosate is a herbicide recognized as a carcinogen by the World Health Organization. Despite these recommendations, the European Health Authority EFSA, whose relationship with the GMO industries has too often been demonstrated, continues to regard it as non-harmful. So I voted against those authorizations. They are dangerous, do not respect the precautionary principle and undermine the European position against GMOs to promote trade at the expense of our health. EFSA's positions in favour of GMOs are becoming increasingly problematic. EFSA must take into account the concerns of citizens and, above all, thoroughly review its assessment procedures, which are playing into the hands of the big multinational seed companies.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the section 106 objection to the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788. The Commission proposes to allow genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788. This GMO is tolerant to glyphosate, which is probably carcinogenic to humans. As with previous GMO authorisation cases, EFSA (Europesan Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including ignoring relevant observations from Member States. Unfortunately, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. This is the purpose of the amendment of the ENL Group, which points to this fact and calls for the authorisations to be issued in the form of delegated acts.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The impact of GM foods on human health is questionable. I therefore support the consumer having information on whether the product is natural or genetically modified. I support the idea that it should be up to individual Member States whether or not to authorise the import of GM products. I am not joining the appeal to ban the import of these foodstuffs across the EU across the eu. I abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Monsanto Europe S.A. in August 2011 applied to the competent authority in the Netherlands for authorisation to market food, food and feed ingredients containing MON 87705 x MON 89788. The MON 87705 x MON 89788 strain contains a protein that also has glyphosate in it. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, an agency of the World Health Organization specializing in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances that are probably carcinogenic to man.  Parliament found in October 2015 that although cultivation takes place on the territory of one Member State, the Commission's prohibition on use and sale is unenforceable as this would require the reintroduction of border controls on imports. The Commission is being asked to withdraw its draft decision and to present a new legislative proposal on the amendment, taking into account national issues that do not relate only to problems related to the safety of GMOs for health and the environment.  I did not support the proposal for an objection in accordance with Article 106, because I think it is important to ensure the protection of the health of all EU and Croatian citizens.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At today's plenary session, I supported all three objections to the European Commission's projects to authorise the placing on the market of three types of genetically modified soybeans. The issue of GMOs has always divided votes in the European Parliament not on a partisan basis, but on the basis of a principled national "for" or "against" stance on the cultivation and placing on the market of genetically modified organisms. Bulgaria has a consistent conservative and restrictive national policy on these issues and strives to prioritise the development of organic farming in the country. I therefore did not follow the ERA line and voted in favour of the proposed objections from the Parliamentary Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Doubts about health risks regarding glyphosate, possibly carcinogenic to humans, and the lack of opinion from Member States required a majority of MEPs to formally ask the Commission to withdraw its draft and not approve the placing on the market of GMO soybeans.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Approximately 4,5 years ago Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the relevant official authorities of the Netherlands an application to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified soybean MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1. In view of the existence of the single market, this application was sent to the Commission, which it would like to confirm. Similar to today's vote, these beans are synthesized by the protein CP4 EPSPS, which confers resistance to glyphosate herbicides, while the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a possible carcinogen for humans. The fact that the existence of various genetically modified goods and their elements in our single market has already become a daily reality is categorically unacceptable for the placing on the market of goods whose placing has not gone through all the legally necessary consultations – which the Commission once again did not implement. To a large extent, that is why the European Parliament voted against the existing proposal. My voice was thus given away for the EP's rejection decision.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution based on objections pursuance to Article 106 on the draft Commission implementing decision approving the placing on the market of products containing them, consist of or are produced from genetically modified soybeans of the MON 87705 × MON 89788 series (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 87788-1). This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this objection. As in previous countries, the European Commission is proposing to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto, including MON 87705 x MON 89788 which, like the previous ones, is tolerant to glyphosate, and is also tolerant to the pesticide 'dicamba', two properties that serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial farmers. In addition, EFSA (the European Food Safety Authority) has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including excluding relevant observations from Member States.  We therefore support this objection.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal noting that GMOs are being authorised in the EU without the support of Member States.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objection under Article 106 "authorisation of genetically modified soya MON 87705 x MON 89788" is not supported.  By stressing the importance of protecting human health, the importance of consumer health and the high level of control needed to protect health from products potentially harmful to the body and health, one understands the reason for the position expressed by the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution seeks that the draft Commission implementing decision on food and feed, constituted or produced from genetically modified soya, is reformulated and improved, as the way it has been presented does not ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests. GMOs and, in particular, these products from soybeans have great intolerance to various types of herbicides, such as glyphosate, which has been considered probably carcinogenic to humans by the International Cancer Research Centre, the WHO agency specializing in this disease.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission decision authorising imports into EU countries of three types of genetically modified soybeans 87705 × MON 89788. The EC's marketing authorisations for food and feed containing Monsanto Europe S.A. genetically modified beans 87705 × MON 89788 do not comply with the principles laid down in EU legislation to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal health, the environment and consumer interests. Soybeans 87705 × MON 89788 are genetically modified to become resistant to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer by the World Health Organisation as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans. On the basis of the scientific conclusions on the negative effects of GMOs and taking into account the negative human opinion on GMO products, the European Commission must review the authorisation procedure and present a new proposal allowing decisions on GMOs to be taken by the Member States themselves. Until a new regime is agreed, the Commission should not issue new authorisations, and I will never accept attempts to do so.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution opposes the Commission's enforcement decision authorizing the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788.  This genetically modified soybean expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein, which confers tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. However, on March 20, 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organization's specialized agency for cancer research, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the exploitation of Europe by foreign interests. The properties of this GMO soybean serve only Monsanto's interests, and in the short term those of industrial producers. These GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. EFSA has ignored the reasoned opposition of several Member States, although its assessment of GMOs has been widely criticised. We have also tabled amendments in plenary calling for authorisations to be granted in the form of delegated acts, with the aim of identifying elected representatives who are against the "democratic control" of the marketing of GMOs. Of course, I voted in favour of the objection to the marketing of MON 87705 soybeans × MON 89788.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted negatively to allow the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified soya MON 87705 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1), pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The motion for a resolution is to ask the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision by presenting a new proposal which may reflect all the concerns expressed in various Community regulations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The causes of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) not to align with the opinion of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) that glyphosate is genotoxic and could be a "probable" cause of cancer in humans. This is because these two organisms have a different approach to chemical classification. The EU system evaluates each individual chemical and each blend marketed separately. IARC evaluates generic agents, including related chemical groups, as well as occupational or environmental exposure, and cultural or behavioural practices. In the context of GMOs, a careful and science-based approach is required.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Commission's proposed ban on the sale and use of GMOs indirectly leads to the closure of borders between Member States of the European Union, which is contrary to Union law, as it does not respect the principle of the protection of human health while ensuring the functioning of the internal market. Member States often express their comments in this area, but they do not sufficiently deal with the Commission's proposal in question. I consider it essential for the Commission to make proposals that take account of Union law while taking into account the requirements of the Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected the authorisation of genetically modified soybean MON 87708 × MON 89788. The soybeans which have been authorised are resistant to certain herbicides, therefore their cultivation could encourage more liberal use of herbicides, which could be harmful to the environment and/or human health. The Commission must come forward with a new proposal for GMO food and feed, which more thoroughly assesses the environmental impacts of GMOs.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed lays down the procedure for authorising the placing on the market of such products. Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands on 11 August 2011 for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87705 × MON 89788. The Commission has adopted a draft Commission implementing decision on authorisation under that Regulation.  In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety referred to Parliament's decision to × NK603 and T25 maize recommends that Parliament express its opinion on the fundamentally harmful effects of GMOs on human health on 16 December 2015 on a Commission implementing decision (EU) 2015/2279 authorising the placing on the market of products consisting of or produced from it. I am convinced that it is not for politics, but for science, to decide how GMO foods affect human health, so I abstained from voting for this decision.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, for an application to place on the market foodstuffs, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87705 × MON 89788. This genetically modified soy mon-877Ø5-6× MON-89788-1 has a reduced expression of δ12 enzymes, fatty acid desaturase (FAD2) and thioesterase acyl plamymitis carrier protein (FATB), which results in a high oleic acid and reduced linoleic acid profile, and expresses the CP4 Protein EPSPS, which confers tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides which, according to the International Cancer Research Centre's classification, is probably carcinogenic to humans. I believe that the EU should ensure the protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests, especially with regard to genetically modified food and feed. I hope that the Commission will present a new proposal for a legislative amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and to take into account the concerns of the World Health Organisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. These votes are intended to signal the European Parliament's opposition to the introduction of three new GMOs by way of importation. These are GMOs MON 87705 and MON 89788. Indeed, the Commission proposes to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto that serve only the interests of this multinational company. As usual, EFSA has provided incomplete explanations that do not take into account the relevant comments of the Member States. It is therefore the whole process of granting authorisations that is at issue, since a study to question EFSA's action will be produced with a view to rejecting the budgetary discharge of this uneasy agency. But these objections from Parliament are likely to remain a dead letter as they are not binding. That is why the ENF group has tabled 3 amendments calling for authorisations to now be in the form of delegated acts and no longer under acts of execution.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection filed by the Socialists, the Greens, the far left and supported by the extreme right, concerning genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 x MON 89788. These groups based their objection on the fact that the European Commission exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of products containing this genetically modified soybean variety, consisting of or manufactured from this genetically modified soybean. Unfortunately, this objection was adopted, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity, and while the Commission complied, before issuing its proposal for authorisation, with the procedure in place for GMOs, based in particular on an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority on the safety of the plant on human and animal health, as well as on the environment. This proposal was forwarded to the Council, which did not reject it.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788, which was charged with a so-called non-compliance with the Commission's powers. The authorisation to market these products was carried out within the scope of the Commission's powers. Moreover, the objection does not have to be to me, as the Member States themselves determine whether or not the authorisation is applied. I therefore voted against a baseless symbolic objection to support the work of the European Commission.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution with regard to the authorisation of placing on the market products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified soybean MON 87705 x MON 89788. The report states that the implementing decision is not consistent with Parliament’s and the Council’s Regulation on ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring effective operation of the internal market.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution of the Committee on Environment and Society Health to withdraw the draft implementing decision of the European Commission on the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON-877Ø8-9 × MON-89788-1.  According to scientific information, in this type of soybean, the expression of enzymes Δ12 fatty acid-desaturate (FAD2) and palmitoyl-[acil-carrying protein]-thioesterase (FATB) is reduced, resulting in a profile with an increased oleic acid content and a reduced linoleic acid content, and expressing the protein CP4 EPSPS, which gives resistance to glyphosate-based herbicides.  The International Agency for Research on Cancer classifies glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans. I believe that even that alone is a sufficient argument to reject such a proposal.  In addition to the scientific justification, much of the public opinion is increasingly strongly opposed to the use of GMOs techniques and technologies. On the eve of the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, this became clear enough.  I think it is socially irresponsible in the name of public health to allow such a culture within the EU or any Member State.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision and instead to table a new legislative proposal, which also includes the concerns of Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organisms. Consequently, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support it because it is not necessary to decide on the placing on the market of each GMO product separately. A holistic approach is needed and the entire legal regulation of GMO products should be reviewed.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission, authorised to import and use three types of SOy bee for food purposes, does not provide sufficient protection for the health of European citizens, who are overwhelmingly opposed to GMO, and I therefore supported the objection to the enforcement of the permit. Gm soy type MON 87705 × MON 89788 is immune to the herbicide glifozate used in cultivation and is most likely carcinogenic to animals as well as to humans, according to the who specialised agency.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing or manufactured by the GM MON-87705 × MON-89788 strain. In genetically modified soybean MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1, as described in the application, and among other modifications, the CP4 EPSPS protein causing tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides was also expressed.  The International Agency for Research on Cancer, a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, placed glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be human-carcinogenic on March 20, 2015, and on September 4, 2015, the California Office of Environmental Hazard Assessment for Health (OEHHA) also issued a notice of intent to add glyphosate to the list of chemicals of that federal state known to cause cancer. I consider the use of a potentially carcinogenic substance in the environment to be a risk that is not justified.  Similarly, I consider that by rejecting the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013, 1829/2003 a situation arisen in which, until the adoption of the new proposal, the right of Member States to independently decide on the use of GMO food and feed on their territory and the possibility to effectively monitor their decisions are not guaranteed. In view of the above, I supported this objection.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Genetically modified strains mon-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1 have reduced expression of the enzymes Δ12-desaturase fatty acids (FAD2) and tioesterase palmitoyl proteins of the acile carrier (FATB), which results in an increase in the proportion of oleic acid and a decrease in the proportion of linoleic acid, And it expressed the CP4 EPSPS protein, which causes tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate, which, according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer, falls into the category of substances that are likely to be carcinogenic to humans.  Therefore, I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not compatible with UNION law based on the principles of preserving human health and the environment. Each of the 21 counties in the Republic of Croatia has decided that GMO is free. To date, no permits have been granted in the Republic of Croatia for the intentional introduction of GMO, either for experiments, commercial breeding or for food or feed containing GMO. As a representative from Croatia, I therefore support the proposal to object to the decision to authorize the mentioned type of soybean.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application for authorisation of the MON87705xMON89788 was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands on 11/08/2011. This request was assessed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which delivered a favourable opinion. It was then considered by the Standing Committee on 18/11/2015 and was assessed with 'no opinion', as has been the case since this procedure was agreed. This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation of the decision, on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well and calls for no new range of GMOs to be authorised, nor renewed the old authorisations until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. We voted in favour of our position of objection to the authorisation of GMOs. The Commission should present without delay a legislative proposal respecting the law of the Member States – and the willingness of consumers – to owe the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on its territory, taking into account the risks to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health, as it is not possible to guarantee scientifically credible the harmlessness of transgenic products in food and feed.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of this particular objection to the decision taken by the European Commission, I voted in favour because I still have doubts about the use of genetically modified foods, including in the case of MON87705xMON8978 soybeans. I recognise some of the advantages of using GMOs, but personally some possible negatives prevail for me, and that determines my position.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I objected to this objection because the arguments developed by the European left, which is largely at the origin of it, are false. The Commission has in no way exceeded its powers to allow these products to be put on the market. I would remind you that this is just an authorization. Effective marketing still depends on the states, and therefore on governments.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the assumption that the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing products consisting of or produced from genetically modified soya MON 87705 x MON 89788 (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1) appears to be in line with EU law, in particular, in addition to the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed, I voted against this resolution which, in accordance with Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure, asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of ‘Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties.’ Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans to be imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the presentation of this motion for a resolution because I agree that the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87705 soya × MON 89788 is not in line with Union law, as it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 of the European Parliament and the Council. I agree that the Commission withdraws its draft implementing decision, as genetically modified soya MON-877Ø5-6× MON-89788-1 expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein, which shows tolerance to herbicides containing glyphosate, which has been considered by the International Cancer Research Centre to be probably carcinogenic to humans. I therefore voted in favour of this document asking the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, based on the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. By 201 votes, the European Parliament has clearly said no to the marketing of MON 87705 x MON 89788 soybeans. Behind this series of figures is a GMO tolerant of glyphosate. However, this active substance, which is found in trade, for example in roundup weedkiller, was classified as a "probable carcinogen" for humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization. And more precisely by its International Center for Research Against Cancer. However, the scientific battle is still fierce, as the European Food Safety Authority recently considered the risk posed by glyphosate to be unlikely. MEPs clearly disagree with EFSA on the issue. They confirmed by this afternoon's vote their concern that part of the European herd, mainly cattle, pigs and poultry, will soon be fed with MON 87705 soybeans.  The political signal from MEPs is clear, but in the absence of a veto, it has no effect on the Commission's discretionary right to allow genetically modified soybeans, rapeseed or maize on a case-by-case basis. The European Parliament must necessarily think about changing its strategy.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Commission doesn't care about the world. It has been condemned by the European Court of Justice for failing to define criteria for endocrine disruptors and would like to accept three glyphosate-tolerant GMO soybeans. This active substance found in Monsanto's herbicide RoundUp is itself an endocrine disruptor that has harmful effects, particularly on human reproductive functions. In addition, two of these soybeans are marketed by Monsanto, which would definitely win on all fronts. We were not elected to serve the interests of this delinquent multinational.  As long as the European legislation governing the authorisation of GMOs remains so lax and the Commission is outlawed, we will reject GMOs as a whole, all the more so when they are tolerant to chemicals poorly regulated by European law. We have already taken this position to the European Parliament in October 2015.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the same way as the objection to genetically modified maize passed last December, I supported the objection to the marketing of products containing genetically modified soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788.  Rejecting the new GMO marketing authorisations is a way for our Parliament to send a clear message to the European Commission to review the current GMO authorisation process. This process is neither satisfactory nor democratic, as each authorisation decision has been adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of the Member States and by ignoring the opinion of Parliament. I would also like to point out that public opinion remains negative about GMOs, that the risk assessment is considered insufficient and that there are no toxicity studies over 90 days.  Finally, I think the precautionary principle here is justified given the tolerance of the soybean in question to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance being evaluated that could be harmful to health.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Monsanto to introduce the variety of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 897885 into the Netherlands. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the marketing of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At noon, I voted for the European Commission not to allow the use of three genetically modified soybeans that tolerate glyphosate in food and animal products. Glyphosate has been classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO) since 20 March 2015. These three genetically modified soybeans that have already been authorised by the EU executive in food and animal products are FG72, MON 87708 x MON 89788 and MON 87705 x MON 89788. In today's vote, of course, I supported each of the three objections that call for their rejection.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the new gmo approval. The soya is designed to be resistant to glyphosate, which is recognized by scientists as a concern. As the European Food Safety Agency, which is attached to the Commission, hastened to deny this fact, the letter of indignation was signed by 90 European scientists working on GMOs. On 28 January, these researchers were supported by 65 MEPs from various groups, with an open letter to The Commissioner for President Andriukai. I hope that the fact that the vast majority of Parliamentarians voted in favour of this resolution will encourage the European Commission to change its behaviour towards GMOs.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the basis of an application made in 2011 by Monsanto Europe S.A. to place on the market foodstuffs, food ingredients and animal feed containing, consisting of or produced from the genetically modified soya variety MON 87705 × MON 89788 (MON-877Ø5-6 × MON-89788-1, it was found that it contained glyphosate, so that for the same reasons as for the Explanations of Vote to Reports B8-0133/2016 and B8-0134/2016 on an objection to an equivalent delegated act, I decided to abstain.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure is more responsive to a purely political act and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I would ask the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, taking into account the frequently expressed national concerns, which do not relate solely to issues relating to the safety aspects of GMOs in relation to health or the environment.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. "I voted against the objection to approving the genetically modified soya bean, above all because we have to rely on science, i.e. if the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) considers that a crop is safe after evaluation, this is what we should start from and nothing else. With a growing population and increased climate threats, modern plant breeding is needed in Europe. This includes modern techniques for breeding arable crops and other plants that can feed the world's population and can contribute to a better climate.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This GMO was submitted by Monsanto to the competent authority in the Netherlands. It is a type of transgenic soybean with a reduced expression of two enzymes, resulting in a profile rich in oleic acid and poor in linoleic acid and is tolerant to glyphosate-based herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization, classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered a positive opinion. The Standing Committee ruled on this as follows: "without opinion", as has been customary in relation to GMOs. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly, and that the ROLE of the EP in these matters should be linked to delegated acts and not to implementing acts. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of Objection pursuant to Rule 106: Authorisation of genetically modified soybean varieties. Our vote in favour will stop three genetically modified soybeans being imported into the EU and processed into feed and food.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the third and final objection relating to GMO Soybeans. The objection states that in October we rejected the new Commission proposal on GM food and feed and called on the Commission to devise a new one, and as such no new GM food/feed should be authorised under the current legal framework, which even the Commission acknowledges is not working in a satisfactory way. I will reiterate that the Commission must come forward with a new proposal on this matter and for GMO food and feed in general and develop a fully-informed and decision-making process that is grounded in science when it comes to GMOs and one that responds to the public concerns and expectations.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to present, on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a new legislative proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which takes into account the frequently expressed comments made by Member States, which do not only concern issues of safety of GMOs for health or the environment. We have asked the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision because we believe that that the draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and 396/2005 of the EP and of the Council, which, according to the general principles set out in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council, consists in providing the basis for ensuring a high level of consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The number of genetically modified products offered on the European Union market is not high. I am of the opinion that their placement should be decided at national level.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion to object to the Commission’s authorising decisions in order to express opposition to authorisation of these particular varieties of GM soybean and to call on the Commission to live up to its obligation to update the Annexes to Directive 2001/18/EC by 3 April 2017 as regards the environmental risk assessment of GMOs, in line with Parliament’s vote of 13 January 2015. With this decision I, along with other Labour MEPs, voted for a fully informed and scientifically guided decision-making process with regards to GMOs that responds to public expectations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ On August 11, 2011, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application to the competent institutions in the Netherlands, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17. Regulations of the Commission and Parliament No 2013/2013 1829/2003, for placing on the market food consisting of or produced from soybean MON 87705 x MON 89788. I don't support this objection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soy × MON 89788. I understand the concerns raised in the resolution, but I do not think there is any need for the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision, which is supposed to be inconsistent with Union law. I believe that there is too little research into gm organisms and their impact on health and the environment, and that those who are are unreliable and inconsistent. We need clear and unambiguous results based solely on science.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report to veto the approval of the placing on the market of genetically modified soybeans, since for us the aim remains to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, the environment and the interests of consumers.  At the same time, we have taken into account the conclusions of the World Health Organisation's Cancer Research Agency, which state that the three species of genetically modified soya have different types of herbicides classified as potentially carcinogenic to humans. In addition, we oppose the EU's practice of deciding and imposing the placing and use of genetically modified products on the markets of the Member States, as under no circumstances should the sovereignty of states be sacrificed on the altar of profit and competition to decide on key issues such as the health and well-being of their citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The placing on the market of genetically modified soya products is not in conformity with Union law and cannot form the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, as well as animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested from a health and environmental safety point of view should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified MON 87705 x MON 89788 soybab. Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted a marketing application to the competent authority of the Netherlands on 11 August 2011. This soybean expresses the fatty acid desaturase enzyme Δ12 and the enzyme palmitoil-ACP tyesterase to a reduced degree, resulting in increased oleic acid content and reduced linoleic acid content, and expressing CP4 EPSPS protein, ensuring tolerance to glyphosate-containing herbicides. The WHO's International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance "likely to be carcinogenic to humans" in 2015. Since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission without the opinions of the Committees of the Member States and, in the case of GM food and feed, it has become common practice to return the dossier to the Commission for final approval. I agree that, even if produced on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders. Thus, the national 'sales and use' ban proposed by the Commission could not be enforced in the single internal market. I supported the withdrawal of the regulation and for the Commission to present a new legislative proposal based on a high level of protection of human and animal health, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have contributed with my yes to the adoption of this resolution. I am against GMOs and I am even more opposed to GMOs which, like soya MON-87705-6 × MON-89788-1, express tolerance for herbicides, in this case the infamous glyphosate.  Crops engineered to resist glyphosate are particularly common in the United States. Their presence has led to a growing use of glyphosate - without increasing yields - and to the appearance of weeds that themselves can resist glyphosate: the massive use of glyphosate triggers a kind of accelerated Darwinian selection (what else could we have expected?) that induces farmers to use even more powerful herbicides. And so on, in a vicious circle of poisons and resistance to poisons. I don't want to see the further "Darwinian effects" of this chemical escalation on weeds. I would stress that the toxicity and carcinogenicity of glyphosate indicates the need for strict protection and prevention measures. It is obvious to expect glyphosate residues in engineered crops to withstand them. All citizens have the right to access quality and contaminant-free food products.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. No, no The Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. Our goal is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests. The European consumer must not be the guinea pig of multinationals!!!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Contrary to the result of the final vote, I opposed the objection to authorise the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified soybean MON 87705 × MON 89788. The application to put the soybean concerned on the market was fully compliant with EU legislation; the technical decision to authorise it or not is then left to the Commission, which assesses the application based on scientific evidence. The Commission agreed to validate the placing on the market and I see no reason for denying the scientific assessment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Motion for a resolution on the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: approval of genetically modified soy bee MON 87705 × MON 89788, as our priority in the field of genetically modified food and feed is to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection and the environment.  Given that this substance is classified as a carcinogen for humans, it is important that we pay particular attention to this, that the Commission submit a new legislative proposal, as this is the only way to protect the interests of consumers, the people of the Union, and to strengthen their confidence.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure is more responsive to a purely political act and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposed to allow three new GMO soybeans from Monsanto. These three GMOs are tolerant to glyphosate. Two of them have another characteristic: different fatty acid composition for GMO B and tolerance to dicamba (a pesticide) for GMO C. These properties serve only the interests of Monsanto and industrial breeders (and again, this is not proven).  As with previous cases of GMO authorisation, EFSA has provided an unsatisfactory assessment, including ignoring relevant observations from member states. Moreover, the objections to acts of execution are only symbolic and do not compel the Commission. So I vote FOR the objection, even symbolic.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. has submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from MON 87705 × MON 89788. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position on this issue.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of GM soybeans MON 87705 × MON 89788 because we consider that, given the nature of the implemented acts, this measure is more responsive to a purely political act and, therefore, the European Parliament must be able to participate in the legislation. In October 2015, the European Commission's proposal on GMO food and food was rejected by different political groups in the European Parliament which understood that each Member State's decision to authorise the use of GMOs in its territory must be respected, but that there is no regulation ensuring the correct implementation of this measure.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have always advocated that Latvia and the European Union as a whole be free from genetically modified organisms (GMOs). We must not allow the health of our citizens to be put at risk in the interests of any economic interest.  It is regrettable that this is another time when the European Commission, contrary to the member states' position, wants to give the green light to the placing on the market of new GMOs, in the exercise of its powers under its own legislation. GMO soya beans are resistant to glyphosate, which has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer as a possible carcinogen for humans.  This time, the EC not only failed to take into account national concerns about the harmfulness of GMOs, but also ignored the world health organisation agency's research into glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance.  In the light of the studies carried out by the World Health Organisation Agency on glyphosate and the negative attitude of the Latvian public towards GMOs, I voted against the placing on the market of these three GMO soybeans.  Furthermore, I believe that the existing legislative procedure should be changed in order to give both the European Parliament and the states greater decision-making rights when authorising new GMOs for the placing on the market, thereby ensuring more effective democratic control and respect for the public interest.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection concerning the genetically modified soybean MON 87705 x MON 89788 because I believe that the Commission should not authorise the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM soybeans in food and feed, specifically for two reasons: the first reason is that glyphosate, a herbicide, was classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans on 20 March 2015 by the World Health Organization’s cancer agency. The second reason is that currently GMOs are being authorised in the EU without the support of Member States: in fact, every GM authorisation decision has so far been taken by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of Member States.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted against the objection to accepting the genetically modified soybean. We must rely on science and our European Food Safety Authority. They believe that this crop is safe. With a growing population and increasing threats to the climate, we need modern plant breeding in Europe. These modern techniques for growing agricultural crops and other plants, among other things, can contribute to a better food for the world's population and a better climate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution objects to the adoption of the draft implementation decision on the basis of the claim that the current authorisation procedure for genetically modified foods and feed is not working well. It calls for no new varieties of GMOs to be authorised, nor have the old authorisations been renewed until the methods used for risk assessment have been considerably improved. Whereas all these soy products confer increased tolerance to different types of herbicides (especially glyphosate) which has been classified as probably carcinogenic to humans by IARC, on 15 March 2015, this draft Implementing Decision is not compatible with the objectives of Regulation (EC) 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed, as well as Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in human and animal feed.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to withdraw its implementing decision. Instead, it should present a new legislative proposal that responds to the concerns of the myriad Member States that are specifically opposed to genetically modified organs. There is an Austrian-wide rejection of GMOs. I agree with this request.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products, the genetically modified soya beans of the variety MON 87705 × MON 89788 (MON-877-5-6 × MON-89788-1) contain, consist of or are derived from, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council. The resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to present a new legislative proposal that takes better account of national interests and concerns. That is my goal. I am opposed to the blanket admissibility of genetically modified organisms and I am in favour of greater consideration for national concerns at EU level, preferably through more subsidiarity.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed text. Our main priority is to ensure public health and the quality of goods placed on the European market.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Commission has once again tried to force its way of taking decisions on agri-food and feed, bypassing any indication from the European Parliament. But the 5-Star Movement managed to move quickly and together with the majority of the European Parliament voted not to give consent to the placing on the market of this new genetically modified product. This soybean was specially created in the laboratory to resist glyphosate, considered by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) to be probably carcinogenic to humans. Authorising the placing on the market of this product would have meant threatening the health of millions of citizens.  As spokesman for the M5S, I have always fought for a ban on transgenic food and feed. GMOs must not enter Europe, without 'ifs' and 'buts'. Unfortunately, the EU imports 32 million tonnes of soya for feed from its farms every year. It is right to aim for ambitious objectives when it comes to protecting the environment and the health of millions of citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the administration of products containing genetically modified soy bee MON 87705 x MON 89788. I agree that we must ensure high levels of protection of human life and health, animal health and protection, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed. However, for the effective and competitive functioning of the internal market, decisions on the possible authorisation to place products containing genetically modified enzymes on the market need to be taken on the basis of independent and consistent research on the potential negative effects of GMOs.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam President! I have today chosen to say no to blocking the new rules on emissions from light passenger cars and commercial vehicles agreed between the Commission and the Member States. I think it is important that we get the introduction as soon as possible that car emissions should be tested on the road and not in laboratories. After all, it is for driving on the roads that consumers buy a car. If today we had blocked the new rules, which the Commission and the Member States have already agreed on, we would have been in a legal vacuum for several years, not knowing when we would get the test on the roads. It had been unsatisfactory and it had actually been like driving a car with a bag over your head. It is important for me to stress that the new rules are not a free card for the car industry to pollute. I would have liked to see stricter rules, but that is the result that could be agreed in the Council and the Commission. It is clear that new testing methods require adaptation in industry, but here we in the European Parliament must maintain an ambitious line to reduce emissions. We must use all the tools at our disposal. I have noted that the Commission has committed itself to an annual review of the limit values and has already set out to lower the limit values in 2017.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – Emissions from cars, especially particulate matter and nitrogen, are particularly detrimental to public health. The recent Environmental Performance Index of the American universities Yale and Columbia shows that Belgium scores particularly poorly in terms of air pollution. Every year, 12 000 people die prematurely, mainly as a result of particulate matter. In Flanders, the Flemish government is making efforts to tackle this problem by greening car taxation. A low emission zone is being rolled out in the city of Antwerp.  However, more European action is needed, because the strict EU legislation to reduce harmful emissions is still not improving in practice, especially because of the lack of practical tests to measure actual emissions on the road. These practical tests must be increased as soon as possible. However, linking them to a relaxation of the Euro6 standard is unacceptable. A better agreement is needed and also technically feasible. There are European engines that meet the Euro6 standard of 80 mg nitrogen per kilometre. Encouraging this innovation is essential and for these reasons I supported the objection.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, everyone knows that the Volkswagen emissions scandal was a disaster for the car industry, but I think we underestimate the extent to which it was also a disaster for the European Union. Thousands of people died needlessly because of a policy driven, uniquely in the European Union, as a result of corporate lobbying. Why did the EU – uniquely in the world – go down the road of promoting diesel, which had always been regarded up until then as the dirtier option? American and Japanese regulators were pushing for hybrid or electric cars but the EU, uniquely, following lobbying from certain car firms which had invented the new engine, decided to push the use of a fuel that emits 40 times as much nitrogen oxide as petrol and 22 times as many pollutants and particulates. We do not know how many people died because the cause of death will have been recorded as heart failure or cancer, not as breathing in a kind of fuel, but they are victims of the corporate lobbying nexus that has grown up in Brussels, and we are all complicit in that tragedy.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have rarely heard such an alarm as the previous speaker. I voted against rejecting the Commission's proposal. The Commission has delivered very quickly on the issue of car emissions. This is a proposal that the car industry and its suppliers can make, which hurts them, but which can be implemented. I therefore voted against the motion to reject the proposal by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European Union, on the grounds that it is 'Dear the sparrow in hand than the dove on the roof' – that is what a German proverb says. With the exaggerated ideas of the left camp, we would have created planning uncertainty and ultimately achieved the opposite for the environment. Today, the majority of Parliament has shown responsibility for industry, for workers and for the environment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we voted to prevent lower emission standards for light vehicles simply because directives and laws are for the benefit of people, not for the benefit of businesses.  Following the Volkswagen scandal, known as 'dieselgate' and affecting much of Europe's car industry, the Commission's proposal represents only the wishes of the same people who have been cheating on emissions for years; which have jeopardized the sustainability of this sector, millions of jobs and, above all, the health of European citizens. Air pollution from nitrogen oxide and harmful particles causes nearly half a million premature deaths in Europe each year.  We tell the Commission that the way to avoid the closure of businesses and relocation is to promote an industry that is both innovative and ecologically sustainable that looks to the future and the long term. Do not give in to the pressures of those who put their interests before the common interest of the people.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, nitrogen emissions currently exceed the permitted limits by five times. Let's put a stop now. I would like to see more ambition on the part of the Commission and the Council. But if the objection were adopted, we would not reduce pollution: we would increase legal uncertainty and extend non-compliance with the regulations, with the consequent health risk. With this Decision, emissions will be reduced to less than half and Europe will be the only region in the world with real road test conditions. Only by implementing these tests will we be able to enforce regulations, protect the environment, protect health, give guarantees to consumers and users, and boost investment and employment in the automotive sector, a sector very important for countries like mine, Spain.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted against the statement of objection. I believe that the rules that the Commission has prepared, which are to apply from 2017, provide a solid basis for a testing system in real terms. The position of my country, the Czech Republic, is the same position. For us, for the Czech Republic, the automotive industry is extremely important, employing thousands, tens of thousands of Czechs, and we want there to be clear rules that will apply to the automotive industry, so that it has stable and clear rules on what each type of car should look like. So I voted for the Commission and I hope that the Commission will do its chedd to make the whole system work smoothly from 2017 on.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we voted in favour of this objection because the most intolerable of all is that the Commission intends to decide without consulting Parliament, again putting our health and that of the planet at risk. Bending the nitrogen dioxide emission limit is an absolutely intolerable concession to large multinationals in the automotive sector.  We do not forget the Volkswagen case, in which the Commission knew more about car tricks than it said and with whose silence and complicity it helped to make an unprecedented scam even bigger. We must prevent such cases from happening again, and this requires promoting democratic control and transparency. This is not a matter of ballad because, ladies and gentlemen, we are into life – ours and that of generations to come – in taking care of this planet.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
