text: – Mr President, I think it is very important that attention should now be paid to this issue in such a way that the right emission levels can also be achieved in Europe and in the European car industry. However, we must also remember that, in addition to environmental issues, care must be taken to ensure that automakers also come to the same levels of emissions globally. That is why I personally see that the Commission's proposal can be accepted as it stands and can be taken forward. In principle, however, I believe that we in Europe must take care of our own competitiveness, our own industry and our companies, and try to challenge this issue so that the entire global industry is covered by the same rules. When trade is global, global, this way we can also ensure that the rules are consistent and that it protects the whole planet, the whole environment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the objection to the agreement on new emission limits for Euro 6 vehicles. However, Parliament did not accept it, thus missing another opportunity to be on the side of the citizens. After the Volkswagen scandal and the ambitious Paris Agreement, the European Parliament had an obligation to send out a strong and clear message on the need to create the conditions immediately to promote increasingly sustainable production. Higher emission limits than those voted for in 2007 are not acceptable, just as when we vote we cannot just look at the demands of industry, ignoring those of the citizens. We are here first and foremost to work and to protect their health. Our cities are besieged by smog, and the high concentrations of fine dust, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, which cause damage to people's health, generating very high health costs, bear witness to this.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Despite the positive change in recent decades, the level of air pollution is a worrying issue. Premature deaths can be as high as 400,000. The problems that came to light in autumn 2015 showed that the legislation was not being respected in the automotive industry. The Volkswagen scandal has demonstrated the need for real-world testing. The Commission's implementing regulation is not capable of achieving the environmental objective pursued. The adoption of the proposal has resulted in the required desirable emission level being exceeded by up to 2020. For this reason, I supported parliament's decision to reject the European Commission's proposal.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted against the objection and I am also glad that this objection was ultimately rejected by the European Parliament. This means that there will be a Regulation of the European Commission, which I think is ultimately a good starting point. The limit, which is strict, means 680 mg of nitrogen oxide, which is a strict limit. What is important is that the measurement will be carried out in operation, which I think corresponds to real possibilities and is also a favourable solution both for manufacturers and, above all, for us who use cars, diesel engines, etc. so this change in measurement proposed by the European Commission, I consider it a step in the right direction, also the factors of consistency that are proposed, I think, are a good solution.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil le mo chomhghleacaithe i bhFine Gael agus i mo ghrúpa EPP, vótáil mé i gcoinne na tuarascála seo. Ceapaimid go bhfuil a dhóthain déanta ag an gCoimisiún. Táimid sásta leis na moltaí atá curtha ar aghaidh acu maidir leis an bhfadhb seo. Agus má leanfaimid an bóthar atá leagtha amach ag an gCoimisiún, is féidir linn toradh níos fearr a fháil. In that Commission proposal published last week, a framework on market surveillance for motor vehicles was outlined. The proposal aimed to tighten the car authorisation process in Member States and to create a more independent procedure. This proposal will also allow Member States – and the Commission – to take action against the technical services that are underpinning, or too lax in applying, approval requirements.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Health protection is a priority for the European Union, unfortunately continued lobby pressure has prompted the Commission to take major steps backwards. The draft regulation presented introduces, among other things, too high a compliance factor, which results in a general derogation from the applicable emission limits. Ambitious measures are needed to reduce emissions, and it is certainly unacceptable to reduce the objectives and content of the previous Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, which opposes these amendments, because the protection of the environment and citizens cannot and must not be threatened by mere economic interests.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because this Regulation developed by the Commission exceeds the mandate of the delegation of powers granted in the basic act. Once again, the Commission uses the delegation of powers in favour of the interests of multinationals, in this case in clear collusion with the multinationals in the automotive sector, which has been affected by the Volkswagen scandal. This resolution rejects that regulation because it seeks to confating Parliament, legislating against the views of democratically elected institutions and therefore against the interests of European citizens. Precisely after the Volkswagen scandal it is the European peoples who must give their opinion on such requirements to the industry. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on the emissions of passenger and light-duty vehicles. This proposal follows the Volkswagen scandal, which revealed the considerable discrepancies between the emission of pollutants in the laboratory and those in real driving conditions. It should be remembered, however, that the cars involved have, on the other hand, emitted less carbon monoxide, a gas that is much more harmful. The resolution is wrong in its strategy as it wants to impose additional, binding and costly standards for a sector already in crisis. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'The Flemish Interest strongly condemns the fraud by car manufacturers. Millions of consumers have been deceived by false information about the emissions of their vehicles. Companies must take full responsibility for their actions and cooperate fully with investigations by the authorities. The consumer must be able to exercise his full redress. At the same time, reliable and independent testing must be done. My party, like everyone else, is in favour of the further imposition of the agreed standards. The Commission's proposal does not relax the standards. They remain what they are. Only another timetable is being rolled out, with a very temporary overrun of the standards, for the sector to be fully regulated. With parliament's proposal to pretend that today's industry can be completely regulated on tomorrow, the hotly contested European car industry could pose a serious threat to the world market. With many tens of thousands of employees in hundreds of companies, the high-tech and sustainable vehicle industry provides about 10% of the employment in the industry in Flanders. Our party is not prepared to simply victimize this sector in the left-environmental blackmail sphere of the European Parliament. Moreover, the Flemish Interest has always been at the forefront of the fight against particulate matter with the promotion of CNG (compressed natural gas) in our country.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This opposition is directed against a decision of the European Commission and the Member States which provides that in future not only car exhaust values will be measured in the laboratory, but also in road transport. Instead of allowing the originally set exceedance of the valid limit values of 50%, deviations of more than twice as high values (so-called correction factor of 2.1) have now been agreed by 2020. Secondly, the majority of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Public Health (Committee on the Environment) also considered this correction factor to be too generous and now submitted this objection to the plenary for a vote. Because I support strict and clear emission standards and appropriate controls to protect consumer health and the environment, I voted in favour of this objection. In addition, the automotive industry should learn that it too must comply with the rules it has decided, which in turn can create a boost in innovation that will drive our economy forward.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The issue of emissions of pollutants from vehicles has returned to the forefront of European politics in the Volkswagen case. The Commission's stringent standards for pollutant emissions do not yet require real driving test (RDE). The limit values set out in a regulation in 2007 are reviewed by internal procedures within the Commission: the requirement of this motion for a resolution was therefore to request a new regulation, to be submitted by 1 April 2016, to impose tests in real condition as soon as possible. This race to the norm is questionable for two reasons: first, Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world. Secondly, technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in terms of combating air pollution, as the EU also encourages more and more the flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in crisis. That is why I objected to this objection.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I would normally vote in favour of an objection to a delegated act, I have some concerns over the proposed alternatives and their viability. I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and to submit a new draft regulation by 1 April 2016 with a view to measuring real-world emissions for all vehicles. The proposal aims to veto the decision to allow more flexible emission limits for diesel cars. The European Commission has proposed measuring car pollution from September 2017 not in laboratories, but in real road conditions. As pollution will be higher in this context, taking into account possible errors in the new measurement system and proposals from EU countries, the Commission has decided to allow the emission limits for nitrogen oxides (80 mg/km) to 110 % and then 50% by the beginning of 2020.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection follows the revelation of considerable discrepancies between emissions of pollutants in the laboratory and those measured in real driving conditions (RDE) for Volkswagen diesel engines. However, the Commission's exacting standards for emissions of pollutants do not yet require such tests: this text therefore calls for a new regulation - to be submitted by 1 April 2016 - in order to impose tests in real conditions as soon as possible. The first recital recalls as a dogma the estimated cost of air pollution (estimated at 940 billion euros per year), and justifies by this assertion the requirement of ever more restrictive and expensive technical standards. These requirements are questionable for two reasons: Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world; technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in the fight against air pollution, as the EU also encourages more and more the flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector already in crisis. That is why I opposed it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The transport sector generated 46% of nitrogen oxide (NOX) emissions and around 14% of particulate emissions in the EU in 2013; these are two types of pollutants linked to adverse effects on health, the environment and the climate.  The outbreak of the VW scandal led the European Commission to first take note of the discrepancy between the emission values obtained by laboratory tests and the values obtained by road tests and then to present a proposal for a regulation aimed at temporarily increasing the permitted limits for nitrogen oxide emissions from cars.  I supported the objection of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy in the belief that the Commission's proposal could constitute a general derogation capable of causing a huge impact on the emission of pollutants into the environment.  Despite the leadership role played by European industry – and within it by Italian industry – in the field of emission reduction technologies, I am convinced that there is still a long way to go. We need a shared effort to ensure that environmental protection and the protection of public health are compatible with the needs of industry and the protection of jobs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the objection to the measures implemented by the European Commission in the RSDS (real driving emissions) report to object to the conformity factor of 2.1 and not to the RDE procedure itself. The basic legislation was adopted in 2007 and published as Regulation No 692/2008 to set the emission limit at 80 mg/km. Now, with the new proposal, which introduces a compliance factor of 2.1, a surplus of 110% is allowed. This is inadmissible regardless of the recent scandal over failures in CO2 emission controls in the automotive sector (Volkswagen case). What the objection is intended to remove this preliminary proposal to increase emission levels and to present a new one by 1 April 2016 that respects emission limits.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. It is not always easy to navigate the legislative and procedural meanderings between the Commission and the European Parliament. This dossier is a very symptomatic example of the smoking methods that can be practised in the passageways of these two European institutions. Indeed, after speaking in favour of this resolution condemning the Executive Commission on the grounds that it had exceeded its rights and enforcement powers to the detriment of the Legal Committee in particular, I was able to realis that this was not the case and that not supporting the Commission's proposal for a regulation meant a late and uncertain result in terms of the policy of reducing polluting emissions. In reality, the key question is what interests we need to protect. These are, of course, those of European citizens, their right to good health and a healthy environment, but I do not forget that the car industry also supports tens of thousands of people in the European Union and that we must not liquidate everything in the name of the absolute protection of the environment erected here as an imperative dogma.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to say that in this report I voted differently on my group, as I voted against Commission Resolution ENVI which considers that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. I have therefore supported the European Commission's initial proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to vote against this motion for a resolution, once again born of a political-media scandal and without any long-term vision of the interests of the European car industry. This proposal follows the Volkswagen scandal, which, admittedly, revealed the considerable discrepancies between the emission of pollutants in the laboratory and those in real driving conditions. It should be remembered, however, that the cars involved have, on the other hand, emitted less carbon monoxide, a gas that is much more harmful. The resolution is wrong about its strategy because it wants to impose additional standards, thus reacting in emotion without taking the time to consult with representatives of the automotive sector and without a real impact study on the health and environmental effects of nitrogen dioxide, in comparison with the effects of carbon monoxide. A resolution of haste, therefore, which motivated my rejection.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6) and to submit without delay a new draft regulation with a view to introducing real-world emissions measurements for all vehicles in order to ensure the effectiveness of emission control. The Parliament found that the draft Commission regulation submitted would de facto allow for a general derogation from the applicable emission limit values and would therefore be in line with EU law.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not support the ENVI committee's objection that the new package of emissions legislation would return to the beginning. It is true, the measurement methodology has been inadequate in the past and the car industry has adapted to this, and even some even with fraud, which I strongly condemn. But now we are where we are and we have to learn from mistakes. The Commission's proposal thus provides for a new measurement methodology that can actually expect real results and a reduction in emissions into the environment in the coming years. Unfortunately, however, this does not go overnight, we cannot do this tomorrow, and some understanding must also be shown for those who employ 12 million citizens in the EU through the car industry. However, I expect the Commission to have an even more precise timeline of how we will reduce the restrictions over the years, and I support that emissions will no longer be smaller only on paper but also, in fact, in the environment. The environmental aspect is very important, but people and their jobs are also important, and we must amend this type of legislation by understanding and taking both aspects into account.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal follows the Volkswagen scandal. The demands in this text are questionable for two reasons: Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world; technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in action to combat air pollution because the EU also encourages more and more flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in crisis. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection under Article 106 of the Regulation on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles because I believe that, in the light of the dieselgate scandal in the car manufacturer Volkswagen and the commitments made in the framework of the COP 21 negotiations, it is counterproductive and wrong to increase the emission limits of these vehicles. I am therefore extremely disappointed that the objection was rejected by a few votes.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is not possible to accept higher emission limits than those voted in 2007 (168 mg/km from 2019, 120 mg/km from 2021 for nitrogen oxides, which then generate fine particulate matter, instead of 80 mg/km).  After the Volkswagen scandal, European governments and the Commission must ensure that car manufacturers comply with emission limits and not, on the other hand, weaken the legislation to allow car manufacturers to pollute more. The protection of citizens' health must be a priority for all European institutions. If the Eu ropean Union were to give in to pressure from the car lobby, it would give in both in terms of protecting public health and competition: because if car manufacturers postpone research and the application of new energy efficiency and anti-pollution technologies today, they will accumulate a long-term technological delay which – like any lack of innovation and efficiency – will have a greater exposure to international competition.  That is why I am voting yes to the objection.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal revealed that the German company had voluntarily reduced the emissions of pollutants from its diesel engines by using fraudulent methods. The aim of this motion for a resolution is to call for a new regulation that will impose tests in real conditions as soon as possible. Under the pretext that the cost of air pollution is exorbitant, our industry and our businesses would face much greater environmental constraints and environmental requirements than those in the United States and emerging countries. EU Member States are already facing unfair international competition, in particular because of environmental dumping by these countries. Respect for the environment must not be at the expense of economic development. I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution from nitrogen oxide (NO2) emissions causes 75 000 premature deaths in Europe each year, with 93% of cases of overshooting occurring near roads, or this situation is worrying and requires specific measures. At the same time, addressing NOx emissions from diesel engines should contribute to lowering current high levels of NO2 concentrations in ambient air. I voted against this objection, because the withdrawal of the commission's draft regulation will make the measures in terms of emissions generated under real driving conditions too late, given that the current emissions tests produced by cars have been unchanged for around 30 years. In this context, I believe that there is a need for immediate application of the draft regulation proposed by the Commission.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. The measure contains a road map which will quickly lead to the elimination, in existing legislation, of loopholes which currently allow large exceedances of the emission limits established. At the same time, it meets, at least in part, the needs of industry. The objection was adopted by the ENVI Committee on the emotional wave caused by the Volkswagen scandal, although this affair has no causal connection with the measure objected to. The adoption of the objection by the plenary would prevent the entry into force of the new road tests and actuallye their postponement (at least by 2 years), with negative consequences for employment levels and the environment.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, the Commission responded by proposing to make emissions tests polluting gas emissions by real-distance diesel cars more restrictive by reducing the difference between the regulatory emission limit that is tested in the laboratory and the value of emissions produced in real driving conditions. This measure, together with the European Commission's ambitious new legislative package, shows the Commission's willingness to do everything possible to increase the reliability of the European automotive sector in terms of compliance with environmental standards. If this objection had been voted on by the European Parliament, the process of setting up new tests in real driving situations would have been delayed by two years. But we need to move quickly. Our aim is to reduce emissions of polluting gases while giving the European automotive industry time to adapt to these new conditions and remain competitive in the international market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion for a resolution because the alternative was vetoing the agreement, which would have led to creating a legal vacuum for at least two years combined with uncertainty for car owners and the industry and absolutely no progress for the environment. On the contrary, now the EU can rapidly implement the on-road tests, which together with the planned Commission proposals for a major overhaul of the EU type approval framework will make it very difficult for the car industry to circumvent the emissions requirements. Road emissions test are more effective than laboratory tests which had been the norm until now. My vote helped to significantly cut pollution emissions by diesel cars in the short term.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report opposes the European Commission's proposal to amend its executive regulation of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 laying down provisions on the type-approval of motor vehicles. The proposed amendment is concerned with a review of the type-approval procedure and the introduction of conformity testing using portable meters from 2017.  The opposition is entirely acceptable: the proposed amendments not only go beyond the delegation conferred on the Commission under Article 5 of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, but also represent a serious decoy to allow a general derogation from the emission limits applicable under Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 in favour of the interests of car manufacturers.  I therefore voted with great conviction in favour of this report which, in fact, calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft amendment.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I find it incredible that, despite the worldwide uproar after the ‘Dieselgate’ scandal brought auto industry cheating on emissions to light, the Member States governments further weakened these overdue standards from the Commission, and now a narrow majority of my colleagues have waived them through. We had known, even before car-manufacturer cheating was revealed, that emissions standards in driving conditions were lacking, but I had hoped we would not let this powerful industry dictate the stringency and the pace of these standards in the present context. The legal limits were set by Parliament and the Council of Member States in law, yet these technical measures allow for error margins of up to twice as much, to be tightened over the years. These are not measures to implement the law, but rather to flout it. Nitrogen oxide alone claims the life of almost 100 000 citizens in Europe a year. We are sending a disturbing signal by allowing corporate giants to avoid the consequences of their actions for as long as possible, with their bottom lines running over health and the environment.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal contains important positive elements, but also contains several negative points. It is therefore considered appropriate to abstain from the vote.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's debate on objections to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles is part of the wider context of our efforts to ensure better living conditions for European society and citizens. It is therefore obvious that we must seek not only to comply with the regulations, but also to implement new ones that will lead to better conditions. The reasonable objections expressed concern the improvement of the existing situation and we must therefore welcome them positively. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the measure because I do not agree with the correctness of the formal and substantive assumptions underlying the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is very important to clarify why I voted against this objection, and therefore in favour of this delegated act, especially since some political groups have speculated demagogically on this vote showing that they have not read the papers.  The question here is: do we want to measure vehicle emissions in real conditions or in bogus conditions? I prefer the former to the latter , which have so far been created specifically to test with rigged values, and so I appreciated the Commission's desire to adapt the limits to real conditions, while at the same time revizing them downwards from what was previously the case in practice. In other words, the vehicle that polluted x in the tests actually polluted y times x. Now the real parameter (y times x) has been taken as a reference and lowered it in such a way as to improve the quality of the environment. It is a pity that many members did not understand this.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The PPE supported the Commission and the decision taken by the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles and rejected the Objection tabled.  It is necessary to examine this implementing act in light of the overall steps taken by the Commission to reduce NOx emission and to improve air quality and protect the environment.  Last week the Commission published its proposal establishing a Framework on Market Surveillance for motor vehicles. This proposal aims to tighten the car authorisation process in Member States and will create a more independent procedure. This proposal will also allow Member States and the Commission to take action against the technical services that are underperforming or too lax in applying approval requirements.  The Dess Report on the reduction of pollutant emissions from road vehicles is currently being negotiated in trilogues. This proposal focuses on areas where market and regulatory failures hinder efforts to address the overarching challenges of improving the EU’s air quality and addressing the Better Regulation Agenda. One political issue in this trilogue is whether Parliament should be involved through delegated acts in setting the limits for emissions. The Council feels this should only be done through implementing acts.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. I am well present that air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the Union every year and has an estimated cost of EUR 940 billion due to its health effects and that exhaust emissions from diesel vehicles are an important source of NOx in europe's urban areas and that, according to the European Environment Agency, NOx emissions are the cause of 75 000 premature deaths in Europe. To achieve the EU's air quality targets, a continuous effort is needed to reduce vehicle emissions, including a considerable reduction in nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel-powered vehicles.  I am sensitive to the Environment Committee's argument that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 and that it may be contrary to EU law, since it is not compatible with the objective and content of that Regulation. On the other hand, I admit that postponing the problem and waiting for a new initiative by the Commission can represent an excessively long legal vacuum time without clear gains in terms of public health. So I abstained on the final vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt I had to vote against this measure which led to the data derived from tests on vehicles carried out in the laboratory being equated with those in real road driving conditions. In reality, it was found that cars placed on the market with laboratory tests did not comply with the limits of gas emissions, on the road, exceeding the limit by an average of 4/5 times.  If the objection had been adopted, we would have been faced with a situation in which the machines currently on the road would continue to emit according to the limits approved by laboratory tests. Therefore, the current objective is to get the Commission to quickly present a RDE package in order to arrive quickly, but sustainablely and with a precise timetable, at compliance factor 1 (80 mg/kg) as soon as possible and at the latest by 2023, re-establishing consumer confidence, safeguarding air quality and allowing automotive companies to invest in more environmentally friendly technologies without having to reduce jobs.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Vehicle emissions are one of the major causes of air pollution for which we need concrete measures to not only counteract its effects but also to prevent it. The proposal to introduce a real driving emissions test for all vehicles so as to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems has already been the subject of a resolution which was voted in by the European Parliament on 27 October 2015.  Today’s resolution asks the Commission to withdraw a draft regulation and submit a new one introducing the driving emissions test in the manner proposed.   While I fully support the need to ensure effective implementation of measures that prevent pollution even from vehicle emissions, I do not believe it will bring better protection to seek the withdrawal of a draft regulation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because this Regulation developed by the Commission exceeds the mandate of the delegation of powers granted in the basic act. Once again, the Commission uses the delegation of powers in favour of the interests of multinationals, in this case in clear collusion with the multinationals in the automotive sector, which has been affected by the Volkswagen scandal. This resolution rejects that regulation because it seeks to confating Parliament, legislating against the views of democratically elected institutions and therefore against the interests of European citizens. Precisely after the Volkswagen scandal it is the European peoples who must give their opinion on such requirements to the industry. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection and against the revision of the emission indices that the Commission intends to apply to the new test for the testing of cars placed on the European market. In my vote, I wanted to defend, to the last, the right to health of our citizens. We have interpreted the demands of associations and mayors, who have asked for our support in their daily fight against the effects of fine dust and high levels of smog.  The decision was far from unanimous and requires a rethink of the timetable imposed by the Commission on such a sensitive subject. We are talking about a subject that is dear to the public, not only in the light of the recent scandals over the falsification of car emissions data by well-known car manufacturers. A theme that requires the utmost attention as well as deep sensitivity. That is why we hope that a new proposal for a regulation will be adopted as soon as possible which, without penalising the productive sectors, will be respectful of the environment and the well-being of our citizens.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Real Driving Emissions (RDE) testing is to be introduced as a new requirement for the approval of new cars and baths as an additional laboratory test. RDE aims to ensure control over vehicle emissions in real life and thereby address the high emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx) from diesel vehicles and to exclude the use of defeat devices, as was the case with VW. The main reason why states do not set limits on NOx concentrations in the air is that diesel vehicles emit significantly more of this substance under real conditions than under laboratory conditions. The introduction of RDE tests will reduce the average NOx emissions from these engines and help countries meet the requirements they have been set, e.g. under the NEC Directive. As I look at the document in question, I share the concerns of politicians from other groups, particularly those concerning the path of investigation to rde by a compliance factor of 2.1. The tests currently required by the Commission have remained unchanged for almost thirty years. With this in mind, I supported the opposition expressed in the document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles – chaired by the European Commission and consisting of national experts – agreed on the second package of RDE test procedure on 28 October 2015. In spite of the recent emission measurement scandal and the widespread exceedances of NOx limits throughout Europe, the committee agreed to allow Euro 6 diesel cars to emit over double the Euro 6 limit from 2017 to 2020, and 50% after 2020, de facto increasing the standard to 120 mg/km forever. For these reasons we cannot accept the political decision made in the technical committee. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this objection and request a new proposal from the Commission by 1 April 2016.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I do understand some of the concerns of the proposers of this objection resolution I do not think that opposing the Real Driving Emissions (RDE) testing proposal is the right answer at this time. The introduction of RDE tests for new cars as proposed by the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles will bring clear reductions in NOx emissions and improve air quality. I do not think we should delay the introduction of RDE testing by months or possibly even years. Current European car emissions tests remain unchanged in almost thirty years and it is critical that we in the European Parliament endorse this latest step towards improving the testing regime. Rejection of this measure does not guarantee a quick revision  on more ambitious lines from Member States; more likely it risks prolonged inaction and regulatory uncertainty. So for those reasons I am opposed to this objection.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft regulation goes in a totally opposite direction to the recent commitments made at COP 21 in Paris and to the principles praised by the same institution in President Juncker's 10 priority points. With regard to the 'Energy Union and climate', one of the key aspects, which is also included in the 2014-2020 planning objectives, is precisely the fight against climate change and the reduction of emissions. Fine words, but today's actions are quite different.  The Commission is trying to encourage the lobby of car manufacturers on the grounds of technical reasons for alleged measurement errors, which in fact allow vehicles to pollute more than twice as much as they do at present. Therefore, instead of providing for stricter rules that effectively limit emissions, both eyes are closed (and the lungs are clogged), allowing even more harmful substances to be poured into the environment.  The motion for a resolution is to be welcomed because it leaves no room for doubt and calls on the Commission to withdraw its proposal immediately, demanding the presentation of a new text, consistent with the commitments it has made towards the protection of the environment and the health of citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to oppose the European Commission's draft decision on vehicle emission limits under EU Euro 6 legislation. The introduction of real-world driving tests, planned in this project, is a giant step in the world. Nowhere else, not even in the United States, are vehicle emission standards so ambitious. Tomorrow, our citizens will breathe cleaner air and live in a less carbon-intensive environment. I therefore object to this objection, which would be to delay the application of the standards by another two years, which I consider counterproductive. While these rules can be improved, the protection of citizens cannot wait. Automakers are engaged in a global industrial battle in which Europe has its champions. Let us not forget that the European automotive sector alone accounts for 12.1 million direct and indirect jobs on the continent. Considering that the role of the European Parliament is to ensure compliance with the rules, while ensuring a transition period that allows our companies to adapt without losing their competitiveness, I welcome the rejection of this objection.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I rejected this objection to a European Commission decision on the introduction of thresholds for real-world driving tests to limit emissions from passenger and light commercial vehicles. Of course, it is regrettable that the emission thresholds proposed by the Commission are not ambitious enough. However, it would have been irresponsible to reject and delay the implementation of European legislation aimed at limiting these emissions, in the direction of better environmental protection. Nevertheless, I am counting on the European Commission to ensure that emissions limits are adequately strengthened in the coming years. These measures are essential both for the protection of the environment by reducing pollution, and for the health of European citizens.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – When legislation is passed, it also has to be implemented and enforced. Car companies have already had seven years to make the necessary adjustments to comply with regulations regarding emissions. I deplore the loose rules that are adopted now, which enables cars to pollute even more. I agree that a certain margin of error in the testing methods could be considered, but the proposed conformity factors are excessive. In many European cities European citizens suffer from bad air quality due to the exhaust from diesel cars. That is why I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. According to the latest calculations of the European Commission, the painful truth is that the emissions of euro 6 diesel engines currently produced on the roads are on average 400% higher than those measured on the test bench!  The European Commission's draft implementing regulation is an important element in solving the problem, with the aim of reducing emissions as soon as possible in real-world conditions. From 2017 onwards, new vehicles may exceed the baseline of 80 g/km set out in the 2007 basic legislation by a maximum of 110% and by 50% from 2020. The reality picture represents a significant step forward in the regulation. Deadlines and targets appropriate to reality and technical possibilities provide predictability for the automotive industry. In addition, the new limit values foreke real emission reductions, significantly mitigating health-environmental risks. In my opinion, the draft legislation strikes the right balance between environmental and public health objectives and preserving the competitiveness of domestic jobs and industry. I am convinced that a responsible decision-maker does not lay down rules based on dreamlike expectations. It would be irresponsible to insist on what has already been proven to be technically impractical over time. No one should be fooled into adopting irrealistic rules.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret that the European Parliament has decided today not to veto the increase in the emission limits for nitrogen oxide proposed by the Commission. Personally, I voted in favour of the objection tabled by the Committee on the Environment. Unfortunately, I must note that this objection was rejected by a majority of Members (323 votes to 317). A few weeks after the VW scandal, I believe that this vote is deeply deplorable because it not only allows the car industry to exceed European anti-pollution standards (Euro 6) by 110% until 2019 and by 50% from January 2020, but also gives a legal basis for this difficult-to-understand easing.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted together with the majority of the Parliament to reject the objection on emissions from passenger and commercial vehicles. This vote enabled us to clear the way to the second Real Driving Emissions package, to avoid any uncertainties and will now oblige the industry to meet the strict deadlines foreseen by legislation.  Furthermore, it will help us to prevent that jobs are lost in the sector and that measures are taken immediately to safeguard air quality. The outcome of the vote means that the manufacturers will need to bring down the discrepancy to a ‘conformity factor’ of a maximum of 2.1 (110%) for new vehicle models by September 2017, and as a second step, lower the discrepancy to a factor of 1.5 (50%) by January 2020 for all new vehicle models. Commissioner Bieńkowska has made a further commitment today to bring down the conformity factor to 1 by 2023.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. The Volkswagen scandal has revealed an urgent need for better control of the car industry – and not least for the proper implementation of the controls. There is opposition and call on several sides to veto it. This is done on the basis of an increase in the limit values for NOx emissions.  However, this is a complex political situation that we find ourselves in. On the one hand, I can partly follow the protests of the other groups, but on the other hand I also believe that we are also in a situation where action needs to be taken.  Many of today's diesel cars already emit far more than they have to. The limit values are already being broken. That is why the early introduction of the new tests means that we will be able to reduce emissions considerably. Postponing and delaying introduction will mean that the environment and human health will continue to suffer. This is a realpolitik, where we have to find a common place with the Commission and the Council.   Introducing the tests in the current, proposed form should not be seen as a service to the car industry, as critics say. Right now there is a need to establish a political platform on which we can build in the future, for the benefit of health and the environment.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, this motion for a resolution aims to demand a new regulation, before 1 April 2016, which would impose tests on pollutant emissions in real-world conditions. However, the estimate of the cost of air pollution at 940 billion euros per year reveals the dogmatic nature of political ecology. This text, which places the responsibility for emissions on european industry in crisis, is characteristic of a counterproductive normative inflation aimed at obscuring all responsibilities on this subject. Refusing that European industry would suffer today from European and global failures to limit pollution, I voted against this resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the opposition in accordance with Article 106 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles. This is because, in my view, this would slow down the process of reducing harmful emissions. I believe it is our responsibility as technology advances to reduce the harm we impose on nature.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating effects of air pollution annually, calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and to submit a new plan without delay by 1 April 2016 at the latest in order to establish a real-world driving emission test for all vehicles in order to ensure the effectiveness of control systems.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. According to the latest calculations of the European Commission, the painful truth is that the emissions of euro 6 diesel engines currently produced on the road are on average 400% higher than those measured on the test bench.  The European Commission's draft implementing regulation is an important element in solving the problem, with the aim of reducing emissions as soon as possible in real-world conditions. From 2017 onwards, new vehicles may exceed the base value of 80 g/km as set out in the 2007 basic legislation by a maximum of 110% (cf multiplier 2.1) and by 50% (CF multiplier 1.5) from 2020. The reality picture represents a significant step forward in the regulation. Deadlines and targets appropriate to reality and technical possibilities provide predictability for the automotive industry. In addition, the new limit values foreke real emission reductions, significantly mitigating health-environmental risks. In my opinion, the draft legislation strikes the right balance between environmental and public health objectives and preserving the competitiveness of domestic jobs and industry. I am convinced that a responsible decision-maker does not lay down rules based on dreamlike expectations. It would be irresponsible to insist on what has already been proven to be technically impractical over time. No one should be fooled into adopting irrealistic rules.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. First the postponement of the vote, then the intensive meetings with the political groups and finally a document of the last hour of the European Commission: with this strategy, the powerful lobby of European car manufacturers managed to overturn the vote of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, which vetoed the European Commission's proposal in December to double the emission limits for cars until 2020. In the wake of the VW scandal, the Commission had put forward a proposal to the Motor Vehicles Technical Committee (CTVM) to introduce a new method for measuring and controlling nitrogen oxide emissions from passenger cars under real driving conditions using portable emission measurement systems (PEMS). Although the European Commission, on the basis of the scientific assessments of the JRC (Joint Research Centre) in Ispra, initially proposed a temporary CF of 1.6 and a subsequent ONE of 1.2, the automotive lobby managed to get an unjustified CF of 2.1 up to 2020 and 1.5 for subsequent years, without time limit, effectively allowing cars to pollute more and legally. My vote was therefore in favour of the objection.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The decision taken by the Commission and the Member States of the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles on flexibility in emission limits for cars undermines the current legislation already decided in 2007. This without any scientific basis for the decision being presented, and despite the fact that the technology to meet the current limit values already exists, is not very expensive and is already being applied by several car manufacturers. The decision can therefore be interpreted as nothing more than a concession to the part of the car industry which has chosen to invest in deceiving the defective tests instead of investing in making its cars more environmentally friendly in order to meet the regulatory requirements and consumer expectations. This is a blow to the responsible environmentally conscious part of the car industry by sniffing it at the reward of its investments by effectively raising emission limits to more than double by 2020. For these reasons, I have voted in favour of a veto on the decision.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure proposed by the European Commission is part of the second package on emissions tests under real driving conditions, which sets the emission limits not to be exceeded and the dates for their application to new models and new vehicles. In the current legal framework, vehicle emissions are determined based on test cycles carried out in laboratories, which does not reflect vehicle emissions under normal driving conditions. The Commission has been developing procedures to determine vehicle emissions under real-world conditions of circulation, which include the use of portable emission measurement systems. With the decision taken it will be possible to move forward with the RDE procedure.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it focuses exclusively on ideological considerations and does not support the car industry in European countries.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As an M5S we are strongly opposed to any method of calculating polluting emissions which, instead of counteracting the action of those who would like to circumvent existing rules and limits, aims to achieve the opposite objective. We will not put the protection of the interests of the powerful European car manufacturers' lobbies before the promotion of research, innovation and technologies dedicated to reducing the production of pollutants. We refuse to believe that the protection of health and the environment can be a systematic detriment to employment and work.  On the contrary, we believe that ideas in defence of the environment can be a great opportunity to create jobs, as is happening in integrated waste cycle management and in the field of renewable energies. If the European Union wants to reduce pollutants in the air, it cannot continue to be a slave to logics that protect only the profits and special interests of the few to the detriment of many.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After a meeting with the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles on 28/10/2015, the European Commission has tabled a proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 on emissions of pollutants from passenger and commercial light vehicles. The Euro 6 emission limit for nitrogen oxides (NOx) for vehicles fitted with diesel engine l is 80 mg/km under that Regulation, applicable to all new vehicles since 1/9/2014 and to all vehicles sold since 1/9/2015. This new proposal introduces a temporary compliance factor of 2.1 resulting in NOx emissions of 168 mg/km in the actual driving test applicable to all new passenger vehicles from 9/2019 (new types and vehicles 09/2017) and a final compliance factor of 1.5 that would apply to all new vehicles from 2021 on, allowing these vehicles to emit about 120 mg/km of NOx in the RED test. In other words, we are in practice facing a considerable increase from the figures previously foreseen. This resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft resolution, as what the Commission proposes would result in the derogation from the NOx emission limit values provided for in Euro 6. We voted in favour.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the adoption of the objection would prevent the entry into force of new road tests with negative consequences for employment and environmental levels.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating effects of air pollution annually, I am voting in favour of this report and agree that the draft regulation should be withdrawn and that the Commission should submit a new plan without delay by 1 April 2016 at the latest, in order to introduce a real-world driving emission test for all vehicles in order to ensure the effectiveness of the control systems.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection as the draft Commission Regulation would result in a de facto blanket derogation from applicable emissions limits, and is therefore not consistent with Union law, in that it is not compatible with the aim and content of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. The Commission should withdraw the draft regulation and submit a new one without delay and no later than 1 April 2016, in order to introduce a real driving emissions test for all vehicles with a view to ensuring the effectiveness of emission control systems and enabling vehicles to comply with Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 and its implementing measures.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it cannot be ignored that air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the EU each year and that the estimated costs of its health effects amount to EUR 940 billion per year and that nitrogen oxides (NOx) are among the main pollutants, causing, inter alia, lung cancer, asthma and a number of respiratory diseases. It is also worrying that recent analyses by the European Environment Agency on air pollution attribute 75 000 premature deaths to European nitrogen dioxide emissions, with 93% of the exceedment of limit values taking place near roads.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection to Euro 6 because we must indeed be demanding with industry, but we cannot forget that the letter of the law cannot go ahead of technology, because in that case, in the end, the result is never success, but failure.  We must be guarantors of legal certainty in Europe in order to be demanding, I repeat, with industry and guarantee thousands and thousands of jobs. From realism we must build a Europe that is a world leader and benchmark in green growth and that is competitive in creating high value-added jobs. A Europe that in turn complies with the agreements we reached a few weeks ago in Paris. This is the Europe we want.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and the Commission has acknowledged, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today Parliament has spoken out in concrete terms in favour of the environment by reducing the emissions that machines will produce, with a review process that will start at the beginning of 2017 and will have annual monitoring. If the proposed 'stop' had been adopted, we would have been faced with a situation in which cars would continue to pollute, with values far higher than those voted for in this text.  We must defend air quality, but we must also relaunch European growth. Instead of a legislative vacuum, pending a new proposal and a new process ( which would have taken between 1 and 2 years), our companies will now have a certain framework, which will allow investment in more environmentally friendly technologies and the protection of hundreds of thousands of jobs, which are our priority, together with the fight against pollution levels.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the objections under Article 106 of the CRP on emissions from light passenger cars and commercial vehicles (Euro 6), as I do not consider the approach of new implementing rules called for in parts to be sensible and profitable.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution of the parliamentary committee ENVI, which demands the withdrawal of the draft EC regulation on the realisation of emissions while driving (RDE). The emergence of an increased number of NOx with a serious reduction in CO2 emissions imposed by the EP, greater than that of petrol engines, was unexpected and was of a step-by-step rather than linear nature, as a result of exceeding a certain temperature threshold in the combustion chambers of diesel engines. At present, it takes time to correct this undoubted defect, as the EC rightly seeks. Thus, I believe, by 2019, this emission should correspond to that of Euro 5 diesel engines. Indeed, the EC project gives automotive companies time for appropriate technical solutions. It is a realistic solution that will save the continuity of production of diesel drives with great, forward-looking potential.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. We need a speedy procedure. The new limit values are ambitious, but they are feasible. It has to start at last. We cannot use another postponement. The Commission's draft before us is an improvement on the status quo. Rejection would have meant that the much-needed RDE tests would be delayed. And it is uncertain whether a new Commission proposal would actually have brought more stringent factors of agreement. Legal certainty and therefore planning certainty are particularly important for our industry, and thus also for the safeguarding of jobs.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues, I strongly support the swift introduction of Real Driving Emissions (RDE) testing so that emission tests for cars reflect pollution emitted on the road and not just in laboratories. The proposed draft Regulation will allow manufacturers to bring to the market vehicles emitting more than double the amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx) set by the Euro 6 emission standards agreed by the co-legislators in 2007. Furthermore, the figure of 1.5 contradicts the Commission’s own assessment of average PEMS error of measurement, which calculated a maximum conformity factor of 1.2. By changing the emission limit values enshrined in the Basic EU Regulation, the draft Regulation exceeds implementing powers provided for in the basic Euro 6 Regulation.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Julie Girling MEP on behalf of UK Conservative delegation. I voted against the comitology objection today. RDE is a crucial issue that must be introduced as soon as possible.  Whilst not perfect, we must ensure that we get the principle of RDE into regulations without delay. The agreement struck at the TCMV allows us to move forward to the next stage of delivering on RDE. The Commission has shown its commitment with the recent formal statement and we must hold Member States to their commitment to deliver a review of conformity factors and a clear path to a factor of one. This is not about allowing car manufacturer to breach Euro 6 standards, but rather about recognising the type approval mechanism is not perfect and ensuring the shift to RDE. The conformity factors included are not as low as technologically feasible, but they are transitional and the mechanism of annual review will allow the consideration of technological improvement moving forward. We have to get these key reforms going, and give some necessary legal and investment certainty. This measure is a major step forward in addressing Europe’s air quality issues.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the measures implemented by the European Commission in the RDE (real driving emissions) report to object to the 2.1 conformity factor and not to the RSDS procedure itself. The basic legislation was adopted in 2007 and published as Regulation No 692/2008 to set the emission limit at 80 mg/km. Now, with the new proposal, which introduces a compliance factor of 2.1, a surplus of 110% is allowed. This is inadmissible regardless of the recent scandal over failures in CO2 emission controls in the automotive sector (Volkswagen case). What the objection is intended to remove this preliminary proposal to increase emission levels and to present a new one by 1 April 2016 that respects emission limits.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's proposal for a number of reasons. Firstly, the European Commission's proposal provides for a mechanism to reduce emissions by around five times and allow the car manufacturing industry to change its manufacturing technology for the next step in reducing emissions. As I have shown before, we need to strike a balance between environmental regulations in Europe and industry support, as long as Europe is not the world's largest polluter and as long as we do not have trade defence regulations for European industry compared to non-European ones.  I support environmental policies, but we need to implement them with reason. According to the Commission's commitment, through Commissioner Elżbieta Bieńkowska, it will track both the emissions decrease schedule imposed and the compliance of the car manufacturing industry in a reasonable time.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles – chaired by the European Commission and consisting of national experts – agreed on the second package of RDE test procedure on 28 October 2015. In spite of the recent emission measurement scandal and the widespread exceedances of NOx limits throughout Europe, the committee agreed to allow Euro 6 diesel cars to emit over double the Euro 6 limit from 2017 to 2020, and 50% after 2020, de facto increasing the standard to 120 mg/km forever. For these reasons we cannot accept the political decision made in the technical committee. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this objection and request a new proposal from the Commission by 1 April 2016.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. This avoids the status quo. A status quo that could have arranged the industrialists in order to continue to carry out unscrupulous tests. The challenge was to put an end to the old laboratory tests, which were unreliable and which did not represent the reality of emissions released into the atmosphere, and to put in place new tests carried out under real driving conditions. This could not be done without transition with such strict limits for such different tests! The limit values will be revised as they go along in 2018 and again in 2020. The European Commission has also put forward ambitious proposals in this area.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal exposed the fraud of emissions of car pollutants. At this plenary session in February, I supported an objection from the European Parliament which opposed a decision by the European Commission on this matter. The Commission wants to allow car companies and vehicles to exceed the nitrogen oxide emission thresholds allowed by current standards by up to 110%, which is unacceptable. Remember that these particles are carcinogenic. Parliament's objection also called on the Commission to carry out tests for the emission of pollutants from vehicles under real driving conditions - the current tests allowing fraud or not always being representative. I voted for this objection because car pollution is a crucial health and environmental risk that must be effectively monitored and whose standards must be respected. However, this objection has been rejected, overwhelmingly by right-wing and far-right MPs, which I strongly deplore.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s objection pursuant to Rule 106 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). There should be set a more efficient emission measurement while driving identified vehicles (Euro6) in actual driving conditions in order to ensure control efficiency regarding emissions.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). This resolution is contrary to the Commission's regulation because it would result in an exemption from the NOx Euro 6 emission limits. In addition, the Regulation goes beyond the implementing powers of the previous Regulation. We voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ New road tests measuring real emissions are urgently needed and the import here is real. Under the present proposal which was agreed behind closed doors by the Commission and Member States there will be a dilution of agreed EU emission norms. In fact we could end up awarding manufacturers who did not comply in the first place. Therefore, I voted in favour of this objection. We need better outcomes for our citizens.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. A major reason why Member States cannot comply with the limit values for NOx concentrations in the air is due to the discrepancy between the real driving conditions of diesel vehicles, where far greater emissions are expected, and the artificial driving conditions in the laboratory. The introduction of "Real Driving Emission" tests will help to reduce NOx emissions from diesel engines. At the same time, it will help countries to comply with guidelines and limits. The parties objecting argue that the new emission limits for NOx are excessive and are not in line with Regulation (EC) No 692/2008. Some others see the measure as a delay in favour of the automotive industry and for weaker implementation of EU environmental legislation. I voted against the objection because I consider innovation in the field of emissions testing to be important. Improving the test system, which is almost thirty years old, is the first step in the right direction.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. According to the latest calculations of the European Commission, the painful truth is that the emissions of euro 6 diesel engines currently produced on the roads are on average 400% higher than those measured on the test bench! The regulation represents a significant step forward compared to the current real emissions. Deadlines and targets appropriate to reality and technical possibilities provide predictability for the automotive industry. In addition, the new limit values foresk out real emission reductions, significantly mitigating health-environmental risks. In my opinion, the draft legislation strikes the right balance between environmental and public health objectives and preserving the competitiveness of domestic jobs and industry. I am convinced that a responsible decision-maker does not lay down rules based on dreamlike expectations. It would be irresponsible to insist on what has already been proven to be technically impractical over time. No one should be fooled into adopting irrealistic rules.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. Overall, the decision should be considered positive. I welcome the fact that the very demanding values are being put in place. This vote has succeeded in taking an important step towards sensible and practical environmental legislation: the reduction of pollutant emissions from road transport will significantly improve the health and quality of life of citizens. Even from a technical-economic point of view, the RDE values can only mean progress, which is associated with many efforts, but can also secure the technological leadership of clean diesel vehicles. The incidents also show that it is important in legislation never to lose touch with reality. It is not a matter of improving statistics, but of reality.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 692/2008 on light passenger and commercial vehicle (Euro 6) emissions, as air pollution is one of the biggest problems of today and the cause of many diseases and premature deaths. According to a recent analysis of air pollution by the European Environment Agency, 75,000 premature deaths in Europe are attributed to nitrogen oxide emissions, in this case no2 in particular.  Significant reductions in nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel vehicles are needed to improve air quality and meet pollutant limits, so the Commission must continue to regularly review individual procedures and processes. I agree that the Commission needs to submit a new draft regulation, as required by the motion for a resolution itself, to examine real driving emissions for all vehicles and to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The issue of emissions of pollutants from vehicles has returned to the forefront of European politics in the Volkswagen case. The Commission's stringent standards for pollutant emissions do not yet require real driving test (RDE). The limit values set out in a regulation in 2007 are reviewed by internal procedures within the Commission: the requirement of this motion for a resolution was therefore to request a new regulation, to be submitted by 1 April 2016, to impose tests in real condition as soon as possible. This race to the norm is questionable for two reasons: first, Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world. Secondly, technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in terms of combating air pollution, as the EU also encourages more and more the flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in crisis.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Although the majority of the European Parliament’s Members did not object, the compromise proposed by EU Member States stating that, following the entry into force of a more accurate testing method of car emission next year, new models would be allowed to emit nitrogen oxide at a rate of 168 milligrams per kilometre, despite an EU limit of 80mg/km, I decided to refuse this compromise. By endorsing this proposal, the European Parliament basically allowed diesel cars to emit double the legal emission limit of nitrogen oxide until 2020. The result of the vote is, I think, a blanket derogation from our emission limits. I believe it is urgent that stricter rules for car emissions testing apply in Europe.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the objection in accordance with Article 106 on emissions of passenger and light commercial vehicles (Euro 6). This rejection will allow for the rapid implementation of emission tests in real driving situations, which will really have an impact on European air quality. Laboratory tests were not reliable enough. Emission limits will be revised over time in parallel with improved testing. The Commission has already presented ambitious measures on the vehicle registration process and on the independence of tests, including their funding.
