This resolution has not been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection, which was to challenge the commission's proposed new car testing framework to check emissions from passenger vehicles in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal. Indeed, the old test frame was very unreliable. The regulatory limits on emissions not to be exceeded in real-world driving tests must be implemented quickly, as this testing procedure is much more reliable than the previous ones.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution because the rapporteur criticises the Commission's draft implementing decision, which goes beyond the Powers of the Commission (VO 715/2007). With its draft, the Commission is creating a general "de facto exception" to existing emission limits. This is contrary to the above-mentioned regulation. The Commission is therefore invited to withdraw this draft and make appropriate adjustments by April 2016, so that all vehicles are tested to determine emissions under real driving conditions.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the recent car emissions scandal, the European Commission has come up with legislation to check the compliance of new car models with european union environmental standards. This legislation is a big step towards returning consumer confidence, as tests will take place under the right driving conditions on the road, not just in the laboratory, as before. If the European Commission's offer were rejected, we would lose for many months or even years until a new regulation was drawn up. The current offer also sends a clear signal and rules to the auto industry. For the above reasons, I voted against the European Parliament's request for the legislation proposed by the European Commission to be withdrawn.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs strongly support the swift introduction of Real Driving Emissions (RDE) testing so that emission tests for cars reflect pollution emitted on the road and not just in laboratories. The proposed draft Regulation will allow manufacturers to bring to the market vehicles emitting more than double the amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx) set by the Euro 6 emission standards agreed by the co-legislators in 2007. Furthermore the figure of 1.5 contradicts the Commission’s own assessment of average PEMS error of measurement, which calculated a maximum conformity factor of 1.2. By changing the emission limit values enshrined in the Basic EU Regulation, the draft Regulation exceeds implementing powers provided for in the basic Euro 6 Regulation.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. A major reason why Member States cannot comply with the limit values for nitrogen oxide concentrations in the air is due to the discrepancy between the real driving conditions of diesel vehicles, where far greater emissions are to be expected, and the artificial driving conditions in the laboratory. The introduction of "real driving emission" tests will help to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel engines. At the same time, it will help countries to comply with guidelines and limits.  The opposition parties argue that the new emission limits for nitrogen oxides (NOx) are excessive and are not in line with Regulation (EC) No 692/2008. Some others see the measure as a delay in favour of the automotive industry and for weaker implementation of EU environmental legislation.  I voted against the objection because I consider innovation in the field of emissions testing to be important. Improving the test system, which is almost thirty years old, is the first step in the right direction.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. According to the latest calculations of the European Commission, the painful truth is that the emissions of euro 6 diesel engines currently produced on the roads are on average 400% higher than those measured on the test bench! The European Commission's draft implementing regulation is an important element in solving the problem, with the aim of reducing emissions as soon as possible in real-world conditions. From 2017 onwards, new vehicles may exceed the base value of 80 g/km as set out in the 2007 basic legislation by a maximum of 110% (cf multiplier 2.1) and by 50% (CF multiplier 1.5) from 2020. The reality picture represents a significant step forward in the regulation. Deadlines and targets appropriate to reality and technical possibilities provide predictability for the automotive industry. In addition, the new limit values foresk out real emission reductions, significantly mitigating health-environmental risks. In my opinion, the draft legislation strikes the right balance between environmental and public health objectives and preserving the competitiveness of domestic jobs and industry. I am convinced that a responsible decision-maker does not lay down rules based on dreamlike expectations. It would be irresponsible to insist on what has already been proven to be technically impractical over time. No one should be fooled into adopting irrealistic rules.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The Euro 6 standard provides for emission limits of 80 mg/km NOx. These are test bench values that can only be tested in laboratories. It is now clear that these test bench values from 1996 differ greatly from the actual exhaust emissions on the road: the driving behaviour has a massive influence on emissions. In real driving, there is an actual nitrogen oxide emission of up to 320mg/km. The introduction of real driving emissions tests (RDE) is therefore absolutely necessary. Subsequently, the limit values must also comply with the new test procedure: the adaptation of the NOx limit values to the real test procedure is carried out by means of conformity factors according to the comitology proposal: New diesel models will be allowed to emit 168 mg NOx/km from 1 September 2017, and from 1 January 2020 only 120 mg NOx/km. This is an ambitious target, given that real emissions are up to four times higher. The automotive industry in Austria inindirects employs 370 000 people. Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular depend on being able to know the regulatory requirements in a timely and clear manner. Rejection of the proposal would mean a major delay in the introduction of RDE tests. RDE tests enable the detection of limit values and provide clarity and transparency in terms of customer confidence and environmental protection. I have therefore voted against the opposition in order to ensure the introduction of reliable tests. Legal certainty must be created for consumers and producers.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the introduction of the new vehicle type-approval tests, in which exhaust emissions are measured in road driving and no longer in the laboratory, technical changes were needed to convert the values in the transition from one to the other method of measurement.  The result of our vote is a result for the environment because it actuallyes the emissions that the machines will produce, with a review process that will start in early 2017 and will have annual monitoring. Cars on the road today emit about 360 mg/km. Thanks to this measure, manufacturers will have to place on the market, from 2017, cars emitting 168 mg/km, a value that will reach 80 mg/km by 2023.  Today we must defend air quality, but we must also relaunch European growth. Instead of a legislative vacuum, pending a new proposal and a new process ( which would have taken between 1 and 2 years), our companies will have a certain framework, which will allow investment in more environmentally friendly technologies and the protection of hundreds of thousands of jobs, and we will protect our citizens by greatly improving the quality of the air we breathe.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I and my colleagues in the EPP Group voted against the objection to vehicle emissions calling on the Commission to withdraw its draft regulation setting limits on diesel engine emissions, which are measured in real driving conditions. I welcome the European Parliament's rejection of this objection, considering that the revision of emissions limits over the years will promote the improvement of air quality in Europe and the performance of these tests. In addition, this gradual review will allow our European automotive industry to gradually adapt to established environmental standards.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. After the Volkswagen scandal, the Commission, which was aware of the frauds long before the case broke, was forced to change the methods of vehicle registration and the conditions for pollutant emissions tests. But the Commission has reverted to its own standards, pressed by the automotive industry lobby worried about having to play cards on the table on their emissions. It has done so by denying its own pollution thresholds, especially for diesel, and by adopting "guidelines" that allow overruns of up to double (more than 110%) thresholds. The manner in which these tolerances have been adopted is a scandal since the Commission has used an internal legislative procedure, which allows Parliament only to oppose this gift to the manufacturers-fraudsters. I have therefore opposed this double legislative sleight of hand, which has taken place at the expense of the anti-pollution standards already adopted, of European democracy and of the health of European citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the objection in accordance with section 106 on emissions from passenger and light commercial vehicles. The Volkswagen scandal revealed considerable discrepancies between emissions of pollutants in the laboratory and in real driving conditions for diesel engines. The Commission's exacting standards for pollutant emissions do not yet require such tests. The requirement of this resolution is to request a new regulation, to be submitted by 1 April 2016, to impose tests in real condition as soon as possible. The first recital recalls the cost of air pollution, and justifies by this assertion the requirement of ever more restrictive and expensive technical standards. These requirements are questionable for two reasons: Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world; technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in action to combat air pollution, as the EU also encourages more and more the flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in difficulty.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it requires, too hastily, that a new regulation be ready by 1 April 2016 to impose pollution controls on diesel engines in real driving conditions and not in the laboratory. However, if I agree to act in such a way that a Volkswagen-type scandal does not happen again, I believe that it must be done without excessive haste, so as not to harm the European car industry, which provides many jobs, and which would need a little more time to adapt to the new standards.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution for several important reasons, namely: – I consider it scientifically incorrect to assume a linear increase in CO2 and NOx reduction in parallel, scientific opinions convincingly prove the absence of such a rule; – the Commission's declarations on the revision of the way emission measurements are measured and the new timetable are convincing. I welcome the Commission's statement by Commissioner Bieńkowska with high hope and anticipation.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. A major reason why Member States cannot comply with the limit values for NOx concentrations in the air is due to the discrepancy between the real driving conditions of diesel vehicles, where far greater emissions are expected, and the artificial driving conditions in the laboratory. The introduction of "Real Driving Emission" tests will help to reduce NOx emissions from diesel engines. At the same time, it will help countries to comply with guidelines and limits.  The parties objecting argue that the new emission limits for NOx are excessive and are not in line with Regulation (EC) No 692/2008. Some others see the measure as a delay in favour of the automotive industry and for weaker implementation of EU environmental legislation.  I voted against the objection because I consider innovation in the field of emissions testing to be important. Improving the test system, which is almost thirty years old, is the first step in the right direction.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is understandable that when the emission measurement procedure (measurements in normal operation) changes, the engines will show other (higher) emissions. Therefore, the transitional measure proposed by the Commission, which will allow cars with emissions above 80 mg NOx per km to pass the test, is also understandable. Accepting the objection would entail a de facto tightening of the standard, but carried out without proper consideration. I voted against.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Every year, 430 000 premature deaths caused by air pollution are recorded in the Union. Achieving the EU's air quality targets requires sustained efforts to reduce vehicle emissions. Measuring emissions in the automotive sector is an essential element in order to maintain air quality and national emission ceilings for certain pollutants need to be introduced.  The automotive industry should be informed of future emission limits, including emission values for Euro 5 and Euro 6 degrees. Setting such measures to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxide at an early stage will provide long-term planning certainty for vehicle manufacturers across Europe. The draft Commission has resulted in a de facto general deviation from the applicable emission limits and is therefore incompatible with Union law. The Commission is asked to withdraw the draft regulation without delay and no later than 1 April 2016 and submit a new regulation, in order to introduce real-world driving emissions testing for all vehicles and to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems. I did not support the objection in accordance with Article 106, as I consider it necessary to have a system and harmonised way of monitoring air emissions without harming the automotive industry. If these measures are introduced too quickly, it could have major negative consequences in the automotive industry.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Light passenger and commercial vehicles, even if abstracted from goods vehicles and others, constitute one of the most important emission groups in parallel with industry, agriculture and various other areas. Consequently, the maximum strict follow-up to the installed emission levels (mg/km) and their non-infringement is of fundamental importance, especially in the European Union, given our comprehensive ecological and environmental protection policy, not to mention emission allowances. This vote concerned a recent draft Commission implementing decision, on which the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles (TCMV) published its opinion on 28 October 2015. With the entry into force, this would actually lead to a situation where, from September 2019 (for new vehicle types from September 2017), potential emissions would amount to 168 mg/km NOx, while the maximum for the Euro 6 standard for that period would be only 80 mg/km respectively. As a result, the European Parliament came to the conclusion that the draft implementing decision supported by the Commission does not comply with Regulation (EU) No 715/2007, not to mention that the Commission actually decided to go against a number of principles that have been largely fought for throughout these years. I therefore voted unequivocally in favour of the EP's decision to reject the Commission's proposal.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ an estimated 430,000 Europeans are dying prematurely due to poor air quality; nitrogen oxides and particulate emissions are a major cause.  At the same time, infringement proceedings are being conducted against 17 Member States for non-compliance with the Ambient Air Quality Directive. The findings showed that there is a significant difference in the automotive sector between emission levels when measured under laboratory conditions or in real driving. We therefore need to reach a situation as soon as possible where today's laboratory limits will be limits even under real conditions. Without the compromise negotiated by the Commission and agreed by the Council, solutions were in danger of being blocked, time was wasting on the road to measuring emissions in real terms, and thus hindering emission reductions in the automotive industry. In Slovakia, up to 44% of GDP is made up of the automotive industry, with more than 200,000 jobs depending on this sector. On the way to our objectives, we must take all measures to protect the environment;

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution based on objections pursuance to Article 106 of the Commission's draft Regulation (EU) amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (EUR 6), it is complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for a set of rules on light passenger vehicles and light commercial vehicles (Euro 6), allowing for the rapid implementation of CO2 emission scans under real conditions so that all requirements in EU law are met. We need consistent European rules that apply uniformly in all Member States. The Commission has come up with a feasible proposal obliging the machinery sector to comply.  The Commission has committed to closely monitor CO2 emissions tests in real-world traffic conditions for all vehicles in the future in order to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems. It's a welcome thing. We need to promote an innovative and sustainable European industry that puts consumer interest first. I call on the Commission to come up with future legislative proposals on the automotive industry with new solutions that are good for both consumers and manufacturers.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this text. It follows the Volkswagen scandal that revealed the discrepancies between emissions of pollutants from laboratory tests and those in real driving conditions. The unachievable and unrealistic emissions requirements are set by the Commission, which unilaterally demands a political ecology that is harmful to European industry, with serious consequences for a sector already in crisis.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided not to support this objection after the EU Commission promised a review clause and tabled a long-term legislative proposal to revamp the EU car approval regime.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objection under Article 106 of the Regulation on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro6) does not meet with my vote in favour. The vote is intended to support the clear importance of being able to provide a certain picture of the rules, thus making it possible for producers to invest, aware of the deadlines, which can actually lead to a reduction in emissions. This is another fundamental point which justifies the vote, since this will lead to a real progressive reduction in vehicle emissions. Finally, it should be emphasized that it is necessary that the parameters that must be respected are those with real road tests and not tests in the laboratory that are not faithful to situations of concrete use of the vehicle and therefore not useful for the purpose of effective information.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The revelations about the polluting emissions of Volkswagen vehicles and the suspicions against other manufacturers have raised legitimate indignation. A major sector of the European economy, largely supported by the government during the crisis, knowingly organised massive fraud to circumvent anti-pollution standards.  The European Commission has taken a crucial decision on this issue, without referring it to either the Member States or the European Parliament: that of giving in to the fraud of the car sector. Rather than punish those who do not comply with the prescribed standards, it prefers to raise the maximum level of permitted polluting gases (including nitrogen oxide).  In the wake of COP 21, the Commission, one of the three pillars of its Europe 2020 strategy is sustainable growth, is giving in to the car lobby without consultation. Small consolation, the tests will have to be carried out in real driving. However, the arbitrary authorisation given to manufacturers to exceed the permitted ceilings by 110% is unacceptable. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution of objection.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's draft provides legal uncertainty for vehicle manufacturers, as the current calculation allows for a margin of uncertainty of up to 30%. This is also at the expense of consumers. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation on vehicle emissions under the real driving emission package (RDE). This regulation allows for exemptions from the Euro 6 emissions limits of NOx (nitrogen oxide) which leads to a lowering of anti-pollution standards. Increasing NOx emission limits for diesel vehicles will have serious consequences for the health of European citizens. Air pollution causes more than 400,000 premature deaths a year in the European Union, and causes significant health costs of between 330 and 940 billion euros per year. In France, air quality causes more than 42,000 premature deaths and costs between 34,999 and 103,497 million euros per year. NO2 emissions (mostly emitted by diesel vehicles) are responsible for more than 7700 deaths per year in France. I vote for this text which opposes the harmful plans of the Committee

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. On the occasion of the Volkswagen case, the issue of emissions of pollutants by vehicles has returned to the forefront of European politics. The Commission's stringent standards for pollutant emissions do not yet require real driving test (RDE). Internal procedures in the Commission review the limits set out in a regulation in 2007: This motion for a resolution required a request for a new regulation, to be submitted by 1 April 2016, to impose tests in real condition as soon as possible. I challenge this race to the norm for two reasons: first, Europe is becoming the least industry-friendly region of the world. Technical standards also show a contradiction in the fight against air pollution, as the EU increasingly encourages the flows that generate these emissions. I note that this text is a unilateral requirement of political ecology, and this is the sole responsibility of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in crisis. I therefore objected to that objection.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection under Article 106: emissions from passenger and commercial light vehicles (Euro 6) It is important that manufacturers are required to ensure, at the time of type-approval and over the life of the vehicle, that emissions produced during an ECR test do not exceed the limit values. The tests must be real, i.e. road side driving tests.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this objection. Vetoing the agreement would have led to creating a legal vacuum for the next two years combined with uncertainty for car owners and the industry and absolutely no progress for the environment. Now the EU can rapidly implement the on-road tests, which together with the planned Commission proposals for a major overhaul of the EU type approval framework will make it very difficult for the car industry to circumvent the emissions requirements.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. It is a great pity that Parliament did not reject the Commission's proposal on the watered-down emission standards for diesel vehicles. The Commission's proposal has made a bad turn. Diesel cars will be given the commission's approval to emit twice as much NOx as legally permitted in the next few years. That's the wrong signal. The diesel scandal has undermined consumer confidence in Europe and the US. Car owners note that manufacturers are deliberately taking a stand against environmental laws and marketing cars that are much more polluting than they want the customer and the legislature to believe. That is precisely why I expected a clear and ambitious proposal from the Commission. The air quality in many of our European cities is still of inferior quality. A correct application of the standard of 80 mg/km would have yielded pure profit. Engines are becoming less polluting, air quality in our cities is improving and people's health is improving. In the US – still a huge potential growth market for the European automotive industry – there is an emissions standard of 43 mg/km. What is preventing the Commission and the automotive sector from pursuing ambitious standards?

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – More than 400 000 people die every year in the European Union as a result of air pollution. The Union has a duty to drastically reduce these figures. However, the Commission's proposal is insufficiently protecting human health. Indeed, this figure is pointlessly high, so harmful effects need to be eliminated from the beginning. I consider it important that checks be tightened up when approving the types of vehicles that will be released for sale, and I also consider it essential that checks be carried out on those cars that are already in use. Checks must be carried out in such a way as to deliver concrete results and thus reduce air pollution levels.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject and veto the Commission’s plan to temporarily raise NOx emission limits for diesel cars. For the sake of our own health and following the recent emissions scandal and the fact that numerous devastating lung diseases and more than 600 000 premature deaths are linked annually in Europe to air pollution, I believe that we have the obligation to protect consumers and provide a better air quality for our citizens. That is why I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6).

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I have today called for stricter rules on emissions tests for diesel vehicles. Unfortunately, the majority of the plenary voted in favour of the Commission's original proposal, which was greatly weakened by the EU Member States. This generous scheme will now mean that the measured value on the road by 2020 may be more than twice as high as the official limit value applicable to laboratory measurement. After that, emissions on the road can still be up to 50 percent higher than the laboratory value. Especially at a time when European cities are increasingly struggling with increased particulate matter pollution and air pollution, and in some cases having to ban cars completely from the road, we MEPs should have been a sign of the health of our citizens.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has adopted a draft regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 as regards emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety recommends that Parliament take a position that the commission's draft regulation would actually result in a general derogation from the applicable emission limit values and is therefore not in line with EU law as it is incompatible with the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. It also proposes that Parliament call on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and to submit a new one without delay, no later than 1 April 2016, with a view to introducing emission measurements under real driving conditions to ensure the efficiency of the emission control system and to ensure that the vehicle complies with Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 and the implementing measures of the Regulation. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has drawn up a draft decision with the support of the Member States. This project is based on an analysis by the Joint Research Centre (JRC) where it was concluded that the actual (and not laboratory) testing procedure may introduce a margin of uncertainty for measurements of a maximum of 30 %, i.e. a 'more pessimistic margin' of 25 mg NOx/km in the case of the limit provided for by Euro 6. I voted against Parliament's motion for a resolution because the Commission has therefore drawn up a new draft implementing measures with the aim of amending the Regulation by adapting the test procedures so that they adequately reflect emissions generated in real road driving conditions.  I also see it as extremely positive that manufacturers are required, at the time of type-approval and over the life of the vehicle, that emissions produced during an ECR test do not exceed certain limit values.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed resolution on emissions of passenger and light vehicles follows the Volkswagen scandal. The revelations had implicated the company for falsifying its tests on emissions of pollutants in the laboratory and in real driving conditions. The text recalls the cost of pollution (estimated at 940 billion euros per year) which would justify the introduction of ever more stringent standards. However, this text imposes on the european industries alone, which are already well degraded, the cost of this ecological burden.  So I decided to vote against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the proposed regulations on emissions from passenger and light commercial vehicles. Filed by the extreme left, socialists, Greens and centrists, this objection would have unreasonably delayed the Commission's process of replacing laboratory tests with real-world tests. With this text, Europe will become the first continent to adopt emission tests in real driving, far more true to reality than laboratory tests, whose theoretical values are always far and far exceeded. These new tests will provide greater visibility and legal certainty for automakers who need to plan their long-term investments in emissions reduction and environmental protection. They will also provide consumers with more reliable information about the polluting nature of the vehicles they acquire. The regulation provides for new thresholds adapted to actual driving. These thresholds will be gradually tightened.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Weighed up the seriousness of the phenomenon of air pollution, which causes 430 000 premature deaths in Europe every year and weighs EUR 940 billion on the public purse, I welcome the objection to the European Commission's proposal. The measures indicated appear, in fact, to be inadequate for effective protection of the health of citizens and too weak to give a signal to the industrial sector and guide investment in the areas of environmental innovation. The political response to the measurement scandal would also be in danger of appearing weakened. Furthermore, given our commitment to the inclusion of strict environmental clauses and the promotion of European environmental standards in international trade agreements, we cannot in any way approve a proposal that could potentially weaken the position of European negotiators in the various trade initiatives and, in particular, in negotiations with the American side. The Commission's proposal also appears to be inconsistent and poorly compatible with the ambitious targets set by the Paris Agreement on climate change. A European diplomatic victory that confirmed the Eu ropean Union's role as the main supporter of the fight against global warming. The European Union has been able to demonstrate the parallelism between growth and environmental protection. We therefore call on the Commission to draw up a new proposal that is equal to the European historic result.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. Taking advantage of the revelations about Volkswagen's rigged tests, an objection to a rule change for measuring polluting emissions from cars has been filed. I voted against this objection, which does not take into account the new binding text, which is already a major step forward for everyone towards better tests and respect for the environment.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Delegation of European Citizens supports the greatest demand and ambition for emissions from passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. However, we also consider that a new directive, which would shorten emission adjustment times for such vehicles, would directly affect the employment and economy of European countries where the manufacture of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles takes place.  In the specific case of Spain, about 60% of the vehicles manufactured are passenger cars and light commercial vehicles (according to figures from ANFAC, Spanish Association of Automobile and Truck Manufacturers).  So, in defence of jobs and considering that the time limits defined by the Directive proposed by the Commission are consistent with the times that industry needs to adapt its manufacturing processes towards the production of less polluting vehicles, European Citizens will vote against reviewing the proposed amendment to Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 as regards emissions from passenger cars and light commercial vehicles.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution that should introduce a new real driving emissions test for all vehicles. The draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing power provided in the European Commission’s Regulation number 715/2007. A new regulation should be drafted by the Commission and submitted by the 1 April 2016.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting in favour of or against this motion for a resolution because I believe that, at the moment, we need more data on the actual emissions of passenger and commercial light vehicles. With regard to the Commission's new proposal, to which this resolution refers, I believe that it must be considered after we can assess its application, in order to see to what extent it is appropriate to find a balance between the emission reduction, desired by everyone, and the damage to the EU car industry.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 After careful thought, I have decided to abstain, although I am not happy with the Commission's decision to introducing emissions tests in normal operation and I consider the permitted variations in emission measurement to be unjustifiably benevolent. I am relying on the Commission's commitment to apply a revision clause in order to get emission levels to approved figures with minimum deviations as soon as possible. This is linked to the need to eliminate as quickly as possible technical inconsistencies in the PEMS measurement software, which may be to some extent responsible for variations in emission measurement.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the opposition to the resolution, which calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and to submit a new one by 1 April 2016 in order to introduce a real driving emissions test for all vehicles.  I do not support the objection as this would leave the EU without any new rules. The proposed report provides an effective way to significantly reduce air pollution from diesel cars in the short term.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution criticises the Commission's draft implementing decision, which would create significant legal uncertainty for vehicle manufacturers. Since this would also be at the expense of consumers, I have spoken in favour of the criticism and in favour of the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The car industry is a very large source of environmental pollution, so the sector must take responsibility for human health. The Commission's proposal foresees more flexibility in the criteria for measuring the emission limit value generated by the automotive industry. Previously, they have been agreed in 2007 and the Commission wishes to relax the criteria, which is unfair to those companies that already comply with the rules that will come into force in 2017. There must also be no further concessions in the form of evading the emission limit.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The text we have just voted on opposes the European Commission's draft measures, which defines how new emission tests for pollutants will be implemented in real circumstances of vehicle use. The draft Regulation introduces so-called conformity factors, which add a margin of flexibility between test results and emission limits. The reason why I voted in favour of the objection is that these factors have set levels which allow manufacturers to continue to significantly exceed the NOx emission limit defined by Parliament and the Council in basic legislation. Volkswagen's recent scandal must serve to take the necessary action on an issue that is not only technically or economically relevant. As I have said repeatedly, through this type of fraud we are all affected: deceived buyers, administrations, but above all citizens in general, who see how money is played with our air, our oxygen, our life and our future. For all of the above, I can only vote in favour of the objection.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and to submit a new draft regulation without delay and by 1 April 2016. The above-mentioned decision, which increases the permitted limits for nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel engines by more than 100%, is in breach of citizens' interests and the objectives of safety and environmental policy. We cannot allow the interests of the car industry to be more important than public safety and its legitimate expectations. We need to lower the emission limits and ensure that vehicles are in a much cleaner atmosphere with regard to pollutants that are harmful to human health.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There has been a lot of criticism about the potential damage caused by nitrogen oxides (NOX). In order to eliminate these critical issues, the Commission is constantly being entrusted with a task of continuous supervision in the text; It is therefore envisaged, if the proportions envisaged are no longer considered adequate, that a review will be carried out.  Considering that the measures taken by the regulation on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6) are in the best interests of eu ropean Union provisions, I do not think it is appropriate to support the objection and therefore vote against it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted against the objection on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6), which would mean delaying the process of finding a solution to reduce emissions. By vote against, we will be able to take the necessary action immediately, thus contributing to reducing the emission levels of vehicles measured under normal conditions of use.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Objection to the Commission's draft regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 2012 692/2008 as regards light passenger and commercial vehicle (Euro 6) emissions did not receive a sufficient number of votes. Withdrawal of the proposal for this act, and as requested in the proposal for a resolution seeking to object in accordance with Article 106 TB, The EP rules of procedure would not bring any progress in relation to the current situation and would further complicate the situation and delay the adoption of appropriate legal acts for at least two years, the average duration of the prescribed procedure.  The proposed would also mean maintaining the status quo until a new proposal is adopted, without actually reducing emissions, which is of no interest to anyone. The proposed 'transitional solution' may not be the best, especially after the detection of the laboratory test results rigging scandal, but it is certainly on the track of achieving the desired objectives. This approach is also supported by a statement by Elżbiete Bieńkowska, Commissioner for Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs, which discusses the wide-ranging amendments to the existing vehicle type-approval regulation.  In this regard, it is necessary to establish a verified and reliable methodology for real-world emission testing, which will result in a real reduction in emissions of air pollutants (in particular nitrogen oxides) from light passenger and commercial vehicles.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation that the Commission has presented on the emission limits for light passenger and commercial vehicles (euro 6) would involve not only a change, but a real reversal of the rules established to date. Indeed, the proposed increase in the maximum emission values for nitrogen oxides is technically unjustifiable and politically unacceptable, because it contradicts the Programme of the European Strategy for Cleaner Air and because the Commission, with its proposal, is trying to appropriate competences that are not its own, as clearly laid down in Article 5(3) of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. It is understandable that the new real-driving emissions testing (RDE) procedure, based on the Portable Emissions Monitoring System (PEMS), requires an update that takes into account the margin of error of PEMS systems. The Commission's proposal, however, goes too far, unjustifiably raising the limits, de facto and forever.  I therefore voted against this increase proposed by the Commission because it is in complete contradiction to the environmental policies that Europe has been trying to pursue for years, without forgetting the very high cost of human life which, according to recent studies on air pollution, is attributed to NOx emissions.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒More than 430 000 premature deaths caused by air pollution are recorded in the Union each year and the costs associated with the health impact of air pollution are estimated at €940 billion per year. According to a recent analysis of air pollution by the European Environment Agency, 75,000 premature deaths are attributed to NO2 emissions in Europe, with 93% of all overrun cases being in areas near roads.  Shocking is this data that points to the urgent need to act to reduce emissions and mitigate the consequences they cause. In paragraph 14 of its Resolution of 27 October 2015 on emission measurements in the automotive sector, Parliament endorsed a provision in the report asking the Commission to 'introduce real-world driving emission testing for all vehicles that have undergone type approval or have been registered since 2015, in order to ensure the effectiveness of the emission control system and to allow vehicles to comply with this Regulation and its implementing measures.  Taking this into account, and the draft Commission Regulation (D042120/03), I agree with the view that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2020/03. 715/2007, that the draft Commission regulation resulted in a de facto general deviation from the applicable emission limits, which is why it does not comply with EU law.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After a meeting with the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles on 28/10/2015, the European Commission has tabled a proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 on emissions of pollutants from passenger and commercial light vehicles. The Euro 6 emission limit for nitrogen oxides (NOx) for vehicles fitted with diesel engine l is 80 mg/km under that Regulation, applicable to all new vehicles since 1/9/2014 and to all vehicles sold since 1/9/2015. This new proposal introduces a temporary compliance factor of 2.1 resulting in NOx emissions of 168 mg/km in the actual driving test applicable to all new passenger vehicles from 9/2019 (new types and vehicles 09/2017) and a final compliance factor of 1.5 which would apply to all new vehicles from 2021 on, allowing these vehicles to emit about 120 mg/km of NOx in the RED test. In other words, we are in practice facing a considerable increase from the figures previously foreseen. This resolution opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft resolution, as what the Commission proposes would result in the derogation from the NOx emission limit values provided for in Euro 6. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a resolution of objection in accordance with Article 106. Rules of procedure on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). Over 430,000 premature deaths caused by air pollution have been reported in the European Union each year and the costs associated with the health impact of air pollution are estimated at €940 billion per year.  Nitrogen oxides are one of the biggest causes of air pollution, causing lung cancer, asthma and many other respiratory diseases, among others, as well as environmental degradation involving processes such as eutrophication and acidification. According to a recent analysis of air pollution by the European Environment Agency, 75,000 premature deaths are attributed to NO2 emissions in Europe, with 93% of all overrun cases being in areas near roads.  To achieve the European Union's air quality targets, sustained efforts to reduce vehicle emissions are necessary and therefore the industry must be clearly informed of future emission limits. It is very important to put in place clear measures to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions at an early stage, as this will allow for the long-term planning safety of vehicle manufacturers across Europe.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its opposition, the European Parliament criticises the Commission for making changes beyond its competence in drafting an implementing decision on, in particular, the introduction of a new real-world emission measurement system (RDE) and raising the nitrogen emission limit for 2019 and 2020 above the target of 80 mg/km, namely 168 and 120 mg/km respectively. The current value is around 600 mg. The EU should strive for the maximum possible reduction in emissions, the real value of emissions emitted (where, on the one hand, our desire to improve the environment, on the other hand, the technological possibilities of manufacturers and the length of the 'life cycle' of innovation in the automotive industry) have been and will be debated. Above all, however, it is important for us to have an RDE testing system in place as soon as possible to provide us with important and much more accurate information. Although I am very dissatisfied with the way in which the Commission has proposed the amendments, and the objection is fully justified in this respect, I am also aware that the adoption of the objection would dramatically delay the introduction of RDE and would have a negative impact on both the environment and producers.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The second RDE (Real Drive Emissions) package, proposed by the European Commission and approved on 28 October 2015 by the Technical Commission for Vehicles, aims to establish certain quantitative criteria, including the so-good compliance factor, in order to equate data from tests on vehicles carried out in the laboratory with those in real road driving conditions and to limit vehicle emissions (Euro 6). This technical need stems from the introduction of new tests, in which exhaust emissions are measured in road driving, and does not change the legislative type-approval limit imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, which remains, in the case of NOx, 80 mg/km for the Euro 6 phase.  If this objection had been adopted, we would have been faced with a situation in which cars currently circulating on the street in our cities and regions would have continued to emit according to the limits approved by laboratory tests, which in real terms, that is, in road driving conditions, are about 400-500% higher.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Commission has decided to raise the emission thresholds for new cars, including diesel. It was late October, just after the Volkswagen scandal. This has made many environmental NGOs cringe. In their desire to destroy European diesel know-how, the Greens have made it a divine mission to oppose this text and have put an objection to it. But what they forgot to say is that the Volkswagen scandal and the revision of the thresholds are two cases totally disconnected. The truth is that we have chosen to go for tests in real driving conditions as early as 2017, and no longer in the laboratory where emissions and consumption were automatically lower. I even asked for it in my CARS2020 report, as early as 2013. It is both a way to regain the confidence of motorists, as well as to meet our commitments to reduce vehicle pollution. But to achieve this, industrialists need legibility and stability in legislation to invest in less polluting technologies. This objection was rejected, a common sense.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having taken into account Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 June 2007, on the type-approval of motor vehicles with regard to emissions from passenger and commercial light vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and access to vehicle repair and maintenance information, the Commission has drawn up a new draft implementing measures with the aim of amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 by adapting the test procedures so that they adequately reflect the emissions generated by real road driving conditions.  However, because it considers that the Commission does not exceed its implementing powers, appearing to be the purpose and content of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007, in so far as the emission limits provided for therein are not called into question, I voted against this resolution which, pursuant to Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure, asks the Commission to withdraw its draft regulation and submit a new proposal by 1 April 2016.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of the objection to the European Commission's delegated act to increase tolerance for polluting emissions from cars. Indeed, Parliament could have vetoed the Commission's proposal to introduce a tolerance margin of 2.1 for nitrogen oxide emission thresholds. Unfortunately, this objection has not been voted on by the required majority, which I deplore, and the Commission's original proposal will therefore be implemented. But we must now look to the future and do everything possible to ensure that this margin is lowered as soon as possible to eventually reach 1, if possible as early as 2020. This is not only about respect for democracy and the European legislator, but also about air quality in Europe, a major health and environmental issue. The work is also far from finished with regard to real-world emissions tests (so-called RDE): now that the Commission's delegated act has been adopted, I will be particularly vigilant to the proper application of the RDE tests, a prerequisite for the effective entry into force of pollution standards.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On Wednesday, the European Parliament rejected an objection to an increase in the maximum limits on nitrogen oxides (NOx) emitted by diesel cars. I personally supported this objection, as I had already done in the vote in the Committee on the Environment last December. One can really talk about the Commission's resignation in the face of intense pressure from some Member States which, more sensitive to the interests of car manufacturers than to the health of millions of Europeans, proposed at a technical committee last October that they would exceed the Euro 6 emission thresholds by 110% in 2017 and then 50% from 2020 to the euro 6 emission thresholds, which they themselves negotiated with Parliament in 2007. It was precisely to reject this absurd initiative that Parliament had to decide: it finally failed 59 votes to reject this eminently political decision, which is difficult to understand, especially since it is in the wake of the scandal of rigged VW engines. Finally, it is the existence of the Euro 6 standard itself that is called into question: what is the point of a standard whose overtaking is allowed, worse, cast in bronze?

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. I am shocked by this vote of the European Parliament. European manufacturers have already had almost 10 years to adapt to the new standards for nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions since Parliament voted for them in 2007. They therefore have no excuse and parliament should have been uncompromising towards manufacturers who, unlike others, have not invested in high-performance technologies and sustainable jobs. The Commission's decision in committee clearly violated European law by allowing manufacturers to exceed the thresholds set by the NOx legislation by more than twice the thresholds set by the NOx legislation We environmentalists want to avoid respiratory problems for our fellow citizens rather than pampering the shareholders of car manufacturers as the majority of parliament has just decided.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the Commission's proposal introducing a compliance factor for new emission tests in real-life driving situations. The proposal authorizes a temporary overshoot of the legal emission limits - by 2.1 (over 110%) 2020 and 1.5 (50%) after that date - to take into account any initial failures of the new measurement device. This is already a marked improvement over the current situation, which is an overshoot of about 400%. In addition, the Commission provides for an annual review clause to reduce the second compliance factor to 1 by 2023 and has committed to activate it systematically. I would also like to point out that the vehicle registration system is currently under review. We will have a say in this and ensure that the monitoring and independence of controls are strengthened. Finally, I wanted to avoid the rejection of this text to ensure a rapid and realistic reduction in the levels of nitrogen oxide emissions currently emitted in real conditions.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As recent studies by independent bodies have shown and acknowledged by the Commission, NOx emissions currently exceed the limits set by up to five times. This situation cannot continue, with 75,000 premature deaths attributed to these emissions in Europe. The Socialists regret the lack of ambition of the proposal drawn up by the Commission and the Council, and we have been belligerent in demanding both of them an unequivocal commitment to set a date for compliance with the 80 mg/km limit. This requirement has been successful: the limits will be met by 2023. However, the proposed measure will already reduce emissions by less than half and make Europe the only region in the world with tests under real road conditions. Only by implementing these tests can we enforce the Regulations, protect the environment, protect health, provide guarantees to consumers, boost investment and employment in the sector and prevent any fraud with emissions in the future. A vote in favour of the objection would therefore have been a vote in favour of everything remaining the same, hence our abstention.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This objection by the European Parliament to block a decision by the European Commission to accept nitrogen oxide standards up to 110% higher than what European legislation (Euro 6 standard) allows, was unfortunately rejected this lunchtime. I deplore its rejection because it was in particular in response to pressure from the European Parliament following the Volkswagen scandal. The objection, made by the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, regarded the Commission's decision as illegal, a view which is further confirmed by the European Parliament's legal services and then by Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee. This decision was drawn up by experts from the Commission and the Member States. Noting that car manufacturers did not appear to be able to meet the Euro 6 nitrogen oxide emission standards, it allowed them to exceed these nitrogen oxide emission standards by 110% until 2019 and by 50% from January 2020.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it was necessary to veto the scandalous decision of the Representatives of the European Commission and the Member States, which increased by more than 100% the permissible emission limits for nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel engines. In principle, experts at technical level, rather than politicians elected in the Member States, have decided to rewrite European Union legislation. This is therefore seen by many as a break in the democratic decision-making process. It is a shame that a significant number of MEPs have nevertheless chosen the interests of the industry when voting and deciding what is more important than public health or the interests of the car industry.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the rejection of the Commission's draft regulation on emissions of passenger and commercial vehicles. The proposed regulation aims to raise the tolerance limit on nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions by diesel cars by up to 110%. In the context of Volkswagen's emissions fraud, such an upward reassessment of the thresholds for carcinogenic pollutants emitted is not acceptable. However, the majority of MEPs chose to reject this resolution on the grounds that the Commission's regulation provides for real-world testing on vehicles. A paradoxical decision that does not guarantee adequate protection of the health of Europeans.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the European Union every year and has a cost of around EUR 940 billion due to its harmful effects on public health. To curb the reality that these figures mirror, and in line with the EU's air quality objectives, a continuous effort to reduce vehicle emissions is needed. To this end, and in view of the need for trade marks to ensure at the time of type-approval and over the life of the vehicle that emissions produced do not exceed certain limit values, measures must be taken to ensure the effectiveness of vehicle emission control systems. To this end, the European Commission has proposed new implementing measures with the aim of amending the Regulation by adapting the test procedures so that they adequately reflect emissions generated under real conditions. Because proper regulation in this area is indispensable and urgent, I voted against this proposal of objection because I believe that the Commission's proposal to adapt the test procedures allows them to adequately reflect the emissions generated in real road driving conditions.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to reward the result achieved after a long and difficult mediation work, where all the interlocutors took a step in the direction of compromise. Parliament has thus managed not to reject the European Commission's proposal on the regulation transposing vehicle emissions tests from laboratory to road, which would, moreover, have blocked work for a further two years.  The tests must be truthful and adapted to the actual driving conditions. It is therefore unthinkable that they should achieve the same results and that emissions should have the same limits. That is why industries must be left time to improve their technology, without imposing unattainable limits. The commission's latest proposal introduces a review of compliance factors in more stringent stages, so as to push car manufacturers to constantly improve, and establishes more transparent and independent control systems.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the measures implemented by the European Commission in the RDE (real driving emissions) report to object to the 2.1 conformity factor and not to the RSDS procedure itself. The basic legislation was adopted in 2007 and published as Regulation No 692/2008 to set the emission limit at 80 mg/km. Now, with the new proposal, which introduces a compliance factor of 2.1, a surplus of 110% is allowed. This is inadmissible regardless of the recent scandal over failures in CO2 emission controls in the automotive sector (Volkswagen case). What the objection is intended to remove this preliminary proposal to increase emission levels and to present a new one by 1 April 2016 that respects emission limits.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I believe that the draft Commission implementing decision overshoots the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 715/2007.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution because it delays the faster mapping of actual car emissions in driving mode. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is committed to the rapid and realistic mapping of emissions actually caused during driving and wants to abolish measurements on the test bench.  The Commission's original proposal must therefore be accepted, because it will speed us up to better regulation of emissions actually caused by driving.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because this Regulation developed by the Commission exceeds the mandate of the delegation of powers granted in the basic act. Once again, the Commission uses the delegation of powers in favour of the interests of multinationals, in this case in clear collusion with the multinationals in the automotive sector, which has been affected by the Volkswagen scandal. This resolution rejects that regulation because it seeks to confating Parliament, legislating against the views of democratically elected institutions and therefore against the interests of European citizens. Precisely after the Volkswagen scandal it is the European peoples who must give their opinion on such requirements to the industry. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the introduction of new tests under real driving conditions (RDE), emissions from road vehicles will be as consistent as possible with those recorded so far during laboratory tests, with the aim of ensuring stricter application of existing regulations and curbing the dangerous increase in pollutant and particulate emissions. It is therefore of fundamental importance that the legislative process on RCE testing should not be delayed or even halted.  For this reason, I voted against the proposal for an objection which would have prevented the entry into force of the new procedure, causing delays in the implementation of emission control measures and actually achieving the opposite result to that hoped for in terms of improving air quality in the European Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I consider the automotive industry to be crucial for the Slovak economy. However, we must also take care to protect the environment. I therefore approve of the RDE proposal, which has been prepared for a long time and which is shared by representatives of the Slovak automotive industry.  I therefore consider it pointless to produce another document that introduces nonsensical standards that even the latest technologies cannot meet. In practice, these new standards could thus lead to a halt in the production of diesel cars. For this reason, I voted against this resolution when voting on the objection under Rule 106 as regards emissions of light passenger and commercial vehicles.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Diesel exhaust is among the main sources of nitrogen oxides that are one of the largest air pollutants . In addition to acting unfavorable to human health, causing cancer, asthma and numerous respiratory diseases, they are extremely devastating for the environment because they lead to eutrophication and acidification.  Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 715/2007 It was agreed to set a EURO 6 limit and to achieve limits that relate not only to the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions, but also to emissions of nitrogen oxides and PM (tiny solid soot particles resulting from the combustion process). Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 692/2008 requires manufacturers not to exceed the agreed exhaust emission values in any way when type-approval.  Given how the draft measure of the Technical Committee - Motor Vehicles (TCMV) introduced a "temporary conformity factor" of 2.1, 168 mg/km instead of the previous 80 mg/km (applicable to all vehicles as of September 2019), and a final requirement for a driving test with a 'final conformity factor' of 1.5 would apply to all new vehicles as of 2021, this would mean a deviation from the underlying limit values.  For these reasons, I supported the amendment to Regulation (EC) 692/2008, considering the Commission's draft implementing decision to exceed the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 100/2009. 715/2007.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Last year, some carmakers' fraud in listing emissions was detected, and it is therefore very important that you properly investigate this CO2 emissions scandal and, above all, that measures are taken to prevent carmakers from cheating and to protect consumers and the environment. The EU 2020 strategy has one of the measurable targets for reducing CO2 emissions, so I welcome the Commission's compromise proposal on measuring emissions from motor vehicles in real-world operation. In Slovakia, the automotive industry currently accounts for 44% of GDP and more than 200,000 jobs depend on car production, so I did not support envi's objection, as its approval could seriously damage the European automotive industry even with an impact on slovakia's economy. I consider the Commission's proposal sufficient to reduce CO2 emissions in the automotive industry and to protect the environment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Air pollution in the EU causes more than 430,000 premature deaths each year. The estimated cost of the health effects of pollution is EUR 940 billion per year.  Diesel emissions in urban areas in Europe are one of the main sources of nitrogen oxides. These, in turn, are one of the main air pollutants that cause lung cancer, asthma and many other respiratory diseases, among others, as well as environmental degradation.  The motion for a resolution concerns a draft Commission Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 as regards emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). Manufacturers should ensure, in accordance with the draft measure, that emissions resulting from type-approval and throughout the life of the vehicle do not exceed the limit values when testing hinge emissions.  The motion for a resolution states that the aforementioned draft Commission regulation would in fact constitute a general deviation from the applicable emission limit values and is thus not in line with EU law. I agree that the draft regulation is inappropriate and should be withdrawn. However, the new draft regulation, which should be submitted by 1.4. 2016, should include an hinge test to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems and allow vehicles to comply with Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. For the sake of the above, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although a majority was not achieved by a few votes, I voted in favour of the resolution recommending that the European Parliament veto the Commission's draft delegated act establishing the procedure for testing emissions from motor vehicles under real driving conditions (RDE). As a result, the text was unfortunately rejected by authorising a temporary increase in emission limits for vehicles under real driving conditions.  According to the European Commission, the measure would be justified by the need to consider technical doubts regarding the use of new portable emission measuring devices as well as technical limits for improving the performance, under real driving conditions, of emission detection for diesel vehicles currently produced. However, in view of the increase in air pollution and respiratory diseases resulting from it, I consider it a mistake and a lack of respect for citizens to fail in their commitments to protect the environment and human health. Today's vote shows that a large part of Parliament wants to meet the commitments made and will continue to follow closely future developments on emissions tests and the responses given by the Commission and Parliament.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 Environmental protection is very important to me. As the only representative of Slovakia on the European Parliament's committee of inquiry, I will advocate that producers strictly comply with the legislation and communicate their comments openly. First of all, there must be certainty that the consumer will receive the product with the declared characteristics for his money.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. The Commission is proposing a major overhaul of the European type-approval legal framework. Under current rules to monitor manufacturers' compliance with relevant EU rules and to confirm that a vehicle meets all marketing requirements, national authorities are solely responsible. The commission's new proposal will achieve more independent vehicle testing and greater control of vehicles already in circulation. Enhanced surveillance at European level will strengthen the system as a whole.  Even before the discovery of Volkswagen, the Commission had already started reviewing the EU legal framework for the type-approval of motor vehicles. In the meantime, it concluded that much more far-reaching reform is needed to prevent recurrences of non-compliance. The new proposal for a regulation on type-approval and market surveillance of motor vehicles complements the work on introducing more reliable emission tests. I rejected the objection, because in the time until the new regulations enter into force, the market needs to be regulated and we need existing regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs strongly support the swift introduction of Real Driving Emissions (RDE) testing so that emission tests for cars reflect pollution emitted on the road and not just in laboratories. The proposed draft Regulation will allow manufacturers to bring to the market vehicles emitting more than double the amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx) set by the Euro 6 emission standards agreed by the co-legislators in 2007. Furthermore, the figure of 1.5 contradicts the Commission’s own assessment of average PEMS error of measurement, which calculated a maximum conformity factor of 1.2. By changing the emission limit values enshrined in the Basic EU Regulation, the draft Regulation exceeds implementing powers provided for in the basic Euro 6 Regulation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The fact is that there are more than 430,000 premature deaths caused by air pollution in the Union every year and that the costs associated with the health impact of air pollution are estimated at €940 billion per year. According to a recent analysis of air pollution by the European Environment Agency, 75,000 premature deaths are attributed to NO2 emissions in Europe, with 93% of all overrun cases being in areas near roads.  In particular, a significant reduction in nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel vehicles is needed to improve air quality and meet limits for pollutants. Setting such measures to reduce early-stage nitrogen oxide emissions will allow for long-term planning certainty for the automotive industry across Europe. I do not support the objection, as the Commission's proposal is in line with the above.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the resolution on the draft Commission regulation amending the Regulation on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles. About 400,000 people die a year from air pollution. In many municipalities and towns, the relevant authorities have difficulties in implementing clean air measures. Clean air is the value of the European Union. It is therefore necessary to start at the source of harmful substances and these certainly include vehicles. A vote in favour of an objection to an act adopted by the Commission would significantly delay the conduct of the tests and it would therefore be irresponsible, both for the environment and for the automotive sector, to delay the implementation of these tests indefinitely. We want to strike a balance between protecting the health of our citizens and preserving the future of the European car industry.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of rejecting the objection to the compromise agreement on new rules for testing. The postponement of this Decision to increase emission limits for diesel vehicles for nitrogen oxides would only increase legal uncertainty for both manufacturers and approval authorities. Any delay in introducing this legislation would leave very little time for the necessary changes and would ultimately delay the desired positive effects on the environment.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this Parliament objection. Whilst I share some of the concerns it expresses, particularly the flexibility provided by a 2.1 conformity factor, I believe that these concerns must be dealt with in parallel to the approval of the RDE testing regime. I believe that the introduction of RDE tests for new cars as proposed here will bring clear reductions in NOx emissions and improve air quality; therefore it would not be the right response to delay the introduction of RDE testing by months or possibly even years.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the joint report to veto the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation which would result in a derogation from the Euro 6 NOx emission limits as defined by Commission Regulation (EC) No 692/2008). Today's vote gives the European Commission permission to adopt the second package for the procedure for testing emissions under real driving conditions and to go beyond the implementing powers laid down in the regulation. What has been the case up to now is that the Euro 6 limit value for NOx emissions from diesel vehicles is 80 mg/km. Under the new plan, car manufacturers will have to reach a "temporary compliance rate" that substantially raises pollutant emissions to 168 mg/km.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the devastating effects of air pollution annually, it calls on the Commission to withdraw this draft regulation and to submit a new plan without delay in order to introduce a real-world driving emission test for all vehicles in order to ensure the effectiveness of control systems.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been looking for years to solve the problem that vehicle emissions are much higher in real-world driving conditions than during laboratory testing. According to the latest calculations of the European Commission, the painful truth is that the emissions of euro 6 diesel engines currently produced on the roads are on average 400% higher than those measured on the test bench! The European Commission's draft implementing regulation is an important element in solving the problem, with the aim of reducing emissions as soon as possible in real-world conditions. From 2017 onwards, new vehicles may exceed the base value of 80 g/km as set out in the 2007 basic legislation by a maximum of 110% (cf multiplier 2.1) and by 50% (CF multiplier 1.5) from 2020. The reality picture represents a significant step forward in the regulation. Deadlines and targets appropriate to reality and technical possibilities provide predictability for the automotive industry. In addition, the new limit values foresk out real emission reductions, significantly mitigating health-environmental risks. In my opinion, the draft legislation strikes the right balance between environmental and public health objectives and preserving the competitiveness of domestic jobs and industry. I am convinced that a responsible decision-maker does not lay down rules based on dreamlike expectations. It would be irresponsible to insist on what has already been proven to be technically impractical over time. No one should be fooled into adopting irrealistic rules.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
