text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the objection to and the vote on the new rules on diesel car emissions to be an important item on the agenda. In addition to introducing real-world emission testing (RDE), the draft new rules will increase the 2007 nitrogen oxide emission limit for diesel cars by up to 110%. This package was approved by the EU Member States by a decision of the Committee on Technical Committee - Motor Vehicles on 28 October, in which the European Commission proposed a 110% increase in the nitrogen oxide emission limit value for motor vehicles for new models from September 2017 and from September 2019 for all new vehicles. By my vote, I supported the objection to the draft decision. In my opinion, the majority's non-support for the objection is a step backwards and is not correct. I think it is important to note that the European Parliament's committee on the environment has already decided that Parliament should veto the easing of the limit values because it undermines compliance with existing EU standards. I am sure that, in addition to the negative environmental and health aspects of this issue, it will also raise other technical problems, which I will take into account in my committee of inquiry into the diesel scandal.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We in the M5S voted in favour of the resolution which favoured the weakening of emission limits, thus vetoing measures to double emissions.  Instead, parliament overturned the vote of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy in December to veto the Commission document which allowed the emission limits for cars to be doubled until 2020. Previously Euro 6 cars could emit nitrogen oxides (NOx) for a limit of 80 mg/km. Now, however, thanks to the Commission document, Euro 6 cars will be able to emit 168 mg/km of NOx until 2020 while remaining in good standing.  The car lobbies have managed to win this battle by making Parliament believe that, if the rejection had passed, it would mean the end of the car manufacturers and therefore the loss of many jobs. It is clearly a scam: cars exported to the USA manage to meet limits of half of those in force in the EU. This is because they are the same limits that were introduced in 2007 to allow car manufacturers time to comply. It is clear that the multinationals wanted to break the rules, rather than invest in innovation to reduce polluting emissions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the objection with respect to emissions from passenger and light commercial vehicles. We cannot accept the Commission's proposal, which finally allowed pollution until 2021 and which deformed the European Parliament's positions in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament rejected a resolution objecting to a compromise on testing of car emissions and demanding a greater say in the EU’s decision-making process on this issue. The resolution was motivated mainly by efforts to limit air pollution from car emissions, namely by introducing a narrower margin for testing emissions on the road. While I believe that stricter rules for car emissions testing should apply, I am however convinced that approval of the resolution would put the entire process into question, create uncertainty for car-making industry and citizens by prolong the process of introducing stricter norms in real driving conditions with very uncertain outcome. Therefore, I decided to vote against this resolution.  Now I however expect the car industry to embrace the new rules and work with us to improve car emissions testing. Car producers had a long time to do something about this situation, and it is now time they start taking this issue very seriously. I expect the revision clause to be used in 2017 in order to introduce an even stricter conformity factor within just a very limited period of time.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. With the "Volkswagen scandal" erupting a few months ago, the European Parliament reacted decisively with a commission of inquiry and an unambiguous condemnation of the frauds orchestrated by the German manufacturer, concealing the actual emissions of its vehicles. Yet, during this session, the right, by its vote, gave in to the motor manufacturers' lobby at the expense of the health of the citizens.  By voting against the objection of the left and the environmentalists, these MEPs approved the European Commission's proposal to create a right to pollute more. Emissions of nitrogen oxides - fine particles shown to be carcinogenic - may exceed legal emissions in the laboratory by 110% under real-world conditions. Public health justifies our refusal to create a right to pollute more and more. Even if industrial activity remains decisive, it must adapt to respect both health and the environment. You can count on me to continue to fight to preserve air quality.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against complaints about light passenger and commercial vehicle (Euro 6) emissions, as I believe emissions problems must be addressed in accordance with RDE. In view of the data manipulation and recent events that have rocked the German car manufacturer, I believe that RDE testing will ensure the control of real driving emissions and thus contribute to a clear reduction of harmful gases and the improvement of air quality.  Since I believe that conducting such tests will reduce emissions and at the same time improve air quality, I believe that such objections must not risk further delaying the achievement of the target of reducing vehicle emissions.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i rejected the motion for a resolution on the article 106 objection to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). I strongly support the need to achieve the EU's air quality objectives. This is why it is necessary to make sustained efforts to reduce emissions from vehicles, to establish standards and to better control this area.  I support the progress and measurement of emissions while driving, as this will only show real results. Currently, however, the results are obtained according to measurements in the laboratory, which is why they are not realistic. The motion for a resolution is superficial, I think we could work it out even further and thus actually help improve the air.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the appeal. I consider the decision of my colleagues to be unnecessary and very wrong. At least of all, the car industry now needs uncertainty and decision-making. The initial agreement of the Member States was hard enough. Parliament's excessive aggressiveness does not solve anything and is more likely to hurt the situation. This will mean delays and, ultimately, probably even tougher demands on the automotive industry. Meanwhile, the European Commission has already partially complied with the demands set out in the statement of err, presenting revised legislation last week tightening the supervision of testing facilities.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution follows the Volkswagen scandal. The latter consisted of the revelation of considerable discrepancies between emissions of pollutants in the laboratory and in real driving conditions for Volkswagen diesel engines. The Commission's exacting standards for pollutant emissions do not yet require such tests. The limit values set out in a regulation in 2007 are reviewed by internal procedures within the Commission: the requirement of this motion for a resolution is therefore to request a new regulation, to be submitted by 1 April 2016, to impose tests in real condition as soon as possible. These requirements are questionable for two reasons: Europe becomes the least industry-friendly region of the world; technical standards are a cataplasm on a wooden leg in action to combat air pollution, as the EU also encourages more and more the flows that generate these emissions. This text is therefore a unilateral requirement of political ecology at the sole expense of European industry, with serious consequences for a sector in crisis. So I'm voting against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the EU each year and the estimated costs of its health effects amount to EUR 940 billion per year. Since nitrogen oxides (NOx) are among the main contaminants and cause lung cancer, asthma and a number of respiratory diseases, they are also responsible for cases of environmental damage. According to the draft measure, manufacturers should ensure that emissions from a real-world driving emission test during type-approval and throughout the vehicle life cycle do not exceed certain 'non-exceedable (NTE) emission limit values'. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the objection to the measures implemented by the European Commission in the RDE (real driving emissions) report to object to the 2.1 conformity factor and not to the RSDS procedure itself. The basic legislation was adopted in 2007 and published as Regulation No 692/2008 to set the emission limit at 80 mg/km. Now, with the new proposal, which introduces a compliance factor of 2.1, a surplus of 110% is allowed. This is inadmissible regardless of the recent scandal over failures in CO2 emission controls in the automotive sector (Volkswagen case). What the objection is intended to remove this preliminary proposal to increase emission levels and to present a new one by 1 April 2016 that respects emission limits.

name: Владимир Уручев (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted to reject the opposition to the new real-world emissions tests, which, if adopted, would lead to a several-year delay in the decision to reduce emissions from cars, given the Volkswagen diesel car scandal.  We now have a clear commitment from the EC to revise the requirements with a specific time frame to reduce the maximum emission limit values to the approved levels. The Commission is also further committed to a legislative proposal for a long-term solution to renew the car approval regime.  I welcome the responsible decision reached in plenary to continue the procedure for assessing real-world emissions and reducing emissions of nitrogen oxides, which are currently 4-5 times above official limits. Today's vote paved the way for the introduction of the vehicle emissions test package approved by the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles, which will be introduced in two stages: first, reducing the emission gap to a "compliance factor" of 2.1 (110%) for new models from September 2017 (and for new cars from September 2019); secondly, achieving a conformity ratio of 1.5 (50%) 2020 for all new models (and by 2021 for all new cars).

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection because I am against the plan to temporarily raise the NOx emissions limits for diesel cars. The recent Volkswagen scandal has shown how car manufacturers produce vehicles which pollute way more than they declare, and I believe that this practice has to be put to an end as quickly as possible. This is why I think that temporarily raising the emissions limits does not follow a clear, reasonable logic. Nevertheless, this objection was rejected as the EU Commission has promised a review clause and tabled a long-term legislative proposal to revamp the EU car approval regime. I sincerely hope that the Commission will effectively tackle this issue in a reasonable timeframe.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I very much regret that this week the European Parliament approved this watering down of the rules on car emissions. This is first and foremost bad news for our public health and our cities. It is also a slap in the face for European consumers. For too long, the European car industry has thought that everything should be allowed, and we are now legalising its cheating. I find this completely unacceptable. Unfortunately, as a Democrat, I have to accept the outcome of the vote on this objection, even though I strongly disagree with it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the wake of the pollution test fraud scandal in the automotive sector, which is the main issue of the German carmaker Volkswagen, the European Commission has proposed a draft regulation to raise existing greenhouse gas emission standards for light vehicles.  Manufacturers have until 2020 to comply with the new legal standards for nitrogen oxide emissions, adopted in 2007, and during this period, to be approved, cars are allowed to emit up to 2 times more nitrogen oxide (NOx) than the future legal standard. Not content with not punishing car manufacturers, who have had almost 10 years to bring themselves up to standard, the European Commission even intends to reward them for their bad practices in this area. This so-called resolution of objection tabled by my group, alongside the Greens and the groups S and D, ALDE and EFDD intended to oppose this proposed regulation and asked the Commission to review its copy by 1 April 2016, I obviously voted in favour. I regret that a majority on the right of the European Parliament, led by FN MEPs, voted against this resolution, which was rejected, thus favouring the interests of the car industry.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After a meeting with the Technical Committee on Motor Vehicles on 28/10/2015, the Commission has drawn up a proposal for a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 with regard to emissions of pollutants from passenger and commercial light vehicles.  This resolution opposes the adoption of the commission's draft resolution, as what the committee proposes would result in the derogation from the NOx emission limit values provided for in Euro 6. It also exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the Regulation. The resolution therefore calls for the proposal for a regulation to be withdrawn and for a new one to be submitted without delay which provides for real emission testing and that it is in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 715/2007.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Commission's draft provides legal uncertainty for vehicle manufacturers, as the current calculation allows for a margin of uncertainty of up to 30%. This is also at the expense of consumers. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on objections under Article 106 of the CRP on emissions from light passenger cars and commercial vehicles (Euro 6). Germany is and should remain a leader in diesel technology. The new test regulations will better reconcile the test procedure with reality. Nevertheless, I object to the draft regulation that has been tabled. I am not concerned with the question of whether the draft takes sufficient account of environmental concerns or whether it serves the interests of industry too much. Rather, it is a question of the procedure as such, which is non-transparent and driven by self-interest. It turns out that it is difficult to legislate objectively when national industrial interests are concerned. The EU should have no competence here, because it is being used as a vehicle to harm Germany's car industry – better than in this case.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution which strengthens the EU institutional framework and which is set for the smooth functioning of industry in line with our decisions and the 2020 Environment Strategy.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am fully in favour of the automotive sector reducing its emissions of polluting gases into the atmosphere and I am aware of the urgent need for this to happen. However, I reject the objection, as I believe it is the only way for new controls under real conditions to be established and, therefore, the only way for emissions into the atmosphere to start to shrink as soon as possible. In addition, these reductions have to be made compatible with the maintenance of our industry in Europe. I therefore firmly believe that my position strikes a balance between the protection of human health and the prosperity of the car industry.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the objection of the ENVI Committee, which called for the submission of a new, stricter proposal for an implementing decision by the Commission in connection with the introduction of so-called real driving emission testing. The introduction of so-called real driving emission testing is an important step both in reducing environmental pollution and in preventive action against a repeat of the Volkswagen scandal. I believe that the introduction of an additional test to the original laboratory tests, which will measure emissions under real conditions, is an ideal and ambitious means of doing so. On the other hand, however, I believe that these measures should not be too ambitious. In fact, unrealistic requirements would only result in a situation where the automotive industry, which also considers the introduction of the test to be beneficial, would not be able to adapt the new strict requirements in a timely manner and develop new technologies, which would ultimately be counterproductive. I also think that the requirement to withdraw the proposal and submit a new one, as contained in this objection, could ultimately cause the introduction of the test to be disproportionately postponed, as it cannot be assumed that a new proposal would be tabled in the short term.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of discrepancies in the results of diesel passenger car emissions tests in laboratory conditions and during daily use has caused a huge storm in both Europe and the USA. The lack of adequate tools to capture fraud and abuse in the approval process for new car models has caused a scandal, which will be explained by the European Parliament.  The adoption of this objection will only lead to a delay in the introduction of the obligation to test cars under real driving conditions. This delay not only does not necessarily bring better solutions, but it can cause further abuse of car companies. The proposed standard allowing diesel cars to exceed the laboratory emissions of nitrogen oxides by 2.1 times in normal operation by 2017 and to achieve full compliance of emissions measured both in the laboratory and in real terms seems reasonable in 2020. This regulation also provides for some flexibility and an annual review of the proposed standards in order to better match the existing law with the actions and efforts undertaken by the automotive industry. However, when deciding to adopt the proposed standards, we must bear in mind that concern for the environment must not mean ignoring economic factors, including the functioning of such an important industry for the European economy and labour market as the automotive industry.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution setting out an objection under Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure to the draft resolution amending Regulation (EC) No 692/2008 on emissions of passenger and commercial light vehicles, because I believe that the Commission has exceeded its powers in the process and as a sign of disagreement with the Council's recent conduct in this regard. I stress, however, the evolution of the European Commission's position on real driving testing and the application of factor 1 of conformity by 2023, and I hope that we can continue to work on a path that guarantees the confidence and competitiveness of the European automotive industry and safeguards the health of citizens and the preservation of the environment.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. With the introduction of the new exhaust measuring instruments, almost all vehicles would have been in danger of being outlawed. The Member States have solved this problem by establishing changes that would parify the emission limits with those measured in the traditional way by the exhaust pipe. Having lower limits would have been irretrievable economic damage for car manufacturers' lobbies. The resolution recommended that the European Parliament veto the European Commission's draft establishing, from 2017, new procedures for the approval and control of emissions on the road using portable detectors. This would have allowed the car industry to adapt to the parameters over a reasonable period of time.  In the meantime, the cars would have been free to pollute twice the limits allowed today. But who can assure us that more restrictive measures will be taken in a year's time?  I voted in favour of this resolution because the least polluting technology already exists and has been on the car market for a long time. There is a lack of courage to take ambitious political decisions that go against the lobbies of car manufacturers.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - I did not support the European Parliament resolution because I do not believe that the proposal for a regulation is yet complete and would not contribute to a significant reduction in air pollution. We need concrete measures, such as better implementation of current legislation and effective control over the implementation of it, not another political gesture.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, with today’s resolution on the TiSA negotiations we are calling on the Commission to change course in these negotiations. This was not an endorsement of a TiSA agreement. Any TiSA agreement must help, rather than weaken, the re-regulation of global trade in services. Citizens have a voice in the European Union and that voice is in this House, the democratically-elected European Parliament. Rather than exercise their powers with responsibility to get results for citizens, some MEPs have chosen to act irresponsibly just to get their press release. The public should not be fooled by this appalling attitude. We have to stand for fair trade and take our responsibilities in acting for it in this House.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I, like my entire group, voted against this resolution for a fundamental reason. What we intend to do through the TiSA agreement is the transformation into a market, the transformation into a profit, of what are fundamental public services such as education and health care. We believe that the issue of the commons, the co-management of the commons and the democratic management of the commons should instead be at the heart of Europe's future. We believe that all the Treaties – TTIP, TiSA, CETA – are leading to a process of deregulation, to the expropriation of the sovereignty of citizens who are not informed and who are gradually being deprived of room for decisions about their future. We have voted against TTIP, we have voted against the TiSA and we are calling for the voice of millions of citizens who have already expressed their opposition to it to be heard.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we are often told during the British referendum debate that EU membership is necessary for our service sector. Yet here we are in this Chamber discussing a free-trade deal on services that, as well as the European Union, brings together 22 other members of the WTO, from Australia and Israel to Korea and Peru. The difference is that, while Norway and Switzerland will be represented separately in those talks at the WTO, the United Kingdom, like every other Member State of the EU, will be represented by one 28th of a European Commissioner. For a country that is so dependent on the service sector, that seems to me a disadvantaged position. We could do far better in the world if we were to rediscover our place as a maritime trading nation with a global vocation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I voted today on the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement. It is a single agreement in history by its size, its depth and the broad framework of countries it includes, countries around the world, including the European Union.  This resolution recommends that the Commission open doors for businesses in the European Union to also help these companies enter the public procurement, telecommunications, financial and professional markets and also to ensure that the best highly qualified professionals are able to work outside the European Union. Reducing red tape is also part of these recommendations. The problem, however, is that, apart from that, each country must ensure its own entry into the services market and not rely on what the European Commission is doing.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Services Treaty, the TiSA, is a bomb that must be defused. So far, thanks to Wikileaks, we've seen only a few of the secret documents, but what little we've seen already paints the end of public health and the disappearance of net neutrality and many other nasty surprises. That is why we could not remain indifferent and we worked the text we voted on today. It is important to understand one thing: the tisa signature is far away and today the 5 Star Movement did not say yes to the TiSA, but said yes to a certain type of mandate for the TiSA negotiators. A mandate that says loud and clear that public services are not affected, that there must be no irreversible privatisations and that citizens' rights come before free trade. The text is a compromise and it is certainly not perfect, but it is important not to give the negotiators carte blanche, because we would only play into the game of lobbies and strong powers. We will follow the negotiations closely and be on our guard because no treaty comes before the citizens.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all we must remember that the TiSA Agreement is reforming, or updating, gatt. The world has changed and trade has changed and e-commerce has become involved. It must also be remembered if you have read this text that public services are outside. Member States will continue to have the right to regulate which services are public services and as far as education or health care is concerned. They're outside of this agreement. Now that the EU is negotiating with twenty-two other WTO member states, some have raised the issue of certain countries. It would probably be appropriate not only to raise Chile and Costa Rica, but to say that there is Australia, there is Canada, there is New Zealand, there is Norway, there is Switzerland. All countries that are very important trading partners to us. It is also very good that trade in services is being extended through this to those countries that are our natural partners and, of course, to other countries. It is worth remembering that the European Union is the largest provider of services in the world. In this regard, I believe that, now updated, the agreement will increase our employment and our economic growth. If I have understood correctly, this Parliament wants economic growth for Europe. We want more work and more jobs. This is one possibility when it is used correctly. With these limitations, which is what is in this area, I believe that we can move forward safely through this.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the TiSA represents an opportunity to consolidate Europe's position as the world's largest exporter of services, since the latter employ 70% of the European Union's workforce and account for 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe. The agreement could stimulate the creation of employment in the European Union by facilitating the internationalisation of SMEs by removing the non-tariff barriers that still affect the sector. Although the TiSA represents a strategically important framework agreement on market access, digital economy, mobility, financial services and logistics, it suffers from its very nature as a plurilateral and therefore partial act. Consequently, its vocation to become a multilateral agreement within the framework of the WTO must be stimulated by the correct application of the general principles of trade policy. Finally, I believe it is essential that the outcome of the negotiations, in addition to real achieving the uneaded potential of a more integrated services market at world level, should be able to avoid social, environmental and economic dumping and to ensure full respect for the European Union acquis.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Colleagues, i would like to take the The Trade in Services Agreement is a global potential agreement on liberalisation in international trade in services – banking, health, transport, several others. The European Union and the US are the main proponors of this agreement, and more than that, the G7 countries are a supporter. In particular, the European Parliament noted the need for the effect of the agreement to cover the maximum number of people and to have a positive impact on job creation and inclusive growth. I would like to point out, in particular, colleagues, the recommendation on the transparency of international roaming, as well as the need to exclude public services – cultural and audiovisual services – from tisa negotiations, with the aim, for example, of guaranteeing the preservation of cultural heritage, especially in the new countries, and I am very positive about this decision.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The report concerns a multilateral agreement on international trade in services. This agreement threatens EU standards and jobs for services, public services for EU citizens and the right of Member States to regulate. I have therefore unequivocally rejected this new step towards globalisation. The union's leadership's task is not to open up new markets for multinationals, partly at the expense of developing countries and weaker EU countries, but to protect eu citizens and jobs and help developing countries to generate their own needs and services and not flood Europe. For this reason, I rejected the proposal.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am quite fascinated by how some of my colleagues say their minute and then walk away and do not know the facts at all. I do not know of any example of a state that, if it fences, will increase its employment, increase its GDP productivity. With all due respect to the previous speaker, Europe is indeed a major service provider, perhaps 40% of our GDP that we provide, and it is our competitive advantage. Liberalising this space is in our life's interest. It will undoubtedly increase employment. Our aim should be to liberalise this environment as well and, of course, to protect what is important. These public services are excluded from this liberalisation under international agreements and we can continue to protect them. For me, for example, it was important that municipalities and their jurisdiction would not be discriminated against in any way by this agreement. We are at the beginning, we should complete this negotiation, this is only a mandate for this negotiation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm a rá gur vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar a rinne mo chomhghleacaithe chomh maith, agus a rinne 531 Feisire eile. Is mór an móramh é sin agus dá bhrí sin tá moladh mór tuillte ag an rapóirtéir, mo chomharsa anseo, Viviane Reding, as an dea-jab a rinne sí. Deireann sí go caithfimid rialacha náisiúnta a threisiú, agus aontaím leis seo. We can now push towards liberalising trade and services between parties and, furthermore, look to eventually making the agreement part of the World Trade Organisation rule book. That would be good. As the world’s largest importer and exporter of services, the EU can benefit immeasurably from supporting and constructing a solid regulatory foundation from international trade in services. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé soiléir go gcabhróidh na moltaí seo chun an aidhm seo a bhaint amach agus chun níos mó jabanna a chothú san Aontas.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for Amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We of the 5 Star Movement are strongly opposed to the TiSa. Having said that, it is important to point out that the M5S did not say yes to the TiSA, but said yes to a certain type of mandate for the TiSA negotiators.  In particular, with the amendments adopted, it has been made clear that essential public services, which guarantee the fundamental rights of European citizens, such as health, the environment, instructions and cultural services, are untouchable. The European Commission will be obliged to negotiate transparently with other countries and through positive lists, that is, by publicly declaring which services to liberalise. Furthermore, there can be no irreversible privatisation. The text thus adopted actually makes it difficult to approve it in the future. I voted in favour because I consider it extremely dangerous to give the negotiators carte blanche.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Tim Aker and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended.  However, UKIP MEPs voted for Amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato, and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the Plural Left, we have positioned ourselves from the outset against different trade agreements, such as TTE or AECG, with which democratic power is being undermined to be handed over to large corporations. This report supports the ACS negotiations, a service trade agreement being negotiated by twenty-three countries, including tax havens, such as Switzerland, and non-signatory countries to ILO agreements, such as the United States. In addition, services are encouraged to remain in the hands of large international corporations, encouraging privatization and complete liberalization of services. The report gives its approval to the privatization of postal services, so far public in the Spanish State. The report also endorses that councils are removed from the capacity to remunicipalize, or that criteria such as gender equality or job creation be taken into account during the negotiation of the Agreement. It should also be noted that we voted an endorsement of the negotiations when we do not know the content of the negotiations, as they take place in no secret and we have only been aware of their existence thanks to the wikileaks revelations. For all this, we find it impossible to support the report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with the negotiations of the Trade Services Agreement (TISA or ACS). The purpose of this agreement is to promote international trade in services and to create international regulation of these services. However, the aim of this text, among other things, is to make it appear that these international standards can be created while retaining the right to regulate or that allowing Europeans' personal data to circulate is possible while protecting them. Moreover, in the name of the borderless market, this treaty would have serious consequences on the sovereignty of States.  Deeply opposed to the establishment of this treaty, which is a real danger to French public services and French businesses, I voted against this text.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, which essentially endorses the EU’s trade and liberalisation strategy. Sinn Féin believes the negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement – currently being negotiated between the EU, the US and 23 other countries – should be suspended. The TiSA will create an international legal regime which aims to deregulate and privatise the supply of services. Our concerns about TiSA include: the lack of transparency; workers’ rights; and the accelerated privatisation of public services. Of particular concern is the impact that TiSA may have on the financial services sector. From what we have seen in leaked negotiation texts published by Wikileaks last year, TiSA may require states to stop and reverse the financial regulation measures put in place in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis. It is clear from the leaked TiSA Annex on Financial Services that TiSA’s extreme deregulation agenda would apply to virtually the entire financial sector.  Governments would be forced to deregulate banking, derivatives, insurance, stocks and bonds, foreign exchange, credit cards, financial data processing, credit-rating and other financial services. If a state refuses to conform to TiSA rules it would face trade sanctions. That is a recipe for disaster.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on negotiations on the agreement on trade in services as I believe that the rules governing world trade need to be modernised and updated, but not at all costs. Transparency of negotiations, the right to maintain privacy within the data stream, the prevention of social dumping are just some of the issues protected by this report

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the TiSA resolution because, despite the positive declarations of intent contained therein, clauses are included that would make it more difficult for our children to take corrective action in the event of possible fears (so-called blocking and standstill clauses). In general, the free trade agreements (similar to CETA and TTIP) should place the arguments for and against each other more in relation to each other: on the one hand, the potential jobs to be won (pro) and, on the other hand, the possible loss of quality, price increases and non-investment (contra), which must not be equated in the debates. The European legislator should analyse in detail past liberalisations and privatisations on what was originally promised and what actually happened afterwards, in order to enable the political decision-makers to make the best possible decision-making in the interests of the citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Wanting to establish a free trade agreement, like the TAFTA (Transatlantic Free Trade Treaty) and the TPP (Trans-Pacific Free Trade Treaty), TiSA deals more specifically with services. At the moment it is at the negotiating stage and includes the EU, the United States, Norway, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea and Pakistan. The stated objective is to establish global standards on trade in services and a broad free trade area. In reality, it is mainly a question of dismantling part of national public services by putting them in competition with private service industries. Being, together with my colleagues of the National Front, absolutely opposed to this world without economic borders that allows multinational companies to dictate their law to the states, and ultimately to the peoples, I naturally voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the EFDD amendments to TISA which aimed, inter alia, to protect public services from the agreement. I do not feel that the report went far enough in some areas to protect public services and consumers, but I do support the overall tone of the report which highlights concerns that need to be addressed. I felt that to vote in favour might signify acceptance that certain amendments had not passed, and might be perceived as supporting a common position. I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In the process of negotiations, ACS (TISA) is a free trade treaty and "global standards" on trade in services, comprising nothing less than the EU, USA, Norway, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel, Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea Pakistan. The aim is to break down barriers to trade in all services. The agreement therefore aims to prevent governments from implementing regulations if they impede the activities and profits of the major service industries. Public services will thus be put in competition with private services with the exception of the regal powers that are: justice, the army, the police, diplomacy. Fundamental services such as health, education or water are considered economic services, and are likely to be open to the market. Public services will be put in competition with services provided by private companies in the same niche and will therefore gradually be "dismantled" as is today the public rail service with SNCF. To say nothing of the lack of protections of private data.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission for the remaining negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (ACS) because Members of the European Parliament have managed to establish sufficiently ambitious and coherent levels of demand, limitations and transparency.  It is essential to leave public services outside this agreement and to ensure that European data protection laws are not compromised.  This report contains the main lines that Parliament recommends to the Commission. They are not binding but are essential for the final fruit of this Agreement, once the negotiation is concluded, to be approved by this Parliament.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Reding report on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). The agreement, currently being negotiated in Geneva, involves 23 WTO countries plus the EU, including 70% of the world's services sector. This is a fundamental process because the Eu ropean Union is the world's largest importer and exporter of services and shows a particular interest in creating sound international legislation for international trade in services.  I believe that the report presented to Parliament effectively emphasises the need to ensure greater reciprocity in market access, to ensure a level playing field at global level and to offer concrete benefits to consumers. The future multilateralisation of the Treaty must therefore be facilitated while keeping public and cultural services, the right to regulate, fundamental data privacy rights and those relating to working conditions out of the negotiations.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report because, despite considerable progress on the original report and the current negotiating conditions, it remains contrary to the interests of the citizens of the signatory countries and, moreover, the developing countries that are excluded from the Agreement. We are not prepared to vote in favour of an agreement that promotes liberalization of services and free trade in areas which include sectors which are very sensitive to well-being and development. This would be an anti-common sense movement in a context where we are still going through the consequences of a crisis largely caused by liberalization.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have obviously strongly opposed this report, which gives recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TISA). As a reminder, this agreement, which mainly concerns the United States and the EU negotiating on behalf of the Member States, aims to reduce barriers in the services market - "barriers" being the term chosen voluntarily as pejorative, but which in reality refers to genuine protective standards. Once again, in the name of the borderless market and the interests of the all-powerful multinationals, the report thus advocates, for example, savage competition in the telecoms sector, which, as we know, would be at the expense of European industries and consumers, particularly in France. TISA is also a real danger to French public services and French companies and that is why it is scandalous that states have no latitude in these negotiations which risk precariously at the expense of all sectors such as education or health. Once again, the logic of the market seems to take precedence over the well-being of citizens and that is why the ENF group called during this vote for an immediate halt to the negotiations around TISA.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that tisa, the negotiation of trade in the services sector, could seriously damage the European production system, causing the loss of regulatory autonomy by the Member States and the EU, as well as undefined liberalisation and privatisation and constraints of services, with unacceptable consequences for consumers and workers. That is why I did not support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has provided Parliament with a list of recommendations to the Commission on what should be provided for in this Agreement, in the light of the ongoing negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA). Parliament believes that any trade agreement should give European consumers more rights and lower prices, create more jobs and ensure the protection of workers. Any EU trade agreement must open up foreign markets for our businesses and create a safety net for EU citizens. The TiSA agreement must thus increase the accessibility of foreign markets, promote best practices and shape globalisation in order to ensure that it reflects EU values, principles and interests and helps EU businesses to thrive in global value chains. In Parliament's view, consumer rights and social and environmental standards are not barriers to trade, but a non-negotiable basis for a European strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, and therefore the objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion must always be respected in EU trade policy.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the negotiations on the Service Trade Agreement (TiSA), which has just been adopted, is called the Own Initiative Report (INI). Accordingly, it is not legally binding and does not require legislation. In line with the assessment of the situation of the FIDESZ-KDNP delegation, I will form my own position in the light of the full text.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. In a sensitive area such as the TISA agreement, the Rapporteur has produced a good and balanced report. With it, Parliament sent a clear message to the negotiators on what to look out for, and we demanded all the transparency of the negotiations. Telecommunications, transport, infrastructure services are a good part of the global economy, and the world is being digitised more accelerated. The 23 members of the WTO are involved in the negotiations. The EU, as one of them, has a lot to gain from the agreement, of course, if the negotiators pay sufficient attention to the most sensitive areas. I myself have also pointed out the rights of workers and the prevention of social dumping, the maintenance of a high level of consumer rights, the protection of personal data and, of course, the most important – public services. The latter must remain 'public' to all and must not be completely left to market circumstances, as it can quickly be the case that it will be short-pulled by the weakest layer of the population. Nowadays, I hear a lot of general opposition to the agreement, especially from an ideological point of view, even though the negotiations are still actively ongoing. But the world is moving forward, we can be on this train of progress and we can work with our proposals and practices, or we can stay behind. The EU cannot afford this as an economic superpower, which is why I supported the recommendations to the negotiators. I will, however, keep a close eye on what will be my final support for the agreement.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) represents an important growth opportunity for the European economy and that the EU must use this opportunity to achieve reciprocity conditions favourable to European businesses.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Trade in Services Agreement (SHA) is a free trade treaty that aims to significantly reduce tariffs on services and harmonize global standards. The main danger of this agreement is the competition of public services, carried out in the public interest, with private services which meet a duty of profitability. With the exception of the regal powers, namely the judiciary, the police and the army, education, health or water, for example, will be concerned. Although the Member States of the Union will benefit from the harmonisation of tariffs insofar as those we set are far below the other signatory countries, the deregulation of public services will be extremely harmful to the most vulnerable among us who will not have enough money to finance their children's school or to pay for social security. We are absolutely not fooled by the so-called red lines that the Commission is not supposed to cross because the European Soviet Union, which destroys national identities and jobs, does nothing to meet the demands and needs of the big multinationals.  That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 TiSA represents an opportunity for the EU to strengthen its position as the world's leading exporter of services, and the framework in which negotiations take place, in order to benefit from success, must be at a high level of transparency, dialogue and accountability. Any trade agreement must offer more rights and lower prices for European consumers, more jobs and a higher level of protection for workers and many other advantages which are easier to pursue when there are more actors involved, pursuing the same objectives beneficial to the Union. In order to achieve a balanced agreement and respect the fundamental treaties of the Union, the Commission must take into account the position of the European Parliament, which plays a decisive role in EU trade policy, and i therefore welcome the call for up-to-date and complete information on the negotiations. Furthermore, I believe that Member States should be encouraged to get involved and consult national parliaments, as well as local and regional authorities, informing them on an ongoing basis of the progress of the negotiations. I support Parliament's recommendations and the opinions of the committees involved, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. The TiSA is a draft agreement under negotiation between 23 wto players. In my opinion, the INTA committee's resolution is negative. It is a text which, although it contains positive references to the risks arising from these negotiations, maintains a favourable attitude towards a possible agreement. That is why the Lega Nord can only confirm in plenary the negative vote in committee. The TiSA is – together with TTIP (USA) and CETA (Canada) – one of the major dossiers that, in the field of international trade, could cause enormous damage to our production system in the coming years. In my opinion, however, a multilateral agreement on such a sensitive issue as services is a risk that is in no way worth taking. Many of the issues also known to TTIP come into play: Member States (and the EU itself) would lose regulatory autonomy and a process of indiscriminate liberalisation and privatisation (and above all not managed by national and regional parliaments) could cause serious risks for both consumers and workers themselves.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted its position on the international trade in services agreement. The agreement is negotiated by 24 parties, including Canada, the United States, Japan and the European Union. Together, they account for 70% of the world's trade in services. The EU is the world's largest exporter of services. This agreement will benefit businesses that will be able to export services more easily. This will generate growth and jobs. Parliament reiterated the importance of preserving European economic, social and environmental standards in these negotiations. Some services such as audio-visual, health and water should be excluded from this agreement. We must also be sure of a total reciprocity of our partners. We have to be in the win-win. If we open our borders to trade in services, we must be sure that each party follows the same rules in fair competition. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted against the Resolution containing the European Parliament's recommendations on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (ACS) for a number of reasons, but above all because I believe that Parliament needs to send a clear and informed message about the importance of international trade and the need to end barriers to trade and protectionism in order to achieve a more integrated Europe , with greater growth and progress. The importance of trade in services is growing, as this is a crucial driver for job creation. This Agreement must increase access to foreign markets, but Europe cannot impose its rules and values on countries, nor introduce protectionist, destructive and very unsyarial factors. Paragraphs such as point (d)(i) of paragraph 1 undermine free movement, which I consider essential. I do not agree, inter alia, that one of the parties is allowed to leave the Agreement. The automatic exclusion of public services should be reviewed: no one guarantees that a service will be better, more efficient and safe for consumers just because it is provided by the State.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it contains many excellent suggestions for the Commission regarding the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) negotiations. The agreement in itself provides many new opportunities in terms of access to foreign markets and reduction of obstacles to trade on the international arena which is bound to result in growth and creation of jobs. This agreement is to cover a large proportion of world trade services and therefore contributes to the setting of new world standards.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eu ropean Union's trade policy is the sole responsibility of the EU. If the European Commission negotiates the agreements on behalf of the EU under WTO rules, the European Parliament must be fully informed at all stages of the procedure and still have the final say. If the M5S delegation voted in favour of the Reding report, it is because clear and clear recommendations must be made to the European Commission.  Today, we have not voted in favour of the TiSA – we are still halfway through the procedure – but of a clear mandate to the European Commission, which aims, among other things, to protect the interests of citizens and prevent the dismantling of public services.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The interests of our citizens and consumers, especially the most vulnerable, must be brought to negotiating table. We cannot allow public services to be further exposed to trade and competition rules and push the limits of the markets because international players are missing out on profits. Health, education or social security are not just intangible commodities. Their provision is essential for the fulfilment of our people’s fundamental rights as citizens and social cohesion. This cannot become a backdoor for social dumping either. Services provided in Europe must be performed by workers who enjoy the standards of protection afforded by European law. I would have liked to see a new Council mandate that constrains the freedom of the Commission trade teams. But Parliament made it clear that we cannot just give free reign to the Commission’s free market Midas touch.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Services are a leading sector for the Union economy. Europe is the world's largest exporter of services, holding 25% of the global market. However, there are still many barriers, especially non-tariff barriers, which slow down the internationalisation of SMEs and prevent them from having access to new markets. Since 1995, with the spread of the Internet, the economy has changed and services continue to become increasingly important in international economies; This is all the more reason to regulate and ensure greater reciprocity in market access, ensuring global equality and fairness in working conditions. The TiSA will have to lead to an ambitious level of opening up the services market to SMEs. Parliament is right, however, to call for public and cultural services and also fundamental rights to data privacy to be excluded. Today's vote, which I fully support, is not a judgment on the agreement or the signing of the agreement itself, but on all the clear recommendations that the European Parliament has made and which the Commission will have to take into account during the negotiations. Respect for working conditions and the environment is one of the main criteria that should guide the definition of the TiSA.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and the rapporteur's position, which stresses that in the TISA negotiations we need to ensure greater reciprocity in terms of market access, create a level playing field, offer tangible benefits to consumers and provide stakeholders with access to the talks in order to facilitate future multilateralisation.  We stress that public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data protection and fair working conditions, as well as the right to regulation, are non-negotiable and should be explicitly excluded from the scope of the agreement.  The European Parliament must work in a constructive and realistic way to give a positive character, clarify and prioritise the TiSA negotiations in order to ensure that a good agreement is concluded in the interests of European businesses and consumers.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We discussed today the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the agreement on trade in services, as this is an important issue on which we must turn our attention.  From the preparatory procedures up to today's vote, we have expressed our opposition to the negotiations in the services sector and, of course, our vote against could only be a sign of consistency in our positions.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe in the importance of Parliament's decisive role in EU trade policy. The rapporteur intends to evaluate the first two and a half years and thirteen rounds of negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and to draw up clear and sound recommendations for the Commission. The TiSA negotiations are aimed at ensuring greater reciprocity in market access, ensuring a level playing field globally, delivering concrete benefits to consumers and allowing stakeholders access to the talks. However, public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data confidentiality and fair working conditions, as well as the right to regulate, are non-negotiable and should be unequivocally excluded from the scope of the agreement.  The European Parliament must work constructively and pragmatically to give a positive image of the TiSA negotiations to ensure that a good agreement is concluded, in the interests of both European businesses and consumers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am in favour of harmonising trading conditions, especially when it can lead to benefits for consumers and businesses in my country.  In this case, I believe that Italy has an advantage from facilitating the exchange of services, because, for example, with the rule of reciprocity in procurement, the skill of our companies can more easily triumph over the mediocrity of others, while consumers are better protected, for example, thanks to the greater rules on e-commerce. I very much hope that the other WTO countries that have not signed this agreement at the moment will also come to an agreement soon.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ 23 members of the World Trade Organisation (including the EU) are currently negotiating the Trade in Services Agreement. The services sector accounts for the world’s largest employer, and produces 70% of global gross domestic product. The agreement aspires to open up markets and improve rules in areas such as financial services, maritime transport, telecoms and licensing. The EU is the world’s largest exporter of services, therefore opening the market for services will encourage growth and create jobs. Consumer rights, along with social and environmental standards should not be seen as trade barriers but non-negotiable building blocks of the Europe 2020 strategy for growth. The TiSA has the potential to address fundamental barriers to trade in services across the globe. The agreement can improve issues such as limited movement of data across borders, unfair competition from state-owned enterprises and lack of transparency.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Trade in Services (TISA) is a trade agreement that is being negotiated between 23 members of the World Trade Organization with the aim of liberalising trade in services between participants. In the light of the Treaties, the European Parliament does not have the negotiating power, but has the power to express its opinion during the negotiation process with a view to influencing its development, which results in this report and the final agreement cannot enter into force without the approval of the European Parliament and the Member States. I support Mrs Reding's report because I believe that TISA is an opportunity for the EU to consolidate its position as the world's largest exporter of services while providing European consumers with more lower rights and prices, more jobs and economic growth in the EU, reducing a number of non-tariff barriers that exist today in cross-border services and disproportionately affecting small and medium-sized enterprises. I welcome the exclusion of public and audiovisual services from the Agreement and i welcome the importance of data protection and respect for privacy requirements.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because this service agreement will make it easier for our companies to access international markets. As with any other agreement, we will only end up agreeing to the agreement if there is no interference with our high standards of protection, whether in consumer, labour and environmental protection or in data protection. This also applies to public services.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TiSA agreement is particularly important in the union's current strategy, which is becoming a skilled negotiater of trade agreements on several tables at the same time.  This agreement is an evolution of TRIPS, since it concerns the liberalisation of services, with the aim of multilaterally improving trade in this sector in order to implement the level of trade. The partners designated were selected by the Commission on the basis of the criterion of making the most of this agreement by all the actors involved.  I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, which contains recommendations to the Commission so that the Commission can make further positive progress as the negotiations progress.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s role in trade policy is very important as it streamlines issues related to trade policies from a holistic angle. However Member States retain a final say on trade agreements.  The current report assesses the work so far carried out on the Trade in Services Agreements and makes recommendations to the European Commission on how to steer these negotiations towards common goals and targets.   Amongst these proposals is that to create a global level playing field and ensuring more reciprocity in market access. It is very important to ensure that SMEs and consumers are provided with the best opportunities that safeguard their opportunities to access the market by seeking measures to do away with obstacles.  I have voted in favour of this report as it contains proposals which take into account both the interests of European companies and of consumers.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to assess the first two and a half years and thirteen rounds of negotiations on trade in services (TiSA) and to make clear and clear recommendations to the European Commission. The TISA negotiations must ensure greater reciprocity in access to services markets (telecommunications, transport, financial services, energy), create a global level playing field (including on the procurement market), deliver tangible benefits for consumers and ensure future multilateralisation of the agreement.  The report is not perfect, but it says loud and clear that public services are not affected, that there must be no irreversible privatisations and that citizens' rights come before free trade. Services must be negotiated through positive lists (i.e. by declaring which services will be liberalised) and local authorities must be given the freedom to decide in future to suspend liberalisation in certain sectors.  The tisa signature is far away and today the M5S did not say yes to the TiSA, it said yes to a certain type of mandate for the TiSA negotiators. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the Plural Left, we have positioned ourselves from the outset against different trade agreements, such as TTE or AECG, with which democratic power is being undermined to be handed over to large corporations. This report supports the ACS negotiations, a service trade agreement being negotiated by twenty-three countries, including tax havens, such as Switzerland, and non-signatory countries to ILO agreements, such as the United States. In addition, services are encouraged to remain in the hands of large international corporations, encouraging privatization and complete liberalization of services. The report gives its approval to the privatization of postal services, so far public in the Spanish State. The report also endorses that councils are removed from the capacity to remunicipalize, or that criteria such as gender equality or job creation be taken into account during the negotiation of the Agreement. It should also be noted that we voted an endorsement of the negotiations when we do not know the content of the negotiations, as they take place in no secret and we have only been aware of their existence thanks to the wikileaks revelations. For all this, we find it impossible to support the report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade in services is a driving force for employment and growth in the EU and I consider the multilateral agreement on trade in services that the Commission is negotiating an opportunity to update the existing rules dating back to 1995 and to close the regulatory gaps that are currently being used to the detriment of workers and citizens.  The adoption of the European Parliament resolution gives a clear mandate to the Commission to negotiate an agreement that consolidates the EU's position as the largest exporter of services and at the same time favours European businesses, guarantees higher rights and lower prices for European consumers, more jobs and greater protections for workers and promotes sustainable development.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – According to Article 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Parliament not only plays a decisive role in the adoption of trade agreements, but parliament must also be informed promptly and fully at all stages of the procedure for negotiating trade agreements. According to the opinion expressed in the report, the TiSA negotiations should ensure increased reciprocating in terms of market access, a level playing field at global level and tangible benefits for consumers. Furthermore, interested parties should be able to access the negotiations. Public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data protection and decent working conditions and the right to regulation should not be the subject of negotiations and should be clearly excluded from the scope of the agreement. An important element is the libe commission's proposal that the agreement guarantees full respect for fundamental EU legal standards by inserting a human rights clause with legally binding and deferred effect, which is a permanent part of the EU's agreements with third countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With this report the European Parliament is laying down its position on the essential elements that it feels should be included in the upcoming Trade in Services Agreement.
