I voted in favour of this report as it called for the exemption of public services from the agreement, workers’ rights safeguards, high data protection standards and the right to regulate to be included as key principles of the agreement. By ensuring that these key issues are highlighted before the negotiations start, Parliament is giving a clear message about the level of standards it expects from such an agreement – and for this reason I supported the rapporteur’s position.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and many of the recommendations contained within it. If successfully concluded, the Trade in Services Agreement, covering as it does partners accounting for 70% of global trade in services, will be a fantastic tool for reform, and bring the trade in services rules into the digital age. We need to ensure that in negotiations the Commission seeks ambitious market access openings for EU companies in public procurement, telecoms, transport, and financial and professional services, while ensuring that any movement of people to provide services remains without prejudice to the right of Member States to manage and legislate concerning access to their labour markets and determine their rules concerning the immigration of natural persons. This will create many more trading opportunities for SMEs as well as boosting access for consumers.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has sought to define clear boundaries for the action of negotiators engaged in dealing with the TiSA, a new agreement that according to a study published on parliament's own website should be "a more effective vehicle for wider liberalisations". TiSA is even more liberalising than TTIP. But we know that behind the word 'liberalisations' are privatisations that generally coincide with a real assault on excellence and public assets. Liberalisations in services through the TiSA can hide pitfalls and dangers for citizens, for employment, for health. Just think of what happened with the creation of multiutilities in the early 2000s in Italy: the private sector swallowed up the public and chased the profit for its own benefit, with consequent decline in the quality of the services provided and with a surge in prices and tariffs.  The vote on the report is therefore a vote not to leave the negotiators unfazed, clearly indicating the limits within which they will have to operate, to safeguard public services and to ensure that any steps backwards in relation to privatisations are contemplated. In other words, it is a necessary vote to protect the citizens.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As was the case with the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Treaty with the US, the European Parliament today gave clear recommendations to the Commission on the ongoing negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). The report makes it clear that the tisa's objective must be to regulate international trade in services, taking due account of the effects of the digital revolution on this sector, with a particular focus on the implications for consumers and workers. We therefore wanted the report to clearly express our 'no' to an agreement without protection, but at the same time to recognise that without clear and effective regulation there can be no protection for citizens. We also want this Treaty, the negotiations of which are progressing between 23 countries, to be concluded in full compliance and consistency with the rules established at multilateral level, so that it can in future include as many states as possible: it is in multilateral for a such as the WTO that we can reach ambitious agreements, which have the merit of leading to ever fairer trade and equal rules for all. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the negotiations on the agreement on trade in services.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the recommendations of the European Parliament as part of the negotiations for the International Trade in Services Agreement (ACS or TiSa in English). The agreement brings together 24 parties (including the EU) and represents one third of WTO members, as well as 70% of world trade in services. While the revision of the WTO's General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) has stalled, due in part to the blockade of the BRICs (Brazil, Russia, India, China), pro-trade-enhancing states began negotiations on an ACS in 2013. The European Commission is in charge of the negotiations on behalf of the Union and its 28 members. We call on the European Commission to exclude public and audiovisual services from liberalisation and guarantees on consumer rights and labour standards. Finally, we believe that more transparency and better access for European companies to public procurement in third countries is needed. Considering that this agreement can open up new markets to stimulate our economy and our SMEs and must preserve our public and audiovisual services, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Through this vote, the European Parliament has set out strong guidelines for the European Commission to continue negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS). The Trade in Services Agreement is to strengthen international rules and increase market opening in services such as digital, financial and transport services. I felt that it was particularly necessary to ensure that the conclusion of this trade agreement actually promotes growth and jobs in Europe and contributes to the competitiveness of our businesses. In this context, it is of course essential to pay special attention to SMEs.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because I believe we need an ambitious agreement on Trade in Services. Services are an ever-growing part of our economy, and using the potential of more easily providing services in these third countries can considerably strengthen the various European services sectors. I also want to stress the importance of fair market access and rules for the digital economy stressing the openness of internet governance.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a process of discontinuous and fragmented globalisation, the European Union needs to have a long-term vision not only of the international markets of which it is a fundamental player but above all in understanding the social and political scenarios interconnected with them.  Today, the value chain has taken on a global scale and allowed a sharp reduction in costs for many European companies, but from the data it seems that only part of europe's heterogeneous business scenario has managed to overcome this global challenge, there are numerous cases instead of companies that have failed to relocate advantageously compared to these new scenarios.  The European Union should have an adequate set of measures to meet the challenge of these negotiations with a positive contribution for Europe as a whole. It is also important to remember the price of this negotiation as far as negotiation is concerned and often the denial of rights both within the EU and in companies outside its borders make up its value chain.  Parliament must be the pragmatic spokesman for all social, environmental and political bodies in order to make Europe as a whole and in its heterogeneity meet this challenge.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This European Parliament resolution is a clear message to the Commission in charge of negotiating the agreement on the European Union.  The main objective of this agreement is to remove certain barriers to trade, on average for an additional 50% cost on the products of European exporting companies. The Trade in Services Agreement must help to defend and better protect European businesses abroad and support the internationalisation of SMEs.  It must also allow for greater reciprocity in market access, with some of our trading partners and WTO member states having very protective and exclusive legislation. In this sense, it is important that the European Union adopts a 'European Business Act', modelled on the 'American Business Act', to give EU companies priority over the Community market, where necessary.    At the same time, it is important that states can continue to protect public health, education or audiovisual services. That is why the Commission is not allowed to make commitments on these matters.  It is on the basis of respect for all the recommendations made in this resolution that our Parliament will ratify, or not, the TiSA agreement.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on TiSA that has just been adopted is called an own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will make its own position in the light of the full text.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. The less well-known TISA than TTIP - which provides for greater liberalization of trade in services by updating the existing multilateral framework and adapting it to the context of the digital revolution - is no less dangerous. Its content is negotiated in the greatest opacity. The report adopted in the European Parliament on Wednesday 3 February sets out a number of red lines and protection barriers. TISA cannot encourage tax evasion, social dumping or weakening of labour standards. Personal data must be protected, while public and cultural services must be excluded from this agreement. On the question of public services, I had pushed this strict exclusionary position through the "public services" intergroup. I regret, however, that we have not been able to find ourselves on the need for positive lists, more protective than negative lists. The Commission must now hear this vote from European elected representatives. If this were not the case, Parliament has a veto and may object as a last resort to the adoption by this assembly of the final agreement to be submitted to it.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the recommendations made by the European Parliament under the agreement currently being negotiated between 23 WTO members. In principle and in general, I am in favour of liberalising trade in services. It is in our interest to seek to increase opportunities for European companies to provide services such as transport and telecommunications in third countries. The negotiations around this agreement do not cause me any problem. At this stage of the procedure, however, I believe it is essential to recall the need to ensure that this agreement will not prevent the EU and the authorities of the Member States from legislating in the public interest, particularly with regard to labour rights and data protection. I do not want TISA to jeopardize our public services, our culture, our labour laws, our environmental standards, the protection of our consumers and our data. For me, neither TISA, nor TTIP, nor any trade agreement should infringe our sovereign right to set our own standards. If that were to be the case, I would not approve of this agreement.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The TISA Treaty, in the name of the principle of free trade and international trade in services, is to eliminate what is left of state regulation. By its provisions, public services will be put in competition with private services, with the exception of the regal powers (justice, army, police, diplomacy). While the protection of personal data is at risk of being undermined by the increasing exchange of information, public services could be dismantled, like that of rail in France. Refusing the proliferation of good intentions, behind which there are disastrous consequences, as on the issue of the transatlantic treaty, I chose to protect French public services and businesses, by opposing this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support this report because it not only called on the EC to seek a more active solution for opportunities for better access to markets for EU companies and professionals, but also calls on the EC to ensure that other barriers to trade based on nationality are no longer allowed. It is extremely important that the EC does not miss the key priorities, but takes care that EU companies and professionals are not behind potential opportunities, such as trade deals. We must increase consumers' access to markets such as public procurement, telecommunications, transport, financial and professional services, and ensure that our highly qualified professionals can work outside the EU without undue obstacles. Moreover, when it comes to legislation or managing the movement of people in general, this is within the competence of the Member States and this report also explicitly calls for this. I also support the fact that, as the report makes clear, EU public services will not be part of the negotiations, and that EU data protection rules will not be affected, especially given the important trade negotiations and internal market issues.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report on the TiSA agreement, given that this agreement compromises EU service standards, employment (including quality jobs), public services for EU citizens and the right of Member States to regulate.;

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report on TiSA that has just been adopted is called an own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will make its own position in the light of the full text.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on the Trade in Services Agreement because it does not deal with the major concerns about the negotiations. The resolution does contain some positive points – namely the demand to exclude all public services and services of general interest (for example, healthcare and water) from the negotiations. It is very important to my constituents in Wales that protection of public services is guaranteed. I will continue to work for this.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The TISA Treaty aims at deregulation and market sharing in favour of large companies and multinationals.  The conclusion of the agreement would lead to the liberalisation of around 90% of the services market, such as banking and finance, the labour market, health, education, scientific research, postal services, air and sea transport, waste collection, construction, telecommunications. The agreement could have a huge impact on essential services. With this report, although it is not perfect, the European Parliament has laid down strict conditions for the Treaty. It has made it very clear that public services are not affected, that there must be no irreversible privatisations and that citizens' rights come before free trade. Services must be negotiated through positive lists (i.e. by declaring which services will be liberalised) and local authorities must be given the freedom to decide to suspend liberalisation in certain sectors.  The tisa signature is far away and today the M5S did not say yes to the TiSA, it said yes to a certain type of mandate for the TiSA negotiators. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 More opportunities need to be ensured for European businesses in foreign markets, the exclusion of public services, the protection of labour rights and the right to legislate in the public interest. If the European Parliament's recommendations are respected, the TiSA will guarantee more rights to citizens inside and remove barriers to businesses outside. It is therefore necessary for the European Commission to ensure that the agreement creates a level playing field in the services sector and opens up new markets for EU service providers in areas such as telecommunications, transport and public procurement.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am opposed to the conclusion of the Trade and Services Agreement.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is very important that the European Parliament keeps a close eye on what is happening in the context of the negotiations on trade in services (TISA), which is currently taking place in Geneva. We have always denounced the risks behind these negotiations, which are no less dangerous than TTIP. We cannot give in to certain fundamental principles for the protection of citizens and the European production system: public and cultural services, fundamental rights to privacy, fair working conditions, among others, are non-negotiable issues that must be excluded from any future agreement.  We agree with the recommendations made by the European Parliament, and in particular with the recognition of the right of Member States and local authorities to regulate the opening up or non-opening of their services. On the other hand, we believe that the negotiations should be regulated by means of positive lists, that is to say, by clearly stating which services will be liberalised.  Finally, it is extremely important that local authorities should be able freely to decide to suspend certain liberalisations in order to cope with possible economic conditions or national strategic choices. For these reasons, while appreciating the balanced content of the resolution, I declare my vote in favour of it.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA), as well as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement (TTIP) and the Canada-European Union Global Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), are part of a strategy with an unprecedented scope of global trade deregulation and liberalisation and the commodification of essential public services. TiSA covers sectors as diverse as telecommunications and e-commerce, financial services and insurance, transport and even health services. On the sidelines of any democratic scrutiny and the involvement of governments in this process, it intends to impose a complex tangle of norms and rules, designed to overcome state constraints and disempower any national parliamentary control. As with other agreements, such as TTIP, the whole negotiation process has been developing in the utmost secrecy. In essence, this agreement represents another violent attack on national sovereignties, public services and a policy of development and well-being of the people.  This report, negotiated between the right and social democracy, underlies the TiSA and the negotiations that have been taking place, even if, as is customary, it seeks to deceive unwary and alleviate some bad consciences by proposing measures mitigating the negative effects that have already been endeared. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution because I believe it is bad for Irish Citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The further expansion of the sector is also linked to the repeatedly stressed need to support the digital economy. We hear very often about the importance of technological and market innovation for sustainable economic growth. Europe maintains its position as a leader in this area. Under no circumstances may this status be jeopardising her position. The possible conclusion of a new trade agreement should be conditional on the clear consolidation of the European Union's position as the most important global exporter of services. In addition to the EU, more than 20 countries are involved in the TiSA negotiations. Their markets mean more than 2/3 of the current global trade in services. At the same time, the European Union already has mutual ties in this area with several of them. The agreement must thus contain concrete potential for further progress. Otherwise, it has no relevance to the European Union. It must bring more employment, more rights and lower prices for European consumers. At the same time, it is essential to define clear boundaries in which it can no longer intervene under any circumstances. This applies in particular to public services, cultural services, the right to data protection or fair working conditions.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because this agreement could cause enormous damage to our production system in the coming years, also causing the Member States to lose regulatory autonomy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA) , as this agreement compromises EU service standards, employment (including quality jobs), public services for EU citizens and the right of Member States to regulate.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have been working as shadow rapporteur for the DEVE opinion on TiSA and I believe our opinion sent a strong message to our colleagues in the INTA Committee, clarifying the fact that the impact of the trade and services agreements on developing countries has to be taken into account and, consequently, calling for impact assessments on developing countries by the Commission. This is fundamental in order to ensure that the principle of policy coherence is respected. We urged the Commission to continue to increase transparency and democratic accountability, and to increase accessibility to all public consolidated negotiation documents, as this is the way by which concerned civil society and citizens, including of developing countries, can be informed and involved in the process. The possibility that developing countries join the agreement cannot be excluded, and, in such cases, the approach has to be flexible, in order to ensure that their access to the global service market is fair. In a multilateral framework, the criteria for admission of developing countries cannot be the same as the ones for developed countries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on TiSA that has just been adopted is called an own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will make its own position in the light of the full text.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Any trade agreement should give European consumers more rights and lower prices, and workers more jobs and protection, contribute globally to promoting sustainable development and global CSR, and ensure a level playing field for European companies. On the basis of the above, I am convinced that trade policy must be fully in line with and contribute to the implementation of the ILO's Decent Work Agenda and the UN Sustainable Development Programme 2030.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conviction that the ACS negotiations can ensure greater reciprocity in market access, create globally equitable conditions of competition and bring tangible benefits to consumers. However, public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data privacy and fair working conditions, as well as the right to legislate are non-negotiable and must be unequivocally excluded from the scope of the Agreement. From the European Parliament we must work constructively to achieve a good agreement in the interests of European businesses and consumers.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The trade agreement on trade in services, currently being negotiated between 23 most developed countries and known as "TiSA", could provide an excellent opportunity for European companies to provide services, especially in transport and telecommunications. Like the Free Trade Treaty with the United States (TTIP), I believe it is essential to have the public interest as a point of reference also in order to avoid exploitation and false fears. In Europe we have labour laws as well as state-of-the-art environmental and phytosanitary standards and it is therefore right not to dilute them for commercial reasons; It is equally important, however, that opportunities for economic growth and business development are not penalised for false pretexts or unfounded fears.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I believe that promoting the liberalisation of trade in services by updating the rules of the existing directive is not only a necessary operation, but an absolutely urgent and priority objective of the European agenda. That is why I believe with conviction that the proposal for the approval of the TiSA, which, involving 23 countries, accounts for about 70% of world trade in services, should be supported and promoted. What is at stake is the opening up of our market to the future, the strengthening of European leadership in the sector, a strong boost to growth, new job opportunities and wider and easier access to foreign markets.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on recommendations to the European Commission, which negotiates on behalf of the EU the agreements on the liberalisation of trade in services (TiSA) under way in Geneva concerning a plurilateral agreement involving 50 members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), because I believe that the EU is today one of the most important exporters and importers of services at the same time.  Consequently, I support the need to update and improve the rules in force on services in the field of international trade, as they have an important impact on employment. I fully share the group's view that there is a need for rules adapted to changing reality; I therefore trust in the EC's commitment to conduct these negotiations in port, but taking into account the recommendations made to it and that the EP will not accept any agreement. I fully agreed with the need to exclude public services and audiovisual services from the agreement, the need to go beyond gats rules with regard to financial services and the inclusion of the review clause. However, the text voted on today must be seen as a means of influencing the EC, and in no way can the ep's final position be taken into account, nor that of the S&D Group.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), as I do not fully support the agreement in this form.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The TiSA provides an opportunity for the Community to strengthen its position as the world's largest exporter of services with a global service market share of 25% and a positive trade balance of EUR 170 billion in 2013. The report adopted today was intended to assess the first two and a half years and thirteen rounds of negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). Of the initial 16 stakeholders, the agreement was extended to 24 parties, including the EU, which in turn represents 28 countries. A total of 51 countries will participate in the agreement: 32 in Europe, 7 in Asia, 10 in the Americas and 2 in Oceania. The aim of the agreement is to liberalise international trade in services such as banking, healthcare and transport. Services account for 75% of the value of the economy in the US, in the European Union – similarly. Eu exports of services have doubled in the last ten years to EUR 728 billion in 2014. In addition, 70% of the EU workforce, which produces 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe, works in the services sector. The agreement is able to further stimulate job creation in the EU. It is estimated that 90% of the new posts to be created in the EU by 2025 will be created in the services sector.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The services sector has the highest number of employees globally. Further liberalisation of existing restrictions would benefit the EU states, as the world's largest exporter of services. At the same time, however, many other states. Pioneering work can be done here, particularly in the area of fair, cross-border competition. Nevertheless, existing standards of protection are non-negotiable.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which covers key aspects on trade in services, including extensive safeguards for workers. It is clear that global rules on the trade in services are in need of an update, and I believe this report goes some way to addressing that.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report containing the Recommendations of the European Parliament to the Commission on the negotiations of the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS).  This agreement aims to amplify the liberalisation of services in all sectors. Designed in principle to win markets in third countries, its main purpose is to level international standards down, drawing in particular on U.S. standards.  In fact, the European Commission, in order to liberalise the market, continues to precipitate the opening of borders and the privatisation of public services, weakening environmental social standards. This imperative erases all others and leads Europe to open its borders ever more without real reciprocity. Even if the report is reassuring and protective, the European Commission is not obliged to follow the recommendations it advocates. In fact, to protect our jobs and public services, the ENF Group is calling for a halt to the ACS negotiations.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against Mrs Reding's report. Reding said in a recent interview that the TiSA treaty would not be used to open up European markets, but to make others less closed. But, Mrs Reding, our markets are already the most open in the world, the least protected from unfair competition, especially our public procurement. And unlike you, I do not accuse other countries of imposing constraints to protect their interests, I reproach the European Union for never doing so, in the name of blind belief in 'happy globalisation'. But globalization is not happy, except for a handful of ultra-privileged people. You offer interesting "red lines." But having to comply with the WTO General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), TiSA cannot be more restrictive. On the contrary, in the face of stalled negotiations in Geneva, TiSA aims to circumvent the difficulty to go even further, first at 23 and then at the global level. In the GATS, however, there is mode 4, that is, a global Bolkenstein directive! In addition, I wonder about the link between TiSA and the transatlantic agreement. It seems to me that we talk about the same things, but not quite in the same terms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite considerable progress on the original report and the current negotiating conditions, it remains contrary to the interests of the citizens of the signatory countries and, moreover, the developing countries that are excluded from the Agreement.  We are not prepared to vote in favour of an agreement that promotes liberalization of services and free trade in areas which include sectors which are very sensitive to well-being and development. This would be an anti-common sense movement in a context where we are still going through the consequences of a crisis largely caused by liberalization.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report as a proactive approach is needed to increase the transparency of the European Union's trade policies. Strengthening the TiSA Agreement requires effective cooperation between the EU and democratic international bodies, taking into account the needs of civil society. Sustained efforts to improve transparency in EU trade agreements are imperative for achieving the sustainable development goals, for the interests of European companies and European consumers, but also for maintaining the stability of financial markets. The importance of the TiSA agreement for Member States is to facilitate job creation, as the European Union is the main provider of services, with tens of millions of service jobs, in the European area. Enabling these services to be exported to other countries will help expand the labour market, which will have a positive impact on the development of the European Union. At the same time, allowing non-European companies access to the EU services market will broaden the range of options and reduce prices for companies and customers in equal measure.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the TiSA report which includes the full exclusion of all public services; strong safeguards for workers; a new binding clause to guarantee data privacy; and greater transparency. Trade in services is vital for the UK and the current rules are grossly outdated, as there was virtually no internet trade back in 1995. So the status quo is not an option: we absolutely need reform, but not at the cost of workers’ rights, and not at the expense of our public services, especially the NHS. The trade in services is a significant and growing part of the EU economy. Creating a level playing field and opening global markets to European service providers is long overdue and crucial to the protection and promotion of jobs in the European Union.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union is the world's largest exporter of services. Services employ 70% of the working population and account for 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe. The opening of markets could therefore represent new opportunities, in terms of growth and employment. The European Union therefore seems to need TISA. This treaty could be an opportunity to put in place better international regulation. However, TISA could be the source of multiple threats. That is why I have spoken in favour of this report, stressing the need to draw red lines which the Commission should not cross. It needs to show greater transparency in the negotiations. In addition, I believe that public and audiovisual services should be completely excluded from the agreement. Personal data must be protected and measures to combat social dumping need to be provided. TISA, left in the hands of the Commission, could take an ultra-liberal turn. It must not impose greater deregulation or financial deregulation that would threaten the rights of workers and consumers. It is now up to the Commission to take these recommendations into account.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support an ambitious TiSA because it will help ensure reciprocity for European companies, large and small, in other markets and benefitting European consumers and workers. However, safeguards are necessary for TiSA, and I support the following recommendations: TiSA must strengthen the global rules-based trading system and encourage reciprocal market access, thereby opening new markets for EU companies, large and small; TiSA must contain safeguards for sensitive areas (audio-visual and public services, data protection and Mode 4); wherever possible, new countries should be motivated to join the negotiations, to work towards multilateralisation of TiSA; and in TiSA, as in all trade negotiations, there needs to be transparency, as well as stakeholder and citizen engagement.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the Trade in Services Agreement now adopted is called own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will shape its final position in the light of the full legal text.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The attitude of the Left both within Parliament and outside, but also the attitude of trade unions, social movements and other social actors is clearly against TiSA, as it was against TTIR. The reasons, as in TTIR, are that the liberalisation of services will start the process of reallocating capital and work to the provision of services for the benefit of increasingly large companies, wages will be pushed down, and collective agreements will be dissolved with negative effects on workers' insurance. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Services are a large sector in the EU and Germany, which accounts for an ever-increasing share of value added. The importance of services for international trade is correspondingly high. International trade creates the possibility of raising absolute and comparative cost advantages that benefit the consumer. TiSA is a multilateral free trade agreement for services that fits into the WTO trade order as a "building block". I would like to support this process in a positive way and call for the most comprehensive free trade agreement possible.  This report makes this demand without jeopardising public services of general interest. Accordingly, I voted in favour of this report and hope that negotiations will proceed swiftly.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report. The trade in services is a significant and growing part of the EU economy. We need to create a level playing field for this and opening global markets to European service providers is crucial for the protection and promotion of jobs in the European Union. The Trade in Services Agreement is an opportunity not only to boost our economy but to update trade rules for the benefit of all and to close loopholes which allow workers to be exploited. Preventing social dumping and ensuring strict data protection is vital as e-commerce grows. Labour MEPs are also very clear about the need for transparency in all trade agreements.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 A trade agreement aimed at liberalising international trade in services is important for the European Union. I would like to thank Commissioner Malmström for the fact that the EU's negotiating positions are public. Yet transparency is not at the same level in the TiSA negotiations as in the TTIP negotiations. Of the Members of the European Parliament, only members of the INTA Committee can see the negotiating positions of all countries.  All trade agreement negotiations must be at least the same transparency as the TTIP negotiations. All Members of this House should have the right to be informed of the progress of the negotiations in the same way as in the TTIP negotiations.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution with recommendations from the European Parliament to the Commission for Trade in Services Negotiations (TiSA) on the basis that TiSA must strengthen the global rules-based trading system and foster mutual market access and therefore open new markets for small and large European businesses and businesses. TiSA must also provide safeguards for sensitive areas such as audiovisual and public services, data protection and Mode 4.  On the other hand, it is good to encourage new countries to join the negotiations to contribute to the multilateralisation of TiSA. As in other trade negotiations, including in TiSA, the principle of transparency and civic engagement are key to the consistent development of negotiations.  I support this report and believe that TiSA can make a significant contribution to European consumers and workers.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Wanting to establish a free trade agreement, like the TAFTA (Transatlantic Free Trade Treaty) and the TPP (Trans-Pacific Free Trade Treaty), TiSA deals more specifically with services. At the moment it is at the negotiating stage and includes the EU, the United States, Norway, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea and Pakistan. The stated objective is to establish global standards on trade in services and a broad free trade area. In reality, it is mainly a question of dismantling part of national public services by putting them in competition with private service industries. Being, together with my colleagues of the National Front, absolutely opposed to this world without economic borders that allows multinational companies to dictate their law to the states, and ultimately to the peoples, I naturally voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Negotiations for a Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), under way since April 2013, aim at establishing international minimum rules for trade in sectors such as financial, digital and transport services between 23 WTO members – EU included, accounting for 70% of global trade in services. These rules will facilitate and liberalise their trade in services. This report defines the European Parliament priorities for the European Commission’s mandate for negotiation. Through this report, we made it clear to that these negotiations should deliver a deal that TiSA should afford more rights to our citizens at home and remove some obstacles to our companies abroad. If the final agreement does not reflect the European Parliament’s priorities, we have the right to veto the text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Viviane Reding's report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations of the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS). This new Trade in Services Agreement (ACS) brings together 24 parties, which account for 70% of world trade in services. The overall objectives of this agreement are to facilitate market access and strengthen international rules in several areas, such as financial and digital services and transport services. This agreement aims to address the difficulties that lie a way in the WTO and improve the current agreement dating back to 1995. Nevertheless, we have adopted blue and red lines to ensure that the future agreement is a source of growth for the European Union. Otherwise I will reject the outcome of the negotiations.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has made a number of recommendations to the Commission regarding its negotiations with the US on the Trade in Services Agreement (SHA). In particular, the report calls for many advances in market access for trade in services, protection of financial regulation and personal data. As red lines have been clearly defined in this report by my colleague Viviane Reding, in particular with regard to the interests of consumers or the transparency of the negotiations, I voted in favour of this text adopted by a large majority.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Most people have never heard of the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). It means an agreement on trade in services to which 50 WTO (World Trade Organisation) member states are parties, including 28 EU countries. The states involved in the agreement together account for 70% of the global services market. The official negotiations, held in Geneva, began in spring 2013 and remained latent to the general public, despite some of the documents appearing on the WikiLeaks website in April 2014. As you might expect, this incident immediately sparked a wave of criticism of the agreement. The main objective of the agreement is to liberalise the services sector: to open up markets and improve rules in areas such as financial services, telecommunications, e-commerce, maritime transport, as well as the movement of workers to provide services abroad. Each party shall make its proposals and participate actively in the negotiations. The European Union is a leader in the export and import of services on the world market, which is why we are striving to regulate international trade in services as much as possible. Looking at the negotiations so far, the report calls for greater rights for consumers in the agreement, also hoping that, in its final form, this agreement will guarantee compliance with Community standards and the privileges enjoyed by workers.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA) cannot be approved. This is a collection of agreements in the form of an international treaty between 23 parties, including the United States and the European Union. The TiSA agreement is intended to liberalize services worldwide, including free data flow. In general, no state should be able to prevent a company from creating information of all kinds outside the country, including personal data that can be exchanged, processed and stored without hindrance.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report submitted because, in my opinion, it creates a very good platform for the negotiations on the forthcoming Trade in Services Agreement (TISA) itself. The document sets clear constraints, the observance of which should prevent the risks contained in the TISA agreement (privatisation of services provided by the public sector, misuse of data in the field of information services, deregulation of financial services, etc.). Even according to many critics of the forthcoming agreements, this is the most progressive report to come out of the Committee on International Trade in the last few years. One can only wish that the negotiation of other free trade agreements, such as TTIP or CETA, should be treated in a similar way.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Trade in services is vital for the UK and the current rules are grossly outdated, as there was virtually no internet trade back in 1995. So the status quo is not an option: we absolutely need reform, but not at the cost of workers’ rights, and not at the expense of our public services, especially the NHS. We also need more transparency in trade agreements, secrecy is not an option. TiSA can help close loopholes that are currently used to abuse workers and consumers, but the Commission needs to get it right. With this vote, we are giving a new mandate to the Commission. If it fails to respect it, the European Parliament will not accept the outcome of the negotiations.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Services are an important sector in the EU and thus also in Germany, which accounts for an ever-increasing share of value added. The importance of services for international trade is correspondingly high. International trade creates the possibility of raising absolute and comparative cost advantages that benefit the consumer. TiSA is a multilateral free trade agreement for services that fits into the Trade Organization (WTO) trade order as a "building block". I would like to support this process in a positive way and call for the most comprehensive free trade agreement possible.  This report makes this demand without jeopardising public services of general interest.  Accordingly, I voted in favour of this report and hope that negotiations will proceed swiftly.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on TiSA that has just been adopted is called an own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will make its own position in the light of the full text.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against Reding’s report. If GATS needs to be modernised, let’s evaluate it and reform it with all parties. But TiSA instead is a new plurilateral agreement negotiated by a club of rich countries, which remains in favour of multinational companies, at the expense of quality jobs, the environment and data protection. It needs to be noted that as a shadow rapporteur on behalf of GUE/NGL, I am glad to see that some of our red lines were adopted by the majority of the EP, such as the exclusion of ratchet and standstill clauses, or the ratification of ILO conventions.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Viviane REDING's report on the negotiation of the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS or TiSa), which is a strong signal to the European Commission and aims to strengthen international rules and increase market opening in digital, financial and transport services. We European parliamentarians are calling for a very large majority to be more transparent, fair in trade rules, reciprocity in opening markets and benefits for more consumers. By seizing these opportunities, we will provide our European companies with levers to boost growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report on Vivian Reding's services agreement acknowledges the dangers of ACS for public services, as well as for the ability of states to legislate. In doing so, it proposes a series of safeguards to prevent: negotiations from further attacking our public services; they do not prohibit public reappropriations; that they undermine existing labour rights, environmental or privatelife protections; and, in general, that states can still legislate and that communities manage their public services and procurement. The finding is the right one and these additional protections welcome. But the ambition to continue the negotiations proves that despite these serious doubts it is the "European offensive interests", those of large companies that take precedence. As for the proposed safeguards, they are part of a European conception of the law, where the rule is competition, and the rest is just an exception. This model is hardly a success for European public services, much less a gift for our trading partners. I have therefore voted against this report which sells us a happy globalization where it is a Bolkestein directive on a global scale that we are being prepared for.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on TISA, the Free Trade Treaty and "global standards" on trade in services, This report is totally hypocritical: the aim of the European Parliament seems to be to make believe that we can create global standards while keeping the right to regulate, let the private data of Europeans wander around the world while protecting them , emptying governments of any sovereignty in regulation while promoting democracy, deregulating public services, putting them in direct competition with private companies while safeguarding them, swearing hand on heart that the public must be informed while never talking about this treaty in the media. In general, this document seems to follow the same strategy as that on the Transatlantic Treaty: the European Parliament writes a catalogue of good intentions, theoretical lines yellow or red which will certainly be blithely overburdened by the European Commission.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it advocates negotiating the TISA agreement. However, it is an agreement that will proceed to the privatization of most French public services, especially in the area of health and education. In addition, Parliament rejected Amendment No.60 tabled by the ENL, which proposed to protect European businesses. It is therefore a very worrying text, which sells our future to the interests of the United States and international lobbies.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. The EU is currently the world's largest exporter of services. In the world economy, the services sector has an increasingly important role to play. TiSA needs to modernise dated GATS rules and reinvigorate the liberalisation of the global services sector in the new digital age. The overall report provides for sufficiently balanced recommendations with a call for an ambitious agreement.  TiSA should lead to improved regulation, better access to foreign markets for different sectors (e.g. telecoms, e-commerce, transport, financial sector) and more opportunities for highly skilled service providers. For SMEs, it must remove the (financial) barriers that currently hinder them from exploring foreign markets.  Our N-VA delegation also endorses the recommendations not to touch sensitive sectors such as public services, audiovisual services or personal data protection during the TiSA negotiations and endorses the 'right to regulate' of governments. It also strives for sufficient transparency to find a sound public support for this agreement. We believe that TiSA will be crucial for the future for the creation of growth and jobs in the European economy.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In the first place, it should be noted that the Agreement on Trade in Services is a trade agreement whose main purpose is to open markets, improve licensing rules, financial services, telecommunications, etc. This report is a step forward on the road to reciprocity in market access and the creation of globally equitable conditions of competition. Similarly, it brings tangible benefits to consumers. The European Parliament is working constructively and pragmatically to bring the ongoing negotiations to fruition. In fact, this report conducts an assessment of the two and a half years and the thirteen rounds of negotiations of the Agreements on Trade in Services to transmit a number of recommendations to the Commission. Finally, I consider it necessary to adopt this report in order to achieve a strong agreement which equally benefits both European consumers and businesses.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Services are a large sector in the EU and Germany, which accounts for an ever-increasing share of value added. The importance of services for international trade is correspondingly high. International trade creates the possibility of raising absolute and comparative cost advantages that benefit the consumer. TiSA is a multilateral free trade agreement for services that fits into the WTO trade order as a "building block". I would like to support this process in a positive way and call for the most comprehensive free trade agreement possible.  This report makes this demand without jeopardising public services of general interest.  Accordingly, I voted in favour of this report and hope that negotiations will proceed swiftly.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 In general, I am in favour of liberalising trade in services as widely as possible. However, I voted against because an amendment to the standards of the International Labour Organisation has been added, where I cannot agree, for example, to ordering employers who they are allowed and not to employ or to rate a worker. Therefore, in the case of genuine market liberalisation, drivers and road hauliers cannot be discriminated against, for example, and their possibilities of entry into the market cannot be restricted. I voted against.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The TiSA Agreement focuses on the liberalisation of world trade in all activities and services. TiSA is a plurilateral trade agreement currently under negotiation between the Union and the 22 WTO Member States, based on the 1995 GATS (General Agreement on Trade in Services).  TiSA should enable European industry to open up to the outside while providing security for EU citizens. Eu integrity and values will be protected, while allowing EU industry to perform globally. This trade agreement would raise employment levels and growth of the economy in the EU and open access to foreign markets, public procurement, transport, the telecommunications sector and other financial services. Furthermore, TiSA would lose tariffs and additional payments while transporting goods outside eu borders. I supported the Commission's recommendations for negotiations on TiSA, as this agreement will provide access to foreign markets and Croatian entrepreneurs. There will be precautions within the EU to protect EU citizens, so that both Croatian entrepreneurs and citizens are protected from negative external influences while also having access to a foreign market.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 3 February, the European Parliament adopted, by a majority of 532 votes in favor, recommendations to the European Commission in relation to the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). The parties to this agreement account for 70% of global trade in services, with the EU negotiating on behalf of its 28 Member States.  The agreement must facilitate European businesses' access to foreign markets and create new growth opportunities in areas such as financial, digital and transport services. I think it is essential to seek reciprocity in the opening of markets. There is no doubt that the relaxed regulations for small and medium-sized enterprises will also be of great benefit. The European Parliament plays a crucial role in EU trade policy, having the final say in ratifying the agreed agreements. The European Commission is therefore obliged to inform MEPs of the progress of the negotiations. In the adopted recommendations we have also highlighted our red lines, namely protection of personal data, cultural services, labour law, education and health.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \u2012 I support the conclusion of a service trade agreement that sets transparent conditions for all partners. The Commission should aim to strengthen Europe's current position as a leader in trade in services and to ensure reciprocity in market access. The agreement can be a way to further liberalise and increase the dynamism of trade in services, which can help European firms, employees and consumers, especially in the areas of market digitisation, financial services and logistics.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS), which cover the exchange of services between some 50 countries including the 28 EU Member States, began in March 2013.  They are being conducted on behalf of the Union by the European Commission at a steady pace and in unfortunately opaque conditions. During these negotiations, Parliament, which does not have the power to amend the text, can, on the other hand, provide recommendations to the negotiators. The report we voted on today is therefore crucial to making Parliament's voice heard.  He called for many advances in the transparency of negotiations, the protection of financial regulation and personal data, and called for the exclusion of public services from the scope of the agreement. There is still a long way to go to get an agreement that fully protects European employees and consumers. Nevertheless, this text makes recommendations in line with our priorities for the ACS negotiations. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA), for the reasons I mention in detail in my written speech on these issues which I tabled in accordance with Article 162(2) of the Treaty. I would like to make a decision on the application of Council Regulation (EEC) No 12 to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. The TISA, or ACS (Trade In Services Agreement), is a logical continuation of the infamous TTIP. It plans to establish free trade and "global standards" on trade in services between the EU, the US and many other countries (Norway, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea, Pakistan). The aim of the agreement is to remove barriers to trade in services, which will prevent governments from putting regulations in place. All public services will be put into competition, including basic services such as health, education or water. The only services spared, for the moment, are the regal powers: justice, army, police and diplomacy. The European Parliament is hiding its face and believes that we can create global standards while retaining the right to regulate, that we can allow the private data of Europeans to be exchanged all over the world while protecting them. He seems to believe that governments can be emptied of any sovereignty in regulation while promoting democracy!

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ongoing talks on a Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), among countries representing 70% of world trade in services, should deliver a deal that eases EU firms’ access to international markets but does not force EU, national and local authorities to open up public services to competition, or otherwise restrict their right to regulate in the public interest.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). These services are becoming increasingly important to the world economy and are a central element of each EU country's economy. The TiSA is an instrument for opening up markets and a network of internal security for citizens, capable of creating correct and effective international regulation. Furthermore, considering that the European Union is the world's largest exporter of services, a sector with tens of millions of jobs across Europe, tisa could be a great tool for strengthening sectors such as employment and EU growth, through a trade policy that ensures the highest level of transparency, commitment and accountability.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We need to ensure our companies have the right level of competitiveness in an increasingly globalised economy. Given the fact that we are one of the largest exporters of services in the world, the TiSA Treaty will bring further benefits. We must achieve these objectives by remaining firm on the protection of privacy and the right of Member States to their sovereignty. I voted for this proposal because I am convinced that Europe can grow further with the TiSA.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations on the Agreement on The Trade in Services (TiSA), together with TTIP and CETA, become one of the greatest tools to enforce the Commission's neoliberal policies which give privileges to large private sector companies, depriving citizens of their rights.  This agreement is not intended to protect public services, compliance with the Conventions of the International Labour Organization, environmental protection, data protection and the right to privacy. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Commission, on behalf of the 28 EU Member States, has been negotiating since 2013 - in an opacity even greater than the TTIP/TAFTA negotiations - a major agreement on trade in services (ACS/TiSA), with some 20 other parties. The few documents available to MEPs come from leaks organised by Wikileaks and are hardly reassuring. They underline the european Commission's deeply deregulatory aims. While the negotiations are far from complete, Parliament was called upon to vote, via a progress report, on the content of the discussions. I supported the report put to the vote because, despite the rapporteur's liabilities, it draws very clear red lines and calls on the negotiators to radically change their approach. It is not a question of supporting the TiSA, which I doubt is true for, but of strongly encouraging the Commission to do things differently. And I will not hesitate to oppose the final agreement if it does not contain the injunctions of parliamentarians: increased transparency in negotiations, safeguarding public services, strengthening the right of states to legislate, protecting financial regulation, preventing social dumping, preserving data protection gains, etc.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Reding has gone from a clear 'no' to TiSA, to a report with 'clear red lines', to a praise for the free trade agreement, which we cannot follow. The report before us says nothing at all about what the agreement will ultimately look like. It is only by rejecting the agreement that dangers to citizens and society are prevented, and I therefore reject this request.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Trade in Services Agreement (ACS) aims to minimize barriers to companies from operating in another country. This is the extension of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) put in place in 1995.  The right and the Social Democrats allowed these secret negotiations to be opened by a vote in the European Parliament in 2013. In addition to the United States and the European Union (on behalf of its 28 states), 22 countries are currently involved in the negotiations. According to the WTO definition, the services concerned are "all services of all sectors." However, the report proposes the establishment of certain safeguards on public and audiovisual services, non-existent services (i.e. future environmental services), social security systems, water and health. But these safeguards are completely hypocritical since they are based on the European conception of public services which advocates openness to systematic competition. I stand by my opposition to this agreement and vote against

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Wanting to establish a free trade agreement, TiSA, on the same agenda as TAFTA and TPP, is more specifically about services. At the moment it is at the negotiating stage and includes the EU, the United States, Norway, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea and Pakistan. The stated objective is to establish global standards on trade in services and a broad free trade area. Its main objectives in the act is to dismantle part of national public services by putting them in competition with private service industries. Being, absolutely opposed to this world without economic borders that allows multinational companies to dictate their law to states, and ultimately to peoples, I therefore voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TISA) The European Parliament plays a decisive role in EU trade policy. It is up to the European Parliament to have the final say on trade agreements. In this regard, the Agreement on Trade in Services (TISA) should mirror Parliament's commitment to project a positive image of the negotiations on the Agreement. The EU should continue to implement measures to increase transparency in its trade agreements.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement because it is important for the European Parliament to continually play an active role in trade negotiations. The Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) ensures that all signatories have a level playing field and more reciprocity in market access. The rapporteur also highlights the importance of data protection and privacy in the agreement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the EP's positive opinion on the Report containing our recommendations to the negotiators of the Trade in Services Agreement. This agreement negotiated between WTO partners, which accounts for 70% of world trade in services, brings opportunities and gains for our businesses. But it must take into account the concerns of European citizens, particularly with regard to respect for fundamental rights and our social and cultural model. That is why our recommendations contain both blue lines, highlighting in particular the importance of reciprocity of market access; but also red lines such as the exclusion of negotiations from public and audiovisual services as well as the protection of data and labour rights. With the adoption of this report, we call on the Commission to follow our lines - red and blue - in the wake of the negotiations of the Agreement, allowing us to reap all the benefits while protecting our citizens.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Europe ranks first in the ranking of trade in services. The European Union has huge potential in this area, and TiSA is an opportunity for it to gain greater access to foreign markets. On the other hand, it is still very important that culture, labour law, consumer protection and, in particular, data protection, simply our entire European way of life, remain inviolable. I support the proposal calling for the highest level of transparency and information to be ensured. National parliaments and other local authorities must also be involved in the debate in order to make the negotiations and the results of them clear to the general public. When concluding agreements of such importance as TiSA, I consider consistency to be the most important element, because its final text will have an impact not only on today's Europe, but also on future generations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement TiSA. It is very important to stress that this report does not determine the final position of the European Parliament or the S&D Group on TiSA. Instead the report adopts various recommendations – red lines and blue lines – for the ongoing negotiations over the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). The aim is to ensure that main priorities are taken into account during the negotiations and in the finalised deal by the Commission. The report addresses all key concerns such as transparency of the negotiations, preserving the right to privacy amidst data flows across borders, a full carve-out for public services and audiovisual services while reserving policy space for cultural issues and preventing social dumping and preserving labour rights. The report also calls for more information for EU consumers travelling and using services abroad, e.g. on roaming fees, commission payments on credit cards and safeguards against spam and geoblocking. If the Commission must respect these recommendations, then TiSA should afford more rights to our citizens at home and remove some obstacles to our companies abroad.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I today endorsed the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). TiSA is particularly important for the EU – we are the world's largest importer and exporter of services and therefore have a fundamental interest in both establishing and co-determining a solid legal basis for international trade in services. The report emphasises that trade in services should not lead to regulatory arbitrage and social dumping. It also provides for the indenting of a 'golden standard' in the agreement in order to render the exemptions for public utilities unassailable in all circumstances. The ALDE Group was particularly committed to high standards in sensitive areas such as data protection and mode 4.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade in services represents the new engine of the world economy. In the EU it is estimated that the services sector accounts for more than 70% of its GDP. TiSA is therefore a crucial opportunity for EU service providers to have access to other markets and benefit from a level playing field. This would create new jobs in the EU and would therefore substantially contribute to our growth. However this trade agreement should not undermine our public services which should therefore be excluded from the scope of the agreement and governments’ right to regulate in the interest of their citizens from consumer protection to data privacy. I voted for a resolution that finds the right balance between these two sets of priorities.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament plays a decisive role in eu trade policy. MePs should not only have the final say on trade agreements, but should also be informed promptly and fully at all stages of the procedure for negotiating and concluding trade agreements, so that they can monitor trade negotiations on an ongoing basis. In order to shape the course of the negotiation, Parliament may express its position at any time during the negotiation process.  In its report, the Committee on International Trade assesses the first two and a half years and thirteen rounds of negotiations on the Trade in Services (TiSA) and recommends that Parliament make clear and firm recommendations to the European Commission. It proposes that Parliament should take a position that the TiSA negotiations should ensure increased reciprocating in terms of market access, a level playing field at global level, tangible benefits for consumers and that stakeholders should be able to access the negotiations in order to facilitate the future multilateral framework. At the same time, it proposes that public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data protection and decent working conditions and the right to regulation should not be the subject of negotiations and should be clearly excluded from the scope of the agreement. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade and Services represents Parliament's position for the negotiations now taking place between the Commission, representative of the Union, and 23 member countries of the World Trade Organisation.  This document presents Parliament's priorities in an agreement which, above all, must guarantee more rights for our citizens while removing barriers to our businesses in markets outside the Union. Conditions must therefore be fair in the service sector, from transport to tourism, public procurement and telecommunications. This agreement will allow new markets to be opened up to Union service providers. The agreement must also respect the Union acquis on data protection and law and respect for privacy.  For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The adoption of TISA would be a legal chernobyl for our public services. Indeed, it is a question of negotiating, in the utmost secrecy, the total liberalisation of services. The stated aim is clearly to strip the state of any economic competence. As a result, some services, such as water, education or health, could be subject to market laws and open to competition. This Redding report obviously validates this process without raising an eyebrow (is it very surprising when you know the pedigree of its rapporteur?). This agreement, if adopted, would deprive governments and peoples of all their fiscal and normative sovereignty, to the benefit of multinationals. It is therefore the "tertiary sector" of the transatlantic treaty. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the TiSA report which includes the full exclusion of all public services; strong safeguards for workers; a new binding clause to guarantee data privacy; and greater transparency. Trade in services is vital for the UK and the current rules are grossly outdated, as there was virtually no internet trade back in 1995. So the status quo is not an option: we absolutely need reform, but not at the cost of workers’ rights, and not at the expense of our public services, especially the NHS. The trade in services is a significant and growing part of the EU economy.
