Creating a level playing field and opening global markets to European service providers is long overdue and crucial to the protection and promotion of jobs in the European Union.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the negotiations on the services agreement under discussion between the European Commission and 23 WTO member countries. This text recalls the European Parliament's guidelines and red lines on this issue, including the essential maintenance of the quality of our standards and public services, which must be safeguarded. The EU is currently the world leader in services trade but also an already very open market. The current negotiations should enable our companies, particularly SMEs, to develop further in international markets and to protect certain particularly vulnerable sectors of our European economies.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of services as an offensive interest to the European Union, we welcome the Reding report with great support. Services are in fact the backbone of the European economy, both in terms of gross domestic product and in terms of employment. The European Union, with a trade deficit of EUR 173.2 billion in 2013, is the world leader in the services market. Despite the considerable level of liberalisation of the internal market, barriers to international trade for European companies remain. We therefore support the call for greater trade reciprocity. The negotiations will also have to regulate trade in digital services, while ensuring maximum compliance with gats forecasts, which is essential for the desired multilateralisation of the agreement. We hope that the agreement will provide global actors with a common framework of rules and values, particularly in the field of work, privacy and consumer protection. Thanks to the great work of the shadow rapporteur, we have finally been able to outline in the report our most important indications and concerns, thus sending a strong message to the negotiators. In particular, the negotiations must guarantee maximum transparency, safeguard the right to regulation, safeguard the stability and irreproachability of the financial sector and exclude all public services.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement, which are aimed at improving international regulation. The interest of such regulation is all the more highlighted by the very large majority who supported the recommendations.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TiSA negotiations are aimed at ensuring greater reciprocity in market access, ensuring a level playing field globally, delivering concrete benefits to consumers and allowing stakeholders access to the talks. However, public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data confidentiality and fair working conditions, as well as the right to regulate, are non-negotiable and should be unequivocally excluded from the scope of the agreement.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe in the importance of Parliament's decisive role in EU trade policy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A decisive role is played by the European Parliament in the EU’s trade policy, thus the European Parliament must work to ensure a good agreement is reached that should benefit European companies and consumers. I have voted for this report on the TiSA negotiations that must ensure more reciprocity in market access, create a global level playing field and provide tangible benefits for consumers.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). This agreement represents an opportunity for the EU to strengthen its position as the world's leading exporter of services, as its share amounts to 25% of global exports of services, which enabled it to achieve a trade surplus of EUR 170 billion in 2013. The services sector uses almost 70% of the EU workforce and accounts for 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe. I stress TiSA's potential to boost job creation in the EU.  Citizens' confidence in EU trade policy must be strengthened not only by ensuring beneficial results in terms of employment and the creation of wealth for citizens and societies, but also by ensuring the highest level of transparency, commitment and accountability, by maintaining a constant dialogue with social partners, civil society, local and regional authorities and any other relevant stakeholder , as well as by setting clear guidelines in the negotiations.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe it is essential that, following the negotiations and the TiSA Agreement, European citizens obtain quality products at lower prices and that competitive European companies can more easily access the markets of partner countries. At the moment, it is clear that the EU is one of the most attractive markets for companies from other countries, and it is appropriate that, through this agreement, European companies receive the same treatment from its partners, which will benefit all EU citizens by creating new jobs. At the same time, consideration should be given to protecting the interests and areas of interest for European States and companies such as those specialising in audio-visual, public services and data protection.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Services Agreement (TISA) because I am in favour of efforts to liberalise services. I am glad that the EP plays an active role in the negotiating process and visibly supports European negotiators. It is in our interest to negotiate an ambitious agreement, to which fast-growing economies, including China, will join. For this reason, the negotiations should also focus on the full compatibility of the TISA agreement with the GATS Agreement, so that there are no obstacles to its integration into the WTO framework. The aim should be to apply as widely as possible advanced rules on trade in services, including rules on digital trade, or to facilitate the cross-border movement of persons for the purpose of trade.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TiSA Trade Agreement seeks to strengthen international rules and increase the openness of markets in digital, financial and transport services, among others. TiSA represents an opportunity for the EU to consolidate its position as the largest exporter of services.  TiSA negotiations must ensure more reciprocity in terms of market access, create a global level playing field and deliver tangible benefits for consumers. TiSA is an opportunity to ensure competition under the rules and I support this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report presented says absolutely nothing about what the agreement will ultimately look like and makes far too little criticism of TiSA. In addition, the report has almost changed from a critical attitude to a favourable attitude. But only by rejecting the agreement can the dangers to citizens and society be prevented. I voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In the process of negotiating the Agreement on Trade in Services, the European Parliament has proposed to the Commission to supplement the agreement. The aim is to reach an agreement that is in the interests of both European businesses and consumers.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The recommendations we voted on today are important in that they lay down the red lines that this Parliament sets when giving a negotiating mandate to the Commission on behalf of the Union on the Agreement on Trade in Services. There are many shadows surrounding the negotiations, not only in terms of transparency and information, but also from the point of view of political content. This text is precisely blunt in all of the above. Transparency and information are a basic requirement in any negotiating process, whether in relation to CETA or TTIP, and we therefore demand rigour from the Commission in its information. In addition, we demand that the Agreement to be negotiated avoid social, environmental and economic dumping and ensure respect for the EU acquis. We call for the right of Member States to regulate and exclude sensitive sectors, such as public service markets, which means respecting the political, social and cultural models of the EU and its States. In short, I voted in favour of a balanced and demanding text in the defence of European interests.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 TiSA is closely linked to TTP and other international agreements, such as CETA and TTP. The OKE voted against the text of the European Parliament's recommendations and did not enter into the debate on amendments supposedly to improve another transnational agreement - an abomination for the people. TiSA, like other similar agreements, scans every right to work, every measure to protect public health, safety and the environment, which are subject to the pursuit of maximum profitability. It serves the need of large monopolistic groups on both sides of the Atlantic to control fully liberalised markets and penetrate new markets, setting aside any obstacles and delivering basic public services such as education, health, water supply, etc. in the hands of business groups. Neither TiSA nor any of the other market liberalisation agreements can be corrected with terms and amendments. Those who try to convince themselves that they can turn into pro-peoples are deceiving the people. In fact, they support the competitiveness of the European Union in their confrontation with the rival monopolies, because above all they defend capitalist barbarism. The COMMUNIST Party rejects TiSA and the "twin sisters" agreements, calls on the people to step up their fight to overthrow them, along with their monopolies and power.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is common ground that trade in services provides a strong boost to employment and growth, and I firmly believe that tisa represents an opportunity to consolidate the European Union's position as the world's largest exporter of services, as improving access to foreign markets and promoting best practices will certainly help EU businesses to flourish in the age of globalisation. I see the TiSA negotiations as a first step towards overcoming the Doha stalemate in order to relaunch the GATS services negotiations and therefore, in view of the predominant role played by the European Parliament in trade policy, I am in favour of what has been done so far and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Services are increasingly important in the global economy and a central part of the economy of every EU country. The EU is the world’s largest exporter of services with tens of millions of jobs throughout Europe in the services sector. Moreover, opening up markets for services will mean more growth and jobs. The TiSA agreement aims at liberalising the worldwide trade of services such as banking, health care and transport. That is why I vote in favour of the report containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ TISA will create fairer trade rules in the service sector and the EP is committed to giving clear understanding to negotiators on how to apply the mandate. It is clear that the EU has the biggest service sector and that TISA is necessary to upgrade previous agreements multilaterally and propel job creation in this sector, also adapting to the new opportunities technology has brought to the sector. However, I want to clearly state that TISA should contain no lazy compromises regarding the protection of our European public services, education and culture. Otherwise, I will vote against, once the agreement is on the table for approval and ratification.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the Report on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission to negotiate the Trade in Services Agreement, as I believe that the adoption of new regulatory frameworks in this area can achieve a better and more competitive market. Some of the measures I support and think will have positive consequences in the area of trade in services are setting common rules and setting standards for cross-border cooperation in specific sectors in trade in services. Also, the measures cover issues such as licensing and qualification procedures, independence of inspections, fair competition in obtaining marketing space, compliance with tender rules and non-discriminatory access to networks.  What I think is of utmost importance and what would be achieved through this agreement is the creation of much-needed jobs. I believe that expanding the market beyond the borders of the European Union would bring various benefits both economically and culturally and in the field of exchanging ideas, which is very important in further development and monitoring innovation. A fairer way of doing business would achieve so-called healthy competition between companies, be small, medium or large, because they would all have equal rights, which I consider extremely important for this market sector. Therefore, I fully support this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), because it contains all the elements that Parliament considers essential for the final approval of the Treaty. Indeed, the negotiations must offer concrete benefits to both businesses and consumers, ensuring greater reciprocity in market access, a level playing field at global level and involving all the parties concerned, so as to facilitate the future multilateralisation of the agreement.  At the same time, it is made clear that public and cultural services and the fundamental rights of data confidentiality and fair working conditions are non-negotiable for Parliament. An update of the existing rules is urgently needed, given the positive impact it would have on employment. In the area of trade in services, Europe has a competitive advantage that, with the removal of international barriers, would lead to a new expansion, increasing a surplus that, in 2013 alone, already amounted to 173.2 billion euros. The recommendations ensure that this objective is achieved without sacrificing any fundamental rights, so as to guarantee broad support for the text, both in Parliament and among the citizens.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The market for services has changed significantly since the last agreement was agreed, mainly through the development of the Internet. While European service providers are highly competitive in the global market with the knowledge and quality they provide, access to many markets is blocked due to legal barriers while at the same time access to the European market is more liberal. Particularly neglected by this non-issue are small and medium-sized enterprises. But reciprocity must not be our only goal. It should be accompanied by strong standards of protection of workers, data, consumer rights and its provisions should be made available to the public. Having participated in the drafting of the Opinion of the Committee on Regional Development, I am pleased that this report calls for the exclusion of all public services from agreements such as health and education and leaves local and regional self-government units with the right to regulate services and introduce safeguards as appropriate. I would like to thank my colleagues for the job done brilliantly, as this report has achieved its objective, clearly denotes Parliament's priorities and expectations for the resumption of negotiations. It does not prejudge the final content or mean automatic acceptance. This agreement is our opportunity to regulate globalization, but it is only acceptable if it allows our principles and standards to be maintained.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The generalisation of free trade agreements, of which this Agreement (TiSA), but also the TTIP or CETA, are part of a strategy with an unprecedented scope of deregulation and liberalization of trade at the world level and the commodification of essential public services. The broad spectrum of sectors covered by TiSA (telecommunications and e-commerce, financial and insurance services, transport and even health services) aims to impose itself as a complex network of norms and rules, designed to overcome state constraints and any national parliamentary control, in a clear attack on the sovereignty of countries, public services and a policy of development and well-being of the populations. All on the sidelines of any democratic scrutiny. Like other agreements, such as those, the whole negotiation process has been developing in the utmost secrecy. The text demonstrates well the agreement between the right and social democracy to facilitate the progress of the TiSA negotiations and make it approve, coating on cunning tricks that seek to deceive the most distracted. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The services market forms the backbone of the European economy. As a Social Democrat, I follow and work, in particular, to improve the conditions of workers and improve public services. The current rules of the services market are outdated and not very functional, so we undoubtedly need new, clear and effective rules. A new and meaningful agreement on trade in services was to be established as soon as possible. However, we will ensure that workers' rights or the level of public and cultural services are not restricted. The agreement must not jeopardise the ability of the EU or the Member States to ensure and protect labour standards and functional regulations. The Commission is receiving a new mandate from Parliament which emphasises, inter alia, the requirements for a global level playing field and reciprocity in the area of market access. If this mandate is not respected, the European Parliament may exercise its veto power. As a member of the ITRE Committee, I will monitor, in particular, the area of telecommunications and energy services, which are essential for citizens and contribute to the creation of quality jobs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 TiSA is being negotiated between 23 WTO members, including the European Union, who want to further liberalise trade in services between them. The ongoing TiSA negotiations should provide more opportunities for European companies to provide services such as transport and telecommunications in other countries, but they will have to ensure that the agreement does not prevent eu and Member State authorities from legislating in the public interest, particularly in the area of employment and data protection.  I voted in favour and I hope that the European Parliament will work constructively and pragmatically to ensure that a good agreement is concluded, in the interests of both European businesses and consumers.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Free trade is beneficial for the Union as a whole and for my home Czech Republic, from which the voters sent me here. For this reason, the negotiations on the TISA agreement also have my support, because it can expand free trade in services.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report of my colleague Viviane Reding, former Commissioner, on the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS), says TiSA. The agreement is currently being negotiated by 23 members of the World Trade Organization (WTO), including the European Union. In a globalised economy, services are increasingly important and a fundamental part of the economies of EU countries. The EU is the world's largest exporter of services (24% of the world market and a trade surplus of 170 billion euros), with tens of millions of people working in this sector in Europe. This report is perfectly balanced and underlines above all the need for reciprocity and the fact that Europe is a fairly open market for services and that from now on it is the other countries that have to open up and use the same rules as us.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole.  The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for Amendment 3-25, which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for Amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome this report, in which the rapporteur intends to assess the first two and a half years and the first thirteen rounds of negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA), as well as to draw up clear and sound recommendations to the European Commission. I believe that the TiSA negotiations should ensure greater reciprocity in market access, create a global level playing field, provide concrete benefits to consumers and also allow stakeholders access to negotiations in order to facilitate future multilateralisation. To this end, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Parliament should work constructively and pragmaticly to project a positive image of the TiSA negotiations and to give it priority in order to reach a good agreement, compatible with the interests of both European businesses and European citizens.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I finally voted in favour of Viviane Reding's report on TISA, which will obviously need to be redesigned before the European Parliament approves the final text in the coming months. At this stage, MEPs have simply set their priorities on the currently negotiated agreement on trade in services. 23 WTO members, including the EU, are concerned and together account for 70% of world trade in services. On the positive side, the members of the INTA committee were able to come together around broad compromises and avoid the pitfalls of the Bolkestein directive. A text on services in the EU which, before its adoption in 2006, had been demonised by a majority of the European left. Negative point: the recommendation adopted this lunchtime is a catch-all text. As a liberal, I am also opposed to certain paragraphs aimed at 1. (c) v. to oppose the U.S. proposals on the flow of information. And at the 1st. (d) i. to insert a security clause to prevent companies from obstructing the right to industrial action. The right to work is as important as the right to strike!

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to welcome the compromise reached by the rapporteur, Mrs Viviane Reding, in particular the refusal of 'status quo' and 'ratcheting effect' clauses and even the proposed safeguards on data protection by foreign companies. Nevertheless, in the vote, I abstained. Some "red lines" are missing. Public services and services to the public of general interest are excluded from the scope of negotiations, but there remains a vagueness as to their definition at European level, undermining the restriction. Let us be careful about these types of negotiations and their impact. To date, there is no guarantee that TISA will impose compliance with the collective agreements of the International Labour Organization (ILO). Furthermore, I am opposed to the principle of "negative list" induced by TISA: only the sectors explicitly mentioned in the agreements will not be liberalisable. Parliament has given the "green light"; I saw an "orange light" there. I will remain vigilant that the essential safeguards that condition the agreement are respected.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support this report because it missed an opportunity for the European Parliament to become a strong player in the negotiations on the trade in services agreement. Despite a number of positive elements showing that all public and general interest services cannot become the subject of negotiations, the European Parliament has not supported the substantial amendments registered by the Greens. They sought to strengthen the report by saying that compliance with the provisions of the document in question would determine whether the European Parliament would approve the outcome of the TISA negotiations. In the event of its rejection of this amendment, the report has been weakened as the Commission retains the right to disregard it.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. In her report, Viviane Reding makes recommendations to the Commission for the negotiation of this treaty, all of which are red lines that she will not have to cross. As with all the trade negotiations conducted by the Commission, the TiSA negotiations are characterized by their lack of transparency. However, this agreement on the liberalisation of services between the European Union and 22 partners carries many risks for European services. This resolution of the European Parliament does not constitute a blank-seing to the european Commission's approach. On the contrary, it calls for greater transparency and counterance insurance and social dumping. Europeans' personal data must also be effectively protected. The European Parliament is calling for the exclusion of public and audiovisual services from the scope of the agreement. As for cultural services, he advocates a "cautious approach". Finally, the report goes in the direction of preserving the ability of states to legislate, rejecting the principle of status quo (standstill) and ratchet clauses. So I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report by Mrs Reding aims to make an assessment of the first two and a half years and the first thirteen negotiating rounds on the Agreement on Trade in Services, which is being negotiated between 23 WTO members with the aim of liberalising trade in services.  From the set of objective recommendations to the Commission, I would like to point out greater reciprocity in market access, a global level playing field, a guarantee of concrete benefits to consumers and stakeholder access to negotiations as a means of facilitating future multilateralisation. Outside the agreement should be non-negotiable services, such as public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data privacy, fair working conditions and the right to legislate.  The TISA should be based on the WTO General Agreement on Trade in Services and the objective of promoting balances in international trade relations. I am sure that this agreement will give European companies more opportunities to provide services to/in third countries, without underpantiating public services, data and consumer protection, as well as high labour and environmental standards, so I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which does not vote for or against the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS or TiSA), but which sends to the European Commission the red lines it will have to respect during the negotiations. Thus, public and audiovisual services must be clearly excluded from the future agreement and our cultural diversity must be protected. It is also about preserving the right to regulate states and our data protection legislation. But we must also keep the goal of reaching an ambitious agreement and remain offensive in terms of market access. The European Union is a leader in services trade and the European market is already very open. We must therefore, through these negotiations, not liberalise more but gain reciprocity because it is essential that our companies access the markets of our partners. We will continue to monitor these negotiations closely in order to defend the interests of European businesses and citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is just another stage reached in a process that began as early as 2013, which sends the European Commission the opinion of the European Parliament, so that negotiations can continue in the most fruitful way possible.  I voted in favour because it is crucial for the European Union to be a major player in international trade. Not only that, our task is also to work to have common rules so that our companies can compete globally with clear and equal rules for all and our citizens-consumers can benefit more from a wider market but seeing their safety safeguarded

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against as I consider the TiSA to be potentially very harmful to the European production system, as well as to the rights of citizens and consumers. The text also points in the direction of a further dangerous erosion of the national sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite considerable progress on the original report and the current negotiating conditions, it remains contrary to the interests of the citizens of the signatory countries and, moreover, the developing countries that are excluded from the Agreement.  We are not prepared to vote in favour of an agreement that promotes liberalization of services and free trade in areas which include sectors which are very sensitive to well-being and development. This would be an anti-common sense movement in a context where we are still going through the consequences of a crisis largely caused by liberalization.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. – the TISA negotiations should ensure a greater degree of reciprocity in market access, create a level playing field at global level, ensure tangible benefits for consumers and provide stakeholders with access to the talks in order to facilitate future multilateralisation. However, public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data protection and fair working conditions, as well as the right to regulate, are not up for discussion and should be unequivocally excluded from the scope of the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report today, as TiSA, with its 24 parties, accounts for 70% of world trade in services and the EU will benefit greatly from it. TiSA creates general principles for those who wish to participate in trade in services and lays down binding rules for this purpose.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the Plural Left, we have positioned ourselves from the outset against different trade agreements, such as TTE or AECG, with which democratic power is being undermined to be handed over to large corporations. This report supports the ACS negotiations, a service trade agreement being negotiated by twenty-three countries, including tax havens, such as Switzerland, and non-signatory countries to ILO agreements, such as the United States. In addition, services are encouraged to remain in the hands of large international corporations, encouraging privatization and complete liberalization of services. The report gives its approval to the privatization of postal services, so far public in the Spanish State. The report also endorses that councils are removed from the capacity to remunicipalize, or that criteria such as gender equality or job creation be taken into account during the negotiation of the Agreement. It should also be noted that we voted an endorsement of the negotiations when we do not know the content of the negotiations, as they take place in no secret and we have only been aware of their existence thanks to the wikileaks revelations. For all this, we find it impossible to support the report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TiSA Trade In Services Agreement is an agreement currently being negotiated between 23 members of the World Trade Organisation, including the European Union and its 28 Member States.  I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the European Parliament's priorities for the continuation of the TiSA negotiations, the aim of which is to liberalise trade in services. I would remind you that the EU is the largest import and exporter of services in the world, as well as having a 70% workforce employed in the tertiary sector. However, barriers to market access for European service providers, when translated into corresponding figures, amount to 15% in Canada, 25% in South Korea, 44% in Turkey and 68% in China, while in the EU the tariff corresponding to restrictions on the provision of services for foreign operators is only 6%.  The European Union therefore has a particular interest in the creation of a sound regulatory basis that ensures greater reciprocity in market access, ensures a level playing field at global level and offers concrete benefits to consumers.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report largely transposes the framework of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). EFDD amendments 2-7 strengthen the report in order to allow for the full exclusion of public services from TiSA, the right to reverse commitments, and the right to withdraw from the agreement. Since these amendments did not pass as a bloc, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain on the resolution as a whole. The resolution passed as amended. However, UKIP MEPs voted for Amendment 3 (25), which calls for a clause allowing withdrawal from the agreement and reversal of commitments by each signatory – and this amendment passed, with those voting against including the entire British delegation from the ECR Group, as well as the entire EPP Group. We voted for amendment 22, calling for a positive-list approach in TiSA (mirroring the existing WTO rules on services and trade). We voted in favour of this, along with other British MEPs Janice Atkinson (ENF), Martina Anderson (GUE), Jill Evans, Jean Lambert, Molly Scott Cato and Alyn Smith (all Greens). All British ECR Group members voted against the amendment, while all British S&D Group members abstained.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the plurilateral negotiations for a Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) because it contains the European Parliament's recommendations and requirements to the European Commission for a fair and balanced final agreement. These negotiations are important for the European Union, which is the world leader in trade in services. What is intended is an ambitious regulation of trade in services covering the main issues of the 21st century, including e-commerce. I support the report because it insists on combating social dumping, calls for the exclusion of public services from the agreement, ensures the right to legislate in the public interest, removes new commitments in the field of financial services that could undermine EU financial regulation, promotes data and privacy protection in the context of a digital economy and advocates enhancing transparency in TiSA negotiations. In a statement, I supported this report in defence of better regulation of trade in services and against social dumping.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade in Services Agreement is a massively controversial negotiation process and international agreement. The rules on global trade in services are in great need of an update, but we cannot just accept any deal and the Commission must take these recommendations into account when securing a final TiSA agreement if there is any hope of the Commission getting the European Parliament's approval. It is great to see the amount of participation in the agreement of this report setting out the Parliament's position on the TiSA negotiations and that the Parliament has come to such an agreement in the end.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 The aim of the Trade in Services Agreement – TiSA – is to liberalise the services sector. However, the agreement will have an impact on our institutes, to which we have been accustomed for years. These include, for example, consumer protection, health, education, social affairs, waste management, as well as the protection of personal data. There is a need to make greater appeals to transparency in negotiating the final form of a document and to assess more deeply the possible negative impacts of this agreement. For this reason, I abstained in voting on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on this agreement.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ TiSA is a plurilateral agreement bringing together 24 WTO members, including the European Union, which account for 70% of all global trade. It aims to enable market opening that would give citizens of this area more choice in the areas of financial and telecommunications services, e-commerce, the development of new maritime trade networks, etc. with a significant focus on the protection of internet users' personal data when using these services.  As the European Union is at the same time the world's largest importer and exporter, expanding the market allows it to be more competitive. The principles of gender equality, the improvement of labour and social law, the provision of assistance to developing countries, the guarantee of the use of domestic health insurance, responsible state lending and borrowing should certainly be supported. However, it is necessary to enable states to take certain measures to protect their citizens as well as national security and to support environmental arrangements.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) is a trade agreement currently being discussed by 52 members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), including the EU, since the beginning of 2013. I supported the resolution because I believe that the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) will remove barriers for service providers and ensure a level playing field through reciprocal market access and fair competition. It is pleased that services already employ around 70% of the EU workforce and represent 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe. I believe that TiSA is an opportunity for the EU not only to consolidate its position as the world's largest exporter of services, but can also, under certain conditions, be an appropriate trigger for inclusive growth, sustainable development, poverty and inequality reduction and the creation of new jobs. I believe that by agreeing on trade in services, we will ensure greater protection of small and medium-sized service providers in the EU against unfair practices by non-EU service providers.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The EP plays a key role in EU trade policy. He has the right to express his views throughout the proceedings, which allows him to influence his course. The report here seeks to influence the negotiations on the TiSA agreement, which, like any trade agreement, should ensure more reciprocity in market access, end a level playing field at global level, provide tangible benefits for consumers, etc.  Major concerns within the framework of this Agreement arise about certain areas of the subject-matter of the negotiations on trade in services. I agree that public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data protection and fair working conditions and the right to regulation cannot be negotiated and must necessarily be excluded from the scope of the agreement.  I believe that the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) should achieve effective international regulations, not worse internal regulations. The report does not directly concern the (non)support of the TiSA agreement, but is primarily intended to make proposals to the Commission on further steps in the context of the negotiations on the establishment of the agreement itself.  In plenary, no amendment was adopted to ensure that the EP's proposals were taken into account and an amendment to gain the right to review the fulfilment of the tasks of the Council's mandate, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution containing the European Parliament's recommendations for the negotiation of the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), a multilateral trade agreement being negotiated between 23 WTO members, including the European Union.  The existing global rules on the exchange of services are defined by the GATS, an agreement signed in 1995 which now appears obsolete due to the emergence of online services that did not exist or were not available 20 years ago. The aim of the TiSA is precisely to update the GATS rules in order to continue to facilitate multilateral trade in services, given the wto deadlock from this point of view.  As a Social Democratic Group, we have managed to point to a number of precise stakes for the negotiation of the agreement, such as the complete exclusion of public services from the negotiating mandate, the safeguarding of social rights and workers' rights, the affirmation of the full right of States to regulate and legislate in the public interest, greater transparency and parliament's involvement in the negotiation process. The Commission should therefore negotiate the agreement in accordance with these guidelines, so that Parliament does not oppose the final text of a treaty that does not meet our standards.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 TiSA is an important opportunity for European companies to provide their services in third countries in order to protect European companies beyond the EU's borders and public services within it. I support this instrument, which is intended to liberalise trade in services in areas such as finance, e-commerce, transport services, licensing, telecommunications, shipping and temporary labour mobility, and is to cover around 70% of global trade in services.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. Each trade agreement should provide greater rights and lower prices for European consumers and more jobs and better protection of workers. Trade agreements should also contribute to sustainable development, promote corporate social responsibility globally and level the playing field for European companies.  In the context of globalisation, digitalisation and the trend towards trade in services taking place in our economies and international trade, political action is needed to improve international regulations. It should be emphasised that the multilateral trading system remains the most effective framework for achieving open and fair trade worldwide. TiSA is an opportunity for the EU, whose share of global exports of services is 25% and the trade surplus for 2013 to €170 billion, to consolidate its position as the world's largest exporter of services.  The value of EU exports of services has doubled over the last ten years to reach EUR 728 billion in 2014. Service sectors employ close to 70% of the EU workforce and services account for 40% of the value of goods exported from Europe. The services sectors will account for 90% of the new jobs created in the EU between 2013 and 2025, and therefore this agreement has the potential to boost growth and job creation in the EU and I have supported it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is in alignment with a number of my priorities and a number of the priorities of my Labour MEP colleagues. It supports a full carve-out for public services, increased transparency and involvement of civil society and extensive safeguards for workers, including equal pay for equal work. I therefore welcome this report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Trade in Services Agreement, like any trade agreement, must provide greater rights and lower prices for European consumers, as well as better protection of workers and create new jobs. While the agreement is plurilaterial in its current form, it should also be pursued to reach critical mass in order to be able to take on a multilateral dimension within the World Trade Organisation. Also, the agreement has great potential for job creation, as the service sectors are projected to account for 90% of the new jobs to be created in the European Union by 2025. The agreement should increase access to foreign markets as well as help European Union companies thrive in the era of global chains. I support the recommendations outlined in this debate, as I believe that the Trade in Services Agreement must ensure more reciprocity in market access, create the conditions for global application, provide tangible relief to final consumers and allow access to talks to other interested parties in order to facilitate the future multilateralisation of the agreement. I agree that the European Parliament must work constructively and pragmatically to reach a good agreement between interested parties through the negotiations on the agreement.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report with the Recommendations of the European Parliament to the Commission for the Negotiation of a Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). I support the clear guidance given by the European Parliament to the negotiators on the TiSA agreement, which I think is balanced. It brings many advantages to large and small and medium-sized enterprises, and workers' rights are also taken care of. There are many misrepresentations on the part of the opponents of the agreement regarding public services, such as public health, safety and the environment, and I therefore support it, which is also very clearly defined in the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution containing the European Parliament's recommendation to the Commission on negotiations on a Trade in Services Agreement (TISA), which should strengthen the importance of services to the world economy. The agreement should contribute to greater progress in financial services, national regulation, telecommunications and other services. By facilitating access to the third country services market and enhancing transparency, TISA will have a positive impact on the service sector and will contribute to intensifying cooperation with non-European countries in this area. The TISA agreement can bring more rights and lower prices to consumers, more jobs and protection for workers. In the field of services, it will bring, among other things, better quality, safety, affordability and equal treatment.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I will continue to support calls for an ambitious trade agreement, which will give world class UK firms market access to 70% of world trade in services markets.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The attitude of the Left both within Parliament and outside, but also the attitude of trade unions, social movements and other social actors is clearly against TiSA, as it was against TTP. In fact, in Uruguay, the trade unions succeeded in withdrawing from the negotiations through the pressure exerted on the government.  The reasons, as in TTIR, are that the liberalisation of services will start the process of reallocating capital and work to the provision of services for the benefit of increasingly large companies, wages will be pushed down, and collective agreements will be dissolved with negative effects on workers' insurance. Like the whole ESA/BPA Group in Parliament, we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement compromises EU service standards, employment (including quality jobs), public services for EU citizens and the right of Member States to regulate

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on TiSA that has just been adopted is called an own-initiative report (INI). Accordingly, it has no legal binding power and is not obliged to legislate. The FIDESZ-KDNP people's party delegation will make its own position in the light of the full text.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the negotiations on the Service Trade Agreement (TiSA). I agreed with the report's call that any trade agreement, such as TiSA, should serve the interests of European consumers and workers and that sustainability criteria should be taken into account in the negotiation.  I also think it is right that the report underlines that trade policy must be fully in line with the Recommendations of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) on decent work. TiSA can open up new opportunities for European companies. At the same time, we must make sure that SMEs also benefit from this opportunity and are not disadvantaged, for example, in the public procurement market. Nevertheless, I regret that the majority did not support the exclusive application of the positive list. I have also taken a position because I believe that this would have created a more transparent situation and a much clearer situation than that contained in the adopted proposal.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of the TiSA Treaty but I voted in favour of these recommendations because they draw important red lines that the European Commission must not cross during the negotiations: public services do not touch each other, irreversible privatisations must not take place, citizens' rights take precedence over free trade. This text is certainly not perfect. It has my support inso far as it does not give carte blanche to the negotiators and lobbies of major economic interests. This is a first step – just a first step – in the right direction: otherwise, I will work with all my might to ensure that the EU and its citizens do not fall into the trap of the international treaties TISA and TTIP, which are in addition to a third treaty, the TPP for countries bordering on the Pacific, and in synergy with the Latter form an economic pincer centred on the USA. It would be reductive to call the TiSA a 'free trade treaty'. Rather, it (just like the TTIP and the TPP), if ever approved, will form part of the web of rules that aims to redesign the structure of the richest part of the world economy. A web woven in the interests of business councils and to the detriment of the citizens.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that closer negotiation of the Agreement on Trade in Services can reduce the obstacles that European SMEs face on their way to the internationalisation of the services provided.  The EU is one of the world's leading exporters of services. Of all services, one third are provided by SMEs. However, the costs of cross-border services are increased by non-tariff obstacles, which affect the proper functioning of the SME sector in the field.  There is still huge potential, untapped at fair EU value, in the global service market. The Commission must have a fair and firm position in negotiating TiSA in favour of the economic environment of all Member States and, in particular, in favour of emerging economies which can lead to sustainable and solid long-term growth of the EU economy.  At the same time, it is very important that the Agreement on Trade in Services does not in any way prevent the proper functioning of the EU and the Member States in the application of social rules, but also in the field of labour. The European Commission must also take into account the recommendations of the European Parliament and the Member States for the development of an agreement for the benefit of all parties involved, but above all for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained for this vote on the ACS. While the European Union's trade and investment policies are closely linked to eu development policies and have an impact on developing countries, the idea of liberalisation of services is raised, a Pandora's box is opened that is detrimental to citizens and workers. However, I would like to underline the excellent work of the European Socialists in this resolution; they have greatly improved it qualitatively and humanly.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It voted in favour of the report on TiSA (Trade in Services Agreement) negotiations today, which started in spring 2013. The Trade in Services Agreement is a multilateral trade agreement currently being negotiated by 23 members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), including the EU – with the aim to liberalise trade in services among those parties. With this report, the European Parliament aims to provide the Commission with guidelines on the Parliament’s priorities for the remainder of the TiSA negotiations. Indeed, TiSA represents an opportunity for the European market to ensure reciprocity for European companies and will thus benefit European consumers and workers.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. TISA is, together with TAFTA and CETA, the third free trade agreement currently being negotiated by the European Commission. Parliament has decided, by this resolution, to set the red lines for the negotiation.  This text provides a solid basis for defending fair exchange. The Commission now has a mandate from Parliament to protect employees and consumers.  Transparency is required and citizens will have access to all the information. The TiSA will in no way facilitate social dumping, tax evasion or weaken our social and environmental standards. It should also exclude public and cultural services, while guaranteeing the protection of the personal data of our citizens. Finally, this agreement cannot restrict the right of states to legislate, either through normative cooperation or by standstill and ratchet clauses. This resolution increases the pressure on negotiators. The European Parliament will vote on whether to ratify the agreement. If only one of our red lines is crossed, the TiSA will not have my voice!

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential that the ongoing negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) are concluded with an agreement that facilitates eu companies' access to international markets, but we need to ensure that public services, which are crucial to our economies, are not included in the terms of the negotiations. This vote by the European Parliament is not a vote for or against the agreement: we want to define the limits, the red lines that will enable us to protect and protect consumers and to respond to the challenges of globalisation and digitalisation, we need a clear mandate.   We need reciprocity in market access, which is why everyone is called upon to respect the rules established at multilateral level, so that trade is fairer. It is important to curb third-country restrictive practices against European companies, such as the forced location of data or restrictions on the presence of foreign capital. Finally, we need less bureaucratic procedures for SMEs, which lack the human and financial resources to juggle the complicated rules of international trade.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 90% of new jobs in the European Union are created in the services sector, and in particular in the sector of highly qualified services, such as specialised and information technology related services.  In addition, services account for about 70% of the EU economy. It is for these reasons that the discussion of this matter is justified. I voted in favour of this report because the document contains important provisions which remind us that the provision of services in the European Union must be carried out on the basis of the principles of universal access, high quality, safety, price availability and equal access. These rules must be guaranteed in all Member States in order to achieve transparency in the labour market. Only in this way can workers' rights be effectively protected.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report, which is recommended by the European Parliament, to the Commission for the Negotiation of a Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) as I believe that such cooperation is important, necessary and useful. The TiSA agreement, which runs between 52 countries, of which together they represent a third of the Members of the World Trade Organisation, will make it easier to exchange services and more jobs.  The agreement will benefit consumers, more opportunities for SMEs and stimulate the entire European economy. However, by joining other large countries in the future, we could in some way achieve not only the advantages and lower prices of products for consumers, but also higher standards. This will not be an agreement that raises new obstacles, but an agreement that will bring them down.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite considerable progress on the original report and the current negotiating conditions, it remains contrary to the interests of the citizens of the signatory countries and, moreover, the developing countries that are excluded from the Agreement.  We are not prepared to vote in favour of an agreement that promotes liberalization of services and free trade in areas which include sectors which are very sensitive to well-being and development. This would be an anti-common sense movement in a context where we are still going through the consequences of a crisis largely caused by liberalization.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The TISA Treaty is strategic. It is about deregulating the services market. Public services will be put in competition with services offered by private companies in the same niche and will therefore gradually be "dismantled". International data flows will take the private data of Europeans around the world (as is already the case). Data protection is therefore not one of their priorities. Audiovisual services, media and publishing are excluded from the agreement. As far as services are concerned, the EU is already very open, it would be a matter of opening up other markets. Tariffs being 6% in the EU compared to 15% in Canada and Japan, 25% in South Korea so we would have everything to gain for the rapporteur, unshared optimism. This document follows the same strategy as that of the Trans-Atlantic Treaty (TTIP) for results that will not be different. I'm voting against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of globalisation, the service-oriented and digitisation of both our economies and international trade requires swift political action to strengthen international rules. TiSA gives the EU the opportunity to consolidate its role as the world's largest exporter of services with its 25% share of global service exports and a trade surplus of EUR 170 billion in 2013. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite considerable progress on the original report and the current negotiating conditions, it remains contrary to the interests of the citizens of the signatory countries and, moreover, the developing countries that are excluded from the Agreement. We are not prepared to vote in favour of an agreement that promotes liberalization of services and free trade in areas which include sectors which are very sensitive to well-being and development. This would be an anti-common sense movement in a context where we are still going through the consequences of a crisis largely caused by liberalization.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I fully share the recommendations to the Commission contained in the text as regards the negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). One of the main issues is ensuring the protection of EU firms from unfair competition abroad, in relation to which we are recommending EU negotiators ensure: 1) reciprocity in market opening, as services in the EU are already more open to foreign competition than those of its partners; 2) curbs on third countries’ restrictive practices against EU firms, such as forced data localisation or foreign equity caps; and 3) less red tape for SMEs, which lack the financial and human resources needed to navigate international trade rules. Likewise, I agree with the ‘red lines’ that are being set out in our recommendations, specifically the areas that should be excluded from negotiations, such as: 1) EU public services, like education, health, social services, social security systems and audiovisual services; and 2) EU citizens’ data protection, which must be up to current and future standards. Also, the EU should agree to accept only highly-skilled foreign workers, on contracts and for a strictly limited period of time.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Mrs Reding's non-legislative report provides a number of guidelines for negotiators in my view beneficial to Europe, such as reciprocity of European services in the face of market opening, limits on restrictive practices that third countries apply to European companies or a lower bureaucratic burden on SMEs. Similarly, red lines for negotiation are identified, such as the exclusion of public services such as education, health, social services, social security systems or audiovisual services, respect for current and future standards of European data protection or the inclusion of a review clause allowing a signatory to the agreement to abandon it if labour and social standards are violated. We are therefore talking about a report which contributes constructively to the negotiations, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists voted in favour of this resolution which calls for a change of course in the ACS negotiations. ACS may be an opportunity to regulate globalization but must adhere to a number of conditions set out in this Resolution. Greater transparency in the negotiations, unambiguous exclusion of public services from the scope of the Agreement and full respect for the labour and social rights of European workers are inescapable conditions for European Socialists. Moreover, the ACS will also not be able to compromise the EU acquis in areas such as data protection, the right to privacy or the regulation of financial and banking services, where the Union must retain full regulatory capacity. This Resolution does not determine a final position of the European Parliament or the Socialist Group on the ACS. With this Resolution, Parliament puts on the table clear demands on the negotiators of the European Commission so that a future agreement on trade in services can count on the majority support of this House, which will have the final say on its entry into force in the EU.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade in Services Agreement is an important part of modernising our trade rules to reflect the globalised world that we live in today. However, workers’ rights remain the same and should be protected. I have voted to protect these rights and to exempt public services. I have also voted to ensure data privacy is respected by asking for an exemption from the agreement for European data protection regulations. This report also demanded a detailed response from the Commission on all of the points that have been raised, a measure I am happy to back to promote transparency in these negotiations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which contains the recommendations to the negotiators of the Agreement on Trade in Services. The agreement is being negotiated between wto partners who collectively represent 70% of trade in services. The European Parliament has succeeded in making recommendations that reconcile both business interests and consumer interests.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the Recommendations of the European Parliament on the negotiations of the "Trade in Services Agreement", better known by its English acronym, the famous TiSA. This agreement, like TTIP and CETA, aims to increase trade liberalization here in services. It is being negotiated by 50 states including the European Union since March 2013 and 14 rounds of negotiations have already taken place in the greatest opacity. In a sign that citizen mobilization against these agreements is beginning to bear fruit, several GUE-NGL amendments have been adopted: an obligation for the parties to ratify ILO conventions, safeguarding universal services, especially for island regions, and a mechanism to suspend the agreement in the event of violations of labour law. However, in addition to the lack of transparency in the negotiations, many problems remain: safeguards on inadequate public services, lack of supervision of financial services, the impact of the liberalisation of the digital economy on data protection too little taken into account... At the GUE NGL, we fought the battle against this agreement, which continues to liberalize all-roundly to the benefit of multinationals and in defiance of the interests of the peoples. I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is under discussion another highly harmful treaty for national states and for the interests of people and workers. This is, as the acronym TISA points out, of the complete liberalisation on an international scale of the so-called service market covering highly sensitive sectors of our economies. In addition to financial services, health, education, transport or audiovisual and culture are appropriate here. The negotiations take place in Switzerland under the utmost secrecy. In other words, it is the large capitalist countries that are looking for what they have not been able to achieve in the great international forums where all countries speak on an equal footing. What this agreement wants, in practice and in a nutshell, is to do the will to the great lobbied of multinational companies, opening up a set of markets that until now were protected according to the will of national governments. On an equal footing in the provision of these services, but also in the collection of public subsidies such as audiovisual. In other words, what this treaty seeks is to end the notion of public service as it was created, that is, as a political instrument at the service of sovereign development and the well-being of the people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Reding has gone from a clear 'no' to TiSA, to a report with 'clear red lines', to a praise for the free trade agreement, which we cannot follow. The report before us says nothing at all about what the agreement will ultimately look like. It is only by rejecting the agreement that dangers to citizens and society are prevented, and I therefore reject this request.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which contains the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission for the negotiation of the TiSa Agreement, an agreement that aims to update the existing rules on trade in services, which are blocked in the WTO.  The TiSA agreement is an important opportunity to regulate globalisation, but we have also expressed some concerns, such as the risks to public services or the lowering of the level of protection of workers' rights. The rules underlying international trade clearly need to be updated, but not at all costs. The Commission will have to take these recommendations into account in order to ensure that Parliament votes in favour.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the motion because, from a national point of view, it leads to the destruction of jobs and a reduction in wages for domestic workers. We need to stabilise and promote our own labour force in the national labour market, rather than further destabilising it with cheap labour from all over the world!

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). Unlike TTIP, TiSA is not about a bilateral agreement, but about an agreement based on the rules of world trade. I regret that there has not been an agreement within the WHO. I share the objectives of liberalising the services market. However, the agreement has nothing to do with genuine market opening. This is reflected, pars pro toto, in the rules on financial market regulation. Parliament called for the agreement to oblige the TiSA parties 'to implement and apply international regulatory and supervisory standards for the financial sector, such as those approved by the G20, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Financial Stability Board, the International Organisation of Securities Supervisors and the International Association of Insurance Supervisors'. TiSA is therefore intended to prevent competition between national regulatory approaches. With regard to the failed Basel regime, it is, of course, absurd to oblige countries with underdeveloped but at least functioning financial markets to comply with the rules. It would be better if sovereign nation states were to decide independently and unilaterally on the opening of their markets.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ International agreements like TiSA will shape globalisation in the 21st century. It is our responsibility to ensure that international trade puts people and planet before profit, and that it raises standards globally, leading to real growth which is sustainable and inclusive, and trade that is fair for all. At the same time, trade agreements must be negotiated transparently, and must not compromise governments’ abilities to govern, or affect our public services. I voted in favour of this report as it sets out a strong Parliament position, demanding high standards, protecting public services and workers’ rights. This is a clear signal to the Commission as to the kind of TiSA we would be willing to accept.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the negotiations on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA). According to the rapporteur' view, the TiSA negotiations must ensure greater reciprocity in terms of market access, create a level playing field worldwide, provide consumers with concrete benefits and ensure access to discussions for stakeholders in order to facilitate future multilateralisation.  I welcome the attention that the rapporteur has given to the SME sector under the TiSA Agreement. It should also be pointed out that this report states that public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data privacy and fair working conditions, as well as the right to regulate are non-negotiable and should be unequivocally excluded from the scope of this agreement.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA) is of vital importance to the EU, the world's largest exporter of services. Given the growing role of the services sector in the Community economy, an agreement with the rest of twenty-three members has a clearly priority interest for the EU. It is also worth noting the work of the rapporteur, Mrs Reding, who has been able to balance the text by gaining the support of the different political groups.  This plurilateral agreement, with a view to multilateralizing, is fully aligned with WTO objectives and can serve as a development lever for countries that are negotiating tiSA— or for those who adhere in the after-year manner. I have no doubt that if this Agreement continues, its implementation will bring great benefits to the economy and employment in the European Union.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 TiSA could have a huge impact on citizens, as its consequences could affect key services such as health, utilities, education and transport, all with a view to liberalisation under pressure from multinationals and lobbies.  However, the report we have voted on today confines itself to assessing the first negotiations and to making clear and clear recommendations to the Commission. By voting in favour, I did not give my consent to the agreement, but to the type of negotiating mandate. It must ensure greater reciprocity in access to services markets, create a global level playing field, offer tangible benefits for consumers and ensure future multilateralisation. Public and cultural services, fundamental rights to data confidentiality and privacy, fair working conditions must not be negotiable, but categorically excluded from the scope of the agreement. The main objective must be to give a negotiating mandate that does not touch public services, that opposes irreversible privatisations and that puts citizens' rights before free trade.  The text is certainly not perfect, but it must serve not to give carte blanche to the negotiators who could play into the game of lobbies and strong powers.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 TiSA is closely linked to TTP and other international agreements, such as CETA and TTP. The OKE voted against the text of the European Parliament's recommendations and did not enter into the debate on amendments supposedly to improve another transnational agreement - an abomination for the people. TiSA, like other similar agreements, scans every right to work, every measure to protect public health, safety and the environment, which are subject to the pursuit of maximum profitability.  It serves the need of large monopolistic groups on both sides of the Atlantic to control fully liberalised markets and penetrate new markets, setting aside any obstacles and delivering basic public services such as education, health, water supply, etc. in the hands of business groups.  Neither TiSA nor any of the other market liberalisation agreements can be corrected with terms and amendments. Those who try to convince themselves that they can turn into pro-peoples are deceiving the people. In fact, they support the competitiveness of the European Union in their confrontation with the rival monopolies, because above all they defend capitalist barbarism. The COMMUNIST Party rejects TiSA and the "twin sisters" agreements, calls on the people to step up their fight to overthrow them, along with their monopolies and power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report, which contains very detailed recommendations from the European Parliament addressed to the European Commission, and I believe that the Commission should definitely include these proposals in the TISA Agreement. I see the recommendation on the protection of personal data as very important, because the Commission is obliged to ensure that personal data can only be transmitted outside the Union if the provisions of EU data protection law on transfers to third countries are complied with. Furthermore, to discuss the provisions on the flow of personal data only if the application of EU data protection law is fully guaranteed and respected. I also agree with the need to exclude existing and future services of general interest from the EU's obligations, as well as services of general economic interest (including, inter alia, health, social services, etc.).

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report containing recommendations to the European Commission on TiSA. I believe that the rules governing trade in services need to be updated, as the original GATS agreement dates back to 1995 and cannot cope on many points with the advent of digital technologies. I believe that TiSA represents great opportunities for our businesses, which, with its help, will be able to penetrate third-country markets and thus not only present their quality services to the world, but also help create new jobs and economic growth.
