In addition to the positive effects on employment, consumers who enjoy protection, but also easier and cheaper access to services abroad, will also be affected by the benefits of this agreement. However, as the report rightly points out, in order to negotiate successfully, it will be necessary not only to define sufficient rules on the protection of personal data, but also other exceptions, for example concerning services of general interest. Last but not least, it is necessary to gain public trust, which can only be achieved by negotiating this agreement transparently and maintaining a constructive dialogue.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The world economy is now a connected vessel system. While, in the case of international trade in goods, WTO agreements provide a very low level of customs duties and thus contribute to increasing the volume of trade, there are still many tariff barriers in the services sector. The negotiations on the TiSA agreement, which have been ongoing since 2012, aim to change this and liberalise trade in services in areas such as banking, medicine and transport. Broad agreement is necessary because highly developed countries outside Europe make it difficult for EU service providers, including Polish companies, to access their markets, while they themselves have much easier access to the EU services market.  The European Parliament has prepared this resolution for the European Commission in order to outline the guidelines and framework within which it should move during the negotiations. The most important issue that we need to raise is the need to ensure that our companies and professionals have equal access to the markets of the countries involved in the negotiations. By agreeing to liberalise trade in services, we must be sure that the rules in force will benefit us as much as we do for our partners. This report clearly clarifies our interests, including the specificities of public services, which should be excluded from the scope of this agreement. I voted in favour of it.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (TiSA) because it makes a detailed assessment of the first two and a half years and the first thirteen rounds of negotiations on the TiSA Agreement and makes progress with clear and consistent recommendations to the European Commission. I agree with the rapporteur that the TiSA negotiations should ensure greater reciprocity in market access, create a global level playing field, provide concrete benefits to consumers and allow stakeholders access to negotiations in order to facilitate future multilateralisation, and exclude public and cultural services from the scope of the agreement , fundamental rights to data privacy and fair working conditions, as well as the right to legislate, because they are not negotiable. The European Parliament must continue its work constructively to convey a positive image of the TiSA negotiations, to demystify them and to give them priority, so that a good agreement is reached, compatible with the interests of both European businesses and European citizens. I therefore therefore therefore believe that the TiSA will have to be balanced, otherwise it cannot exist.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report in question aims to assess the progress of this first phase of negotiations on the Treaty on Trade in Services (TiSA) and to draw up clear recommendations for the European Commission. The final text of the agreement should ensure greater reciprocity with regard to access to services markets (in the telecommunications, transport, financial services and energy sectors), creating a level playing field at global level (including on the procurement market) and, at the same time, offering tangible benefits for consumers.  After the first thirteen rounds of negotiations lasting two and a half years, thanks to the 5-Star Movement, the European Commission will no longer have carte blanche, since the recommendations approved by Parliament contain fundamental principles for the protection of public services that can no longer be ignored. Services linked to culture, data privacy rights and fair working conditions must strictly be excluded from the scope of the agreement, because I consider them non-negotiable. I am convinced that consumers and local service providers must be protected through proper regulation, so that we can make the most of all opportunities at European level. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendations for negotiations for the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) as they reflect the EU's values, principles and interests. It is essential for the EU to protect consumer rights, data protection and the right to privacy and to improve social and environmental standards even at the level of an international agreement.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my group and I personally supported this resolution, referring to what this Parliament had previously called for. On 9 June 2015, we clearly spoke out and clearly drew attention to the need to formulate a new post-2015 gender equality strategy. I believe that we in the European Parliament must continue to implement gender policies more and more, including by permeating every aspect of human rights policies. I say this because this Parliament is working very the issue of human rights. I believe that if we manage to permeate the prospect of women's rights and self-determination, all our policies on the issue of human rights will probably begin to move in the right direction.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the strategy for equality between men and women expired in 2015 and all the Commission has produced for 2016 is basically a working document on gender equality for 2016-2019. Now, those who want to think badly can say that behind the adoption of such a weak act, even less effective than a communication, there would be the specific political will of the Commission not to concern itself with equality between men and women. That would be very serious, given the situation of proven inequality and the difficulties that women encounter every day as professionals and as working mothers and mothers. Yet there are many points to be faced, many barriers still to be overcome. It is not ideology, this is real life: parental leave, wage gaps, pension gap, employment, health. I believe that it is an objective of civilisation, just as gender equality deserves greater efforts than a working document. I am sure that the Commission will do its best now, and I hope so.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Commission has presented us with a working document, not a strategy for gender equality. It has no objectives; has no budget; it does not have measurement indicators or subsequent evaluation.  This Commission proposal not only ignores the European Parliament's June 2015 resolution and the results of the October public consultation of the same year, but can be a regrettable setback on the road to equality.  Yesterday, the Commission told us that gender equality has all its political support, but the facts are proving that it has no political will and that it is enroached in its patriarchal deafness.  We do not accept the Commission's indolence. The struggle for women's rights, for equality between men and women, must be at the heart of our policies, at the heart of European Union policies. That is why we voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I supported the European Commission's 2010-2015 strategy for gender equality. I also supported the European Parliament resolution on gender equality in the European Union, which was voted on in 2015. Today I voted against this resolution, not because I am against equality between men and women and equal opportunities, but because I do not like it and it is ineffective to adopt resolutions after resolutions, documents after documents, papers after papers that are not put into practice.  We go home to the electorate, and what do we say: have we voted for another resolution on gender equality? But we are not saying that, in fact, we are not looking at the implementation of the Commission's strategy and previous resolutions. Let us follow the application of these previous resolutions which provide for gender equality and not continue with the adoption of new resolutions that become useless!

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Ninsab żafna ddiżappuntata gťall-fatt li l-Kummissjoni ddeżidiet li tinjora t-talbiet tal-Parlament Ewropew u tagżżel li tniżżel l-istrateżija, issa skaduta, gťall-ugwaljanza tan-nisa gťal-levelll ta' Staff Working Document. Dan huwa dokument ferm 'il bogťod mill-impenn leali biex isseťť bidla gťan-nisa u t-tfajliet fl-Ewropa. Dan id-dokument mhux ser jiżi ppreżentat lill-istituzzjonijiet l-oťra tal-Unjoni Ewropea, se jkun anqas transparent, mhux se jkun sożett gťall-approvazzjoni demokratika, u mhux se jkollu l-profil politiku mistťoqq. Fir-rwol tiegťi bťala mp ta' din il-Kamra se nkompli ninsisti mal-Kummissjoni Ewropea biex tippreżenta strateżija żdida, li tipprovdi viżjoni fit-tul, li tikkonsisti f'qafas ta' politika żenerali b'mekkaniżmu ta' monitorażż u ta' responsibility. Gťalhekk jiena ivvutajt favur il-mozzjoni gťal riżoluzzjoni dwar l-istrateżija l-żdida gťad-drittijiet tan-nisa u l-ugwaljanza bejn is-sessi fl-Ewropa. Insejjať gťall-adozzjoni immedjata ta' din l-istrateżija biex kwistjonijiet ta' ugwaljanza fl-oqsma ta' vjolenza kontra n-nisa, fil-ťinijiet tax-xogťol, fit-teťid tad-deżiżjonijiet, fl-edukazzjoni, fil-midja u fir-relazzjonijiet esterni, fost l-oťrajn, ikunu indirizzati.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I did not support the resolution that we voted on today, which was proposed by colleagues on the left. I am therefore taking the step because, with this vote, I do not want to say that I am against equality between men and women, in any case. Of course, I support absolute equality between men and women, but the question is what means are we supposed to achieve this. And whether the means that particularly left-wing colleagues have debated and proposed are feasible at all, and whether, for example, individual Member States in the European Council will then be willing to accept and support them. And there I believe that the real policy that we are able to enforce and implement differs from nice declarations in lofty words, from things that end only on paper. And as a real politician, I'm interested in what we're able to actually push through. Let us look, for example, at the problems with the Directive on quotas for women in the administrations of individual companies. This material has stumbled upon the Council of Ministers, and I fear that this may be the case with other ideas.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Colleagues, i would like to take the I share the wish of a majority of MEPs to see a qualitatively developed new strategy as soon as possible. After 2015, I really also call on the Commission to draw up a full-fledged project, not a working document, as they say, for the service. And above all, this document includes principles based on the successes and real results of the previous strategy up to 2015. It could start active negotiations not only between the Commission, Parliament and the Council, but also involve as many other institutions as possible, european union agencies and so on. The same is true of the strategy itself: it would be better for the next strategy to be 2020, despite the fact that in 2019 we will have to re-elect the new European Parliament and the Commission accordingly, but it would be good for the next five years to be the next strategy.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab After the discussion, we received a document on a new equality strategy, which is based on the European Union's characteristic selfish self-ache. The document is based on the belief that women's rights and the social status of women in Europe have been getting better for 20 years. But what is the context? – Undermining the importance of marriage and its permanence, weakening the authority of the mother and father in the family, abortionism, whose greatest enthusiasts are usually well-earning or young men. Does all this build the social status of a woman?  I think we should not so much wonder how to continue going in this direction, but rather how to turn back from this path, because in order to ensure Europe's life, we must really turn our backs on this path to perdition.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament today adopted a resolution in which it commented on the Commission's strategy paper on gender equality. I regret that a version of the European Parliament resolution has been adopted calling for a new strategy, which is called for by the European Summit on Gender Equality, instead of focusing on concrete steps by which we can actually improve the position of women in the European Union. And it is precisely the strategy put forward by the European Commission through Commissioner Jourová that contains these steps, because there are objectives that also concern improving the position of women in the labour market, improving their employment, improving the pay situation, pensions, improving their representation in public administrations, but also private firms. So it is the specific elements that are contained there, and unfortunately instead there is a declaration that does not solve anything.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is a bit difficult for me to speak after the previous speaker, because I have been thinking for quite some time about how to vote on this particular matter here, and I will admit that I have found no reason not to support this resolution. Firstly, I would like to mention that I really do up to the principle of equality of persons. About gender equality: I think that's a bit of a shifting gender equality, it's a bit of a political fetish. For me, it is essential that equality of persons is a fundamental principle of all constitutional documents and basic documents of the European Union. As regards these objectives, if I have read directly in that resolution, it is written that progress is required in areas such as violence against women, working hours, decision-making, health, education, the media, external relations. So, in my opinion, these demands are legitimate, and for that reason I have not found a single reason not to support this resolution, and I have supported it with my vote.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, last but, hopefully, not least. Equality between men and women is a core value of the European Union and, while the Member States, including Ireland, have taken important steps to promote equality between women and men, there has been a slowdown in political action and reform at EU level over the last decade. In Ireland, despite some progress in this area, today’s statistical overview underlines considerable differences in the sectors in which men and women participate and the under-representation of women at senior levels – even in sectors which employ significantly higher numbers of women. This is not good enough. Therefore I welcome this new strategy, which calls on the Member States to take further steps to address equality issues and ensure equal opportunity in the fields of employment, health and education, and in both the public and private sectors. Finally, we are calling an election in Ireland right now; thankfully, 30% of the candidates from the political parties have to be females: a step in the right direction.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer-funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidence of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on the strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015. A joint resolution by, among others, the Socialist Group and the Liberal Group was tabled and voted through. It is a resolution that is very critical of the Commission and wants the Commission to initiate new legislative processes. I do not share that view. On the contrary, the Christian Democrats have been highly critical of many of the legislative proposals that the Commission has previously presented in this area. This concerns, not least, eu regulation of parental leave. Legislative work to promote gender equality belongs at national level in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring gender equality has been one of the key objectives of European policies in recent years.  The European Strategy 2010-2015 focused on a few key points, such as the right to equal pay, a fair access to managerial posts and the fight against all forms of violence and discrimination. The achievement, however, of effective and real equality is still a long way off, undoubtedly requiring further efforts. The new strategy for gender equality and women's rights drawn up for post-2015 certainly makes improvements to the previous wording, while maintaining a still too general and incisive treatment of the problem. That is why I have chosen to abstain, hoping for clearer policies aimed at effective equality between women and men that will put an end to gender inequalities.

name: Tim Aker and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution because it contains an express mandate from Parliament and, previously, from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, so that the European Commission can continue, through a new strategy that succeeds it, the so-called Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015, the scope of which was already clearly limited by not achieving any of its five main lines of work in its entirety. In this way, the Commission is requested to take more seriously one of the fundamental principles of the Treaties, that of equality between women and men, ingesting it to adopt a strategy as an official communication and not as a mere working document. In my view, these are some of the evidence showing that the current European Commission has no interest in highlighting realities as unfair as the scourge of gender-based violence, persistent wage inequality or the lack of policies to reconcile personal and working life (as demonstrated by the withdrawal of the proposal to extend the Maternity Directive).

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against these resolutions on the strategy on gender equality and women's rights for the post-2015 year. Indeed, while I support actions to ensure equal pay, I am opposed to measures to introduce quotas, particularly in boards of directors in companies that are real constraints and do not systematically reflect women's personal aspirations. In addition, requests for new proposals for gender equality have crept into this text, while the current texts have not yet been implemented.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This oral question to the European Commission concerns the creation of a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period after 2015. Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU, recognised by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  The current strategy for equality of friends ended in 2015 and Parliament in its resolution of 9 June 2015 underlined the need for the Commission to present a new specific strategy. On 3 December 2015, the Commission presented the "Gender Equality Cooperation Strategy 2016-2019". However, this is only a working document and has therefore not been approved by the Commission, nor has it been interinstitutional. In addition, the Council has also called on the Commission to set specific benchmarks and allocate a budget for this objective.  Gender equality is one of the objectives of the Treaty, while women's rights and gender equality are two of the European Union's most important values, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to review its strategy on 'equality between men and women'. It refers to "gender equality", the feminization of boards of directors, "women's rights", etc. However, there are a few positive aspects: the need, for example, to take into account different cultural contexts from one country to another, from one region to another, and respect for the sovereignty of states in the choice of wage laws... Nevertheless, it is clear that the general orientation of the document contains a very ideological aim, namely the feminization of all parts of society regardless of the complementarity of the two sexes. That is why I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for resolution from other political groups, having preferred the wording of the EFDD resolution, and feeling that the final resolution requested Commission action in areas where it should not.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the intolerance of violence against women. According to the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, one third of women in the EU have experienced physical or sexual violence. The European Commission is being called upon to present a new strategy for gender equality and the protection of women's rights. There is a need to put forward rules to combat violence against women as soon as possible and to call on the European Union states to ratify the Istanbul Convention without delay. More than half of eu countries have not done so.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I support actions aimed at ensuring equal pay, especially, provided that it is a matter of aligning women's wages with those of men and not the other way around.  On the other hand, I am opposed to all the quota provisions, particularly in the boards of directors in companies. These mandatory quota policies transform women into adjustment variables to meet administrative constraints and deny their personal skills and aspirations.   Finally, I supported the motion for a resolution which was the most respectful of the principle of subsidiarity and cultural diversity of the Member States, while aspiring to a fair remuneration for women: the proposal of the group of European Conservatives and Reformists. I voted against the other proposals which call on the Commission to propose new measures against gender equality, even though they are being voted on in all areas to the point of absurdity. The promoters of the evil gender ideology are never far away.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Charter of Fundamental Rights defines gender equality as an essential value of the Union, carried out through a series of important initiatives aimed at protecting women's rights.  However, the poor results of the Commission's strategy between 2010 and 2015 call for a new initiative to address obstacles to the full achievement of the objectives already identified. I supported the resolution for a new strategy on gender equality because I am convinced that we need to call for an EU summit on gender equality in order to identify progress and renew commitments under the EPSCO Council scheduled for next March.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The EU had a Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 which came to an end last December. Previously, in June, Parliament adopted a resolution laying down the Commission to develop another strategy for the period 2016-2019. On the other hand, a consultation open to citizenship highlighted the popular views of Europeans, who are in favour of this new strategy. Unfortunately, however, on 3 December 2015 the Commission published a mere working document of its services entitled 'Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019' which is not only a smaller internal document, but is also limited in scope and reflects less institutional commitment. That is why we voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution to call on the Commission, in addition to the working document, clearly insufficient, to urgently develop a strategy with objectives, measures, measurement indicators, budget and evaluation, to implement actions for gender equality and demonstrate the Commission's true commitment to this equality in a cross-cutting manner.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I fully supported, even signed the Resolution on the new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights in Europe after 2015, agreed between four parliamentary groups. We need to have a legislative proposal from the European Commission that marks a clear and 21st century strategy for gender equality that is a pioneer. Society claims it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, which ignores common sense by asking the Commission for new proposals on gender equality, even though the current gender equality texts are not being applied. The legislative outbid will not ensure equal pay, in particular. In this regard, it is also up to the Member States to propose solutions, especially since the socio-cultural situations in this area differ greatly from one nation to another. I am also opposed to the principle of quotas for women on boards because I believe it is an insult to women's ability to rise to the highest positions simply because of their merits and talents. Women should never be reduced to victim status, as is unfortunately the case in some parts of the Beijing Declaration. However, I welcome the fact that the importance of respecting equality between men and women is being recalled, taking into account their differences and complementarity.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While containing some ideas that we can support, they have been developed in an excessively general way and therefore this report is devoid of new or concrete proposals. That is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 concluded in December. Parliament, in its Resolution of 9 June 2015, stressed the need and urgency of the Commission presenting a new specific strategy for gender equality and women's rights in the EU. However, on 3 December 2015, the Commission presented a mere working document which has no interinstitutional value. A genuine strategy is therefore called for in the Commission's claim to lower its level of action in this area, since it neither sets specific benchmarks nor allocates a budget, and that it will therefore not be possible to assess the progress made towards the objectives. For these reasons I support the resolution adopted by the European Parliament in order to correct these shortcomings.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament urges the Commission to present a new Strategy on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in Europe. The Commission's previous strategy for equality between women and men expired in 2015, and Parliament explicitly called in its resolution of 9 June 2015 for the adoption of a new, separate strategy on gender equality and women's rights after 2015. In addition, the results of the public consultation showed that 90% of the survey participants welcomed the new strategy. Unfortunately, the Commission did not carry out its work and on 3 December 2015, the Commission did not carry out its work. The Commission published only the Staff Working Document 2016-2019. Thus, in the light of the simplified internal document, the Commission also limited its period of validity. The European Parliament shares the Commission's view set out in the above-mentioned Staff Working Document on strategic action for gender equality, but regrets the absence of specific indicators and a specific budget, without which progress towards objectives and indicators cannot be measurable or achievable. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to take further action, taking into account the above-mentioned results of the public consultation and the position of Parliament and the Council, and to adopt without delay a communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period 2016-2020, which addresses gender equality issues in the areas of violence against women, working time, decision-making, health, education, media and external relations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i did not support the proposed resolution because, in my opinion, the European Commission is sufficiently active in ensuring gender equality and women's rights. The authors of the resolution have put form, not content, at the forefront. Indeed, the motion for a resolution drafted by the European People's Party, which was rejected, concerned the implementation of the Commission working document on strengthening women's rights and also recognised the Commission's progress in this area. I believe that the matter should be approached operationally. A strategy as a dead letter on paper can mean much less than a concrete working document with clearly defined operational objectives.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is a key principle of the European Union, a value recognised by the Treaties and necessary in order to achieve the objectives of social inclusion, growth and employment that are central to the Europe 2020 strategy.  The European Commission's efforts in this regard bode well, but it has proved not broad enough to achieve the objectives set. Thanks also to pressure from the European Parliament in 2015, the Commission has made some progress with the drawing up of a new roadmap on work-life balance in the Union and with a working document presented in December, but lacking precise benchmarks and a clear budget, without which it is difficult to estimate any developments and the effectiveness of the policies adopted. I therefore support the resolution, calling on the Commission to give new impetus to this issue and to take more concrete and ambitious measures from 2016.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. –in 2012 As many as 90 percent of citizens consider a new strategy on gender equality necessary, and the Commission has down their wishes to a working document. It's a slap in the ass to all women in the EU. The EU must be an example of preserving the values of tolerance and equality, especially in such turbulent times. You'd expect some things to be implied in 2016, but on gender equality issues we often take one step forward and two steps back. A strategy on equality should not be a matter for discussion, but our obligation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document because I believe that gender equality and women's rights must be a priority for the European Union and its institutions and that, therefore, the Commission must make greater efforts to devise and implement a new and more effective strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period after 2015.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality and the fight against discrimination, particularly for women, have always been recognised as priorities by the European Union which, over the years, has promoted the adoption of strategies to protect women's rights.  Despite the commitment and efforts to recognise and assert women's rights, sexual discrimination continues to be present in European societies and gender inequalities have direct consequences for economic and social cohesion, sustainable growth and competitiveness, as well as demographic challenges. Europe, which is regarded as a civilization of progress, must be able to translate its principles and values into reality.  That is why the European Union must today work to remove obstacles, both culturally and materially, by adopting a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Confounding equality with egalitarianism, this motion for a resolution takes up absolutely ridiculous data to highlight the inequalities faced by women: part-time work without even knowing whether it is desired or suffered; the employment rate, which is lower among women than men, without knowing whether it is due to the willingness of some of them to remain inactive in order to take care of their children's education.  Although we are fully in favour of equal treatment in terms of remuneration, for example, and it is essential to combat all forms of discrimination and violence against women, I voted against this motion for a resolution which does not provide any solution to the problem mentioned.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to equal treatment is a defining right underpinning European society, being crucial for its future development and its implementation must be done in accordance with the different cultural contexts and practices of the Member States. This right, in order not to remain at the declarative level, should be applied from legislation, in practice, then in case-law and with an impact in everyday life. Either this can only be done through a clear, transparent, legitimate and public communication, supported by all EU institutions at the highest political level. Only in this way will we be able to make progress in implementing the principles of equal treatment and opportunities between women and men at European level. However, given that within the New Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights post-2015 there is not enough evidence to ensure that we are indeed talking about gender equality between men and women, I voted against this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. Very general, usual rhetoric, it proposes nothing new. Recommended vote less. It points out that the Commission's work programme for 2016, published in November 2015, does not contain any specific reference to the EU's post-2015 gender equality strategy. It calls for the immediate adoption of a communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights 2016-2020 to address gender equality issues with regard to violence against women, working hours, decision-making, health, education, the media and external relations.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Equality between men and women must become a reality in the European Union. We need to put in place a European Union strategy for gender equality after 2015 that is in line with the principle of subsidiarity. We cannot continue to see cases of discrimination against women. The European Union must be a model in this area to be able to export these values around the world. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for a resolution because while the concept is noble, we should perhaps first focus on relevant legislation that already exists but has not yet been implemented by the Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution is aimed at calling on the European Commission to urgently produce a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights 2015. The plan presented by the Commission on 3 December 2015 is, in fact, completely unsatisfactory as it consists of a simple working document of the Commission services that has no interinstitutional value.  Although I believe that the text of the resolution is entirely acceptable, I have chosen to abstain because I believe that it is nonetheless too general and too lean in its requests to the Commission.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We recall that equality between women and men is one of the objectives of the European Union. Unfortunately, we must vote against the motion for a resolution, as important amendments which we supported and considered to be unnecessary were not voted for by the plenary.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period after 2015. This issue concerns the whole of our society and its development is a clear sign of progress for Europe. Efforts to eliminate inequalities and discrimination in all sectors of European society are particularly important and it is our obligation to welcome and use them to improve conditions for citizens. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because I do not agree with the formal and substantive assumptions underlying the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution. A little reluctantly, I have to admit, because I appreciated the efforts made by the negotiating team as a whole. However, because of the extremism of certain political groups, I had to reject the whole text when there was a lot that could be fine.  Here we are talking about an issue that, especially at a cultural level, should no longer even be topical, while in 2016 we still find ourselves talking about it. Well, on this issue we cannot overcome the ideological fences and therefore we do not realize that we are moving in a regulatory framework in which the competences of each one are well defined and must be respected, in which too many rules have been written and there is no point in watering down the work of legislators and those who then have to apply them on a daily basis by writing further legislative texts , where equality between men and women should be taken for granted and is not yet so. Too bad.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current strategy for equality amongst women and men ended in 2015. On 9 June 2015 the Parliament made a resolution urging the Commission to present a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women’s Rights within the EU. Gender equality is a core value of the Member States and is crucial to achieving the overall aims of employment, growth and social inclusion. The employment rate in the Member States is still higher for men (70.1%) than among women (59.6%). The Commission’s previous strategy for equality 2010-2015 did not adequately advance equality at European and international level. The post-2015 strategy is necessary to deliver new momentum and concrete action to further women’s rights and achieve gender equality. While useful, the staff working document since produced by the Commission for gender equality policy post-2015 does not have interinstitutional value. Member States must mobilise themselves to address equality issues and take action against gender-related violence. Equal opportunities in employment, education and health should be made a priority in Member States. Member States are encouraged to take responsibility in transposing, implementing and evaluating existing legislation and policy tools for equal opportunities at national level. The Commission should adopt an official strategy on gender equality without delay.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality and women's rights remain a priority of the European Parliament. Unfortunately, and despite the immense progress made, both the European continent and the world remain uneven.  It is therefore necessary to remain uncompromising in the defence of fundamental rights. Achieving results in this area is only possible through a joint effort involving every citizen and the various levels of governance, from the parish council to the United Nations. A concerted strategy with clear objectives and well-defined instruments is also justified at European level. I am, of course, a supporter of an active strategy that goes beyond the mere decree of equality. However, I cannot agree with the instrumentalisation, for purely political purposes, of the Union's core values. I therefore abstained from this resolution.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report because, although I support the resolution on the substance, I cannot share the call for new legislative proposals. The existing rules must be properly implemented and applied in their entirety. This is where the Commission is called upon, because its task is to push forward the implementation of the principles of equal treatment and equal opportunities for men and women at national level.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Gender equality is an important objective to be achieved, especially as human rights, and women in particular, are enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. This means that these values are rooted in our civil society and must also be adequately protected within the framework of EU regulations and regulations.  The Commission has drawn up a plan for the period 2016-2019 to increase the implementation of women's rights and gender equality, which is very concrete and I hope that it will contribute in a short time to reducing the disparities that still persist within the EU. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Targets set for gender equality in leadership positions, at work and in other social and economic sectors are not being met. Yet despite the fact that all the political groups work towards attaining gender equality, they fail to obtain consensus on the drafting of a motion for a resolution. Politics with a small ‘p’ should be set aside and common aims and language ought to be sought. Only a joint force reflecting the support of all the political groups can truly lead to significant development in gender equality. I have voted against the proposal voted on in today’s plenary because I believe a different proposal contained a more effective approach to gender equality. However, I remain in favour of gender equality.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution because it contains an express mandate from Parliament and, previously, from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, so that the European Commission can continue, through a new strategy that succeeds it, the so-called Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015, the scope of which was already clearly limited by not achieving any of its five main lines of work in its entirety. In this way, the Commission is requested to take more seriously one of the fundamental principles of the Treaties, that of equality between women and men, ingesting it to adopt a strategy as an official communication and not as a mere working document. In my view, these are some of the evidence showing that the current European Commission has no interest in highlighting realities as unfair as the scourge of gender-based violence, persistent wage inequality or the lack of policies to reconcile personal and working life (as demonstrated by the withdrawal of the proposal to extend the Maternity Directive).

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to equal treatment is a right deeply rooted in our society and is fundamental to its further development. The European strategy on this issue ended in 2015 and was not followed by a new strategy. The European Parliament resolution, which I supported with a vote in favour, calls on the Commission to present a new specific strategy for women's rights and gender equality 2016-2020 and to start discussions with the Council and Parliament.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as I believe that the Commission must present its post-2015 strategy on gender equality in the form of a strong legislative proposal with concrete benchmarks and a precise budget dedicated to progress in this field. In order to ensure real gender equality within the Union, the Commission must present a full strategy in line with Article 2 of the TFEU, which goes above and beyond the already created staff working document.  Furthermore, I believe in enhancing and supporting the 7 December declaration by the current EU Presidency trio – the Netherlands, Slovakia and Malta – on gender equality which calls for a new strategy for 2015-2020 in order to ensure the full utilisation of the available workforce, and empowerment of women and young girls throughout Europe.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a major player committed to promoting gender equality and combating discrimination. Although the Union has taken on the specific task of integrating gender equality into all its activities, despite gradual progress in this area, many inequalities still persist between women and men. In the EU, around 42% of the actors regularly involved in agriculture are women, and three out of ten eu farms are managed by women. Promoting the principle of equal opportunities between men and women, together with ensuring greater participation of women in economic and social life as a full protagonist, must be constant concerns at European level. I believe that the European Commission, together with the Member States, must contribute to the promotion of a strategy that also leads to job creation for women in rural areas and, by implication, to the provision of decent pensions for women who are retiring in the EU who live in precarious conditions, many working or who have worked in agriculture and who do not have pensions or whose pensions are very low.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this proposal for a joint resolution by the left, MEPs call on the European Commission to formulate a legislative proposal on a "new strategy on gender equality and women's rights for the post-2015 period". Defending gender equality in society, the EPP Group has tabled a number of amendments to this draft resolution which does not respect the competence of Member States in this matter. The EPP Group defended its proposals in its own resolution. Having lost our amendments and our resolution in the plenary vote, I have decided to vote against this draft resolution.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 For gender-based violence and discrimination against women to be just a thing of the past and not, as unfortunately we are forced to see every day, a tragic everyday reality, there is a need for a binding commitment by the institutions against gender inequality.  That is why I voted whole much in favour of the resolution on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights in Europe after 2015, for a greater and more concrete commitment by the Commission and for the convening of an EU summit on gender equality and women's rights.  In fact, only by strong political will, by an analysis of progress and failures and by targeted legislative initiatives will it be possible to achieve a real result in terms of equality, which is becoming a more urgent need every day.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the report to urge the European Commission to present a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights. The EU has long played a major role in improving the equality of all its citizens, but much remains to be done. I note that Commissioner Jourova has repeatedly committed to delivering a new strategy, and has not spared any effort to mediate with the Council in the negotiations on the directive on the presence of women on boards of directors. I note his efforts to bring the maternity leave issue back to the table by taking a broader approach to work-private balance. Unfortunately, I must note that so far the Commission does not take this issue very seriously. However, this subject deserves better than a simple internal discussion paper. In voting for this report, I therefore encourage all political groups in the European Parliament to join forces in the fight for a firm and clearly necessary strategy for women's rights and equality in the EU.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the resolution on the ‘New Strategy for Gender Equality and Women’s Rights post- 2015’. Equal treatment of men and women is a fundamental principle of EU law and needs to be implemented. However, like on previous occasions, the measures, such as the Women on Boards Directive, outlined in the resolution aimed to attain equal treatment, go beyond my views on how to achieve such goal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. It is commendable to recall that the principle of gender equality is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. Nevertheless, the text envisages asking the Commission for new proposals on this matter, even before the current texts are properly implemented. In addition, I am opposed to the requirement to apply quotas for women, in this case on boards of directors. Apart from the fact that they are double-edged, it is not to serve women to mark them, at all stages of socio-professional life, with the seal of supposedly positive discrimination. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided not to support this proposal because, despite the fact that I support the principle of equality between all citizens, I do not agree that the EU must be counterproductive and start creating legislation on issues for which instruments exist.  Furthermore, the EP has already adopted the resolution on 9 June 2015.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against, the approach that the report has is not compatible with the ideal family for us, instead it promotes an image of individualism, the giantism of which has led Western societies to today's downfall.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. Gender equality is a fundamental value of the European Union and is thus reflected in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The importance of equality between women and men leads us to continue working on new strategies for the next five years with the aim of removing all those barriers that hinder the development of women, both at the work level and profession within society. Ending all forms of discrimination and violence faced by women must be our main objective in developing new strategies. Women, like men, should be a certain that they will not suffer any harm because of their ethnic origin, sexual orientation, sexual identity, disability, region, nationality or age. We must think of gender equality as a strategic and universal objective that will help us achieve Europe's economic, social and employment objectives.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution because, although it points out that equal treatment and opportunities for women and men is a key objective for all Member States and regrets that the Commission's work programme for 2016 does not contain any specific reference to the EU strategy for gender equality after 2015, it does not express an explicit criticism of the content of the EC working document. Furthermore, with regard to certain commitments made by the European institutions, the joint resolution goes beyond respect for the principle of subsidiarity.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Equality between women and men is a fundamental value of the Member States and is decisive as a strategic objective to achieve the overall goals of growth, employment and social inclusion. Member States have been taking some important steps to strengthen women's rights and equality between women and men, but there has now been a slowdown in political actions and reforms over the last decade at EU level. The employment rate in the Member States for men (70.1 %) was still higher than in the case of women (59.6 %), which is added to the fact that almost a third of women (32.2 %) work part-time.  I therefore agree that Member States should take further steps to address equality issues, combat violence against women and ensure equal access and opportunities in the fields of employment, health and education, both in the public and private sectors.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this resolution is to call on the European Commission to immediately take a Communication on a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights 2016-2020, addressing gender equality issues in the fields of violence against women, working time, decision-making, health, education, the media and external relations , and which is in line with the international agenda, namely the final document 'Beijing +20' 2015 and the new framework for "Gender equality and women's empowerment: transforming the lives of girls and women through the EU's external relations (2016-2020)". It calls on the Commission to propose legislative initiatives in its Work Programme to eliminate the remaining inequalities between women and men in the EU. The Resolution is somewhat critical of the Commission's 2016 Work Programme for not making any specific reference to the EU's post-2015 Gender Equality Strategy. It deplores the lack of concrete objectives and a specific budget, without which progress on targets and indicators is neither measurable nor achievable. We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ It is essential that we adopt a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the post-2015 period, as the previous strategy expired last year. The new strategy should cover important areas such as the need to effectively combat violence against women or to improve their position on the labour market. Although we have certain objectives set in this area, we are indeed approaching them at a slow pace. Without a clear, joint commitment on how to work towards them in the coming years, which should be brought about by the new strategy, this will be very difficult. A few years ago, a new binding legislative act was promised to specifically address, for example, the issue of gender-based violence. When this was not enforced, the European Commission came up with a strategy, which is still not visible in the reality of the daily lives of the people of the Member States. Instead, the European Commission presented a document entitled 'Strategic commitment to equality between women and men' in 2016-2020, which paradoxically obliges no one at all. This shows that the European Commission absolutely refuses to reflect a reality that speaks unequivocally of the exact opposite.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution because it is very general and does not propose anything new.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period after 2015. The approach taken by the report is incompatible with the ideal family for me, but rather promotes an image of individualism, the giantism of which has led Western societies to today's downfall.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality is one objective of the Treaty, and it is essential as a strategic objective to achieve the overall EU objectives, such as the employment rate target within the Europe 2020 strategy. Women’s rights and gender equality is a core value of the EU. It seems that the Commission shows willingness to downgrade its action in the field, with a lack of concrete benchmarks and dedicated budget, without which progress made on the targets and indicators is neither measurable nor achievable. The Commission should instead adopt a transparent and public communication for a ‘New Strategy for Gender Equality and Women’s Rights post-2015’, in line with its European and international objectives and agenda, and inform us as to when it will present its official strategy on gender equality.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the Resolution, considering that gender equality is a central value of the EU and that, as a strategic objective, it is essential to achieve the overall objectives of the EU. Much work remains to be done to consolidate women's rights and gender equality, we have a lot of legislation passed, and we must ensure that states transpose into their internal rules what is already the norm in Europe. That is why I believe that it will be much better to facilitate legislative simplification and for legislation to be implemented in the Member States than to develop new directives that can be used as measures to block the implementation of measures for gender equality and the rights of women already adopted.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I am pleased to support the oral question tabled by my colleague Iratxe García Pérez, which reiterates to the Commission the need to present a new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in the EU as soon as possible. I believe that Europe must continue to give strong signals in this regard and to demonstrate a solid commitment to its fight against social and sexual discrimination and to the protection of human rights.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the oral question, tabled by the FEMM Committee to the European Commission, on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights in Europe after 2015, because I agree with the urgency and the desirability of such an initiative. Equal treatment for men and women is not only a fundamental right but also one of the cornerstones of the EU's ideological system and a prerequisite for a fairer and fairer society. The EU has always been an example in equal opportunities policies and has inspired initiatives to strengthen women's rights. However, in recent years we have seen a worrying slowdown in political activity in this area and a consequent failure to achieve the objectives set out in previous strategies.  It is disappointing in this sense that the Commission did not include any kind of reference to the EU Post-2015 Gender Equality Strategy in its 2016 work programme, merely presenting a working document of little legislative and content value. I therefore agree with the call for the Commission to work with Parliament to renew its commitments and to reinvigorate its action on gender equality.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the resolution on the 'New Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights after 2015', as this text repeatedly misinterprets the concept of gender in the European context. The term 'gender mainstreaming' is based on Article 8 TFEU, which states that 'in all its activities, the Union works to eliminate inequalities and promote equality between men and women'. As the European Commission states in its response to one of my questions, this is the result of developments at international level to which the EU and its Member States are committed. Gender mainstreaming is an integral part of the Commission's work on gender equality and serves as a guide for this work.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Equality between women and men is a cornerstone of the European Union. These must continue to be strengthened. However, the demand for ever new legislative proposals is the wrong means. The first is that existing regulations will be better implemented in all Member States. Only then can it be evaluated whether further measures are really necessary. This is where the Commission is called upon.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has played a key role in promoting gender equality. Yet, we should not be complacent. Across Europe, progress on gender equality has ground to a halt in recent years and in many areas we have gone backwards. Gender equality is not only an end in itself but an essential component in promoting fair and sustainable economic growth. In order to be effective, and to avoid fragmentation, our approach must take the form of a comprehensive and official action plan which addresses every dimension of inequality and proposes clear outputs. The Staff Working Document published by the Commission at the end of last year simply will not cut it. My Labour colleagues and I made our position clear in a resolution adopted by this parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. The December EPSCO Council agreed that this should take the form of a Commission Communication and the Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016-2020 strategy and focus on delivering concrete action.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. – The UK Delegation is fully committed to the principle of equality between men and women and we recognise that gender equality is a core value of the EU. Accordingly, we have voted in favour of those paragraphs and amendments that reaffirm the fundamental right of all men and women to equal treatment and equality in opportunity.  The UK Delegation was unable to support the text as a whole due to some notable elements which were of concern to us. First, we believe a budget should be allocated to where the need is greatest. A dedicated gender budget runs the risk of diverting funds away from other groups. Secondly, we were unable to support the call for a package of legislative proposals, initiated by the Commission. We are consistent in our firm belief that national governments are responsible for social policy and consequently cannot support the attempted ‘Europeanisation’ of this policy field. The UK Delegation was unable to support this resolution but felt it was more appropriate to abstain in this instance. We were happy to support alternative texts tabled by the EPP political group and our own group, the ECR.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. MEPs voted on several resolutions on the strategy to achieve equality between men and women.  I support actions aimed at ensuring equal pay, in particular, provided that it is a matter of aligning women's wages with those of men and not the other way around.  On the other hand, I am opposed to all quota obligations, particularly on the boards of companies. These mandatory quotas transform women into adjustment variables to meet legal constraints, thus denying their personal skills and aspirations. Of the four motions for a resolution presented, I finally supported the most respectful of the principle of subsidiarity and the cultures of the Member States, while encouraging better remuneration for women.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Gender Equality Report underlines this fundamental value of the European Union and shows that it is a determining factor in achieving European objectives, such as improving the employment rate. In order to develop sustainable, the European Union must integrate gender equality and women's empowerment into its trade policy, and the principles of inclusion and fairness must be applied in legislation and case-law, procedurally, structurally and politically, but also in everyday life. Legislative proposals that correspond to the current needs of potential women entrepreneurs, such as maintaining work-life balance, can positively influence their involvement in the labour market. Therefore, through regulations and legislation adapted to the requirements of European society, horizontal and vertical gender segregation in terms of women's access and participation in the European labour market can be drastically reduced by facilitating entrepreneurship to create a sustainable and inclusive growth economy. It is time for no further differentiation between women and men in terms of employment, position or salary.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs made our position clear in a resolution adopted by this parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. This must take the form of Commission Communication, not a Staff Working Document. The Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy, and the December EPSCO Council supported this position too. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016-2020 strategy and focus on making gender equality – a core value of the EU – a reality.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The fight against violence against women remains a daily task. At least one in three European women is a victim of violence. This is not acceptable and that is why gender issues deserve better than just an internal working paper at the Commission. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that proper communication, which covers a wide range of topics such as the gender pay gap, work-life balance and the place of women in political and economic decision-making. In addition, as a Socialist I call for zero tolerance towards all forms of violence against women. It is in this sense that EU Member States must ratify the Istanbul Convention, the only legal instrument for preventing and combating violence against women in the world. The European Commission should also present coherent European legislation that addresses all forms of violence against women. The EU Treaty obliges the Commission to act in favour of gender equality. It is up to her to act with the utmost diligence on this fundamental issue.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the new strategy for gender equality and women’s rights post-2015. Gender equality is a core value of the EU – as recognised in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights – which the EU has committed to integrating into all its activities, and whereas gender equality is essential, as a strategic objective, to achieving the overall Europe 2020 objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution calls for an explanation from the Commission for the fact that it has presented only one working document and not a real public communication on a 'New strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015'. The groups proposing this resolution consider this Approach by the Commission to be a degrading action in relation to these issues.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given that gender equality is a core value of the EU and considering the strides the European Union has taken on the matter, the Commission’s strategy for gender equality in 2015 was not comprehensive enough to affect justice in gender equality on a European level. The Commission is bound by Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union and by the Charter of Fundamental Rights to act in favour of gender equality. The Commission must now adopt a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women’s Rights 2016-2020 which is in line with the international gender equality agenda and deals with issues such as violence against women, health, education, working time, etc. The Commission should also cooperate with the Parliament and the Council in order to establish an EU summit on gender equality and women’s rights which would identify progress and renew commitments to gender equality and women’s rights within the EU.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs made our position clear in a resolution adopted by this parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. This must take the form of Commission Communication, not a Staff Working Document. The Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy and the December EPSCO Council supported this position too. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016 -2020 strategy and focus on making gender equality – a core value of the EU – a reality.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (
text: alde), in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, we must recognise that the implementation of gender equality policy in all other policies is making very slow progress overall for the European Union. There are also a number of difficulties for non-governmental organisations in this direction.  The 2015 Council Conclusions on equality between women and men in decision-making and development cooperation, reached after consultations between Member States, recognise that the empowerment of women and girls must also be accompanied by adequate financial means to meet the desired objectives.  Unresolved issues of equality would be easier to overcome and policy more strongly stimulated than the operation of a dedicated gender equality programme at EU level. I find that the new gender equality strategy should set out in 2020 such a European agenda that will ensure that the commitments of all its beneficiaries are effective.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality is a core value of the European Union. It is very important to achieve the overall EU objectives, such as the employment rate target within the Europe 2020 strategy. The current Strategy ended in 2015. The European Parliament in June 2015 urged the Commission to present a new dedicated Strategy. The Commission presented in December its ‘Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019’ staff working document which does not have interinstitutional value.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on a new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015, as the Commission's 2010-2015 strategy on gender equality was not sufficiently comprehensive to sufficiently contribute to gender equality at European and international level. The objectives, planned under this strategy, have not been effectively achieved and the new strategy provides an incentive to implement concrete measures aimed at strengthening women's rights and promoting gender equality in the areas: violence against women, remuneration, working hours, decision-making process, health, education, media and many others.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to review its strategy on 'equality between men and women'. It refers to "gender equality", the feminization of boards of directors, "women's rights", etc. However, there are some positive aspects: the need to take into account different cultural contexts from one country to another, from one region to another; respect for the sovereignty of states in the choice of wage laws... Nevertheless, it is clear that the general orientation of the document contains a very ideological aim, namely the feminization of all parts of society regardless of the complementarity of the two sexes. That is why I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the new strategy on gender equality and women's rights for the post-2015 term. I largely agree with the substance of the text and I consider gender equality to be a major issue that deserves to be treated seriously. However, this resolution is in confrontation with Commissioner Vera Jourova because she published her strategy in the form of an internal document and not a public communication. This reason of form does not, in my view, justify the Commission's criticism of this resolution, because I believe that it is the substance that must take precedence.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The post-2015 Gender Equality Strategy is a very important goal for the EU. I see gender equality as a major issue in our society. Nevertheless, the various political groups wanted to politicize the subject by attacking Commissioner Jourova in charge of this strategy. I therefore voted against this resolution, which did not focus at all on the substance of this important issue.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with this report. An attempt is being made in the Member States to implement a strategy of gender equality in everyday life and in all areas of society, which provides for far more comprehensive and preventive measures to prevent inequality, rather than paying attention to the existing equality policy between men and women. This is by no means the subject of the Union's legislation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. The EU has been instrumental in promoting gender equality. Unfortunately, across Europe, progress on gender equality has stalled in recent years and in many areas we have gone backwards. Labour MEPs made their position clear in a resolution adopted by this parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. The December EPSCO Council agreed that this should take the form of a Commission Communication and the Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016-2020 strategy and focus on delivering concrete action.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this resolution is that the European Commission adopts a transparent and public communication for a new strategy in gender equality for 2015 and after. I voted in favour of this resolution, to oblige the European Commission to fulfil its duties.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new post-2015 strategy on equality between women and men presented by the European Commission is an example of modern thinking about implementing ambitious policies, focused on clear, achievable objectives and concrete methods, free from abstract demands. The Strategy rightly recognises that equality between women and men requires the continued inclusion of women in the labour market by providing care services for adults and children and promoting a more balanced division of responsibilities. Greater participation of women in the labour market based on the principles of equal pay for equal work and fair promotions is the best recipe against women's poverty, the pension gap and the chance to make full use of talent in the economy. However, the path to full equality between women and men does not only lead through the labour market, but is primarily based on ensuring that women respect fundamental human rights. The anti-violence policy set out in the Commission document is rightly based on the methods proposed in the Istanbul Convention and the commitment of the European Union to ratify it. I call on the Commission to systematically and effectively implement the actions proposed in the strategy and to carefully evaluate the progressive change that brings us closer to achieving the call for equality between women and men.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution because we should completely condemn violence against women and all kinds of gender inequality. It is totally unacceptable in the 21st century that gender stereotypes and discrimination exist in our societies in one form or another. We should call on the EU and the Member States as soon as possible to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. The ratification of the Istanbul Convention will provide foundations for the launch of a new strategy to fight gender inequality in our societies. In this regard, it is vital to note that the new strategy should aim to make society more aware of the problem of violence against women through awareness campaigns and facilitate prevention measures such as access to justice, support for victims, etc. Last but not least, we should call on the Commission to encourage cooperation between Member States, women’s rights organizations and the social partners in order to successfully develop and implement a new strategy for gender equality and women’s rights in a post-2015 world.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution on the "new strategy on gender equality and women's rights for the post-2015 year." Of course, I am in favour of the principle of equality between men and women. However, it is up to the Member States to take the necessary steps to ensure that this principle is applied, not to the European Commission.
