However, this report calls for new proposals from the Commission on gender equality, without the current texts already being implemented.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it calls for new measures on gender equality when it would be more useful to get the implementation of the measures already voted.  I am also opposed to Amendment No.16, tabled by the EPP and voted, which calls for quotas for women on boards of directors.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The adoption of a new strategy on gender equality and women's rights after 2015 is necessary to achieve the EU's objectives in this area. This strategy requires a very comprehensive approach and priority to be given to violence against women and to all issues related to discrimination against different groups of women in the professional, economic, social and political spheres.  Equal access to quality education regardless of gender, national origin, social, cultural or religion is essential to ensure full participation in socio-economic life, improve its quality and prevent the creation of inequalities. In this context, early school leaving should also be prevented, which can lead to social exclusion and marginalisation.  Another issue is access to vocational education and training for women throughout their lives. Women are more likely to take breaks in their working lives for various reasons. They should therefore be able and encouraged to participate in tailor-made vocational education and training so that they can acquire new qualifications that will enable them to return to work more easily.  Education for gender equality is a non-discriminatory education that strives for personal, social and economic development in a spirit of tolerance, partnership, dialogue and responsibility for life in society.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the EU creating new gender equality strategies or holding a conference on gender equality, which is why I voted against.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Equality between women and men is one of the core values of the Member States, of utmost importance for achieving the EU's overall objectives. In 2010-2015, the Commission's past strategy for women's and men's equality failed to ensure gender equality at European and international level.  A new strategy is needed and must result in the right objectives and realistic results, as, according to recent Eurostat statistics, the employment rate of men in 2014 in the Member States was still higher than that of women (70.1% among men compared to 59.6% among women). Furthermore, the employment gap between women and men when it comes to entrepreneurship remains large - in 2012, women made up only 31% of self-employed citizens, i.e. only 10% of women in employment were self-employed.  In a resolution in June 2015, Parliament highlighted to the Commission the need to introduce a new strategy. As there remains a need for a strategy, a new, decidued Strategy for Gender Equality within the EU needs to be presented. As the same problems continue to arise, a resolution is needed to help strategically address these problems, and unfortunately this resolution is not appropriate, so I did not support it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the right to equal treatment, equal access to employment opportunities, education, healthcare and building a strategy for equality between men and women, taking into account a woman's unique specific maternal mission, I take for granted a part of any European Union policy. I consider it essential for the Commission to present as soon as possible a strategy for gender equality and women's rights, which will define the conditions for the natural and self-evident equality of women in all areas of life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the new strategy on women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 2/2/2016, and because this motion for a resolution is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. We voted on several motions for resolutions on the strategy for gender equality. These resolutions were diverse, which is why I supported everything that could ensure equal pay, provided that it was done by adapting women's wages to that of men, not the other way around. On the other hand, I have opposed all the quotas, especially on the boards of directors. These measures are an attack on the dignity of women, who are no longer recognized for their merit or abilities, but simply for their gender, as a simple adjustment variable!

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Resolution which ‘Considers it regrettable that the 2016 Commission Work Programme, published in November 2015, made no specific mention of the EU Strategy for Gender Equality post-2015; deplores the fact that on 3 December 2015 the Commission published only a staff working document entitled ‘Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019’, thereby not only presenting a downgraded internal document but also restricting the duration of its action’.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 When it comes to gender equality, the EU cannot get stuck in the legal distinctions between "working papers" and "strategies". What we need at the moment is the correct application of all the legislative instruments that have been approved so far.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Gender equality is a key value of the EU, enshrined in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and is a key step towards achieving the overall targets of the 2020 Strategy for growth, employment and social inclusion.  For these reasons, the European Commission should not neglect these assumptions, and it is regrettable that, in its 2016 Work Programme, no specific reference is made to the EU Gender Equality Strategy post-2015 and that in the working document 'Strategic Commitment for Gender Equality, 2016-2019' no specific objectives or budget are presented, enabling the feasibility and measurement of the targets proposed by the strategy.   To this end, I support the position of the Resolution, which calls on the Commission to present a Communication on a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights 2016-2020, which takes into account gender equality issues in the fields of violence against women, working time, health, education and taking new legislative initiatives in this regard in its Work Programme.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against the motion as it would have the effect of mainstreaming gender mainstreaming in national law. Equality between men and women is an important objective that must be pursued ambitiously. However, it should be left to the Member States to decide what paths they are taking to achieve this objective. Gender regulations at EU level are certainly the wrong way to go. In addition, individual performance and not gender should always be decisive for professional success.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to review its strategy on 'equality between men and women'. There are the recurring themes in question, those of "gender equality", the feminization of boards of directors, "women's rights", etc. The need to take into account different cultural contexts from one country to another, from one region to another, and respect for the sovereignty of states in the choice of wage legislation, are interesting aspects to note. It is clear, however, that the general thrust of the document contains a very ideological aim, namely the feminization of all parts of society regardless of the complementarity of the two sexes. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution on the new strategy for gender equality and women's rights post-2015. I disagree with the text which has been put forward which does nothing to enhance and strengthen gender equality.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Gender equality is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, deeply rooted in our society. As the five-year programme draws to a close, I believe it is essential to promote a new gender equality strategy for the post-2015 term. The Commission must urgently set out to specify the concrete objectives of the measures to be taken in the future and to establish the budget allocated to it in order to close the remaining inequalities between women and men in the Union. As you know, my fight against violence against women calls for communication on a new strategy for 2016-2020 that can respond inclusively to the challenges of tomorrow. I would like to organize a summit on gender equality.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Although not only the European Union, but at all the whole of European society, prides itself on the balanced position of men and women, we know that true equality between men and women is still not achieved. Personally, I do not see the strategy presented as an instrument to eliminate these inequalities. On the contrary, she reminded me of a picture that spreads on social media. It shows nicely the difference between justice and equality. Three kids, from the taller to the lowest, want to look over the fence, but neither reaches. Thus, each of them receives an equally high degree, which is only suitable for the highest child, the other must stand on the tips, and the third, smallest child, nevertheless or precisely because they have received "fair" help, still does not see through the fence. I see the problem in the constant twisting of the word equality. Women still do not have the same rating at work as men, and those who give birth and raise multiple children have almost no concessions. Social assistance for mothers with children is still insufficient, parental allowances are minimal. I see these and other areas as real problems for today's women, and therefore for society as a whole, and tackling them would contribute to real equality between men and women. I consider the documents and strategies that bypass them to be conscious ignorance and disregard for them.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Four draft resolutions were tabled on the new European strategy for women's rights and gender equality for the post-2015 period: the motions of the EFDD, PPE, ECR political groups and the joint proposal of the S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE groups. By my vote, I supported the latter.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is a policy which, because of its importance, must be horizontally integrated into all Member States' policies. The Union, for its part, through the EU2020 Strategy and its Gender Equality Strategy, has also taken decisive steps to ensure that gender equality is strengthened at Member State level.  I therefore consider it crucial that work continues in this area, always respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a set of motions for resolutions on the strategy to achieve gender equality. While I support actions aimed at aligning women's wages with men's (not the other way around...), I am opposed to the introduction of binding quotas, particularly on company boards. Women are not adjustment variables, and should not need quotas to access these bodies, since they deny their personal skills and aspirations. I therefore supported the resolution which most respected the principle of subsidiarity of the Member States, as well as this aspiration for equal pay.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained in the final vote of this resolution on the new European strategy for equality between men and women.  The European left criticises the Commission in this text for publishing an internal working paper on this important issue, rather than a communication as was previously the case. On the substance, I support the commission's proposals for a new strategy for gender equality, including those aimed at improving work-life balance.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to produce a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015. Indeed, we fully agree with the need for communication, on an equal footing but with greater ambition than the 2010-2015 strategy, different from the simple working document presented by the Commission on 3 December. Let us remember that this has no inter-institutional value and is considered to be of lower political importance, as it does not need to be approved by the College of Commissioners and provides neither a dedicated budget nor concrete benchmarks, making it impossible to assess the progress made on the objectives set.  With regard to this document, we also regret not only the 'downgrading' but also the narrow time perspective (here limited to 2019), which should, instead, extend to 2020 in order to commit the future College of Commissioners to this issue. Finally, we would like to stress the right call in the text of the resolution for greater cooperation between the institutions on the subject of gender equality: we are still waiting for a solution in the Council on the proposal for a directive on women in the BoDs and a new proposal for a directive on maternity leave.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. Commissioner Jourova's new post-2015 gender equality strategy presented quality commitments that deserved support. The European left, however, opposed it, in order to show a formal disagreement at the expense of an important resolution. I therefore voted against the resolution put forward by the left-wing parties, far from the necessary progress on gender equality, while respecting subsidiarity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on Member States to take further steps to address equality issues, tackle violence against women and ensure equal access and equal opportunity in health, employment and education.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. This is important not only for the role of women in the economy and society, but also for achieving the EU's wider economic goals.  On the other hand, we see that we have not even achieved the objectives of the 2010-15 strategy, the political momentum has slowed down over the last decade and the Commission is hesitant to adopt a document for the next period. This is done with discrimination against women at government level in Hungary, the average hourly gender pay gap reaching 25-30% in some Member States and 16 Member States inexplicably refusing to ratify the Istanbul Convention against Violence Against Women, including Hungary, but also Germany. How can we credibly support gender equality in our development policy in third countries when there is so much to do in our own Member States? It is clear that further efforts are needed, a coherent legal framework. It is unacceptable that, when, as a representative of both the European Parliament and the Member States, the Council calls for a concrete strategy to continue the programme, which will be expiring in 2015, with the overwhelming agreement of European citizens, the European Commission is not fulfilling its duty and is not adopting a specific document. Concrete commitments are needed, with targets and a budget for this. Without them, progress cannot be measured and there is no way to move.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report. We do not need any further implementation of gender mainstreaming in our daily lives, nor do we need further quotas to address perceived or actual inequalities. Gender equality does not mean, in my understanding, equality imposed from above.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Commission must formulate a strategic and improved plan to help resolve member states' differences in gender equality issues. The strategy of the proposal addresses, inter alia, the condemnation of violence against women and the reduction of the gender pay gap.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. – This Parliament has already stressed its Resolution of 9 June 2015 on the need and urgency of the European Commission presenting a new specific strategy for gender equality and women's rights in the EU.  The above strategy has been insufficient to help advance gender equality at European and international level while not effectively fulfilling its intended objectives. I regret that the European Commission has not yet presented this strategy, and I therefore vote in favour of a text which demands and insists that it is urgent that it do so.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women is an indicator of the real progress of a society. However, in order to be able to apply it to an absolute extent, it must be implemented through legislation, case law and everyday life. It is therefore necessary to have a new coherent strategy on women's rights which, inter alia, should address issues such as the wage gap between men and women, the harmonisation of family and working life and the position of women in the political and economic decision-making process.  It must also include specific evaluation criteria and a specific budget in order to be able to develop and progress with indicators that are measurable. The above is necessary if we are to talk about truly developed societies in which fundamental human rights can be applied unhindered and thus be able to overcome existing inequalities between men and women. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on a new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In order to create legislative frameworks that will be of sufficient quality and effectiveness to properly protect women's rights and enable the creation of a level playing field and access and equal opportunities to exercise their rights to both women and men, we must focus on the specific problems women face, as well as those in implementing existing instruments that have failed to protect women's rights.  Women need our active engagement in the fight to exercise their rights, but it must be properly targeted. We need to ensure equal access to women's education and jobs in all positions. We need to provide women with equal pay for equal work. Women deserve to have their role as mothers appreciated and create the right balance of private and work life so that they can successfully balance their role as a mother and a working woman.  In terms of protecting women's rights, we've failed a lot. By adopting hasty strategies, without clear analysis and clear and measurable indicators of change, we cannot make significant progress, but we will only go round in circles.  I did not support this resolution on the new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015, as I believe we need to focus on addressing priorities and analysing the current situation and legislation. Only then can we create new regulations.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010-2015 Gender Equality Strategy, however much it had the merit of bringing this issue to the attention of the European agenda, did not achieve the results it set itself and that we had hoped for. The Commission was supposed to propose a new post-2015 strategy, but no communication has been presented to date. Last December, the Commission published a document, but it is simply a downgraded internal document, with too little incisive and too short time horizons, in which there is a lack of concrete benchmarks and objectively measurable objectives.  The situation of women in the European Union still sees too many disparities in the world of work, education and pensions. there is a need for decisive action against violence against women, both in public and domestic places, a real social scourge that struggles to emerge and therefore be eliminated.  With my signature and my vote in favour of this resolution, I hope that we can give a new impetus to the fight for gender equality, which must remain one of the main political objectives of this European Commission.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Gender equality is one of the EU's core values, as established by treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and the EU has committed to integrating it into all its activities. Gender equality is also key as a strategic objective to achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy on growth, employment and social inclusion.  In its resolution of 9 June 2015, the European Parliament clearly called for the adoption of a new, separate post-2015 strategy for gender equality and women's rights. The need to adopt a new strategy is best evidenced by the results of the public consultation, which showed that 90% of respondents favoured a new strategy.  I therefore support calls on the Commission, in response to the results of the public consultation and the positions of Parliament and the Council, to immediately adopt a communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period 2016-2020, addressing gender equality issues in the areas of violence against women, working hours, decision-making, health, education, media and external relations, and which will be in line with the international agenda.  I also agree with the Call on the Commission to propose legislative initiatives in its work programme to address remaining inequalities between women and men in the EU, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution adopted calls for the immediate adoption of a communication on a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights 2016-2020, addressing gender equality issues in the fields of violence against women, working time, health, education, among others. Calls for the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 to be in line with the international agenda, namely the Beijing +20 document and the new framework for 'Gender equality and women's empowerment: transforming the lives of girls and women through the EU's external relations (2016-2020)'.  If, on the one hand, the Commission takes on the strategic commitment to gender equality, it is devoid of concrete objectives and a specific budget.  It reinforced the EP's call for a new specific strategy for women's rights and gender equality post-2015 (absent from its Work Programme, which says well of the Commission's position on gender equality and women's rights) and to propose legislative initiatives in its Work Programme to eliminate the remaining inequalities between women and men in the EU. From the above, we voted in favor.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Social Democrat, I reject the current state of gender inequality, and I will therefore continue to fight for women's rights in order to achieve social justice. Moreover, equal treatment and equal opportunities for women and men are a key objective for all Member States. It is therefore regrettable that the Commission's work programme for 2016 does not contain any specific reference to the EU strategy for gender equality after 2015. That the Commission is not paying sufficient attention to the issue is shown by the fact that it published only a minor internal document in December last year and also limited the duration of the measures. I therefore join the call on the Member States to take further measures targeting equality issues, address violence against women and ensure equal access and opportunities in the areas of employment, health care and education, both in the public and private sectors.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The format, not the substance, seems to be the cause of these many plenary resolutions. Again, I see that some of our fellow left-wing MEPs spend most of their time opposing on principle, instead of talking about the substance of the issues. Equality between men and women, however, is a defining issue for our societies. And the Union must take an interest in this to prevent any drift, especially through a strategy. But I repeat: most measures to combat gender inequality are taken at the level of national governments. It is a question of subsidiarity. We owe the truth to our fellow citizens, otherwise we will continue to think that Europe takes care of everything, when it should be focused on the skills for which it is most effective.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I support the creation of a new post-2015 strategy that gives new impetus and allows concrete measures to be taken to strengthen women's rights and promote gender equality, as political action and reform in this area have been slowed down over the last decade at EU level. I welcome this document which calls on the Commission to adopt a Communication on a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights 2016-2020, covering gender equality issues in the fields of violence against women, working time, decision-making, health, education, the media and external relations.  I therefore support the holding of an EU summit on gender equality and women's rights, so that progress can be identified and commitments renewed. I would also stress the importance of the Commission cooperating with Parliament and the Council during this process.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, in which this House calls for a new strategy for women's rights and equality between women and men in Europe. The finding is bitter. Actions at European level were not sufficient and the Commission's previous strategy for 2010-2015 was not comprehensive enough. We need to build momentum to ensure that the next few years see significant progress. That is why we need to launch new policies for gender equality and women's rights for the period 2016-2020, which are up to the challenges we face. It is regrettable at the moment that only an internal document in the Commission has been published on the subject for the period 2016-2019. Let's move on! Is it necessary to remember that gender equality is a fundamental value of the European Union, that it must be at the very foundations of our societies and that the necessary political actions must therefore be taken in order to achieve it?

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 concluded in December. Parliament, in its Resolution of 9 June 2015, stressed the need and urgency of the Commission presenting a new specific strategy for gender equality and women's rights in the EU. However, on 3 December 2015, the Commission presented a mere working document which has no institutional value. A genuine strategy is therefore called for in the Commission's claim to lower its level of action in this area, since it neither sets specific benchmarks nor allocates a budget and, therefore, it will not be possible to assess the progress made towards the objectives. For these reasons I support the resolution adopted by the European Parliament in order to correct these shortcomings.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission must present a full-time communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights for the period 2016-2020 and deliver on its commitments. That is the content of the resolution that I supported today. This new communication from the EU executive will have to address gender issues, while being in line with the programme set at international level, the text adds. In my view, the Commission's old strategy (2010-2015) was not comprehensive enough to contribute to gender equality at European and international level.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it calls on the European Commission to develop a new strategy for gender equality. The old strategy expired in 2015. Meanwhile, until now, the Commission has published only the Staff Working Document "Strategic action for gender equality 2016-2019", which is not binding and has no political "weight".

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which was carried out by the Socialists and Democrats, the Greens, the European Unitarian Left and the Liberals. While the European Union has taken important steps in the past to ensure equality between women and men, this resolution notes that these measures have not always been followed by sufficient effects. Indeed, the strategy for equality between men and women has not produced enough results in practice to achieve such equality. In its work programme for 2016, however, the Commission made no mention of a post-2015 strategy in this area, while under Article 2 of the EU Treaty it is obliged to take measures to promote gender equality. This resolution therefore clearly calls on the Commission to adopt a new strategy for the period 2016-2020, incorporating the results of the public consultation carried out as well as the positions of Parliament and the Council.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the founding principles of the European Union.  Since 1957, the principle of 'equal pay for equal work' has been part of the Treaty of Rome. Since the right to equal treatment is a symbolic right in European culture, it must be the subject of legislative harmonisation that is not dissonant to judicial decisions and what constitutes practical reality. The European Commission's proposal for the 2015-2020 strategy includes a number of very satisfactory measures, so I do not consider that there is a need for extra action, such as the creation of new legislation on this subject, given the already large number of existing legislation.  I do think it is important that it be implemented effectively so that the EU is going in the stride towards an increasingly just, more united and egalitarian Europe. Because I did not fully comment on the content of the proposal put forward by the rapporteur, especially in view of what I have set out in the third paragraph, I have decided to abstain—even though I consider this matter of extreme importance and great sensitivity, even considering that women's rights should play a basic role in the legislative architecture of the Union and the Member States.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because I find the text, although partially acceptable, excessively vague and incisive as a whole.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU had a Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 which came to an end last December. Previously, in June, Parliament adopted a resolution laying down the Commission to develop another strategy for the period 2016-2019. On the other hand, a consultation open to citizenship highlighted the popular views of Europeans, who are in favour of this new strategy. Unfortunately, however, on 3 December 2015 the Commission published a mere working document of its services entitled 'Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019' which is not only a smaller internal document, but is also limited in scope and reflects less institutional commitment. That is why we voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution to call on the Commission, in addition to the working document, clearly insufficient, to urgently develop a strategy with objectives, measures, measurement indicators, budget and evaluation, to implement actions for gender equality and demonstrate the Commission's true commitment to this equality in a cross-cutting manner.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. I believe that this is important, as equality in the EU is still an important battle to fight.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Women's rights are not just abstract problems – women in the European Union face wage discrimination every day, problems in re-tracing work and personal life, or a higher risk of poverty. I have therefore joined the European Parliament's call for the Commission to present a binding strategy as soon as possible on how it wants to promote gender equality between 2016 and 2020.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution because it contains an express mandate from Parliament and, previously, from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, so that the European Commission can continue, through a new strategy that succeeds it, the so-called Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015, the scope of which was already clearly limited by not achieving any of its five main lines of work in its entirety. In this way, the Commission is requested to take more seriously one of the fundamental principles of the Treaties, that of equality between women and men, ingesting it to adopt a strategy as an official communication and not as a mere working document. In my view, these are some of the evidence showing that the current European Commission has no interest in highlighting realities as unfair as the scourge of gender-based violence, persistent wage inequality or the lack of policies to reconcile personal and working life (as demonstrated by the withdrawal of the proposal to extend the Maternity Directive).

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. It contained calls for more EU interference, initiatives and taxpayer funding. Current EU policies have completely failed women, as witnessed by the attacks and rising incidents of assault and harassment in public places. UKIP believes the only people who should decide such strategies are our own elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has been instrumental in promoting gender equality. However, we cannot afford to be complacent. Across Europe, progress on gender equality has stalled in recent years and in many areas we have gone backwards. Gender equality is not only an end in itself but a key component in promoting fair and sustainable economic growth. In order to be effective, and to avoid fragmentation, our approach must take the form of a comprehensive and official action plan which addresses every dimension of inequality and proposes clear outputs. The Staff Working Document published by the Commission at the end of last year simply will not cut it. I, alongside my Labour colleagues, have made our position clear in a resolution adopted by this Parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. The December EPSCO Council agreed that this should take the form of a Commission Communication, and the Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016 -2020 strategy and focus on delivering concrete action.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that men and women should be treated equally in terms of pay, human rights and many other areas. The joint motion did recognise that equality is a matter for Member States to act on, respecting the principle of subsidiarity, which I always point out. However it went too far in proposing that a quota be applied as to how many women should be on company boards. Instead of focusing on the successful implementation of existing legislation it called for additional legislation and unjustified investment in new strategies. For these reasons I voted against this resolution, and note that it was adopted by just a small majority.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Gender equality represents one of the european union's based values. Unfortunately, many times there has been a lack of perseverance in the fight for equal rights between women and men. Women still face traditional prejudices that affect the division of domestic work, the level of education, the business environment and society as a whole. Exposure to discrimination is the biggest problem. A common opinion in society is that women can hardly compete with men in certain types of jobs, primarily in scientific and technological fields, which is why they opt for completely different professions in advance and very rarely to enter entrepreneurial waters. In addition, they face difficult work-family life adjustments, problems in terms of unequal pay, underrepresentation in politics and the economy that could affect collective decision-making.   For all of the above, aware of the magnitude of this problem, I supported the European Parliament's resolution aimed at eradicating discrimination, respecting the dignity of women, the right to equality in the labour market and raising awareness of prejudice and traditionally conditional role-sharing.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing \u2012 Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU. The right to equal treatment is an important right recognised in the EU Treaties and it is essential for the further development of society to be applied in law, practice, case law and everyday life. That is why, in the EP resolution, we called on the Commission to take follow-up to the results of the public consultation and the positions of Parliament and the Council by adopting immediately a communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights 2016-2020, addressing gender equality issues in the areas of violence against women, working time, decision-making, health, education, the media and external relations, and which is in line with the international agenda , namely the Final Document of the Beijing+20 Conference of 2015 and the new framework for gender equality and women's empowerment: How the EU's external relations can change the lives of girls and women in the period 2016-2020. On this basis, the Commission should propose legislative initiatives in its work programme to eliminate persistent inequalities between women and men in the EU.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on a new strategy for gender equality in the period after 2015, because I believe that this instrument can be crucial to achieving the overall objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion in the European Union. Although the Commission presented some guidelines on this issue in a working document ("Strategic Commitment to Gender Equality 2016-2019"), with this resolution we call on the Commission, as it did in a previous resolution adopted last year and as also requested by the Council, to exercise its power of initiative to adopt a real strategy that can deal more concretely with gender issues , including violence against women, the wage gap and work-life balance.  A working document for internal use cannot be sufficient to express the Commission's vision on this point, while more detailed action is needed to define a clear strategy to strengthen women's rights and actively promote gender equality.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I propose increasing women's participation in the labour market, but not by introducing quotas for employers, which could interfere with the freedom to do business. Furthermore, I support the abolition of the pay and pension gap, the promotion of equality between men and women in the decision-making process.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012, the European Parliament, in its resolution of 9 June 2015, clearly called for a new strategy for women's rights and gender equality for the post-2015 period, as the objectives set in the last strategy (2010-2015) were not met and were not comprehensive enough to contribute to greater gender equality.  In 2014, almost a third of women (32.2%) Since 2014, the employment rate of men in the Member States of the European Union remains higher than that of women (70.1% versus 59.6%). Over the past decade, there has been a slowdown in political action and reforms at European Union level in terms of strengthening women's rights and greater gender equality. The right to equal treatment is one of the fundamental rights of European society. I do not support the proposal for a resolution because I believe that existing legislation must be better used.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution on a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015. In the labour market, we still often see women being subject to a pre-employment relationship so that they do not have children for a few years. To change this, we need a political commitment at the highest level. However, instead of 2015, the Commission's communication on a strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015 is a Commission staff working document. In doing so, the President of the Commission sent a message that the issue of gender equality is a minor issue, given his statement that the Commission will be more ambitious on bigger issues and more modest and more restrained on smaller issues. There is still much to be done in the post-2015 strategy for gender equality and women's rights.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the joint resolution as it criticised the EU, which, despite its commitments, has not made a strategy and instead has contented itself with the presentation of a working text with a general implementation framework, which it called the "Strategic Commitment to Gender Equality 2016-2019", and which has no legislative force.  The delay in setting up a new European strategy for equality between men and women reflects the EU's general tendency towards what it considers to be of secondary importance. As ACPL, we place equal treatment between men and women in our main actions and priorities and consider that the EU's key policies on the issue are unfortunately ineffective and do not meet the real needs of societies as their aim remains to protect the competitiveness of large capital.  This objective is pursued by ensuring a cheaper labour force and flexible forms of work, as evidenced by the 2014 statistics showing that 32.2% of women employed took part-time jobs, while the proportion of men stood at 8.8%, at the same time as the EU was celebrating increases in women's employment rates.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The approach taken by the report promotes an image of individualism, which is incompatible with the ideal family for us, and which is largely responsible for the current decline suffered by Western societies.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the new post-2015 strategy on women's rights and gender equality. I believe that the aim of ensuring gender balance is an important objective. Gender equality is one of the EU's core values and is recognised in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The European Union has committed itself to incorporating this objective into all its activities, as gender equality is essential for achieving the Pan-European objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion in 2020 as a strategic objective. Together with the resolution, I regret that the Commission's work programme for 2016, published in November 2015, makes no specific mention of the EU strategy for gender equality after 2015. The European Commission has published only one Commission staff working document entitled 'Strategic engagement for gender equality (2016-2019)'. In doing so, it not only presented a downgraded internal document, but also limited the duration of the action.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The issue of equality between people before and against the law is one of the most important challenges facing humanity. The European Union also has a leading role in achieving this objective. The actual implementation of this principle is necessary for the further development of society and should be applied not only in legislation, but above all in everyday life. Unfortunately, the Commission's previous strategy for equality between women and men for the period 2010-2015 did not achieve its objective because it did not contribute sufficiently to ensuring gender equality in the EU. Therefore, in June 2015, the European Parliament called for a new strategy in this regard, which should give fresh dynamism to the issue of equality and result in concrete action. Above all, however, it is necessary to identify the reasons for the non-implementation of existing legislation in the Member States so that new legislative proposals in the field of gender equality are actually implemented. Given the extraordinary importance of gender equality, I have chosen to support the proposed resolution.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality of opportunity and gender underpins the European project as a fundamental value that defines us as a model political and administrative alliance for the whole world. Given that the idea of proposing a woman for the position of UN Secretary-General was born in the European Parliament, I am confident in our strength to produce the change of mentality needed to achieve a fair and balanced system between women and men. However, the Commission is not sufficiently involved in the transparent communication of the objectives of the 2015-2020 Gender Equality and Women's Rights Strategy. This communication from the European Parliament is a call on the Commission and the Council to make European commitments to the establishment of clear and strategic objectives to protect the fundamental principle of equal opportunities and gender in the EU, against discrimination of any kind.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the various points raised by this resolution as a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. It is regrettable that the Commission's work programme for 2016, published in November 2015, makes no specific reference to the Union's post-2015 Strategy for Gender Equality.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality is a core value of the EU and the right to equal treatment is deeply rooted in European society. Gender equality is also essential, as a strategic objective, to achieving the overall Europe 2020 objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion. I nevertheless abstained on the final vote as I am opposed to any binding quotas for women on a board. I believe that this is for subsidiarity and that Member States should decide.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i rejected the motion for a resolution to the oral question B8-0103/2016 in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure on a new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe after 2015, as there were quite a few key points for the EPP Political Group, but unfortunately they were not voted out. Among other things, points concerning the competences of the Member States and the proposals for new legislation. I believe that we must first realise everything that is in the already existing guidelines and commitments. With new proposals and promises, we will not achieve a significant shift. At first, we need to realise everything we have set out so far, but unfortunately it is not being implemented.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU had a Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 which came to an end last December. Previously, in June, Parliament adopted a resolution laying down the Commission to develop another strategy for the period 2016-2019. On the other hand, a consultation open to citizenship highlighted the popular views of Europeans, who are in favour of this new strategy. Unfortunately, however, on 3 December 2015 the Commission published a mere working document of its services entitled 'Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019' which is not only a smaller internal document, but is also limited in scope and reflects less institutional commitment. That is why we voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution to call on the Commission, in addition to the working document, clearly insufficient, to urgently develop a strategy with objectives, measures, measurement indicators, budget and evaluation, to implement actions for gender equality and demonstrate the Commission's true commitment to this equality in a cross-cutting manner.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this motion for a resolution by my colleague von Storch. In my opinion, these initiatives put the gender issue on an unacceptable level even for women themselves.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. MEPs voted on several resolutions on the strategy to achieve equality between men and women. I support actions aimed at ensuring equal pay, in particular, provided that it is a matter of aligning women's wages with those of men and not the other way around. On the other hand, I am opposed to all the quota provisions, particularly in the boards of directors in companies. These mandatory quota policies transform women into adjustment variables to meet administrative constraints and deny their personal skills and aspirations. I finally voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which was the most respectful of the principle of subsidiarity and cultural diversity of the Member States, while aspiring to a fair remuneration for women.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the EU's core values, recognised in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, for which the EU has committed to incorporate it into all its activities, and whereas gender equality is essential for achieving the Pan-European objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion in 2020 as a strategic objective. The right to equal treatment is a fundamental right recognised in the Treaties of the European Union and deeply rooted in European society, which is essential for the further development of this society, and whereas that right must be applied in legislation, practice, case-law and everyday life. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU had a Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 which came to an end last December. Previously, in June, Parliament adopted a resolution laying down the Commission to develop another strategy for the period 2016-2019. On the other hand, a consultation open to citizenship highlighted the popular views of Europeans, who are in favour of this new strategy. Unfortunately, however, on 3 December 2015 the Commission published a mere working document of its services entitled 'Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019' which is not only a smaller internal document, but is also limited in scope and reflects less institutional commitment. That is why we voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution to call on the Commission, in addition to the working document, clearly insufficient, to urgently develop a strategy with objectives, measures, measurement indicators, budget and evaluation, to implement actions for gender equality and demonstrate the Commission's true commitment to this equality in a cross-cutting manner.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I call on the Member States to take further steps to address equality issues, to combat violence against women and to ensure a level playing field and opportunities in employment, health and education in the public and private sectors.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because with this text we urge the Commission to table a communication on a new strategy for gender equality and women’s rights 2016-2020 as soon as possible, which should address gender equality issues in line with the international agenda and deliver on its political commitments. While I, along other MEPs, believe that the Commission has a clear responsibility to launch policies on equality between women and men and to address important issues such as violence against women, the gender pay gap, and the balance between personal and working life, so far it has only presented a staff working document, which has no interinstitutional value, on a ‘Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019’. What we need is a proper Commission communication that includes concrete benchmarks and a dedicated budget, in the framework of a new strategy which should provide new impetus and deliver concrete action to strengthen women’s rights and promote gender equality.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Labour Party in the European Parliament has always been very serious on the issue of gender equality. However, no complacency can be afforded. Across Europe, progress in improving the rights and the economic status of women has stalled and in some areas is being reversed. We cannot create fair and sustainable economic growth without gender equality at all levels of our society. In order to be effective our strategy must take the form of a comprehensive and official action plan which addresses every dimension of inequality and proposes clear outputs. The Staff Working Document published by the Commission at the end of last year is simply inadequate. We need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. The December EPSCO Council agreed that this should take the form of a Commission Communication and the Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016 -2020 strategy  and focus on delivering concrete action.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I call on the Commission to come up with a new strategy for gender equality and women's rights post-2015. I regret the fact that the Commission does not take this issue seriously. Gender equality is one of the core values of the European Union and much remains to be done to strengthen women's rights. It is therefore particularly disappointing to note that, according to the European Commission, gender equality deserves only a working document and not a comprehensive strategy. That is why I abstained on this point.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this resolution is to call on the Commission to immediately take a communication on a new Strategy for Gender Equality and Women's Rights 2016-2020, addressing gender equality issues in the fields of violence against women, working time, decision-making, health, education, the media and external relations , and which is in line with the international agenda, namely the final document 'Beijing +20' 2015 and the new framework for 'Gender equality and women's empowerment: transforming the lives of girls and women through the EU's external relations (2016-2020)'. The resolution is critical of the Commission's 2016 Work Programme, published in November 2015, for not making any specific reference to the EU Strategy for Gender Equality post-2015. It advocates holding an EU summit on gender equality and women's rights to identify progress and renew commitments at the next EPSCO Council meeting in March 2016 and calls on the Commission to cooperate with the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against the motion as it would have the effect of mainstreaming gender mainstreaming in national law. Equality between men and women is an important objective that must be pursued ambitiously. However, it should be left to the Member States to decide what paths they are taking to achieve this objective. Gender regulations at EU level are certainly the wrong way to go. In addition, individual performance and not gender should always be decisive for professional success.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution on the new strategy for gender equality and women's rights after 2015, as I firmly believe that we, as Europeans, do not need transgender and gender mainstream education. Every people has the right to decide for themselves how women and men behave in society. There is no need for legally laid down EU directives and laws, which also in this highly sensitive area of society are humming and destroying traditionally grown rules.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution because it is unnecessary. This is also found by 286 members, as only 337 out of 750 members voted in favour. Finally, it was only six months ago that we adopted a resolution on this matter. The European Commission has certainly promised to pursue the five existing priorities. There is simply no reason for another resolution. Furthermore, the debate in plenary has shown that there is no interest in it. Not even the chairman of the committee followed the debate to the end. I am very satisfied with paragraph 10 of the resolution, which is based on my amendments. It now states: 'Points out that the implementation of EU legislation and policy instruments must be compatible with the principles of subsidiarity and added value, that uniform rules for the practical functioning and competition of the internal market are not always necessary and that the Commission is aware of the administrative burden arising from its legislative proposals and the different cultural contexts and practices in the different Member States. , must be taken into account'. I am pleased that Parliament, which is not always the case, agrees with the opinion of the European Treaties, namely that the EU's powers here are really very limited.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has been instrumental in promoting gender equality. However, we cannot afford to be complacent. Across Europe, progress on gender equality has stalled in recent years and in many areas we have gone backwards. Gender equality is not only an end in itself but a key component in promoting fair and sustainable economic growth. In order to be effective, and to avoid fragmentation, our approach must take the form of a comprehensive and official action plan which addresses every dimension of inequality and proposes clear outputs. The Staff Working Document published by the Commission at the end of last year is disappointing and ineffectual. Labour MEPs made their position clear in a resolution adopted by this parliament last year: we need a clear, comprehensive and achievable strategy for women’s rights and gender equality. The December EPSCO Council agreed that this should take the form of a Commission Communication and the Commission’s own consultation showed overwhelming public support for a new strategy. The Commission should now adopt an official 2016-2020 strategy and focus on delivering concrete action.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 3 December 2015 The Commission has published a Staff Working Document entitled 'Strategic Engagement for Gender Equality 2016-2019' (Post-2015 Strategy). The strategy included women's rights in a feminist perspective, m.in. by promoting access to reproductive and sexual rights (abortion), the recommended 40% parity on company boards and the call for ratification of the Istanbul Convention.  The publication of the strategy in the form of a working document, not a communication, and the shortening of its time perspective were met in the FEMM committee by members from the PPE, S&D, ALDE, Verts/ALE and GUE/NGL groups. They believe that this situation detracts from the importance of EU policies related to this aspect. Against this background, a motion for a resolution was tabled regretting the lack of progress in increasing women's rights over the last 10 years and calling on the Commission to adopt a new strategy for 2016-2020 in the form of a communication.  I believe that such a demand is irrational. The Union's legal and political decisions must take account of different cultural contexts and comply with the principle of subsidiarity. The focus should be on implementing and evaluating existing gender equality legislation before new policy tools are introduced. The proposed course of action aims to consolidate ideological solutions in EU law. I therefore voted against.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support every effort to strengthen the role of women in all sectors of our society. I certainly supported this report which provides the main points for the new strategy and gender equality, in employment, health, public and private life.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I fully believe that it is crucial to achieve equality between women and men, as it would be a step that would benefit the EU in all aspects, especially social and economic. I therefore agree with the ideas presented in this Resolution. However, I believe that before we start trying to implement new measures, it is necessary that the measures of the strategy for gender equality and the rights of women prior to it be implemented optimally, through quality legislation and implementation control.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the motion for a joint resolution of the four political groups. In particular, their proposal called for the Commission to take steps towards a mandatory, post-2015 gender equality strategy in force. In fact, it is not enough for these political groups to confirm that equality between men and women remains a priority for the new Commission. According to them, the 40-page working document is also not a sufficient tool and is seen as undermining gender policies. I do not share this view. I do not believe that it is necessary to create new binding strategies and new instruments at all costs, especially if the position of equality as one of the priorities has been confirmed by the Commission and the instruments at our disposal have not yet been fully implemented and subsequently assessed. Of course, a strategy in this area is needed, but since I consider the instruments in force to be sufficient and not yet exhausted, I voted against this resolution.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Strategy for Equality between Women and Men expired in 2015 and, through a resolution, Parliament pushed for the European Commission to urgently present a new ad hoc strategy to defend women's rights and gender equality in the EU.  In the FEMM Committee, there was disappointment at the work carried out by the European Commissioner and a new resolution was tabled, which, although I agree with it, I do not think it goes into more detail on the subject in its complexity. In my opinion, the political message should have been clearer in order not to lend itself to ethical discussions, which can be easily exploited and which do little to help achieve tangible results. I hope that there will be equality of rights which is not just a great ideological manifesto, but which will result in concrete actions that go beyond ancient socio-cultural heritage and which will lead citizens to a full awareness of the importance of equal opportunities. Having made these assessments, I have chosen to vote to abstain.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Gender equality as a strategic objective is essential in achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for growth, employment and social inclusion. I did not support the new strategy for women's rights and gender equality after 2015 because I believe that the guidelines are not ambitious enough and will not lead to concrete measures to strengthen women's rights and promote gender equality. This issue deserves more attention and consideration than is given to them by this political act.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I think we witnessed significant steps in our relations with Serbia last year, which have culminated in the opening of our first two negotiating chapters. This now puts concrete substance on the accession process and clearly marks the way forward. I think this progress is the result of our common efforts and commitment, so it is positive news. In particular, the Council has taken positive note of Serbia’s submission of its action plan on the rule of law. We are now looking forward to their solid implementation and a clear track record in these areas. Let me also underline that, in line with our new approach, the Rule of Law Chapters 23 and 24 will be addressed early in the negotiations. Progress under these chapters would need to be made in parallel with progress in negotiations overall. Among the chapters that we opened in December, Chapter 35, dealing with the normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Pristina, is key. The landmark agreements that were reached in the EU-facilitated dialogue in August are an important achievement. We know that it has not always been easy politically and we have encouraged Serbia to keep up its constructive engagement by swiftly implementing its part. The Council will closely follow these developments. Progress in the process of the normalisation of relations with Kosovo needs to be made in parallel with progress in Serbia’s accession negotiations. Serbia is playing a very positive and constructive role in handling the refugee and migration crisis, which it is seriously affected by. It will be important for us to continue and to increase our close cooperation on this critical challenge for the European Union. We will, equally, continue supporting Serbia technically and financially in this field. The Council notes with satisfaction Serbia’s increasingly constructive engagement in regional cooperation and strengthening good neighbourly relations. Serbia’s role remains central for stability in the region. Serbia is an important foreign policy partner for the European Union. We commend Serbia for its successful OSCE chairmanship in 2015. It now remains essential that, as a Union and together with Serbia, we address the numerous challenges we are facing, in particular in our neighbourhood. The Council therefore calls on Serbia to progressively align with the European Union Common Foreign and Security Policy. A European Serbia is part of our common vision. Overall, we can conclude that our enlargement policy with Serbia bore fruit last year. We have made clear from our side what we now expect from Serbia, namely for legislative reforms to be intensified and effectively implemented, in particular in the key areas of judicial reform and the fight against corruption and organised crime, as well as freedom of expression and the media. Moreover, we look forward to seeing further progress in the implementation of the agreement with Kosovo. In this context, we hope that the announced early parliamentary elections will not slow down this process. It will also be essential for these elections to be held in accordance with international standards. Provided that the conditions are met, we look forward to opening further negotiation chapters with Serbia under our Presidency.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to extend, in particular, a very warm welcome to Minister Joksimović and her team, and also to the Ambassador of Kosovo. I would also like to congratulate David McAllister for his resolution on the 2015 Report on Serbia. This is a balanced and comprehensive assessment of service progress on its path to the European Union and is overall in line with the findings of our own 2015 report. Serbia has taken major steps on its EU path. I share your view that Serbia has indeed achieved a lot towards this strategic objective of EU membership. It has made concrete progress in implementing an ambitious economic and structural reform programme. Serbia remains committed to improving regional and bilateral ties in the spirit of reconciliation and good neighbourly relations. Serbia is also making progress in the reform of its public administration and strengthening the rule of law by adopting comprehensive action plans and further normalised its relations with Kosovo with key agreements reached in August last year. I am also impressed by the very positive and human manner in which Serbia and Serbian citizens are handling their unprecedented numbers of refugee and migrant flows, under very difficult circumstances and in full respect of EU core values. All these efforts required courage and commitment, and the opening of the first two negotiating chapters – namely 32 and 35 – in December last year is a well-deserved acknowledgement. Serbia should now build on this progress with a renewed commitment to moving decisively forward with reforms, in particular in the areas of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of expression, public administration, anti-discrimination, the protection of the most vulnerable groups and minorities and the economy. Of equal importance for Serbia is to continue its constructive approach and to continue making further progress in normalising its relations with Kosovo. This should run in parallel with the accession process, with a view to reaching the comprehensive normalisation of the relations targeted as the ultimate goal in our negotiating framework. I also look forward to the next step, namely the opening of the Rule of Law Chapters 23 and 24. I hope, together with the rapporteur, Mr McAllister, that this can happen in the first half of 2016. This will, of course, depend on Serbia’s ability to deliver on its commitments. In this regard, I welcome the presentation of Serbia’s dedicated action plan on minorities today in Brussels. But this will also depend on the Member States moving quickly to agree about the next steps on this. We should be careful not to add requirements not provided for under the EU acquis or the negotiating framework. It is important that bilateral disputes do not hamper the overall accession process. Finally, we have taken note of the Serbian Government’s announcement to hold national elections. We are confident that, during the run-up to the elections and after the establishment of a new government, Serbia will remain committed to its reform agenda and the dialogue with Kosovo. The European Commission remains firmly committed to supporting and guiding Serbia on its European path. I appreciate that the European Parliament is on the same page.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, just before Christmas, Serbia made a huge step forward towards European Union accession. Two years after the start of the accession talks with the European Union and only a few months after new agreements with Kosovo, the first negotiation chapters were opened. The Serbian Government, like the Minister for European Affairs, Ms Jadranka Joksimović, who is with us here today, shows commitment to the EU integration process. I would like to stress four main points of this year’s resolution on Serbia. First, the rule of law. The European Union is based on the rule of law. When a country respects the rule of law it is beneficial for its citizens, its businesses, its state institutions and the economy as a whole. Serbia should fight organised crime and corruption with determination. An independent judiciary must be guaranteed. Second, democracy. This resolution stresses the importance of an active role for the Parliament and the participation of constructive opposition forces that are so vital for a democratic society. Third, media freedom. The freedom of the media is a constituent element of democracy that cannot only be achieved by adopting laws. It is also about creating a friendly environment for an independent media. Fourth, regional cooperation. Regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations form an essential part of the Western Balkan countries’ process of moving towards our European Union. Serbia’s engagement and role to promote regional cooperation and reconciliation in the Western Balkans is most welcome. The latest agreements in the framework of the Brussels dialogue marked a significant step forward to further normalising relations between Serbia and Kosovo. Both sides must now fully implement the agreements which have already been reached. A final remark – and I would like to address the Dutch Presidency of the Council: I firmly believe that the Rule of Law Chapters 23 and 24 should be opened as soon as possible in order to help Serbia to continue on its path towards the European Union.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. In the resolution, we welcome this, and more why we call for Chapters 23 and 24 – key to the reform of Serbian society – to be opened as soon as possible. Based on the experience of my country, Slovenia, I can say that it is important to maintain the dynamics and rhythm of the negotiations. I therefore very much hope that early parliamentary elections will not affect the speed at which the reforms are implemented. Serbia needs a united and clear position at the moment on the European Union, the direction in which it is going, excellent experts, motivated officials in the civil service and the will of all citizens to achieve a common goal – a modern and economically prosperous country that plays an important role in the Western Balkans region. Serbia does not need to politicise politically diverse areas at the moment and put selfish political interests ahead of the interests of society. Responsibility to citizens will be borne by the leaders themselves. Who bears responsibility for the situation in which the Serbian media is located? As a former journalist, I cannot pass the events that marked the end of the past year in Serbia. The minister's inappropriate statement about the reporters who "easily kneel" was just a fire on... oil on fire. It has led to a protest by journalists demanding more decent working conditions. I am concerned about the state of the media in Serbia. And that is not the future I indulge in serbia. It is precisely the young people that we must make the future as promising as possible and prevent the mass abandonment of the country. In Slovenia, special attention will be paid to this in slovenia. Because if young people lose hope, Serbia has lost its future. And that's not what anyone wants.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as rapporteur for neighbouring Montenegro I worked closely with David McAllister and congratulate him on this year’s report on Serbia. Serbia is still in the relatively early stages of EU accession, having only just completed the screening process in March of last year. The report shows, nevertheless, that there has been progress in a number of areas of the acquis and that there is reason to be optimistic about Serbia’s ability to continue along this trajectory, in spite of the stresses coming about from the refugee crisis but aided by the fact that there are better relations in terms of dialogue with Kosovo. Serbia-Montenegro relations continue to be strong and are developing. The Joint Centre for Police Cooperation continues to develop and is an institution that has the potential to be further utilised in the fight against cross-border crime and corruption. I agree with David that Chapters 23 and 24 must be opened soon. An agreement regarding the exchange of social security data is also a welcome step, whilst the implementation of the existing 2015 agreement aimed at reducing mobile roaming charges across the region will also help sell the practical benefits of better cooperation. I also take the opportunity to call on the Belgrade Government to try to more closely align itself – particularly on Chapter 31 – with the EU Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), particularly over sanctions with Russia. Serbia is a key player in the Western Balkans and its EU accession process is very much part of the process of stabilising the entire region.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – I am pleased to note that the ALDE Group supports Serbia and has successfully pledged work in meeting the conditions and harmonising the standards leading candidate countries towards the European Union. I would like to thank the rapporteur, David McAllister, for his excellent document and cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs. Let us keep our eyes that we are assessing each of the western Balkan countries that want to enter the European Union on the basis of its concrete achievements, and their progress is also a contribution to the common European perspective. Based on the principle that the rule of law is the cornerstone of the European Union's enlargement policy, and when we find that Serbia has made progress in the area of judicial reform, we cannot get past the fact that there is too much policy-in-point in this area. Political interference is also recorded in the media area. Starting from the rich traditions of Serbian journalism and culture, it would be expected that all political factors in the country will be interested in media freedom, for diversity, and that the media scene will not be in the function of promoting the respective authorities. Civil society must, more than it is now, be recognised and accepted as a creative part of democratic processes, rather than something above which power can shake its discontent and desire for domination. We expect Serbia to align its foreign policy and security priorities with the European Union, because for integration into the European Union and for the common security policy, Serbia has no alternative with which to flirt. I welcome the continued progress in the process of normalising relations with Kosovo, and the success of this process undoubtedly depends on both sides. It is important that Serbia deepens its democracy, which excludes the desire to concentrate political power, which – thus teaching us experience in Serbia and elsewhere – does not lead in the right direction.
