(The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I am speaking as a friend of Serbia, but I would like to ask whether you think that Serbia needs a lot of improvement in terms of the rights, freedoms and security of national minorities. Secondly, what do think about the fact that the Serbian Government sometimes engages in anti-EU rhetoric? Do you not feel that this Government should refrain from this? Also they sometimes try to manipulate the public on this issue.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I indicated in my speech that Serbia has to be very clear in its option for our common security and foreign policy, and that I do not think that it is very productive and useful for Serbia itself but also for the integration process if they are kind of coquette, with the alternative in Moscow.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the countries of the Western Balkans have gone through very significant difficulties, particularly in the 1990s, through many wars and too much blood. Today, however, we are in a new phase in which a strong effort is being made to resolve issues, not with arms this time, but through dialogue and the will to cooperate.  The European Union should stand by this effort and, in particular, in this particular case, in the dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina to find a political solution to the Kosovo issue. Any settlement should be the result of the dialogue between Pristina and Serbia.  As a group, we support Serbia's accession path. However, we disagree with the Union's stance expressed in the report and interferes in the conduct of Serbia's foreign policy. But also in the imposition of economic models that have proven to have had such a negative impact on the peoples of Europe. Let us deepen our relations in order to support the country in its efforts to tackle very serious problems it has, to deepen the rule of law, to tackle corruption, organised crime and the refugee flows that have recently arrived in the country.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – First of all, I would, of course, like to warmly thank Mr McAllister for his excellent work and all my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their good and successful cooperation. I think we have all managed to produce a very good text for serbia's 2015 progress resolution, which includes all the important aspects. Like my predecessors, I believe that Serbia has made great strides in the last year, which is clearly visible by opening the first two chapters, and I sincerely hope that the government will continue with such momentum and motivation as well as... So far. I think it is important that Serbia remains a leading and strong player in establishing good cooperation and relations in the countries of the Western Balkans region. These good neighbourly relations actually benefit everyone, of course Serbia, the environment and, of course, the economic development itself. McAllister also stressed the importance of the rule of law. I would add that, of course, the rule of law actually affects everyone. It affects society, the economy, the state of democracy, human rights, reasonable trial deadlines, an independent judiciary and these are all things that we must of course be aware of at all times and where improvements are always possible. As well as relations between the Serbian Government and the non-governmental sector, there is still room for improvement, particularly in the area of communication and consideration of opinions, in the state of civil society in the decision-making processes. And, of course, I would also join those who also point to the situation in the media, the so-called self-censorship, the position of journalists and, in fact, the fact that there is actually no fear if you also say something that is not like, of course, government or authorities. Finally, the only thing that Serbia has played an important role in the migration crisis, which cannot be overlooked, and I wish Serbia a happy and courageous forward even after the elections.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this progress report perfectly highlights a key aspect of the upcoming UK referendum on our EU membership, when the British people will not just be voting on our current relationship with the European Union but also on the prospect that a ‘stay’ vote grants de facto permission for the EU to move, full steam ahead, with their neo-colonialist ambitions. In the midst of the current migration crisis, the promise of reaching the UK, Sweden and Germany and the rest of the EU has – as we have witnessed – placed a great burden on Serbia. This situation will become further compounded by eventual Serbian EU membership. I cannot fathom how the EU’s proposed solution to the current migration crisis – bringing its borders closer to the Middle East and thus further facilitating this mass transit of people – can be seen as doing anything other than compounding this crisis further. The increasing public concern over the issue of the free movement of people perfectly underlines the failure of Mr Cameron’s farcical renegotiation and supports the case for Britain to see the EU for what it is and, accordingly, to vote to leave for a brighter and bigger future. The world is our oyster, but inside the European Union, Britain’s future is as a clam.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Serbia is no doubt destined to join the forthness of the union to come, renovated by the people, even if efforts are still to be made in the fight against crime. But why, if this report claims to balance, silence the acts against the Serbs and the Orthodox Christian culture committed in Kosovo, mafia state? Why silence our duty of repentance, our shame for our crimes committed against the Serbian people: NATO propaganda, false evidence of ethnic cleansing invented by Germany to justify the bombings, all the false propaganda to justify the unjustifiable, the economic destruction of a country and its civilian population? Why silence the international, one-sided, ideological justice that suppresses even people so that they do not speak? Why silence our lie about Kosovo, a mafia state that we, Europe, built on the basis of criminal networks, by dismembering it from Serbia? More generally, our enlargement policy is a disgrace to a European Alsatian. Instead of making all these Eastern European countries bridges between East and West, you turn them into countries from one side to the other, fractures, ruptures, to the benefit of Western domination, in the service of the United States. Your enlargement policy is anti-European.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Do my fellow Members know that the report on Serbia is on the agenda?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, Serbia has made significant progress in its efforts to become a full member of the European Union. This effort is of particular value because You are asking Serbia to take tough and serious decisions, such as, for example, to harmonise its foreign policy with that of the European Union, including Russia, not to weaken Vojvodina's autonomy, to deal with those who have been classified as war criminals and to address the different perception of history in the region.  Moreover, its accession path has been linked to progress in relations with Kosovo and the recognition of Kosovo, which, as we know, is the historical cradle of the Serbian nation. But while the European Union is asking Serbia to be consistent with all these obligations, it is not doing the same with Kosovo. There it tolerates the violation of a basic principle of the Republic, the separation of powers and the Parliament of the country to circumvent and not accept decisions of the Constitutional Court.  So two measures and two weights, so the question arises: do we want Serbia in the European Union or are we simply playing it to satisfy the political aspirations of some states, especially Germany, which is responsible for everything that is happening today in the European Union?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate my colleague, David McAllister, on his report in which he underlines Serbia's progress towards European integration. Of course, this progress allowed Serbia to open the first negotiating chapters with the Union on 14 December. I'm very glad that this happened. This is an important point in the European course of this country.  I would like to mention in this context the situation of the Romanian minority in Serbia. The McAllister report contains a substantial paragraph on the topic of minority protection, a paragraph to which I contributed through amendments. This is not the first time we have spoken about the rights of the Romanian minority, which must become a reality, that it is about representation, access to education, religious services or the press.  Finally, because I am the rapporteur of this Parliament for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would like to say that there are some ambiguities in Belgrade that need to be removed. In particular, I believe that Prime Minister Vučić must make a very clear choice between Russia's position, which supports the planned referendum in Republika Srpska, and the alignment with the European position, which sees in this referendum as a blocking factor in Bosnia and Herzegovina's European integration. I am pleased to welcome here the Presidency of the Council which, in a few days' time, on 15 February, will receive Bosnia's request, and I am convinced that it will be an important moment.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr McAllister, if you can still tolerate it, i would like to congratulate you on that too! Of course, we can clearly see that there is still a great deal to be done in Serbia. But the progress that has been made cannot be overlooked either. In addition, we have every reason to thank the government and the people for the European spirit they have shown in their help on the refugee issue. The first two negotiating chapters were opened in December 2015. Chapter 35 is also about progress in normalising relations between Serbia and Kosovo. It is true that this chapter should be opened as one of the first, because for Serbia and Kosovo to be successful in the EU, it is essential that relations between the two countries allow constructive cooperation both on all issues of neighbourly cooperation and within the EU institutions. I believe that it is at least as urgent – and it has already been mentioned several times – that accession negotiations for chapters 23 and 24 should now be opened quickly. Since the opening of accession negotiations with Montenegro, the Commission has rightly argued that these chapters should be opened first and finally closed. Reforms to strengthen the rule of law bring the most positive changes to people's everyday lives; they strengthen democracy and allow faster progress to be made in other areas. However, they cannot be implemented from one day to the next. Successful reforms are based on the long-term entrenchment of the principles of the rule of law, such as the limitation of state power by law, the independence of the judiciary, and the granting of fundamental and freedom rights. That is why the Commission should have a demanding and encouraging enlargement policy in this area – perhaps a little more than it has done so far.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the first chapters in the negotiations with Serbia have been opened and this is progress, but we should not kid ourselves that there have been some special turns in Serbian politics. Serbia's efforts to normalise relations with Croatia are minimal.  Questions are still open about missing persons and recognition of the existence of camps for Croats on Serbian soil in the Homeland War, as well as the return of Croatian property and cultural treasures. Initiatives on common European defence and the military are increasingly coming from the Commission and this home. Member States and their citizens should trust their partners and neighbours immensely, so much so as to put their security in their hands.  How do you expect Croatian citizens to believe in joint defence in some future wars if the Commission has so far been unable to defend the dignity of the victims of the last great war on European soil, but continues to give in to Serbia because of particular interests?  Mr. Delegate, you cannot ask that bilateral interests not interfere here if this is the only way to resolve these interests and problems. (The Speaker accepts to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Of course, it is safe to criticise everything, and I myself am often dissatisfied with certain reform processes in relation to the associated countries, but the fact is that this current Commission has in fact suspended the accession processes for 5 years. Do you think that this has not had a disingenerative effect on the Serbian processes, and perhaps this is where the problems should be traced back. I don't know. What do you think of that?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague Szanyi, it was not Croatia that attacked Serbia, but Serbia attacked Croatia. So when you attack one state you have to admit that you have carried out aggression and you have to do everything that is required of you.  Serbia would like to close its eyes and act as if nothing had happened. What are you going to do with those refugees? What about the hundreds of raped women who haven't gotten justice yet? What are you going to do about those stolen kidnapped treasures still on Serbian soil? Doesn't Croatia have the right to ask for some kind of content?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there are long-standing expectations of Serbian citizens to start negotiations and start the process of Serbia's entry into the European Union. That is why it is good, Mr. Commissioner Hahn, that we have opened negotiations and that we have initiated the process of Serbia's entry into the European Union. Serbia's series of positive steps in regional stability should be appreciated. Serbia's role in the migrant crisis should also be appreciated. This definitely needs to be indicated and should be further assisted as we know the migrant crisis will continue.  What is also important in all this is that Serbia respects the rights of minorities. Not only of course the Croatian minority, but also of all other minorities, Romanian, Bosniak on Sandzak, to speak openly about the right to autonomy of Vojvodina, this must not be questioned. Also, of course, we must not leave out either the issue of the judiciary, nor the issue of press freedom.  Overall, I think further chapters should be continued and opened, as this will allow for further democratisation of Serbia.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: I can see, Mr Carver, that you're applying for the Catch the Eye Blue Card procedure, but you've just commented in a minute and a half. Many of my fellow Members are waiting for the eye procedure. I can't give you a word. He had a chance to say what he wanted to say. Please understand, it's a long list.

name: Tamás Meszerics (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I believe that we in this Chamber have many and very strong reasons to support the accession process of Serbia. I agree with my colleagues that Serbia has already made considerable progress on this road. I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur on a very strong and balanced report and I urge everybody to vote ‘yes’ in the vote next time. As a friend of Serbia, however, I would like to raise one point that has already been underlined by my esteemed friend Charles Tannock, and that is that, sooner or later, Chapters 30 and especially 31 of the acquis will be opened. As a historian I fully understand that nations have traditional friends among the great powers, but this is going to raise issues because the acquis requires an accession state to contribute to the common foreign and security policy. There may be political powers which Serbia might be looking for which are trying to undermine the common foreign and security policy, but I am just warning that these are exactly the same political forces that are against enlargement.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have just returned from a mission in Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia and I would like to say that Serbia is a great nation, an unmissable nation, a European nation.  Serbian leaders love Europe but not the European Union. Serbian leaders want Europe, but not Europe of radical Islamism as practiced in Bosnia or Sanjak. Serbian leaders want Europe, but a Europe that respects peoples and identities against the desires for separation, as in Vojvodina. Serbian leaders want peace, but without NATO's tutelage. Serbian leaders want European integration, but the Serbs do not want to become the new Kosovo. Let us help this friendly people, this Serbian people so that they become a true European nation.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate David McAllister on the report, which is both balanced and objective. My congratulations also go to Commissioner Hahn for guiding Serbia to open the accession negotiations and my encouragement to the Dutch Presidency to carry on actively along this path. Serbia first opened negotiating chapters last year. Expectations towards the country have thus been raised. This also sends an important message to the whole region of the Western Balkans that the integration process is going on. Serbia has made good progress in many policy areas and we should appreciate that. Yet, at the same time, it is clear that the country needs to strengthen its democratic institutions, the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary, and also its activities in regional cooperation, including the dialogue with Kosovo. Despite the dramatic situation in the whole region, as a country negotiating EU accession, Serbia needs a free, plural and independent media landscape free from political pressure. No doubt Serbia is an important partner in the region and one which we should be able to rely on. The migration crisis has shown that Serbia is, in many respects, on the same board as the EU. I have no doubt that this attitude will also prevail in other areas of our foreign policies in the future.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I join others in this Chamber in welcoming the opening of the first EU negotiating chapters, including Chapter 35 on normalisation of relations with Kosovo. I also want Chapters 23 and 24 on justice and fundamental rights open for this and all accession countries, and I support Commissioner Hahn’s efforts in this respect. In Serbia, as in some other Balkan countries, this is the correct way to address concerns about deteriorating human rights. Early elections in April will be a test of the quality of the country’s democracy, especially for the rights of opposition parties, and Human Rights Watch says that freedom of the press in Serbia is under threat. The OSCE reported 34 attacks on journalists in 2015, and the Balkan Investigative Reporting Network has published accounts of independent media being smeared as foreign spies by the tabloids. I ask the Commissioner to comment in his reply on one further difficult issue, but one which we should not dodge: what we should read into the joint military exercises between Serbia and Russia. I join colleagues in appealing for European solidarity with all in Serbia, including in relation to security issues, but I am pleased that the EU is showing that same solidarity back by devoting some of the Trust Fund for Refugees to assisting the country, recognising Serbia’s commitment to engage in the EU quota system. We want Serbia to be part of European integration and to be part of European solutions.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I too want Serbia's integration, but for the good of the people, not for politicians. That is why I will say a few critical things (three): 1. the press: in Serbia, journalists are subjected to intimidation by politicians, they are threatened, they are even physically assaulted. This must stop, because there is no democracy without freedom of the press; 2. The judiciary: I am glad that Serbia has adopted an action plan on the reform of the judiciary, but the most important thing is implementation. If we don't see investigations, final convictions for politicians, oligarchs, businessmen who have made their fortunes in the fog of transition, then nothing is credible. It remains a plan on paper; 3. In order to make progress also on the accession path, Serbia must review its foreign policy towards Russia and move decisively westward.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – My fellow Member David McAllister has successfully summarised the issues that defined last year in the Serbian euro integration process. Important steps have been taken, which have led to the opening of the first negotiating chapters with Serbia. It is also important that the EU's partnership with Serbia deepens, for example, in dealing with the migrant crisis, where, unfortunately, we have to say that in many cases the EU has remained ind payful to Serbia in terms of the formulation of precise expectations. At the same time, serbia still has important tasks to do in order to catch up on a number of topics. Among the priorities, I would like to mention the provision of the rule of law and human and minority rights, in particular because the Commission and the Council will examine the steps taken in this area in the coming months to give the green light for the opening of negotiating chapters 23 and 24. Serbia has drawn up many promising law action plans in recent months, but we are well known that implementation is the key, and this is important not only because of the opening of the negotiating chapter, but primarily so that the citizens of Serbia enjoy a rule of law at European level as soon as possible. This is particularly important for national minorities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina, to which I belong. I believe that this parliamentary report seeks to provide further impersiment and guidance to Serbian governance on the road to the EU.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is good to stand here to see the commitment of Serbia to European integration. Indeed, the Commission concludes that Serbia is building a track record on implementing the obligations in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA). The commitment to European integration is bearing fruit; in fact, negotiations opened in December. That is a good sign, and Serbia has taken steps ranging from normalisation with its relations with Kosovo to reducing the government budget, and it is good to see that. At the same time, opening negotiations and opening chapters is not the same as closing them or closing the negotiations. There is still a lot of work that needs to be done. Let me highlight two of the points. Last September I was at the Gay Pride parade in Belgrade, and there was a cordon of policemen. I do not think they were there to protect the participants in the Gay Pride; they were there rather to protect the population of Belgrade against the LGBTs. This only shows that the position of LGBTs is still very poor in Serbia. Secondly, freedom of the media, which is essential for any democracy, is still shaky. I have read the Human Rights Watch report and there were many molestations of journalists and media workers reported in Serbia. So a lot of work needs to be done. I thank David McAllister for a very balanced, good report, and I would like to underline that I would very much like to see the opening of Chapters 23 and 24 as a good sign of faith, but also as a sign that a lot of work needs to be done.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam Vice-President, Minister Koenders, Respected Commissioner Hahn, Minister Joksimović, first of all I thank our colleague David McAllister for another well-prepared report on Serbia's progress and I appreciate that he has incorporated into it a series of constructive amendments that we as Croatian MPs have tabled.  I welcome the opening of Chapter 32 on financial supervision and the chapter on other issues involving the main issue of normalisation of relations with Kosovo. It is essential that Serbia continues reforms in the area of two key systemic chapters -- Justice and Fundamental Rights and Justice, Freedom and Security. I am pleased that the report clearly emphasises the need for judicial independence and ensuring media freedom, as key European values and preconditions for Serbia's further journey on the road to the European Union.  It is therefore important that the report correctly warns against the need to depoliticise public administration and to protect minority rights in accordance with international treaties and bilateral agreements. Adequate representation of minorities in local, regional and national representative bodies should be achieved and the possibility of using minority languages in media and education should be ensured. Therefore, the shutdown of minority media programmes due to privatisation and the unresolved issue of textbooks is worrying.  It is important that Serbia also enables the discovery of missing persons from the 1990s and continues its co-operation in prosecuting war crimes with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. I also expect the disputed law on the expansion of jurisdiction in other countries to be addressed, and I hope that this issue will also be resolved in dialogue with neighbours and with the help of the European Commission.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I welcome Mr McAllister's report on Serbia. As chairman of the informal group "Friends of Serbia" and as a Romanian MEP, I am extremely happy for the opening of chapters 32 and 35, the latter referring to the process of normalising relations with Kosovo. This demonstrates Serbia's seriousness and commitment to the European integration process. On this occasion I congratulate Serbia on its constructive approach to the migration crisis compared to other Member States of the European Union. At the same time, I believe that Serbia needs to step up its efforts in terms of the protection of minorities and their non-discriminatory treatment, with a focus on education, access to the media and religious services in the language of national minorities. In the process of European integration, a permanent political will is needed, effort and sacrifice is needed. That is why I think it is imperative that all European institutions show their support for Serbia. We must assure the pro-European Serbian people that their efforts and the authorities are working and that they belong in the European Union.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I am pleased to welcome serbia's progress, as the report by my colleague McAllister is fairly noted. The opening of negotiations represents a significant shift in the accession process, which demonstrates that Serbia has sufficiently fulfilled the agreed commitments at this stage. I want Serbia to maintain a stable, reform and pro-European line, regardless of the elections, in the spirit of pre-accession commitments. The same applies to the dynamics of pragmatic development of good relations with Kosovo. I will not compete with those who list what is another problem in Serbia, but I join a number of colleagues who are campaigning for the imminent opening of Chapters 23 and 24. Not because I'm impatient, but because these are areas where progress is most needed and desirable.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my colleague McAllister on a really good report on the state of affairs and Serbia's progress over the last year. An improved legislative framework to be followed by effective implementation, participation in peacekeeping missions, progress on the Euro-immigration path are just some of the positive moments. At the same time, this report covers much of the content of last year's reports, which means there is still a lot of work ahead for Serbia. Threatened media freedom, an insufficiently effective fight against corruption, progress in the rule of law, opposition participation in democratic processes, respect for human and minority rights, alignment with european union foreign policy are part of the to-do list serbia must accede to without delay. The opening of negotiations with Serbia marks the beginning of positive pressure aimed at seriously transforming a large number of sectors in Serbia. As the report pointed out, it is of utmost importance in this process to improve relations with neighbours and resolve remaining bilateral issues, such as border demarcation, determining the fate of the missing, the circumstances, minority rights in Vojvodina and the law on prosecuting war crimes.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – It can only be welcomed that, after a difficult year, accession negotiations with Serbia finally started last December. However, substantial progress requires that the symbolic opening of the 23rd and 24th negotiating chapters take place this year, i.e. serbia's real achievements in the areas of democratic rule of law, legislation and justice, as well as fundamental human and minority Community rights.  It is typical that most of the amendments received in the McAllister report fall within the scope of minority rights. In the past, there have been several cases of excessive leniency in minority cases when some countries joined. Let us not make the same mistake in the case of Serbia. As a Hungarian from Romania, I have maximum expectations for the minority action plan and serbia's minority policy, protecting the interests of Hungarians and Romanians and VLachs in Serbia. Their fulfilment should be an indispensable precondition for the country's inclusion in the EU.

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The EU has much to gain from the eventual creation of an open and well-functioning Serbia as a new Member State. That is why it is important for the EU to speak with one voice and convey a unified message, so that Serbia has a stable counterpart to relate to in the run-up to the further accession negotiations.  I therefore welcome the European Parliament resolution which recognises the ambitious reform agenda that Serbia has embarked on, and which calls on it to continue with the reforms necessary for future EU membership. It is particularly important to push Serbia forward in its efforts to guarantee the rule of law, media freedom, democracy and human rights.  This is perhaps the criterion that the country is furthest from fulfilling, but which is crucial for European integration. In this work, europe must ensure that Serbia receives sufficient support to meet the requirements, because as much as we have to gain from Serbia approaching europe, we have to lose out because it would choose a different path.

name: Андрей Ковачев (
text: PPE). – Madam President, Serbia's European integration guarantees peace and economic prosperity not only for Serbian citizens, but for the whole region. However, this process necessarily goes through overcoming communist and nationalist practices from all countries that have divided the region in the past but have relapses in the present. Fate has determined different ethnicities – Serbs, Bulgarians, Hungarians, Croats and others to live in the same place. Our goal today is not just to live next door, but to live together in good neighborliness. Nationalism has never done anything good for people. In the presence here of the Serbian Minister for European Affairs, I would like to call on the authorities in Belgrade to satisfy the will of the citizens of Tsaribrod and return the historical name of the city instead of the current divisive name of the communist dictator Dimitrov. I also call for the multi-annual saga of translations and the publication of textbooks in the languages of national minorities to finally be finalised so that young citizens of different ethnicities can study the subjects in their mother tongue. These steps in the right direction will prove that Serbia is changing and taking its rightful place among the family of European peoples. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ecr), a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague Kovachev, I agree with you with regard to the name of Tsaribrod – of course, it must return. But I would like to ask you, do you not think that the Serbian state should first of all guarantee all the rights and legitimate interests of the Bulgarian national minority recognized by the peace treaties and stop harassing the representatives of this minority, for example the case of Ivan Nikolov, the case of Dimitar Dimitrov and guarantee the rights of the Bulgarian community in Serbia – this would be a condition for integration Isn't that right?

name: Андрей Ковачев (
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr Dzhambazki, indeed, on the one hand, Serbia has perhaps one of the best laws with regard to national minorities, but the issue of the application or practice of this legislation has come under great criticism. In many places in the past, these practices are abused in local authorities, courts, prosecutors and police, and people from national minorities have problems. What you said is accurate. The Bulgarian national minority in Bosilegrad and Tsaribrod has repeatedly experienced poor or negative treatment by the Serbian authorities.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In the NEGOTIATIONS between the EU and Serbia, human rights are by far the most important area that will also determine how well the objectives are achieved in other areas.  There are still considerable concerns about the implementation of anti-discrimination legislation, particularly with regard to the rights of LGBTQI people. Civil society in Serbia today is doing a good and extremely important job and it is very important that it is supported for its activities and involved in all human rights policy work on the basis of the principles of democracy.  During an AFET/DROI delegation trip to Serbia last September, I raised the issue of men's increasing violence against women with Prime Minister Buzek, where he said at the time that they need and will improve legislation to protect women who are victims of violence so that they are up to EUROPEAN standards. I want us to follow this up, and see it as a very important security issue.  As far as the situation of the Roma is concerned, it is very worrying in Serbia. I am pleased that the report has taken up this, it is a very important part of the report. But to get success in this, you need to.... (The speaker declined a question ("blue card") from Buonanno.)

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, relations between Serbia and Kosovo must be an integral part of the negotiation process for Serbia's accession to the European Union. I am very glad that these negotiations have started with Chapter 35, which deals with these relations. But I have a question about last week, when there was a very lengthy meeting in Brussels between High Representative Mogherini and the Prime Ministers of Serbia and Kosovo, and we did not learn too much information about the negotiations. This was to concern, in particular, the implementation of an agreement to strengthen the status of municipalities in the north of Kosovo, an agreement whose validity has been suspended by the Kosovo Constitutional Court and which is very unpopular among the Kosovan people. Could you tell us, Commissioner, whether there are any conclusions from the negotiations to unblock the implementation of this agreement in Kosovo and what role will the European Union continue to play in the implementation of this agreement?  (The speaker rejected the question asked by Gianluca Buonanno by raising the blue card).

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the continuation of Serbia's European path is important for normalising relations in Southeast Europe, which is the interest of all neighbours, but also of the European Union. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with Serbia's progress in respecting the rights of national minorities. This is specifically related to the shutdown of media broadcasting in Croatian as well as the languages of other national minorities.  The lack of financial support for the printing of textbooks in Croatian and the lack of political representation of Croats constitutes a gross violation of the interstate treaty and the acquis of the European Union. I ask that Serbia change the Law that took the role of little Hague and which is a threat to Croatian defenders from the 18 Member States of the European Union.  I call on Serbian authorities to reconsider the decision to rehabilitate Draza Mihajlovic's 2015 regime, and for Serbian politicians to refrain from radicalising public space. By resolving these outstanding issues, Serbia will send a clear message that it is ready to respect the acquis of the European Union, continue the integration process with the Union and build good-budgetary relations with the countries in its surroundings, which is a common goal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union, and in particular Germany and Austria, with its foreign policy in the 1990s, bear an important responsibility for the dismemberment of Yugoslavia. After a decade of wars and NATO bombings targeting Serbia, serbia was found to have lost significant territory inhabited by Serbian populations. It lost access to the sea, but also the cradle of Serbian culture, namely Kosovo, while important infrastructure was destroyed.  In a society which has been in a state of economic insecurity ever since, the European Union is coming and in its most hypocritical way is calling, here and now, for an absolute adaptation to the Western European standards of state organisation. And as if that were not enough, the European Union is calling for Belgrade to de facto recognise Kosovo, which, among other things, reinforces Albanian nationalism.  We highlight Serbia's positive role in the refugee crisis and state that Orthodox Serbia's position is in Europe and the Greek people support Serbia's European course.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, and I would like to support all those who have spoken here about the importance of Serbia's European path because it will lead to the democratization of the state and society and is important for the entire area of the Western Balkans, but I would like to point out one controversial process that is happening in Serbia, which is the process of privatization of the media that leads to a concentration of media that can be dangerous to media freedom and in the meantime led to the shutdown of a number of media in minority languages.  Protecting media freedom and protecting minority rights, especially the right to inform minorities in their own languages, is one of the fundamental democratic rights, which is why I call on the European Commission and the European Parliament to monitor the process of privatization of the media very closely, especially the right of minorities to inform in their own language.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I just wanted to take the floor as rapporteur for Kosovo – and I will speak straight afterwards – but I would like to express my appreciation for the work done and the good cooperation with the rapporteur, Mr McAllister. I would also like to express my appreciation for the progress made in Serbia in recent months and years on many grounds – in the dialogue with Kosovo, but also on other grounds, for example, the fight against corruption – I find that extremely important. I also support the opening of two chapters with the European Union in negotiations there because I want Serbia to become a member of the European Union, as I want Kosovo to become a member of the European Union. I would nevertheless like to raise two issues which are of huge concern to me as a European citizen. One is that, in the dialogue between Serbia and Kosovo, there is the principle of good neighbourly relations, as in the European Union. This means that Serbia should support Kosovo’s bids to join the United Nations or to join organisations like FIFA or UEFA or others and not block them, because that is being part of a cooperative international community. I would also like to call on the authorities not to go against certain critical journalists and media, because that is also part of democracy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, mr McAllister's report mentions many important issues and touches on issues that we fully support: the problem of the judicial system, which is still aggravated by backward causes and is also under political pressure; corruption, which is an absolutely persistent scourge, not to mention discrimination against vulnerable groups such as LGBTI and linguistic minorities; the necessary participation of civil society and the opposition in the political process and also in integration, not to mention rhetoric that is still too militaristic.  Unfortunately, however, the report suffers from a great evil: it touches on the subject of relations with Russia. I do not understand why we persist in seeing these as an obstacle and not as a means of relaunching a serious and frank political dialogue and putting on the table the issues that have divided us over the years, all the more so since in reality our policy is also very ambiguous and very different and varied. Just think that, while on the one hand we are calling for intransigence, on the other hand we are negotiating the doubling of the North Stream. Then we finally decide on a line and start using common sense. Let us take advantage of this opportunity, which may not happen again.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – I want to address the situation of national minorities in the context of the EU Progress Report on Serbia. The Law on National Councils has still not been changed. According to the Constitutional Court, the deadline was the end of 2014. The EP urges the adoption of the law as soon as possible. However, this does not oblige Serbia to do anything. Meanwhile, national councils are unable to function properly because of cuts to their powers. Following media privatisation, programmes will cease to be broadcast in minority languages. This means a violation of acquired rights. In the report, the EP calls on the Serbian Government to implement international conventions on the rights of minorities. That's the word I'm asking, it's very little. It is about the implementation of international obligations. Serbia should be clearly called on to do so here.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, at the beginning I would like to congratulate Mr. McAllister on the extraordinary report that covered everything we have talked about over the past few years, but also a lot of amendments we have given, especially those of us from Croatia.  However, a lot of the same details from past reports are repeated, which means that there is a long list of jobs that Serbia still has to do. In any case, what I would put an accent on is the alignment of Serbia's foreign policy with that of the European Union. I especially mean relations with Russia, but also the part related to Bosnia and Herzegovina where Prime Minister Vucic supports the referendum on Republika Srpska, which in my opinion is unacceptable.  Of course, there are also minority rights, especially Croatian minorities and their participation in the Serbian Parliament, then the autonomy of Vojvodina and recognition of its cultural diversity, but also the return of cultural goods and the fate of missing persons. We will insist on this and I would like to thank you for including this in this report as well. I believe that during this process we will resolve this issue bilaterally.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – I think that recent steps have been taken by both Serbia and the European Union to accelerate the country's European integration. This is certainly encouraging, but at the same time I would like to draw attention to the situation of national minorities. The aim in the accession negotiations is to establish a durable mechanism that gives irrevocable powers and opportunities to the Province of Vojvodina, strengthens the powers of national councils and regulates all sub-areas that legitimate organisations of minorities consider important for the future of communities. The coming period is important because experience has shown that, after becoming a Member State, regression in the majority-minority relationship can begin, as has happened in Romania and Slovakia. At the same time, it is important that the commitments are made before accession, since in Romania the minority law adopted by the government in 2005, two years before accession, has not yet been adopted by the legislature and the EU is no longer able to enforce it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I congratulate my colleague David McAllister on the balanced report on Serbia, which is very encouraging. Serbia has made great strides in a number of areas, which is why Serbia quite rightly opened Chapters 33 and 35 on 14 December last year. Serbia has emerged as a very responsible and stable partner in resolving the migrant crisis. I believe that this will continue to be the case, when the migrant flow continues along the Balkan route. A stable, democratic and economically prosperous Serbia is a guarantor for young Serbs to see a bright future at home in Serbia, and such Serbia is a prerequisite for a stable whole Western Balkans. Serbia must help Serbia along the path of urgent economic reforms and improve transport and environmental infrastructure with sufficient pre-accession assistance. With the help of IPARD resources, we also create new jobs. I expect the opening of Chapters 23, 24, which talk about justice, fundamental rights, freedom, security, earlier this year. The report mentions the problems in these areas, and the opening of these chapters and the democratisation of Serbian society is a prerequisite for things to go in the right direction. I wish Serbia well after the elections and succeed on the European path.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting debate, which reflects the importance of the enlargement process. As a key stabilising factor in and for the region, I fully appreciate the sensitivity of bilateral issues where further efforts will be needed to overcome the legacy of the past. At the same time, as I mentioned in my introduction, we should ensure that bilateral issues do not hamper the accession process. Part of the negotiation process, by the way, is also a gradual alignment with European foreign policy. In that respect, a joint military exercise with Russia does not send the right signal. The effective and impartial handling of war crimes in line with international standards features high in our negotiations with Serbia. We will carefully monitor the implementation of the measures Serbia has undertaken in its Action Plan on Chapter 23 to address our recommendations on the need for efficient and impartial treatment of war crimes, equal treatment of suspects, proportionality of sentences and protection of victims. I also take note of your concerns regarding the protection of national minorities. This is also a key requirement for Serbia. The legal framework is broadly in place and we are closely monitoring its consistent implementation across Serbia, particularly in education, the use of languages and access to religious services and media in minority languages. In the end, Serbia needs to guarantee all these rights in practice. Here again, we will monitor Serbia’s progress in implementing the measures it undertook under its Rule of Law action plans and the dedicated action plan on national minorities. Once again, thank you for this valuable report, to all of you who contributed to it.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, from my side I would also like to express my sincere gratitude for the report and the commitment of the rapporteur, Mr McAllister. I have the impression that this has been a very useful debate. Serbia now has a clear path for moving ahead in the accession process and, most notably, in the area of the rule of law and the normalisation of relations with Kosovo. Mr McAllister mentioned the need to open Chapters 23 and 24. Let me also underline from my side that, in line with this new approach, the rules in Chapter 23 and 24 will be addressed early on. Of course we have to discuss this in the Council, but I think it is important that we are already working hard in the COELA working groups to get agreement on this. Some Member States would like to see additional progress on minorities. I think the National Action Plan on minorities that is being presented today in Brussels by the Serbian Government will help in this respect. From my side, I would also like to underline the importance of continuing to solve bilateral issues. As stated in the last Council Conclusions on Serbia, the Council encourages Serbia to further intensify its reform process. I think these issues were also mentioned by many Members here today – an independent judiciary, building up a track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. Moreover – some Members have mentioned this and I think it is important – particular attention needs to be paid to full respect for fundamental rights, including protection of the most vulnerable groups – in particular the Roma – as well as to the effective implementation of legislation on the protection of minorities, tackling discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, and further improving the business environment and the investment climate. Some concerns were mentioned about deteriorating conditions for the full exercise of freedom of expression. It is important, of course, that, within the context of reform, progress continues to be made on this issue, as well as – as Commissioner Hahn mentioned – to deal proactively with the issue of war crimes. Serbia needs to maintain an active and constructive engagement in the normalisation process with Kosovo, which has made significant progress. I think there has also been a productive approach from Serbia towards the issue in Kosovo. We will come to that later on this afternoon in the debate on Kosovo. On the issue of foreign policy, which some Members have mentioned, the European Union closely follows the alignment of candidate countries with European Union external policies and actions, including the EU’s relationship with Russia. According to the Commission’s last progress report, Serbia’s alignment rate was 65%. In line with the negotiating framework, Serbia needs to progressively align its policies and positions with those of the European Union in the foreign and security policy area, which will be assessed within the screening of Chapter 31. As we know, Serbia did not align itself with the European Union sanctions towards Russia. That was also rationalised, if you like, during their chairmanship of the OSCE in 2015. We hope that we will see alignment on this file as well in the foreseeable future. Let me underline again that, in line with our new approach, Rule of Law Chapters 23 and 24 will be addressed early in the negotiations. I think that was also the main message from the rapporteur.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: 1 motion for a resolution submitted to me in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 4 February 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: in writing. – The 2015 progress report rightly reflects the fact that Serbia has made significant strides on reforms to fight corruption and strengthen the rule of law. These efforts should be recognised and welcomed. However, there is still more work to be done to protect the independence and integrity of the judicial system and access to justice, and exercise of freedom of expression. And, as the report highlights, Serbia also needs to focus on other concerns and sectors, for example the education system, promoting work and training for young people, respecting the rights of workers, development of the public transport system, and respecting its environmental and energy commitments. As a Socialist member of our Serbia Committee, I would have preferred that the report emphasise further that the social dimension of EU accession must be addressed. Employment, labour and trade union rights still remain limited. It is also clear that social dialogue in Serbia remains weak and the consultation of social partners irregular. Agency and other less secure workers are not adequately protected. Furthermore, restructuring and privatisation should not be regarded as goals for their own sake. Many Serbians rely on public sector jobs and negative employment effects must be avoided where possible.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 2015 Country Report on Serbia is a balanced, realistic, objective document. Serbia has taken important steps over the past year, which have led to the opening of the first negotiating chapters. The report highlights the progress made so far in regional cooperation and in addressing the migrant and refugee crisis, but also highlights shortcomings, in particular in the areas of freedom of speech and media, the rule of law, corruption and the fight against organised crime. In Serbia, many promising laws and action plans have been drawn up over the past year, the implementation of which is crucial not only because of the opening of the negotiating chapters, but also in order to ensure that the citizens of Serbia have the rule of law at European level as soon as possible. This is particularly important for national minority communities, including the Hungarian community in Vojvodina. In this report, it seeks to provide further encouragement and guidance to the Serbian Government.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – I congratulate my colleague McAllister on a balanced annual Serbia report covering all important areas. I welcome the fact that, in adopting our amendments, a separate chapter on respecting and protecting minority national communities is being addressed this year. These communities are in a unique situation and it is important for them not only to have the right, but also to ensure equal opportunities. It is important to ensure equal treatment so that members of these communities are treated as equal citizens, whether in any area of life. It is essential to ensure the use of the mother tongue, access to native language education, appropriate textbooks. I welcome the fact that the report underlines that the cultural diversity of Vojvodina contributes to Serbia's identity and stresses that its autonomy should not be weakened. The Law on the Resources of Vojvodina shall be adopted without further delay, as provided for in the Constitution. The system of national minority councils in Vojvodina is functioning well and their role in promoting the rights of national minorities is paramount and should therefore be funded. The report welcomes Serbia's commitment to put together a targeted action plan for national minorities, but also stresses that rights already acquired should not be revoked or mutilated. By properly guaranteeing minority rights in this way, the previous experience of accession could be avoided, where candidates only temporarily take the interests of these national communities into account until accession. I therefore consider it important that the application of existing legislation and its compliance be monitored by the Commission.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Serbia is a strategically important partner of the EU in the Balkans. Especially in the refugee crisis, the country currently has great importance and responsibility. The indicators suggest that Serbia will be up to the challenges of EU membership in the future. The Serbian Government is pushing ahead with the integration process and is ready to implement the acquis legislation in a planned and coordinated manner. Awareness of the rule of law is becoming increasingly strong, leading to a relaxation of relations with neighbouring countries. More rule of law is also important for the investment climate and is the basis for liberalising the economic structure. The involvement of social partners in legislation is progressing, as are efforts to make the judiciary more independent. In view of the pressure from the media and political parties on anti-corruption measures and the high level of organised crime, which is hampering Serbia's democratic, social and economic development, the country still has a lot of catching up to do. The same applies, as the rapporteur rightly points out, to freedom of speech: there are repeated cases of threats against journalists or self-censorship. Despite everything, Serbia seems to be on the right track. Public administration reform has begun, regional self-determination has largely been implemented and the government is restricting interference to coordination.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. – The progress report on Serbia's accession impressively demonstrates that it is possible to implement the Copenhagen criteria, even in difficult circumstances. This is also due to the firm affirmation of the European perspective by the current Serbian leadership. The self-critical reappraisal of the recent past, which results in a positive affirmation of the multiculturalism of the Western Balkans, is particularly positive. This is also acknowledged in the motion for a resolution. With regard to the autonomous province of Vojvodina, for example: "The cultural diversity of Vojvodina contributes to Serbia's identity." Serbia must be supported in this process of self-discovery. In this context, we should also mention those efforts devoted to dealing with the expulsion of the Danube Swabians after the Second World War. This is an important step towards a European perspective, which does not amount to the reciprocal offsetting of the past, but rather to reconciliation and mutual understanding.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on kosovo's process of European integration (2015/2893(RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, firstly, let me welcome Parliament’s recent consent to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) with Kosovo. It was an important decision. We are now working in the Council to conclude the Agreement and have it enter into force as soon as possible. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement – the first comprehensive agreement between the European Union and Kosovo – sends, in my view, an important political signal of support and it is of critical importance for the future of Kosovo. A lot will now depend on how the Agreement will be implemented. The people in Kosovo will feel the concrete benefits from the Agreement if comprehensive reforms are undertaken. It is, therefore, now essential for Kosovo to focus on the implementation of the Agreement. I think, in particular, attention should be made to improving the rule of law, including judicial independence. Kosovo also needs to intensify the fight against organised crime and corruption, which remains a serious problem, and to build a track record in high-profile cases. The Council is concerned about the current political standoff in Kosovo which, in our view, needs to be urgently resolved. We condemn all use of violence and we have clearly called on all sides concerned to address the challenges through political dialogue and to engage on the implementation of Kosovo’s European reform agenda. Strong political will is required from all political actors now to overcome this difficult internal situation and move Kosovo far forward. Political stability is an essential ingredient to consolidate the European process launched with the SAA. Association and stabilisation go, in the end, hand in hand. Stabilisation in this context also includes moving forward on the normalisation of relations with Serbia, as we just discussed in our previous debate. Unless stabilisation is clearly visible, it will be difficult to move forward on association. We have seen very encouraging developments in the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue over the last year. The key agreements that were reached in August are an important achievement, and we know that this has not always been easy politically. It continues to remain a very politically-sensitive issue and a divisive issue, and I think it will now be important for Kosovo to swiftly implement its part of these agreements, despite the internal difficulties it is facing. In this sense, I am encouraged by the meeting last week between Prime Ministers Mustafa and Vučić, by which they reaffirmed the importance of the dialogue for both countries. The Council will closely follow these developments and we will continue to support Kosovo. We will put particular emphasis on furthering Kosovo’s socio-economic reform agenda, including through financial and technical assistance. Economic growth, and specifically, I think, creating employment, is a main concern of the Kosovo people. Let me add just a few comments on the visa liberalisation process, which is a top political priority for Kosovo. The Commission’s recent report considers that Kosovo has been steadily and effectively progressing in all areas covered by the visa liberalisation roadmap. At the same time, it also notes eight outstanding requirements which will need to be fulfilled, of which four important areas remain key priorities. I think it will now be central for Kosovo to work on these areas. Once all these criteria have been fulfilled, the Council will revert to this issue. Let me finally underline the important role EULEX continues to play to support reforms and further the rule of law in Kosovo.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, only two weeks ago I addressed this House to thank it for its support in the continuing development of EU-Kosovo relations and its support for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) we negotiated with Kosovo. I would like again to thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs and in particular rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek for their support. This House’s overwhelming vote in support of the SAA on 21 January was welcomed in both Brussels and Pristina. In Brussels it should allow the Council to adopt the agreement later this month, and in Pristina it reminded everyone of the support Kosovo has in this House. I look forward to the SAA entering into force in April or May. Implementation of the Agreement will not only deepen our political relations, it will also ensure a more predictable business environment, leading to much-needed jobs and growth. I hope that political leaders in Kosovo take the opportunity of the adoption of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement to sit around the table to discuss their differences and find a way out of the political stalemate. The political paralysis in Pristina has lasted far too long and has caused a great deal of damage. It is high time that the opposition renounced violence and obstruction and got down to business. Our 2015 report on Kosovo confirms that Kosovo needs to address structural reforms to tackle key economic reform challenges. Unemployment is unacceptably high and economic development is not sufficient. More focus is needed on delivery of results in the fight against organised crime and corruption. The same goes for the independence and capacity of the judiciary. Improvements in these areas should provide the people of Kosovo with a perspective for a better future. As reflected in the SAA, we attach great importance to the normalisation of Kosovo’s relations with Serbia. Kosovo needs to implement the agreements it has reached and continue to work towards further agreements. Kosovo also needs to ensure that the specialist chambers become fully operational quickly. Kosovo’s cooperation with the chambers will be of critical importance to the country’s image and international standing and therefore to its European future. Similarly, Kosovo needs to continue to work with our European Union Rule of Law Mission (EULEX) in the execution of its mandate. This is a legal obligation under the SAA. We fully understand that visa liberalisation is a key issue for Kosovo and that Kosovo’s progress in this area is important to this House. The Commission’s third and final report on Kosovo’s visa progress last December noted substantial progress but also concluded that eight requirements still had to be fulfilled before it could proceed with the proposal. Kosovo is working hard to fulfil the remaining recommendations and therefore I hope this will be possible very soon and then we can indeed have a positive report. Once again, allow me to thank all of you for your support, and I am looking forward to the debate.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Madam President,  Kosovo is the youngest European state. In two weeks it will be eight years since it declared independence after war, after very difficult times, and there are lots of young people there – younger and older ones – who are sure they want this country to become a member of the European Union, a fully-fledged member of this European community. It is a very pro-European citizenship there, and there has been progress over the last years, as you have mentioned, Commissioner, and also you, Minister, for the Council. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) was adopted just two weeks ago in this House and this will come into force very soon. There is also progress in the dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia: not good enough yet, but there is progress. Kosovo will soon, if things go well, have a telephone code of its own, which it has not had yet. So there is progress, but still it is not enough. This Parliament has been supportive of Kosovo’s statehood, of its independence, since the beginning, and we need to move forward on that with the Commission and the Council, because this country is still not fully recognised by all EU Member States. Five are still blocking, for example, Kosovo from becoming a member of Europol or Interpol, to increase the fight against corruption and organised crime, or also blocking things as important to citizens as the International Football Association or UEFA – or even the Eurovision Song Contest for those who like it. So, these things are important for citizens here. More needs to be done, and most of all visa liberalisation, as has been mentioned, because of this feeling of being locked in. Just imagine you live in a very small country; all citizens of countries around you can travel freely to the European Union to visit friends and families, and to visit the beautiful sights etc., of this European Union, and you cannot, although your parents and grandparents in Yugoslavia, more than 25 years ago, could do that. So this is something where efforts need to be improved. Kosovo has to do a bit more yet, but so has the Commission – and here I directly address the Commissioner – to move forward as soon as the Commission gives a green light, and I would also call on the Council Presidency: please give the green light to make sure that Kosovo citizens can travel freely. Coming to the domestic crisis in Kosovo: last week we had the European Integration Committee of the Kosovo Assembly here – all parties, government and opposition. This is the way forward, and I have called on the opposition time and again to stop blocking the Assembly, to stop using violence in the Assembly – and also outside, demonstrations are fine, but peaceful ones please – and to go back in, and I would also call on all of them to follow the call of President Atifete Jahjaga to get around the dialogue table and to find a non-violent solution to the domestic crisis. When it comes to the implementation of the dialogue agreement between Kosovo and Serbia, I need a couple of sentences more, thank you. It is important to implement it, but also, for the association of Serbian municipalities, in line with the ruling of the Constitutional Court of Kosovo. This is possible. It is about the laws and the statutes, whereas the agreement is only on the principles. The Constitutional Court is part of the statehood of Kosovo, with three international judges on it, so this is something I appeal also to this House to vote in favour of. Many other details are in the report. I have no time to go into details on that. I would like to thank all the shadows for their good cooperation, and I hope from this House there will be good support for Kosovo in its European process, strong support from this Parliament as in all the years before. (Applause)

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the Commission’s progress report has been issued at a significant time for Kosovo. This Parliament has just voted positively on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, an agreement that is not only important for the economy but also for Kosovo’s integration within the EU. Despite this, new and further steps need to be taken. Two examples: firstly, visa liberalisation. Many of us hope that the Commission will find the necessary criteria fulfilled as soon as possible, not least because we know that such a move would send an important signal to the Kosovars that the country’s pro-European alignment generates results. Secondly, the establishment of an association for communities with a Serbian majority is for the moment one of the most pressing issues facing Kosovar politicians. A successful implementation will hopefully mean further steps on the way to normalisation with Serbia and a return to a constructive relationship between government and opposition in Pristina. The resolution we are debating today has been well prepared by Ms Lunacek and reflects the general view of Parliament. In order to support the people of Kosovo on their path towards the European Union, the EPP will vote for the resolution in the final vote.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Lunacek for his work. This progress report in Kosovo captures the current situation of full transition. As has already been said, the signing and then approval by the European Parliament of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which confirmed the European perspective for Kosovo, is an important fact. We believe that the conditions are in place for Kosovo to move towards consolidated objectives of rapprochement with the European Union. The Lunacek report indicates what commitments need to be made to make this happen. The important steps towards normalising ties with Serbia must be consolidated and a policy of reform must be developed more quickly. The efforts made to reform public administration are important, but politicisation continues to give rise to enormous concern. The main economic problems include factors such as low competitiveness, the black economy and high unemployment, which objectively hamper the country's chances of growth and development. The issues of the rule of law, the fight against corruption and the fight against organised crime must be taken seriously.  We expect progress on all this. We must be aware that they are the essential condition for building a positive perspective for Kosovo, sheltered from the violence that we have witnessed recently. All this must be done as soon as possible, not least in order to overcome difficulties and mistrust, especially in those countries which have not yet recognised and which we hope will be able to recognise this important state.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Lunacek, colleagues, I thank my colleague Lunacek for working on the resolution and for its overall contribution to Kosovo's cohesion to the EU. I also thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation in drafting the final text of the resolution. Undoubtedly, I am pleased with the text drawn up; many of the country's problems have been addressed and constructive criticisms and recommendations have been made. The issue of ethnic minorities has also been addressed and we call on Kosovo to step up efforts to protect and guarantee the rights of all national minorities, including foresters or Bulgarians, especially in the area of Prizren, as we made clear during our meetings and talks with the Kosovo delegation. However, I would like to draw attention to a call with which I do not fully agree, namely visa liberalisation with Kosovo. Both I and my EQF group are of the opinion that the visa regime should not and should not be liberalised prematurely before the country has fulfilled all its obligations. Let's not forget that the so-called "Balkan battalion" of The Islamic State is actually made up most of fighters from Kosovo and then Bosnia and Herzegovina.  It is not the Commission, but Kosovo that needs to step up its work and, in this respect, show real progress, real and real results in the fight against organised crime, media freedom, freedom of justice, etc. Thank you again, Mrs Lunacek, and I hope that Parliament's resolution will be adopted by a large majority.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – There are countries that want to leave the European Union and there are those that are making efforts to get in. It's a beautiful world, Europe, we could almost say.  I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mrs Ulrike Lunacek. We have been able to work together with all our colleagues in a good atmosphere, Mrs Lunacek, and the result certainly takes into account the latest developments. Those talks on 27 January show that both sides are serious about reaching out. We have therefore added an additional amendment to this end. If it goes well, it can also be said.  We are adopting a very important resolution today, ladies and gentlemen, a few months after the association agreement was concluded. We're seeing progress. We can hold out hope. Only 15 years ago, ladies and gentlemen, I was standing on that border between Kosovo and Serbia. Where we now let students do an exchange, hostilities were exchanged. Kosovo has made a lot of efforts over the past year. They have even passed a law on gender equality and developed a vision, something we cannot even say about our European Commission today. But, of course, many points remain: freedom of the press, the fight against corruption.  Mr President, we are living at a time when many states in the EU are reacting to the refugee crisis and closing their borders. A time when refugee children - and I insisted on this yesterday - were wandering around without their parents - 10 000 children are missing - and becoming victims of traffickers. Also a time when people are just looking for a better future. Kosovo is our partner in this and we must help them. The Commission considers that there is a possibility of visa liberalisation if all the conditions are met. We will therefore debate in the future the status of Kosovo as a safe country. The ALDE Group will be happy to say yes to this resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this is another chapter of this 'overintegration' bubble in the European Union, which will one day explode. But in this case, we are talking about a purported state created by NATO bombs, encouraged by Albanian Mafia-funded criminals who provoked the attack on civilians and the exodus of refugees.  Just look at former minister Thacai, accused of heroin trafficking, weapons or organ trafficking by, for example, Carla Del Ponte. In fact, in The Hague, in an EU-funded court, these crimes will be tried.  The self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo does not belong to the UN, has not been admitted to Unesco and more than eighty countries do not recognize it. UN Security Council Resolution 1244 is still in force.  And I believe that the European Union should, in this context, help to have a political agreement and not to a purported state that looks more like an aircraft carrier for the US military projection.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "Kosovo per srce Srbije" – I am a little surprised that we are discussing a European integration of Kosovo here. Would it not be better to discuss European integration in the whole of Serbia? Kosovo is a province in the heart of Serbia, and the Serbian majority there has been deliberately promoted to a minority. If the Muslim majority in Kosovo is now taken as a legitimate reason to recognise that country, then – that is for sure – other regions in Europe will follow, who want the same thing. It is also important for us that the destruction of Serbian identity in this region is a sad reality. Recently, an attack was prevented in the monastery of Desani. In the Balkans, a radical Salafist Islam is flourishing and developing. We all know this from our debates, which we have already had here in this House. In this sense, there are also junior recruitment camps in the Balkans, which certainly cannot be in the interests of all of us.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, it is an insult and a tragedy that we are only discussing the prospect of the Kosovo-Metochia region joining the European Union. Enlargement, which is being promoted under the pretext of European integration and cohesion, serves the interests of economic and geopolitical centres of power. Let someone tell me how to make the accession of a Land take place when it does not meet the Copenhagen criteria.  A region deliberately populated with thousands of Albanians and which envisions its union with Albania, according to the statements of Albanian Prime Minister Rama and Kosovar Foreign Minister Thaci, a former UCK leader and well-known war criminal. A state that produces Islamic extremism, corruption, crime, hosts and trains jihadists and cultivates hatred towards other peoples of the Western Balkans.  A region that has been violently separated from Serbia and on whose territory an international military peacekeeping force is still operating.
