Already five Member States of the Union have not recognised the state of education, so what exactly are we discussing here? So let's stop comedy and do the right thing. Immediate reunification of the Kosovo-Metochia region with Serbia.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Since the Thessaloniki European Council in 2003, all six countries of the Western Balkans have a clear European perspective. The European Union reaffirmed this promise by signing the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo, which we as a Parliament ratified two weeks ago. Unfortunately, riots on the streets of Pristina and members of the Kosovar Parliament in breathing masks have shaped the public image of Kosovo in recent months. It is quite clear that tear gas has nothing to do with a parliament, it cannot be part of a functioning democracy. Therefore, the government and the opposition should now sit down at the table as soon as possible to discuss fundamental issues of the country's political orientation. Finally, I would like to make a comment on the ongoing negotiations with Serbia. Both Prime Ministers – Aleksandar Vusic and Isa Mustafa – have my respect for the historic results they have achieved in Brussels. Negotiations have not been and are not easy. Now both sides – Kosovo and Serbia – must swiftly implement the agreements already reached. My greeting goes to the ambassador present, Mrs Ahmetaj, and my best thanks go to the rapporteur responsible, Ulrike Lunacek, for her good work. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. In this Parliament, we are looking at the european approach of several countries. In the case of Kosovo, we will also tell you what they should do, but do you feel that we have homework too? For example, the five Member States of the European Union have not yet recognised Kosovo as an independent state. What do you think of this?

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is clear that all six countries of the Western Balkans have a European perspective. This is what the Heads of State or Government agreed in 2003. All six countries of the Western Balkans are moving towards the European Union, albeit at different speeds. And the question of the recognition of Kosovo is a question that nations must raise independently. The fact is that 23 EU Member States have recognised Kosovo, five of them have not. I come from Germany, we have recognised Kosovo.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Lunacek on her report because she fully presents the opportunities in Kosovo and the progress made in the past year.  Certainly the most important thing is the signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement that we recently ratified in the European Parliament. It is a kind of recognition of Kosovo's commitment to joining the European Union. But further progress will depend on consensus-based cooperation between all political stakeholders, which is not unfortunately the case now. Once again, the problem of opposition obstruction in Parliament is happening, which must be the birthplace of discussions on the country's future. The scenes we've been watching lately don't look like a country of serious European aspirations. I hope that all the circumstances of the case involving the arrests of opposition representatives will be investigated. We expect government and opposition representatives to replace the conflict as soon as possible by cooperating on European issues.  In the past year, the legislative framework has been improved, the success of which will nevertheless depend on implementation. But organised crime, the level of corruption, the high unemployment rate, especially young people, and the threatened freedom of the media continue to press society hard. It is worth commending the adopted measures to combat terrorism and radicalisation, the reduction of illegal migrants and asylum seekers in the European Union, as well as the progress made in meeting the criteria for visa waiver for Kosovo citizens. I hope that by the next report the issue will be closed as well.  It is certainly worth commending the constructive approach and progress in the dialogue with Serbia. I am sorry that the same principle was not applied when applying Kosovo for UNESCO membership. Throughout the transition process, communication of adopted policies with citizens is of utmost importance, which would facilitate their application, increase the level of their participation, but also really contribute to the building of a multiethnic society in Kosovo, especially when it comes to the education and employment of minorities.  In conclusion, I hope that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement will be a strong boost to the many reforms that Kosovo needs to implement. It would be quite in the European spirit if the youngest European country finally received undivided European support along the way.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I think that the Minister representing the Dutch Presidency has, in very few words, best expressed what should be going on in relations between the European Union and Kosovo. It is about supporting reforms and at the same time expecting reforms that bring kosovo's community closer to European Union standards.  I would have preferred, truth be told, to make the report more cost-effective in content, but focused on what is most important: the construction of democratic state structures, the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption, the fight against terrorism. Too much ideological emphasis in this report. Better less, but clearly and more unambiguously. Like my colleague, Mr Dzhambazki, I would be very restrained in the face of hasty visa liberalisation.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, Kosovo is the youngest European country created in a war that ended fifteen years ago. I particularly emphasise this because in countries that have gone through the war it is much more difficult to carry out internal democratic processes, and also to normalise the relations between these countries and the neighbourhood.  And Kosovo is a very important country, which is very important for normalising relations with Serbia. This is one of the most important processes in the Western Balkans, and of course it also has an impact on stability and relations with other countries. That is why I especially welcome the signing of a Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which will help speed up democratic processes in Kosovo, and would certainly help the recognition of Kosovo by the other five European Union countries and visa liberalisation. But, of course, the first assumption for this is the stabilisation and unblocking of internal relations in Kosovo, in the Kosovo Assembly, and that is why I welcome the fact that the opposition from the Kosovo Assembly was also present during a recent visit by the Committee on European Affairs to the European Parliament.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Madam President, while the European Union is disintegrating piece by piece (employment, economy, security and living together), which is more than ever a symbol of your stinging failure, you continue to consider the accession of a territorial entity that nothing qualifies for integration into the European Union.  It would seem to remind you that Kosovo is still not accepted, as a sovereign state, by all the members of the United Nations, including five Member States: Spain, Cyprus, Greece, Romania and Slovakia. More recently, on 12 November 2015, fifty Unesco member countries denied Kosovo permanent member status. Perhaps you should start by explaining and demonstrating to the Kosovo Serbs, even if you tell us that there have just been new exchanges, victims of real massacres between 1999 and 2004 (235,000 exiles in less than ten years), these famous advantages to Christian and Orthodox minorities still largely persecuted in this part of the Balkans. Just this weekend, the monastery of Visoki De-ana was the target of another attempted Islamist terrorist attack with a weapon of war. I also look forward to you explaining the benefits of integrating into the Union a territory where trafficking of all kinds is rampant and which, in 2014, ranked 110th in the world ranking of the countries most resistant to corruption.  Finally, with all due respect, when the house burns down, we no longer take care to enlarge the garden, but we worry about the foundations. So I expect you to take responsibility and suspend any perspective...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the question posed by the MP by raising the blue card – I want to ask you, Mrs Bilde, do you think, as I think, it is better to have a realistic policy in the Balkans that leads to peace rather than the restoration of old wars and old hostilities? And is it any better that Mr. Vucic and Mr. Mustafa, the prime minister of Serbia and the prime minister of Kosovo, have a dialogue than not have one, because I am sure that contributes to peace, not wartime logic?

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, dear colleague, I certainly agree with you that these two countries should continue to have exchanges. We ourselves are already struggling, at the moment, in our own countries of the European Union, to create a rather calm atmosphere. So I don't see why we could integrate people right away who haven't found their own calm.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the resolution on Kosovo and thank the rapporteur. The SAA agreement brings a new perspective to relations between the EU and Kosovo. I urge Kosovo to take advantage of this agreement and work on the reforms needed for its implementation. This report justly welcomes progress by Kosovo in many areas. However, we also need to pay more attention to the state of the democratic institutions and issues related to the rule of law, justice and corruption, as they are at the very core of the integration process. Therefore, I am bit surprised that these issues have been sidelined in the report, especially when we are talking about phasing out EULEX. We should give Kosovo a chance to develop and grow so that its people feel equal in the region. It is important not only to involve Kosovo in EU programmes and to move on with visa liberalisation but also to support its participation in regional organisations. I cannot help but mention one thing concerning the rapporteur’s introduction. With all due respect, I cannot agree substantively with what you said. Concerning the implementation of the agreements, we say to Serbia: implement everything fully and unconditionally. Yet we are saying to the Kosovars: do not fulfil, do not implement, wait for the decision of the constitutional court. That is a double standard and I cannot accept it. I will vote against it.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: – I always appreciate working with you, and that also goes for Kosovo, even if I know that your Member State does not recognise it. You have been very cooperative. But when you say now that I demand different things than I demand from Serbia in my report, then that is simply not true. Yes, Kosovo also has to implement for sure. But in certain things, like the Constitutional Court, it can be done in accordance with the agreement that was achieved on 25 August. This is possible, and I ask you to support that and not to vote against.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Without wishing to go into your presidency, however, may I ask you to clarify something: was it a blue card, was it a question or a co-department? If you are already giving the rapporteur more than half a minute more time in her report, then I would make sure that, at least if she raises a question with a blue card, she actually raises a question and does not give a co-lecture here, thereby using her opportunities a little more than usual. Madam President, let us all remain in solidarity and stick to our possibilities and also to our time.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: I feel like congressman has ordered me to take my seat. Congressman, do you think that all my fellow Members, when they use the Blue Card, will ask only one question on a permanent basis and for 30 seconds? The thing is, it's not. So the direction is right, of course the blue card question is a question, but it also includes an opinion and an opportunity to respond. Thank you for your warning.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the recommendation by my colleague Ulrike Lunacek regarding the conclusion of this agreement, which not only enhances political dialogue and opens new forms of cooperation but also creates opportunities to enhance contact between peoples. Citizens and civil society must be included in the process of implementation of the agreement and citizens must be informed about the process in a transparent manner. Citizen initiatives remain at the heart of ongoing work in Kosovo to document sexual violence conducted by Serbian military and paramilitary forces during the conflict, to locate missing people and mass graves and to rebuild lives, and this must be supported. I deeply believe that more consideration must be given to the power of civil society to pursue intercultural exchange, people-to-people dialogue and initiatives bringing together citizens from EU Member States and Kosovo, particularly in respect of young people. Kosovan youth are the promise of its future. They are the ones who stand to gain from the ongoing dialogue. A young generation of Kosovars have grown up with the European vision and we must not let them down.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, Kosovo is europe's youngest democracy and we must take particular care when discussing the European perspective facing the country. Kosovo has made significant progress over the past year and we need to take into account government efforts to adopt human rights legislation and to take a constructive approach in the negotiations with Serbia.  This undoubtedly proves the existence of a political will for reform and a desire for European integration. It is this ambition for change that underpins the signed Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the European Union, which will give new impetus to the development of the country's fragile economy. There is no doubt that political dialogue with the European Union will be fundamental in finding solutions to serious problems such as the rule of law, freedom of speech, high-level corruption and the unsatisfactory participation of civil society in the country's socio-political life. Kosovo's development is of great importance, both for the Balkans and for Europe.  This argument must be taken into account by member states that do not yet recognise the independence of the country, because only the full integration of the Western Balkan countries means stability and prosperity for the region.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Minister Koenders, Commissioner Hahn, first of all I thank our colleague Lunacek for a well-prepared progress report that should be an incentive for further progress on kosovo's European path, which I personally strongly support as well as the new Croatian government. I welcome the ratification of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which is now the cornerstone of Kosovo's European integration. I am also sorry that Kosovo has not become a MEMBER of UNESCO.  It is good that progress has been made in relations with Serbia, while all signed agreements should be implemented. Resuming dialogue with Serbia is necessary for normalising relations between the two countries, and I expect the issue of missing persons to be resolved. Kosovo is the only Southeast European country whose nationals still need a visa to travel to the EU, and I favour visa liberalisation for Kosovo citizens, which will reduce the pressure of illegal migration.  I am pleased that the report also includes full support for the Council's intention for the Commission to continue talks on a framework agreement that would allow Kosovo to participate in European Union programmes, and I hope that the parliamentary dialogue between the authorities and the opposition in Kosovo will be of better quality and will act constructively with a view to reaching the European standards of democratic institutions.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Lunacek for the great work she has done with her team. The entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is, of course, a very important step for Kosovo, for its reform process and also for strengthening cooperation in many areas of the country. However, what the Kosovar citizens are asking for – as we know – is only one thing: visa liberalisation. Visa liberalisation towards Schengen, above all, towards our countries, and it is important to talk about this at this very moment. Kosovo is the only country in the Western Balkans whose citizens still do not have this status, and it is frustrating to think that when they had a Yugoslav passport the situation was quite different. Of course, Kosovo still has to take great strides, it must take steps towards the rule of law, towards the fight against corruption. It will be the task of this Parliament to ensure that the rights of the Kosovars are guaranteed and that Kosovo makes the necessary reform path.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – The signing of the Stability and Association Agreement with the EU last October is an extraordinary and rapid step forward for the young State of Kosovo. However, the support of the European Community does not mean that we can be satisfied with the achievements of the former Yugoslav province so far. While we can rightly expect the remaining five states to recognise Kosovo's independence and Serbia to normalise its relationship with it, we also rightly demand that the new Albanian State be able to aveend himself in all respects, implement the necessary reforms, tackle corruption and violence. First of all, give the Serbian community on its territory the rights it rightly claimed from the then Serbian state majority in its previous minority state. In their European integration, Kosovo and Serbia inevitably rely on each other. It is up to them whether they enter the Union by strengthening each other or by blocking each other.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, after Kosovo’s unilateral declaration of independence in early 2008, the EU almost immediately initiated Kosovo’s European integration process. The same applies to assuming the mantle of chief intermediary between Belgrade and Pristina, and I think there are two key points. First, if Kosovans truly want to become part of our family of nations, European values of respect towards democracy, freedom of speech, good governance and others have to be fully respected. This is not conditional – it is obligatory. Second, Kosovo and Serbia have to reach a mutually-satisfactory compromise, paving the way to long-term peace and cooperation. Serbians’ attitude towards Kosovo is that of grieving, disgruntled people who have lost their historic homeland. This mutual understanding has to resolve this serious injury. And, of course, there can be no EU membership perspective for Kosovo unless all our Member States recognise it as independent. Cyprus, Greece, Romania, as you know, Slovakia and Spain – 5 out of 28 – have not yet done it, each for their own reasons.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Kosovo had to overcome internal and external obstacles to conclude... that it has taken a very important step forward towards a full European perspective through the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. I am pleased to see this, and I congratulate this Kosovo on this. I congratulate the rapporteur, Lunaček, on another excellent report. As regards the continuation of the accession process, it is clear that the construction of relations with Serbia will continue to play an important role. I see no better basis for progress towards lasting coexistence within Kosovo or between the two countries, such as the European principles of respect for the dignity of different identities and reconciliation. In this context, I particularly welcome the efforts and achievements of Commissioner Hahn and The Vice-President/High Representative, Mrs Mogherini. At the same time, I recommend high attention to the issue of visions, which should be resolved soon.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we must not lose sight of the view that the negotiations of the European institutions with the Kosovar authorities are also negotiations for cooperation between Kosovo and Serbia and, therefore, for peace and fraternity in Europe. They are inseparable from serbia's future integration into the European Union. This process proves that the spirit of the European project is still alive despite the anxieties that the Union has known in recent times and also proves that Europe's future is a culture of responsibility and commitment.  I would like to welcome federica Mogherini's efforts and personal commitment in the framework of high-level dialogues for the normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Pristina, initiated in 2012 by her predecessor. The benefits of this dialogue are already visible in the daily lives of the Kosovar people and the Serbian people, with the mutual recognition of diplomas and with significant advances in freedom of movement, to give only two examples. The path is clearly around.  On the other hand, the poverty of the Kosovars and their lack of prospects are a cause of great skepticism and disillusionment. An unemployment rate of close to 50 % and mass emigration are undermining the hope of the population. Further reasons should be encouraged by the implementation of the Cooperation and Stabilisation Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, as it involves improving the living conditions of the people and gradually bringing kosovars closer to European values.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I want to take the opportunity to thank Mrs. Lunacek for her quality report, but also to Mrs Mogherini and Mr. Hahn who have contributed significantly to not only this report, but that we can assess the situation as progress.  In any case, progress in Kosovo is important because it contributes to the stabilisation of the entire Balkans. Likewise, it is obvious that the most important condition is the relationship with Serbia and it is necessary to take an important step towards reconciliation. A lot has already been done here, but it needs to be insisted on. Of course business legalization is important, too. It is important to stress that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is also one of the important steps and also the relations between the authorities and the opposition. Therefore, cooperation is necessary, it needs to be worked on.  It is a pity that Kosovo has failed to join UNESCO and it is bad that this situation is being used and in some way blackmailed so that it does not join UNESCO. I would also like to stress that the five Member States should slowly consider and accede to recognising Kosovo's independence.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Kosovo is another sad monstrosity of military interventions to which the European Union has also contributed. We note that the pseudo-state of Kosovo has unilaterally declared its independence, which is contrary to UN Security Council Resolution 1244, which provides for Kosovo's autonomy within Serbian territory. We also note that in a report by the Council of Europe the current Minister for Foreign Affairs and former Prime Minister of the pseudo-state Hashim Thaçi is accused of setting up a network of illegal trafficking in human organs.  We highlight the systematic persecutions and threats experienced by Kosovo Christians, the majority of them Serbs. We note that Kosovo is on the list of the ten countries with the highest percentages of people directly involved in Daesh Islamic terrorism. We also note that the nationalist movement claiming union with Albania receives 14% of the vote.  These figures therefore show that they are prohibitive for any European course of a Paria State, which is not recognised by all the States of the European Union.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Without the accession of the countries of the Western Balkans to the EU, a united Europe cannot be imagined, so Kosovo cannot be left out of this process, although there is undoubtedly a lot of work to be done by the country's leaders. Accelerating reforms and closer ties would be helped if those five Member States formally recognised Kosovo, which for some reason had not yet done so. The withdrawal of Kosovo from Serbia cannot in any way be regarded as a process that would have been a natural development of Kosovo's autonomy. Contrary! Territorial autonomy in the territory of the Member States reduces inter-ethnic tensions and contributes to increasing the internal cohesion of that country. The example of Kosovo shows the dire consequences of a state's ethnic majority not paying attention to the needs and needs of the minority. It is therefore another argument for the need for well-functioning territorial autonomies, not a dangerous precedent for secession.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I have a little request. The previous chairman allowed me one blue card and if ALDE can get a word in, I would kindly ask you that Mr. Selimović speak for me. Under catch-the-eye. Be kind, please give your word to Mr. Selimović on behalf of the ALDE group.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Kosovo's rapprochement with the EU is welcome and it will mean an end to an era of war and tragedy and, at the same time, surely a better future for Kosovo. It is only to be hoped that it will be quick and that the necessary reforms are implemented at a sufficient pace. Therefore, the issue of the Serbian minority must also be resolved soon.  Just as the recognition of Kosovo and the normalisation of relations with Kosovo are a condition for Serbia's rapprochement with the EU, an agreement with Kosovo on the issue of the Serbian minority must be a condition for Kosovo, and the EUROPEAN Union must help. We cannot allow honest and sincere efforts by a legitimately elected government to be undermined by the opposition for domestic political purposes. I expect the Commission to send out clear signals about this.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I, too, would like to thank Mrs Lunacek for her excellent report. So Kosovo is one of the youngest democracies and a country with one of the youngest populations. And it is also up to us to allow Kosovo to become a normal democratically developed country, where, of course, mass migration will not, of course, weaken kosovo's perspective. But there's still a lot to do, of course. There are significant structural changes, including the issue of crime, corruption, the issue of the division of the judiciary, supervisory institutions, public finances and spending transparency, including controls on spending, public finances, including regional development and inter-neighbouring cooperation, including Serbia. But I think it's important, of course, to let go of... it also lets Kosovo join various international organisations, as has been pointed out, from, of course, football to Eurovision and, of course, UNESCO.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, in various questions that I have asked the Commission on territories seeking their right to self-determination, I have heard how the EU respects the principles of internationally-recognised borders and that they do not have the competency to recognise states. Does this not perfectly highlight the hypocrisy of the European Union: how willing it is to bend and even break its own rules when the ends justify the means? Kosovo is not a United Nations-recognised state. However, the EU has extensive relations with the territory and even recognises it as a potential candidate country, despite no permanent and viable political solution between Serbia and Kosovo currently being on the table. If anything, the current heavy-handed diplomacy by the High Representative in the establishment of Serbian municipalities within Kosovo only works to further destabilise the region. Is there anything the European Union would not do to pursue its neo-colonialist agenda?

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that we should give the facts openly: 200 jihadists come to Kosovo for every one million inhabitants. The country is thus still ahead of Belgium and thus has the highest density in Europe and even surpasses Libya by 100%. In the country, mosques are being built across the country by hardcore Saudi Islamists. Kosovo is now a long way from a European secular Islam as we knew it from a bygone era. Therefore, the prognosis of a Swiss newspaper seems very realistic that Kosovo could become the first Islamic State in the Union. By the way, Kosovo is seen as a hub for organised crime. There are therefore no cultural, economic, and certainly not security reasons for association with this country. Let us therefore respect the will of European citizens who do not want to enlarge the Union – certainly not an Islamic state within the Union. I fear that with Kosovo, we have the next European time bomb ticking.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think that the majority in this House is aware that we need the full integration of the Western Balkans into the European Union. Peace, stability, reconciliation, reconciliation, integration and economic development are only guaranteed in the setting of the European Union and that all the uncertainty and irritation that some have expressed today can only be resolved if there is inclusion here, if there is a European perspective. I honestly cannot imagine, for strategic and security reasons, that there is, so to speak, a white spot or a black hole here in the Western Balkans, where European rules and competences and the rule of law are not guaranteed. It would probably have much more serious consequences.  We must work on the development of these countries here. There is no question that we are already where we want to be. But I think that there is no way around this necessary process – and the concept of process is to be seen and less negotiations – that these countries must be brought closer to the European Union economically, in their social development, in their development under the rule of law. For Kosovo, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is, for the moment, the most appropriate instrument for promoting this route accordingly. What is important now is implementation, implementation, and here we can only appeal to all the political forces in Kosovo to devote themselves to this task, to face up to this task.  With all due respect to the political disputes that we are used to here in this House, there are, so to speak, national common objectives, and the European perspective should at least be one of the vast majority of the political actors in Kosovo. That is why this point, too, can only appeal to those responsible in Kosovo to sit down here, to make the political decisions in the interests of the country in the discussion, in the debate and in the debate, and to refrain from any form of violence or insurrection.  The Commission will continue its efforts to bring Kosovo closer to the European perspective, to Europe, as it can. Visa liberalisation has already been mentioned, or strengthening the rule of law, improving the business climate.  Remember: Kosovo still generates more than a third of its income from tariffs – in a Europe without tariffs, this is no longer sustainable and sustainable. That is why we must now work on slowly reshaping this, so that the conditions are met. We must also address the high level of unemployment, the brain drain that we see in this region, and all these are the necessary measures – as I said, without alternatives , to bring Kosovo closer to it and to contribute to the fact that there is peace, stability and prospects for the people in the region, so that they can remain in the region and are not forced to do so. emigrated within Europe, for example.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like first to express my sincere gratitude to the rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek for the very important work she has done on the important region of Kosovo. Kosovo has a very long history, as you know, with lots of violence, and I think some of you were referring to that this afternoon. I think that is correct. If we look at the situation since 1999 we see enormous progress, and that progress has to be reinforced. It has sometimes gone in cycles up and down, but I can tell you that the European Union will continue to assist Kosovo, including through its strength and presence on the ground. But obviously the primary responsibility for progress lies with Kosovo, with its leaders, with its institutions and with civil society. Reforms are crucial, and they will require the political leaders to live up to their responsibilities for the good of Kosovo and of its citizens. Key EU- related reforms are essential, not just to please the European Union but because they are in the interests of Kosovo itself. On the political crisis we are obviously following the situation with concern with many of you. We have made it clear that violence for political purposes is not acceptable and have appealed to all sides that challenges need to be addressed as part of a joint effort through political dialogue. Madam rapporteur, I think you were referring also to the Kosovo Constitutional Court. As we all know, it has ruled that the Association/Community of Serb majority municipalities is to be established, as provided by the First Agreement in accordance with the Constitution. It will now be essential to work concretely on the drafting of the statute of the Association/Community in the framework of this dialogue. You also spoke about the European aspirations of the people of Kosovo. Of course I have heard some of the language again, I think, from some of the representatives on that side of the corner with a known anti-Islamic language which has, in my view, nothing to do with the issue we are discussing today. When I represent the Council here, I would really like to appeal to you to confine yourselves to arguments that have to do with the case itself and not with religious discrimination. We should also acknowledge that visa liberalisation is a process based on conditions. I would say that. Of course we hope it will be possible. As Ms Lunacek states, there is progress but it is not enough, and now the work has to be done to make it enough. I understand it in the prospect for the young people of Kosovo: they want to travel. The visa can help there, but at the same time I think Commissioner Hahn mentioned that combating corruption and organised crime, and the independence of the judiciary and the specialist chambers, are really important elements in this. This is a conditions-based policy. We will continue to support Kosovo in its reform efforts with financial assistance and expertise through EULEX, and if Kosovo delivers on its obligations then of course we can consider and honour the commitments. Ultimately that, I think, will mean that the people of Kosovo will be able to travel freely like all other Europeans. Lastly, I wanted to mention the importance of the entry into force of the SAA. After the consent that you have given, the Council needs to adopt a decision on the conclusion. It is planned for 12 February and then the Agreement enters into force on the first day of the second month following notification that internal procedures have been completed. It could be possible by 1 April or 1 May.

name: President. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2)) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 4 February 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Defending the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity recognized to Serbia and guaranteed by the Helsinki Final Act, my country considered the Kosovo Unilateral Declaration of Independence contrary to international law. However, this has not prevented it from maintaining a constructive attitude, even within the EU, provided that the proposals seek to promote the well-being of the population and include the necessary measures to protect our position of non-recognition. However, I would particularly like to stress that, although the Feira European Council (2000) declared the countries of the Western Balkans as potential candidates by specifying the principles of the Stabilisation and Association Process, this cannot be applied to a territory whose Unilateral Declaration of Independence subsequently takes place. Therefore, Kosovar territory may be part of the Stabilisation and Association Process but not the enlargement Process, so it cannot be considered a 'candidate' or a 'potential candidate'.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the electoral process in Haiti (2016/2560(RSP)).

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of the Vice-President/High Representative, I welcome the opportunity to join you today to discuss Haiti and the serious political and institutional crisis the country is going though. The situation in Haiti is of great concern and we believe it is fully justified that we address this issue today. The recent postponement sine die of the second round of the presidential elections, originally scheduled for 27 December and subsequently for 24 January, has opened a phase of instability and created the risk of an institutional vacuum. Above all, it risks depriving the Haitian people of the right to democratically choose their leaders. Against a background of a general lack of confidence in the Haitian institutions and low voter participation, preparation of the second round of presidential elections took place in a polarised environment, characterised by accusations of electoral fraud by a number of actors. The provisional Electoral Council, faced with the resignation of several of its members and the danger of further escalation of violence, which tragically has already cost several lives, decided to postpone the voting. I do not need to stress the risk that this situation generates, especially in a country like Haiti, affected by widespread poverty and many vulnerabilities. This crisis could jeopardise the reconstruction efforts and the results achieved after the disastrous earthquake which hit Haiti in 2010. These results were achieved thanks also to the major contributions made by the European Union to the development of the country. In July 2015 the EU fielded a large electoral observation mission, headed by honourable Member Elena Valenciano, and I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to the sterling work carried out by Ms Valenciano and her team. They provided an invaluable service to Haiti and to the EU through their vigorously independent and professional observation and analysis. The EU election observation mission reported several irregularities but also concluded that no massive fraud took place at the 25 October election, and that results announced in the first round of the presidential elections were substantially correct. Unfortunately, the candidates who did not come first in the first round of the presidential election refused to accept this result. They made known substantial accusations of massive fraud and increased the widespread lack of confidence in public opinion. This led to the current deadlock. The Haitian voters could not exercise their political rights in full. As a consequence, there will not be an elected president by 7 February when, according to the Constitution, President Martelly will step down. The Constitution does not precisely provide for this, but of course it contains provisions for cases of incapacity with guidance given. Negotiations are currently ongoing in Haiti. We are all following the developments very closely. The Organization of American States (OAS) sent a special mediation mission, and a similar mission by the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) is also planned. We hope that a general consensus will emerge in favour of a swift completion of the electoral process on the basis of the will expressed by the Haitian people on 25 October and with practical improvements to the process. The work of the EU electoral observation mission could again be extremely valuable in this context. There is, however, the risk that an agreement may not be reached in the short term and that the transitional government finds itself faced with a legitimacy issue. This could have serious consequences for democracy and for the country. The EU is a long-standing and committed partner to Haiti. In these difficult times we call on all stakeholders to refrain from violence and to accept political responsibility in a democratic way. Democracy is necessary for sustainable development. I very much look forward to hearing the views of the honourable Members.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, I would like to first and for all congratulate Mrs Valenciano and her colleagues who participated in the observation mission in Haiti, who found that the elections were fair. I want to congratulate them for contributing to this electoral process through their work. Our election observers of course also found all the difficulties and problems that took place in the process, which is no wonder in the political and social conditions of this Caribbean country, but in the end they concluded that the elections in October 2015 were fair, that is, that the basic standards by which we can say that the declared results reflect the will of the voters in Haiti were met.  Therefore, taking into account the work of our colleagues from the observation mission, and convinced that any other position would call into question the credibility of this Parliament and our election observers, in the European People's Party we feel that the results of the first round of the presidential elections must be taken into account and a runoff held as soon as possible in order for Haiti to get a new head of state to succeed President Martelly. In doing so, we call on all political actors, state institutions and all relevant political and social factors to be prudent and dialogue so that an inclusive approach can ensure institutional stability and peace in the country, which is particularly important after President Martelly's term expires on Sunday February 7th. Haiti is the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere and one of the poorest in the world in general, with a poverty rate of 77%. The dire economic and social situation was further marred by a severe earthquake in 2010. Faced with such a difficult socioeconomic situation, haitian citizens no longer have time for political bickering and antics. The people of Haiti need a government that will implement the necessary structural reforms to complete Haiti's democratic transition and that will enable sustainable growth and development, and thus ultimately eradicate extreme poverty.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the first thing I want to do is confirm the European commitment to the people of Haiti and its constitutional authorities, a European commitment which we translate and which is the solidarity of the citizens of the European Union with that country which has suffered so much. So, first of all, commitment to Haiti.  The second thing I want to say is that I have had the honour, I have the honour, to lead a team of professionals of the highest quality, very committed to democracy in the world, who have done an excellent job in monitoring the electoral process which, unfortunately, has derailed, for the time being, in Haiti.  The work has been serious, rigorous. You can all be calm and, if you are not, you can check our website and our reports to see that we have the capacity to say that the elections on 25 October, the first round of the elections in Haiti, were surely the cleanest and least violent elections Haiti has ever had in its history. And therefore, we confirm that the outcome of those elections, from the first round, could have accompanied the holding of a run-off.  Right now, there is an institutional crisis in Haiti, there is a political impasse in Haiti that Haitians must solve. It is the Haitian authorities and the people of Haiti who have to resolve this important impasse, whose analysis Mrs Creu has done perfectly and which I will not insist on. That impasse has to be solved by haitians.  I hope that they will do so through dialogue and consensus, but our recommendation – humble recommendation – based on serious, rigorous and committed work, is that the second round of the elections in Haiti be held. It'll be the most legitimate thing we can do. Let us hope for the solution given to us by the Haitians and, if there is finally a run-by, the European Union's election observation mission will be there to bear its testimony.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, before we begin I would also like to thank the human team which has worked so hard in Haiti to carry out this report, and Elena Valencian, too, for her work and for her cooperation and coordination with this team in Parliament. But, as responsible for the European Parliament's observation mission in this presidential election in Haiti, I believe that our main contribution, from the European institutions, is to support the holding of the second round, suspended on 24 January, to choose between the two candidates who on 25 October moved on to the second round. At the conclusion of this process democratically, it is the best way to overcome the period of interinitiality that will open on Sunday, following the march of Michel Martelly, and which may include the election, by consensus as well, of an interim prime minister. On October 25, Haiti experienced the first round of these presidential presidencies calmly and calmly, overcoming the violence experienced in the legislative ones on 9 August. On the ground we could see problems such as poor participation, discriminatory legislation to be able to formalize nominations, or improved judicial review, or the absence of sanctions against perpetrators of violence offences in previous elections. But both the day of 25 October and the scrutiny have been an unprecedented step forward for the country's democratic culture. As you know, Haiti is one of the poorest countries on the planet. Its inhabitants deserve and need to give up the time of the subsistence economy and the pain of a society still sore by a history of domination and violence. And achieving this is about generating the union and hope that arises in societies that, with that background, try to succeed by betting on democracy, dialogue, agreement and the rule of law. Haitian citizens need reasons to feel that they are the protagonists of their future and need to verify that their votes are good for something. Children who looked at us curiously, adults who were looking for a reason for hope in the interest with which we follow, from the European Parliament, those elections, people punished by uncertainty, and too often by extreme poverty, deserve that opportunity. They deserve democratic institutions focused on lighting a fairer and more prosperous Haiti, and a good way forward is to be able to democratically elect, in the second round of elections, a new leader that people feel close and legitimized to improve governance, strengthen the rule of law and reach the consensus the country needs.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, the second round of the presidential elections in Haiti has just been postponed once again. This political impasse is worrying, but it would not be wise to over-dramatize. Building a stable democracy is not a long, quiet river and the Haitian people are coming back from afar. I took part in the European Union's election observation mission which took place on 25 October. I thank everyone who has accompanied us. I have seen the distrust of Haitians in the electoral process and the discredit that afflicts politicians in the country, as evidenced by the very high level of abstentions: more than 70%.  It is imperative to address the root causes of this discontent. It is based first of all on the non-treatment of the social issue in the poorest country on the continent and one of the poorest in the world. However, the country has a strong potential in agriculture and tourism, in particular. The issue of water must also be addressed. Six years after the earthquake, about 80% of the 12 million promised aid for the reconstruction of the country would have been disbursed, but it is enough to travel through Port-au-Prince and Pétionville to realize that much of this aid had not had to reach the population. It also fuels mistrust of international actors, whose interference has left its mark - I will not mention anyone. Helping Haitians improve their daily lives, to restore their confidence in the electoral process, in the institutions, is the key to breaking the current deadlock. We must continue to monitor what is happening in Haiti, especially after February 7th and therefore, on the face of it, Mr Martelly's departure. Commissioner, you can count on us: dialogue and consensus are keys, contributing is our duty.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too should have been part of this last cancelled election mission. I fully agree with what Mrs Valenciano said about the recognition of the result of the first round and the need for these elections to be held as soon as possible. What about Haiti? If there was hunger, violence and corruption in Haiti before the earthquake, after the earthquake, after six very long years of attention from the United States but also from Europe, we can say that there continues to be hunger, violence, corruption and attacks, as well as a fragile democracy that we have seen at this time. We can declare, without any hesitation, that the 2010 earthquake was and continues to be a business for part of international cooperation and for part of politics. In the meantime, there have been some much-discussed events, including the passing of a mining law, which is so dear to multinationals, for example. The environmental situation is a major problem, extreme deforestation has exposed the country to floods, hurricanes and landslides. Cooperation, with a few exceptions, has been uninterested in this issue and has not contributed to the sustainable development of the country. We ask the Commission whether we want to be really decisive players in this matter.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, following the start of the electoral process on 25 October, we are today faced with strong political instability in Haiti which can destroy the already fragile balance of a country torn apart by extreme poverty. But let us face it now: the Eu ropean Union Election Mission has shown that the elections were held in a calm atmosphere and that, apart from minor incidents, they complied with international standards. Despite this, those who lost wanted to stir up the population by spreading unfounded reports about the unreliability of the electoral process and the global media themselves have contributed greatly to spreading the perception of electoral fraud around the world. But we were there and we documented, also with the excellent work of Elena Valenciano, the success of the electoral process. The European Union now has a specific task, that of appealing to all the actors involved and calling on them to assume political and moral responsibility, on behalf of their own people, in order to put an end to the current political bloc and to respect the election results of 25 October. A new timetable based on the validity of the first round of voting must be organised as soon as possible. We hope, Commissioner, that the European Commission will be consistent and determined in this area. We all have the task of accompanying Haiti in the democratic process, which will ensure stability and which will begin to provide answers to the many problems facing that country, starting with social and economic conditions, in order to repair the many damage that has occurred in addition to that of the earthquake. We have a great task and we must do it to the end.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: Għalkerata l-elezzjoni Presidenzjali li saret f'Ottubru f'Ħaiti kienet ikkunsidrata mill-osservaturi tal-Unjoni Ewropea bħala waħda ġusta, xorta eventwalment inqala' l-inkwiet, u t-t-tie rawnd ġie pospost darbtejn għall-24 ta' Jan. Bħala waħda mit-tim tal-osservaturi tal-Parlament Ewropew għall-monitoraġġ tat-tieni rawnd, nixtieq ngħid biss "X'diżastru u x'ħasra ta' pajjiż!"   Inqas minn tmienja u erbgħin siegħa qabel il-votazzjoni, l-awtoritajiet elettorali pposponew l-elezzjoni għat-tielet darba, iżda din id-darba għal perjodu indefinit fost oppożizzjoni bi protest vjolenti, ighrħq ta' bini, vett uuri qtil ta' nies.   Għal wieħed mill-pajjiżi l-aktar fqar tad-dinja, bidla democrat hija essenzjali għal politika politicalcastli u biex tirkupra l-ekonomija. Jekk le, il-miżerja ta' dan il-poplu ser tibqa' tikber aktar, miżerja li sfortunatament ġiet ikkawżata minn politika ta' dittatorjat, mill-korruzzjoni, nuqqas ta' edukazzjoni, u nuqqas ta' saħħa, nuqqas ta' direzzjoni u wkoll l-effetti tat-terremot devastanti ta' ftit snin ilu. U hu għalhekk importanti li dan il-pajjiż jirbaħ lura l-fidu大ja tal-poplu. Iżda biex dan iseħħ huwa importanti li l-vjolenza tieqaf minnufih, u l-partijiet involuti jinvolvu ruħhom fi proħess maħsub biex jaslu b'su大大ess għal elezzjoni trasparenti u demokratika. L-Unjoni Ewropea tista' tgħin billi tawtorizza missjoni spe大jali li tgħin f'azzjonijiet politi大i sabiex jinnegozjaw data ġdida għall-elezzjonijiet, tagħmel monitoraġġ tas-sitwazzjoni attwali biex jiġi evitat aktar vjolenza u tassisti sabiex tissolva l-kriżi b'mod imminenti.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Mrs Valenciano and all my fellow Members who have taken part in this mission. I was part of the delegation of the European Union Electoral Mission in Haiti on 25 October 2015. Haiti is a country that is struggling to recover from the devastating consequences of the earthquake that struck it six years ago. The situation, I do not deny, is still difficult. The country has many contradictions, but in spite of everything it strongly claims its right to free and democratic elections. We have ensured that this happens. Thanks to our presence in Haiti, the elections of 25 October were held regularly and without fraud, in a climate of legality and respect for the rules, as my fellow Members have also testified. The people welcomed us with enthusiasm, making our presence on the island even more significant, despite the low turnout in the election, I must admit, due to the lack of confidence in local institutions. Since these elections, the Haitian people have expressed two candidates. We must acknowledge and recognise the will of the people and, above all, we must carry out our mission: to ensure that, in the short term, Haiti has democratic and stable institutions capable of bringing the country out of the precarious situation in which it has been in the country for far too long. I would remind you that the task of election observation missions is also, through the promotion of democracy, to consolidate peace and security. I believe that we should give continuity to a process which, in our opinion, has not been completed.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I agree with what Commissioner Creţu said. It is a fact that when an institutional crisis is triggered in a country on the basis that one candidate refuses to respect an election that has not been accompanied by any mass fraud, it is indeed throwing the country into chaos. And I do not think that the solution to such a situation is that we will leave this country, that we will leave the people of this country and so-called leave them at the mercy of their fate. I think that what the previous speaker, Mr Corrao, has proposed is not the solution. In my opinion, we should continue to monitor this process, probably send another mission. To try to increase people's motivation to vote and, of course, to complete the democratic process that is going on in Haiti. We mustn't resign, that would certainly be a mistake.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as a Greek MEP I express my solidarity with the people of Haiti, the first people to recognise the independence of the newly created Greek state after the Revolution of 1821.  After the 2010 earthquake, NGOs and the West imposed a paria government. In fact, in Haiti, the paradox is that the international community manages ten times more funds there than Haiti's budget. This is a phenomenon of modern Hollywood so-called humanism, but it has completely failed, having deepened the food crisis, uprooted farmers and failed to organise democratic elections. That is why he is dealing with the very population of Haiti, which has been uprooted.  The path to the elections has been marked by controversy and violence and there is also questioning, as it has been heard, about the outcome of the October 2015 elections. There is already a deadlock, as the second round of the presidential elections is constantly postponed and it is certain that the Haitian people will send a message with many recipients about the democratic transition, the completion of the electoral process and the blow of poverty.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, when Haiti was hit by a catastrophic earthquake in January 2010, when over 200,000 people died, we were all in solidarity, we all sympathized with this people and knowing that it was one of the poorest states in the world, knowing that the state lived mainly in chaos, instability and corruption. We all hoped on October 25th last year that elections that were both free and regular according to everything our colleagues and colleagues saw in Haiti, we hoped that there would finally be a new process of stability on the island. Unfortunately, that didn't happen.  Europe has helped Haiti through its most difficult moments. Europe has stood with Haiti in this past election. Europe needs to keep going because I am sure that our help to this people is in dire need.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, it has been a very useful exchange and I thank all Members for the clarity of their interventions and, of course, for their efforts to find a solution to these deadlocks we are facing now in Haiti. The subject is the crisis after the elections but I should say, and I am sure that you all know, that the EU has been providing support for the Haitian people, in one of the poorest countries in the world, for long years now. Especially after the earthquake in 2010, one out of two Haitians has been reached by some help in one way or another. From this debate I conclude that we all agree on using EU diplomacy, EU diplomatic efforts and other instruments to support the Haitian-led solution to the current crisis, grounded in respect for democracy and human rights. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in election observation and in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya (2016/2537(RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I welcome the opportunity to join you today to discuss an important topic on behalf of the High Representative Federica Mogherini: the situation in Libya, the advances made so far and the challenges that are still lying ahead. We have seen considerable progress since the last debate in this Chamber. The Libyan political agreement was signed in Skhirat on 17 December, a Presidency Council has been formed and is meeting and working, and the Government of National Accord has been announced and the Temporary Security Council has been appointed. As soon as she could, on Friday 8 January, the High Representative travelled to Tunis to meet the Presidency Council to express the EU’s political support for their action and to discuss with all its members, all together, about the immediate and longer-term assistance the European Union can provide to the new Libyan authorities. She reminded them that the European Union’s EUR 100 million aid package for Libya has been ready for a while and that all it takes for its full implementation is for the Government of National Accord to start working in the country. On the ground, promising new truces were signed recently between the municipalities: between Misrata and the neighbouring Tawergha, finally putting an end to an enmity dating back to the 2011 revolution; and between Zawiya and Zintan west of Tripoli, in Sorman, again just west of Tripoli and in the south, although it remains shaky between the Tebus and the Touareg, who have been fighting for months in Obari. The House of Representatives voted on 25 January to approve the Libyan political agreement, albeit conditionally. The recognition of the UN-brokered process is the sole genuine political process in Libya. At the same time the House of Representatives did not approve the ministerial appointments in the proposed GNA. Further discussions are required, but eventually we hope and expect that Libyan decision-makers will realise that there is no alternative to a Unity Government representing all the regions and all the social and political groups and that only such a government will give real hope to the Libyan people that their country can finally tackle, hopefully once and for all, the spread of terrorism, an economy on the brink and threats to Libya’s integrity and development. When the Unity Government is endorsed by parliament, the priority will be the security of the population and the fight against Daesh. Tripoli’s security must be essentially enforced by the Libyans themselves. Libyans will provide the core of the new security apparatus and the international community can provide further training and assistance should the new government request it. The European Union is also actively engaged in this security effort. Our liaison and planning cell in Tunis has been active and will continue to support the United Nations and the new Libyan authorities in drafting plans. Member States have agreed to bolster the cell and also to reinforce civilian planning capacity through a reactivated and expanded EU-BAM mission. It should become operational in the next few weeks and provide capacity on a broad spectrum of police support including counter-terrorism, customs, border security and migration. Mr President, honourable Members, the democratic transition in Libya is a difficult and complicated process, but a UN-brokered Libyan political agreement has made important progress and deserves our continued support. The alternative is simply chaos – a country on the brink of economic catastrophe – and all this can still be avoided. It is our duty as Libya’s neighbours to continue supporting the United Nations process and the GNA, and we are fully committed to continuing doing exactly that.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Minister, yes, the priority in Libya today is the formation of a government of national unity. We can only support Martin Kobler's unparalleled efforts. The government's installation in Tripoli is also a key element in ending the political vacuum and the symbolic and geographical division of the country, which allows terrorism to spread. In the immediate future, the situation in Libya is at a major turning point and it is worth recalling the responsibility of the Libyan parties, not only towards Libyans but also with regard to other countries in the Sahel region, including Burkina Faso and Mali. We have known for a long time that the situation in Libya is a regional and international security issue. The responsibility and conscience of the Libyan parties are now the decisive elements. In the short and medium term, the European Union and the international community will need to be ready on various fronts, once the government is back in place, in order to redeploy the border management assistance mission and to rapidly deploy a new civilian mission. Apart from these priorities, we must work to mobilize the international community for economic reconstruction, because political peace will be in vain if the country's economy collapses and the government is powerless. Third, the coordination and complementarity of the support of the international community must be organised. The United Nations, the European Union, the African Union, the League of Arab States all have a role to play in economic, security, reconciliation and the prevention of radicalisation, for example. Only together can we prevent the situation in Libya from having ever more serious consequences for all of us.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the latest information we have received from Libya is of a country on the brink, as was mentioned before, who knows how many times in this House. The humanitarian situation is disastrous and needs immediate relief. Daesh has managed to put down roots. It used to have only a few hundred fighters on the ground, now there seem to be thousands. It is easy to understand what it means in terms of eradicating them. A political solution with a government of national accord is essential – imperative – and we call on the House of Representatives to show a spirit of compromise and to endorse the new list of ministers once it is proposed, hopefully in the coming hours. But this will only be a small step in the right direction, because the challenges ahead are many and all of them are urgent. Let me not miss another important point: until now, sanctions against certain people were threatened but never put in place. It is now time to be more concrete and effective and to apply sanctions against those people who undermine the political solution for Libya. The new government will have to tackle the disastrous humanitarian and security situation in the country, which is already in the wind. To do so, it needs the help of the EU and the international community. As the President of Nigeria, Mr Buhari, mentioned this morning, the situation in Libya is not only a local problem, it is becoming a major regional one, with huge consequences for a region which is already confronted with too many crises. Today Libya desperately needs a united army to eradicate Daesh, but this will not be enough if it is not complemented with all the necessary means from the international community.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as the UN—brokered talks continue, we must remain optimistic that the agreement reached in December of last year can be fully implemented and that a stable and durable Libyan Government of National Accord can now be formed. Such discussions take time, however, and we cannot ignore the growing presence of ISIS in the region. As the coalition against ISIS meets in Rome to discuss progress, militarily speaking, in Iraq and Syria, I am pleased to see that Libya is also now on the agenda. All options must remain open. I welcome the news that the United States is considering military offensives against ISIS in Libya, as well as Syria and Iraq, in the event of a UN agreement breaking down. Whilst reports suggest that the French Government has ruled out any further military action, I would hope that other EU Member States, not least my own, the United Kingdom, would also consider supporting such action, as we were active in Libya when the Gaddafi regime fell. Entrenched ISIS strongholds on the coast of Libya after their defeat in Syria or Iraq would constitute a complete failure of the Neighbourhood Policy and pose a grave security risk to EU Member States, particularly in the context of the migration crisis.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister for the brief and show my appreciation for the efforts from colleagues from the other political groups on the draft resolution that we have managed to agree on. It is a very good text. It is balanced, and what is important is that there was strong support behind it. I hope that this will also show tomorrow during the vote. It has already been said today that President Buhari has reminded us of the situation not just in the south of Libya, and not just in Libya, but in the whole Sahel region, which is in crisis. It also has to be said that there is now one of the highest concentrations of arms that has ever been seen in the region. It is also a matter of fact that human trafficking has been present for years and is further intensifying. The situation of the people, as well as of minorities and migrants, is just devastating. It is tragic. So it is high time that we were able to arrive at an agreement, but of course we need that agreement to be supported. What can we do apart from assisting Libya in this respect? I think that it is a condition sine qua non that we will be communicating only with those entities that are party to the agreement. This is absolutely necessary. We know that sometimes some of our Member States and some of our politicians find informal channels. This is not an issue on which we should play with fire. Daesh is present. A part of the coastline is basically in the hands of Daesh, or groups loyal to it. The territory is not that far from Europe, so basically we have all the prerequisites for a widespread conflict in which ISIS will be gaining ground. We should therefore avoid making the mistakes of the past and make the best of the opportunity today. It will not be easy, but it needs to be supported. For me, the last resort – if political efforts fail – would eventually be an intervention. I understand that the coalition against ISIS has not reached that yet in Rome, but this is the option of last resort.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are seeing that there are difficulties in implementing the political agreement in Libya sponsored by the United Nations. It is something that is encouraging the intention to abandon that slow but safe route and that they are launching, again, so that we go through the winds of war.  We have listened to U.S. commanders and NATO Secretary-General advocating for new military intervention. We must remember what happened with NATO's previous intervention: total destruction of the Libyan state; thousands of innocent victims; permanent destabilization of the region and the expansion of terrorism.  We reject any military intervention. We reject NATO's attempt to replace the United Nations. We demand the cessation of all arms exports and the cessation of militia funding – i.e. buying their oil – and the investigation into the violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1970.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU's most urgent task at the moment is to support the UN in the fight for a unity government in Libya. The rival factions must prove that they have leadership and are committed to such a government. There is no alternative to this. There is no question that some population groups and militias were not taken into account in the negotiations. But let us be realistic: without joint action by the governments of Tripoli and Tobruk, there will be no basis for a peace process. We observe that in the chaotic Libyan conditions the so-called Islamic State has been able to spread further and further. That is why every effort must be focused on combating it. But anyone who thinks that this can be achieved by military intervention at the moment is mistaken. In view of the chaotic situation, such actions would not only be doomed to failure; they would also be water on the mills of those groups that are propagandistically using any international action as an attack on the country's sovereignty. In this context, the planned third phase of the EUNAVFOR MED operation, i.e. an armed operation against smugglers on Libyan territory, is also more than questionable. Such an approach would further fuel the conflicts. With regard to human rights, we are noting that there is a constant deterioration. People are being arbitrarily abducted, tortured, violence against journalists and human rights activists is on the increase, refugees and migrants are living in appalling conditions. We cannot accept that! If the international community does not want to create a second Syria, it must support the future government with humanitarian aid and strengthen civil society organisations. And we must work to ensure that those responsible for serious human rights violations are held accountable to the international criminal justice system.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, politics today suffers from a terrible evil: the syndrome of doing. Do anything in order not to give the impression of being immobile and therefore surpassed by competitors or at least overwhelmed by events. One of the chronically ill of this evil is the current prime minister of my country Matteo Renzi. But to make choices with very serious consequences, such as starting military intervention without having a clear political objective to pursue, is unforgivable for a statesman. Worse, it's flag-waving one reason to chase another, that's just a crime. A crime that, for example, took place in 2011, and everything that came next was the direct responsibility of those who intervened recklessly at the time. According to the Blumenthal official of the Us Government, that intervention was pushed by Sarkozy to pursue two-sided economic and commercial interests: to get his hands on more oil concessions, taking them away from the Italian ENI, to increase French influence in Africa, to reaffirm military and also internal prestige – in this case Sarkozy –, but above all to prevent Gaddafi's possible plan to supplant the African French franc , the CFA, with a new pan-African currency guaranteed by libyan reserves. There were so many suspicions and now there is the word of the United States diplomatic corps. When I hear the itchy interventionists of France, Great Britain, Italy and the United States in Libya, I think certain lessons have not been understood. I am thinking of those leaders who care too much about the media responses to the Paris attacks, to show their muscles. I think that the only real fear that afflicts them, and that Daesh has understood well, is simply to defend the oil infrastructure, certainly not the rights of libyans or the security of Europeans. All the more, they are aimed at not losing the elections.  The priority objective is to stabilise Libya and resume the transition. If we go to bomb and deploy our armies we will only end up co-joining the Islamist militias around the catalyst of Daesh. The capture of Sirte is nothing more than what happened in Tikrit after the fall of Saddam Hussein: the exclusion of a community in retaliation, the logic of revenge instead of reconciliation. And daesh grows with the former elements of Gaddafi and the tribal elements, not for ideological choices but for political mistakes. If action is taken without a clear political agreement, the factions and militias that will approach our forces will then become portrayed as collaborators of the invaders, they will be discredited, and then the reconciliation process will be further undermined. Instead, the regional powers should be expected, in the face of growing chaos, to finally stay away from interfering and stop being seized by the logic of strong men like Aftar who have only complicated the negotiations. If the factions do not want to negotiate, let the talks be to be addressed to local realities, to municipalities, to tribal leaders directly. Let us not again allow the catastrophe of a careless war of the emergency to hit us to make it easy. It is time to demand what is right.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have today received a letter from the Parliament in Tobruk, signed by dozens of Members, to pass it on to the High Representative, which I have done. In it, the Parliament of Tobruk informs us that, as a result of the embargo, it is unable to defend itself against Isis and that it wants a government that is not an instrument of external forces interested only in controlling Libyan resources. Why has the European Union done nothing in Libya so far to really help libyans fight Isis and let it expand to Europe's doorstep?
