Given the results of the Franco-American intervention, does the High Representative not think that further un coordinated intervention, which the Libyans will not accept and will fight, can lead to a complete loss of border control and increase a further invasion of Europe?  The Libyan Government inherited the embargo to which the Gaddafi regime was subject. But has the European Union realised that Gaddafi is no longer there and that the situation has therefore changed? We call on the European Union and the Member States to sign readmission agreements with the new government, such as the one that Italy already had with Libya. Let us remember that, according to the UN, there are 400 000 migrants in Libya ready to leave for Europe, among whom, as the Minister of Defence, Mr French, can easily join a large number of terrorists or men linked to Isis and Daesh anyway. I believe that this appeal from the Members of the Tobruk Parliament must be taken seriously by this Parliament and, of course, by the High Representative, who has so far been deaf to these appeals.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, in my constituency, Northern Ireland, and indeed for all victims of Gaddafi-sponsored IRA terrorism, the fight for justice and compensation goes on. The Northern Ireland Affairs Select Committee at Westminster has rightly criticised our former Prime Minister, Tony Blair, for his unwillingness to give straight answers to straight questions regarding what discussions he had about compensation for IRA victims when Colonel Gaddafi was in power. His approach ignores the valid concerns of innocent victims of terrorism. I am under no illusions; we must see a relative and sustainable peace in Libya in order to further our goal of negotiating a fair financial settlement for these innocent victims. In Libya we want a peace that is democratic, upholds fundamental freedoms, and that provides space for religious minorities who, at present, live under an escalating threat of persecution. We in this House must play our part in bringing that about. But we must then stand with the victims of IRA terrorism in pressing their right to compensation.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, High Representative Mr Gonzato, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work he has said. We should see one thing: resolving the issues and establishing peaceful and stable conditions in Libya is a matter of humanity for a country, but it is crucial for our own stability. That is why we must immediately continue this process, which Mr Kobler has sensibly initiated and advanced – on the part of the High Representatives, on the part of the Member States – in order to achieve a way of enabling our EU mission SOPHIA to be set in motion, in order to include territorial waters and thus combat smugglers and traffickers, and also to get a step under the control of the number of refugees. We may be expecting something bad in Italy and in this direction if there is no progress here by the spring. Secondly, we must achieve stability in the country. That is why it is urgent to stabilise this country through economic and security aid in such a way that it can fulfil its internal obligations. We must also see here that the Member States talk a lot, but so far hardly anyone has paid into the Africa Fund, for example. The aim is to ensure that the Member States meet their financial commitments, so that the appropriate margins are made to develop a better situation in that country and in other countries, thereby preventing ISIS from continuing to establish itself and prevail there. We must also provide military support here, because if they enter the oil fields, including the oil fields of Algeria – which is obviously their aim – we will have even worse situations than we currently have or when we have them in Syria and Iraq. That is why this is such a priority.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the indications in the motion for a resolution are quite clear. The Libyan political agreement represents a unique opportunity to deal with the current untenable situation and to lay the foundations for the construction of a civil and democratic state. The agreement reached in Morocco aims to guarantee the Libyan people a government based on the principle of the separation of powers and to strengthen state institutions, in particular the government of national accord, so as to address all the challenges facing Libya.  Our task today is to put in place all the political and diplomatic action necessary to ensure that not only is the agreement approved, but that it is implemented and that the foundations are created for greater inclusiveness of all actors within the framework of the necessary process of national reconciliation. In this context, I would like to highlight three elements, in addition to those already present in the resolution, on which it would be appropriate for the Council and the Commission to work. The first is the important role of neighbouring countries, a role that they are in fact already playing, to help the stabilisation process, and we must invest in this role. Secondly, it is important to give the municipalities a further role. Precisely because of the way in which the libyan reality is conformed, starting with the tribal reality, local institutions can play a vital role in the process of democratic stabilisation. Finally, there is a further message that I think it would be useful to give here to Parliament: avoid the mistakes of the past. It is to be hoped that the international community and the ruling class will use greater awareness, foresight and wisdom this time. Use your head and not just your belly.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – The debates on Libya are repeating themselves a bit in this hemisphere. Every time we say, time is running out for Libya. Meanwhile, we see anarchy, porous borders, people smugglers, long lines of desperate refugees: a catchment area for IS. And as the Islamic State gradually loses ground in Iraq and Syria, it is gaining ground in Libya. Along the southern coast of the Mediterranean, just 300 kilometres from the European Union, IS is building a bridgehead, an outright threat to stability and security in Europe. From the throngs of people from Sudan, Nigeria and Chad, IS recruits its army of the poor. Time is running out. Time is up. Without a safe and stable Libya, there is no security for the region and for the EU. A legitimate, inclusive Libyan government is a prerequisite. And then an international peacekeeping mission can help to stabilise the country - hopefully with the support of the Arab League and the African Union - and we are also planning a step forward this time. Reconstruction must be an integral part of such an intervention.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am less optimistic than you are, Mr Koenders. I fear yet another war in Libya because we are now aware of the disasters of the anti-terc wars. Let us not forget that refugees are the result of the chaos that we have been soeling everywhere for years. Foreign fighters talk confusingly about Islam, but they think mostly of themselves as war generations. You cannot untie the Syrian knot and you do not want it, since you accept the Turkish diktat: no Kurds in the negotiations for now. The only one who wants them is Putin, perhaps the only one who knows the indispensability of the Kurds if you want to win ISIS. Same blindness in Libya: The failed intervention in 2011 opened the country's doors to ISIS and has now prepared an intervention without being sure that there is a state in Libya. Last but not least, I do not think that Italy should set foot in Libya because of its colonial past.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I think it is clear that the European Union has not played a very good role in Libya. We have serious doubts about the suitability of sending military contingents there, and we do not quite know what these thousand British soldiers, those five thousand Italian soldiers, are doing; what they do or who they're serving, actually. At the very least, our two objectives are clearly stated in this Resolution. Firstly, to exhaust in every way possible this peace process, that constitution of a unitary government that really serves the interests of the Libyan people. And secondly, to help refugees, who are suffering in their flesh that war and who are also producing destabilization in the Mediterranean, and especially in the neighbouring country, in Tunisia. But I would like to point out that this resolution cannot be completed if there is at least no reference to the case of the Spanish diplomat Bernardino León, that high envoy of the United Nations who, at the same time as a mediator, negotiated with the United Arab Emirates – with one of the parties involved – a great personal contract. This is a conflict of interest that we cannot tolerate and which we must condemn and reflect in this Resolution. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, colleague, for taking my blue card. Do you agree with me that the European Union getting involved in this dispute further complicates the situation? Should this not ideally be left to local actors, i.e. the African Union, with support from the United Nations? Is European Union meddling just exacerbating the situation and making it worse?

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response. – Dear colleague, I do not share your point of view. I believe that the European Union should not be involved in a military way , I think I have made it very clear.  But we are on the border with Libya, we have interests in Libya and we also have a call made in our own Constitution to defend human rights. And so we have to get involved in resolving the Libyan conflict with all our energy.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, David Cameron’s support for the UN resolution to overthrow the Gaddafi  regime in Libya is a classic example of the short-sighted reaction to events which these days takes the place of any proper strategic thinking on the international stage. By overthrowing a dictator using a bombing campaign, we created anarchy in Libya and left a power vacuum which the murderers of Islamic State have been able to exploit. What this has led to is a humanitarian crisis on the EU’s external borders, the consequences of which we saw this summer and continue to see in the Mediterranean, in Scandinavia, Calais, and of course the recent disgraceful events in Germany. And now the EU wants to lead the military mission in resolving the situation in Libya, as we heard from the Chairman of the EU Military Committee at last week’s defence committee meeting. I would suggest that rather than dilute our sovereignty further by joining up with the doomed-to-fail EU mission, the UK Government instead learn from its mistakes and stop rushing in to remove leaders without considering the consequences. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – I have listened very carefully, Colleague, to your contribution and have a small question. Did I understand correctly that, in your opinion, it was wrong that we contributed to the overthrow of dictator Gaddafi? Please clarify, thank you.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Right: if you go around interfering in foreign countries without having a plan for fixing it, what you do instead is you bring horror and terror to the poor people who live there and you bring terrorism and issues relating to this to your own borders. I hope that clears it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: Mr President, the situation in Libya is, among other things, the consequence of the intervention of Nicolas Sarkozy, under the aegis of NATO, supported by some French members of the PS and the former UMP, here elected. It led to the fall of Colonel Gaddafi, the only one capable of unifying the 150 or so tribes living on Libyan soil and making Libya the richest country in Africa, with a very low unemployment rate. Today, this country is plunged into widespread chaos. The only credible way out would be to support the tribes that oppose the Islamic State group.  I read an interview with Franco Roberti, national prosecutor of the anti-mafia and anti-terrorist directorate in Rome. I've learned two things from that. First, its services suspect the "Islamic State" group, which is present in Iraq, Syria and Libya, of being involved in the smuggling, which is not surprising. Secondly, Mr Roberti affirms what we have always denounced: among the immigrants crossing the Mediterranean, there are terrorists linked to the "Islamic State" group. We know that this group is making progress in Libya, so we can really fear for our security. We must urgently review our immigration policy, which prevails in this House, and to put an end to the departure of illegal boats from Libya.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Libya is much more than worrying: it promises us a bleak future in Europe if we do not act quickly. The attacks of the "Islamic State" group against the oil terminals east of Sirte, the situation of the city of Houn in Fezzan, its many training camps: all this shows that, every day, our enemy is gaining ground. There are at least two legitimate grounds for intervening in Libya: first, the rapid advance of the Islamic State group and, second, the explosion of illegal migrant flows. In a country that the intervention against Gaddafi has destroyed, the urgency is to take these two subjects into their own hands and avoid their combination. I see two solutions to be pursued together. First, a new European military intervention coordinated with Egypt to eliminate the "Islamic State" group, but France, already heavily engaged in the Middle East and Africa, cannot carry it out alone. Secondly, the construction of detention and eligibility centres for political refugee status on Libyan territory, as indeed at the start of all migration routes that converge towards the Union. On this subject, our States could be strengthened by the use of private security companies acting under EU contracts.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, when we look at Libya, we have an impression of déjà vu. The political situation is once again deadlocked. The Parliament of Tobruk, although recognized by the international community, has just rejected the un-sponsored government. The hope of signing the political agreement last December was quickly dashed.  The Union must now do all it can to enable this agreement to be implemented through the formation of a credible and legitimate government of national unity in the eyes of all Libyans. While they fail to agree on a government, the Islamic State group is taking advantage of instability and dissension to gain a further foothold. This terrorist organization threatens not only the security of the country, but also its economic survival. By targeting oil infrastructure, it is endangering the only source of income for Libyans, who are facing a catastrophic economic situation. The diplomatic route in the Libyan conflict must of course be favoured, but military support cannot be ruled out. One thing is for sure, the Libyan government will not be able to ask for our military assistance to stabilize the country if this government does not exist. Military intervention by coalition countries cannot be envisaged without an effective political strategy that is accepted by all Libyans. We need to work hand in hand with them to define this strategy.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Union and the Member States have failed to act as a cohesive and coherent Europe to assist Libyan transitional governments in the task that should have been a priority, without which it was obvious that neither a state nor governance would function.  The construction of security forces under national command, which meant demobilizing the militias, not letting them infiltrate by criminal and terrorist networks, exploiting Gaddafi's armours at the arms bazaar, of which we still hear from nigeria's president today.  The Union and the Member States continue to bury their heads in the sand, all reducing tribal struggles between Libyans, continuing to denied the proxy war conducted on Libyan soil by rival Sunni powers, Egypt and the Emirates behind Saudi Arabia, which funds salafist groups against Turkey and Qatar, which support the Muslim Brotherhood.  Proxy war that organizes the disintegration of Libya and the expansion of Daesh and other terrorist groups on the ground. The Libyan political agreement that UN Secretary-General Martin Kobler's representative has managed to negotiate offers an opportunity that the Libyan people and the European Union and the region cannot waste. It is an opportunity in extremis to prevent the escalation of violence.  A terrorist attack organised from Libya against Europeans will be responsive and no one will know how to control the impacts of external military intervention. For the Libyan political agreement and the Government to avenge national agreement, it is vital that the European Union immediately imposetargeted sanctions against any individual, or organisation, Libyan abroad, boycotting the agreement and the Government.  Europe must assume that it is its vital obligation and interest to invest in security in Libya. The eradication of terrorist sanctuaries involves working on the demobilisation, disarmament and reintegration of any militia in combating arms and human trafficking and training Libyan security forces under unified command.  If security is not restored, there will be no democratic transition in Libya, no capacity for governance, respect for human rights, control of migration flows, nor oil management. The Union must engage in Libya and be interested in the Libyan people. This is the only way to ensure your safety and security in the region.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – I hope that the government of national unity will be established immediately. It is necessary for the security of the population, the absorption of aid measures, the displacement of Daesh and the associated smuggling mafias, control of mining facilities. I support EUBAM Libya, I support EU NAVFOR MED Sophia, the efforts of the High Representative and the international community as a whole.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is where the adventures that have been supported by parliamentarians here by Mr Sarkozy, former President of the French Republic, and the coffee philosopher Bernard Henri-Lévy have led us. The observation, we have here: the dramatic situation of Libyans and Europe, which is the direct consequence of this adventure in Libya. The truth is that our governments today deal with terrorists, Islamist terrorists on one side or the other, but terrorists anyway, and no one wants to discuss or continue to discuss with the Parliament of Tobruk, which has partly the key to the recovery of the situation. In this criminal geopolitical fog that we have created, we must send a signal and a mission of MEPs, especially in Mali, to take stock of the situation and no longer be mistaken about our adversaries and our friends in this region.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the political agreement signed on 17 December in Sjirat, subsequently endorsed by the Security Council in its Resolution 2259, was a very positive step for Libya, but the decisions taken by the Tobruk Parliament, as has been said last week, namely the rejection of the proposed Government and the differences around Article 8 of the agreement , are very important pitfalls; must be overcome quickly. Alongside armed clashes, political division has only aggravated the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people, sinking the Libyan economy and facilitating the establishment and progressive expansion of Dáesh, which is very worrying. Dáesh seems to have become strong in Sirte and we have already seen his capacity for attraction and destabilization in the Middle East. We need final agreement on a government of national unity as soon as possible. It will be the best formula to combat Dáesh and to pacify and stabilize Libya, a very important Mediterranean country, whose situation also affects neighbours such as Algeria, Egypt and, of course, Tunisia. In addition, Libya is the direct connecting route between the convulsive Sahel region and the Mediterranean coasts, which are also our shores. It is imperative, I repeat, that a unity government should be formed quickly to combat terrorism and trafficking in human beings and to lead Libya on the path of peace and prosperity. I hope that the efforts of the United Nations Special Envoy, Mr Kobler, and the involvement of the various actors with the greatest influence in the region will also contribute to the early overcoming of existing obstacles.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the incantations and the speeches, it is time to take action. We know that in order to deal with the chaos we are seeing in Libya, the threats in Tunisia but also in relation to the European continent, we will have to take action, and that is what I am asking the European authorities, the Council and the High Representative. First of all, military strikes must be implemented as a matter of urgency. To do this, there must be a rule of law and a government of national unity in Libya. The Parliament of Tobruk must be told to accept the government of national unity to allow these military strikes and to enable the fight against the "Islamic State" group. And, of course, we must also fight against these mafias, against these smugglers who bring death. Thirdly, economic aid will also have to be granted to the Libyan people at the initiative of the European Union. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask my colleague whether or not he agrees with lifting the embargo, as the Tobruk Government is calling for, that is, whether he believes that without the embargo we could go further than the fact that the Government of Tobruk has an embargo and therefore cannot do what it thinks it is doing, whereas, let us say, the Muslim Brotherhood has the opportunity to do what they want.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, in response to my colleague's question, it is now appropriate to allow the neighbours (Egypt, but also Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia) to be involved in a discussion, a power relationship with the Parliament of Tobruk, in order to find a diplomatic solution and an agreement to establish a government of national unity. It is not a question of whether or not the embargo should be imposed or maintained. We must find a way out, a way out that will effectively fight the "Islamic State" group.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, Dutch President of the Council, Minister Koenders, I very much appreciate your presence here as a compatriot. Mr President, it is increasingly clear that the Libyan battlefield is by no means a side stage for the Islamic State. The facts speak for themselves. The Islamic State is currently directing prominent commanders toward its strategic stronghold and Base of Sirte. In addition, IS propaganda advises African and European Muslims to jihad instead of travelling to Libya in Syria, so in addition to our Syrians, we now have our Libyans. Add to that a huge Libyan coastline under direct IS control. In short, the Islamic State poses a direct threat to our continent from Libyan territory. And passant establishes the EU, as I have heard from Minister Koenders, its hope for a Libyan unity government. However, another Libyan scenario is possible, a true doomsday scenario in which al-Qaeda, IS and the Muslim brothers find each other. Minister Koenders, have you heard about this in the Arab press and what do you think of that? You must have all channels open.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to encourage all efforts of the Libyan leaders to reach a political agreement on swiftly forming the Government of National Accord. No doubt this could be a crucial breakthrough for Libya and a positive contribution for the security and stability of the whole region. Let us hope that this is going to last. Only a united Libya can start the long-overdue process of addressing its political future and the security, humanitarian and economic issues. Continued chaos in Libya would be a major threat to the security of the region and of the EU, with the possibility of a new migration wave. Therefore in this respect the EU’s support for peace in Libya and stability in the entire Southern Neighbourhood is essential. The European Union can be and should be of crucial humanitarian and institutional assistance to the country, including in the security sector reforms. Let us assure the Libyans that we are at their side.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too would like to congratulate the negotiators on this start of agreement, but I will spend the little time I have asking for humanitarian aid for Libya.  The aid required by the humanitarian response plan is not being delivered. There are two and a half million people who need our help. Humanitarian is not political, but to make policy, it is probably most urgent to resolve the humanitarian situation. It's winter and there are many people who need the urgency of our intervention right now.  So I appeal to the Commission's leaders, our agencies, those responsible for the European External Action Service to be aware that only the human being does not live by political agreement alone. Human beings need help, need blankets, need medicine, need food, need a way out that allows them to have a horizon of hope.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Mr President, while I support UN-brokered negotiations and hope that they bring lasting peace to Libya, the reality on the ground is particularly worrying. Mounting speculation about another military intervention in Libya shows that the country is closer to chaos than anything else. Ultimately, this is yet another stinging indictment of the international community’s inability to effect positive change in the region. If Libya were to fall apart again, it could also have a devastating impact on Tunisia – alas, the only bright spot of the so-called Arab Spring. This would only add insult to injury. A lasting outcome will undoubtedly require concessions, patience and, most significantly, Libyan solutions to Libyan problems. Nevertheless, we must support democratic reform, as the consequences of failing again would be far more dramatic than what Libya and its people are living through right now.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, with this resolution on the situation in Libya, Parliament is drawing the right attention to a country which is at a crossroads. As we have heard this evening, the humanitarian crisis in the country is worsening. Extremist organisations and movements in Libya are on the rise and represent a major threat to the stability of the entire region, and neighbouring countries like Egypt, and particularly Tunisia, are in danger of a security spillover from the Libyan conflict. I firmly believe the European Union must now assist the country in the creation of effective and nationally-commanded security forces that can ensure order in Libya. Another priority must be support for initiating a ceasefire and a mechanism to monitor it. These actions, however, have little prospect of success as long as the endorsement of a Government of National Unity has not taken place. The international community must therefore continue to support Libya in making this key step.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the situation in Libya is becoming desperate. Daesh extremists are extending their reach. The time to stop them is as soon as possible. However, the European Union decided to await the formation of a Libyan Government of National Unity under the aegis of the United Nations. It should honour this decision so that it can reclaim the respect and trust of the Libyan people. Negotiations towards a National Unity Government have been spiked with mistrust, for Libyan society has been deeply fractured by the events of the past few years. It cannot surprise us that negotiations have encountered long delays. Nor should one overlook mistakes in mediation efforts that were made. Irritated by delays, they went for speed. The main players in the Libyan drama share a country but have totally contrasting perspectives and interests. Whether in good or bad faith, they must decide the future of the people. Imposing sanctions against those who fail to deliver unity now is a bad decision, especially if taken independently of the United Nations system. That will serve to kindle the suspicion of the Libyan people in European intentions. True, quick action is required against Daesh, but allowing more time to truly find a lasting solution by establishing a Libyan National Unity administration is one risk to take.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – For four years now, we have been watching the events in Libya with concern, but also with concern. This has implications for European affairs, both in terms of oil and the threat of terrorism and the wave of refugees. There are currently two parliaments in Libya, although there was little to form a government of national unity. The un cooperating with the European Union is the facilitator of the agreement. I think this is a good configuration, which is also advocated by our group of European Conservatives and Reformists. This configuration should be used primarily with a view to not accidentally creating a third one by way, involuntaryly strengthening islamic state jihadists. The latter also persecute and murder Christians en masse in Libya. Everything must be done to stop them.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as I have said on numerous occasions in this House, the uncontrolled fall of Gaddafi meant that Libya is now a failed state, which has caused the armament of its army of mercenaries to have served to destabilize many countries in the area and, as President Buhari said this morning, that southern Libya has become an arms market.  Libya is currently facing two major problems: the continued expansion of daesh and its attacks on the population and oil facilities; and also a catastrophic economic situation due to its huge dependence on oil.  In view of this dramatic situation in a country, which I would like to remind you that it is on the doorstep of Europe, it is essential to make every effort to implement the Political Agreement signed on 17 December and, above all, to reach the creation of a National Unity Government based in Tripoli.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, time is running out to stabilise Libya. The security, humanitarian and economic situation has become dreadful. ISIS is seizing territory and has now access to significant oil reserves. We know that the US is looking at military options for stopping ISIS advances. At the European Union level we have been supporting Libya primarily with humanitarian aid and by assisting the political process that will lead to a unity government. Libyans want this agreement to succeed; after five brutal years, they must see some hope. Only a government of national accord can stabilise Libya. The House of Representatives in Libya needs to ensure that, although not perfect, the agreement on a unity government needs to be endorsed so that Libya’s situation does not become hopeless. The EU should continue providing the necessary humanitarian and development assistance. We must not allow any other Libyan military leader to hijack the political process. Libyans do not need another Gaddafi.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – Libya, a country just 300 km from Europe's southern border, is mired in growing political chaos five years after the fall of the Gaddafi regime, and it is essential that a government of national unity is formed as soon as possible. In fact, the country is in real danger of being taken over by Daesh radicals. Already, by attacking oil refineries, they are dragging Libya to the economic bottom and creating a breeding ground for chaos, radicalisation and terrorism. Libya has become a place where not only arms trade thrives, but also people who want to embark on a better life in Europe. Human rights violations are multiplying, not only for the people of Libya, but for hundreds of thousands of refugees living in disastrous conditions. Today, Libya, more than intervention from the outside, needs a clear vision of its political elites, it needs unity and more support and humanitarian aid from us, because which direction the country will take in the near future will affect not only its future, but also the security of the whole region, including Europe.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Libya is our neighbouring country. The situation is extremely dramatic because a political vacuum is being exploited by Daesh and other extremist forces, and their growing presence and influence is now spilling over to neighbouring countries like Tunisia, Egypt, the Sahel and even Europe. On the coast of the Mediterranean, there are estimated to be about 3 000 Daesh fighters who are also targeting Libyan oil fields and refineries. Today the EU should concentrate all political and humanitarian efforts on supporting the implementation of last December’s political agreement and the Government of National Unity, but in case this fails, we should consider another alternative – military intervention by a UN-backed international force just to prevent Daesh taking over Libya, which is our neighbour.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last week the agreement to form a government of national unity failed, and this is a report that is very serious and tragic. The absence of legitimate government is destabilizing the region. The political vacuum is exacerbating the humanitarian situation of its population and fundamentally destabilizing neighboring states, especially Tunisia and Egypt; the Libyan vacuum is fertile ground for IS-linked extremist organizations. Until there is a government of national unity, the impact of the EU naval military mission against smugglers (Operation Sophia) will also be very limited. Only the legitimate Libyan Government can allow its vessels to enter territorial waters. I therefore urge EU leaders and the international community to make every effort to stabilise this country and to help reach an agreement on a government of national unity.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the debate that has been said here, and I agree with the analysis that colleagues have carried out here. The situation in this country is utterly bleak and Europe is in danger of another influx of refugees from that country in the future. However, I would like to mention in my speech one thing that has not fallen here and which is also a threat to Europeans, and that is the abduction of Europeans who somehow appear on the territory of Libya. I wanted to speak and give information to the Commission and representatives of the European Council that a Czech was kidnapped in this way, I represent the Czech Republic here, last March 2015. It was Pavel Hrůza, who worked in the oil field and was kidnapped by terrorists and has been detained for more than a year. It is good to know this information and, if necessary, to take it into account in negotiations with certain groups, because the risk of kidnapping is current here and will increase in the future if the situation in Libya does not improve.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Libya's current economic and political disintegration is affecting the country's already oppressed people. Firstly, we are still seeing attacks today against important oil infrastructures, which are of paramount importance for the well-being of the Libyan population, since 80% of its GDP depends on the oil sector. Recently, Daesh terrorists, who have consolidated their influence in the country since Gaddafi's overthrow in 2011, continued for a second day the bombing of the port and oil station Es Sider, causing a large fire in an oil tank.  The result of this war situation in Libya is the forcing of thousands of people to leave the country, thus intensifying migration flows. It is therefore clear that all the Member States of the European Union should oppose the violations of international law that occur daily in the country, as well as any action that violates human rights. At the same time, Turkey's action supporting Daesh terrorists operating in Libya must be supported.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: "Mr. President, when I first spoke about Libya in this Parliament, I said we know what we will not do. We didn't want a dictatorial Gadafi. We know what we want: we want a democratic Libya, but we don't know how we want it. Now do we know what we really want and do we know how we're going to do it? It's amazing that several thousand thugs are creating a complete problem for us in our southern neighborhood, destabilizing our friendly states.  We can't solve this problem, and we could have once destroyed a powerful military force led by Gadafi. I cannot believe that this European Union of ours does not have enough diplomatic means to solve this problem. We need urgent and radical measures because all the accidents from the southern Mediterranean are coming through Libya.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that today all the main candidates of both the Republican and Democratic parties recognise that the fundamental mistake of the United States was to clear the field in Iraq, that it created a security vacuum and created a pre-field for the expansion of Da'ish. I think it would be a considerable mistake if we repeated this process if we left Libya at this time. It is necessary to say that the largest concentration of weapons, according to all available information, is indeed on the territory of Libya today. And we should be looking at how to establish a government of national unity, I think there have been a number of instructional instructions in this debate. I would very much like the Minister and, of course, the Institutions of the European Union to continue to play a positive role in this matter, even though some other powers are trying to keep Libya in the state it is in. This should certainly not be in the interest of the European Union.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, supporting militarily the toppling of Gaddafi, Europe and the United States were wrong in not providing support to Libya after the intervention. Everybody assumed that the Libyan institutions were strong and stable enough, despite the fact that the country was the playground of a single dictator for 42 years. Four years after the fall of Gaddafi and a horrible civil war – the end of which is only now in sight – the advance of Daesh should not come as a surprise. Drawn by the oil infrastructures of Libya, the terrorist group gains ground in a war-torn country with porous borders, which lacks the structures to resist its advance. We should draw the consequences of our inaction until now and provide all the necessary financial, political and security assistance we can in order to support the establishment of a functional and inclusive Government of National Accord and a state strong enough to withstand the spread of the cancer that is Daesh.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Thank you very much, Mr President. Thank you for this interesting debate and for the important remarks made by Members. I think we all agree – and I am speaking here on behalf of the High Representative – that Libya is absolutely crucial for our common foreign and security policy. Libya is close by. It is close by Tunisia and Egypt and it is close by Mali and Niger; and I also agree with those of you who said that there are risks, and increasing risks, of a Daesh presence in Libya. We also agree that the political process, although advancing, is not proceeding fast enough, that there are plenty of hurdles ahead, and that the new authorities are fragile and need all our support. I think we also agree, if I listen carefully to Members, that the European Union, so close to Libya, is confronted with serious threats; that terrorist groups are expanding and must be contained; that Daesh is posing a growing threat, for instance to Libya’s oil industry; that the threat reinforces even more the urgency of finding a political solution through implementation of the LPA, enabling Libyan forces themselves to unite against Daesh; that the Libyan economy and its social fabric are in a perilous state; that there is a serious humanitarian crisis – I shall return to that in a second – that needs to be tackled; and that smugglers must be confronted and illegal migration brought under control. It is important to say that we all know that the real solution to all these daunting problems would be a Libyan Government endorsed by all Libyans and working for all Libyans and benefiting from all the support the international community can give. If you look at the different entities, the many militias and the presence of Daesh in so many parts of Libya, is it possible still to come to a compromise? It will not be easy. We have no doubt that the vast majority of Libyans are not radicals; they do not support Daesh in any shape or form. The new authorities represent much more a relatively moderate majority and we have the obligation to encourage and support them for that precise reason. The European Union will continue to do all it can to contribute to this effort and to make sure Libya emerges a safer and stronger country after five years of upheaval and disappointment. I think it is important also to say that I understand the reasoning that many of you want to talk about plan B. But we firmly believe – and I think the international community as a whole firmly believes – that a unity government at the stage where we are right now, accepted by all Libyans as a result of wide-ranging negotiations, is now the only chance to restore peace and security in the country and prevent a total economic collapse. That is not a matter of naivety; that is where we are right now in negotiations, and going along any other track, in my view and in the view of the High Representative, would not be wise. It is important to say also that, obviously, we are ready to support not only the negotiation process – we do already, the High Representative is active on this; we work very closely with Martin Kobler, whom I would like (and I think many of you said that) to applaud for his work. He came into a very complex situation in December and has immediately taken up the initiative to work not only with the parties in the country but also with the municipalities, which I think is extremely important. Those of you who are closer to the situation in Libya know how important it is to work on different fronts, if you wish, and he has been working on that. He knows the region; he knows how to negotiate, but we have to support him. A special representative cannot do this by himself or herself; it needs the support of the international community, the European Union, but obviously also the members of the Security Council in New York. I think many of you mentioned also the issue of the humanitarian crisis. I think it is important because, in a fragmented security situation, what happens always is that the citizens of the country are victimised. They pay the price, and there is no doubt that the complete disregard for international humanitarian law and limited access make the delivery of humanitarian aid a real challenge. In spite of this, the Commission remains the main humanitarian donor for the Libyan crisis. Besides ECHO, several projects funded from other instruments have been revised in order to respond to the most urgent needs of displaced peoples and migrants, both in terms of humanitarian assistance and protection. It does not mean that we can reach everybody, but the European Union is, I think, the most active actor in responding to this very important humanitarian imperative. That also refers to the issue of human rights abuses. When we work towards a political solution, when we think through the risks of Libya, obviously we realise that human rights abuses are tremendous. You see how many of the militia groups are present in Libya and how they actually, in many instances, control the populations and also abuse their rights. It is important that we keep not only drawing attention to this but also doing the maximum we can do. I have no doubt that it can only be done if we have further progress on the whole discussion of this new government: on the discussions around the formation of that government – how many members – all these issues that play right now and that are in the middle of the fire of the discussion, so to speak, so I do not want to go into them in detail. But an EU human rights mission has taken place in order to at least know exactly what is going on. We work also in the media sector. That also includes training people to ensure that these kinds of things are actually reported, and there are several projects dedicated to transitional processes. To save time, I will not go into all the details. I would like to close with these remarks, realising that I feel very much that there is broad support also in the European Parliament for continuing without any naivety. I realise that: without any naivety. But I also realise that in the end, a political solution, as elsewhere, is actually the most effective one. It is not a soft approach. It is an approach in order to bring some order. It will not be automatically a Denmark or another democracy in Europe in a few years, but it is the only way to bring about stability and to fight, with the support of the European Union, also the threats of Daesh and other extremists.

name: Președintele. –
text: We have received eight motions for resolutions, tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) and (4) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – To many, the situation in Libya may seem nothing more than another conflict on TV. However the reality is that one of the world’s worst internal armed conflicts is happening less than 300 km away from Europe’s borders. We are not talking about the other side of the world, we are talking about our neighbours – and this is why it is imperative to promote peace efforts within the region.  However, this Parliament needs to be clearer – in its words and its actions. We can no longer support one faction, or another – we can only support peace. We must encourage and promote dialogue between all parties that want unity, democracy and above all, amity. We need to ensure that Libya empowers itself, but through unity not division – we must look towards combating terrorism in the region not simply through military actions, but through political ones.  Daesh aims to divide and conquer – and it is only through accord that we can triumph over terrorism. This is why I commend the efforts of the United Nations and Member States like my own, Malta, for taking on an active participatory role in bringing both sides together for a sustainable way forward.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – A politically stable Libya is necessary not only for Libya itself, but for the whole region as well as for Europe. Finding an agreement between all parties is key and can then be moved forward with the help of state building, security, peacekeeping, etc. Libya also has an important role to play in the current migration crisis. It is also worrying that Da'esh's presence will increase in days. You have to fight it now.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Since the overthrow of muammar Gaddafi's dictatorship in 2011 Libya is facing political turmoil and a wave of violence. In mid-2014, the country was divided into two separately administered areas. The hostilities have forced the displacement of 435,000 people, the collapse of the justice system, which is conducive to the spread of extremist groups such as ISIS. Civilian areas are shelled, militias use anti-personnel mines and cluster munitions. As a result, tens of thousands of people are choosing to flee by dangerous sea through Libya to Europe. Humanitarian organisations have serious difficulties in reaching those in need, and food shortages, water and electricity outages and limited access to healthcare are on the agenda.  I call on the Commission to continue to support the UN's efforts to implement the political agreement in Libya, despite the rejection by the Libyan Parliament of the newly formed government of national unity and the political agreement between the rival authorities. Free access to humanitarian aid should also be ensured and mechanisms such as the Trust Fund for Africa should be put in place to respond quickly and flexibly to crises , including the current one on immigration.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2016/2538(RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the delegation from Venezuela, and I would like to thank you for putting Venezuela on the agenda today. Two months after the legislative elections of 6 December, it is timely to debate what impact – or lack thereof – the very significant result of those elections has had on the political and economic course taken by this important country in its very difficult situation. Let me first thank Parliament for the continuous attention you have been paying to the worrying situation over the last two years since 43 people died during the violent street protests of February and March 2014. The resolutions adopted on three occasions since then gave a strong expression of our common conviction that the current crisis can only be overcome by means of a peaceful and constructive dialogue and in respect of human rights and the Venezuelan Constitution. The elections of 6 December, with a high turnout, produced an unequivocal result. A strong majority of the Venezuelan people have given a clear mandate to parliament for taking political decisions in order to address the country’s challenges. The people of Venezuela are suffering. They suffer from rampant violence and insecurity, with Caracas being a city with one of the highest murder rates per capita in the world and an even higher number of kidnappings and other violent attacks. They are suffering shortages of basic goods and food, medicines and medical care. With their peaceful and clear vote on 6 December, the people have requested a political response to these challenges. All political actors and institutions need to respect this democratic vote for the National Assembly as well as the legitimacy of the current government. Now is the time to work together in finding pragmatic and workable solutions to these difficult challenges. Ideological confrontations or institutional standoffs will not bring these solutions, and there is not much time left to lose in political manoeuvring as economic and financial resources are running out, the oil price is not likely to recover soon and inflation and shortages are getting more acute by the week. Initiatives for a national economic dialogue and for a certain process to address the issues of the victims of 2014 have been put forward by the executive. They will be useful if they are inclusive and conducted in a spirit of genuine openness for compromise and new solutions. This requires careful and critical reflection about what has not worked. It is important not to forget the plight of several dozen protesters who are still in jail or have been sentenced in questionable trials. I will only mention the most publicised case of Leopoldo López. Victims of violence must be protected. To achieve this, it is essential to ensure that those accused of having committed acts of violence during the protests get a fair and speedy trial based on objective evidence. All of these issues together form a complex reality that must be tackled. These initiatives should now be embraced as opportunities by both sides – executive and legislative, government and opposition – in a spirit of constructive cooperation and in full respect for the Venezuelan Constitution. It is the Constitution that offers a lawful, peaceful framework in which the Venezuelan body politic can operate as a democracy. Those on either side who feel tempted by non-constitutional methods or parallel structures must know that they have a heavy responsibility. Let us be clear. If the current absence of real dialogue persists, there is a distinct risk of new street protests and violent confrontation, which can easily get out of hand. We know that society is polarised, and there is no escaping that fact. There is a history. Both sides must accept that the other side has a role to play. Neither side is in a position to solve the multiple crises on its own. This is the message that Europe has been giving to our Venezuelan friends. Dialogue and compromise are the only way forward. The European Union and its Member States are working closely together in Brussels and Caracas to convey this message, and we join the considerable number of regional organisations and partner countries that have voiced the same call for national dialogue. Europe has legitimate concerns. There are more than half a million EU citizens living in Venezuela. EU companies are important investors and the European Union is also concerned about regional stability and the negative impact the worsening situation will have on the region. Europe has close ties to the region, and we are cooperating in many ways: from trade to security and from the fight against drugs to education and human rights, to name just the main areas of our cooperation with the region. We stand ready also to step up our cooperation with Venezuela. We know that many Venezuelan citizens are looking to the European Union as a good friend that can help to rebuild constitutionality and economic prosperity. This is the offer we have been making in various ongoing contacts both in Caracas and Brussels. That is also the message that I have expressed in quite a few public statements. Let me take this opportunity to thank you for the strong support that I have felt from the House in taking these positions, and I thank you for your attention.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Minister, Venezuela was once synonymous with progress, well-being and hope. But chavismo, Maduro and his "beautiful revolution" ended that, and only the ruins remain of that Venezuela.  It is astonishing to see how in just ten years its greedy leaders can ruin a rich country. That's not a revolution: that's a demolition. When pharmacies are missing 93 out of 100 medicines, it's not a revolution: it's a demolition. When children go hungry, when on the street a human life is worth less than a gas tank, that's not a revolution: that's a demolition. When good men, when peaceful students, when democratic opponents are in jail, while the Malanders are on the street doing their business with full freedom, that's not a revolution: that's a demolition.  Fortunately, in Venezuela the winds of the people are blowing, and the chavistas, who tried to put democracy in prison, will see democracy change the regime. Thanks to brave women like Mitzy Capriles, like Maria Corina, like Lilian, like Mari, freedom will soon come out of jail in Venezuela.  Antonio Ledezma said that freedom is not negotiated; that justice is not negotiated; Venezuela is not negotiated. It's true. The European Union knows that with Venezuela we must always be at the side of the brave Venezuelan people.  I don't know if there are two parts in Venezuela. If there were, one is still in power, taking advantage of power, and the other is imprisoned.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Pons, I would like you to explain here why in Galicia and the Spanish State there are children also going hungry, and why in Galicia and the Spanish State there are trade unionists pending pardon and trade unionists threatened to enter prison.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Senra, in Venezuela there is a prison called "La Tumba" where, yesterday, a student was locked up, without process, to live five floors underground, without sunlight and without even being aware of the time in which he lives, indefinitely. And you get me out with that one? The truth is, I'm ashamed and I'd rather not answer him.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I too would like to welcome Mrs Capriles and the representatives of the MUD, and I would like to express, on behalf of this Parliament, three messages which the people of Venezuela need to hear. The first is that, indeed, the people of Venezuela, on December 6, just two months ago, voted massively. He voted in peace and gave a resounding triumph to the opposition, to the MUD. And this Parliament welcomes this democratic holiday and claims that only democracy and only democracy will be possible solutions to the problems of the Venezuelan people; first message. Second; the Government of Venezuela cannot reduce the powers of the new National Assembly. This is a legitimately constituted assembly and parallel assemblies cannot be created and the powers of the legislative branch cannot be reduced by conscaying artificely and illegally powers in the executive branch. That, at the moment, would mean a violation, a clear violation of the democratic mandate of 6 December. And thirdly, which I would like to express on behalf of many of this Parliament, because we will hear here today many speak very badly of chavism — I could do so - and others, defend chavism — I could not do so - but both are legitimate expressions. I want to claim here today something that the Dutch minister has just said very correctly. The popular mandate in Venezuela is a mandate for dialogue. There's a reconciling mandate. There's a town that demands solutions. There are two legitimate powers, the power of the executive and the power of the legislature. And they have to talk. And they have to understand each other, because the people want solutions, because citizens want there to be arrangements in the very serious problems that Venezuela suffers from insecurity, lack of supply, deteriorated macroeconomics. That means dialogue, and I ask everyone to dialogue and to fix the problems for Venezuela's future, which the people of Venezuela deserve.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr Minister, first of all I would like to greet Mitzy Capriles who is here with us today, whom I thank for his presence. On December 6, Venezuela took up its place within the democratic nations. I was fortunate to witness this historic day in Caracas. I regret, however, that this Parliament has not approved the move of an official delegation, contrary to what the Minister has said, the European Union has not been right in this matter.  Venezuelans relied on opposition forces to President Maduro's regime and that trust was translated into a significant absolute majority of the opposition. This is indisputable. For two decades Venezuelans have felt the oppression of absolute power with attacks on freedom of organization and expression and all kinds of repressions, with arbitrary killings and arrests, which still overflow the jails with political prisoners. Anyway, a situation worthy of a real horror movie but the B series.  The new Assembly, despite threats to block the politicized Supreme Court of Justice, was faced with a humanitarian crisis resulting from the country's dramatic economic and social situation, with the declaration of national emergency and the food and health sector.  Mr President, at this crucial moment in its history, Venezuela needs the firm support of the European Union so that the election results and the principle of separation of powers are respected. If we falter at this very decisive moment for the adoption of the law of amnesty and national reconciliation and for the change in the political model that has contributed to this crisis, which we will call into question, Mr President and ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly the right rule and democracy itself.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are witnessing long years of campaigns seeking the destabilization of Venezuela, something that unfortunately is shared and encouraged by many in this House.  2002 coup d'coup: oil sabotage, permanent climate of media harassment and political violence. April 2013: "La Arrechera", 11 dead. February 2014: "Operation Exit", where Leopoldo López was involved, 43 dead. February 2005: "Operation Jericho", where Antonio Ledezma was involved.  Despite holding twenty electoral processes over seventeen years, a permanent campaign of deligitimation against the electoral system was installed, which was internationally audited: it was good for opposition governorates, for the internal primaries of the MUD and even for the victory of the opposition in the legislative ones of 6 December, of which I witnessed.  Although former presidents, media and opposition spoke of fraud or suddenly, his speech changed completely when they realized the victory. It is not a total victory, Mr Minister, there is no outgoing government. That is, the National Assembly is not a supraconstitutional power. There are counterweights, there is an Executive, that is, a President elected with the same legitimacy as Members.  Let's not contribute to the fire. Let's change the role. Let us not support sectors seeking destabilizing and violent change, and let us help to reduce tension in the context of a democracy with institutional counterweights.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – You said that the last elections were audited internationally. This Parliament was unable to go, because it was not invited by the Venezuelan Government and because the Venezuelan Government did not guarantee him security. Despite everything, I was there and saw what happened. There was no international audit. I was. My question: were you there?

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Obviously, I was: an electoral escort according to Venezuela's law and sovereignty, which you do not impose.  In addition, there were former presidents, among others, our former president. I visited twelve schools, sixty tables, more than 38,000 people in opposition schools. And there was normality. Not what you said, who only use lying to change the realities that don't interest you.  (He refused to have Mr Faria ask him a question under the 'blue card' procedure)

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would ask you to put some order in this House, which I think is not respecting the minimum elegance that I think we should show. Again we care about Venezuela and I think it is very important. I would like, however, that time, a little of the time we spend on Venezuela, would also be devoted to Mexico, which is not so far geographically and which is a country full of femicides, violence, where journalists are threatened and killed. It's a suggestion I make to the Minister. I think we should welcome the outcome of the elections, the election process, that democratic holiday that has already been discussed here. Again, because previous, and previous, and previous elections also had international guarantees and were also conducted in a transparent, clean and democratic manner, as always. What is the role that the European Union should play in Venezuela? Of course, defending human rights there, because that is in our founding letters, is in our Treaties. I just hope that we will do a little better than we do in countries like Israel or Morocco, countries where impunity shines and where no one does anything and with which we also have shamefully cordial relations. What do we really want to do in Venezuela? Do we want to support the people? Do we want peace? What we have to do, logically, is modify, help change Venezuela's productive economic model. Venezuela has lived forever—and I'm afraid some colleagues here speak of a golden age, pre-Chavism, which never existed, never existed in Venezuela—it lives doomed to oil extraction, to the monoculture of oil. And that creates instability, corruption and violence. If what we want here is to have good relations with the oil oligarchy again for our companies to benefit, we will not be helping the people of Venezuela.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from this privileged position we can see that politics is being used by private interests and multinationals to destabilise governments and the will of the people. On the situation in Venezuela, I believe that there are objective problems: corruption at excessive levels, even within Maduro's party, the scarcity of food and medicines, inflation at 500%, the presence of the diabolical phenomenon of paramilitarism. Faced with this situation, the wealthy and powerful countries such as the European Union and the United States of America, what are they doing to improve the situation of the Venezuelan people? I think the answer is clear, both in intention and in practice. This is a real economic war against the Bolivarian Republic perpetrated by the Troika. Attacks on Venezuelans are visible to everyone. Think of the sanctions by the United States, which sees Venezuela as a threat to their country. I recall the alarmism and hysteria of some Members of this House, who expected President Maduro not to acknowledge the possible and then defeat in the December elections. Instead, I congratulate President Maduro on accepting the outcome of the votes and encourage Venezuelans not to give up and to pursue the independence and values of Alba.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank God it is not just Ukraine in our debates. Latin American countries are committed to forging privileged relations with European countries, particularly in the construction of a multipolar world. They must come out of mortal Marxism, and most of them come out of it, and also reject the nearly two-century-old Monroe Doctrine, which makes them a backyard of the United States. Today, neo-Bolivarism and the globalist left in South America are being swept away or are being swept away, as in Brazil and Chile, in favour of anti-Brandist governments. In Venezuela, the ballot boxes have spoken. Maduro's Marxist government was severely beaten in the last elections and today it must be punished. Our Parliament is here to remind us of the basic rules of democracy, but the GUE/NGL, which today, here and elsewhere, is still an admirer of the worst Marxist dictatorships.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you are right to work together in such a country. But that starts with recognizing elections. The elections are not recognised. The rights of the two-thirds majority parliament are being eroded and undermined. Rights are being taken away from them, parallel parliaments are being set up and opposition leaders elected by a two-thirds majority are still in prison.  That is the starting point that I do not think we can take away, and we must see that Venezuela, the country with the greatest oil wealth on earth, is one of the poorest countries on earth. A country with poverty and crime, with less and less democracy and the rule of law – and this is now being continued. It is a sign that chavistic or any communist socialism is increasingly leading to less democracy, fewer human rights and more poverty among people. That is the historical experience that we need to see, and I believe that this must be seen clearly, and I am also surprised that here representatives in this House, such as Mr Couso, are still defending this system or at least declaring that it is not all that bad. Simply acknowledging elections and the will of the people, that is democracy, and not undermining the will of the people with any tricks. I wonder how Podemos and its friends will become members of a government in the European Union in the future. I cannot understand this connection, that those who believe that the Venezuelan system is right are now in power in the European Union.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is true that free elections have taken place in Venezuela, but it is not entirely true that President Maduro has fully recognised the election results. It has always reacted very badly to these election results, right away with the idea of creating a kind of parallel parliament, calling into question the fundamental principles of a representative democracy, continuing to call into question the principle of separation of powers, which is an elementary principle of any liberal democracy. Permanent attempts to asphyxiate Venezuelan civil society by keeping political figures in prison for the simple reason of disagreeing with the power currently in force in Venezuela. We are therefore not facing a democratic regime that should not be the subject of criticism and our role as European parliamentarians must first be that of giving our solidarity to our colleagues who have just been elected parliamentarians in Venezuela and to tell them that we are with them at this difficult time on a path that must be a way for Venezuela to win back political democracy.  It is true that we can speak of other dimensions, economic and social, but without this political dimension there is no democracy that is entitled to that name and that is also what is happening today, is at stake in Venezuela.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, although December brought new hope for democracy in Venezuela, what we have seen in recent weeks in Caracas is quite the opposite. The Government continues to reject the voice of the people by denying the powers of the newly elected Assembly. That's not how a democracy works. What does Venezuela need right now? First, we must solve the urgent problems affecting the Venezuelan economy and society, agreements must be reached rather than confrontations. The first step in restoring a real climate of national conciliation would be to free all political prisoners.  Secondly, Europe needs to be more present. I call on the High Representative to expand the mandate and increase the funding of the European Union's current instruments to respond to the serious crisis in Venezuela now.  Before I finish, I want to convey my deep respect and admiration to the brave women of Venezuela, some of whom are with us today too – Mitzy Capriles, their daughter Antoinette and María Alejandra Aristeguieta-Alvarez , as well as Lilian Tintori and Tamara Suju, who could not be with us today. They are part of a unique force for freedom in the country. The change that is now taking place in Venezuela is largely due to these courageous women.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this country we are talking about — which is not a small or un important country, but I remember that at the moment the United Nations Security Council is presiding over — we have already spoken in this Parliament. And we have spoken bluntly, claiming freedom. We have nominated political prisoners and the Bureau of Democratic Unity to receive the Sakharov Prize, and we have gone those of our capacity alone— because we do not receive company — to witness democratic elections to the Venezuelan Assembly. And what happened? Well, the opposition swept the Maduro regime. And how did Maduro's regime respond?  By uninsiring and forgetting the importance of the legislature, trying to manipulate and remove Members so that they do not obtain a qualified quorum and can make it a revocation. And what has the opposition done, which today is worthily represented here by its relatives? Continue to defend the freedom of your prisoners. But the prisoners are still in jail, Madam President. He's still in Leopoldo Torres Jail. Antonio Ledezma is still in jail. And an amnesty law is imposed. Political prisoners have to be on the street and then there will be dialogue, then cohabitation can be requested and then the executive and the legislature will be able to dialogue, if Maduro knows how to live up to his country.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that sometimes there is good news, such as that democracy can more than the efforts some make to weaken it. What happens many times is that those who try to weaken democracy end up defeated by democracy.  I believe that Venezuelans and Venezuelans have before them a much more hopeful future now that the people, through the polls, have spoken; now that they have a democratically elected Parliament and that has the strength to make the changes that the country needs – because it needs change and needs to get out of the crisis situation, which is already almost humanitarian, which it is forced to make.  I don't want to be a Spaniard who is positioned on one side or the other in Venezuela: it's not right with me. I believe that we must appeal both to the democratic opposition, now a majority in the House, and to President Maduro to enter into a dialogue, to initiate a transition, a reconciliation in that country, which is what people are really asking for right through the ballot box: dialogue, reconciliation, transition and democracy.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Minister, once again we are talking about Venezuela here in this House, and once again we could repeat the same thing as on other occasions. Political prisoners such as Leopoldo López or the Metropolitan Mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, are still in prison. Venezuelans continue to suffer the world's highest desupply and inflation rate. The country remains in the first position as the most corrupt country on the continent and, now also, as the most violent. And the risk of a humanitarian crisis or social outburst remains. And these are facts, not opinions. But, dear Mitzy, dear Alejandra, something has changed since we last debated in this House, because the whole world has already found that most Venezuelans want peaceful and constructive change for their country and leave the Maduro regime behind. The Venezuelan government, however, does not seem to wholen the will of the Venezuelan people and has continued to try to boycott the outcome of the elections with all sorts of trickery. In the coming months the new National Assembly will propose urgent democratic reforms, such as the adoption of the Amnesty and National Reconciliation Act, which will test Venezuela's institutionality and democratic character, but also our commitment. The European Union must lead international support so that the new National Assembly can carry out these democratic reforms and, immediately, the European Parliament must send the committed official delegation to see this unequivocal support. I do, as a Spaniard, but also as a European, wish and trust that we will be able to live up to it, with forcefulness and concrete actions.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, after years of Chavista rule, Venezuela is on the brink of a humanitarian crisis. Widespread desupply includes shortages of necessities, which first affects the humblest sectors of society. We are facing an alarming situation to which we must respond with solidarity, but also understanding and making it clear that this situation is the direct result of the policy carried out by an authoritarian regime that began by imprisoning opposition leaders and now has all the Venezuelan people imprisoned and plunged into misery.  Venezuelans took to the polls on December 6, in the elections of the new National Assembly, and with their vote demanded a change of course. However, Mr Maduro turns a deaf ear to the popular will: he puts obstacles on the National Assembly, hardens his control of the judiciary, and seeks to suspend constitutional guarantees and further concentrate power on the Executive.  That is why, in solidarity with the people of Venezuela, from this Parliament we seek the release of political prisoners, respect for human rights, respect for the rule of law that the Chavista regime has devastated.  In his ideological blindness, Maduro does not want to see new winds blowing in South America, from Macri's victory in the homeland of St. Martin, to the victory of the democratic opposition, in December, in Bolivar's homeland.  The populist model is exhausted, but the Chavista regime can still do a lot of damage. For this reason, we must be vigilant and stand in solidarity with the people of Venezuela in their struggle for freedom.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Minister, strengthening the European Union's political and economic relations with Latin America must be a priority of our foreign policy. This priority is based on the complementarity of values between these two major regions. And that is why it is so important to speed up the Trade Treaty with Mercosur, in the expectation that one day Venezuela can join it. But in this context the European Union and this Parliament cannot fail to express their deep democratic indignation at the systematic trampling of the rule of law and international law that have taken place in that country. The government of Venezuela must respect its Constitution and the rights of its citizens and, in particular, the citizens and bodies that have been elected.
