It is important to strengthen the European Union's cooperation with Venezuela, but there is a red line, ensuring legal certainty and the functioning of the rule of law in Venezuela. Minister, the High Representative and the Presidency have our full support to continue this path of work and the defence of human rights in Venezuela.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the victory of the Bureau of Democratic Unity in the Legislative Elections in December was a historic fact after seventeen years of chavism, but the situation remains difficult. Indeed, the Maduro Executive's response to the triumph of the opposition has not been dialogue, but confrontation. Let us see: the appointment in a hurry of thirteen judges of the Supreme Court, reduction of the control mechanisms available to the House, the creation of a parallel communal Parliament, so to speak, the Assembly, the suspension of three MEMBERS of the MUD. Moreover, in a very economically and socially serious situation, the President has unilaterally launched an economic emergency plan without the triumphant opposition at all. And political prisoners whose release demands large sections of the country and also the international community, including this Parliament, continue to be detained. And from here I send a loving and supportive greeting to Mitzy Capriles, the wife of the Metropolitan Mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, and his daughter. Tomorrow, precisely, a bill for the release of arbitrarily detained political prisoners will be presented to the Venezuelan National Assembly. I hope that this liberation that we have been claiming so long will prosper and soon be a reality. And I'm done. Venezuela requires the freedom of political prisoners, dialogue, tolerance, agreements, consensuses. The country is no longer for unilateral decisions, abuses of the rule of law, fraud of the law. He wants a change after many years of increasing authoritarianism. The regional context, as Davor Stier has very well described, favors this change in Venezuela, to which Maduro, however, and his regime, unfortunately seem to continue to resist.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, for almost 17 years the economic and democratic development of a country which is rich in natural resources has been paralysed by harsh ideological and political control and government intervention. The result has been what it always is: the centralised exercise of so-called socialism by one-party rule ends in economic bankruptcy, social misery, massive human rights violations, corruption and muzzling of the free press. Only last year the economy shrank by 10% and inflation galloped up by 700%. These are devastating figures for the political leadership. But even more, less than two years ago, 43 citizens were killed by the government forces and more than 3 000 arrested, including Leopoldo López and many others, who are still imprisoned. There was a quest for change and justice only two months ago, but the problem is that we are worried that President Maduro is not prepared to share power. Yes, we need national dialogue to overcome the crisis, but first of all Venezuela needs genuine respect for human rights. That is the criterion to overcome the crisis.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I think that the European Union, the Council, must put maximum pressure on President Maduro to be willing to respect the results of the elections, because it is nice to talk about dialogue, about reconciliation, but there must be both sides to that, and that is not objectively on the part of the President at the moment, that is my first point. And the second point. I believe that Parliament will have to carry out fundamental reforms, because it is clear that this is not only about amnesty, it is about other things, but it is also about the overall reform of the rule of law in this country. The rule of law is not objective in Venezuela, it also shows what has been mentioned here, how the Supreme Court works, which has unlawfully taken away the mandate of three Members. This means that if a country is to go down the path of prosperity, it is not possible without law and an independent judiciary. And we should send all these signals, as representatives of the European Parliament and also representatives of the Council of Venezuela, and especially to President Maduro.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the political result of last December's parliamentary elections reflects public dissatisfaction with the previous government's management of the economic crisis triggered by the rapid fall in oil prices.  It is only natural that the new government will be cohabited with President Maduro causing friction. Venezuela's newly elected Parliament, dominated by the opposition wing, has promised to overturn The Maduro Government's social and economic policies. The expulsion of four Members for irregularities in the electoral process has been much discussed in Europe, but it is not the major issue in Venezuela today. After all, one of the four Members belongs to Mr Maduro's party.  On the contrary, there is a great deal of social reaction to the bill that the new House is expected to vote in favour of privatising social housing infrastructure, in a country where 50% of the population lives in makeshift housing. Concrete measures are needed to strengthen the European Union's economic relations with Venezuela, with a view to the mutual benefit of both parties and respecting the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of each Party.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the elections in Venezuela on December 6th brought new hope. A new atmosphere that will hopefully bring more happiness to this afflicted people and more opportunities for the fantastic resources venezuela has to benefit for the benefit of everyone in Venezuela, not just multinationals and individuals.  What I want to emphasize today is that Venezuela is about to choose, or dialogue or chaos, or reconciliation or violence. Whoever chooses the wrong side will be responsible for what happens in Venezuela. I call on the winners of the elections to be patient, to choose dialogue and reconciliation, and I also call on President Maduro if he really wishes good to his people and his country.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we all know the current situation: Venezuela is governed by a drug addict, by Nicolás Maduro, who has led his people to economic ruin and an unprecedented humanitarian crisis with their communist and Chavista dictatorial policies.  But today, moreover, this Parliament must be loud, once again, to denounce these facts and call for the release of political prisoners unjustly imprisoned in Venezuela on maduro's orders and by the judicial tentacles of Nicolás Maduro. The human rights of these people are being violated and Maduro is shown to be a warlord who tries to eliminate anyone who does not dance to the chavismo-marking son.  Ladies and gentlemen, the Venezuela of the good people, the Democrat, the one who asks for freedom and justice is suffering. All of that Venezuela is in jail with chains and the European Parliament has a key to taking those chains away from Venezuela. Let's use it and free the people of Venezuela.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I was proud to witness how this strong victory of the Opposition Bureau was received and celebrated. We were in a small room, like this of people, and I guarantee that the first words of the opposition were not of triumphalism, not against Maduro; they were hand-held, thanks to the Venezuelans, of unity, thinking, confident that this gesture would be returned, on the part of the Government, in a position to open the prisons for Leopoldo López and Antonio Ledezma, who are inside to think, to think differently and to want freedom for their people. I want from here to thank Mitzy Capriles and her daughter, who are here. Lilian, Maria Corina, so many political prisoners who have been in "The Tomb". That I've seen it, that they've come to tell me. For nothing: he was a physiotherapist who was in a demonstration. I saw that with my eyes, because I was there. And therefore, I want to thank you and, above all, the Venezuelan people, who are the great architect of that great victory. This is not reversed, no long as many here don't want to recognize it.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by saying how important it is to listen to this debate and to again underline the importance of this discussion, two months after the legislative elections on 6 December. The importance of this debate is, first of all, that the elections of 6 December produced an unequivocal result: a strong majority of the Venezuelan people have given a clear mandate to the parliament to take decisions in order to address the country’s critical challenges. We have heard a lot of debates on how we can assist from the European side to accommodate a process in which really we can assist the Venezuelan people to come out of the crisis that they are in right now. First of all it is important to underline the importance of the Constitution. The Constitution offers a lawful, peaceful framework in which the Venezuelan body politic can operate as a democracy. Those on either side that feel tempted by non—constitutional methods – and the temptation is there – or by parallel structures to organise the consultations, must know that they are taking a very heavy responsibility at the moment, when the situation in the country is obviously very serious from an economic and security point of view. If the current absence of dialogue persists, there is really a risk that things will get out of hand. Therefore I find it important that we are putting forward these two issues: constitutionality and dialogue. There is no alternative. You cannot have one without the other, and it is important that the European Union underline that in its policy towards Venezuela. It is also important to mention human rights, and I appreciate the presence today of a Venezuelan delegation, which is active not only in showing support for, but also interest in, the fate of political prisoners. We are here in the European Union to defend human rights and it is important to put that forward also. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in supporting the Venezuelan people in addressing their difficult economic and security situation and in overcoming the political polarisation that stands in the way of solutions. What Europe can now do to help the Venezuelan people in tackling these challenges is to keep calling on all the political actors to understand what happened: look at the elections, look at the constitutionality, see that nobody can decide this on their own and work on a constructive dialogue. There is no alternative. In this regard I think Members’ own parliamentary contacts they have been developing are of great importance. I would like to thank the honourable Members who travelled to Venezuela last year in order to listen, to support dialogue and to carry this European message of support for peaceful and constitutional solutions. That is a very important role they can play. They are particularly effective when they are representatives of the full geographical and political diversity of this House and, in this sense, I would of course encourage – to the extent that I can do that – the Foreign Affairs Committee delegation to see if they can visit Venezuela. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this urgent issue on the international agenda and in calling for peaceful constitutional solutions to the crisis in Venezuela.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – Faced with the situation in Venezuela, the European Parliament must send three clear messages: first, to hold the outcome of the elections of 6 December 2015, which gave victory to the opposition; it was a democratic triumph that we must all recognize. Second, that the National Assembly is a legitimately constituted body as a result of these elections, and that the Government should not take stratagems to undermine its powers. And thirdly, that the Venezuelan people clearly demand dialogue, reconciliation and the search for solutions to the serious problems afflicting the country, through the consensus between the executive and the legislative branch. That is the path that Europe must favour and support.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Venezuela has for a long time been in an extremely difficult situation. It is not only the economic and social experiment, which brought this country to its knees, it is also the loss of respect for democracy, civil liberties and human rights that has been disabling the country from moving on. The victory of democratic opposition in last year’s elections brought a hope for change. We need to support the democratic developments in the country as we had been supporting the Democratic Unity Alliance for past years. I would like to use this occasion to plead for the liberation of one of the great figures of the Venezuelan opposition movement, and my friend, Leopoldo López. His imprisonment was clearly politically motivated and unjustified. Therefore, I would like to join many public persons and human rights organisations in a plea for the liberation of Leopoldo.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Worsened economic, political and social situation in Venezuela has created conditions for massive human rights violations. In this regard, opposition victory in recent parliamentary elections on 6 December 2015 was welcomed by many as the beginning of the transition period and democratisation. The EU should provide assistance and support to new Venezuelan government, which has not an easy task to tackle a wide range of human rights issues, such as impunity, accountability for extrajudicial killings, arbitrary arrest and detention, fair trials, the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly and association, and media freedom. We should call on Venezuelan authorities to work actively to promote and protect human rights in their own country and beyond, particularly in the shadow of Venezuela’s membership of the UNHCR.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council on the UN Convention on Transparency in Treaty-based Investor-State Arbitration by Bernd Lange and Salvatore Cicu, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade [2015/2930(RSP)].

name: Bernd Lange
text: Author. Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- Recently, a member of the Trade Committee said: "ISDS has a few friends left in the European Parliament." ISDS is controversial for many reasons because commercial considerations are applied in private arbitration courts and this can have significant consequences for public budgets, because democratic decisions are attacked and and and. There are many critical points of view. But the key momentum, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, is that there is a lack of transparency. The procedures are indeed behind closed doors and completely opaque. In this respect, it is hardly surprising that scepticism is growing. In the debate on TTIP, the European Parliament has also made clear proposals for reform on all these issues. Incidentally, this applies to new treaties, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, but this also applies, of course, to the old Treaties, where we have a large number of ISDS regulations, particularly from the European Union, from the Member States, which are completely non-transparent. There is, of course, a certain contradiction. On the one hand, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the Council stresses that its members stress transparency in all sorts of areas, particularly trade agreements. But on the issue of bilateral ISDS treaties, the Council is walling up. And I think that is particularly important for the EU and for the Member States, because the EU, the Member States, are virtually the world champions of ISDS treaties. Now there is the Mauritius Convention, which has been adopted by the United Nations General Assembly and creates more opportunities for transparency. The EU's signature would be the signal of transparency in the Energy Charter. The Energy Charter is, after all, the only treaty where ISDS is provided for by the European Union – incidentally, since 1994, well before the Treaty of Lisbon – and the signature of the Member States would then be a signal that the bilateral ISDS treaties would also become transparent. At the moment, there seems to be some dispute over the competence of the Council as to who is responsible for what. I cannot understand this, and it really baffled me, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, that such conflicts of competence are blocking the signatures of both the EU and individual Member States, thereby signalling to the outside world that the European Union is not, in fact, interested in transparency. This is contrary to our common objectives. And then again, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, on the Energy Charter: this is often not discussed in public, but the Energy Charter is the Treaty where most ISDS cases take place. There are currently 89, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, 89 cases. That, by the way, is what the secretariat of the Energy Charter says. They don't really know that either, because it's very secret. There is no obligation to notify these cases, which can only be drawn from public publications. So there are at least 89, maybe even a few more. I find this state of affairs totally unacceptable! Some Member States have signed: France, Germany, the United Kingdom, but the EU is not. Hence the three questions, Mr President-in-Office of the Council: firstly, does the Presidency of the Council not agree that we must convince the Member States that this blockade will finally end and that the EU can sign up? Secondly, does the Presidency not agree that this blockade has caused immense damage to the image of the European Union, because transparency is, of course, formulated everywhere, but the world champion of the ISDS Treaties does not make that transparency? The third question is this: will the Presidency motivate those Member States that have not yet signed up to do so quickly so that we can say at the end of the year: yes, we stand by transparency, we also want this in the case of existing ISDS treaties?

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Thank you very much, Mr Lange, for your three questions. I could be very short and answer, ‘yes’, ‘yes’ and ‘yes’, and then we would be finished, but I guess you need a little bit more language around that. But I would just say three times ‘yes’. Transparency is the key for the Dutch Presidency and it fits into our priorities of focusing on the essentials and creating simple and more reliable legislation, as you also mentioned. Let me recall that the Council, in its conclusions on the EU’s trade and investment policy adopted in November last year, recognised that a responsible EU trade policy must be accompanied by a high level of transparency and effective communication with citizens and better involvement of all stakeholders in the preparation, negotiation and implementation of initiatives in the area, while respecting the institutional balance and the applicable rules. But that is a long sentence to have the second ‘yes’. In the context of investor-state dispute settlement, enormous efforts championed by the European Union have been made globally towards improving the level of transparency under which disputes are conducted with the aim of providing maximum access to the public on documents and hearings, as well as allowing interested third parties to make submissions. Also the Commission announced its intention to contribute from the EU budget to increase transparency in ISDS by financing UNCITRAL’s publicly-accessible register on documents that supports the implementation of the ISDS UNCITRAL transparency rules. The EU is committed to systematically incorporating these transparency standards or comparable rules into all trade and investment agreements under negotiation, and in order to facilitate their application to existing agreements, a multilateral convention – as you mentioned – was negotiated under the auspices of the United Nations: the Mauritius Convention on Transparency in Treaty-based Investor-State Arbitration. In February 2014 the Council authorised the Commission to participate in the negotiations on this Convention on behalf of the Union. The Convention in question would apply in respect of the EU for one treaty only, namely the Energy Charter Treaty you mentioned. The decision of the Union to sign the Convention has, however, proved more difficult, as you also mentioned. Despite a number of discussions within the Council last year on the basis of the proposals by the Commission for decisions on the signature and conclusions of the Convention, not all Member States who remain competent for matters covered by the Mauritius Convention agree that this convention should be applied to the Energy Charter Treaty. Let me stress that the Presidency is committed to making progress on this very important file. It is among the priority issues on which we would like to advance discussions during the next six months. In this regard, bilateral contacts with the delegations concerned continue in order to iron out the remaining differences, because I think there is also the risk that you mentioned to our image in the outside world, and we encourage all Member States to assume a constructive position on the issue in order to allow the EU to sign a convention with respect to the Energy Charter Treaty. We have already gone a long way with the formulation and reform of the EU’s investment policy, which is an area of shared competence and responsibility. Rest assured that the Union and the Member States’ expertise in investment protection and dispute resolution guarantees their solid image vis-à-vis third countries. In this regard, in November last year the Council welcomed the Commission’s innovative and ambitious approach to modernising investment protection. The Council has further taken note of the Commission’s intention to consider this approach, where appropriate, in other EU trade agreements and to work towards the establishment of a multilateral investment court as a final goal. The Council also welcomed the renewed pledge to respect the governments’ right to regulate. Regarding the application of the transparency convention to Member States’ bilateral investment treaties, the Presidency remains unreservedly committed to the objective of increasing the transparency of the investor-state dispute settlement system. We as the Presidency cannot, as you know, easily interfere with Member States’ competences. We cannot force Member States to apply the UNCITRAL transparency rules to their own bilateral investment treaties concluded before 1 April 2014. Against this background, I am truly hopeful that we will be able to find a solution within the Council on this important dossier. On the Presidency side we are certainly working very hard to make this happen.

name: Salvatore Cicu
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the GROUP of the European People's Party believes that the inclusion of transparency rules in international agreements, as well as improving the same transparency in disputes, would have the effect of finally giving the agreements overall credibility. These two elements are extraordinarily important and central to us in the PPE. That is why I am addressing the Council here today – the answers that have been given in part – to overcome as soon as possible this stalemate that has arisen between the institutions, because it would be a question of ratifying the rules of the Union, the first convention that will finally reform and improve the law of international investment. Both the Council and my fellow Members present here, as well as the Commission, are well aware of the fundamental, central and priority for the future of the credibility of international trade agreements, where the Union invests, where the Union represents a project that is achieved through a fundamental element. This deadlock at Council level can therefore give rise to a worrying situation. We regard it as such because at the moment the only agreement that has been signed since the convention was adopted is the Energy Charter, which is currently excluded from the scope of the UNCITRAL transparency rules. Where, in ISDS cases, the Union is the defendant in investor dispute settlement proceedings in the European Union and the applicant comes from a third State, the rules on transparency may not be abdicated with serious injury.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Dutch Presidency, both for staying here and being involved this marathon session, and also for the encouraging reply and for the ‘yes, yes, yes’. Of course, what we now want is for you to ‘do, do, do’. That is the next stage. I am sure that the Council is very aware of the Socialist position on ISDS. We reject the old Bilateral Investment Treaties (BITs), and we rejected the Commission’s attempt to continue to use secret courts. In the long term, we are demanding a multilateral solution to investment disputes, but while we push for this, we strongly support bringing more transparency to existing ISDS provisions worldwide. We therefore welcome the Mauritius Convention at the UN level on new minimum standards, which we believe apply to existing Member States’ BITs, as well as to the Energy Charter. The blockage in the Council on progressing with this is unacceptable. I accept that it is not the Presidency’s fault, but it is unacceptable. It is important to continue to clarify that investment is a European Union competence. It is deeply regrettable that eight Member States have unilaterally signed the Convention without waiting for the authorisation of the Union. This has shown to the outside world a divided and disorganised EU when we should be a strong voice internationally, defending the Mauritius Convention principles. It is also troubling to hear that, within the Council, some Member States do not support these transparency rules. The new UNCITRAL rules are now the minimum standards for the EU, and the Council should endorse them unanimously. We are calling for the Council to authorise the Union to sign the Convention as soon as possible so that it can apply to the Energy Charter immediately. We also demand that all remaining Member States, when authorised, sign the new rules to apply them to all their bilateral agreements. The Union is now a world leader in reforming investment protection provision, but we can only do so effectively if the Member States put institutional squabbles aside, recognise that this is an exclusive competence of the Union, and allow the EU to move forward.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Minister for staying for the debate. This is a simple and straightforward issue. We talk a lot about transparency in this Parliament, and we genuinely believe in it. But sometimes it is difficult to accept what we hear from the Council, and that is certainly the case in this situation. It is difficult to accept that the Council has not yet managed to resolve this existing impasse. I would like to be able to understand why this situation is continuing. I was going to ask you, of course, whether you were taking an active role, but you have already told us: yes. Great news. So maybe I can ask you for a little bit more detail about exactly what you are doing, and maybe you could be just slightly more transparent about the negotiations within Council as to how you are going to resolve this issue. Obviously, it does affect the way that the world looks at the European Union. It is regrettable that eight Member States have had to unilaterally go forward, but I do not blame them: I think it gives the clear impression that they are getting a little impatient. So please, Council, wake up and get on with agreeing this very sensible notion.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Minister Koenders, more transparency in EU decision-making, access to information in trade treaties, from the street to the inbox and also at today's meeting in Amsterdam, people called on Commissioner Malmström to make documents public.  This Parliament has already successfully pushed for new transparency initiatives in trade and investment agreements. The signing of the Uncitral Treaty is part of that. This leads to greater transparency and access to information in ISDS cases, the controversial mechanism that allows interstate and investor arbitration. It is therefore crazy that the Council, in which Member States together included 1 300 of these controversial clauses in trade treaties, is not moving forward with transparency initiatives. The Netherlands, which, as President of the Council, claims to focus on transparency, but has not yet signed up for more openness in the affairs themselves, more access to documents and a greater role for civil society organisations. In the Council, a number of Member States such as Germany, Italy, Sweden and Belgium have already signed up, but the United States and Canada are also more transparent than we are.  It is really strange and disappointing that the problem lies with the Council and we also hear tough words from Minister Ploumen, who says he is going to oppose the European Commission for greater transparency. You are right to say that you cannot force other Member States to do so. That is true, but you can probably lead by example and show during the presidency how we are going to solve this by signing ourselves, by taking other Member States with you. Perhaps today you can explain which Member States are obstructing and what concrete plans you have to bring more transparency and get the whole EU and all Member States to sign the Uncitral Treaty.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for The Union's accession to the Convention would undoubtedly help to finally raise the public eye for the shady ISDS procedures initiated by the Energy Charter Treaty against governments of EU Member States. That is why we support the questions raised today, and I see great agreement here in plenary as well.  The real problem, however, is the ISDS procedure in the Energy Charter Treaty itself. Since 2014, it has overtaken NAFTA with the sad record of being the world's most widely chosen basis when profit-seeking companies sue a government over a law passed in the best public interest. The process documents remain hidden from the public, often even the sums agreed in a conciliation.  Italy has now decided to leave the Energy Charter Treaty in order to avoid being constantly threatened with ISDS procedures. I call this an exemplary decision that the European Union and its Member States should follow, not least the Federal Republic of Germany with its experience of the Vattenfall complaints. The Council should finally act. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Scholz, you have just mentioned that 'profit-seeking companies are suing on the basis of the Energy Charter'. My question to you is this: Since the Stadtwerke München and the Stadtwerke Köln, as municipal companies, also use this instrument – do you consider municipal companies to be profit-seeking companies?

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not think so. The problem is that they are also subject to the logic of ISDS procedures. And precisely because Vattenfall is suing the Federal Republic and these ISDS procedures take place on a daily basis, so to speak, as a principle, these practices have obviously been adopted by the municipal utilities.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, trade should be about economic benefit, not politics. Yet the EU uses trade to promote a political agenda, and that is exactly what it is trying with the Mauritius Convention. The EU is pressurising all Member States to sign, so that the EU itself can sign and thereby serve its own interest of making ISDS a pillar of EU trade policy. The EU is carrying forward the assumption that ISDS is a legitimate system; it is not. It subverts national laws, and it has been rejected by two committees in this House for the TTIP Conventions negotiations. It is opposed by sizable numbers of MEPs, and still the Commission wants to make it part of its trade negotiations and has already put it into the draft trade agreement with Canada. We hear the words trotted around by the EU – ‘transparency’ and ‘investment court’– but these are surface changes that do nothing to alter what is an illegitimate and unnecessary system. Trade Commissioner Malmström has stated that trade must support Europe’s wider international goals. So long as they remain in the EU, Member States have to barter their sovereignty for the interests of the EU, in trade policy as in anything else. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Can the Member tell me how many bilateral investment treaties exist worldwide and how many the United Kingdom has signed up for? And does he believe that they should all remain secret? Because this is not about future investment treaties, this is about the existing investment treaties that, as the Chair of the Committee on International Trade rightly pointed out, we know very little about, and this is already costing the taxpayer millions of pounds every year. (Applause)

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The answer is no. I doubt many people do. However, the fact remains that ISDS is being pushed in through the back door, and it is absolutely unacceptable. Anybody who believes themselves to be working in the interests of ordinary people should know that and should accept that.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The submitter of the parliamentary question wants the EU to sign the UN Convention, which allows investors to go to arbitration for disputes between the investor and the state. These judgments shall be binding and final for the parties. At present, the EU cannot sign the Convention because it is blocked by a sufficient number of Member States. This sovereign decision is not accepted by the submitors and calls on the Council Presidency to put pressure on the Member States. This is a very dubious procedure. Moreover, for those who, as we have heard, consider the ISDS procedure to be illegitim and consider it to be a serious violation of the sovereignty of the Member States, why would they accept it in itself if this rejected process otherwise becomes transparent?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Protection against expropriation without compensation is a fundamental right under the UN Charter of Human Rights and, at the same time, we want to ensure that no one in another country is discriminated against according to their nationality. That is what the many investment protection agreements that are in force, and if Mr Finch had not left the Chamber very un-British, I could now tell him that his home country alone has 94 such treaties in force.  However, the Treaty of Lisbon transferred competence to the European level in 2009, and we want to ensure investment protection, but to reform the tried and tested system. Secondly, we want more transparency, and that includes this UN Convention. That is why I would like to know from the Council: which countries are blocking this? Which ministers are responsible? Which parties do they belong to? And are n:0 d'e.g. same-level ministers saying that we need more transparency – which they are blocking at European level? What does the Presidency do in concrete terms? When will the Member States finally implement the Treaty of Lisbon in trade policy and let the European Union do what is European competence?  And are you not ashamed of having to defend such inaction on the part of the Council here before the European Parliament? You have just said yes, yes, yes three times. My answer is: three times no, that is not the way to do it. Please finally do what you need to do and make sure that the Council authorises the European Union to sign this Treaty.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the Un Convention on the Transparency of Arbitration between Investors and States exists for two reasons: because there was a serious problem of a lack of transparency in arbitration systems and because the European Union has taken the lead in the fight for a convention capable of solving the problem. It is incomprehensible that, now that this convention exists and eight Member States have already ratified it, endless divisions prevent the European Union from ratifying a convention which it itself has demanded. This problem needs to be solved. This convention is necessary and the delay in its entry into force has consequences.  I would therefore like to encourage the Dutch Presidency to follow up on its commitments and to take concrete initiatives, not only to convince the Member States to sign this convention, but also to ensure that these new rules apply to the Energy Charter Treaty, whose dispute settlement system needs more transparency.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is clear that there are democratic deficits in ISDS mechanisms. Lack of transparency is one of the most bleeding, but it's not the only one. The fact that many European countries do not accept even this minimum must make us understand that something has been done very wrong. And it's time to change it. We will start with transparency, but we will go further, because each piece of the ISDS is designed to be susceptible to abuse by investors: the lax interpretation of non-discrimination clauses or that the lawyers themselves are now a judge and then a party. But increasingly we are vigilant and raise our voices. I would like to use this rostrum now to read to you the words of the United Nations Special Rapporteur, Alfred de Zayas, who says: "Over the past 25 years, bilateral treaties with ISDS have eroded the basic principles of the United Nations, state sovereignty, democracy and the rule of law. The impartial observer can only produce a moral vertigo." The problem is not transparency, gentlemen, is the very existence of isDS, which directly attack the foundations of democracy.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, so far 127 known ISDS cases have been initiated by powerful multinationals against EU states and have led to EUR 3.5 billion in compensation already paid. Applications for those still in progress amount to more than EUR 30 billion, but it is not known what has already been granted as a result of friendly transactions, such as the EUR 2 billion paid by Poland or the environmental legislation changed by Germany. But even more so, these figures do not take into account many other causes that remain secret. In order to avoid these situations, there is a United Nations Convention which obliges information on ongoing ISDS cases to be made public, but the Eu ropean Union and many other states are not party to it. This causes serious problems, particularly with regard to the Energy Charter, a treaty which provides for ISDS and which is giving rise to a very large number of causes. We in the 5-Star Movement are opposed to ISDS, but we want the convention ratified immediately because we are calling for something fundamental for the citizens, namely transparency.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Minister, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, but last but not least, the Member States and international institutions of profile must have as their main concern the strengthening of an economic environment capable of guaranteeing the security of investment and international trade. The creation of a harmonised legal framework for the fair and effective settlement of international investment disputes is likely to increase investor confidence.  In this context, we appreciate the efforts of the UN Commission on International Trade Law, which has focused its work on introducing the concept of transparency in international investment arbitration, culminating in the adoption of the UN Convention for the Application of Transparency Rules in State-Investor Arbitration. Therefore, the signing of this convention would also lead to increased investment security, with positive implications for economic growth at Member State level and, of course, a substantial increase in jobs. I also believe that Member States should be authorised for the individual signature of the Convention, but taking into account the bilateral investment treaties concluded by them.  Today, unfortunately, the negotiations on the TTIP, which the European Union so badly needs, are experiencing a not at all favourable development, precisely because of the issues relating to dispute resolution through arbitration. It is therefore important that a set of procedural rules are established at international level to ensure transparency and accessibility for the public, from the start of arbitrary procedures to their completion.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – I have spoken out against private investment tribunals several times, but the reality is that ISDS exists and is part of thousands of bilateral investment treaties. It is fair to say that companies from my own country are major users of the ISDS route and are asking for compensation. That is precisely why I support the Uncitral Treaty for greater transparency, precisely because we are working on a new fully fledged alternative to replace ISDS.  The UN rules pull ISDS cases out of the backrooms by disclosing what has been decided and on what grounds and for what amount a settlement has been reached. Of course, it would be nice if the Netherlands signed itself and got movement in the presidency on this issue, because it is now about the Energy Charter. But the problem is, of course, broader and I would think: are the Member States already not cooperating, how do we ever get public, transparent investment protection under, for example, TTIP and CETA?

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is good that the Council has expressed itself so clearly on the subject of transparency, because this is the fundamental pillar of our understanding of the conduct of the Community's trade policy and in order to have a fruitful relationship with our partners and, above all, with European public opinion. It is all the more regrettable, therefore, that procedural reasons have been put in place to block the ratification at Community level of the Mauritius Convention on the Transparency of Dispute Settlement Mechanisms and, at the same time, that some Member States have not yet ratified the Convention. While we are aware of the Council's limitations in this matter, as has been pointed out, we believe, unlike some of my fellow Members, that it is absolutely necessary for all the institutional players to intervene in order to exert pressure to unblock this situation. All the more so, at a key time for the reform of the dispute settlement mechanisms, the Council and the Member States are called upon to demonstrate maturity, which also involves the ratification of the UNCITRAL Convention.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we are discussing the arbitral settlement of disputes between investors and states, the well-known ISDS, as well as the transparency issues that arise in its operation. Initially, what the ISDS system has achieved so far is to allow multinational undertakings to take action against specific States for damages suffered by those undertakings following a public policy decision. In other words, the existing system of judicial protection is abolished and companies have the possibility through ISDS to be handsomely compensated by the States.  At the same time, in order to be transparent about ISDS, the European Union must incorporate the transparency standards of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law into all trade and investment agreements, including talks with the United States on TTP. Among the actions proposed by the United Nations Commission to achieve transparency is the publication of the European Union's negotiating texts, as well as the relevant hearings being open to the public.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, I would like to make clear at the outset my very positive position in order to move towards the signing of this Convention and to introduce more transparency. I expect the Dutch Presidency to actually try to persuade the Member States to sign this agreement, and thus for the European Union to be a signatory to the Convention. Because, let's put our hand on the heart, objectively the isds mechanism hides many problems.  With this method, however, we will try to bring more transparency and more clarity to contracts. And my country recently signed a pre-agreement on an energy project. And we already know that we can suffer serious harm because of it. So I am confident that we have to do everything to bring more clarity to these agreements, because it is good for our budgets, and as soon as it is good for our budgets, it is certainly good for citizens as well.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I have been listening with great interest to your views on this very important topic, and I think it has been very valuable input to the process of finding an adequate solution that would allow the European Union to sign the UNCITRAL Convention on transparency and treaty-based investor state arbitration. I said in the beginning, immediately upon starting, that the answer is ‘yes, yes, yes’. I understand that the conclusion from you is – and I support that – ‘do, do, do’. So I can only prove that once it happens, and that is for you to judge. When I listen to what most Members have said, there seems to be no difference of opinion. As I have said, transparency is key for our Presidency. It fits into our priorities on focusing on the essentials and creating simple and more reliable legislation. I mentioned the Council conclusions last year. Let me stress that the Presidency is committed to making progress on this very important file. It is among the priority issues on which we would like to advance discussions during the next six months. We are all ready. The question was there in the bilateral contact with the delegations concerned, and they will continue to iron out the remaining differences. There was a question: why have we not signed the Mauritius Convention yet? First of all, we are 100% in favour of the transparency rules in the Mauritius Convention. There is a difference of opinion – it was also mentioned by you, I think, from the Socialist Group – on whether a Member State needs prior authorisation from the Commission to sign. We have decided to wait with our signature until the moment that this issue is resolved. But I must admit that we are getting pretty restless. My Minister for Trade is also getting very impatient, because we want this transparency. We therefore find the current deadlock in the Council regrettable. That was my second ‘yes’ to Mr Lange. It reflects badly on the image of the European Union on all these points. We also hope that the conclusion of the Court of Justice on the issue of the ‘mixed nature’ is quickly resolved. We are looking forward to receiving the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union in relation to the division of competence between the Union and the Member States under the EU-Singapore FDA. We are hopeful that this will come quickly. Against this background, I am hopeful that we will be able to find a solution within the Council on this important dossier. On the Presidency side, we are certainly working very hard to make this happen.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) is a mechanism used in international investment agreements to ensure that states' mutual investment obligations are respected. There are currently more than 3000 such agreements, 1400 of which are agreements concluded by EU Member States. The basic principles of commercial arbitration are very helpful for investor-state dispute resolution. As these disputes often concern public policy issues or public finances, greater transparency is needed in their resolution by ensuring public access to documents.  Efforts to improve transparency have been ongoing since 2010. In addition, it has helped to induce the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) to establish global transparency rules and to apply these improved rules to the 3000 investment agreements currently in force. However, Member States have not reached an agreement with the Commission and have not signed a United Nations Convention to implement these global principles, which consequently has a negative impact on the handling of many international disputes in which the Union is a defendant and the reason is a non-EU country.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent In general, I support the introduction of transparency in investment arbitration and the appropriateness of making certain information on arbitration proceedings public, but within reasonable and precise limits. In arbitration proceedings, it is essential that it is conducted with due safeguarding of the interests of the State concerned. It is therefore of great doubt that the proposed transparency rules provide for a significant increase in the scope of mandatory disclosures, while not being able to claim the confidentiality of relevant information relevant to both States and investors.  I would like to remind you that the confidentiality of arbitration proceedings is regarded in doctrine as one of the most important and valuable features of such conduct. At the same time, subjecting the dispute to public judgement may result in pressure on its course and its politicisation, which makes it difficult to consider amicably and to conclude smoothly. I would point out that the EU's accession to the Convention entails the need for Member States to be bound by this agreement in the field of the Energy Charter Treaty. Disputes in the energy sector will require the parties to address sensitive information that could be contrary to the interest of the State. Furthermore, the requirement to disclose, translate and publish all documents significantly increases the costs of proceedings. In my opinion, the issue of the EU's binding on the Convention must be subject to a sound impact analysis and be taken up without any pressure, in particular in a situation of such a significant extension of the scope of the information to be disclosed.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. – Transparency is always essential in matters of public interest. And arbitration proceedings initiated in connection with investor-state dispute settlement are clearly matters of public interest and human rights. Such arbitration procedures may have a direct impact on the State budget and on the ability of the State to provide essential primary benefits for citizens. When, in the context of an investment agreement, the contracting parties agree on the use of this dispute settlement procedure, whether or not we agree with the raison d' law of that institution, it is essential that there is nothing to prevent the application of the rules ensuring transparency. Following this principle promotes the accountability of the State, since not only the transaction between the investor and the State, but also its consequences, are public affairs.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on ending sexual harassment and violence against women in public spaces (2016/2539(RSP)).

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is very important to have this subject on the agenda – ending violence against women. As you know, this issue is a priority for the Commission. We cannot, of course, accept or tolerate any kind of violence. Also, I need to point out from the very beginning, very clearly, that matters of public security and order are not within the competences of the EU but of the Member States. Gender-based violence violates the fundamental rights of the victim, and this is an expression of inequality between women and men. Violence against women, including sexual harassment and sexual violence, is unacceptable wherever it happens, whatever the circumstances, and regardless of the background of the perpetrators. Everyone in Europe must respect the law and abide by the common values upon which the EU is founded. Sexual assault and sexual violence are not new or imported crimes. In fact a survey by the Fundamental Rights Agency has shown that half of the women in the EU have experienced sexual harassment. More than one in ten women in the European Union say that they have been victims of sexual violence and one in 20 has been raped. We must ensure that our streets, squares and stations are safe for women and girls. We must create an environment where the victims are not afraid to report sexual harassment and violence, like they would if they had become victims of robbery. And we must make sure that perpetrators are prosecuted and convicted. The events in Germany on the last night of 2015 have put a focus on the special challenge of sexual assault in public spaces. We welcome the measures proposed in Germany to address this via stronger provisions in the National Criminal Code. We are considering exchanging detailed views on this through discussions among Ministers of Justice. The Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, called the Istanbul Convention, sets legally-binding standards at international level, as the parties must protect women and girls against gender-based violence, including sexual violence and sexual harassment. The Commission is at an advanced stage in its considerations on a possible accession to the Convention. A first concrete step was the publication of a roadmap by the Commission in October 2015. The EU has adopted legal measures that provide for protection and support for victims. One problem is that currently, not enough victims of sexual violence report the crime to the police authorities. Here the new Victims’ Rights Directive can make a difference, as it will strengthen support for victims in the Member States. Member States have to apply the Victims’ Rights Directive, which grants rights to victims of crime and their families concerning information, translation, support and protection, while police investigate the crime and during court proceedings. The specific needs of victims of gender-based violence and sexual violence are highlighted and addressed. They should have access to specialist support, and special measures have to be put in place to protect them from further harm during criminal proceedings. The Commission will closely monitor full and correct implementation of the directive. We all know legislation alone is not enough. Therefore, we finance projects that make a real impact on the life of women and girls in Europe through our rights, equality and citizenship programmes. Currently there are two open calls for proposals. We have over EUR 3 million available for national and transnational projects to enhance the rights of victims of violence, and we have another EUR 3 million available for transnational projects to combat sexual harassment and sexual violence against women. Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, and we remain strongly committed to achieving gender equality. Our efforts to combat sexual harassment and sexual violence are therefore part of a larger strategic engagement for gender equality. Let me reassure Members that in the coming years we will take a series of actions to improve equality in the Union and, through that, decrease violence against women. I look forward to our debate and would like to convey the message from my colleague, Věra Jourová, that she was not able to be here today due to other commitments arising from her portfolio.

name: President. –
text: I would like to inform the House that, in agreement with the political groups, the Council does not take part in this debate.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Through the events in Cologne, the topic of "sexual violence against women" has taken on a new dimension and, thank God, a new public discussion has also found. In Cologne, it was mainly perpetrators from North African backgrounds, especially from Morocco and Algeria, who attacked, sexually coerced and sexually harassed women. Although this was the case in Cologne, it should not be forgotten that in discotheques with knockout drops there are also perpetrators who are not North African identity and do not have a migrant background, but that sexual coercion and sexual violence against women occur again and again in many places and in many places. In my view, it is necessary in Germany to punish such crimes very consistently and therefore to revise this law nationally. I think it is very good, Commissioner Creu, that you have pointed this out, because it is still the case in the national legislation of many countries that women have to prove how the attacks took place and not first hold the perpetrators to account, and that the situation in such a case is for women who are already reluctant to reveal themselves and talk to someone else about it. , is particularly difficult and particularly complicated and particularly precarious. On the other hand, however, it was also clear that there are no no-go areas. We must enforce the law, regardless of the nationality of the perpetrators and the reason for which the acts are committed. We must also ensure that women are not expected to have to potentially take the perpetrators to an arm's length, that they are no longer allowed to go to a swimming pool in a miniskirt or swimsuit, because our standard of living includes freedom, democracy and the rule of law, and equality between men and women is part of it, unlike some totalitarian states or, unlike some states, , which also legally approves violence against women.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of President, one in three women in Europe is, has been or will be a victim of violence, and the vast majority of women are victims of violence, and the vast majority of them are the work of a spouse, friend or family member, not necessarily a migrant. In 2014, 13 million women were found to have been subjected to violence. In 2014, we were far from the migration crisis. No, violence against women in Europe did not wait for migrants to strike. For us, the group of the S and D, all women victims of violence must be defended and all perpetrators prosecuted, regardless of their origin, class and religion. What happened in Cologne - and it has been said - is regrettable. Those responsible must be identified and prosecuted, but it is not by brandishing a racist approach that the problem of violence against women will be solved, either in the public or private space. We must defend a substantive approach, methods to combat stereotypes, against preconceived ideas, such as: a dominant man, a dominated woman; an independent man, a dependent woman; a strong man, a weak woman; an active man, a passive woman.  You only have to look at the advertisements in Europe today, which are not carried out by Qatari agencies, to see how these stereotypes are embedded in our European culture. This debate shows once again that emotion kills reason. I therefore appeal to reason, for substantive work, long-term work, such as the strategy we voted on this morning in favour of equality between men and women.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The mass sexual assaults that occur in European cities are discrediting the EU's policy of multiculturalism. It is no coincidence that on New Year's Eve the German police did not respond and the German media remained silent. The Imam of Cologne stated that the victims themselves were to blame for the attacks because they provoked the costume and perfume. In our own home, in Europe, we are forced to adapt to other people's rules.  Vice-President Timmermans spoke about the situation in Cologne, that the reason was a lack of public order and that this had nothing to do with the immigration crisis. I would therefore like to ask how long the Union intends to place the good name of immigration policy above the dignity and security of women? Is the Commission aware of the scale of violence in and out of refugee centres? Will we finally stop talking about putting a dam of violence against women, or will we finally start working so that women can actually feel safe in Europe? I am surprised that someone may not notice this greater wave of violence against women and its connection to the immigration crisis.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very pleased and impressed by the sudden rise of feminists across Europe. At last, everyone seems to have understood that a woman's 'no' actually means no. However, I am now beginning to wonder why, according to a Eurostat survey, 25% of Europeans still believe that a girl in a miniskirt is causing problems or challenging problems. Unfortunately, this answer is very simple. The Cologne attacks were used in a populist way to incite hatred against refugees. Women's rights play only a very minor role in this. Let me give you an example: women have been complaining about sexual harassment at Munich's Oktoberfest for many years. What is the consequence of this? Virtually none, and no media attention. So I say, thank you for your feminist support. But the last thing we need now is a bunch of opportunistic feminists. There is no doubt that the events in Cologne are the result of a lack of integration and existing problems in the legal system. However, there is a need for a fundamental change in perception of the role of women, not only in the context of the migration debate, but also in our European society. Offenders must be punished, regardless of who they are or where they come from. We need a European framework and national implementation to combat violence against women by all means. It is also clear that there are cultural differences, and this cannot be denied at all – cultural differences within the European Union, but also, of course, outside the Member States. However, migrants are no more likely to commit a criminal act than nationals. Instead of falling victim to our own fear, we should respond with positive action and confidence to deal with the wave of refugees and to integrate people into our society in the best possible way. What Chancellor Angela Merkel is saying is true: if we compare the numbers of refugees with the European population, then, believe me, we will realise that the problems can be solved. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 of rule 8 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Mlinar, you said that schoolgirls are being asked not to wear miniskirts and that 25% of the German population would support this. In fact, it was German school leaders who asked schoolgirls to dress in this way so as not to provoke the refugees from a nearby refugee shelter.  They lead the Oktoberfest, although at the Oktoberfest the police chief himself has said several times that there have been no assaults here that are even close to the size of five million visitors. How do you classify the fact that schools in Hamburg were asked to take children to school to warn against sexual assaults by refugees?

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For me, this information is new, but if you say so, it may be true. Only what you said at the beginning is not correct. What I have quoted is a Eurostat record; that means that this has nothing to do with what you have just said or what you have said.  Ultimately, we know that violence against women happens. Regardless of who commits it, it must be punished, and I make no difference in that respect, but I will not join the quasi-opportunistic feminists who are now showing great. Rather, I am committed to ensuring that women's equality is enforced at all levels.

name: Malin Björk
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is an important debate, because everyone who grows up as girls in our communities knows what it feels like to have their living space restricted in public: in schools, in streets, in squares, on social media and on social media. Everywhere there is harassment and threats of violence generated by a destructive, sexist and patriarchal culture of violence.  As a public figure and a woman, I often receive sexist or threatening messages from men. In my case, it's from white offended men. There are two things that need to be said clearly in this debate. Sexism and violence against women are a structural problem in Europe and globally, and much, much, much more needs to be done to combat that violence. All women must be vindicated and perpetrators must be punished. Police and the judiciary, everyone needs to get better.  But what must also be said with clarity is that those of us who stand up against violence against women every day and who are fighting for a more feminist Europe, we will not tolerate this right and the extreme right using our bodies for racist rubbish. For our struggle for women's bodies, it is also for a life free from violence, a life where you get to choose your sexuality, it is for free abortion, it is for freedom and equality for women, and it is all that you work against normally.  Yesterday, when we were debating in this House, there was empty on the right bench, on the far right bench, because you do not care about women's bodies and women's lives. Because you care about polarizing and creating threats and hatred. We will not let you stand in our way. We will stand up for equality and for women's rights every day in this Parliament. Mr. Applause. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. " Dear Lady! Do you not think that you are using arguments in the discussion to exclude that the words and terms you say to Members on the right of the political scene are terms that are unseasy to a Member of the European Parliament? And I do not wish that on behalf of this right. Your language is the language of hate. If you had looked closely yesterday, you would have seen that I was also sitting in the same place.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: answer ("blue card"). I can only say that every time we discuss gender equality and women's rights and women's rights to our bodies, your groups vote against our right to decide whether we want abortion and when we want children and that we want the right to sex education for young people, that women should have the right to choose their lives and that we should have economic equality. I call this against women's equality in Europe today. We cannot support you now coming here with racist rubbish and saying that you are interested in defending women's bodies. It's hypocrisy, it's nothing else.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, sexualised violence, be it in a public or private space, is not just a petty issue that feminists speak about because they are bitter and frustrated. Sexualised violence is one of the biggest challenges that we are facing in the European Union and beyond. Without ending sexualised violence and violence against women, full equality as mentioned in the Treaties will never be reached. To tackle these big problems and to do our utmost to make equality reality, we cannot stop at proposing awareness—raising campaigns, however important and powerful those are. If we want to change the situation of women and girls in the European Union for the better, we need to tackle the legal shortcomings that still exist with regard to sexualised violence and violence against women. Yes, of course we have to speak about patriarchal masculinities. We have to speak about the fact that emancipated free women taking decisions over their bodies and lives threaten dominant, patriarchal, heterosexual masculinity norms. Let us address these challenges, be it in the democratic arena, in education or in the academic field, but let us do this without scapegoating specific groups and fuelling racist ressentiments. The same man who was spamming me with hate mail half a year ago saying that I should finally stop complaining about this feminist bullshit is now threatening me because I am not doing enough to protect women from violence. What a cynical situation. I am sick and tired of people, discourses, religions or cultures trying to instrumentalise my freedom and my body for their own political agenda. If we want to be successful in our struggle against violence against women and for equality for all, we have to dig deeper. We have to really go to the root causes and we have to use all the instruments that we have to hand without falling back into simplistic racist and useless debates.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it is okay for MEPs, with no responsibility or power, to sit here and say that we need an open door to limitless numbers of people. But people in the real world are being hurt. It has even been reported that the Commission will not accept that there is any link between the migrant crisis and the sexual assaults in Cologne and elsewhere. Indeed, in the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) two weeks ago, a Labour MEP called me racist for saying that migrants and refugees were involved in the attacks. If it was your mother, your daughter or your friend, would you still deny that anything happened? This is what happens when you open the door to other countries and cultures that treat women as second-class citizens. Then we have the attempted cover—ups by the police, the politicians and the press. To hear Swedish police say they will not report what happened because it might benefit some political parties, and for a German politician to say that women should act differently in public, is disgraceful. The people we vote for and the authorities we expect to protect our safety are cynically turning their backs on ordinary women and men for the sake of political correctness. And what happens when the people who have committed these crimes get EU passports or are given nationality from EU countries? They will have the right to come to Britain without any criminal background checks. In 2015, 100 000 illegal migrants were stopped trying to enter the UK. This shows the scale of the problem heading towards Britain. But what happens if we look at the other side of this crisis? Over 10 000 migrant children are missing. Europol has said that these children and young people are being forced into sexual exploitation and slavery by criminal gangs. The International Organisation for Migration said it was to be expected that many of these will be caught up in exploitation. That is without mention of the thousands dead and missing in the Mediterranean. So not only are these EU policies putting women under threat at home, they are also having horrendous consequences for women and children trying to seek safety. Of course we must open our hearts and help innocent women and children, but this is not the way. For the EU to expand the meaning of the Geneva Convention through the Qualification Directive to mean anyone fleeing armed conflict has led to one million people arriving in Europe in 2015, many turning to criminal gangs to get here. The EU free movement rules allow them to be trafficked all across Europe, because there are no border controls and no criminal background checks between countries. Free movement is a huge security risk, which was exploited in the Paris terrorist attacks. Weapons, criminals and terrorists can move freely around Europe and attack public places, all thanks to the EU. The EU is putting women at direct risk, and clearly they cannot cope with this crisis. For the safety of our own women and men, for the sake of innocent victims, and for other countries, we must get control of our borders and we must leave the EU. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Terry Reintke)

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. I am furious, furious at the European elite, who are always talking about security until it becomes clear that the danger to women is a direct result of the asylum tsunami and Islamisation made possible by the European Union. Because the testosterone bombs with an ideological disdain for women who harass, assault and rape women in Cologne, In Hamburg, Frankfurt and other European cities, show that Europe is facing sexual jihad. The only noise that came out of Brussels is that the problem is not immigration but public order. Where do you get the guts to keep Schengen and the European Union out of the wind in this way? It's outrageous. Mr President, the European Union, Schengen and the Junckers of this world are precisely the danger to public order by allowing thousands of misogynists in, to facilitate sexual jihad. There is only one solution, Mr President, to this Islamic barbarism, and that is to close the borders and de-Islamise.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Women's rights activist Alice Schwarzer has described this excess escocity as "the deepest product of a failed, even never really sought integration; they are the product of a false tolerance." That is right, Mrs Schwarzer! The blame lies with those politicians who for decades have preached a policy of open borders and misunderstood tolerance. The highlight was Mrs Merkel's decision on 4 September to stop carrying out border controls and registrations, effectively suspending Schengen and Dublin. The events in Cologne and other European cities and the concealment of the origin of the perpetrators of violence were not a police failure, but the result of truntured statistics, and were supported by the media with a misunderstood political correctness. Who is surprised that they are now called the press of lies? As the Commissioner herself said, it is not Europe that is responsible for law and order, but the nation states.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Madam President, if we are meeting this evening, unfortunately at a late hour - but we are a little used to it on issues of women's rights and gender equality - to re-discuss violence and sexual harassment against women, it is not because it is the ritual exercise that we engage in once a year. , moreover, by holding a solemn debate on the occasion of the International Day to Combat Violence Against Women, it is not because there is an oral question, a written statement or a resolution, it is because there has been a significant current event, which has caused a real shockwave, not only across Germany. , but across all European countries as well. I am referring to the mass violence and mass sexual harassment that took place in Cologne and other German cities on the night of 31 December to 1 January. This incredibly new fact had never happened on European soil: mass violence and an extraordinarily violent and aggressive occupation of public space by a group of men. Violence against women certainly has no religion, nationality, skin colour or origin, as we know. Sexism, machismo, violence, starting with domestic violence, domestic violence, are not the unfortunate prerogative of any group. These are scourges that we regularly denounce, with zeal and determination, on the many benches of this House, especially on the occasion of the International Day to Combat Violence Against Women in November. Undoubtedly, we cannot dodge, look away, be in denial of reality. What happened had never happened that way. We must show solidarity. It is a left-wing French philosopher who calls us to be by the side... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the events in Cologne, which are extremely serious and must be pursued with the utmost severity, must not, however, serve to create a dangerous and sterile confrontation that feeds populist winds that want to destroy Europe. The condemnation of what happened in Germany on New Year's Eve must be unanimous, in the knowledge that it was, however, a real terrorist attack, studied in every detail in order to further destabilise the increasingly delicate balance that we are experiencing in our European Union. This must not, of course, lead to generalisation, pointing the finger indiscriminately at all migrants, even if there were also migrants among that thousand men.
