Their assault and everything from that evening were organized and carried out as a semi-military operation, certainly predicting its effects that would follow. Such a vast, continued and determined harassment operation cannot be seen merely as a gesture against women. It was a gesture of defiance against the whole of society, against our culture, against our own freedom. Identifying only foreigners and all migrants as a potential danger to women will not help us in the battle against violence and harassment of women themselves. That episode shocked the world, just as unfortunately it still does not happen sufficiently when women in our cities are daily victims of violence, harassment in public and even in private, or when it is necessary to become aware that, unfortunately, a woman's mentality and culture are still rooted as an object. We need strict, very strict measures and definite condemnations, but above all it is the mentality of abuse, possession and bullying that must be combated, first and first and for all by educating people to respect the person who is the basis of respect for women.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think it is wrong to call other Members racists when they have different opinions. Yes, Commissioner Creu, since New Year's Eve and today Cologne has been the epitome of sexual violence in public spaces. Cologne has its history: state failure, a failure of the police, too little use against criminal gangs. But we are seeing this everywhere, europe-wide. We all want to put an end to sexual harassment and violence against women, not just in public places. One in three women in the EU has experienced physical or sexual violence since their youth. That's about 62 million women. Across Germany, every 68 minutes, a woman is the victim of a rape – an issue that is all too often silenced. Cologne has definitely changed something. The sexual assaults on New Year's Eve have sparked a debate about protecting sexual self-determination, especially in public spaces, which as such was long overdue. I am glad that we in the European Parliament are giving the impetus to this debate throughout Europe. What is clear is that anyone who wants to conduct the debate objectively and help the victims needs reliable facts. However, it also needs clarity on the legal situation, and this varies greatly from one Member State to another. For example, sexual violence is at best an administrative offence in Germany and is only considered a sexual offence if the woman was legally in a helpless situation. But their self-defense against the attacking man is quickly considered a physical injury. I could give an example here, but I am over time. We definitely need to talk about police .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, bullies and rapists are criminals, and criminals must be prosecuted, tried and convicted whoever they are, wherever they are and wherever they come from. I think that's what we agree on, but the question is how we're going to act.  I would like to congratulate the current Dutch Presidency on its imminent ratification of the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument covering violence against women in a comprehensive manner, and I would like to ask you whether the Council includes on its agenda the ratification of it by the European Union this year, as the Commission has already confirmed, through Mrs Jourová. Or can we afford not to use it? I would also like to ask the Commission when we are going to know the effectiveness of the Directive on victims of crime which we have in 2012. When are we going to carry out a transposition report in the Member States, given that the deadline ended last November? We have the instruments; we have to use them.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When I heard about the events in Cologne, my breath really stopped, because that is a special dimension of sexism towards women. These acts cannot be put into perspective by anything – really nothing – and we must not do it to a single victim to use this debate for other purposes – not for national election campaigns, for Nazi hatred, nor for getting rid of refugees more quickly.  What happened is deep contempt for women, which has its roots not in ethnicity, but in patriarchy! We really need to talk about that. We must talk about stricter legal penalties for sexism, about the fact that harassment in public spaces, as in Germany, is punishable as an administrative offence. That women should no longer be afraid to go to court and sue their tormentors. That it never happens again, that the police look away when crimes against women take place – when they are robbed or even raped, as in one case. We must ensure that violence against women is finally recognised by us in all Member States as a major, very great social problem and is not dismissed as collateral damage; that help is given to victims as long as they need it; that women's shelters and anti-violence projects are compulsory tasks in each Member State. Politics and society must actually live an idea, equality as an idea and as a reality, because there is no freedom without an end to violence against women.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the facts of Cologne, as well as any act of violence against women, are regrettable. You must pursue yourself with the full force of the law, but I now want to invite some of you to cease your efforts to try to turn this debate into a debate against refugees.  Because the phenomenon of violence against women is a global phenomenon, and it is a particularly European phenomenon. Many of my predecessors have said this before and recalled the report of the European Institute for Gender Equality, stating that a third of European women reported having experienced some episode of gender-based violence. Do you know how many deaths we have in Spain from gender-based violence this year 2016? Eight. Last year, fifty-four. This is a problem of gender-based violence and must be fought everywhere. So, representatives of the Commission, a good conclusion to this debate today, do you know what it might be? To be presented with the directive against gender-based violence that we have been calling for for so long and which would be the best instrument to combat such situations.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is not acceptable for this debate to be relegated to this late hour and more than a month after the events. In German squares, the "Taharrush", the game of rape, has been practised, and it is not a journalistic supposition, but the conclusion reached by the German Federal Police. It is not helpful, for the purposes of the debate, to know whether or not they are refugees who have acted, because it is a criminal network of men who have abused women. We strongly condemn this practice and all forms and acts of violence, regardless of who does it or where, whether it is in Europe, Asia or Africa. I am not going to see the hard-won rights and freedoms of us women trampled underfoot. The Commission is demonstrating that it wants to tackle and resolve the scourge of violence and stop hiding behind embarrassed silence or worse political correctness. Women do not need talk but facts.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Cologne, Dusseldorf, Stockholm, Stuttgart, Zurich, Hamburg and so on... In each of these cities, hundreds of women have been raped, victims of vile sexual assaults by hordes of migrants.  In response, it must be acknowledged that French feminists have remained very silent, they so quick to denounce the patriarchal fascism supposedly carried by French grammar were able to tell those who denounced these rapes as the consequence of the arrival of migrants, I quote: spill your racist elsewhere. In contrast, around Marine Le Pen, the patriots of France spoke. The truth is that the Front National is the most feminist of the French parties because it is the only one to speak out against mass immigration. Feminists have long believed that the danger to their rights would come dressed in cassocks, that he would try to prevent them from having an abortion. But in France, no major party opposes women's abortion rights. The National Front defends this achievement. The danger to women comes from uncontrolled immigration, and the patriots I represent are the best bulwark to protect them.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. On the one hand, I welcome this debate because we are talking honestly about an important issue, and on the other hand, I am very sad because it had to be triggered by a series of events that we may not even be talking about honestly. Yesterday, the excesses that seemed distant were now cruelly close to us.  I think we are facing a new type of and organised violence that we are not prepared for. It is a regrettable fact that it is precisely young women, girls, who are most affected. Organised violence in itself always creates fear, especially if we allow it to do so. Violence must be countered in any way in the spirit of zero tolerance. Effective action is needed, not overheathing. I can't understand how the mayor of Cologne meant it, keep an arm's length, so girls don't wear short skirts or use perfume. Nonsense! Let's not be naïve. The cologne rapist knew exactly where the border was, they were just trying. Right now, they're winning. It is a regrettable fact to say that this is real. Women have always been respected in European Christian culture. We can't let that happen.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I join with colleagues in this Chamber in condemning the attacks on women across Europe on New Year’s Eve. However, harassment of women did not begin on 31 December 2015. Indeed, just two months earlier there was the October Beer Festival, where hundreds of women reported sexual harassment. There appears not to have been quite so much concern about those women. Equally, the Fundamental Rights Agency reported in 2014 that one in three women have been the victim of violence of some sort. So harassment of women is not a new phenomenon. Violence and discrimination in Europe pre-date the events in Cologne and elsewhere. I have condemned and will always condemn these actions and whoever perpetrates them, and I am proud that my colleagues and I have been promoting action to take practical steps to address this problem. However, in all the time I have been doing this, I have never seen some of those who are shouting the loudest now stand shoulder to shoulder with me fighting for women’s rights before. Well, Heaven rejoices at the repentance of sinners. I am somewhat sceptical at UKIP and France’s National Front’s conversion to the cause of women. I suspect them of trying to instil fear and hatred rather than trying to protect the victims. But perhaps those on the Right will prove me wrong. Perhaps they will now call for the UK Government to ratify the Istanbul Convention with legally-based standards combating violence against women. I live in hope. In the meantime, let us take this moment to pursue policies that will protect women from experiencing harassment – whatever form it takes, and whoever the perpetrator. (Applause) (The speaker declined to take a blue card question from Marek Jurek)

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, the events in Cologne are not an isolated case. In fact, women in about 20 German cities have been the victims of similar assaults. The so-called dancing by mostly North African young men – that is, robbery, often combined with sexual assaults up to rape in public places – seems to be becoming a sad normality in some places, and German society seems to be getting used to it. Especially for women in our cities, everyday life has already changed, because it is they who adapt their behaviour when they are sexually harassed in public places and do not receive adequate protection. They avoid public places and change their style of dress. Mayors advise keeping an arm's length apart, and some cities plan to set up pink "ladies zones" on public transport. When Merkel said in the autumn that Germany would change as a result of migration, was that what she meant? Do we really want women to become second-class citizens again? German politics conceals, trivialises, denies and blames others, often enough the German police. This has long been overwhelmed in terms of personnel and has also been called upon in many cases to refrain from investigating refugees, as it does not want to stir up resentment. Politicians are concerned about refugees, not the victims of out-of-control migration. When politicians make bad policies, the media must report on it. Last week, the Council of Europe issued a resolution calling for the media to no longer hide the truth from the citizens in the interests of political correctness. It is essential that we here in the European Parliament agree with this.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the episodes of harassment and organised sexual assaults in the New Year in several European cities are not a new phenomenon or linked to the immigration crisis. "It's intolerable for them to do this with our women!" said many on January 1. And it will change the situation when people say convinced, "It's intolerable for them to do this with women!"  To achieve this, we must invest in equality, understand that inequality not only harms women and treats this issue as what it is: a structural problem. Sexist aggressions are a very unpleasant constant in many everyday environments and in Europe, also with European protagonists. In a war frame, they are weapons of war that victimize girls and women especially.  And just an assumption of the real scope of the problem, a critical reading of many attitudes towards aggression, also starring ours, education, the definitive eradication of stereotypes, zero tolerance with aggressors and the sincere integration of men into this cause will improve the situation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the events that took place on New Year's Eve in Cologne are of enormous gravity. Sexual assaults on women, the characteristics of an apparent coordinated action and the number of actors define a framework that requires careful and exhaustive clearance of the facts that occurred to ensure an objective analysis, free from the instrumentalizations of the extreme right and racist generalizations that sought to snare from these and other events.  It should be said that it was the Commission itself which rejected the false associations between the migration flow and the criminal acts of Cologne on 13 January. It is absolutely essential to focus on what is in fact the fundamental problem: the ignoble sexual assault of women, violence in any form against women. The answer involves the fight against the aggressors, along with the firm fight against the dissemination of values that embody the woman as an object. The answer is the unequivocal affirmation of women's rights, the affirmation of their dignity by the consecration of effective equality policies, something that the European Union insists on neglecting.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, unlike other colleagues, I am going to talk about the subject that brings us here tonight. And I take back my partner Urtasun's words. Are you going to promote, at once, a European directive against gender-based violence? Because that's what we need. We are wrong to compartmental in compartmentalating the space of violence. We are talking about violence against women in public spaces, but there is because there is also violence in private spaces. And there is violence against women because we continue to drag the patriarchal clichés that have constituted this European society. Some colleagues put a blindfold on their eyes and blame immigrants. The figures have already been said: one in three European women has been the victim of gender-based violence. There aren't that many immigrants. This is a European problem. It's a European disgrace. Aggressors enjoy impunity, women are used in an embarrassing way in advertising, and that creates stereotypes and the environment and breeding ground for this violence to continue to exist. Is the European Commission going to do anything to solve the big problem of violence against women in Europe?

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Smajna ħafna diskors dwar l-in大identi f'Cologne, u fi bliet oħra Ewropej. Fl-istess ħin aħna qed ngħixu fenomenu ieħor taż-żieda ta' sentimenti xenofobiħi. L-Unjoni Ewropea trid tipprovdi r-risposta, u r-risposta tagħna trid tkun mibnija fuq il-valuri li aħna nħaddnu, il-valuri li nemmnu fihom. Il-mibegħda hi dejjem u f'kull 大irkustanza ina大大ikeettabbli. Dan jgħodd lejn in-nisa, minoritajiet differenti, reliġjonijiet jew kwalunkwe settur ieħor. Kulħadd għandu jħossu moħħu mistrieħ fil-bliet tagħna li jkun fihom. Dan irid jifmhu kulħadd u hemm bżonn li nkunu iebsa ma' min jaħseb mod ieħor. Nagħmilha ħara, m'hemm l-ebda skuża kulturali għal dak li rajna f'Cologne, bħal ma hemm l-ebda skuża kulturali għar-razziżmu u l-vjolenza. I jimpurtax int min int, kif tidher, x'temmen, jew x'tipprattika, min huma l-għeżież għalik, kif tilbes. Il-messaġġ tagħna minn dan il-Parlament għandu jkun wieħed li inti tista' tgħix bil-libertà kollha, u mingħajr biża. Dan hu messaġġ li nsibuħ fil-qalba tal-valuri Ewropej tagħna, fil-qalba ta' dak li verament tfisser li tgħix fl-Ewropa.  U filwaqt li d-drittijiet ta' kulħadd għandhom ikunu ggarantiti huwa ġust u leġittimu li l-libertajiet u l-valuri bażi大i jkunu rrispettati minn kulħadd f'dan il-kontinent, ikun min ikun.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Patriarchal fascism – yes, I am glad that the problem of sexual harassment in the public sphere is finally being discussed and that it has come up on our political agenda. I would like to stress that it is neither a new phenomenon nor limited by national borders, nor of a social cultural or religious background. Men's violence against women is a global pandemic that requires comprehensive political solutions.  One in three women in the EU has been subjected to violence and/or sexual harassment. One in four women living in a relationship with a man has been subjected to violence by her partner. This means that the most dangerous place for women in Europe to be in is in their own homes.  This is the most important security policy issue we face. The fact that half of the EU's population cannot feel safe in their own homes, or in public places, is a major security problem. So we have to deal with it now. This must therefore be part of the EU's security strategy.  What is outrageous about the cologne incident is not what background the perpetrators have, but that sexual harassment and other crimes can be committed in our society without penalty.  The events in Cologne are nothing unique, it is not a special case. Crimes like these are committed, as I said, all the time by men from different cultures, different social classes and different nationalities. That's what we need to stop now.  It's nice that we get a hearing for this, even though it's from a completely different focus. But it also proves how important this issue is that it is now being raised; women are now important. In Sweden there was a campaign that prompted the mob in Stockholm this weekend. The campaign was aimed at extremists, racists who wanted to protect their women, our women. I'm not their woman.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like to join with everybody here in condemning what happened in Cologne – it was unacceptable. But I also would like to make the point that, yes, it is absolutely true that we have not just discovered violence against women. I would just like to reflect back on what I was doing about 40 years ago as a student in the ‘70s when we had a movement called ‘Reclaim the Night’. It was all about allowing women the space to go out on their own as they wished without harassment. I am talking about the UK. It was absolutely essential that we brought attention to this problem at that time, and at that time there was no so-called ‘Islamisation of Europe’. This was nothing to do with culture; it was British – English – culture and men were simply not letting women behave normally and have normal lives. It is deeply regrettable that we are still in that position now, and I hope that the Cologne lesson can teach us that it is time that we got on with the real roots of this and changed life for women. (Applause)

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the events in Cologne must be told and judged on the basis of solidarity, without ifs and buts and without any mitigating factors, with women who have been harassed, who have suffered violence. I believe that solidarity with women is the starting point for any reasoning about what has happened.  I also believe that a genuine policy against violence against women, against male violence against women, must start from ensuring full self-determination for each and every one. In a Europe where gender inequality is still so great, it is difficult to talk about full self-determination, it is difficult to combat male violence in depth, which is symbolic and material. I believe that women are treated as an object when they are harassed and treated as an object when they are exploited by xenophobic campaigns and racist campaigns. As my colleague said before me, we are nobody's women, no one should protect us, we do not need armies, we do not need godparents.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In a free Europe, women must also be able to move freely in public places at night without fear. This is no longer the case in many places today – a scandal! On the one hand, this is due to the far too lax sex offender law, according to which rapists often get away with minor sentences. It is also important, however, that we in Germany have received a million new citizens within a year. More people need more police, logically. Every village has its village policeman, every small town has its police station. And in Germany, the number of police officers has not been increased, but on the contrary has been reduced. That cannot go well. My opinion is therefore that it should not have been the police president who should have resigned, but the associated Minister of the Interior, and just as many other interior ministers from the neighbouring countries.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – First of all, I would like to say something about the strange title of the point that we are dealing with tonight. I wonder why we don't call it a spade. Why are we not nameing the migrant violence that has happened in concrete places in concrete places by a specific group? Instead, we use empty phrases like harassment, violence against women in public places and the like. But this debate is well-intentioned at its core. Its aim is to do everything to ensure that events in Cologne and many other cities are never repeated. Today, it is quite clear that this sexual violence against women was not spontaneous. This was an organised and massive attack. The attacker sent a message to the European public about what he thought of the system – our system of values. We need to be determined at this point. We need to return a clear message – no one will change the way we live, nor our values, which include gender equality, tolerance of otherwise religious or otherwise minded. I regret the fact that many, even women, NGOs have remained a nem nouous in this terrible event. Some left-wing organisations have even tried to justify this incident by otherwise violence against women, for example in the family, which is, of course, too much. It is also a pity that other European institutions and institutions – such as FRA – have also missed the opportunity to call the spade a spade.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, sexual harassment and violence against women is completely unacceptable in all circumstances and must be punished in the strongest terms. Of course, when it happens in someone's four walls, sometimes it is impossible to react because the abuse goes unreported, but there is absolutely no justification for avoiding drastic sanctions of violence in public. We are witnessing a growing trend of public abuse of women in Europe, which is a direct result of poor integration of immigrants coming from non-European cultural and civilization circles. Up until the latest incidents in Germany, many have closed their eyes to this because of political correctness, but now it is no longer possible. This kind of anticivilisation behaviour from the point of view of the law and morality is completely unacceptable and must be eradicated. The law is the same for everyone and applies to migrants and asylum seekers. For those who are not ready to accept it in Europe, there should be no room.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I condemn the events in Cologne in the strongest possible terms, and New Year's Eve once again raises the question of how to protect women from sexual assault. After all, 40% of women in Germany are victims of physical or sexual violence after the age of sixteen. But to have proxy debates now on asylum policy and migrants is simply disgusting. After all, we must not allow the New Year's Eve in Cologne to be misused for racist propaganda by the far-right NPD, the tanned AfD and other right-wing parties in Europe. We must not allow targeted sentiment to be made against people with a migrant background and to pretend that sexism and sexual violence are something completely new to us.  It is unacceptable that we should place people under general suspicion simply because they come from the Middle East or Africa. We must, of course, build a society without racism, without sexualised violence and sexism, but we must beware of descending into xenophobia. In doing so, we would be doing Europe a very disservice.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – One of the fundamental values of the European Union is human dignity. Respecting and protecting the dignity of every single person, woman, man or child, is not only a matter of cultural tradition in Europe, but also an imperative of law. Actions threatening another person's human dignity are punishable and must be harshly punished, especially if their victims are women. It does not matter if the person who perseveres is a national, a tourist, a migrant or a refugee. The Geneva Convention provides for the expulsion of a refugee where he or she endangers the security of the State or if he or she is convicted of a particularly serious crime. Personally, I believe that both violent and verbal attacks on women's dignity should be classified as serious, regardless of the origin and status of the perpetrator. However, in a situation where tensions are rising in Europe caused by a large wave of migration, any such action by migrants must also be treated as a security threat. I therefore appeal to the Member States to amend their laws in order to protect effectively and decisively the human dignity of all those who live here.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: "There have been terrible things in Cologne, but they have revealed what is happening in many parts of Europe. I thought we would hear a serious debate, but I am really confused by what we are hearing in this House: the humiliation of women is a common phenomenon, so actually nothing special has happened in Cologne. Women often hide when they are harmed, so concealment by the police in Germany – but not only in Germany – is also nothing out of the question. In fact, there are general topics, but the one we should be discussing does not merit any particular debate.  Do I have a specific question for the European Commission? Does the European Commission condemn the concealment of information by the police about crimes, about offenders? Does the European Commission condemn politically motivated concealment as a violation of the values defined in the second article of the Treaty on European Union or not? And I ask for a specific answer.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ending sexual assault on women must be an absolute priority.  The problem is that this is an empty debate if we do not talk about the real and profound causes of violence against women. Let us not be cynical: aggressions against women are not determined by the origin or economic condition of the aggressor, but by the machismo that is rooted in our society.  Another thing is that the far right, or also the right, as we are seeing, try to stigmatize migration and refugees to try to win a handful of votes; the same formations that silence the sexual assaults that occur every day within our borders, perpetrated by European men, in a society that is called "civilized".  Around the world, women live under this subjugation. We have to work so that words become facts, to change things.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am fighting violence against women, not because I am a feminist, do not really suspect me of this, but because protecting the dignity of human life is a priority for us Christian Democrats here in the European Parliament as well. We know that, unfortunately, violence against women is not something new in Europe, as has already been said here, up to 30% of women experience violence here, but today's debate was triggered by an unprecedented attack on women in Cologne, when this attack was a refugee attack on New Year's Eve. And we expect refugees to accept asylum with gratitude, to behave with some respect. Unfortunately, I do not think it is possible to underestimate these security risks, on the contrary. It turns out that there is a need to increase security measures. Of course, such an attack strengthens the anti-shower moods, and we do not wish that. I think that it is not possible to remain silent here in the European Parliament either, and that we must be aware of the risks that increased concentration of people from other socioeconomic, sociocultural backgrounds brings, and we must answer this, I am thinking of the Member States now, but also of the European Commission, we must respond with increased security measures.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Madam President, so much happened on New Year’s Eve in Cologne and many other cities that even the media and the European Left could not ignore it. But let us not pretend this is something new: it is not. For years and decades, immigrants from the Middle East and North Africa have been hugely over-represented in European sexual and violent crime statistics. Only the numbers have changed. Our approach to this problem is rather naive. We think that if we put those young men into a classroom and teach them about gender equality, they will suddenly abandon their old ideas and values and become nice European social democrats. That does not happen. If you transfer people from the Middle East to Europe, they will bring their Middle East way of thinking with them. Do these young men behave the way they do because they do not know that it is wrong? No, they want to show us who is the boss now and who rules the public space.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, nobody can claim that violence against women in Europe is a crime perpetrated only by immigrants. Sadly, millions of women in Europe experience sexual violence or harassment in the EU every year. According to the 2012 survey of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, one in five women in the EU had experienced sexual harassment and 2% had experienced sexual violence in the 12 months before the interview. But we cannot deny either that it was mostly immigrant men that mugged, sexually harassed and assaulted more than 600 women outside Cologne station. What was different in this case was that the attacks were not carried out in a hidden way; the perpetrators were making a public spectacle of instilling fear and humiliating the victims, being well aware that what they were doing was not acceptable in Western European culture. This is why we should not minimise the significance of what happened in Cologne and make sure that those who commit such acts are brought to justice. It does not follow from this that we should not offer asylum to those who are truly fleeing from persecution and death, or that we should not condemn, in the strongest way, attacks by the extreme right on immigrants, which could lead to an unstoppable spiral of violence. The main lesson we should draw here is that if the receiving societies are to integrate asylum seekers, they must first change this attitude of vengeful aggressiveness and educate them to adapt to basic European values.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, according to one survey conducted in London in 2012, 43% of young women said they had experienced harassment during the last year. A survey, a study conducted in 2013 in France, found that one in four women experienced fear in the street and that one in five women experienced verbal abuse on the street. This kind of violence diminishes the freedom of movement of women and girls, diminishes their ability to participate in school, at work, in public life. It restricts their access to basic services, in cultural and recreational activities and negatively affects health. This discussion was initiated by recent events in Cologne. So Cologne should be a teach for all of us. But in a free Europe we must not allow our women and girls to be able to move freely in open spaces. We know that these are concrete activities for specific crimes, not misdemeanor offences, and therefore, regardless of whether someone is a migrant or an asylum seeker, they must equally be held accountable before the law. Therefore, I believe that the law needs to be well applied and I believe that we should not generally condemn foreigners, i.e. newcomers to the European Union, but apply the law.  Thus, we will avoid making a general assessment against those who move to Europe from other parts. So it takes the rapid integration that we talk about all the time to protect the fundamental value, which is dignity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Madam President, all violence deserves condemnation. There is no justifiable reason for violence and there are no conditions under which it can be allowed. Unfortunately, women are more likely to be victims of violence, especially sexual violence, which we often talk about in this Parliament. But the events we have recently faced in several Member States go beyond the issue of protecting women and combating violence against women. These horrific events, apart from the victims, put the perpetrators of these terrible crimes at the forefront. We must not generalise and condemn all refugees and migrants for what happened, but we must also not ignore the fact that violence was not committed by European Union citizens. We owe this, not only to women victims of violence, but also to all refugees who have fled war to seek protection in Europe, because we must also take into account their safety and dignity. The European Union is built on values. The European Union believes in the dignity of a woman. The European Union protects women's fundamental freedoms and rights. The European Union does not accept violence against women in any form. These are European values that we are obliged to protect and must be accepted by all those who want to find their home in Europe – temporary or permanent. Respect for European values, culture and laws is a prerequisite for life in the European Union. Fighting violence while promoting the values we believe in, integration and intercultural dialogue – these are the key things we need to work on.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, alone and in the dark, I saw us Finnish women jogging without fear. I do not know about European values, about these great words that are so cultivated here. But I'd like to keep this run. Sexual liberation, you should. The fact is that in many authoritarian Muslim countries, sex is a problem. Homosexuality and women's sexuality in particular are taboo. When desires are denied, pathouts are created. The consequences are known: harassment in Cologne, Helsinki, wherever. Ladies and gentlemen, values make no difference if they are not defended. In this job, we all have room for improvement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, harassment and assault on women are based on the patriarchy that dominates our societies and is not exclusive to both cultures or migrants. All violence must be condemned and must be punished. More than half of women in the European Union are afraid and alter their own habits to avoid certain places or situations for fear of being victims of physical or sexual assault. In 2014, 21 million women in the European Union reported having suffered assaults or sexual incidents by an adult before the age of 15. In the Spanish state, in the last nine years, 553 sexist killers have killed, taken the lives of 553 women; only one month this year, eight women have been murdered. Commissioner, this situation cannot wait. Strong actions and coherent policies are lacking against machismo and to eradicate violence in every way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, sexual harassment and violence against women is a chronic social problem which is intensifying in the midst of an economic crisis. Recently we noticed the mass sexual harassment of some ninety women that took place in Cologne, for which according to the police authorities Africans and Arabs appear to be responsible The following day were organized protest rallies against violence against women, but also against Merkel's immigration policy. It is certain that refugees and migrants must integrate smoothly into European society as long as they remain temporarily in Europe.  However, violence against women is a problem that knows no nationality, classes and social strata. In particular, in countries affected by the economic crisis and austerity policies, cases of violence against women and gender inequality are intensifying.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, one in three women in the European Union has suffered in her life some form of sexual or physical assault. In Spain, one hundred and nine women were killed at the hands of men in 2015, and we have already been eleven in 2016. More than thirty thousand women, five thousand of them girls, are victims of sex trafficking in the European Union. Sexist violence is therefore as European a structural problem as this Parliament. It is not a problem of other countries: we have it in Europe. Sexual assaults on hundreds of German women last New Year's Eve are part of that conception of women who unfortunately travel through all towns, cultures and nationalities without exception. Making racist and Islamophobic propaganda is insulting to the victims of machismo. It is the European xenophobes who attack refugees who have always advocated cutting women's freedoms. Our recipe against machismo and anti-racism is the same: more public resources for an education that fights stereotypes.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this has been a very useful debate and I very much appreciate Members’ efforts to highlight the necessity of ending sexual harassment and violence against women. I know very well how much you are fighting here in Parliament for women’s dignity and women’s rights, including in the labour market and also in political life. It is very sad that we have had to start talking about violence rather than disrespect, which also exists everywhere in all Member States. As all of you here have stated, we cannot turn a blind eye to violence and to events like those in Cologne or in other parts of Europe and in the world. This debate should send a very important signal to the whole of Europe. But, as I said in my introductory remarks, Member States, due to the principle of subsidiarity, should be in the front line to assure public security and order. They have to assume their responsibilities, because nowhere in the Treaties are there competences for the European Union to assure public security and order. Of course, as you all know, the EU has adopted several legal instruments setting up common rules and protecting and assisting victims of crime, and I am sure that my colleague, Commissioner Jourová, will come here with more detail. We have a horizontal instrument dealing with victims’ rights in general, which addresses the specific support and protection needs of victims of gender-based violence and more specific instruments on protection measures. The Commission is currently focusing on the implementation of the existing legislation. We have a Victims’ Rights Directive. The Commission will, of course, monitor and evaluate implementation by Member States before deciding on the follow-up. I would like to inform you that so far only 11 Member States have notified the Commission of their implementing measures. Anyway, I would like to tell you that I agree with all of you that we must firmly condemn and prosecute, as we stand with the millions of women in Europe who have gone through violence. The Commission would like to work with Parliament to make our values of equality and fundamental rights a reality for all who live on European soil. Neither custom, tradition, culture, privacy, religion nor so-called ‘honour’ can justify violence or be invoked to avoid the obligations of Member States with respect to the prevention and elimination of violence and the prosecution of the perpetrators.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome what the Commission has said. Sexual assaults of any kind, be it the terrible events in Cologne or the administration of knockout drops in discotheques, must be combated by all means at our disposal. This means that we must stand up openly and strongly for equality and respect for women and that law enforcement must be effective. We must send out a clear signal that no one in Europe can disregard our fundamental values with impunity.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Violence against women is a global scourge that takes different, sometimes drastic forms and finds various justifications. These include the belief that everything that happens in the family is a private matter, or that religious traditions cannot be opposed, even if they order the physical and mental punishment of women for breaking the rules (honor killings). Cultural differences mean that the same behaviour can be understood and judged differently.  In order to avoid the pitfalls of relativism with regard to violence, a procedure was launched in 2011 to sign and ratify the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women, which explicitly states that neither tradition nor religion can be used to justify violence. Almost all the countries of the European Union have signed this Convention, and more than a dozen have ratified it. At a time of europe's growing cultural diversity, this document takes on a new meaning and becomes a direct tool to help resolve conflicts of values that can influence the assessment of events, e.g. sexual attacks on women, depending on the ethnic origin or religion of the attacker or victim. The Convention recalls that while cultural differences may result in misinterpretation of women's behaviour, this cannot be an excuse for the harm suffered by victims, and that preventing violence is about instructing perpetrators about women's rights rather than instructing women about the acceptable length of their skirts.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The events in Cologne have rightly attracted attention and indignation. Any sexual harassment is unacceptable and it is shocking that it has occurred on such a scale. What is particularly alarming, however, is that one in three European women has experienced physical or sexual violence in their lifetime. This is far from just a problem of harassment in public places, although it is now attracting the most attention. The most common form of violence against women is that which takes place behind closed doors of households. Only in the Czech Republic has every other woman experienced psychological or physical violence, most often from her partner. It is very important to combat violence in public places. But it is equally important that states that have not yet done so join the Istanbul Convention and commit to combating violence against women wherever it takes place.
